title: SCHEDULE CHANGE CONFUSES RIDERS
description: An overnight change in schedules on the New Haven, Harlem and Hudson Divisions of the Penn Central caught many commuters unawares yes terday.

title: CoStars for Hansberry Play
description: Hal Linden and Zora Lampert have been signed as costars in Lorraine Hansberry's play The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Win dow, which was originally clone on Broadway in 1964. The production will have music by Garry William Friedman. Ray. Erroll Fox wrote the lyrics, which will he sung by a rock quartet as part of the play. It opens at the Longacre Theater on Feb, 1.

title: JAMES F. STEVENS, WROTE OF BUNYAN
description: SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 31 (AP) James F. Stevens, Who popularized the tales of Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox while working in an Oregon logging camp, died Thursday at the age of 79.

title: Mary L. Lane Married To Stephen P. Lagoy
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 31Miss Mary Louise Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Lane of Franklin Lakes, was married here to day in Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church to Stephen Paul Lagoy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Lagoy of Leo minster, Mass. The Rev. Frederick LaBrecque, a cous in Of the bridegroom, per formed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Boulah Sariford France Dies; Health Educator and Author
description: Mrs. Beulah Sanford France, a registered nurse and health educator who for many years lectured, broadcast and wrote a daily column on child care, died Wednesday. in St. Barna bag, Hospital. Her age was 80 and her home was at 186 River side Drive. She was the Wife of Harry C. France, financial Writer, and lecturer.

title: Talk of Crisis Is just a Joke in Albany
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31Even the lame and the suntanned legis lators, were here ready to vote on the last day of what the Governor emphasized was the most urgent fiscal crisis of 1971.

title: Clerk Disarms a Gunman And Foils Brooklyn Holdup
description: A 67yearold liquor store clerk foiled a holdup yesterday afternoon by disarming one gunman and wounding his armed accomplice twice in an exchange of gunfire at a shop ping center in Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Slowdown in Medical Costs
description: The cost of medical services in the United States increased by only onetenth of 1 per cent in November, the smallest monthly gain in six years. Since medical charges have led the general inflationary upsurge recent years, that result testifies to the effectiveness the ninetyday economic freeze, at least in this area.

title: Telephone Stock Led Activity in 1971
description: No clear price pattern emerged among the most ac tively traded issues on the New York Stock Exchange in 1971.

title: Cecil Beaton Knighted by Queen; A Racing Driver Is  Also Honored
description: LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 1Cecil Beaton, the designer and photographer, and Jackie Stew art, the Scottish racingcar driver, won places today in Queen Elizabeth's annual Nev Year's honors list.

title: HAGGLING HURTS. POLITICAL IMAGES
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31After days of haggling, cajoling, agreeing and rebelling, three prime movers in the unresolved disharmony the state's fiscal problem the Capitol today with their politicial images scuffed not demolished.

title: Japanese Premier Hopes for Relations With China in 1972
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 1 (UPI)Premier Eisaku Sato said today that he hoped that Japan and China would estab lish diplomatic relations in 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was a most unfortunate choice of picture The Times used to illustrate Robert L. Zion's letter (Dec. 18) pro testing the boring empty plazas that front too many of New York's office buildings. The unnamed plaza pictured is that of the Time & Life Building.

title: Poles Standing in Queues To Sell Hoarded Dollars
description: CRACOW, Poland, Dec. 31Thousands of Poles, who have been hoarding dollars for years are crowding into branches of the state savings bank, PKO, in this region to convert their hardcurrency savings into zlotys.

title: Mrs. Goldman Married
description: Mrs. Audrey Vandergrift Gordon Goldman, daughter of the late George Anderson Gordon of Savannah, Ga., onetime Ambassador to the Netherlands, and the late Mrs. Gordon, was married here yesterday to Arthur Ed ward NievaWoodgate, an ac count executive with Kidder, Peabody & Co., Inc., stock brokers. He is the son of Arturo Guillermo Nieva Woodgate of Buenos Aires and the late Mrs. Hero Mar tinez Deniz de NievaWood gate. The ceremony in the Central Presbyterian Church was performed by the Rev. James Crawford. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: 2d Autopsy Disclosed in Death Of Gail Richards, Medical Aide
description: Police officials said yesterday that two dozen young women had been questioned by invest gators looking into the mysteri ous death of Gail Richards, 30yearold medical assistant who died of barbiturate poison ing in September.

title: AntiIndia Remark Is Laid to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The syndicated columnist Jack Anderson reported today that Henry A. Kissinger, Presidential, assistant for national security affairs, told senior Administra tion officials during the India Pakistani crisis that. President Nixon does not want to be evenhanded.

title: AWED BREWERIES HOLDS BID PRICE
description: Allied Breweries, Ltd., an nounced yesterday in London that it would not raise its 145million ($369,750,000) bid for Trust Houses Forte, Ltd., a leading operator of hotels and inns in England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland. On Thurs day, Trust Houses rejected the Allied Breweries bid made a few months ago as totally inade quate. In reject ing the offer, Trust Houses said the Allied offer dis regards the future of Trust Houses capital projects and that its shareholders would not benefit from the merger.

title: Miss  Statter Has Nuptials
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 31Miss Phyllis Joynson Statter, daughter of Mrs. Richard Shepard Clarke of Bedford and Humphrey Statter of New York, was married here today to David Craig Oxman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob H. Oxman of Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate.

title: TAIWAN WILL LIMIT EXPORTS OF TEXTILES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  The State Department an nounced today that two agree ments had been signed with Na tionalist China, limiting Tai wan's textile exports to the United States during the next five years.

title: The Latest German Vintage: They Say It's Very Good Wine, but Not for Now
description: NIERSTEIN, West Ger many  German wine grow ers will have only their older and second best wines to taste for months to come. The new harvest holds the prom ise of being one of the great vintages of the century, but it is still lying in the casks.

title: Colonels Beat Cougars
description: GREENSBORO, N,C., Dec. 31 (AP) The Kentucky Colo nels outscored the Carolina Cougars, 4222, in the third quarter tonight and broke open a close game for a 124106 vic tory.

title: F.P.C. CHIEF URGES ENERGY RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today that the United States would become increas ingly dependent on imports of various forms of energy in the rest of this century. He urged that the trend be curtailed by, the urgent development and careful allocation of continental and offshore resources.

title: A Suspect in Panther's Death Here Is Slain by F.B.I. in South
description: A suspect in the slaying of a West Coast Black Panther of ficial in Corona, Queens, last April was killed in a gun battle yesterday with agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Florida, the bureau an nounced early this morning.

title: Youths See Little Effect From Newly Won Rights
description: DETROIT, Dec. 31Maureen Doyle, an 18yearold student in Vermont, got not only the right to vote last July but also the right to enter contracts, serve on juries, sue in court and marry without her parents consent.

title: Issues in Strike
description: PARTICIPANTSThe New York Telephone Company and the 23 state locals of the Communications Workers of America. The members in clude 38,500 installers, re pairmen, switchmen and linemen.

title: 1,625 Slayings Here in71 As Rate Continued to Rise
description: More people were slain in 1971 in the city than ever be fore, acording to the Chief Medical Examiner's office.

title: Peter Duel, Actor, Found Shot Dead In Horne on Coast
description: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 31 (AP) Peter Duel, a television actor, was found fatally shot today in his Hollywood Hills home, the police said.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Philosophic in Press Talk
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 31Prime Minister Indira Gandhi offered some glimpses into her lifestyle and goals at a news conference here today.

title: U.S. Population 208,557,7351
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) The nation's population stood at an estimated 208,557,735 as revelers rang in 1972 at mid night, Census Bureau officials said. Thus, in 1971, the popula tion increased by 2,040,059, against increases of 2,239,000 in 1970 and 2,100,000 in 1969. The greatest net annual in crease ever recorded was 3,058, 000 in 1956.

title: AMERICAN CAN LIFTS PRICES OF BOTTLES
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday that it would increase prices by 3 per cent on highdensity polyethy lene and polyvinyl chloride plastic blowmolded bottles, ef fective Feb. 1.

title: PROFESSOR AND SON DIE IN BLAZE ON L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 31 (UPI)An associate profes sor at City University and. her 7yearold son were burned to death today in a fire at their rented home here.

title: Mrs. Ernest T. Bower Dies; Widow of RealEstate Man
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 31 Mrs Kakharine Bunker Bow er, the widow of Ernest T. Bower, a lawyer and realestate operator who died in 1951, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospi tal. She was 85 years old and had lived in Yonkers for many years before moving to Bronx ville recently.

title: Ernest tothrop, ExPartner Of Price Waterhouse, Dies
description: Ernest O. Lothrop, who re tired as a partner of Price, Wa terhouse & Co. in 1957, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 570 Park Avenue.

title: Hanoi Names 3 Fliers
description: SAIGON, Dec. 31 (UPI)The Hanoi radio said today that North Vietnam has captured three American pilots and it gave their names. They were the names of three men who had flown two of three planes the United States command in Saigon admits having lost yes terday and Sunday.

title: U.S. Court Upholds Ouster of a Student For His Long Hair
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Dec. 31 A Federal District Court has re fused to interfere with the ex pulsion of a high school student whose hair, was longer than specified under the school's dress code.

title: 2 WANTED HERE GUILTY ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31Two young men who are under indictment by a New York grand jury for the murders of two policemen in Harlem last May, were convicted here yes terday on multiple counts of armed assault on a policeman.

title: Paksong Reported Razed
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Military sources said today that North Vietnam ese troops had burned the strategic Boloven highlands town of Paksong to the ground.

title: Ohioan Endorses Muskie
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 31 (AP)  Mayor Harry Kessler en dorsed Senator Edmund S. Mus kie of Maine today for the Dem ocratic presidential nomination.

title: Chiang Denies Secret Contacts
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec, 31President Chiang Kaishek, in his New. Years Day message, denied that Nationalist China has made any secret contacts with Peking and said that Peaceful settlement between them was impossible.

title: KNICKS PHASE 2 STARTS TONIGHT
description: For good teams, like the New York Knicks, the National Bas ketball Association season is a fivemonth preparation for a serious sixweek competition. As the Knicks begin a new cal endar year tonight by facing the Cincinnati Royals at Madi son Square Garden at 8 P.M., they move into a new stage of the preparation.

title: Colorado Downs Houston As Davis Excels, 29 to 17
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  A sophomore tailback, Charlie Davis, scored touchdowns on runs of 27 and 1. yards to lead Colorado to a 2917 victory over. Houston tonight in the 13th annual AstraBluebonnet Bowl.

title: Shula Wants to Pull the Rug Out
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31Don Shula, the coach of the Miami Dol phins, called today for a new playing surface next season in the Orange Bowl Stadium, the site of Sunday's American Foot ball Conference championship game with the Baltimore Colts.

title: Penguins, Sabres Tie, 33
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 (UPI) Jean Pronovost and Bob Leit er scored thirdperiod goals to bring the Pittsburgh Penguins from two goals behind to a 3.3 tie with the Buffalo Sabres to night.

title: Antiques: Limited Editions Popular
description: Antiques shops are going to be selling an increasing number of the obviously con temporary limited edition plates and figures in the new year.

title: Miss Kelman Bride Of W.M. Bargower
description: Miss Barbara Anne Kel man, managing editor of the Straight Arrow Press in San Francisco, was married here yesterday to William Michael Burgower, business and eco nomics editor of the Canfield Press in San Francisco, a division of Harper & Row. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman per formed the ceremony in his study at the Little Synagogue.

title: Art: An Adventurous Woman's Works
description: The Paula ModersohnBeck er exhibition at La Boetie, 1042 Madison Avenue at 80th Street, is primarily a draw ing show, even though it is exceptional in including her complete etchings. (There are exactly a dozen pf these, some existing in only one or two proofs.) There are also four of her paintings, which are interesting enough in view of the. pitifully meager number she had time to pro duce. But the drawings tell best, bringing is close to the sensitive intelligence of a lovely woman who, on her deathbed at the age of 31, was the first to say what others have said of her death ever since: What a shamel.

title: Supplies Are Short For Burlap Bagging
description: The IndiaPakistan War, labor troubles in Calcutta and the recent dock strike on the East Coast have all combined to create a very tight situation in burlap bagging and carpet backing. A good part of the shortage has been offset by woven polypropylene, but here too, there is a tight supply sit uation with goods sold strict ly on allocation.

title: U.S. UNITS STUDY YUGOSLAVIA DEAL
description: Nearly a dozen major Amer can corporations are in the advanced stages of negotiation with the Government of Yugo slavia for jointventure projects largely as the result of their meeting last October with Yugoslav President Tito and several of his top economic ministers.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported yesterday the following spot primary prices for the, week ended Dec. 21:

title: U.S. Sues Seven Companies
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP)  The Government filed an antitrust suit here yesterday seeking damages from seven concerns for allegedly conspir ing to fix prices on wallboard and plaster.The suit named as defendants: the United States Gypsum Company, of Chicago; the National Gypsum Company of Buffalo; the Kaiser Gypsum Company of Oakland, Calif.; the Flintkote Company of White Plains, N.Y.; the Fibreboard Corporation of San Francisco the Celotex Corporation, of Tampa, Fla., and the Georgia Pacific Corporation of Portland, Ore.

title: BAD DEBTS REPORTED BY BANK OF AMERICA
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, charged off $39.9million in bad debts in the first nine months of 1971, against $38.7million for the full year of 1970. In a pre liminary offering circular for its pending offering of $150 million in capital notes, a copy of which was obtained yester day, the bank also disclosed for the first time, certain other details of its business.

title: ROYAL OWL VICTOR, WITH SHOEMAKER UP
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) Willie Shoemaker guided Royal Owl to a 6length vic tory in the $59,100 California Breeders Champion Stakes to day to record his 46th stakes victory of the year and the 548th of his career.

title: BRESSLER EXCELS AT CONCERT HERE
description: The New York Chamber So loists, with Charles Bressler front and center, gathered around the Christmas tree in the Medieval Sculpture Court of the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night to present choice assortment of baroque music for an audience that filled all the available space in the splendid setting.

title: Bridge: A Frustrated Defender Holds The Cards but Not the Lead
description: One of the most irritating situations in the game arises when a player knows that he can cash the setting tricks at once but he does not have the lead: His partner has the lead, aid will inevitably make the wrong decision with disastrous results.

title: Chiefs Top Red Devils, 4341, In Roller Derby at Garden
description: Madison Square Garden threw a New Year's party last night and 6,927 fans came to see the Chiefs, the Garden's Roller Derby team, defeat the Red Devils, 4341, in an Interna tional Roller Derby League, game. The crowd was given; noisemakers and party hats to help celebrate.

title: The Individual as Institution: II
description: TORONTOFrom the burning bush of Moses to the burning sand of Ala mogordo, man's answer has always come from the desert.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Mutual Broadcasting System announced yesterday the appointment of C. Edward Little Sr. as president, succeeding Victor Diehm, who has resigned effective January 31. He will remain. in an advisory capacity, the Mutual Broadcasting Cor poration, the parent company, said. Mr. Little presently president of radio station WGMA, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: ERNEST C. DEMPSEY, CLEVELAND LAWYER
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 31 Ernest C. Dempsey, retired cor poration lawyer and director of several companies, died yester day at his home suburban Bratenahl He was 81 years old.

title: Penn StateTexas Showdown Arrives Two Years Too Late
BRUNDAGE WARNS OLYMPIC TEAMS
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, issued new warning today to Olympic skiers and other winter sports competitors about advertising.

title: Hanoi Claims 24 U.S. Planes
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 1 (AP)North Vietnam said to day that it had shot down 24 United States warplanes and had captured seven American pilots in the five days ended Thursday.

title: Amex and O.T.C. Score Final 71 Gains
Rockets Beat Pros, 10891
description: DALLAS, Dec. 31 (UPI) Ralph Simpson scored 43 points to lead the Denver Rockets to a 108.91 victory over the Memphis Pros tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his article PompidouIII: Prag matist (Dec. 26), C. L. Sulzberger writes that the French President ... appeals to the less flamboyant side of the French character, which stresses pragmatism over panache. In this re spect, he relates historically to Henry, of Navarre..

title: Moslems Back Birth Control
description: RABAT, Morocco. Dec. 31 (Reuters)  The first Islamic conference on family planning has ruled that birth control is permissible in Moslem law but that sterilization and abortion are prohibited, according to a statement issued here today. The fiveday conference was or ganized by the international Planned Parenthood Federation.

title: Calman Leads by 7 Points In Frostbite Regatta at Rye
description: RYE, N. Y., Dec. 31Michael Calman of the Mamaroneck Frostbite Association sailed to a 7point lead today when the American Yacht Club's annual threeday New Year's frostbite invitation regatta began with five races in a puffy northwest to northerly wind.

title: City Bank and Irving Trim Lending Rates Charged Businesses
description: The First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company, both of which have minimum business lending rates that float in relation to the money market, yesterday lowered their charges for the week beginning Monday, respectively, to 5 per cent and 5 per cent.

title: Soviet May Widen Mideast Role
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 31 The Soviet Union, apparently encouraged by the success of its support for India, has shown signs of pursuing, a more ag gressive policy in the Middle East.

title: 20 Injured by Bomb in Belfast's Center
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 31 (AP)  A large bomb exploded in the heart of Bel fast today, injuring more than a score of people.

title: BombingScored in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 31 (AP) A group protesting recent United States bombirg of North Vietnam smeared what its members said was blood on desks, walls, floors and the Navy flag at the Navy recruit ing office here today. The police arrested the man they said was leader of the group, Charles W. Rawlings, 40 years old, of Shaker Heights, a for mer minister, and dispersed the rest of the group.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Dec. 23 Is Yugo slavia in Danger? suggests the possi bility of a danger that Yugoslavia will vanish and be replaced by half a doz en mutually hostile ministates. This gives ground for the following thoughts:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 (Reu ters)Mrs. Meir said on the Is raeli radio today that the fact that the State Department did not deny the reports yesterday that Israel. would get F4's showed that the planes would come. She did not, however, explicitly confirm the reports.

title: Four Copper Producers Cut Exploration Efforts
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 31 (AP)Four copper companies with exploration offices here are reducing or completely shutting their exploration work because times are tough the copper business. The Ken necott Copper Corporation, the ,Anaconda Company, the Copper Range Company and the Cerro Corporation dis closed the moves today.

title: Wedding Is Held For Mrs. Peters And Psychiatrist
description: The marriage of Mrs. Flor ence Marie. Peters to Dr. Sam uel Sheinkman took place here yesterday at Temple Emanu El. The senior rabbi, the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, per formed the ceremony.

title: ARGENTINE ORDERS PAY RAISE FOR ALL
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31The Argentine Goyernment last night decreed a 25 per cent wage increase for all workers payable in two installments.

title: STOCKS END YEAR IN A MODEST RISE
description: The stock market rang out the old trading year yesterday with modest price gains for its closing session and high hopes for 1972.

title: NEW YORK MAY GET NEW JOBLESS FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Labor Department said to day that it currently estimates that unemployed workers in 13 states and Puerto Rico will be eligible for 13 extra wdeks of unemployment benefits on Jan. 30, 1972.

title: Lefkowitz Signs Agreement On Building of Hall of Fame
description: Construction of the collegiate football Hall of Fame building will be started before the open ing of next season, Louis J. Lefkowitz indicated yesterday following the signing of an agreement with his office by the National Football Founda tion and Hall of Fame.

title: Jenkins Named for Award
description: TORONTO, Dec. 31 (AP) Ferguson Jenkins of Chatham, Ontario, righthanded pitcher for the Chicago Cubs, was named today Ontario's athlete of the year for 1971.

title: Orange Bowl a Classic Confrontation
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31Bear Bryant is calling tomorrow night's Orange Bowl Classic just about the bigges't college game that's ever been, which is fine for Bryant: Alabama is No. and its New Year's night op ponent, Nebraska, is sitting in the hot seat.

title: Year of the Trillion Dollars and the Freeze
description: Following are the highlights and chronology of some major economic events that occurred in 1971:

title: Birth of Son Prompts Aid To Neediest
description: Every year we meant to contribute to the fund but found excuses for delaying and forgetting, Diane and Phil Barbers wrote in One of the letters that accompanied contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded yesterday.

title: Nixon Challengers on Ballot
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 31 (Reuters)Representatives Mc Closkey and Ashbrook will ap pear on the Nebraska primary ballot as challengers to Presi dent Nixon, the Secretary of State, Allen Beerman, said to day.

title: BANGOR PUNTA SUED BY B. &
description: The Bangor & Aroostook Railroad has filed suit against the Bangor Punta Corporation and Bangor Punta Operations, a subsidiary, on 14 separate charges totaling more than $13.6million, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Farber Paintings Show Shift to a Quieter Style
description: Manny Farber, a painter who has also been widely published as both a film crit ic and an art critic, has come a long way since his first New York exhibition 10 years ago. At that time he turned a Manhattan gallery into something that resem bled an artist's studio, smear ing the ceiling, floor and walls with splashes and splat ters of paint. The work was the attempt of an abstract expressionist artist to create an environment. As it was, all Mr. Farber succeeded in creating on the gallery sur faces was a series of undis tinguished paintings in a fa miliar style.

title: Angry Drunk Burns Home
description: DUNKERQUE, France (UPI) Bernard de Weille, 23 years old, burned down his family home in anger because his parents refused to go with him to midnight church services on grounds he was drunk, the po lice said.

title: Meany Says People's Faith In Government Is Eroded
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said today in a New Year's Eve statement that the public's confidence in its government had been seri ously eroded

title: Louis and Nikolais Groups Slated to Dance on One Bill
description: The Murray Louis Dance Company and the Alwin Niko lais Dance Theater will appear together on one bill for the first time at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music from Jan. 18 through Jan. 30.

title: Young Crees in Montana Educated From an. Indian's Point of View
description: ROCKY BOY RESERVA TION, Mont.  What haunts the parents on this north eastern Montana reservation is the fact that in 10 years only 12 Cree teenagers have graduated from high school.

title: Jordan Charges Violations
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 31Israeli planes entered Jordan ian airspace twice today, broke the sound barrier and caused sonic booms Similar to, explo sions, a Jordanian military communique said.

title: DR. ASSAR G. JANZEN, SCANDINAVIA EXPERT
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 81Dr. Asser Gotrik Janzen, pro fessor of Scandinavian, who es tablished, the Scandinavian der partment at the University of California 25 years ago, died Monday at his home. He was ayears Ago.

title: It's 1972  The Year of the Calendar
description: Supersized, supergraphic calendars are big sellers in stores these days. And, say some producers, the boom has just begun.

title: Electronic Tube Stores Images
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31An electronic storage tube in vented by a Princeton, N. J., engineer and business man has already found many uses, including the recording of pictures of Mars being re turned from Mariner 9. Steven R. Hofstein was granted Pat ent 3,631,294 this week for the Lithocon, which he says is the first storage tube to record on silicon and sili con dioxide. The patent is assigned to Prin ceton Electronic Products, Inc., of which Dr. Hofstein is organizer and president. The company has been turning out the device for two years.

title: Market Place: Where Is Next Nixon Market?
description: Jeremy Biggs, who runs the money at the $58million New York Venture Fund, might be more politically oriented, than the average money manager. At any rate, he's willing to put his fund's money where his mouth is. Mr. Biggs, blondish, young ish and thoughaful, has scanned recent Nixon moves for clues to the next market beneficiary. Politically, he believes, President Nixon has done something for the econ omyboth America's and the world's. He notes that Mr. Nixon has approached China, and that he's unwind ing the war in Vietnam.

title: Finds Said to Date Aegean City Back to 1000 B.C.
description: A bevy of terra cotta god desses and many bronze clasps that were excavated recently in Cnidus are evidence that the Greek settlement on the Aegean Sea in southwestern Turkey was not begun in 340 330 B.C., as had been supposed, but centuries earlier, a New York archeologist says.

title: 1972: No Time for Comedy
description: On New Year's Day it is possible to be sentimental sardonic, nurse a hangover or the world. It's no trick et all to be serious; anyone, poet or journalist or subway straphangerif there is a subwaycan study the front pages of the past twelvemonth and shudder.

title: WINGS WIN, 6 TO 3, FOR 3D STRAIGHT
description: DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UPI) Mickey Redmond maintained his team lead with his 17th and 18th goals of the season tonight to pace the Detroit Red Wings to their third straight victory, 63, over the California Golden Seals in the National Hockey League.

title: Notes On Metropolltan Congressmen
description: Representative Shirley Chis holm, the Brooklyn Demo crat, is going to Florida next week, and a fellow Demo crat, Mayor Lindsay, doesn't like it.

title: LIBRARY'S DRIVE SHORT OF ITS GOAL
description: The New York Public Li brary's science and technology division has fallen $9,000 short of its goal of filling an $86,000 budget deficit and will close its doors, at least temporarily, on Monday.

title: Medicare Fee to Rise By 20 Cents Next July
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)An increased rate of $5.80 a month, effective next July 1, for the medical insur ance part of Medicare was announced today by Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and. Wel fare.

title: LEGISLATURE FAILS TO ACT ON TAXES; RESUMES MONDAY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31The emer gency session of the Legislature on the state's shaky fiscal situ ation degenerated today into a hubbub of partisan accusations in which no action was taken on a proposed $413million tax program or on bills to limit an increase in the New York City transit fare to 5 cents.

title: Blues Farm Out Goalie
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) The St. Louis Blues sent a goalie, Peter McDuffe, to their Denver farm club today after calling Jacques Caron from the Spurs to the parent team. Caron made his debut with the Wednesday night.

title: UM SHOWS LOSS AS SALES EXPAND
description: Lower operating income and net losses for the quarter and ninemonth periods ended 30 were announced yesterday by the USM Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For anyone who is still in doubt about the social philosophy of the Nixon Administration, it may be quite revealing to compare two recent Ad ministration decisions: the President's veto of legislation that would establish a broad national system of voluntary daycare facilities, including after school facilities, for middleclass fami lies as well as for the poor, and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's approval of the New York State Department of Social Services dertonstration project requiring wel fare mothers with children over the age of six to accept public employ ment.

title: SALVATORE GRILLO, RETIRED ARCHITECT
description: Salvatore Grillo, a retired architect, died Thursday of coronary attack in Long Beach Hospital. He Wes 74 years old and liven in Island Park, L.I.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 31Outside, in the dazzle of sun on the palm trees, people sprawled on the beach and autos moved past the luxury hotels on Collins Avenue.

title: NASSAU ANNOUNCES CONTINGENCY PLANS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 31 The Nassau County Department of Transportation has prepared an emergency plan for Monday morning if there is a transit strike in New York City.

title: U.S. Group Drops Writer Over Article on Princess
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) Steffi Fields of Women's Wear Daily was expelled today from the Association of American Correspondents in London.

title: Jazz Horns Make Welcome Addition To Band's Concert
description: For the second time in about a month, a major rock act has appeared in concert accom panied by a completely unex pected horn section. A few weeks ago, it was James Taylor with the horn players from Dreams. Thursday night, at the Academy of Music, it was The Band, backed by a fivehorn unit that included some of New York's finest jazz men.

title: Books of The Times
description: Today is just the day made for a ses sion with any or all of the title's listed at the head of this column, They're a good excuse to linger in bed. They don't need a lectern to prop them up. Each can be read at nearly one take. They're as good as the hair of the dog, the cold towel around the forehead, the effervescent pill in the glass of water. Well, anyway, they're more fun.

title: Lucien Hubbard, Film Director, Producer and Author, Is Dead
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 31Lucien Hubbard, a film director and writer, died today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Betty Heasley. He was 82 yeira old.

title: No Pretty Picture
description: Phase One of President Nixon's renewal of the air war against North Vietnam has ended after five days of the heaviest bombing since President Johnson suspended the attack in 1968 to get peace negotiations started. The renewed bombing halt is a welcome start for 1972. But a bigger and even more perilous Phase Two cannot b'e far behind unless Mr. Nixon abandons his vain pursuit of military victory in Indochina and acts to revive the neglected Paris peace talks.

title: Tax Deadlock at Albany
description: The bitter pill is slow going down. Some Republican members of the State Legislature have balked, at least temporarily, at accepting a tax package agreed on by Governor Rockefeller and Republican and Democratic legislative leaders.

title: New Year's Eve Closing A Saving for jersey Bar
description: WAYNE, N. J., Dec. 31Twelve years ago Jack Gabriel did; some calculations and dis covered that he could save $650 by closing his gloomy restau rant and bar at 10 P.M. on New Year's Eve.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: May I offer some blotting paper to those tired New Yorkers who may have read with moist eyes Helen Near ing's recent OpEd page article en titled: More Notes from the Wilder nese?

title: Britain Firm on Date
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP)A spokesman for the Defense Ministry said Malta's extension of its deadline for the with drawal of British troops from the island would make no dif ference to Britain's own with drawal timetable.

title: Faulk Gains at Christchurch
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea land, Dec. 31 (AP)  Steve Faulk of Madisonville, La., de feated Armistead Neely of Tampa, Fla., 36, 75, 63, to gain the semifinals of the Can terbury lawn tennis tournament today.

title: TOLL MEN CALL OFF THREATENED STRIKE
description: A threatened strike by 600 Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority workers was delayed yesterday when the dispute was submitted to a factfinder who recommended that the two sides meet again next Tuesday.

title: STANFORD TRIES FOR UPSET AGAIN
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31Can thricebeaten Stanford make it two upsets in a row over the Big Ten's best in the Rose Bowl?

title: The Cat Lady's Trying to Survive, Like Everyone Else
description: The old woman with the bandaged legs and flat feet always carries bunch of bags around. At night she picks up stray cats and sells them to an animal laboratory for fifty cents each. Everybody around here knows the cat lady. We don't like what she's doing but we don't say anything. She's just trying to survive, like every one else.

title: SUGAR BOWL FOES VARY IN OFFENSE
Agreement Reached On Transit Contract
description: The Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority reached an agreement on a new contract shortly before 3 A.M. today, averting a strike threat ened by the union for 5 A.M.

title: Soviet Tells of China Opposition Group
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31An au thoritative Soviet newspaper reported today that a power ful group close to the Chinese, leadership had publicly ex pressed its opposition both to improying relations with the, United States and to an. all pervasive role for the army in China's affairs.

title: 3 NEW IN CAST SING HANSEL AND GRETEL
description: Three major cast changes left the charm of the Metro politan's Hansel and Gretel undimmed Thursday night, and so, with an encouraging num ber of children in contented at tendance, the Wicked Witch got hers (or his, actually) and everyone else lived happily ever after. Even the few stag ing mishaps along the waythe Witch's house surfaced too quickly and snagged one of the flying trees, the famous oven explosion almost missed its cue, etc.were taken in un concerned stride, and seemed only to add to the fun.

title: WEST WINS, 1713, IN SHRINE GAME
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Gary Hammond of Southern Methodist threw scor ing passes of 45 and 28 yards today as the West rolled to its fourth consecutive victory, 1713, over the East in the 47th Shrine Football Classic.

title: News Analysis
description: The announcement that An glicans and Roman Catholics had reached agreement on the essential teachings about the sacrament of Holy Communion constitutes an advance for the ecumenical movement at a time when most church leadeis acknowledge that it has lost a good deal of momentum. The 1,500word Agreed Statement on Eucharistic Doctrine, made public this week, was worked out by the 24 bishops and theolo glans Who make up the Angli canRoman Catholic Interna tional Commission and released with the approval of Pope Paul VI and the Most Rev. Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, the Archbish op of Canterbury.

title: Slaying Confession Read at Hearing
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 31A detailed signed statement that purports to describe how narcotics addict shot and killed a Nassau. County patrolman after a holdup Wednesday night was read In a crowded courtroom in First District Court here today.

title: MALTA POSTPONES BRITISH DEADLINE
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 31Prime Minister Dom Mintoff announced tonight that he was extending to Jan. 15 his dead line for withdrawal of all British forces from Malta.

title: American Women Gain Final
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Dec. 31 (AP)Linda Tuero and Sharon Walsh moved into an allAmerican women's singles final with victories to day at the Free State Sugar tennis tournament.

title: PAUL A. SRACKLEFORD
description: Paul A. Shackleford, a former excecutive of International Business Machines Corpora tion in charge of transpor tion programs, died Thursday in Booth Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 8124 Austin Street, Kew Gar dens, Queens.

title: Rozelle Says 78 Players In N.F.L. Remain Unsigned
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP)  Com missioner Pete Rozelle disclosed last night that 78 National Football League players were still unsigned for the 1971 sea son.

title: 470 IN GREECE URGE PRISONERS BE FREED
description: ATHENS, Dec. 31  Some 470 Greek intellectuals and civic leaders today urged the Gov ernment to free all Greek polit ical prisoners on the New Year in response to their urgent humanitarian request and a na tional imperative.

title: U. S. WON'T COMMENT ON F4s FOR ISRAEL
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP)  The Florida White House today refused to con firm or deny reports that the United States had agreed to sell more F4 Phantom fighter bombers to Israel.

title: U.S. Analyzes Restraint By Peking on Bombings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 United States Governmentan alysts said today that China's relatively restrained reaction to the fiveday American bombing of North Vietnam indicated a wish to go ahead with President Nixon's trip in February even at the cost of additional strains in Peking's. relations with Hanoi.

title: Humphrey to Announce Entry Into Presidential Race Jan. 10
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, the Democrats 1968 Presidential candidate, will announce Jan. 10 his deci sion to try again for the nomi nation.

title: Schlitz Ends All Activity At Its Brooklyn Brewery
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company closed its Brooklyn plant completely yesterday. Two weeks ago the Milwaukee based company announced that it was halting beer production at the plant, which annually turned out a million barrels (of 31 gallons each) since it was purchased in 1949. Pack aging operations continued un til yesterday.

title: Technique Developed to Save Birds Caught in Big Oil Spills
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31A California veterinarian has developed what appears to be a successful technique for saving wild water birds from the lethal aftereffects of oil spills.

title: FRANCIS W. MURRAY JR.
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Dec. 31 Francis W. Murray Jr., former chairman of the board of the Bank of Orange and Ulster County, died yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: Revelers by Thousands Usher in Frosty New Year
description: To a bedlam of hornblowing in Times Square and spectacu Nr fireworks in Central Park, many thousands of revelers last night shouted in a New Year that they hoped would be bet ter than 1971.

title: Thousands of Iranians Are Expelled by Iraq
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 (AP)  Thousands of Iranian men, women and children were trudging back to Iran today in freezing tempera tures after being, ordered out of Iraq.

title: Record Subsidies Are Expected For Farmers to Stem Surpluses
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  me Nixon Administration plan to make 1972 the most expeinsive farmsubsidy year on record in an attempt to head off growing crop surpluses and discontent Over sagging farm income.

title: Nixon's Filing Expected
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 31President Nixon's campaign or ganization plans to file Mr. Nixon's name Monday in New Hampshire's Presidential pref erence primary.

title: Text of CatholicAnglican Accord on the Communion Sacrament
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 Following is the text of a joint statement on Holy Communion drawn up by an Anglican Roman Catholic commission and made public this week with the approval of Pope Paul VI and the Most Rev. Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: Guild Here Will Submit A.P. Pay Offer to Members
description: Negotiators for the Wire Service Guild agreed late last night to submit the latest wage offer of the Associated Press to its members for a vote this week on a new twoyear contract.

title: UNFAMILIAR PIECES ON ANCERL PROGRAM
description: Karel Ancerl altered his New York Philharmonic program somewhat Thursday night. From the previous evening's concert he kept a Suite in F by Zelenka and Dvorak's Sym phony No. 8. The new items were three pieces by Pavel Josef Vejvanovsky and an or gan Concerto in F by Frantisek Xaver Brixi.

title: 49ers'
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 31 (UPI)The San Francisco 49ers coach, Dick Nolan, admitted that he respects the Dallas Cowboys running attack his team will face in Sunday's National Foot ball Conference championship game. But he doesn't expect the Cowboys Duane Thomas to explode for 143 yards like he did a year ago.

title: Colleges Expand Modern Psychiatric Aid
description: The college health service, long viewed by students as good only for doling out aspirin, patching up athletes and diag nosing the common cold, is now emerging as a leading counsel ing and treatment center for student sex and psychiatric problems.

title: HUTSON, SIMPSON TOP ALLROSE TEAM
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP)  Don Hutson, the Ala bama end who caught two touchdown passes in the 1935 Rose Bowl game, heads the 50year Rose Bowl team an nounced today.

title: Man In the News
description: Israeli tank commanders are reputed to ride with tur rets open, heads and shoul ders exposed, in even the sharpest of battles.

title: Union Post to Change Hands
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 31  Joseph Belsky of New York will take office tomorrow as president of the Amalgamated Meat Cut ters and Butchers Workman, a union representing more than 500,000 workers in the United States and Canada. Mr. Bel sky, the union's senior vice president and an officer of Local 234 the Hebrew Butchers Union, will succeed Thomas J. (Jack) Lloyd, who is reviring today after serving as uresi dent for 14 years.

title: Memphis State Wins, 9277
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 31 (AP) Memphis State University jumped to a 24point lead in the second half and coasted to a 9277 basketball victory over the University of Arkansas to night. The Tigers, despite hav ing four starters with three fouls each at halftime, built a 7450 lead with 10:30 to play.

title: TOPPER CORP. SUED BY 2 STOCKHOLDERS
description: Two shareholders of the Top per Corporation, a toy manu facturer, have filed a class ac tion suit in Federal District Court here. The suit accuses the company and certain in siders of having made false statements and of having un loaded substantial amounts of stock in the company in under written public offerings.

title: Challenge Was Gone in Advertising, So He Chose New Career as a Nurse
description: Last August Stanley Birn baum announced to his boss at the Kenyon & Eckhardt advertising agency that he was leaving his $20,000ayear job as Director of Media Research to become a nurse.

title: AUSTIN R. ZENDER, AN INDUSTRIALIST
description: MILFORD, Conn., Dec. 31 Austin R. Zender, former pres ident of National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, died Yes terdity in Milford Hospital. He Was 68 years old and lived at 6 Ranch Road.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Dec. 31  Before 1967, more than 100,000 people lived in the Plaine des Jarres. They got in the way of the American bombers operating over Laos, but this inconvenience was removed in a way reminiscent of Swift's A Modest Proposal: The in habitants were all either killed or forced out of their homes as refugees.

title: Anderson Jolts Newcombe in 5 Sets
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (AP)Mal Anderson, who won the United States title 14 years ago, upset John New combe, the reigning Wimbledon champion, in a fiveset men's singles quarterfinal match to day in the Australian open ten nis tournament.

title: P. S. C. Tells Con Ed to Retain Reserves Even if Coal Is Used
description: The Public Service Commis sion has announced in Albany that it intends to order, the Consolidated Edison Company to maintain adequate operating reserves even if it means high output from a controversial coalburning generating sys tem.

title: J. R. Ferris Weds Mrs. Langmuir
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 51Mrs. Nancy Steven son Langmuir, widow of Peter Bulkeley Langmuir, was mar ried here this afternoon to John Riker Ferris, who is de scended from Jacobus Riker, for whom Rikers Island in New York is named.

title: Why More Men Are joining Field
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)  Mother thrilled when her son decides to be come a doctor. But what if Johnny wants to be a nurse?

title: Celtics Win 10th in Row; Greer Hits 21,000 Mark
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)The surging Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek, Dave Cowens and Jo Jo White, swept their 10th consecutive National Basketball Association vic tory today by defeating the Philadelphia 76ers, 131119.

title: Tantamount Takes Purse As Laurel Meeting Ends
Egypt's Year of Decision On New War Ends Quietly
description: CAIRO, Saturday, Jan. 1Egypt's year of decision dead line for war or peace with Israel passed quietly yesterday with no clear indication of what decision, if any, had been taken.

title: Georgia Beats NC., 73
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla:, Dec. 31 (UPI)Jimmy (the Greek) Pou los's 25yard touchdown run late in the third period gave Georgia a tougherthanexpect ed 73 victory over North Caro lina today in the Gator Bowl football game.

title: Manhattanville Will Offer 5Day Program in the Arts
description: Manhattanville College will present a fiveday Improvisa tional Arts Institute at its Pur chase, N. Y., campus from Jan. 17 through 21.

title: Seven Large de Kooning Lithographs Are Shown
description: Pictorial styles that rely on an essential painterliness for their expressive force are not always easily transferred to the lithographic medium. Di vorced from the visual and physical properties of the actual pigment, even the most powerful pictorial style may be reduced to a hollow caricature of itself. The dynamics of the painting may be evoked without being effectively realized.

title: PACERS TOP NETS ON RALLY, 104100
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 31 (AP)The Indiana Pacers ral lied in the final minutes tonight to beat the New York Nets, 104100, in the American Bas ketball Association.

title: MRS. GANDHI SAYS INDIA WOULD LIKE U.S. FRIENDSHIP
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 31Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said to day that India would like to have a friendly relationship with the United States again, but she wondered whether the United States Administration wants friendship or not.

title: POPULAR VOTE URGED FOR ITALY PRESIDENT
description: ROME, Dec. 31  The neo Fascist party started collecting signatures today on a petition to parliament for a constitu tional amendment providing for the popular election of the president of Italy.

title: Phone Men Still on the Line
description: For 25 weeks now, pickets carrying signs saying Ma Bell Go to Hell have been marching in front of New York Telephone Company buildings, new tenants have been learning the vexationsand occasional joysof life without telephones and representatives of the tele phone company and the 23 locals of the Communications Workers of America through out the state have been ne gotiating in a midtown hotel and, in their own words, getting absolutely nowhere.

title: Grass Roots Helps Minority Ventures Vie for Contracts
description: Grass Roots Exposition, Inc., which just completed its first year of operation, has de veloped a new program for bringing together prime con tractors and other major cor porations with minority busi nesses.

title: Stolen Porcelains Are Described In ParkeBernet Sales Brochure
description: The theft here of valuable porcelains in the last six months, under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation, is being publicized in an illustrated brochure in serted in a sales catalogue of the ParkeBernet Galleries, re cently mailed to subscribers.

title: Melba Rae Is Dead at 49; Starred in Serial on C.B.S.
description: Melba Rae, a wellknown tel evision actress, died on Wednesday evening of a cere bral hemorrhage at New York Hospital She was 49 years old and lived at 175 East 79th Street.

title: Marooned Players Get No Rise Out of Paterno
description: DALLAS, Dec. 31Much of Penn State's football of fense and defense was stalled for 37 minutes today: 17 Penn State players had jammed more than 3,900 pounds into a 4footby6 foot elevator when it be came stuck between the third and fourth floors of the Fairmont Hotel.

title: ANGUS L. CRAIO
description: WARWICK, R. I., Dec. 31Angus L. Craig, who at his re tirement in 1947 was chief ex aminer of survey, of the San born Map Coinpany of Pel ham, N. Y., died Wednesday in a nursing home after a two week illness. He was 89 years old.

title: OPTIMISM SHOWN BY STEEL MAKERS
description: The nation's steel industry, hit by what one company termed a drought in the latter part of 1971, looks to better times on hopes that the entire economy will grow at a higher rate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Several suburban newspapers have commented editorially that the Forest Hills publichonsing project seems to be a bad example of a good principle too large a project and perhaps on an unfortunate site but good because it is in a middleincome neighborhood rather than in the middle of the slums.

title: Blast Damages Queens Cafe
description: A hand grenade slightly dam aged a Queens pizza restaurant at 8128 Lefferts Boulevard in the Kew Gardens section yes terday. No one was injured.

title: Bible Society's Medium Spreads Message to the Jesus People
description: An eightpage paper entitled Great News and aimed at the Jesus People, has been issued here by the traditionally con servative New York Bible So ciety.

title: Mrs. Hopkins Wed To Arthur Baer Jr.
description: Mrs. Joan Rich Hopkins of New York, daughter of Mrs. Timothy White of Winthrop, Mass., was mar ried here yesterday after noon to Arthur Bugs Baer Jr., also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur (Bugs) Baer. The bridegroom's father was a sports writer and columnist for the Hearst newspapers.

title: New Medical Institute to Study Nation's Top Health Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31A new unit of the National Acad emy of Sciences is tooling up for 1972 with plans to confront some of the most difficult questions involving American health.

title: Judge Goddard Retires
description: Judge J. Eugene Goddard of Rochester retired yesterday from the State Court of Claims. Judge Goddard, a Republican who served for 16 years in the State Assembly, was appointed to the court by Governor Rock efeller in 1966. Judge Goddard reached the mandatory retire ment age of 70 last April 28.

title: JUDGE CALLS LAW ON RAPE LENIENT
Parting Shots
description: The Cold War Mr. Truman fears war, but remains evasive about peace. The meaning of the Hbomb and the new weapons of destruction is that men must learn to live together on the same planet In mutual forbearance.... But Mr. Tru man's emphasis was on his old hope that if cold war and containment were continued long enough the Soviet re gime would somehow crack up from within... Mr. Truman set the mood and Mr. Acheson coined the phrase for ittotal diplomacy....

title: 1971 Was a Banner Year For the Holiday Festival
DR. WARREN KERSHNER
description: BATH, Me., Dec. 31Dr. Warren E. Kershner, a retired ophthalmologist and otolaryn gologist, died yesterday in the Bath Memorial Hospital. His age was 91.

title: Elliott Retains U.S. Title In CrossCountry Skiing
description: LYNDONVILLE, Vt., Dec. 31 Mike Elliott, the 29yearold American Olympian from Du rango, Colo., found today's crisp conditions ideal as he retained his national 15kilo meter crosscountry skiing championship by less than minute.

title: Running Against Washington
description: Over the years there has always been one sure applausegetter for barnstorming politicians whenever they run out of anything useful to say: denounce the alien power centers in New York. To Governor Wallace, Vice President Agnew and an endless company of similar deep thinkers, it has always been axiomatic that the country would be better off if this city were sawed loose and floated out to sea.

title: Episcopal Editor Scores St John's on Political Rally
description: The editor of an Episcopal weekly charged yesterday that the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine should no longer enjoy the right to tax exemption because it was re cently used for partisan po litical gatherings.

title: On Icy Day at Rowing Race, Winning Woman Coxswain Benefits From Change of Heart
Peking Terms 71 a Year of Victory
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 31 Pe king greeted the new year with a declaration that 1971 was a year of victory and reaffirmed its determination to liberate Taiwan.

title: MRS. JENNIE KLATSKY, A FOUNDER OF ORT, 80
description: Mrs. Jennie Chenerinsky Klat sky, a founder of the Women's American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) and a former national vice president, died Thursday in Peninsula General Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. Slip was 80 years old and lived at 561 Norman Way, Wood mere. L.I

title: Charles Posts a 200 to Win Auckland Golf by 2 Shots
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 1 (AP)  Bob Charles of New Zealand won the Spanding Masters golf tournament at Tauranga today in a rainshortened threeround tournament. The lefthander posted a 10underpar 67, 67, 65200.

title: List Wins $12,500 Feature At New Orleans Track
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 1 (AP)List, leaving the pack at the 16th pole, drew away and scooted home to win the $12,500 New Year's Handicap today at the New Orleans Fair Grounds.

title: Travel Notes: Some Guidelines for Flying Smoothly on Charters
description: GROUP fares and charter flights continue to be thorns in the sides of carriers, the traveling public and even the Government. Late last month, scheduled airlines flying between the West Coast and Hawaii asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to discontinue group fares on that run. They complained of widespread rate cutting and other violations of the C.A.B's groupfare rules. The board was urged to grant the request because of unmanageably low profit margins on group fares and to head off an impending rate war among CaliforniaHawaii airlines.

title: The Season On Canada Goose Nears End on L.I.
description: WAINSCOTT, L.I.Turkey dinner is a wintertime treat here, but a few families are able to enjoy an old East End traditionwild Canada goose.

title: Decision Favoring a Reservist May Aid WarFoe Discharges
description: A physician in the Army Reserves has won a court battle that may substantially strengthen the rights of reservists seeking to be discharged as conscientious objectors.

title: Bryant: Nebraska Team Toyed With Us
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1 (UPI)Paul (Bear) Bryant said tonight that Nebraska's Cornhuskers toyed with his Alabama football team and he shouldered the blame for the Crimson Tide's worst bowl beating.

title: My Life and Times By Henry Miller. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Playboy Press. $17.95.
description: I have spent a sedative summer rereading most of Henry Miller. Sedative? Yes, inevitably, since it's the fate of all revolutionary writers to encompass their own supersession. How shocking Tropic of Cancer was when I got hold of a smuggled copy in the late thirties; how merely charming it is now, redolent of Paris in which the coffee and Gauloises were alike more aromatic than they've been since the war, a genuine vie de Boheme, the physical act of love as fresh as if the French had just invented it. Miller unbuttoned the fly and tore open the placket with a fiercer gust than Lawrence (who was still mother's boy) or Joyce (who let language get in the way). Today's naked generation has learned nearly everything from himeverything, that is to say, except his bookishness, his capacity for recapturing innocence, his sense of wonder, his sense of words.

title: Bhutto Is Said to Plan Mujib's Quick Release
description: Time magazine yesterday quoted President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan as having said he plans to release unconditionally in a couple of clays Sheik Mujibur Rahaman, the Bengali leader jailed on treason charges by former President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan.

title: Stamps
description: A NEW booklet of 25 eightcent Eisenhower stamps, selling for $2, and without the usual interleaving, will go on sale Jan. 28 at Casa Grande, Arizona, during ARIPEX 72, the stamp exhibition of the Arizona Federation of Stamp Clubs. The $2 booklet will replace the current $1.92 booklet of 24 Eisenhower stamps to simplify purchases for Postal Service patrons and to ease calculating tasks of post office clerks.

title: Winged Foot to Be Host
description: The 1974 United States Open golf championship will be played over the West course of the Winged Foot Club at Mamaroneck, N. Y.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 25 (UPI)The Olympic organizing committee is hoping for a fat bonus checkthe profits from Christmas business in Olympic souvenirs. The shops of the Olympic City are filled with gifts and goods marked with the symbols of the 1972 Munich games.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I read with great interest the Nov. 7 article, The Suburbs Have to Open Their Gates, by Linda and Paul Davidoff and Neil N. Gold.

title: Art
description: FOUR white rabbits, placidly munching, on a plot of green grass. With marvelous economy, the shaggy figures occupy nearly all the available space, except for the right hand side of the picture wherecontrary to every rule of spatial logic or illusiona tree no larger than the rabbits stands cleanly against the sky. The picture by Chang Tung Fu, age 12, of the Taitung Family Helper Project in Taiwan is one of 59 paintings and drawings in an admirable little exhibition of children's art currently installed in the Junior Museum Studio at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The works have been selected from the more than 15,000 entries submitted to an international contest sponsored by the Christian Children's Fund on the theme, Why I Want Peace. Many of the childrenmost of them in orphanages and charitable institutions associated with the Fundare Chinese and Indian; a few are Africans and South Americans. Judging from the exhibition, Taiwan is particularly strong in young artists; several works, some of the most engagingare from that island.

title: CELTICS STREAK HALTED BY SUNS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1. (AP)  The PhoeniX Suns halted Boston's winning streak at 10 games tonight, blanking the Celtics from the floor for nearly half the second period en route to a 114104 National Basketball Association victory.

title: U.S.Soviet Gas Deal?
description: The frantic search for supplementary supplies of natural gas to meet the threatened energy crisis has led to many strange sources: liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Algeria and Venezuela; synthetic, or substitute, natural gas (SNG) from naphtha; gasification of coal, oil or the Athabasca sands in western Canada and even a suggestion that the industry look into producing synthetic gas from garbage.

title: BOTTLE DEPOSITS UPHELD IN BOWIE
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 1A judge has upheld this city's ordinance requiring deposits on all beverage containers. It is believed to be the first court ruling in the United States upholding ban on nonreturnable bottles and cans.

title: Airline Deaths Up in'71 After TwoYear Decline
description: A disastrous midair collision, a mysterious mountainside crash in Alaska, and a flaming accident in a landing approach in fog at New Haven produced an increase in airline deaths last year after two years of sharp improvement in air safety.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I doubt that when Rockefeller had lost for sure at Miami, Henry was seen weeping (The Road to Peking, or, How Does This Kissinger Do It? by Barnard Law Collier, Nov. 14).

title: Woman, 76, Man, 81 Both Blind, Married
description: LAS VEGAS; Nev., Jan. 1 (AP)Marjory Stewart, who has been blind since infancy, was married this week to Gene Stahl, blinded by glaucoma 16 years ago.

title: Pact Lets Air France Make 2 Shanghai Runs a Week
description: PEKING, Jan. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  A new agreement under which Air France, will double its ParisShanghai service was announced here today.

title: Residents Avoid PrizeWinning Park
description: How do community leaders and local civic groups react when the city builds an innovative, awardwinning park in the middle of their neighborhood?

title: William Pfeifer, Banking Aide, Fiance of Gwynne Lee Macrae
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 1Mrs. Elliott Beach Macrae has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gwynne Lee Macrae, to William Alfred Pfeifer, son of Charles F. Pfeifer of New Canaan and New York and the late Mrs. Charlene Church Pfeifer of Duluth, Minn.

title: 2 of the Richest Men In Pakistan Are Put Under House Arrest
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Tan. 1 Two of the richest men in Pakistan, Ahmed Dawood and Fakhruddin Valika, were put under six months house arrest today.

title: RANGERS, BRUINS TO MEET TONIGHT
description: The New York Rangers will play the Boston Bruins tonight at 7:05 P.M. at Madison Square Garden in the thiid of fivegame home stand fora the Rangers.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Because of a revised printing schedule, The Week in Review section is folded inside the Financial section,

title: Pro Golf Tour, Richest in History, Starts With Los Angeles Open: Thursday
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (AP)The professional golf tour will begin the longest season in sports this week.

title: Best of Two Worlds On Governors Island
description: A hundred and sixty families, some with as many as seven children, have moved into what seems to be a New Yorker's impossible dream:

title: The World
description: RAWALPINDI  President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto assembled foreign ambassadors and newsmen last Monday for an important announcement. He had just held a meeting, he revealed, with his prisoner, Sheik Mujibur Rahman. It was a painful first step, the President said, which should have been taken long ago.

title: When the Melting Pot Doesn't Melt
description: THERE are many questions raised by the astonishing spectacle of the liberal, middleclass Jewish community of For. est Hills fighting the building of a housing project. But the most serious question is whether the hope for an integrated America is a false one. Are we, as so many believe, an irretrievably racist society, one in which even the liberal will be proven a bigot when he is forced to accept Negroes into his own community? Unfortunately, this is what most people will conclude. It is certainly what the local N.A.A.C.P. chapters of Queens have concluded. It may end up being what the people of Queens who oppose the project conclude about themselves, too.

title: CITY WILL LOBBY FOR 173 OLD BUS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1  Like wallflower who dresses hopefully for every Saturday night dance, the Lindsay admmistration plans to try again this year for 173 of it favorite bills that failed in the last session of the State Legislature.

title: N.F.C. Officials Are Named For Cowboys49ers Clash
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP)Officials have been announced for tomorrow's game between the Dallas Cowboys and the San Francisco 49ers for the National Football Conference championship.

title: Photography
description: AN 8session workshop for beginners will be conducted, by Stuart Keener, 2 Edwards Street, Roslyn Heights, L. I., beginning on Saturday at 10 A.M. To be conducted on Thursday evenings from 8 to 10, and on Saturday mornings from 10 to noon, the course will include darkroom, instruction and field trips, and the cost will be $70. For information call (516) 6213963.

title: Garden Preview
description: WHEN the seed catalogues start to arrive in the mail, spring comes a little bit closer. Hours can be spent pouring over the pages, if only to satisfy that yearning for the feel of soil between the fingers once again.

title: The Circle Of Life
description: Surely even the young are getting weary of ecology sermons and dulled to the threat of poisonous surroundings. The web of life is an attractive. gratifying subject, and the primary reader has an openness to the idea of man's dependence on nature. But his hunger for seeing relationships needs some subtlety in its care and feeding.

title: DWIGHT MARVIN, NEWSMAN, DEAD
description: TRYON, N.C., Jan. 1 (AP) Dwight Marvin, former president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and former editor of the Troy, N.Y., Record, died today at St. Luke's Hospital here. He was 91 years old.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  There has been no official announcement, but knowledgeable lawyers and draft counselors are convinced that draft calls this year will be quite small  only a fraction of the calls during the peak of the Vietnam buildup and less than half the size of last year's total call.

title: Boston State's Comeback Beats Yale In Hockey, 75
description: NEW HAVEN; Jen. 1Boston State's hockey team dissipated a 51.lead tonight but rallied in the third period to defeat Yale, 75.

title: Music
description: New York Rock Ensemble. THERE I was, a promising young oboe player. From my vantage point at Juilliard, it seemed that on graduation I might join an orchestra  perhaps the Philharmonic  or maybe be a successful freelance, playing chamber music. Some day I might make records as a soloist; there would be some time to compose, some time to perform  and time Co practice and shave my reeds.

title: Stuffed Bird Protected Too
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)The Department of Fish and Game says that whoever stole the mounted whitetailed kite from its headquarters here this week illegally bagged a fully protected game bird, stuffed or not. As a result, the thief faces a fine up to $1,000 and a year in jail, officials said.

title: NEW BUS SERVICE IS DUE TOMORROW
description: The first expressbus service between Brooklyn and Manhattan will start tomorrow with morning and evening rushhour service, linking the Bay Ridge section with the Wall Street and midtown areas. The service will be operated by the. Transit Authority.

title: The Brandts, in Florida Mix with '72 Revelers
description: LONGBOAT KEY, Fla., Jan. 1 (UPI)  Chancellor Willy Brandt of West German and his wife ushered in 1972 by attending a private reception in their honor and a good oldfashioned American New Year's Eveparty.

title: 91 Policemen Reported Killed In First 9 Months of 1971
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The International Association of Chiefs of Police reported that 91. policemen were killed in the line of duty in the nation, during the first nine months of 1971.

title: Humphrey Aide Is Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) Daniel Hackell, 34 years old, a former newsman for the American Broadcasting Company, has been named campaign press secretary for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, an aide of the Senator said today. On Jan. 10, Mr. Humphrey will announce his decision to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination this year.

title: Knee Braces No Handicap to Skater
description: It is difficult for any Skater to do a double Lutz jump,backwards down the ice, shooting up into two revolution in the air with a clean controlled landing, on the other foot. But I4yearold Austin Mitscher of Roseland, N.J, has braces on both knee's. Without them, he couldn't skate at all.

title: AWARD ESTABLISHED IN JONES'S MEMORY
description: A Bobby Jones Memorial Award has been established in honor of the amateur golfer who died last month at the age of 69 by the Spalding sporting goods company.

title: Dietzel Informs Broncos He Won't Take Head Post
description: COLUMBIA, S. C. Jan. 1 (AP)Paul Dietzel, athletic rector and head football coach at the University of South Carolina, says he has asked that his name be dropped from consideration for the post of head coach and general manager of the Denver Broncos of the National Football League.

title: Man Is Stabbed to Death In Park Sheraton Hotel
description: A former assistant manager of the Park Sheraton Hotel was found stabbed to death yester day morning in a 21stfloor. room of the hotel, at Seventh. Avenue and 55th Street.

title: REID HOLDS LEAD IN PENGUIN RACES
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1Mel Reid, the defending Penguin Class champion from the Setauket, L.1., fleet, and Randy Bartholomew of the host Manhasset Bay Interclub fleet, held comfortable leads after four races today in the 41st annual New Year's Frostbite Regatta on Manhasset Bay.

title: Leafs Beat Cancliens, 52 Erasing 21 Deficit With 4 Goals in Final Period
description: TORONTO, Jan. 1 (UPI) Thirdperiod goals by. Gary Monahan, Ron Ellis, Paul Henderson and Norm Ullman earned the Toronto. Maple Leafs a 52 victory over the Montreal. Canadiens tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: WESTBURY TRACK TO OPEN MEETING
description: Roosevelt Raceway will open for its 33d season of harness racing tomorrow night. The 50night meeting will continue through Feb. 29.

title: Women's Lib Unit.Needs A Woman To Head It
description: Things have come to an unpretty pass for the West Queens Independent Democratic Club in Sunnyside.

title: Reader's Report
description: After several years on American campuses the daughter of a Calcutta tobacco potentate returns for a summer to her native city. Tara Banerjee Cart wright has acquired a degree, an American husband and the makings of dissertation on Katherine Mansfield. None of these is adequate preparation for reentry into the Brahmin beau mondewhich, in the author's reflective eye, is reminiscent of the Cherry Orchart syndrome. Tara's daddy, known to family and friends as The Bengal Tiger, belongs to a mercantile aristocracy with its roots in the ageof Victoria.. This chauffeured, unimaginablycosseUed upper crust is, threatened from within by aggressive new men of the stripe Chekhov characterized so well in Lopaklin, and from without by militant hordes of the destitute.

title: Dance
description: THIS is written in Jamaica, so if it sounds too sunny, put it down to the climate. My habit of taking a seasonoutofseason at the year's end at least provides a strange and personal punctuation to the year, conducive not only to retrospective thought but also to assessment of figure prospects.

title: PULITZER JURORS ARE ANNOUNCED
description: Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, announced the appointment yesterday of 45 editors as Pulitzer Prize journalism jurors for 1972.

title: The naked nape
description: The skin game is back. In 1972, it's neat to bare your back in a long sophisticated dress cut down to a seductive there. The black rayon mat jersey dress (on the standing model), shaped like a slip, has a swoopingly low back. It's by Victor Joris for V&J designs. And it's $185 in the Park Avenue Room at Saks Fifth Avenue (special order). The black wool jersey outlined in bright yellow blanketstitching crisscrosses to a new low in the back. It's by the 499 division of Kloss Pruzan. You can buy it for $60 in Sutton Place at Bloomingdale's. The jewelry is by K.J.L.; hairdos are by Paul Mitchell of Henri Bendel.

title: Niagara Beats Canisius, 9182, and Wins Queen City Tourney 2d Year in Row
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 1 (UPI) Marshall Wingate scored 15 of his 20 points in the second half tonight as Niagara University won, its second straight Queen City trournament by defeating Canisius, 9182.

title: GULFSTREAM PARK WILL OPEN JAN. 17
description: A record of 111 nominations for the $125,000 added Florida Derby March 2 at Gulfstream Park has been announced by Edward C. McKinsey, racing secretary. The 21st running of the Derby is expected to gross in excess of $160,000. and will be the richest race in Florida history.

title: FRANZE WINKLER, A PSYCHOLOGIST, 64
description: GREATBARRINGTON, Mass., Jdn. 1Dr. Franz E. Winkler, a New York physician and psy?? who wrote and lectured widely on problems of youth, education and drugs, died last night of a heart attack at his country home here.

title: 73 UP FOR VOTES TO HALL OF FAME
description: Sixtyone semifinalists, have been named for 1972 college Football Hall of Fame Considerition in the after 1920 player eategory, the National Football Foundation's board chairman Vincent depaul Draddy, announced yesterday.

title: Nixon for the Third Year Heads Gallup's MostAdmired List
description: For the third consecutive year, President Nixon heads the list of men the American people admire most In the world today, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: Pro Bidder Triumphs by Two Lengths in $22,900 Handicap at Bowie Opening
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 1 (UPI)Pro Bidder sped to a twolength triumph today in the $22,900 Southern Maryland Handicap as Bowie Race Course opened a 61day meeting.

title: A POLICE SHAKEUP STARTS IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 1A deputy police superintendent and a district commander were demoted this week in a shakeup of the Chicago Police Department's top command as a Federal grand jury continued its investigation of alleged corruption in the department.

title: Reader's Report
description: The hero in question is a film actor named Johnny Lewis, who makes three pictures in the 1950's and becomes a legend after his death, age 24, in a motorcycle accident. Seems to ring a bell somewhere, doesn't it? For reasons not too distinct, the author plays Time Machine with the deceased. As narrator, he returns to the 1950's to become his shadowy pal, skipping periodically into the future, (or the present) to write a screenplay based on his life. In the final stages of the novel. narrative chores are assumed by the dead star, with Mr. Corley as kibitzer, riding pillion on the fatal motorcycle.

title: If a House Is on Fire and I Cry Fire
description: AT a recent meeting in Cambridge, the speaker introducing Edward Bond claimed that if England ever went fascist, Bond would be the first writer to be apprehended and jailed. Perhaps, this is the highest compliment that can be paid to a consciously political English playwright. Surely, Harold Pinter and John Osborne would suffer no deprivations, and I doubt whether Arnold Wesker or Robert Bolt would even earn the privilege of being interrogated. But Bond, whose mordant comedy, Narrow Road to the Deep North, opens Thursday at Lincoln Center, would certainly pose a threat any government bent on repression.

title: Taking off the minstrel mask
description: Nathan Irvin Huggins's fiarlem Renaissance is the first fullscale treatment of the period, roughly the 1920's, when a considerable flowering of literary and other arts occurred among black Americans. Coming hard upon such major changes in black life as the massive migration to the cities and bitter World War I and postWorld War experiences, the Renaissance's aim was expression and celebration of black life and culture through a free sensibilityan achievement requiring a radical dissociation from the sensibility provided by Euro American culture, which had imposed selfglorifying definitions of blacks through the minstrel tradition. Out of the movement arose such wellknown writers and artists as Langston Hughes, Arna Bontemps, Claude McKay, Jean Toomer, Countee Cullen and Aaron Douglas.

title: Education
description: The Regents Examinations in New York State have long been regarded as one of the nation's most prestigious statewide testing systems. They have served as measures of academic achievement for college admissions and jobs, and some high schools have required the Regents for graduation. Last year more than 700,000 of the state's high school students took the examinations.

title: Food for Temple Workers
description: CAIRO, Jan. 1 (Reuters)The World Food Program, a joint effort of the United Nations and the Food and Agriculture Organization, will provide food worth $2.4million for workers in the project to salvage the Philee Temples in upper Egypt from the waters of the Aswan dam.

title: Ellen Erpf Fiancee. Of Jeffrey Miller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl K. Erpf of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellew Erpf, to Jeffrey A. Miller; son of Mr. and Mrs, Arthur Miller of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title: Television
description: TOKENISM has come to Sesame Street. Since Its inception, the much publicized vanguard heavy of educational programs has educated children in part by its consistent presentation of a world virtually without female people.
