For a little girl engaged in her own passionate struggle for selfdefinilion, watching Sesame Street last yearand even this fallwas like taking lessons in invisibility. Each appearance of a female character in her constricted, stereotyped role was doubly damaging because female characters actually appeared so very rarely.

title: WARENTRY PLANS LAID TO ROOSEVELT
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP)Formanly top secret British Government papers made public today said that President Franklin D. Roosevelt told Prime Minister Winston Churchill in August, 1941, that he was looking for an incident to justify opening hostilities against Nazi Germany.

title: COURT TO WEIGH DEMOCRATS'SUIT
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 1A Superior Court judge has ruled that a suit seeking an injunction restraining John M. Bailey, the Democratic state chairman, and the Democratic State Central Committee from enforcing a new state party rule that forbids local town committees to endorse themselves for new terms must be tried on its merits.

title: Is Pollyanna Just Around The Corner?
description: JUST possibly, it's going to be a Happier New Year than anyone imagined. I'm not dreaming, I've just been reading and watching.

title: Editor Fights Communists'Charges
description: Paul Novick, editorinchief of the Yiddishlanguage Morning Freiheit, is resisting charges by leaders of the Communist party, U.S.A., brought to expel him from the party after more than 50 years membership.

title: Israel Names General Tal As Deputy Chief of Staff
description: TEL AVIV, Jan 1 (Reuters)Maj. Gen Israel Tal, who commanded an Israeli armored column in the Sinai Peninsula in the 1967 war, was appointed Deputy Chief of Staff tonight. General Tal, 47 years old, succeeds Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, who yesterday became Israel's ninth Chief of Staff.

title: Chou Croute First In Tropical Stakes;
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1Chou Croute, a 4yearold filly, lost out to Turkish Trousers in the balloting for the division championship. But anyone who saw her win the $25,000added New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park today must be wondering if Chou Croute got an honest count.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Hungary, to the author of Budapest on a Shoestring (Travel section, Nov. 21), means nothing more than gypsy music and goulash. Yet, out of a population of barely 10 million, Hungary has produced many internationally known scientists, artists, Nobel Prize winners (Karmen, Teller, etc.), teachers, actors and writers. It has cities and cultural centers dating to the Roman Empire and universities where American students and postgraduates go to complete their education. Goulash, indeed!

title: JAMES D. M'CALLUN, ENGLISH PROFESSOR
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 1Prof. James Dow McCallum, a member of the English department of Dartmouth College for 39 years and an author, died Thursday. His age was 78.

title: Emma Emory Plans Bridal
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 1Miss Emma Gray Emory plans to he married June 24 to Samuel Chase Coale 5th. She is a senior at Wheaton Colleeg in Norton, Mass., where he is an assistant professor.

title: At Half Time in Football, A Big and Costly Show
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 In 1869, when Rutgers defeated Princeton In the first college football game, reports do not indicate what happened between halves of the game. Probably there was a lot of gasping for breath. But there is a record of the first college football cheer: Siss Boom Bah, Princeton!

title: Garcia Missed 5 Goal Tries In Earlier Stanford Loss
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI)I wasn't real nervious but I was slightly nervious, said the Rose Bowl hero, Rod Garcia, with a grin.

title: Globies in Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (UPI)  The Harlem Globetrotters make two Bay area appearances this month. They play Saturday night, Jan. 22, at the Oakland Coliseum Arena and then in the Cow Palace here the following afternoon.

title: Quick, Bouncy Lion Defense Cracks Wishbone
description: DALLAS, Jan. IPenn State's quick and bouncy defense snapped the feared Wishbone of Texas today in the Cotton Bowl, and the way the Nittany Lions did it will become a classic study for theorists, experts and coaches.

title: Eastern College Coaches Back. Return of Summer Basketball
description: College Sports Notes;

title: Art
description: CERTAIN exhibitions are more interesting as episodes in the history of taste than as events in the history of art. For myself, the John Chamberlain show currently installed at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, is an exhibition of this sort. The work itself is not really substantial enough to fill the large quantity of space assigned to it. Diane Waldman, the museum's curator of exhibitions, has brought together nearly 80 sculptures and 10 paintings dating from 1957 to the present. This is four or five times the number of works needed to demonstrate the scope of Mr. Chamberlain's gifts. Indeed, there is something a little callous, or maybe just stupid, in treating this minor artist as if he were a major figure. One cannot help wondering what sort of artworld political machinations lie behind this inflated enterprise.

title: Jay on Controls
description: The Phase Two pried controts and other restrictions on American corporations, if firmly applied by the Nixon Administration, may result in a new growth of multinational corporatism Antony Jay, a British Management adviser, predicted here recently.

title: Police Reorganize Amid Confusion
description: A citywide reorganization of detective functions affecting 2,500 detectives and more than 22,000 uniformed men of the Police Department began yesterday with widespread confusion over assignments, procedures, paperwork and the transfer of men, files and furniture.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I AM extremely disturbed by the recurrence of artists excremental vision on the movie screen. If modernday life has not pushed us beyond the bounds of human despair, then filmmakers like Mike Nichols, Ken Russell and now Stanley Kubrick (A Clockwork Orange) will do the job. For what end? It is no news to us to be shown the rot and the filth and the corruption. We have that before us every day. It is in the newspapers, on the streets, the TV screen. Repeated exposure to scenes of violence and atrocity seem to be dulling our senses, our sensitivity to these things, not heightening them. Are these illustrious filmmakers out to create monsters in the audience as vicious as those on screen so that by some kind of selffulfilling prophecy they can point and say, Look, see how realistic my film was? Who says people are not that bad?

title: SOVIET GAIN SEEN IN SATELLITE TEST
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. (AP)  On Dec. 3 the Soviet satellite Cosmos 462 was launched from the Tyuratam rocket base. Within hours it zipped close to Cosmos 459, launched four days earlier, and exploded into 13 pieces. Both satellites were destroyed 150 miles above the earth.

title: Paul C. Katz to Marry Miss Betsy Schreiber
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Schreiber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Louise Schreiber, to Paul C. Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Katz of Chicago. A June wedding is planned.

title: Study Finds Black Market Developing in Methadone
description: The drug methadone, which is gaining popularity as a clinically administered alternative to heroin, is gradually joining heroin and other drugs on the streets of urban America as a blackmarket commodity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After our Government's shabby behavior in the PakistanIndiaBangladesh affair, it is imperative that it extend diplomatic recognition to Bangladesh and begin a program of relief and rehabilitation for that strifetorn land. Failure to do so would be morally insensitive and politically stupid.

title: HISPANIC SERVICE ENDS AT RIVERSIDE
description: Riverside Church has discontinued its 12yearold ministry to a small group of Spanishspeaking churchgoers in favor of a broader service to the Hispanic community largely outside the walls of the church.

title: EyeballtoEyeball Talks Help Speed Transit Pact
description: Eyeballtoeyeball negotiation between Dr. William J. Ronan and Matthew Guinan in a private suite instead of the traditional committee confrontation was a key factor in the unexpectedly early agreement yesterday on a, new transit contract.

title: Dreamers of Decadence Symbolist Painters of the 1890's. By Philippe Julian. Translated by Robert Baldick. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Praeger Publishers. $12.50.
description: Looking upon the 19th century from the vantage point of European art and literature, one is put in mind of Freud's dictum that no mortal can keep a secret. The century began out of doors with poets trumpeting their innocence after the fashion set by Rousseau; it drew to a close halfway toward the couch, in rooms filled with chimerical bricabrac where the Decadents sedulously cultivated evil. Rousseau's boast that, were his head made of glass, he would feel no shame in walking about publicly sounded increasingly remoteenviable yet hollowas the century wore on. The glass darkened, and the head admitted its fantasies.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE MARTIN REPORT on the securities markets was attacked by a group of 19 prominent economists led by James It. Lorie of the University of Chicago and including Milton Friedman and Paul A. Samuelson. They said acceptance of the recommendations would help to reestablish the eroding monopoly power of the New York Stock Exchange and urged Congressional leaders to oppose the report... A highlevel committee of the Big Board urged adoption Of. one of the Martin recommendations: reorganization of the exchange's governing board to give the public a greater voice management.

title: FRAZIER GETS 41 IN KNICKS VICTORY
description: With Walt Frazier scoring 29 of his 41 points in the second half and Dave DeBusschere and Jerry. Lucas tossing in a few timely longrange baskets, the New York Knicks started the new year properly enough by beating the Cincinnati Royals, 10494, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Times to Produce Microfilm Of Times of London's Files
description: The New York Times Company has acquired the exclusive rights to produce and distribute The Times of London on microfilm in the United States and Canada and will start doing so in July.

title: U.S. Now Big Landlord In Decaying Inner City
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1A new and ominous chapter has opened in the decline of the central cities: The Federal Government has begun to come into ownership or control of a large portion of faltering or abandoned innercity housing.

title: Muskie to Get Aide
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 (AP)Anthony J. May, 29 years old, press secretary to Gov. Milton J. Shapp, will resign to work for the Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, it was reported Thursday.

title: The Last Word: Call It Oral History
description: On May 18, 1948, a cool, drizzly day in Manhattan according to. The Times, two mena newspaperman who had turned college professor in middle life and a graduate student in historyarmed with pencil, notebook, and a stock of leading questions, invaded the East Side living room of a banker named George McAneny. For several hours Prof. Allan Nevins tactfully led the elderly gentleman through his memories of the construction New York subways while. young Dean Albertson took notes.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Poor Jerome Chodorov! But if he thinks he had trouble at the Columbia 1, listen to this. My wife and and two friends waited on line on a cold Saturday afternoon for 40 minutes to catch the 5:30 offering of The Last Picture Show.

title: The Bowl Games
description: ORANGENebraska, sparked by a 77yard punt return by Johnny Rodgers and the aggressive defensive play of Rich Glover, reaffirmed its claim to the mythical national championship by overwhelming Alabama, 386, before a orowd of 78,151 at Miami.

title: Shelter Island Race Is Finally Decided
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.Thomas L. Jernick, the Republican candidate for Town Supervisor of Shelter Island, has been declared the winner over the Democratic nominee, Louis H. Price.

title: Safetyman Dazed
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP)The Texas defensive safety, Mike Bayer, was dazed and wandering around in a semiconscious fog when Penn State made two key passes that helped it win Cotton Bowl game, Coach Darrell Royal of Texas said today.

title: Maryland Adopts New Traffic Signs Based on Symbols
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 1 (AP) Maryland adopted a new system of international road signs today based on symbols rather than words.

title: For the Rich, Acapulco Isn't What It Used to Be
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico A tanned young man grabbed his girl friend and jumped into the pool at the Villa Vera the other day, gaily knifing through a thin layer of sewn floating on the water's surface.

title: A Jailed Crusader Loses Hope in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, tan. 1Gai had hoped that in 1971 a small, desperate student movement could change South Vietnam. It changed nothing, so Gai a 23yearold University of Saigon graduate, stopped believing that she could do anything about a country that, she felt, urgently needed so much.

title: Australia, Now Out of the War, Assesses Her Role in Vietnam
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 1With the Australian combat role in South Vietnam now at an end, this Southwest Pacific country is reassessing her controversial involvement in Asia. The intimate association of Australia with United States foreign policy, not only in Vietnam but in China and elsewhere, is one aspect of the commitment being questioned.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The candidacy of Representative John M. Ashbrook as a superconservative challenger to President Nixon's renomination probably does not mean that Mr. Nixon will have serious trouble at the Republican convention in San Diego. It is further evidence, nevertheless, that the present twoparty arrangement is less and less adequate to American political developments.

title: Platypus: Births Indicated
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP)Two platypuses are believed to have been hatched at Sydney's Targona Zoo. It would be the second time a platypus has bred in captivity. A zoo spokesman said it would be three weeks before the births could be confirmed.

title: >ORANGE BOWL ROUT
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1Exploding for three touchdowns in a fourminute burst during the first half, Nebraska crushed Alabama, 386, in the Orange Bowl tonight and confirmed its place as college football's No. 1 team for a second consecutive year.The imposing Cornhuskers capitalized on a series of firsthalf errors and turnovers, by their Southeastern Conference rivals and a 77yard punt return by Johnny Rodgers to register their 23d straight victory and 32d without a loss.

title: Bowdoin Defeats Princeton, In Hockey Tourney, 6 to 5
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 1  Bowdoin College defeated Princeton, 43, and Dalhousie University of Halifax, Nova Scotia, edged Air Force Academy, 65, in overtime tonight in openinground games of the ROWdoin Holiday Hockey Tournament.

title: 10 Former Giant Baseball Stars To Be Cited Hereby Sports Unit
description: Ten of the most illustrious players in the long and successful baseball history of the New York Giants will be reunited on Saturday, Jan. 22, when the group is honored by the B'Nai B'Rith Sports Lodge.

title: A Hill of Garbage Just Grew
description: When he moved to Astoria, Queens, in 1945, Benjamin Barbere recalls, he could gaze several blocks to the north and see the East River from his home.

title: Reader's Report
description: I can remember when the only defacement on the Columbia campus was the ,letter Y some daredevil had chiseled high up on the Barnard College lintel, between Barn and ard. Such wishful thinking! Barnard girls in those days were from devoutly square homes in New Rochelle; their mothers stayed awake until they came home from a date. If you wanted to meet a social revolutionary, you had to prospect over in Teachers College or 3ohnson Hall, where the women graduate students lived.

title: Most elegant
description: Named after the greatest of gastronomic writers, Jean An, thelme BrillatSavarin (17551826), this rich ruinsoaked Cake is worthy of its name. There is no more elegant dessert in the French repertory.

title: Mary Savage Is Affianced
description: ST, PAUL,Jan. 1Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Richard Savage of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Van Dusen Savage, to Franklin D'Olier Stowell, who is associated with the Johnson O'Connor Research Foundation, Inc., in New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stowell of Basking Ridge, N. J., and CornwallonHudson, N. Y.

title: Reader's Report
description: Look in the Yellow Pages for a plumber, and you will find an operative whose competence is established by uniform licensure. Look under Psychologists, and you will find a bewildering variety of qualifications beginning at ground zero. Since psychologists deal with an area of experience every bit as critical as plumbers, the way is open to defective repairs on the psyche, malpractice and personal mischief, some of which is cataloguedin Anne Richter's fascinating book.

title: Miss Tuero Tennis Victor
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Jan. 1 (AP)  Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., defeated Sharon Walsh of San Rafael, Calif., 61, 62, today for the women's singles title at the Free State Sugar tennis championships.

title: State's Panel on City Names New Head
description: Stephen Berger, a tough young politician with ties to the Reform Democrats, was appointed yesterday to head the staff of the state commission investigating New York City government.

title: Miss Marra Engaged To School Principal
description: Miss Margaret Marie Marra plans to be married in July to Lowell James Crandall Jr., principal of the Jackson Miles School in Troy, Mich.

title: Multinational Quandary
description: PARIS  You're the chief financial officer for Europe of one of those behemoths straddling several continents and employing hundreds of thousands of workers.

title: Long Island's 16 Colleges and Universities Plan to Pool Efforts
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Jan. The 16 public and private colleges and universities on Long Island have united in major cooperative effort that they hope will eventually lead to a common pooling of energies in every field of education, from curriculum through scientific research to construction programs.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 1All American things to do in 1972

title: Number of Policemen Dismissed Rose to 59 Here During 1971
description: Far more New York policemen were dismissed or suspended on charges of serious misconduct in 1971 than in 1970, according to the Police Department. The increase occurred despite a small decline in the number of policemen.

title: Chaffee Heads NineMan U.S. Alpine Squad Named forWorld Cup Events
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 1A nineman squad that will represent the United States in the men's World Cup Alpine competition that resumes at Berchtesgarden, West Germany, next Sunday was chosen today. Seven of the athletes eventually will make the Olympic squad when the international winter classic is staged in Japan next month.

title: Horticulture Where Is It Going?
description: MANY TIMES I have been asked to look into the future and project what the job potential will be for students who are interested in the field of horticulture. Many contacts with prominent people in the profession have given me some firm footing to make a projection of these opportunities.

title: Bonaventura Kenny Is Fiancee Of Bruce Cooper, Bank Officer
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 1The engagement of Miss Bonaventura Elizabeth Kenny to Bruce Dow Fuller Cooper has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. H. James Kenny Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald W. A. Cooper of New York.

title: John Klein Takes Over In Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.His postelection suntan having faded, the man who is now the County Executive Suffolk talked in scanty terms of the spoils of his elec. tion victory.

title: WORLD SHIFT SEEN BY FREEDOM HOUSE
description: An evaluation by an American organization on the state of freedom around the world has concluded that 1971 was a year in which the superpowers began to stir out of positions they had occupied for a generation.

title: Field of 64 Will Compete In Tennis Qualifying Event
description: Vern Morgan is among leading players in this area who will compete in a qualifying tournament for the Clean Air Classic beginning Jan. 15 at the armory on 145th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Home Improvement
description: TO provide flexible and instantly available lighting over workbenches and counters which have perforated hardboard (Pegboard is the best known brand) on the wall above them, a new lighting fixture has been recently introduced that needs no special mounting. As illustrated in the accompanying photograph, the fixture has hooks on its base plate that fit right into the standard holes or perforations in the hardboard. Thus, the fixture can not only be mounted or hung simply by slipping its hooks into the holes, it also can he quickly moved from one location to another (or raised or lowered) when desirable. After insertion, a slight downward pressure locks it securely in place.

title: The Stewardesses'
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1Darlene Fuentes has jumped out of airplanes, put out fires and earned the nickname Iron Butterfly in her job as hostess training manager for Continental Airlines.

title: Books:
description: If you buy this book by the page or by the pound, it probably is a bargain. In fact, the book has been compiled in sections numbered individually so the exact, number of pages is impossible to determine without counting.

title: Muslc
description: AS ONE of music's avantgarde centers, the State University of New York at Buffalo is likely to turn up some strange and wonderful items. The latest is a totalenvironment work called Rage Over a Lost Beethoven, and the title accurately reflects the subject matter. It lasts about an hour and will be given four times in the sculpture court of the AlbrightKnox Gallery, at 8 and 10 P.M. on Feb. 19 and 20. The performances will be dedicated to the gallery's 110th anniversary.

title: Shabel to Direct Directors
description: Fred Shabel, director of the division of recreation and intercollegiate athletics at the University of Pennsylvania, will assume the duties of chairman of the Ivy League athletic directors association at the 66th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association convention, Thursday through Saturday, in Hollywood, Fla.

title: Martha Miller To Wed in June
description: KINNELON, N. J., Jan., 1Miss Martha DeCraw Miller and Mark Christopher Riley will be married June 17.

title: North Shore Hospital Forms Heart Institute
description: MANHASSET, L.I.  An institute to combat heart disease has been formed by North Shore Hospital.

title: Do You Mind Critics Calling You Cheap, Decadent, Sensationalistic, Gimmicky, Vulgar, Overinflated, Megalomaniacal? I Don't Read Reviews Very Much, Answers Tom O'Horgan
description: WHEN Tom O'Horgan's production of Jesus Christ Superstar opened on Broadway at the Mark Hellinger Theatre last October, the high and the mighty of New York theater criticism suffered what might be described as a collective fit. Their highvoltage invectives, hurled primarily at O'Horgan's direction and concept, all but charred the pages they were printed on.

title: NEW MEXICO DROPS BUFFALO PROJECT
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Jan,, 1The New Mexico Department of Game and Fish announced here this week, that it had abandoned plans to establish a huntable herd of buffalo in the state and that lit would sell most of the animals during the next two months.

title: MARXIST VOW IS SET FOR CZECH TEACHERS
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  Czechoslovak teachers at all levels and in all branches of education will be required from now on to take a solemn oath of faithfulness to MarxistLeninist ideals, the Education Ministry's weekly, Ucitelske Noviny, has disclosed.

title: HIPPIES FIND INDIA IS NOT SO GROOVY
description: BOMBAY, India  While they still come to India looking for love and searching for spirituality, there are fewer American and European hippies here today than there were two years ago.

title: SOVIET SKATERS TROUNCE U.S., 111
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Ian. 1 (AP)The Soviet Union blitzed the United States National hockey team with seven goals in the first period. and wound: up with another lop sided victory, 111, tonight in a secondround World Cup hockey match.

title: RULING AIDS FIGHT FOR HANDICAPPED
description: Charges that the Board of Education had failed to provide adequate educational facilities for braininjured children have become the center of a complex legal fight in both state and Federal courts here.

title: Canadians List Contraband
description: GRAND BANK, Newfoundland, Jan. 1 (AP)The Royal Canadian Mounted Police has reported that during 1971 it seized $20,000 worth of liquor and other contraband coming from the French islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, off southern Newfoundland.

title: Pacts on A.F.C. Game
description: ParticipantsEastern champion Miami Dolphins (10.31) and Easttern runnersup Baltimore Colts (10.4).

title: WALLACE REPORTED TO PLAN ON 4 RACES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was, reported today to be planning to enter at least four Democratic Presidential primaries next year.

title: Fire Department Will Add 37 Tower Ladders in 1972
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery announced yesterday that in 1972 the department would add 37 tower ladders, known as cherry pickers, to bring to 50 the total in the city.

title: A BRAZILIAN STAR ENDURES CENSORS
description: RIO JANEIRO, Jan. 1 (AP)They censor his songs. They've even pulled his records out of stores. But Chico Buarque de Hollanda, a star in Brazilian music, says he'll keep composing and singing there despite pressures from the militaryrun Government.

title: Ski Injuries, and How to Avoid Being a PlasterCasted Dropout
description: GLIDING along very nicely, gracefully, swallowing the clean cold air. A sense of abandon, and achievement as well. And what lovely country this is: tall spruces, vista of valley. Suddenly, one ski tip hooks under a mound of deep unpacked snow. A certain confusion results (and lack of finesse), ending with snow on the cheek and ear, pain somewhere below the knee. Oh my God!

title: The World
description: LONDONThe present troubles in Northern Ireland started in August, 1969. Since then, 206 persons have been killed in the terrorism or the efforts to counter it. More than twothirds of those deaths, 143, have occurred in the last five months, or since the policy of internment without trial began on Aug. 9.

title: The Maharajas of India Now Just Plain Misters
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 (Reuters)  India's maharajas passed into history today, deprived of their titles, privileges and taxfree privy purses by Government legislation.

title: Informer Says He Was Part of Coast Plot to Kill Cesar Chavez
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1Despite the disclaimers of Federal officials, an unemployed laborer who describes himself, as a paid police informer insists that certain farmers in the San Joaquin Valley of California ordered the assassination of Cesar Chavez, the farm union leader.

title: 150MILLION PACT AVERTS WALKOUT ON TRANSIT LINES
description: A new transit labor agreement costing an estimated total of $150million averted bus and subway strike in the city yesterday, but an early fare increase of at least 5 cents is certain.

title: Priest Quits to Marry
description: TULSA, Okla., Jan. 1 (AP)The Rev. Bernard T. Flynn, headmaster of Cascia Hall preparatory school, has resigned his post and announced plans to many a Chicago woman on Tuesday. Father Flynn, 43 years old, also said he was renouncing his membership in the Order of St. Augustine after two years of study and consultations with professional counselors.

title: Out of the Wilderness
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1It is no secret that soccer is the fastestgrowing college sport, but this week's National Collegiate A.A. games in the Orange BOwl did reveal something new about the sport: the caliber of play is rising along with the number of participants.

title: CHINA ANNOUNCES ECONOMIC GAINS
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 1Yearend reports released in Peking yesterday depicted soaring economic growth in China for 1971 and announce a gain of about 10 per cent in the value of industrial and agricultural output.

title: Tunney Appointed to Post
description: DEL MAR, Calif. (UPI)Peter W. Tunney has been appointed racing secretary at the Del Mar Thoroughbred Club, moving up from assistant racing secretary. Louis H. Silken and Frank E. Kilroe were named to share the post of director of racing.

title: Egypt Opens Libyan Bus Link
description: CAIRO, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Bus service on a new coastal highway linking Egypt with Libya starts operating this weekend. There will be three trips weekly in each direction on this new route.

title: On His Sins of Omission
description: I have very little communication with other writers. Nothing like the heart to heart talks I have had with painters throughout the years. I am writing this to find out if other writers are plagued with the same torment as I am.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: While grouse shooting in 1970 on Lord Thurso's holdings in Caithness County, Scotland, I noticed tracks leading over the moors and learned that they had been made by carts bringing back the stags that hunters shoot in the fall.

title: Britain Plans to Spend Billions to Clean Up Rivers
description: LONDON, Jan. 1  About $1.8million for a mile of pure river waterthat is the cost of cleaning up Britain's fouled waterways.

title: A Church Is Threatened With Prosecution Over Sex Education
description: BROOKFIELD, Wis., Jan. 1A Unitarian church in this Milwaukee suburb has been threatened with criminal prosecution because of the explicit nature of a sex education course that, has not yet started.

title: Kathleen McGamvon Is Bride Of Peter Jenkins,Regis Student
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn Jan. 1Miss Kathleen McGannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. McGannon, was married here today to Peter J. Jenkins son of Mr. and Mrs., Peter Jenkins of NeedhaM, Mass. A nuptial mass performed by Msgr. Francis X. McGuire in the private chapel of the Holy Ghost Retreat House was followed by a.Roman Catholic ceremony at the McGannon home, performed by the Rev. Thomas Birmingham.

title: Larry Barretto, 81, a Novelist And ExCorrespondent, Dead
description: CARMEL Calif. Jan, 1 (AP) Larry Barretto, novelist and former war correspondent, died Thusday at the age of 81.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Modesty Blaise's real name is Superwoman. She can handle, easily, two killer thugs in a dirty fight. She is an expert in singlestick, karate, savate and kongo, and she has a punch that would jar Muhammed Ali. She flies a plane; she likes oldfashioned sex; she has the yogalike ability to control her breathing so that she can induce unconsciousness in herself. She also is a Good Girl, automatically on the side of the angels.

title: Westinghouse Is Setting Up Complaint Suggestion Unit
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 1 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which makes appliances, said this week that it was establishing a department to record and analyze consumer complaints and sugbestions about product features, reliability, serviceability and style.

title: Bridge What does your opening lead tell partner?
description: PICKING the best opening lead is usually a matter of choosing the right suit. The question of which card to lead once the suit has been determined was apparently settled 40 years ago when the authorities of that period published tables of opening leads based on the customs that prevailed in auction bridge.

title: WEST HAM VICTOR IN SOCCER, 3 TO 0
description: LONDON, Jan, 1 (Reuters)Manchester United's lead at the top of the First Division of the English Football League was cut to 2 points today when they lost to West Ham United, 30.

title: Local Control Delayed at Bronx Center
description: The implementation of community control of the Martin Luther, King Health Center in the South Bronx has been delayed, according to the fiat of Economic Opportunity, because of a dispute between black, and Puerto Rican board membera of antipoverty programs.

title: A Landscape Architect's Outlook for the Seventies
description: SUBURBIA was formed by people from the country and the city in the 1930's and 1940's. The homeowner worked six days a week, had limited funds and no time or inclination to do anything with his land other than plant grass. His children had plenty of space to play in the wooded area around his house.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Sprots of The Times;

title: Lafayette's Five to Oppose Seton Hall and La Salle
description: Lafayette's basketball team will play its fourth and fifth straight road games this week when the Leopards visit Seton Hall in South Orange, N.J. Wednesday and play La Salle at the Palestra in Philadelphia Saturday.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1In normal years, we celebrate the first New Year's baby after midnight but in election years in America we note the arrival: of the first Presidential candidate. Pray silence, then for Big Ed Muskle of Maine, newest candidate of the New Year.

title: Cruise Director On the Titanic
description: Cruise Director On the TitanicSo, what sort of propaganda about the United States are the Commie ratfinks of the Kremlin dishing out these days to the Russian people? Perhaps only Richard Helms and Harry Schwartz know in detail, but it has lately been stated in Moscow by Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, that the wellknown American journalist Art Buchwald turns out his satirical columns about the Nixon Administration under instructions from the Federal Government, as a deliberate safety valve to reduce the impact of such New York Times photograph by GEORGE TAMES developments as Negro and student riots. In short, Pravda was suggesting that Buchwald is in the pay of the White House, which should certainly come as news to President Nixon, who is known to have been exceedingly annoyed by several of the satirically barbed columns that Buchwald has written about him. Says Buchwald of the charge that he's secretly on the Government payroll, TrueI'm an agent of the C.I.A. And every third word in my columns is part of a coded message to one of my fellow agents in Moscow.

title: Tomatoes The Best of the Bunch
description: A PRINCIPAL pleasure for the home gardener during the dreary winter months is planning what to grow the following summer. After the seed catalogues have arrived, he spends many happy hours reading through them selecting the varieties that look most appealing. Only someone with a large garden, however, can grow many varieties of a single vegetable to find the ones most suitable for him. This is especially a problem with the tomato. More than 300 varieties are currently available.

title: Cahill Proposes Jersey Take Over Camp Kilmer Site
description: TRENTON, Jan. 1Gov. William T. Cahill wants to take over Camp Kilmer for development of moderate income housing industry and health and educational facilities.

title: Linda Little Is Betrothed
description: CLARKS GREEN, Pa., Jan. 1Mr. and Mrs. Richard Little 3d gave a party at the Scranton Country Club on Wednesday to formally announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Jean Little, to Alfred Stabel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stabel of Vienna.

title: Tunisian Attached to U.N. Killed in HeadOn Car Crash
description: A 30yearold secretary with the Tunisian delegation to the United Nations was killed early yesterday when his car was hit head on by an automobile that jumped a divider on the Major Deegan Expressway near East 233d Street in the Bronx.

title: PROMOTERS SEEK JAI ALAI FRONTONS
description: With offtrack betting on the horses a fact of life in New York, can jai alai be far behind? Jai alai (pronounced high lie) is an ancient form of handball admirably suited to mass wagering, a percentage of which can be skimmed off as government revenue.

title: Three Rare Breeds on View Next Weekend
description: Of the 116 breeds eligible to compete for American Kennel Club championships, the field spaniel has the dubious honor of being tied for last place with the English foxhound, each with two registrants. At No. 113 is the Sussex spaniel, with four, and a notch higher, the Welsh

title: MRS. BARNEY BALABAN
description: Mrs. Tillie Urkov Balaban, widow of Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, died last night at New York University Hospital after a long illness. Her husband headed Paramount from 1936 until his retirement in 1964.

title: the traveler's world
description: THIS is not a matter over which Bess Myerson, the consumer's friend, should get all worked up but, rather, a point of information for those who have found in traveling around the country that their coffee or tea tasted sweeter in one place than in anothereven though they used the same number of packets of sugar per cup.

title: Kimberly Style Without Gimmicks
description: A Kimberly fashion show Is as unpretentious as the clothes. No eyeboggling accessories. No mood music or tricky lighting. The company just puts up few extra chairs in its showroom, calls in a few models and has them circle the room, likely as not in their own shoes.

title: Hunter Picks Mat Captains
description: Hector Negron, a senior from Brooklyn, andJohn Andosca, a junior from Southampton, L. I., have been named Hunter's wrestling captains for the 197172 season. Negron led the Hawks in points a year ago. Andosca competed for two years at Queensboro Community College before entering Hunter last fall.

title: White House Discounts Bid by Ashbrook
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The decision of Representative John M. Ashbrook, the conservative Republican from Ohio, to challenge President Nixon in the New Hampshire primary surprised and perturbed White House political strategists. But their inclination for the present is to ignore the challenge and hope it will go away. Ashbrook is hardly a household word, said one Nixon adviser. He's nuisance and a bother more than anything else.

title: Victoria King Neumann Engaged
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 1The engagement of Miss Vivtoria King Neumann to Paul Lacoste Maddock Jr. son of Mrs. Allison F. Fleitas and Paul L Maddock both of Palm Beach, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles P. Neumann. A wedding in June is planned.

title: The New Year
description: And now a new year, as we say in calendar terms, has begun. An old year is completed, put away with the archives. So run the records.

title: Food for Madagascar
description: ROME, Jan. 1 (AP)The United Nations World Food Program has announced that it will provide $137,000 worth of. food over three years to 1,270 families settling virgin land in the westcentral part of Madagascar.

title: Ox Ridge Club Will Stage Two 2Day Winter Shows
description: A change in the pattern of its winter show series will be instituted by the Ox Ridge Hunt Club this year.

title: ARKANSAS STUDIES CRIME FUNDS USE
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 1Your present and former state officials are under investigation regarding their ownership of stock in a Texas consulting company that received about $600,000 in contracts with state agencies the last two and half years.

title: Going home with bitterness and joy
description: In his latest book, Albert Murray employs a style that allows for the fruitful marriage of instinct and intellect. In South to a Very Old Place, he is dealing with an experience that can only be impoverished if one is rejected for the otherthe experience of going home. On this journey, Murray proposes to rediscover not just the history of black America, but the meaning of that historythe true meaning of the involvement of blacks and whites in the United States that lies beneath the facts, of their surface relationship. Using the resources of the intellect and the emotions, he is able to probe deeper and render that experience as both concept and image.

title: BRONX BOARD BACKS HOME FOR TRUANTS
description: Members of Community Board 9 in the Bronx have voted unanimously to allow home for chronic truant and runaway boys to open in their neighborhood.

title: New Owners Take Over Spectrum in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) A courtapproved plan for the transfer of ownership of the Spectruma sports arena here went into effect yesterday, according to a spokesman for the Philadelphia Flyers hockey team.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In regard to your Dec. 23 editorial, The New Secretary General, it is significant to have President Nixon join Pope Paul In the hope that 1972 will be a time when world peace will be greatly advanced. We also hope this will be true. But it is not likely to happen if the United States continues to take a unilateral position in world affairs. The missing element in President Nixon's peacemaking is the realistic use of the United Nations.

title: Marcos Frees 473 Convicts
description: MANILA, Jan. 1 (UPI) President Ferdinand E. Marcos pardoned 192 convicts yesterday, bringing to 473 the number of prisoners given clemency during the holiday season.

title: U.S., Spain Gain Final In Sunshine Cup Tennis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 1 (AP)The United States upset top seeded Italy, 21, and Spain beat South Africa, 20, in the semifinal of the Sunshine Cup, international junior tennis tournament today.

title: Transit Fare Situation,
description: The 30cent fare on the city's subways and buses will be increased this week to at least 35 cents and possibly as high as 45 cents as a result of the new transit contract.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The criticisms of the Fielding travel books in Guidebooks as Christmas Presents (Travel section, Dec. 12) were valid, but Herbert R. Lottman's failure to mention the real value of Fielding's Travel Guide to Europe was a disservice. His descriptions of hotels and restaurants are absolutely authentic. He has an uncanny way of pinpointing the personality of these accommodations. never travel to Europe without taking Fielding and my wife (in that order).

title: ROSEWALL GAINS IN AUSSIE TENNIS
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1  Ken Rosewall, the defending champion, breezed, into the semifinals of the Australian open tennis championships today with a 63, 61, 6.3 victory over Dick Crealy.

title: Governor Holding Fiscal Talks Today
description: Governor Rockefeller scheduled a meeting with the four top leaders of the Legislature for today to try to rebuild a coalition of bipartisan support for his battered emergency fiscal program.

title: DEADLINE EXTENDED ON CON ED PROJECT
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Jan. 1The city council here voted late Thursday to extend for another five years the deadline by which the Consolidated Edison Company must apply to the Atomic Energy Commission for a license to build nuclear power plants on David's Island: in Long Island Sound.

title: Child for O'Shaughnessys
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 1A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. William O'Shaughnessy on Dec. 23 at the New Rochelle Hospital and Medical Center. The child has been named Kate Wharton. Mrs. O'Shaughnessy is the former Ann Wharton Thayer, daughter of Walter N. Thayer of Rye, director of publication of The International Herald Tribune, and Mrs. Jane Wharton Sockwell of Greensboro, N. C. Mr. O'Shaughnessy is president and treasurer of HudsonWestchester Radio, Inc.

title: Bowling Begin Tomorrow
description: The $100,000 United States Open, sponsored by the Bowling Proprietors Association of America, will begin tomorrow at Madison Square Garden with the first of three eightgame qualifying rounds. Another 32 games will follow, with the field reduced three times before five finalists are determined for Saturday's televised final.

title: Man Taken From Jet For Hijacking Threat
description: OMAHA, Jan. 1 (UPI) A United Air Lines passenger plane made an unscheduled landing tonight to allow the authorities to remove an unarmed man who threatened to hijack the plane to Cuba if he was not served unlimited liquor.

title: Sharp Rise in Immigration Expected by Israel in 72
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 1  An exhilarating but quite unexpected challenge Is confronting Israel in 1972: the absorption of a great stream of new immigrants in numbers expected to be comparable to the new arrivals in the heady first years of statehood beginning in 1948.

title: Jesuit Institute Seeks a More Inspirational Liturgy
description: Resplendent in what looked like the remnant of an orange and blue striped awning, the Rev. Robert Nagy danced to frenzied strains from the sound track of Black Orpheus while members of his class, garbed in wrapping paper, whimpered and groaned under the dimmed lights, pleading for help.

title: Beame says City Did Not Collect Shea Stadium ParkingLot Tax
description: The city, which operates the parking lot at Shea Stadium, is failing to collect its own per cent parking tax there, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: Soviet Hockey Team Here Thursday
description: The Soviet Union's national hockey team, whose dazzling, intricate maneuVers, give it the appearance of a set of chess pieces on ice makes its first Madison Square.Garden appearance next Thursday, opposing the United States national squad.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Fielding gives the reader flavor and inspiration far surpassing Frommer's Europe on $5 a Day. Often on winter evenings I have reread Fielding's descriptions to recapture pleasant memories. After all, when one goes on vacation one sometimes wishes to experience excellence after a year of frugality in ??rder to get there.

title: 22 Are Presented at 50th Assembly Ball
description: Twentytwo young women were presented at the 50th Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball in the Grand Ballroom at the WaldorfAstoria last night. Mrs. Robert Stith Williams Jr. is chairman for the dinner dance which was founded by her mother, the late Mrs. Thomas Webster Edgar.

title: Flyers Tie Blues, 44
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 (AP) Rick Foley scored with 51 seconds left to, give the Philadelphia Flyers a 44 tie with the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your editorial of Dec. 23 you discuss the exemption of the wages of the working poor from wage restraints during economic stabilization. This exemption, written into the recently enacted economic stabilization legislation, was based on a bill, H.R. 11406, which I introduced. This exemption provides that:

title: Xavier Defeats Yale
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 (AP)Jerry Helmers scored 20 points six coming in a. late Xavier (Ohio) flurryto pace the hotstrooting Musketeers over Yale, 7569 today in college basketball action.

title: Fighter Pilots in Idaho Are Confident and Impatient as They Fl F111F's
description: MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, IdahoThe men of single combat in the skiesthe fighter plane pilotswait here impatiently, tending the giant birds of war that the Department of Defense has given them to fly.

title: You Don't Have to Be 80 to Join The Trike Craze But It Helps
description: WHEN an 80yearold housewife goes shopping these days in the Mainlands, a 12,500home retirement community west of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., she is likely to climb aboard her trusty trike for the trip to the supermarket.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The General Federation of Women's Clubs has supported conservation and environmental protection measures for decades and will continue to support these activities. It appears, however, that th'ere may be danger in overemphasis on specific aspects of environmental concern that may have detrimental side effects on other equally vital environmental values as well as on critical social requirements.

title: New S.E.C. Role
description: A new kind of relationship is burgeoning between Wall Street and Washington and it may ultimately blossom into greater public confidence in the workings of the securities markets.

title: Landes and Grant Capture Eastern Junior Net Titles
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1Jim Landes and Mike Grant won Eastern junior indoor tennis titles yesterday in the finals at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: A Brave Display in Brooklyn of Peruvian Art
description: Even the implacable die! bard critics and historians who base most of their judg mental standards of art upon Western European tenets will have difficulty dislikihg the current exhibition of Peruvian colonial painting at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: CRISP, SUNNY DAY BUT FEW GO OUT
description: For the information of those who did pot make it to a door or window from their television sets yesterday, the first day of 1972 was crisp and sunny and a few people went out for strolls.

title: CHARLOTTE FRIEL, 42, C.B.S. RESEARCH AIDE
description: Charlotte Friel, manager of research and administration for the Columbia Broadcasting System corporate affairs staff, died, Friday in New York Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 15 Sheridan Square.

title: J. M. Hatch Will Wed Anne Caples
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 1 Mrs. Martin H, Caples of Princeton Junction has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Lloyd Caples, to James Morris Hatch,. a descendant of Samuel Morris, a founder of the Philadelphia City Troop.

title: WALDHEIM TO FILL TOP U.N. POSITIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 1The new Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim of Austria, faces a major job of staff reorganization as his first problem as he takes over the office from U Thant today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The college campuses across the country were silent this week as the seasonal wish of peace on earth was desecrated by our air force in Vietnam. Students were scattered far from their, schools for the Christmas vacation when they heard of the escalated attacks against North Vietnam. There was no chance of an outbreak which would threaten Washington's commuter traffic. Yet the injury inflictedon the student world by the 1971 Christmas bombing was greater, I am afraid, than any which need be feared from their demonstrations.

title: Ducks Defeat Devils, 65
description: COMMACK, L. I., Jan. 1 (AP) JeanMarie Nicol scored his 28th goal of the season midway in the third period, leading the Long Island Ducks to a 65 Eastern Hickey League victory over the Jersey Devils tonight.

title: BoatShow Parade Begins This Week
description: London will beat everybody to the mark when the first boat show of 1972 starts Tuesday for 12 days at Earl's Court. However, not far behind is San Francisco, which will lead this country's boatshow parade, starting Friday at the Cow Palace.

title: Lonely Sea Gate's Streets Still Belong to Its People
description: On the parking lot inside the entrance to Sea Gate, a boy, off a rocket and up it whooshes.

title: Pitcairn Island Politics Is a Game of the Name
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Jan. (UPI)Candidates surnamed Christian swept to victory in elections this week on Pitcairn Island. But considering the electorate on the tiny British possession, that might have been expected.

title: Dave.Anderson
description: Sports of The Times;

title: Dennison's Farewell: He Cajoles A Last Time
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.  It was the last time that he Would address Suffolk County as its leader, so when H. Lee Dennison made his farewell speech last week, he masterfully entertained and cajoled his listeners  as he had for the last 12 years as County Executive,

title: A Remote Alaska Town Travels by Snowmobile
description: BARROW, AlaskaYou're 500 miles from anywhere7that means. Fairbanks  and theie are no road connections at all. But watch out for the speedy traffic on the icepacked streets of this northernmost town in the United States.

title: New Mexico Celebrates
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Jan. 1The 60th anniversary of New Mexico's statehood will be observed at special functions throughout the State on Jan. 6.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  William D. Eberle, the President's energetic new chief. trade negotiator, was commenting wryly the other day about the problem of dealing with the European Common Market.

title: A Female Trotskyite Nominee Stumping in. Texas
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 1Sitting in a German restaurant sipping gin martini with two olives, Linda Jenness looked more like a suburban housewife having lunch in town than the candidate of the Socialist Workers party campaigning for President.

title: Mobutu Changes Name Of Katanga to Shaba
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu today announced new changes in wellknown place names in Zaire, the name he bestowed last October upon the Congo, former Belgian colony.

title: E. A. Powell Jr. Plans to Marry Mary Candler
description: GROSSE POINTS FARMS, Mich., Jan. 1The engage. ment of Miss Mary Edith Candler to Edward Angus Powell Jr. of the Naval Reserve has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Nall Candler, parents of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Powell of Richmond and a nephew of Lewis Powell, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Although guidebooks are often unreliable, something canand often doesswing the balance. For example, when I broke my dental plate during a transAtlantic crossing to Italy I telephoned an Englishspeaking dentist in Rome whose name I found in the Fielding book. In four hours the good dentist had the seven pieces back into one denture; the price was low and the work excellent. That one item made every travel book purchase worthwhile!

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS CITY JAR INQUIRY
description: A report by the State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction has renewed its call for an investigation of the city's Department of Correction.

title: East Germany, Czechoslovakia And Poland Drop Travel Curb
description: BERLIN, Jan. 1Beginning today, East Germans, Poles and Czechoslovaks will be able to travel freely, without visas or, special permits, in each other's countries.

title: 80 WOMEN PROS SET FOR TOURNEY
description: One of the largest fields in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf Association is assured for the fourth annual $30,000 Burdine's 54hole invitation golf tournament at the Doral Country Club in Miami Friday through Sunday.

title: Maurice Chevalier Dead; Singer and Actor Was 83
description: PARIS, Jan. 1Maurice Chevalier, probably the most popular and bestknown entertainer that France has produced this century, died here tonight. He was 83 years old.

title: The Nation
description: Starting tomorrow, the American consumer, who has long complained about his inability to influence government policy, will get a chance for a starring role in Phase II of President Nixon's economic program. Whether he will be ready, willing or even able to grasp the unique opportunity, however, is uncertain.

title: ALASKA AREA PICKED FOR PIPELINE ROUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The Interior Department has acted to block either the state of Alaska or the Alaskan natives from gaining control of the rightofway for a proposed $2billion oil pipeline.

title: Eager Exchange Scores
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1Continuing his perfect record since leaving New York, John D. Marsh's Eager Exchange captured the $28,700 Alleghany Stakes at Liberty Bell Race Track with a threequarterlength triumph over Rocky Reef.

title: The President in 1971
description: It has been a historic year for the United States and for President Nixon. In economic policy and relations. with China, Mr. Nixon has shown himself able to break away from his own past positions and let the facts prevail.

title: Movies
description: IT is no secret that being Black or Puerto Rican does not open doors in the movie world. However, things are looking up a bit, and perhaps the most encouraging development in recent years is the formation of a group called Third World Cinema Corp. This group, headed by Ossie Davis and Mrs. Hannah Weinstein, was founded last February for the purpose of increasing the number of opportunities for Blacks and Puerto Ricans on the movie scene, and now  in less than a year's time  comes word that 20th CenturyFox has agreed to distribute several films to be made by Third World.

title: Black SEEK Students Score Article
description: Six black students in the SEEK program of the City University denounced today the publication of an allegedly antiJewish article in The Voice of seek, the program's newspaper.

title: Music
description: MRS, DOROTHY RETALLACK of Denver grows plants to music at Temple Buell College. Experiments indicate that the plants respond favorably to Bach and to Ravi Shankar's classical Indian music. But when the plants hear acid rock, they cringe. They lean sharply away from the sound and die in a few weeks. Even their roots grow aslant, rejecting the music.

title: League Names Six Officials For Title A.F.C. Contest
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1 (AP)The six! officials for the American Football Conference championship game tomorrow between Miami and Baltimore were named today by the league.

title: Ear Protective Devices Ordered for Employes
description: Employers in noisy industries will have to provide personal ear protective equipment to every employe starting Feb. 1 under a new state industrial code rule on noise control, the State Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: On planning a recent camping trip to the West my husband and I decided it would be fun to go out via Ottawa and Sault Sainte Marie. We were surprised to find that Canadian customs made us surrender all our potatoes, onions and carrots and were dismayed when customs officials poured all but three bottles from our case of wine down the drain. Why wouldn't our neighbors to the north permit us to pay duty on the wines?

title: Rowing Yearbook Due
description: The 1972 Rowing Yearbook will be published March 1. It will contain international national and local rowing records for the 197071 Seasons with articles by experts and a complete listing of the major 1972 regattas.

title: Law Protects Projectionists
description: TRENTON, Jan. 1Gov. William T. Cahill has signed a bill that will protect professional movie projectionists from prosecution under state obscenity laws in the event a film they are showing in a theater is declared obscene. The bill followed public hearings last year by a special legislative pornography panel at which witnesses noted that projectionists had no control over the quality or type of film they show.

title: 26 Nassau Libraries Lending Cassettes
description: Patrons of 26 branches, of the Nassau Library System, may borrow cassette tape recordings on a variety of subjects of current or artistic interest.

title: Movies
description: THEY'RE curled up, curved against each other like a couple of shrimps, on a couch at the Pierre, Twiggy and Justin, and Twiggy, the chocolate fiend, is drinking hot chocolate with whipped cream, and eating a chocolate bar (if she ever got sick, they could probably cure her with transfusion of Hershey's syrup) and Justin's talking about the reviews of The Boy Friend.

title: Four Texas Players Are Selected To Magazine's 72 Honor Team
description: Four players from Texas and three from Louisiana led Parade Magazine's ninth annual allAmerican high school football team for 1971.

title: WALL STREET
description: What goes up And Own at the same time? One answer would seem to he closedend investment panies.

title: Medicine
description: The use of methadone to treat heroin addiction has grown dramatically over the last six yearsfrom a small New Yorkbased program with handful of patients to scores of programs in dozens of cities across the country. Yet methadone is still an ex perimental drug, still not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The reason: Strong public pressure to do something about heroin.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: It ought to be apparent even at this early date that in the performance of the Pay Board, and particularly in the pattern of individual decisions by its members, the basic cause of American inflation is becoming vividly illuminated, to wit: It appears that Big Labor and Big Management if not in outright cahoots with each other by design are at least sufficiently in sympathetic selfinterest to find, themselves naturally ganging up on the public (as long as it is willing to pay the higher price).

title: LIONS ROUT TEXAS ON 2DHALF SURGE Penn State 306 Victor in Cotton BowlRecovery of Fumbles Spurs Drive
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1Joe Paterno, Penn State's dynamic and optimistic football coach, was out of character all week as he expressed fears that the Texas Wishbone offense might blow us right out of the Cotton Bowl.

title: India Begins Returning Bengal Refugees
description: CHAUGACHA, Pakistan, Jan. 1Some 400 refugees arrived here today as India formally opened its mass repatriation program.

title: Colt Defense to Test Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1Against the backdrop of a fiery frontoffice feud, the Baltimore Colts will oppose the Miami Dolphins here tomorrow for the American Football Conference championship. The game in the Orange Bowl stadium will be televised in the New York area at 4:30 P.M. on Channel 4.

title: Wrote on Religion
description: Mr. Marvin was the author of The Faith I Found: A Layman Looks at Religion, published by Crowell in 1954. After his retirement he contributed.a column, A Thought for the Day for The Record papers. He had broadcast from radio station WFLY in Troy and had written several college songs and hymns.

title: The Nation
description: These pictures depict a mission typical of the kind U.S. planes carried out on North Vietnam and the Ho Chi Minh Trail supply complex last week. Clockwise from above: An Ainerican crew is briefed aboard a carrier in the Tonkin Gulf; 500pound bombs are loaded aboard an A6 fighterbomber; the plane is signaled for takeoff from the carrier deck; the target area is left scorched and pocked by craters. The objective of the trail bombing is to interdict Communist troops and supplies.

title: Home for the Blind Consolidates Services
description: The Industrial Home for the Blind has consolidated its services for Brooklyn and Queens children into a Children's Center at 57 Willoughby Street in Brooklyn.

title: SCHOLARSHIP WON BY SUSAN WIENER
description: Susan Hallie Wiener, a graduate student at Boston University whose home is in New York, has been awarded the 1971 Thomas Fleming Day scholarship by the National As sociation of Engine and Boat Manufacturers.

title: Medicine
description: The fastest growing innovation In American medicine today is the medical foundation. The probability seems high that before the 1970's are ended millions of Americans will look to such organizations  essentially, loose form of group practice  for their medical care. About 50 foundations are now functioning or being formed, a number that is expected to rise to 200 a year from now.

title: FOOD STAMP USE SET RECORD IN NOVEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) Despite a new record in enrollment in the food stamp program in November, total participation in food aid programs for needy families in that month remained below the peak reached last March, an Agriculture Department report showed today.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS AID THURMOND RALLY
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. Three Democratic State Senators have declared that they are not endorsing Senator Strom Thurmond, a Republican, for reelection even though they are among the sponsors of a massive nonpartisan rally for him here Feb. 21.

title: 10 That Deserved A Better Fate
description: AVERY few movies are great. A few more are so memorably dread ful that one remembers them after a while with affection, like serious injuries that have been successfully repaired. Instead of compiling a list of the year's dreadfuls,I'd like to recall some of the inbetween movies of the yearfilms that deserve something less than the complete oblivion in which they've so quickly fallen. All opened in the first seven months of 1971, which probably has as much to do with their absence from most 10best lists as does their mixed quality. Everybody forgets what opened last week, unless it was a smash hit or a spectacular flop.

title: Suharto Announces Release Of 20,000 Held Since'65
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. (Reuters)  President Suharto has announced the release of more than 20,000 prisoners held since an abortive coup in 1965.

title: Hotel Doomed, but Lindy's Room May Survive
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.The Garden City Hotel is decaying and standing empty in the middle of this village as it waits, demolition, but an effort is under way to rescue a part of it that has links to early aviation on Long Island.

title: Stamp
description: THE story is that Buddha had invited all the animals of the kingdom to a conference, but only 12 turned up to discuss the nature of things. As a result, according to the story, each of the 12 animals that showed up had a year named for It, so the 12year cycle was established. This year, 1972, is the year of the Rat.

title: Miss Janet C. Waterhouse Is Betrothed
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 1The engagement of Miss Janet Christine Waterhouse to Ronald S. Reich, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Joseph R. Waterhouse. The wedding will take place here on Feb. 26.

title: Black Photographers Work Displayed
description: The beauty of being black, especially that beauty found in the energy of children and in the dignity of the elderly, is the dominant theme of the photo exhibition being shown at the Queens Storefront Museum until Jan. 14.

title: Son to the Sommerfields
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Barrie Sommerfield of New York and Greenwich, Conn., on Dec. 12 at the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Sommerfield is the former Miss Faith Gimbel Solinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Solinger of New York and Greenwich. The child, whose father is a vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, has been named Peter.

title: T.W.U. and 5 Private Bus Lines Reach Pact Like One With City
description: The Transport Workers Union reached a settlement last night with five private bus lines in the city that was virtually identical to the 27month, 18 per cent wage increase agreed upon earlier with the Transit Authority.

title: Mrs. Nixon Starts 8Day Trip to Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1Mrs. Richard M. Nixon left tonight for an 8day, 10,000mile journey to Africa, the first visit of an American President's wife to that continent and Mrs. Nixon's second foreign assignment on her own.

title: Drug Prosecution Of Coast Lawyer Will Be Resumed
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Jan. 1The Marin County District Attorney's office plans to resume prosecution of Michael H. Metzger, former assistant district attorney of New York County, on narcotics charges.

title: 9 PIRATE ROOKIES INVITED TO CAMP
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have named nine nonroster players to train with the club next spring in Bradenton, Fla. Of the nine, seven played ,their first year of pro ball in 1971, while the other two began their baseball careers in 1970.

title: Theology Student ToWed Miss McKee
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 1Mr. and Mrs. James McKee have announced the engagement of their daughter; Miss Lucile Best McKee of New York, to William Clarkson 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarkson 3d of Corsicanna, Tex. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Quiet Life of Sihanouk's Daughter
description: PNOMPENH, CambodiaPrincess Bopha Devi, the 29yearold daughter of the exited Cambodian head of state Price Norodom Sihanouk, last danced three years ago when Princess Margaret of Great Britain visited here.

title: GROUP SAYS SYRIA PERSECUTES JEWS
description: PARIS, Jan. 1Syria is the only Middle East country still persecuting and harassing its Jewish minority and forbidding its emigration, according to a yearend survey by the American Jewish Committee of the situation of Jews in the Moslem world.

title: Child to Mrs. Abramowitz
description: A daughter was born to Capt. Marc A. Abramowitz, Chaplain Corps, U.S.A., and Mrs. Abramowitz of Far Rockaway, Queens, in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway. The. child, whose father is stationed in Vietnam, is named Dena Beth.

title: Illegal Parking Ruled Legal in Oregon Town
description: MILTONFREEWATER, Ore., Jan. 1 (AP)For years, the police in this eastern Oregon town have been ticketing cars parked at curbs painted yellow. And, for years, the owners of the ticketed cars have been paying the $2 fine without a murmur.

title: Hogarth His Life, Art and Tones. By Ronald Paulson. Illustrated. Vol. 1, 558 pp. Vol. II. 557 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $40.
description: Apart from a few uneasy excursions into the grandiose sublime history painting fashionable in his age, William Hogarth worked within rather small dimensions, as might be expected of an artist who learned his tradeand in doing so discovereu his geniusas an engraver on silver and a book illustrator. By contrast, Ronald Paulson of Johns Hopkins takes some 1,100 large pages to present his account of Hogarth's life and works and their relation to the social, moral and esthetic currents of his time. Happily, the discrepancy in scales allows few of the ironies about art and scholarship that come so easily, at least to artists.

title: Suit Attacks Prison Rule
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Jan. 1 (AP)A suit has been filed in United States District Court here challenging a federal prison rule barring inmates from sending letters to the news media or being interviewed by reporters. The suit was filed Monday by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., and the Illinois Division of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Professor Ordered Rehired In 1950 Loyalty Oath Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (AP)A college professor dismissed 21 years ago for refusing to sign a loyalty oath has been ordered reinstated by the California Supreme Court.

title: Why the Bombers Thundered
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Administration's decision to reactivate the air campaign against North Vietnam could well be the most serious escalation since the Gulf of Tonkin in May, 1964.

title: UNBEATEN RIVALS WILL FIGHT HERE
description: Three undefeated fighters, who are among the most exciting newcomers to boxing, will be seen in a trio of 10rounders that open the boxing year at Madison Square Garden on Friday.

title: Television
description: IT'S a new year, and it may seem like a good time lean back and concoct predictions about the next 12 months in television. But TV does not lend itself easily to the ponderings of sages. In fact, one the medium's more enduring charms is its insistent unpredictability.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The development of the European Communities has been economically favorable to both the United States and the E.C. Trade both ways has significantly expanded, though there has for a long time been a considerable deficit in the balance of trade on the European side. We have accepted this without liking it as part of what, for us, is one of our most important trade relationships.

title: Lynn B. Weigel Jr., a Student, To Marry Irene K. Malozemoff
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 1The engagement of Miss Irene Katherine Malozemoff to Lynn Burkhart Weigel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Weigel of Knoxville, Tenn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Plato Malozemoff, parents of the future bride.

title: The Nation
description: Following Orders What would most people do if ordered to shoot all the inhabitants of a Vietnamese village suspected of aiding the enemy, including old men, women and, children?

title: Computerized Murder
description: It's a new year for OTB, but the old problems are still unsettled.

title: MICHIGAN IS UPSET
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1In,a Rose Bowl game they'll be talking about for another 70 years, Stanford finally caught up with Michigan today for the 490 pasting it took in the 1902 contest, the first of this postseason football series.

title: Dartmouth Dean Named To Head A.A.A.S. in'73
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP)  Leonard M. Rieser, dean of the faculty at Dartmouth College, was named presidenteleot of the American Association for the Advancement of Science Thursday. He will head the organization in 1973.

title: Anne L. Kelly Plans Bridal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 1Miss Anne Leslie Kelly and John Richard Kelly have made plans to be married July 15. The future bride and her fiance were graduated last June from Syracuse University.

title: Lebanese Battle Fedayeen; Clash Is Worst in 2 Years
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 1Lebanese security forces and Palestinian guerrillas fought a pitched battle with machine guns here last night in the worst clash between them in almost two years.

title: No One Really Travels Now. We Are All Tourists.
description: UNTIL about 40 years ago there used to be a type called the traveler. He or she went offgenerally on their own or with a friend or someone called a guideto some very little known country where they saw extraordinary sights and perhaps suffered hardships. Yet they enjoyed it all and were interested in it all, and the only thing against it was that they probably quarreled with their companions.

title: The Nation
description: A few hours after 15 antiwar veterans moved with military precision to occupy the Statue of Liberty last Sunday, the superintendent at the monument presented himself at a barricaded doorway to discuss their demands, The veterans demanded to know what television networks had aftived.

title: Making beauty from racial anxiety
description: The gypsy cab moved rapidly through Harlem traffic. In the passenger seat, Gwendolyn Brooks, official Poet Laureate of the state of Illinois, now Distinguished Visiting Professor of the Arts at the City College of New York, and I debated the importance of the sonnet form to black literature and life. Suddenly the cab swerved to avoid a collision with another car, evoking a shout from the AfroAmerican driver: You old quat! Miss Brooks laughed, turned to me and noted, Now that's a great line, a great line!

title: When the Old World Came to Sea Gate
description: Before I came to this country, I had often read the memoirs of immigrants to the United States. The story they, told was almost always the same: they had smuggled themselves over the Russian frontier, waited for weeks or months in an immigrant shelter somewhere in Hamburg or Amsterdam, traveled steerage in a ship where the only kosher food was potatoes in their skins and briny herring and thewEllis Island and a shared room on Broome, Attorney or Orchard Streets.

title: New Dynamism in Home Building
description: Should a potential home buyer question why he is offered a town house 40 miles away from town, or a highrise apartment on the outer fringes of suburbia, the answer might shake him. It is that the land, like the Indian, is vanishing.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Bank Robbery Suspect Killed By Police in Escape Attempt
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Jan. 1A Pennsylvania man was shot to death by a policeman after allegedly attempting to rob the National Bank of North America at 928 Broadway here yesterday.

title: The Travel Bookshelf
description: NOW that the holiday hubbub has subsided and the new year has been dutifully ushered in, let's settle down to some quiet reading and take a look at the latest crop of guidebooks on Mexico. The books to be considered here include one that is chattily informative, a second that is practically a walking encyclopedia, a third rich in background material and a fourth designed for those planning to settle permanently in the land south of the border. The quartet follows:

title: Music composed in an atmosphere of despair
description: For Alban Berg, the outbreak of war in 1914 came as a horrible release. He hoped it would be a long one:

title: One Governor's Poll
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) Gov. David Hall of Oklahoma was so jubilant about the Sooners Sugar Bowl victory over Auburn today that he said the team deserved top ranking nationally. Asked if he thought Oklahoma, now ranked third, should he No. 2, he replied: No sir, we're No. 1 and holding.

title: New Services From thePostal Service
description: In 1967, shortly after the First National City Bank established its MaSter Charge credit card service, the bulk loss of cards in the mail accounted for 70 per cent of the dollar loss suffered by the bank through the illegal. use of the cards.

title: Donna Smith Fiancee
description: WESTON, Conn., Jan. 1The engagement of Miss Donna. Loorman Smith to Charles Alexander Downie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Downie of Pomeroy, Ohio, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford D. Smith of Weston. The prospective bridegroom is teacher in Middleport, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title: Utah State Wins, 9089
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Jan. 1 (AP)Utah State, receiving total of 54 ,points from Ron Hatch and Lafayette Love, upset EVansville, 9089, in basketball tonight. Hatch scored 30 points, Love 24 and grabbed 19 rebounds.

title: The Nation
description: ALBANYThat addlepated crib from a nursery rhyme describes the notsospecial extraordinary special session of the Legislature that met here last week in customary confusion to deal with the expected 15month budget deficit of $1.5billion. Perhaps the only extraordinary thing about it was the ability of the state's lawmakers to compress into such a short time the entire range of a regular monthslong session's machinations.

title: Shula of Dolphins Is Selected As A.F.C. Coach of the Year
description: Don Shula of the Miami Dolphins was named yesterday as the American Football Conferences coach of the year by United Press International.

title: The Elegant Boulevardier
description: No French entertainer was so jaunty, so debonair, so burnished yet so saucy, so much the elegant boulevardier of an idealized Paris as Maurice Chevalier.

title: RELIGIOUS SPLIT IN ISRAEL DECRIED
description: The head of the Rabbinical Council of America has decried the religious tensions between secularist and religious factions in Israel, asserting that the conflict poses a grave threat to the nation's existence.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: If John Simon finds Peter Brook so reprehensible for falsifying Shakespeare, I wonder why he reports the facts so falsely in writing about Brook's King Lear"?

title: AROUND THE
