description: We'll be back in this corner next week with plenty of chores to keep everyone busy.... Meanwhile, enjoy the holiday spirit.... Start fulfilling those New Year's resolutions by recycling the leftover Christmas greens as mulch and compost; take unwanted gift boxes and cartons to paper collection centers for reuse; include old seed catalogues, too.

title: Art
description: THE title of the NewYork Historical Society's new exhibition, Society's Sculpture, could make you feel a bit queasy when you realize it's a pun, and also there are a couple of dangerously slick spots where the vehicle threatens to skid over the edge of affectionate recall into something sticky. But Mary Black, the Society's curator of painting and sculpture, who arranged the show, keeps everything under control in an entertainment that can be enjoyed by practically anybody at whatever level. When you think about it later, you are likely to realize that what seemed to have been offered as an informal excursion through an attractive installation of some of the Society's prize objects led by an amiable hostess with a knack for anecdote, has really been an examination of American taste in the 18th and 19th centuries (with a dip into the early twentieth) by a serious guide.

title: Joanne Elizebeth Arnold Engaged
description: ST. LOWS, Jan: 1Mrs. Cecil Price Arnold has announced the, engagement of her daughter, Miss Joanne ElizabethArnold, to Donald Monroe Strathearn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Strathearn Jr. of Arlington, Ill,

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Jerome Chodorov's letter is priceless. Once again our knowledge is confirmed that New York can be a hell of an awful town. I wish, however, that I could share his enthusiasm for The Last Picture Show. It gets my vote for the most overrated film of the year.

title: Polaris Officer Plans to Marry Carolyn Zoephel
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Jan. 1 The engagement of Miss Carolyn Strahan Zoephel to Lieut. (Jg.) James Bicknell Lockhart 3d, U.S.N., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Karl H. Zoephel.

title: 3 JAIL GUARDS ADMIT STRIKING A PRISONER
description: Three prison guards pleaded guilty yesterday to departmental charges of using unnecessary force against an inmate, Robert Drake, after the riots at the Queens House of Detention Oct. 5, 1970.

title: Cowboys to Face 49ers
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1Thaddeus John Kwalick, who is only 24 years old, has figured out; tomorrow's game here between his team, the San Francisco 49ers, and the favored Dallas Cowboys.

title: SUPPLIES FLOWN TO BASE IN LAOS RINGED BY ENEMY
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 1Communist forces today eased their pressure on the vital and encircled Long Tieng base in northern Laos after two days of heavy shelling, enabling American planes to fly in ammunition to the allied garrison there.

title: Son for Roger Cruises
description: A son was born Dec. 1 to Mr. and Mrs. Roger F. Cruise of Scarsdale, N. Y., in the New York Hospital. Mrs. Cruise is the former Miss Vivian Eve Lester. Her husband is a security analyst with F. Eberstadt & Co. The child has been named Daniel Lester.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Importers returning from the Orient are threading through a maze of proposed new regulations on quotas for apparel that could seriously affect supplies and prices in the months ahead. And if they don't have enough headaches already, they are faced with renewal of the West Coast dock strike Jan. 10 and the East Coast strike Feb. 14, events that can cause pain that aspirin won't relieve.

title: Chess
description: ALEXANDER ALEXANDROVICH ALEKHINE (18921945) was, as most chess fans know, champion of the world from the time that he defeated the Cuban Jose Cepablanca in a 1927 match until he died a few months after the end of the Second World War: It is obvious from a glance at his name that he was born in Russia but, because he was a member of the nobility (his father was a count) he had to flee his homeland after the 1918 revolution. He became a citizen of France, representing that country in several team events and when he died was buried in Paris.

title: TriCaptains Elected
description: Jim McKiernan, Mark Poulin and Ken Stepanik have been elected tricaptains of the 1972 Southern Connecticut State football team.

title: Movies; How Does De Sica's Garden Grow? Beautifully
description: OF all the emotions, nostalgia is one of the most treacherous and Selfdeluding. In so many examples of longing for the past we detect an essential fakery, an impulse to dramatize the self, to make display of feelings that aren't truly justified by what was left behind. For instance: Do adults really value their undergraduate days, or is it only a boring pretense they act out to assuage their later disappointments and gull the young?

title: Wanna Buy Brando's TShirt?
description: MOVIE buffs the nation over were torn between sadness and joy about the recent news that 20th Century Fox's film props had been sold to the highest bidders. But this kind of auction, in keeping with the trend started by MGM to ease its financial plight, might be a boon to the real nostalgia addict who treasures items used by the great and neargreat of moviedom. For instance, something like the repeating rifle which Raquel Welch held tightly against herself to fire in 100 Rifles should bring a healthy sum from movie fans, gun hobbyists and or lady lovers everywhere. (Hey, look what I bought, Larry. Imagine where that gunbutt has been? This is what they call sentimental value.)

title: Congressional Study Accuses Penn Central Directors of Mismanagement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) Congressional investigators said today that the directors of the bankrupt Penn Central, had repeatedly ignored warnings from a fellow board member of impending financial trouble before the collapse of the line.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The wonderful Michelin guides are the only ones I have found which think updating means more than changing listed prices. We once drove for an hour and a half over harrowing Yugoslav roads to see a monastery that a guidebook raved about only to find that it had been closed for many years for restorations.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Barrel staves have long since given way to fiber glass or spaceage metals, foamfilled plastic boots have replaced random footwear, high fashion has moved into the apparel end of it and everywhere one looks, skiing has clearly become a big and still growing businessseasonally adjusted, of course.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On Dec. 19 James Reston castigated the two women who lead nations currently at odds with their neighborsMrs. Gandhi and Mrs. Meir. He does not mention that they head the only democratic governments in their areas and that both face male dictators who see all solutions out of a gun barrel.

title: ISLES IN RYUKYUS CLAIMED BY CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 1China has vigorously reasserted her claim to the Senkaku Islands, which Japan says are part of the Ryukyus and belong to Japan.

title: Neighbor Who Sang At Parties Moving Up
description: Al Ryden and his wife, Peggy, live three doors away from us in Forest Hills and in keeping with my New York upbringing I knew little about them. What the heck, I'd only been at the location about nine years. There's no need to be pushy.

title: The Nation
description: Does every Mayor of New York have to leave City Hall on a political stretcher? Last week John Lindsay made his bid to upset that tradition, officially announcing his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: We are now well into the eat your heart out season. That's when you sit around trapped in a cold and crowded New York, Boston or Philadelphia looking at ads showing palm covered islands, clear waters, warm white beaches littered only with bikiniclad damsels, and eat your heart out.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: It would be in the interest of your readers to be presented with a competent study of the actual and potential effects of the arrangement made by American Telephone and Telegraph to sell a billion dollars of 25year notes and nonconvertible preferred stock to 16 large Institutional investors. According to your article, The Week In Finance of Dec. 26, this was the largest direct placement of securities ever done.

title: Suffolk's Welfare System Is Said To Be on Verge of Breaking Down
description: BAY SHORE, L. I.Six months after the implementation of a statemandated change in the welfare system of Suffolk County, many social workers contend that their department is on the verge of a total breakdown, :with services to clients at a standstill.

title: Pesticides Head Scientist's List Of Dangers to the Environment
description: Among the environmental problems, big and small, that are said to be leading the world to doom, the severest at present, in the view of a scientist who has invented a system for rating priorities, is the, misuse of pesticides.

title: Taconic Auto Club Ice Racing Series Opens Sunday
description: Racing on frozen lakes and rivers, immensely popular in New England and Canada, has something of a foothold in the New York area despite inconsistent weather. Next Sunday the Taconic Auto Sports Club will begin its ninth annual Icekhana Series. Races will continue, weather permitting, each Sunday through Feb. 27. The races are run on Lake Osceola at Jefferson Valley, N. Y., in upper Westchester County.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Donations Fall $28,000 Below a Year Ago
description: With the 250 contributions recorded yesterday, the 60th annual appeal of the. New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reached $602,013.93. The fund is nevertheless still $28,000 below the comparable amount recorded a year ago and more than $128,000 below the amount published on Jan. 2, 1968.

title: Mississippi Woodcutters, With Strike Over, Hampered by Rain
description: LAUREL, Miss, Jan 1The pulpwood cutters strike, which last fall drew national attention, support from Charles Evers, the Negro gubernatorial candidate, and a rare unity of poor Mississippi whites and blacks, is over, but things are still lean for the men who hack their livelihoods from the forests.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWhy was so much of the country surprised last week when President Nixon ordered the bombing of North Vietnam? The President had said a year ago that he would do it.

title: The World
description: The big news on the Indian subcontinent last week was the absence of any crisis headlines.

title: EGYPT CUTS PLAN FOR RECLAMATION
description: CAIRO, Jan. 1  A sharp cutback in ambitious landreclamation projects using water from the Aswan High Dam has been disclosed by the Egyptian Premier, Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi.

title: Ralph Bunche Jr. Fiance Of Patricia E. Hittinger
description: Miss Patricia Elizabeth Hittinger and Ralph J. Bunche Jr., son of the late Dr. Bunche, former United Nations Under Secretary for Special Political Affairs and winner of the 1950 Nobel Peace Prize, plan to be married here on Jan. 22. The ceremony will take place in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church with only immediate families and a few friends in attendance.

title: The World
description: Eastern policy was the big question: West German Chancellor Willy Brandt has been pursuing his Ostpolitik to improve relations with Communist Europe; President Nixon is about to make historic journeys to Peking and Moscow.

title: News of the Rialto
description: LIKE every other town, this one loves a winner. But, back in the late Fifties it lost its heart to a perennial loser, Gittel Mosca, as portrayed by Anne Bancroft in William Gibson's smash hit, Two for the Seesaw.

title: Forest in Poland Shelters 200 Bison
description: BIALOWIEZA, Poland,, Dec. 27The Russian border is that way, only a few kilometers, the Polish guide said, indicating a clearing in the Bialowieza Forest that was enveloped in the thick winter mist.

title: Heckl Athlete of Year
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI)Frank Heckl, the PanAmerican Games swimming sensation, has been named Southern California Athlete of the Year for 1971 by United SavingsHelms Athletic Foundation. The 6foot5inch, 195pound University of Southern California senior captured six gold medals and a silver at the PanAmerican games competition at Cali, Columbia last summer.

title: Science
description: PHILADELPHIAVirtually every field of science has its own club with periodic meetings at which members report on their findings and pass judgment on those of their colleagues. But once a year, traditionally during the week from Christmas to New Year's Day, there is a super conclave attended by scientists of every specialty from anthropology to zoology the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: The Olympic Flame Reaches Tokyo on Its Long Journey From, Greece to Sapporo and the Winter Games
description: TOKYO, Jan. 1 (UPI)The Olympic flame was flown into Tokyo from Athens today for the Winter Olympic Games opening Feb. 3 in Sapporo on Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island.

title: Public Hearings Slated By Albany Committees
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1Following are public hearings scheduled for January by committees of the Senate and the Assembly:

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Dr. Walter, Smartt, head of venereal disease control in Los Angeles County, states in Cokie and Steven V. Roberts's article, The Venereal Disease Pandemic (Nov. 7), that the attitude of physicians toward treating these diseases is that private medicine isn't interested, it couldn't tare less, it doesn't give a damn. This is a blanket indictment not descriptive of the situation in New York State. Practicing physicians who are members of the Medical Society of the State of launched an educational campaign at their own expense which is reaching college campuses, high schools and junior high schools. As a result, numerous young people have been referred to health clinics and physicians throughout the state.

title: Miss Mary A. McReynolds Is Wed
description: CARTHAGE, Mo., Jan. 1Miss Mary Armilda McReynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen McReynolds of Carthage, was married here at noon, today to John De; Quedville Briggs 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Briggs. Jr. of Concord, Mass.

title: Sports, 1972: A Montage of Games, Races, Fights, Bets, Courts and Television
description: For the wholeheartedly committed spectator sports addict, the year 1972 promises extraordinary mindblowing  or is it stupifying?  Potential.

title: The Good Word: Beat Down and Beatific
description: Did you catch Kerouac tonight? He was wild. Yeah, well, we had Kerouac last week. Equally wild, man. Columbia fortiesfifties, long before On the Road. As a neighborhood kibitzer, I kept missing him by five minutes, with the new smell, marijuana, still heavy on the air, like Satan's homebrewed incense. You probably had such a hot dog at your schoolthe country was starved for hot dogs then. But this one, in the media capital, produced with just one formidable friend and a few assorted spearcarriers, the Beat Generation.

title: Cincinnati Is Focus of Fight to Curb Transit Fares
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 1.The Federal Price Commission has temporarily blocked skyrocketing bus fares here and is also suing to roll back a 5 cent increase instituted the day the wageprice freeze ended. But elsewhere in the country pressure for higher transit fares continues to mount despite the economic controls.

title: Books:
description: TECHNIQUES IN CORPORATE REORGANIZATION. Edited by William M. Mishkin. 294 pages. Presidents Publishing House, New York. $25.

title: Pop
description: ROBERTA FLACK: Quiet Fire (Atlantic SD 1594). When I first heard Roberta Flack she reminded me of a lowkeyed Nina Simone. Good enough musically, but lacking the passion that Miss Simone generates so easily.

title: Recordings
description: ONE of the surest signs of advancing age is a blossoming interest in ancestors and family trees. It is as If, having become dead certain where we are going, we need with increasing urgency to learn where we have been. There is nothing reprehensible in this, of course, though an elder's mumbling preoccupation with the dead can certainly be tiresome enough. But ancestorhunting can, intelligently pursued, prove enlightening and civilizing, and the best musicological studies offer fine examples of how to advance by going backward. Right now, it is must illuminating togo back to Monteverdi, whose opera II Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria has been recorded beautifully and in full by Nikolaus Harnoncourt's Concentus Musicus Wien (Telefunken, Das Alten Werke SKBT 23/14). There is no doubt that the Renaissance composer is one of the half dozen greatest figures in musical history and it is scarcely overstating it to say that 'Monteverdi was the first and greatest among muscians in his blending of art and life, as his biographer Leo Schrade puts it. We should know his works as thoroughly as we do those of Bach, Mozart or Beethoven, and that slowly is being made possible.

title: Philippine Village Raided
description: MANILA, Jan. I (UPI)Some 300 armed Moslems raided Christian village in the southern Philippines today, killing one person and setting fire to 70 houses. National police drove the raiders from the village of Ampatuan in Cotabato province. There were no police casualties.

title: Atlanta Gets U.S. Tennis
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 1 (UPI)The National claycourt amateur tennis championships will be held July 10 to 16 at the Bitsy Grant Tennis Center. The event is expected to draw 64 leading amateurs.

title: SEOUL TO LET ARMY REQUISITION LANDS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan: President Park Chung Hee has issued a National Mobilization decree to impower the armed forces to requisition privately owned land for military operations, especially when deemed necessary for the defense of the Seoul area.

title: Theater In Providence A Too Baroque Bovasso?
description: SOMETIME during the sixties, the avantgarde of the Absurd was outflanked in the American theater bywhat shall we call it?the environmentalparticIpational avantgarde, the avantgarde that aspires to be a Theater of Cruelty. The new avantgarde is more communal and less individualistic than the old, more concerned with political realities as opposed to merely subjective states, eager to incite to action, not just to bear witnessmore in tune, therefore, with the needs, or at least the wants, of these times.

title: A Catholic Decline In Quebec Reported In Study by Bishops
description: MONTREAL, Jam 1 (Reuters) The Roman Catholic Church is in a state of crisis in Canada, according to a report made public here.

title: New Transit Contract Ends 30Year Tradition
description: The new year ended a 30yearold tradition  the New Year's Eve transit negotiation cliffhanger  as the result of the contract agreement reached yesterday that extends through March 31, 1974.

title: LETTERS
description: To The Financial Editor: The article Why Quotas Are Necessary by O. R. Strackbein (Nov. 28) is a lucid explanation of the facts of economic life for the other countries of the world. There is probably no doubt in the minds of most Americans that one of the most potent obstacles to free trade throughout the world is the great disparity of wages paid for the production of goods.

title: Miss McMahon Plans to Marry Investment Aide
description: The engagement of Miss Lauree McMahon to Gregory Charles Hickok, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Hickok of Minneapolis, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Mc. Namee McMahon of New York. A wedding next month is planned.

title: Who knows what frustrations lurk in the hearts of X million Americans? George Wallace knowsand he's off and running
description: FOR the last decade, George Corley Wallace has been America's political poltergeist, a bumptious bogeyman personifying the cholesterol in the nation's bloodstream.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: The oil business is a whole new ball game today with many of the old rules eliminated or totally changed, a trim, grayhaired man commented from behind a desk in the Pan Am Building.

title: Treatment: exhortationprognosis: excellent
description: With great good humor but with devastating effect, Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes in 1860 assessed the medical career of Benjamin Rush, up to then the only American physician who had achieved an international reputation:

title: Sadat Raises New Arab Union Flag
description: CAIRO, Jan: 1 President Anwar elSadat raised a new banner of Arab unity  the red, white and black flag with a golden hawk of the Federation of Arab Republics over Cairo today amid the contrasting sounds of a 21gun military salute and the fluttering of doves of peace.

title: Looking Back at Lumumba
description: MURDEROUS ANGELS is a grotesque example of history rendered as fiction. Under the guise of pursuing truth, it creates images of men that actually slander and finally destroy those men.

title: POPE PAUL URGES A NEW JUSTICE
description: ROME, Jan. 1Pope Paul VI, in an address marking the Roman Catholic church's annual Day of Peace, issued a call today for a new justice.

title: Ferguson of Drexel Wins N.C.A.A. Graduate Grant
description: Blake Lynn Ferguson, Drexel University's most honored athlete, has capped his collegiate career by being selected to receive a National Collegiate Athletic Association post graduate scholarship award. Ferguson is one of 33 chosen for the honor from thousands of applications from all across the country.

title: ChildCare Agencies Cooperating in 5 Towns
description: Childcare agencies in the rive Towns area of Nassau County have joined together in a Children's Services Committee under the sponsorship of the Five Towns Community Council.

title: Davidson Tops Wm. &
description: DAVIDSON. N. C., Jan. 1 (AP) Davidson used a balanced attack today to register an 81 68 Southern Conference basketball victory over Wil lian and Mary.

title: British Pony rlab Plays Ox. Ridge In Darien Friday
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. IEd McNamara Jr., a Fordham Prep senior, spent a frustrating time in England playing against British Pony Club Teams last summer.

title: Big Shot II, $10, Wins San Gabriel Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan 1 (UPI) Big Shot II, under the guidance of Eddie Belmonte, scored by 1 lengths today in the $45,000 San Gabriel Handicap at Santa Anita Park.

title: Coins
description: THE fourth medal in the Indian Tribal Series honoring America's outstanding sovereign Indian nations was released last month. This new issue commemorates the Sioux of the Rosebud Reservation in South Dakota.

title: Westminster Coach Resigns
description: NEW WILMINGTON, Pa., Jan. 1 (UPI)Dr. Harold Burry, who compiled a record of 127 victories, 31 defeats and five ties as head football coach at Westminster College since 1952, resigned today. Joe Fusco, 33 years old, the Titans offensive coach for the last four seasons, succeeds Burry. Burry, 59, will remain as Westminster's athletic director and chairman of the physical education department.

title: Mrs. Skolnik Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Skolnik of Scarsdale, N. Y., on Dec. 6 in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Skolnik is the former Miss Rebecca Maca of Izmir, Turkey. The child, the couple's third daughter, is named Emily Suzanne. Her father is secretary and corporate counsel with Plessey, Inc., in New York, subsidiary of Plessey, Ltd., London.

title: Brooklyn College Cites Zerden As Most Valuable Soccer Fan
description: I was shocked and in tears, Sheldon Zerden, a stockbroker, was saying one day last week with a smile as wide as his necktie. It was a moving thing, what those kids did.

title: U.S.Bangladesh Contact
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 (AP)In the first public contact between a United States official and the secessionist government of Bangladesh, the former American Consul General in Dacca called today on Abdus Samad, the Bangladesh foreign minister, to exchange New Year greetings, United News of India reported.

title: 3 G.I.'s on Furlough Held In Robbery of Gas Station
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1Four young men, three of them soldiers on furlough, held up a service station last night and escaped with $231, according to the police. The suspects, Who were found with drug apparatus in their possession, were caught 10 minutes after the holdup took place at 9:45 P.M.

title: Nassau's Black Population Climbs
description: Nassau, while easily retaining its place as the most populous suburban county in the metropolitan area, has begun to take on some of the demographic characteristics of New York City.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe new United States Asian policy focuses directly upon relations with China and clearly expects that as a consequence of this emphasis settlement of the Vietnam war can ultimately be arranged. The search for accommodation with Peking began three years ago and will be dramatized next month by President.Nixon's visit. TWo significant developments can be related to this policy. The. first was expression of unqualified, American support for Pakistan against India during their recent war. The second is resumption of bombing in North Vietnam and U.S. postponement of scheduled sessions of the Paris peace negotiations'.

title: Dutchess County Group Honors King's Donohue
description: Ed Donohue, director of athletics and basketball coach of King's College in WilkesBarre, Pa., will be inducted into the Dutchess County Hall of Fame in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., on Jan. 26.

title: Moral Aftermath
description: The question of amnesty for the many young men who have avoided military service or deserted in recent years is properly part of the moral aftermath of the Vietnam war. The first difficulty in this tangled ethical problem is that the war his not ended. Although draft calls are temporarily suspended and casualties greatly reduced, each week a few American soldiers are still killed in Vietnam, scores are. wounded and thousands run the risk of military combat if the enemy should choose to go on the offensive.

title: U.S. Planes Fly 200 Strikes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 2 (AP)American planes made more than 200 strikes against North Vietnamese supply lines in Cambodia and Laos yesterday.

title: Diane Wright Oschwald Wed in Jersey
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Jan. 1Miss Diane Wright Oschwald and Charles Jacques MeissirelMarquot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles MeissirelMarquot of Grasse, France, were married here this afternoon.

title: PRIMROSE ASSIGNS HAWKINS TO JUDGE
description: Primrose Farms In Somers, N. Y., will hold the second of its winter indoor show series next Saturday with Arthur Hawkins assigned to judge all classes.

title: Survey in Soccer Shows 16 Million Are Playing Game
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 1 (AP)Close to 16 million soccer players are active in nearly 300,000 clubs throughout the world, according to a survey published recently by the International Football Federation.

title: Motors Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 9Mustang Club of Fort Lee Motors gimmick rally; start at parking lot No. 29, Bergen Mall, Route 4, Paramus, N. J. Registration: 11 A.M., first car off at noon. Information: Cindy Rush, phone (201)7970318.

title: Diving for Long Island Treasures
description: A growing number of scuba divers have been searching the waters off, Long Island for treasures to be found in the sleeping hulks Of shipwrecked vessels.

title: Jose Marti Marries Miss Sally Aller
description: SALISBURY, Conn., Jan. Miss Sally Martin Mier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Aller Jr. of Lakeville, was married in the Salisbury Congregational Church today to Jose Luis Marti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Marti of Alicante, Spain. The ceremony was performed by the :Rev. Dr. Charles Ranson, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Forte of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lakeville.

title: Susan L. Wernyss Prospective Bride
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Courtney Wemyss of Boston. and Lake Placid, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Leslie Wemyss, to Winthrop Carter Lockwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood of Lake Placid. A Feb. 12 wedding is planned.

title: Broader U.S.Soviet Trade
description: The recent Kremlin award of a major industrial design contract to a subsidiary of Pullman, Inc., makes it evident that SovietAmerican tension over the Indian subcontinent has not immediately damaged the outlook for Improved trade relations between the two countries. Recent progress on this front has been startling. Secretary of Commerce Stans and Soviet Agriculture Minister Matskevich have exchanged cordial visits in which both officials warmly expressed their interest in increased commerce. Moscow has agreed to buy about $150 million of American grain; there has been a substantial barter deal involving the exchange of Soviet metals for American machinery, and the Administration has become much freer in granting licenses to American firms wishing to export machinery to the Soviet Union.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE stock market closed a very erratic year in a calm fashion Friday, but with hopes flying rather high for significant improvement in 1972. It was difficult to find an outright bear in Wall Street In recent days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I consider myself one of the silent minority who thinks. Amid all the hysterical debate by the politically ambitious of our country, one must evaluate what the leadership is doing, and on balance for the long run of our American society, is it good? Did Senator Kennedy want the President to send a crusade into India or Pakistan, escalating our involvement the way his family escalated our Vietnam debacle? The Times in its editorials also thought the Administration did not do enough in the right direction to avoid the subsequent war.

title: AMERICANS FEEL HOSTILITY IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 1The United States Ambas Sador, Kenneth B. Keating, has an Indian police bodyguard 24 hours day.

title: 71 PEAK IS LIKELY IN STEEL IMPORTS
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2Steel imports probably set a record level in the past year.

title: Grenade Found on IRT
description: A simulated hand grenade used in military training was found along the elevated IRT White Plains Road line early yesterday morning and was removed by the bomb squad, the pblice reported. A Transit Authority patrolman spotted the device on a girder below the Jackson Avenue Station at 1:30 A.M. Service was uninterrupted as the bomb disposal unit removed it. The police said the grenade could have done light damage if it had exploded.

title: Manhasset Sailing Canceled
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 2Strong, gusty winds forced cancellation of today's sailing in the 41st annual New year's frostbite regatta on Manhasset Bay. Awards were based on yesterday's four races. Mel Reid, Setauket Yacht Club, with 10 points, won Penguin honors in a fleet of 54 boats. Randy Bartholomew, Manhasset Bay Y. C., beat 44 Interclub rivals with 15 points.

title: Steel Town Still Awaits Phase 2 Gains
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio President Nixon's economic program has raised expectations that better clays are coming in this small Middle Western steel city, but so far those prospects have gone unfulfilled.

title: Marion Goertzel Is Wed to an Interne
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 2Miss Marion B. Goertzel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Goertzel, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Stephen L. Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Stern. Both families live in White Plains. Cantor William Wolff performed the ceremony in the White Plains Hotel.

title: BRAZILIANS SELL SUGAR TO SOVIET
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 2 The Soviet Union has bought 200,000 metric tons of Brazilian sugar at a higherthanmarket price for immediate delivery, the Government's Sugar and Alcohol Institute announced here just before the New Year holiday.

title: Mr. Crangle Moves In
description: The New York State Democratic partybadly divided, perpetually wrangling, deeply in debthas a new chairman, Joseph, F. Crangle of Buffalo. He is from the regular, rather than the reform, wing of the party and a man many jobs: partner in a Buffalo law firm, Erie County Democratic Chairman, executive assistant to Assembly Minority Leader Stanley Steingut

title: $14,016 DONATED TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Several donations of $1,000 or more, a number of $100 contributions and many, many contributions of smaller amounts added $14,015.69 yesterday to the recorded total of the 60th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Federal Aid to Housing Has Produced Widespread Criticism and Condemnation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The controversy over national housing policy is building up so rapidly that many authorities believe it will become more widespread and heated than that surrounding public welfare in recent years.

title: 40 Lost in Persian Gulf
description: DOHA, Qatar, Jan. 2 (Reuters)About 40 persons were drowned when a Qatari ship sank during a storm off the island of Qais in the Persian Gulf last night, Government officials announced. Only two passengers survived when the vessel AlRayyan sank, the officials said.

title: NEW PAPER GOLD TOTE $3BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The International Monetary. Fund distributed today nearly $3billion of Special Drawing Rights, or paper gold, to its member countries, including $710million to the United States.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDONSam Peckinpah and Andy Warhol have little in common except far their depiction of a certain underbelly of American life. Peckinpah is a film director whOse themes are rooted in violence. Warhol is an artist and filmmaker who is intrigued by sexual kinkiness, drugs and the grotesqueries of a curiously arid subculture. In the last few weeks both of these controversial artists have been the focus of an angry and somewhat fascinating tugofwar between critics here and the powerful British Board of film Censors. What the dispute involves is Peckinpah's violent film Straw Dogs, which recently opened to outraged reviews in London. At the same time, the censors barred public showings of Warhol's Trash, a film with the artist's stock cast of transvestites and spacedout performers. What the British critics are asking is why should violence be any less pornographic to censors than bizarre sexuality and drugs?

title: Miss Alexandra D. McConihe Is Married to David Delapalme
description: HOBE SOUND, Fla., Jan. 2 Miss Alexandra Diana McConihe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stuart McConihe Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Hobe Sound, was married here this afternoon to David Delapalme, son of Mrs. Gerard Delapalme of Paris and the late Mr. Delapalme. The ceremony in Christ Memorial Chapel at the Jupiter Island Club was performed by the Rev. Dr. Louis Hirshon, an Episcopal clergyman.

title: LEVITT AUDIT CITES WASTE IN STATE U.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 2A radioTV facility that not too many students want, dormitory rooms that are increasingly unpopular and a variety of other opportunities to cut waste and save costs are among the findings of an audit of the State University construction program released today by State Controller, Arthur Levitt.

title: Staubach Thinks Cowboys Deserve to Win Super Bowl
description: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP)This is the culmination of an unbelievable year, said Roger Staubach today after the Dallas Cowboys beat the San Francisco 49ers, 143. We deserve to win the Super Bowl.

title: WILLIAM M'MORROW, WROTE SOAP OPERAS
description: William F. McMorrow, a writer of short stories for magazines and of radio soap operas in the nineteentwenties and nineteenthirties, died of cancer Saturday at Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L. I. His home was at 23 Schenck Avenue, Great Neck. He was 82 years old.

title: Writers Pick Nebraska No. 1 2d Year in a Row
description: Nebraska was voted the top college team in the country yesterday by the Football Writers Association of America, becoming the first school to win the Grantland Rice Trophy twoyears in a row.

title: Efforts Grow to Bring Here Babies That G.I.'s Left in Vietnam
description: Ruth Friedman's first daughter was not delivered in a hospital. The 2yearold. Vietnamese girl was delivered Into her mother's arms at Kennedy International Airport on Dec. 11.

title: Schoolboys Clip 3 Records In lona College Track Meet
description: Three meet records were set yesterday in the 11th annual Iona College Spike Shoe Club schoolboy track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: ITALY PLANNING AID FOR HER 79 PAPERS
description: ROME, Jan. 2The Government today sent a bill to Parliament that would make $160million in state funds available annually to the country's ailing newspaper and magazine industry.

title: U.S. Plane Losses High
description: SAIGON, San. 2 (AP)Records of the United States command show that the United States cloasd out 1971 with the heaviest losses of tactical aircraft since the period before the bombing of North Vietnam Was ordered halted on Nov. 1, 1968.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Despite the Arab rhetoric about 1971 as the year of decision In the struggle with Israel, the year came to an end much as it began: with neither war nor peace in the Middle East and seemingly little prospect of either in the near future. The year of decision theme, first proclaimed by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt last July, generated an artificial tension in the area, a tension unjustified by either the political or military realities. When Dec. 31 finally passed, the only shots being fired were those between Lebanese security forces and Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut.

title: Stage: Her Water Bed Frozen Solid
description: Joan Rivers is a very funny lady, as anyone who has seen her in nightclubs or on television can testify. Over the years I have had the pleasure of seeing her perform her comedy act on numerous occasionsand I saw it again last night when her first play, Fun City, opened at the Morose.

title: Kennedy Says He Dropped Plan To Block Jackson at Convention
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Two months ago, Senator Edward M. Kennedy was seriously considering active interv'ention in the 1972 Democratic National Convention, but now he says he has dropped the idea.

title: America Comes of Age
description: The Administration's overtures to China and its aggressive economic policy toward Japan and Western Europe have set off an enormous upheaval in this country's diplomatic relations, but their most profound effect may be In the intellectual sphere.

title: Nixon Indicates He'll Run, With Agnew on the Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2President Nixon left little doubt tonight that he intended to run for a second term in office, and said that his present inclination was to keep Vice President Ag1 new on the ticket.

title: The House of a Rothschild Will Be U.S. Envoy's Home
description: PARIS, Dec. 30The Arthur K. Watsons of New Canaan, Conn., are preparing to move into their new place here, and it's certainly grand.

title: Legislatures in 12 States to Consider Plans to Strengthen Antipollution Laws
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2In at least a dozen states, proposals for stiffer laws to combat air and water pollution will be submitted to new legislative sessions this year.

title: Indian on the Border Sees Life Reviving
description: BOYRA, India, Jan. 1Triloknath Mandal, sitting crosslegged in his small, boxlike store that looks out on East Pakistan across the Kabuthaki River, watched intently as small groups of refugees ferried back home,

title: Pope Offers 72 Greeting To a Throng at the Vatican
description: ROME, Jan. 2 (AP)Pope Paul VI offered a New Year's greeting to several thousand people who assembled in St. Peter's Square in the Vatican today.

title: HAROLD HARPER, 86, U.S. LAWYER HERE
description: Harold Harper, a New York lawyer and former Federal attorney, died Friday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 86 years old and had been a resident of this city all his life.

title: Subway Skyrocket
description: For the harried subway rider, relief from one uncertainty simply opens up another. New Year's Day brought tentative assurance that the subways and buses would not be halted by a strike. Now the big question Is how much more the straphanger will have to pay for the indignities daily inflicted, on him in dirty, overcrowded trains subject to frequent breakdowns and delays.

title: New Mediator Joins in Parleys To Avoid Yonkers School Strike
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 2A State Supreme Court Justice, a new stateappointed mediator, and negotiators for both sides met today in a final effort to avert a strike called for tomorrow morning by the Yonkers Federation of Teachers.

title: Lively Economic Growth In 71 Hailed by Canada
Lindsay Is a TVShow Host for the Last Time
description: Flankedby heads of key city agencies, Mayor Lindsay last night ended  temporarily at leasthis Sundaynight television series on WNEWTV entitled, With Mayor Lindsay.

title: SOONER DEFENSE GETS CREDIT, TOO
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (UPI) Nobody has been able to stop Oklahoma's tripleoption steamroller offense all season, not even the No. 1 team, Nebraska.

title: GERMAN ART BALLAD SUNG BY FAIRCHILD
description: Few doctoral candidates in music are willing or able to complement their dissertations with a public recital. David Fairchild took the plunge yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, illustrating his Ph.D. thesis The Literary and Musical Evolution of the German Art Ballad.

title: Bruins Triumph, 41, End Rangers Unbeaten Streak
Clayton Gets State Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) Zach Clayton, the boxing referee, was appointed today to the threemember Pennsylvania Athletic Commission.

title: Dr. Miriam Schloessinger, Collected Ancient Lamps
description: Dr. Miriam Schaar Schloessinger, a retired opthalmologist and an archeologist, who had a notable collection of ancient Roman and Judaean lamps, died yesterday at her home, 10 Park Avenue. Her age was 91.

title: Soviet Opens a 300Mile Canal To Bring Water to Steel Plant
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 2 The Soviet Union has announced the completion of a 300mile canal to provide water for a major Central Asian steel plant. The canal, under construction for 10 years, was needed to correct a significant error in the choice Of a site for the steel project.

title: Limousine Bandits Loot Hotel Pierre Safes
description: Welldressed gunmen who arrived by limousine took over the fashionable Hotel Pierre, at Fifth Avenue and Gist Street, for nearly two hours before dawn yesterday, handcuffed 19 employes and guests and looted 47 safedeposit boxes of jewelry and cash. The loss could total over $1million.

title: AN END TO CONTROLS PREDICTED BY STEIN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Herbert Stein, the Nixon Administration's chief economist, said today that at some point the country Would move to a system free of wage and price controls, but he refused to predict when.

title: Bridge Workers Ratify Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) ridge employes at two spans connecting pennsylvania and New Jersey  the Benjamin Franklin and Walt Whitman bridges ratified a new two year contract today ending a fiveweek strike. Terms call for a 22centsanhour increase retroactive to last Nov. 1 and an additional 20 Cents hourly in the second year of the contract.

title: EDWARD WELTON
description: Edward Welton, who retired as president of the Williams Furniture Company, a Long Island retail chain, six years ago, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Pay Unit Member Explains Stand on Merit Increases
description: William G. Caples, president of Kenyon College and a public member of the Federal Pay Board, said in a recent interview that the board was concerned about the possibility that some companies might give illegal pay raises. by ,misusing merit increases.

title: Third Rose Bowl Victory in Row Regains Luster for West Coast
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. (UPI)West Coast football regained some of its luster as result of Stanford's 1312 victory over Michigan in the Rose Bowl game yesterday.

title: Libya's Premier Crusades Against Tea Break and the OilRich Life
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec, 28Chairs for visitors abruptly disappeared from Government offices recently, underlining a challenge by the revolutionary regime of Premier Muammar elQaddafi to relaxed work habits and frequent office gatherings for gossip over tea.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Colts Greeted by Throng On Returning to Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 2 (AP) Several thousand fans assembled at Friendship International Airport in 42degree weather tonight to welcome home Baltimore's dethroned Super Bowl champions.

title: Buoniconti Is Singled Out by Unitas as Key Man in Dolphins'
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2Nick Buoniconti, shunned by the National Football League 10 years ago as too small and too short, received a tall tribute from The Master today

title: John H. Heuer, President Of Paper Companies, Dies
description: TAMARAC, Fla., Jan. 2John H. Heuer, president and chief executive officer of Fraser Paper, Ltd., of Greenwich, Conn., and the parent company in Canada, Fraser Companies, Ltd., died of heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 54 years old and also lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Focusing on Chayefsky: Make It Picture Maker
description: Paddy Chayefsky is a picture maker. That's the term he uses for it, since it is as direct and accurate as a nail driven home.

title: PENN STATE FINDS WISHBONE LUCKY
description: DALLAS, Jan. 2 (UPI)Each time the University of Texas is defeatedand it has happened only five times since the start of the 1968 seasonthere is great discussion on what kind of defense was used against the Wishbone offense.

title: Rep. Reuss Says Tax Loopholes Still Let Wealthy Avoid Paying
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Representative Henry S. Reuss reported today that 112 Americans with annual incomes of more than $200,000 were legally able to avoid paying any Federal income taxes for 1970.

title: Say Goodby to Hendrysburg
description: COLUMBUS, OhioZip Code No. 43744 is about to disappear, victim of the most literal ripoff ever to hit this nation. And when it does, the only official notice the Government will take is to erase, a post office for the little village of Hendrysburg, Ohio 43744. Two businessesthe fourthclass post office and Kaplet's Grocery are all that remain to bind a hundred families into a community.

title: Advertising:
description: R. J. Reynolds, the country's No. 1 cigarette salesmen, this week begins a very different advertising campaign for its fairly new brand, Vantage, which Is supposed to offer high filtration and good taste.

title: Legislative Leaders Meet Governor on Fiscal Crisis
description: ALBANY, Jan. 2Legislative leaders met at the Executive Mansion tonight with Governor Rockefeller in an attempt to revive last week's compromise tax plan for closing a projected 15month, $1.5million budget gap.

title: Lawyer Group Challenges Remap ping of Legislature
description: The bitter controversy over] the reapportionment of the State Legislature is likely to be replayed in the court's as a group of lawyers prepared yesterday to challenge the Republican remapping of State Senate and Assembly districts.

title: Quake in Mexico Recorded
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 2(AP) An earthquake with a magnitude of 5.5 on the Richter scale near Oaxaca, Mexico, was recorded shortly before 5 P.M., Eastern standard time, today by the University of California seismograph station.

title: Bowdoin Six Wins Final
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 2Ned Dowd and Dick Donovan scored three goals, apiece tonight as Bowdoin .College won its Holiday hockey tournament with a 96 victory over Dalhousie University of Halifax, Nova Scotia. Air France Academy beat Princeton 61, for third place. Dowd was voted. the most valuable player.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Schlitz Is Told to Keep Its Plant In Brooklyn Open for 17 Months
description: An arbitrator yesterday ordered the Schlitz Brewing Company not to close its Brooklyn plant today and to continue operations there for at least another 17 months.

title: Do Not Abandon Your Children
description: These are excerpts from a statement by the father of one of three students who were expellecI from the Lycee Montaigne in Paris. This originally appeared in Le Monde.

title: 1 Dead, 2 Lost as Blast in Buffalo Rips World's Biggest Flour Mill
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 2  An explosion and fire this morning destroyed a Pillsbury Company grainstorage building at the world's largest flour mill here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MORTGAGED HEART. By Carson McCullers. Edited by Margarita G. Smith. 294 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $7.95.

title: TransitWorker Ratification Of Pact Expected in 3 Weeks
description: Worker ratification of the new transit Contract is expected in about three weeks, a spokesman for the Transpprt Workers Union said yesterday.

title: A Vote for 2Term Accountability
description: There has been increasing discussion recently of the joint Senate resolution proposing a constitutional amendment to limit the President to a single six. year term. Proponents advance the statesmanship argument that such single term would free the President from resorting to partisan politics to seek reelection and permit him to concentrate his total efforts on the momentous domestic and foreign probi lems of our times.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 (UPI)Foreign Minister Abba Ebarr teported to the Cabinet today on the latest contacts with' he United States, an official spokesman said.

title: U.S. Sources in Saigon Say Rains Hampered Bombings in North
Economist at M.I.T. Sees Profits Up 15% This Year
description: LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP)  An American economist predicted during the weekend that corporate profits in the United States would increase by at least 15 per cent in 1972, but he said that unemployment by the end of the year was likely to be still above 5 per cent.

title: Restrictions Facing a Credit Reporter
description: TULSA, Okla.For the past 11 years Paul Polin, a management consultant, has been engaged in a battle with the Atlantabased Retail Credit Company, one of the nation's largest credit reporting agencies.

title: ROSEIWALL TO PLAY ANDERSON IN FINAL
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (UPI)Ken Rosewall, the defending champion, will meet Mal Anderson in the final of the Australian open men's singles tennis championship tomorrow at Kooyong Courts.

title: Miss Baiocchi Has Nuptials
description: Miss Judith St. George Baiocchi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Baiocchi, of Sewickley, Pa., was married here yesterday afternoon to Albert Bacher, son of Albert Bather of Bolzano, Italy, and the late Mrs. Bacher.

title: Family and Career
description: Sheer indomitability was the most distinguishing mark of character in Dr. Lillian Mol er Gilbreth, who provedspecacularlyto herself and others that a woman can have a family and a career.

title: Miss Archibald Wed
description: RIVER EDGE, N. J., Jan. 2 Miss Shirley Noyes Archibald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Coxe Archibald, was married here this afternoon to William Ledford Ballard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Ballard of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Sumner Harley Gill performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Jordan Super Confident
description: IRVING, Tex, Jan. 2 (AP)We don't care who we play in the Super Bowl, said Lee Roy Jordan, the Cowboys middle linebacker, after Dallas defeated the San Francisco 49ers, 143, today. This time we will win it. I said after the Baltimore game last year we would be back.

title: PREHISTORIC SITES FEARED IN PERIL
description: Within, the next 20 to 30 years, the buried and still mostly, unstudied record of prehistoric man in America may be largely destroyed, many archeologists are beginning to fear.

title: Mexico's Year of Juarez
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 (AP)Mexico officially opened The Year of Juarez todaya year long tribute to Benito Juarez, an Indian born in 1806 who as President defeated the French attempt to set up a Mexican empire under Maximillian from 1864 to 1867.

title: He Left the Paris Couture for Shirtmaking
description: LOS ANGELES  In Beverly Hills, where the list of custom shirtmakers occupies almost half a page in the Yellow Pages, a Jack Varney custom shirt is something special.

title: WINGS OVERCOME CANADIENS BY 64
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2 (UPI)Mickey Redmond registered his 19th and 20th goals of the season tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 64.

title: MILITARY LEADERS CONFER WITH SADAT
description: CAIRO, Jan. 2 (Reuters). President Anwar elSadat conferred today with military leaders on the Middle East situation, according to a brief Government announcement.

title: Mauro Scoccimarro Dies at 76; A Shaper of Italian Communism
description: ROME, Jan. 2  Senator Mauro Scoccimarro, a founder of the Italian Communist party, died here last night at the age of 76.

title: N.F.L. Owners Get Lie Detector Test
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League acknowledged yesterday that he had given lie detector tests to club owners In regard to gambling on professional football games.

title: Liberians Greet Mrs. Nixon Warmly
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 2 Mrs. Richard M. Nixon arrived in West Africa today for a oneweek goodwill tour in which, she said, she hoped to say hello to old friends and make a lot of new ones.

title: Danang Base Attacked
description: SAIGON, Monday, Jan. 3 (Reuters)Enemy gunners fired rockets into the large United States air base at Dating early today, apparently in retaliation for last week's bombing of North, Vietnam, military sources here said.

title: Trade Group Backs Investment Abroad
description: The National Foreign Trade Council, a group whose 600 company members play an active role in international business, has renewed its support for continued expansion of American investments abroad as. a means of strengthening the domestic economy and, the country's competitive position.

title: More and More Prefer Europe for a Weekend
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Pegott, who own a farm near Aurelia, Iowa, didn't spend New Year's Eve at home this year. They spent the weekend in Malaga, Spain, along with 158 fellow members of the Iowa Beef Producers Association.

title: Roosevelt Will Open Tonight; Court Ruling on OTB Awaited
Nebraska's Devaney Runs Out Of Challenges at College Level
description: MIAMI, Jan 2  Basking in the glow of what he termed the biggest Win of my career," Bob Devaney was asked about his future plans as football Coach at the University of Nebraska.

title: Israeli Armed Actions Listed
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 2 (AP)Isreel forces have entered Arab territory 5,270, times in land, sea and air military operations since the 1967 war, the former Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Haim BarLev, said in a television interview today. Only 577 of them were reported by the military spokesman, he said, but did not elaborate.

title: MYRON K. WEINBERG, MOVIE EXECUTIVE, 43
description: Myron K. Weinberg, a former vice president of the Allied Artists motion picture compEmy, died Thursday in an auto accident near Cheltenham, England. His age was 43. Mrs. Barbara Connell, a New York filmmaker, a passenger in the car, was also killed. The third passenger, David Bernstein, of New York, survived.

title: Bridge: Mela, Player of Year Here,  Shows Why He Is on Top
description: The New York PlayeroftheYear title for 1971 was won by Prank Mela, who is little known outside New York since he rarely plays in national Climpionships. Consistent success in the tournaments Of the Greater New York Bridge Association gave him the victory.

title: Miss Hernandez Bride
description: In the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon Miss Angelina R. Hernandez, who is with the offices of the Secretary General of the United Nations, was married to Gary L. Griffin, an art director with Benton & Bowles, Inc., the advertising agency. The Rev. Michael O'Connor performed the ceremony.

title: The BombingII: The Message
description: I can assure you tonight with confidence that American involvement in this war is coming to an end.

title: Sports of The Times
description: IRVING, Tex, Jan. 2The Dallas Cowboys, who lost the shabbiest Super Bowl game ever played last January, won the chance to do it again when they beat the San Francisco 49ers this afternoon in as dull a championship struggle as the National Football League has presented. It was the sort of entertainment that can make millions of fans for Roller Derby, but at least they had a nice day for it. Dazzling sunshine shone through the hole in the roof of Texas Stadium, a $25million blister on the plains here about seven miles from downtown Dallas and approximately halfway between Grapevine and Farmers Branch. The temperature was 48 degrees outside the gaudy ,playpen and as cozy as anybody chose in the mezzanine boxes, glassfronted cubicles 16 feet square that sell for $50,000 each. (Naturally, they come unfurnished; there's an extra charge for chairs, and it reported that one of the 80 purchasers has spent $58,000 prettying up his quarters.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Says Woman Could Be President
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 2 (UPI) President Nixon said today that a woman could become President of the United States, but he expressed a personal preference for Miss and Mrs. instead of the new feminine title Ms.

title: Mr. Bhutto's Ace
description: Zulfikar AU. Bhutto, a shrewd player of political poker, picked up a nearly hopeless hand when he assumed the presidency of a defeated and despairing Pakistan two weeks ago. But Mr. Bhutto inherited one ace that he obviously intends to play for all it Is worth in the delicate threeway diplomatic game now unfolding among Pakistan, India and the :breakaway Pakistani province of East Bengal, newly proclaimed as Bangladesh.

title: Dr. Gilbreth, Engineer, Mother of Dozen
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 2 (AP) Dr. Lillian Moller Gilbreth, pioneer in timemotion studies who was better known as the reallife mother of the family in the book and movie Cheaper by the Dozen, died today at the age of 93.

title: GROUP SEEKS TO CUT DISCOUNTS ON POWER
description: The National Audubon Society has filed a letter with the state's, Public Service CommisMon supporting a rate increase sought by the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Squires Drop Bill Bunting
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 2 (AP)The Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association placed 6foot8inch Bill Bunting on waivers today. He played in only 16 of the Squires 40 games.

title: Two Royal Suits of Jade Found in Chinese Tombs
description: Treasures from Chinese tombs, found during the Cultural Revolution but spared the destruction of relics that marked that upheaval, included two royal burial garments of jade, the like of which had been unknown.

title: A DISCLOSURE STUDY ASKED BY GOVERNOR
description: Governor Rockefeller asked the state Public Employment Relations Board ,yesterday study the problem of full public disclosure of governmentworker contracts and to make specific recommendations on the subject.

title: Nixon Bats an Amnesty Until the War Is Over
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2President Nixon said tonight in his teleVised intervie that he would not grant amnesty to Americans who have refused to serve in Vietnam, but he held out the possibility that there would be a liberal amnesty policy when there were no American troops in Southeast Asia.

title: Soviet Aide's Car Burns; Maryland Firemen See Arson
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md. Jan. (AP)The car of a Soviet Embassy official was virtually destroyed by fire early today, and firemen said they believe it was caused by arson.

title: MAJOR REVISION SET IN AID AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2A major reorganization of the Agency for International Development has been ordered by its administrator, John A. Hannah, to improve its operating efficiency and to reduce costs in line with the smaller role of American foreign aid.

title: Laurence Klurfeld Weds Miss Lewent
description: Miss Judith Carol Lewent was married here at noon yesterday to Laurence Franklin Klurfeld. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony in the Central Synagogue.

title: LOSS TAKEN HARD BY BUBBA SETH
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2 (AP)  I can't believe it. I don't understand what happened. I still don't believe we lost that game.

title: MRS, JAY CRANE
description: ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 2Mrs. Amy Nagel Crane, wife of Jay E. Crane, formerly vice president and director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Wednesday in Livingston, N.J. She was 77 years old and lived at 715 Berkeley Avenue.

title: Willis Hanks, Swimmer, Dies; Tried Crossings of Channel
description: Willis Hanks, a letter carrier here who tried unsuccessfully to swim the English Channel in 1953 and 1954, died Friday of a heart attack in Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx. He was 61 years old and lived at 818 East 22ad Street, the Bronx.

title: Britain Barred Proposal to Form Jewish Army Division in 44
description: LONDON, Jan. 2 Britain's War Minister in 1944, Sir. James Grigg, rejected as a Zionist ruse a preposal that Jews from around the .world form a dtvlsion of troops for the British Army.

title: PAKISTAN ORDERS  NATIONALIZATION OF 10 INDUSTRIES
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 2President Zulfikar All Bhutto today ordered the nationalization of major Pakistani Industries and moved to break up an undue concentration of economic power.

title: BRODIE WOULD LIKE TO HAVE PASS BACK
description: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 2 (UPI)John Brodie, the San Francisco quarterback, would be willing to play today's National Conference championship game all over again as it was played, except for one rather large detail. He would like to have that first errant pass back.

title: EXENVOY DENIESLINK TO PENTAGON PAPERS
description: HILLSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 2 (AP)The daughter of Vu Van Thai, the former South Vietnamese Ambassador to the United States who was named as a coconspirator in the Pentagon papers case, said today that her father told her he had never seen the documents.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: BOSTON, Jan, 2 (AP)Herbert G. Juster, 49 years old, who underwent heart transplant surgery at the Stanford University Medical Center eight months ago, died today of lung infection at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: 2,000 in Belfast Protest Internment of Suspects
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 2 (AP)  Two thousand people protesting the internment of suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas marched, sang and demonstrated in Belfast today without violence. Many marched in seven parades to a twohour rally, slowed here and there by British troops and the police, who made the paraders go through barricades two and three persons at a time.

title: KELLER SETS MARK IN SPEED SKATING
description: INZELL, Germany, Jan. 2 (AP)Erhard Keller of West Germany, the 1968 Olympic 500meter champion, broke the world speedskating record of 38.30 seconds for the distance today in competition on the Inzell artificial track.

title: CHEVALIER'S RITES SET FOR WEDNESDAY
description: PARIS, Jan. 2 (UPI)Trib, utes to Maurice Chevalier flowed in from all over the world today but in accordance with his last wishes his household turned away even close friends who came to say their last farewells.

title: Restoring Allied Unity
description: What happened at the NixonBrandt summit in Key Biscayne wits not. nearly, as important as what didn't happen: a planned meeting between Treasury Secretary Connally and German Finance. Minister. .Schiller. The absence of Mr. Connallywhose tactics for four months. heated up America's relations with its chief allies abroadconfirmed a turn away from goitalone policies by the United States.

title: MiniNader Crews Act on Complaints
description: There is a new phenomenom In the consumer movement these days: the miniNader.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNGLE OFFERS FUNDING PROGRAM
description: A plan to seek $25a year sustaining memberships to support headquarters operations of the currently debtridden Democratic State Committee was disclosed here yesterday by its new chairman, Joseph F. Crangle.

title: Japan, Inc., Shuts Down to Greet the Year of the Rat
description: TOKYO, Jan. 2  It was the day after New Year's and all over Tokyo, not a pollutant was visible, not even a photochemical molecule.

title: Spain Conquers U.S., 20, In Sunshine Cup Net Final
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 2 (AP)Spain defeated the United States in two straight singles matches today to capture the Sunshine Cup international junior tennis tournament.

title: Ellington to Take jazz to the Far East
description: Duke Ellington will climb aboard a plane tomorrow and, with his 17piece orchestra, take off for Japan where he will start another of the farflung, whirlwind tours that have become his regular way of life in recent years.

title: Pakistan Denies Report On Plan to Free Majib
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 2The Pakistan Government said today that Time magazine had misquoted President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto when it reported that he intended to release the Bengali leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, in a couple of days.

title: HARRY GREGG, 88, AN INDUSTRIALIST Founder of a Rehabilitation Home for Handicapped Dies
description: Harry A. Gregg, New England industrialist and financier who founded the Crotched Mountain Rehabiliatation Center for the physically handicapped at Greenfield, N. H., died yesterday at his winter home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived at the center.

title: MRS. ETHEL N. DANA, WRITER, DEAD AT 93
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 2Mrs. Ethel Nathalie Smith Dana, a writer and widow of Richard Henry Dana, the architect, died here Friday. She was 93 years old.

title: DeSota Outspeeds Schutz In Coast Motorcycle Event
description: VALENCIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)John DeSoto of Long Beach, Calif., held off Werner Schutz of West Germany in two straight heats today and won the open motorcycle competition in the manufacturers Gold Cup motocross. DeSoto rode Suzuki.

title: He Says U.S. Will Wind Up Its Role bat 25,000 G.I.'s Will Remain
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 President Nixon said tonight that the United States would continue to wind up its involvement in Vietnam in coming months, but said that 25,000 to 35,000 American troops would remain until the North Vietnamese released all the American prisoners of war.

title: Automobile Proliferation in Suburbs Becoming a Frustrating Problem for Planners
description: To Arthur Freed, Westchester's chief highway engineer, Christmas is really 25 per cent of the year.

title: Holiday Season Closes in a Gloomy Rain
description: Lowlying clouds shrouded the pinnacles of New York's skyscrapers and cast a pall of darkness over the city yesterday as the holiday weekend drew to a close with a steady, daylong rain that left sidewalks nearly deserted and streets slippery for thousands of homebound travelers.

title: Excerpts From the Television Interview With President Nixon at the White House
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Nixon by Dan Rather of the Columbia Broadcasting System last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Arranging an Adoption: Confusion and Red Tape
description: There are a few set procedures for those American families wanting to adopt Vietnamese children. Unlike Korean adoptions, where there are at least some clear avenues of approach, Vietnamese adoptions are hit miss, guessasyougo procedures where patience, unyielding determination and cultivation of the right people are the decisive factors.

title: Frostbite Regatta Off
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 2A 40knot wind kept the Dyer Dinghy fleet from sailing toddy in the American Yacht Club's annual threeday New Year's Frostbite invitation regatta. It was the second straight cancellation. Michael Calman of Mamaroneck, who led Friday, took the title.

title: Long Tieng Shelling Goes On
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)  Enemy artillery continued today to bombard Long Tieng, the most important Government military base in northern Laos, while, in the Governmentcontrolled parts of the country, legislative elections were held.

title: Floridians Cool Off Stars By Posting 119113 Triumph
Japanese Skier Triumphs
description: OBSERSTDORF, Germany, Jan. 2 (AP)Yuko Kasaya of Japan soared to his third straight victory in the fourhill ski jumping tournament today. He had leaps of 275 feet, 7 inches and 2722 for 247.9 points.

title: EdwardO'Shea,Gym Teacher  Who Was Starter at Garden
description: Edward A. O'Shea, a starter at track meets in Madison Square Garden and intercollegiate races, who retired as a physical education teacher at Far Rockaway High School last year, died Friday of a heart attack while on vacation in Townshend, Vt. He was 65 years old and lived at 105 Mohawk Avenue, Long Beach, LI.

title: Advertising:
description: For months now, publishers, salesmen and interested members of the financial community have been doing without their customary comparative reports on advertising linage as the 43yearold company tried to adapt itself to a computer world.

title: WILLIAM B. LEEDS, SPORTSMAN, DEAD
description: Heir to TinPlate Fortune Donated to Medical Causes

title: Kings Topple Canucks
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press)The Los Angeles Kings scored three goals in the third period to break a 33 tie and defeat he Vancouver Canucks, 63, in he National Hockey League oday before 15,570 fans.

title: Muskie Set for Entry Into Presidential Race
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Jan. 2 (UPI) Senator Edmund S. Muskie drove through snow and freezing rain to his cottage here on the Maine seacoast today to prepare for his formal entry into the race for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

title: The Size of Greatness
description: A charming little Colonial home in Morristown, N.J., served as the headquarters of the Continental Army and still had space to spare upstairs to house General and Mrs. Washington. It is a long journey from the days when the Supreme Commander could run and win a war, while living like a candy store owner above the nervecenter of operations.

title: Cowboys Send Owner of L.B.J. Ranch Home Happy
description: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 2Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, personally congratulated each of the Dallas Cowboys in the happy winners locker room shortly after their defensive masterpiece against the 49ers today.

title: A Journalist Is Linked To Murder of Bengalis
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 2To his fellow reporters on the Bengalllanguage paper where he'worked, Chowdhury 1V1ueenuddin was a pleasant, wellmannered and. intelligent young man. He had an open, handsome face, with a neatly trimmed beard, and there was nothing exceptional about him except perhaps that he often received telephone calls from the leader of a rightwing Moslem political party.

title: Lakers Capture 31st By Downing Celtics On Coast, 122 to 113
description: INGLE WOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers, their record winning streak threatened repeatedly, held on behind the 40point scoring of Gail Goodrich to beat the Boston Celtics, 122113, for their 31st straight victory tonight.

title: DAVID WITTES, 67, OF TEACHER UNION
description: David M. Wittes, treasurer of the United Federation of Teachers, and of the United Teachers of New York State, and trustee of the New York City Teachers Retirement Board, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 35 West 92d Street. He was 67 years old.

title: SOVIET PLAYWRIGHT EXPELLED BY UNION
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 3  A Jewish playwright and songwriter has been expelled by the Moscow Writers Union on the ground that he eneouraged Jews to emigrate to Israel, informed sources disclosed today.

title: 2 COMPANIES RAISE PRICES FOR COPPER
description: The Olin Corporation announced yesterday that its brass group had increased base prices of copper and copper alloy sheet and strip products 1.5 cents a pound, effectively immediately.

title: Amex Picks Senior Officer, 30
description: The American Stock Exchange moved yesterday to bridge the generation gap by naming Thomas E. McInerney, 30 years old, as a senior vice president.

title: Muskie and McCarthy Entered In Illinois Primary on March 21
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 3Petitions were filed today to enter Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota in the Democratic Presidential primary in Illinois. The primary, which will be March 21, is nonbinding.

title: 2 Assemblymen Ask Court to Halt Special Session
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3The premise of the current special legislative session Was attacked in State Supreme Court today by two Democratic Assemblymen who argued that the Governor had exaggerated the urgency of the fiscal problem in order to obtain a blank check of new taxes.

title: Buying Time in the Vietnam War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3President Nixon has now offered the outline of his plans for a fourth year of withdrawals from Vietnam, still leaving the end in doubt because he is still buying time to strengthen Saigon's forces and to improve the antiCommunist positions in Laos and Cambodia.

title: Pho, the North Vietnamese Soup, Catches On in Saigon, Too
description: SAIGONEvery morning, thousands of North Vietnamese, who came south before and after the partition of Vietnam in 1954, gather in sidewalk soup stalls of crowded, unpretentious shops in Saigon for a morning rituala bowl of pho, a beef and noodle soup they have preserved from their old lives back home.

title: Some Parents Dodge School Integration
description: ATLANTA; Jan. 3In Charlotte, N.C., a city caught up in the uncertainties of racial, change, there is a white man who dislikes what is happening so much that he is willing to pay for a $100amonth apartmerit near the downtown area while also making mortgage payments on the suburban house where he and his family live.

title: Suit Calls Kosher Slaughtering Unconstitutional
description: A suit was filled in Federal Court here yesterday challenging the constitutionality of laws that permit the Jewish ritual slaughter of livestock.

title: Do You Know Any 12 Year Old Junkies?
PricePosting by Stores Found Spotty
description: Retail stores in the New York area and in major cities across the country showed only spotty compliance yesterday with a new Federal order requiring the prominent display of base period price lists, a spot check by The New York Times indicated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBIN S. KERSH
description: Robin S. Kersh, a former vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, died Sunday in a nursing home in Peekskill, N. Y. He was 63 years old and formerly lived in Short Hills, N. J.

title: AGENCIES DIFFER OVER AIR MERGER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Justice Department and the Department of Transportation took opposing stands today on the proposed merger of American Airlines and Western Air Lines.

title: Aide Fears It May Be Overrun
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 3 (AP)  North Vietnamese troops jumped a 25MAR United States infantry patrol in jungles 40 miles northeast of Saigon yesterday and shot down three medical evacuation helicopters marked with red crosses trying to lift out the wounded. An observation helicopter also was shot down.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The campaign that year began with President Nixon sitting in our cellaron the television screen, of coursetalking to Dan Rather. Dan was with C.B.S. President Nixon was with the U.S. Government and traveled a lot.

title: Rich Pakistani Friend of Mujib Is a Refugee Here
description: Yusef Haroon, the head of one of Pakistan's wealthiest families, has decided to regard himself as a refugee here. His refuge is an elegant Fifth Avenue apartment with Italian marble floors, gilded Louis XV and Louis XVI furniture and an art collection that Includes numerous miniature paintings and illuminated Korans once prized by Mogul emperors.

title: Mrs. Nixon Sees Liberian's Inauguration
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 3William R. Tolbert Jr., 58yearold Baptist minister, was inaugurated as Liberia's 19th President today amid colorful celebrations in which Mrs. Richard M. Nixon played major role.

title: McGovern Spending Listed
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 3 (UPI) The Wisconsin McGovern for President campaign spent $22,504 in the state last year, the group said today. The organization, which is backing the candidacy of Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, called on other candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination to disclose all contributions and expenditures in Wisconsin last year.

title: Fischer and Spassky Match Draws High Cash Bids
description: The largest cash prizes in the history of tournament chess Sums up to $152,000were offered yesterday in the international competition for the site of next summer's world championship match between Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union. and Bobby Fischer of the United States.

title: Two Subsidiaries Combined By Aetna Life and Casualty
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 3 (AP) Aetna Life and Casualty announced today that two of its subsidiaries  Civic Finance Corporation and Amsterdam Overseas Corporation  had been combined into Aetna Business Credit, Inc.

title: Union Is Ordered To Reclassify 169 Of Minority Groups
description: A Federal judge here ordered a conStruction union yesterday to promote 169 black and Puerto Rican apprenticeswhom he namedto journeyman status.

title: Democrats Seek Time On,TV to Rebut Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The Democratic National Committee asked today for equal time on the Columbia Broadcasting System to rebut an hourlong television interview with President Nixon broadcast last night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C.M. to Close Plant
description: DETROIT, Jan. 3 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation said today it would close its Norwood, Ohio, plant for five weeks, starting Jan. 14, and furlough 3,600 of the 3,950 workers in order to change the plant over to production of Chevrolet Novas from Chevrolet and Pontiac sport cars.

title: ' Dynamite Chicken' Is Aimed at the Young
description: Having described "Dynamite Chicken," which landed at the Kips Bay yesterday, as a "multi-media movie magazine inspired by the TV generation," Ernie Pintoff, its producer-director, has almost said it all.In this case, the medium is mostly the message.
