description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 5 Though the years ski injuries have occurred most Often on slopes and trails, frequently producing leg fractures. In many cases such mishaps have resulted from faulty ski equipment or just carelessness.

title: Tensions Rise in Rockaway After Woman's Slaying
description: The important thing is to remain cool and let the police solve things, Mrs. Yetta Parnes was telling fellow tenants of her housing project in the Rockaways. We must not let outsiders and radicals stir things up, she said.

title: Dartmouth Earmarks $3Million for Center
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. (AP)Dartmouth College says a $3million gift will be used to finance construction of $5.3million physical sciences center.

title: Laotian Positions Attacked
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 5 (UPI)Coinraunist troops were reported attacking Government positions today along Route 13 about 55 milles north of here. The attacks followed fighting yesterday 115 miles to the north in Which a key road bridge was destroyed near the besieged Laotian guerrilla base at Long Tieng.

title: SONG RECITAL GIVEN BY LISANTI, A TENOR
description: Mario Lisanti, a tenor born and trained in New York who has sung here previously, came to Town Hall for a recital on Tuesday night. Accompanied by Mitchell Andrews, he offered a program that included SchuImann's Liederkreis and MenIOW's Canti della Lontanaza in addition to songs by Arne, IFalla, Rachmaninoff and Barber.

title: Emilio Schuberth, a Couturier In HighFashion, Dies in Rome
description: ROME, Jan. 5  Emilio Schuberth, couturier of royal families and movie stars, died of a heart attack last night in his Roman penthouse. He was 67 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The shortening of the 1971 Maine deer season in both the northern and southern zones has created some resentment among those who suddenly saw their projected hunting trips vanish into thin air.

title: Pirates'
description: Roberto Clemente, whose.414 batting average led the Pittsburgh Pirates to their World Series victory over the Baltimore Orioles, was named yesterday as the recipient of the Babe Ruth Award by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Outlook Is Promising for Forest Products
description: If the economy in 1972 works out the way most economists say it will, the year should be a very good one for the forest products industry.

title: C.B.S. Acquires TV Rights To Salinger's Instructions
description: Television rights to Pierre Salinger's suspense novel On Instructions of My Government have been acquired by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the story will be presented as a multipart motion picture on the network during the 197273 season.

title: EMILIO RIVERA, DEAN IN STATE UNIVERSITY
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 5Dr. Emilio Rivera, associate university dean for special programs of the State University of New York, died last night at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 42 years old and lived at 28 Lawrence Lane.

title: McCosey's Campaign: TruthinGovernment Issue Is Key Hope
description: CONCORD, N. HThe show, which had been falling all morning had stopped The old low red Cottage on the edge of Ddrham which had been Once a farmhouse looked like calenclart except for the Cars In the driveway and the big poster ir front with McCloskey in large red letters.

title: LOUISIANA OFFICIAL GETS JAIL FOR LYING
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 (AP)Attorney General Jack P. F. Gremillion of Louisiana, standing glum and silent beside his lawyer, was sentenced to three years in prison for lying to the Federal grand jury.

title: Allen of Redskins Wins Coaching Poll By a Wide Margin
JOANNA DE KEYSER, CELLIST, BOWS HERE
description: The debut program that Joanna de Keyser gave in Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night seemed to have two beginnings. A cellist who has performed extensively outside New York and is on the faculty of the University of New Mexico, she opened her recital promisingly with a Couperin suite. The tone was full and smooth, the pitch accurate, the rhythm steady, the phrasing flexible. It was a performance of sweetness and grace.

title: BENJAMIN MITGANG
description: Benjamin Mitgang, a retired dress contractor, died yesterday of a heart ailment at St. Jo. seph's Hospital in Far Rockaway in Far Rockaway, Queens He was 80 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: JAMES M. KELLY JR.
description: James M. Kelly Jr., supervisory customs inspector at Kennedv Airport since 1969, died Wednesday night while on a cruise aboard the Sea Venture. He was 54 years old and lived in Elmont, L. I.

title: Bengalis Seeking to Prevent Wheat Shipment to the West
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 6 (UPI)A representative of Bangladesh, the nation proclaimed by the Bengali secessionists in East Pakistan, sought today to halt 7,860 tons of American wheat from being shipped to West Pakistan, on the ground that it was originally intended for delivery in East Pakistan.

title: A Vacation to These TeenAgers Means Hard Work in a Hospital
description: A couple of 16yearolds, Isabel Camara and Jayalakshmi Menon, are back in the United Nations International School after a special Christmas holiday. At least it seemed special to them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Caledonian Rink Wins
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 6 The New York Caledonian Curling Club No. 2 rink, skipped by Archibald W. Smith, won an extraend match tonight from the Canadian Club of New York, in the first round of the 37th annual Douglas Medal bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Nixon Enters Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) President Nixon will formally declare himself a candidate for renomination and reelection in a letter to be made public tomorrow at Concord, N. H, authoritative sources reported in Washington today.

title: 53CENT INCREASE IN REAL TAX SEEN BY BUDGET GROUP
description: A shocking record 8.87 per cent increase in the local real estate tax was forecast yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, based on the estimate of the city's debt for 197273.

title: Dragons To Hang On Wall
description: When United States Customs lets a wall hanging enter this country duty free and gives It a certificate of authentication, it means that the Government officials consider it at least 100 years old. That is what happened with 75 embroidered wall hangings from China that Bloomingdale's will offer for sale in its sixthfloor rug department, starting today. The usual duty on Chinese embroideries is 90 per cent. Every hanging is in perfect condition, although some may be more than 300 years old. All are of silk, some with a satin finish, and the colors range from lacquer red to the most delicate of blues, with gold and silver threads used in profusion.

title: Innovative Theater Invades the Folger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The newest stage company in Washington is bringing youth and spirit to a periodpiece house that waited for regular theater for 40 years.

title: Fischer Due to Take On 20 In New Rochelle on Sunday
description: Bobby Fischer, who will play a match for the world chess championship with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union before the end of June, is scheduled for a simultaneous exhibition against 20 selected members of the Westchester Shore Chess Club at 3 P.M. Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Queens District Attorney, Thomas J. Mackell, announced yesterday the start of a grand jury investigation of infiltration of legitimate business in that borough by organized crime.

title: Administrative Post In Health Is Going To Dr. McLaughlin
description: The city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Mary C. McLaughlin, was appointed yesterday a deputy administrator of the Health Services Administration the superagency that reigns over the Departments of Health and Mental Health, the Medical Examiner's office and the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Triborough Tolls Cause Snarls Inside and Outside Cars
description: New, higher tolls on all facilities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which went into effect in time for the morning rush yesterday, caused confusion, delays and new traffic patterns.

title: AIRQUALITY PLAN OFFERED BY STATE
description: New York State presented its longawaited plan yesterday for meeting Federal air quality standards for the metropolitan region, which comprises New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland and Westchester Counties.

title: FORD URGES FUNDS FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: FLAT ROCK, Mich., Jan. 6  Henry Ford 2d recommended today that some of the Federal highway trust fund, used to build the nation's freeway system, be diverted toward mass transit.

title: College Fees Suggested
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6 (Reuters)  Governor Reagan asked the Legislature today to give state education trustees the power to impose tuition fees for the 242,000 students who attend 19 state colleges.

title: Lindsay. Questions Losses in Medicaid
description: Mayor Lindsay and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday questioned the estimate that almost a billion dollars went down the drain in the city's Medicaid program.

title: Mrs. Nixon Joins Dance At Chiefs Fete in Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 6 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon joined royal Ghanaian women in a traditional tribal dance today, executing a mincing little promenade at a lush hilltop festival held in her honor by Ghanaian chieftains.

title: Money Supply Rise Pushed
description: The Federal Reserve appear finally to be achieving some success in causing the money supplya widely watched indicator of credit policyto show greater expansion than the tiny growth that has prevailed since last summer.

title: In Re Stenos v. Machines: People Win
description: Court reporters have proved far superior to electronic devices in recording the proceedings in the city's courtrooms.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTONThe scramble for the Presidency is on, and as usual, it sounds as if the candidates disagree with one another on almost everything. But in their occasional candid moments, they all agree on at least one thing: that they have never been confronted with such an unpredictable electorate, or more baffled about how to deal with the rapidly changing patterns of American politics.

title: Marti, With 65, Leads on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (UPI) The 1972 Professional Golfers Association tour got off to a flying start in balmy weather today in the first round of the 72hole $125,000 Glen CampbellLos Angeles open, and Fred Marti, a 31yearold Texan, led the field by a stroke with a sixunderpar 65.

title: Laub Leads Bowling
description: After leading the $100,000 desperately not to get any Bowling Proprietor's Association of America United States Open tournament at Madison Square Garden for the last three days, Ernie Schlegel, a 29yearold from Newburgh, N. Y., is trying rest.

title: B52's Continue Heavy Bombing Of Border Regions for Third Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan:, 7 (AP)Wave after wave of American B52 bombers struck along the eastern borders of South Vietnam today.

title: Dill and White Wine Flavor This Salmon Dish
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by recipe.

title: End of a Fiscal Era...
description: The understandably reluctant decision of the State Legislature to impose $400 million in additional taxes brings New York to the end of a fiscal era. The decision had to be reluctant because New Yorkers are already the highest taxed citizens in the nation; and as members of the Legislature face elections this year, they can hardly have been eager to alienate any voters. The decision was made, nonetheless; and it was a responsible one. Additional revenues are absolutely essential to the maintenance of basic services.

title: Red Smith
description: Richard Nixon, the football strategist, favors the bomb with a downandin pattern and applauds the deception of the flanker reverse; Spiro Agnew is irrevocably committed to the shotgun attack; Edmund Muskie relies on the belly series; in longyardage situations, George Wallace goes the Statue of Liberty play; Gene McCarthy is strictly Wishbone man, and Hubert Humphrey clings to the old Minnesota shift. As for John V. Lindsay, give him the quarterback sneak anytime. New York's Mayor employed the maneuver successfully again this week when the City Planning Commission picked out Yankee Stadium for urban renewal. This was a trap up the middle enabling the Mayor to finance his $24million plan to buy and refurbish the old ballpark without approval of the Board of Estimate. The urbanrenewal designation permits use of capital budget funds earmarked for commercial and industrial redevelopment, without consulting the Board of Estmate or holding a public hearing.

title: Councilmen Find Mixed Results In Housing Rebuilt With Loans
description: A City Council committee that is preparing a report on the scandalridden Muncipal Loan Program took its , first look yesterday at rehabilitated housing financed under the program.

title: Executive Changes
description: Lord & Taylor, the largest store division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, announced yesterday that a new management team has been appointed, effective Feb. 1. William J. Lippincott, president, has been named chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds Melvin E. Da*ley, who has been with Lord & Taylor for 35 years and now will become honorary chairman. The management reorganization involves the appointment of an executive committee headed by Mr. Lippincott. It also will include Harry A. Murray, vice chairman, who has been appointed president, and Joseph H. Johnson, senior vice president of finance, who has been named executive vice president and chief finance officer.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: The latest stock market advance kept moving along yesterday on heavy volume amid signs of increased public participation.

title: 2 in Motorcycle Gang Held In Rape on Staten Island
description: Two members of a motorcycle gang were arrested on, Staten Island last night and charged with rape and sodomy in an assault at gunpoint on two young women.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor;

title: New Trial for Rep. Dowdy Urged in Plea to Court
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 6 (AP)Attorneys for Representative John Dowdy filed a motion for acquittal in United States District Court today and requested a new trial on his bribery conspiracy conviction,

title: ... Beginning Transit Subsidies
description: The transit fare package worked out among city and state political leaders is essentially a subsidy package. The fare has been raised a nickel, but, without revenues from increased bridge and tunnel tolls and loans from both city and state, the fare would have been increased much more.

title: SALES SHOW RISE AT RETAIL CHAINS
description: Strong late Christmas buying by consumers and a continuation of the trend into the month's final week provided number of the country's largest retail chains with substantial gains in business in December over the 1970 month

title: Enemy Sets P.O.W  Price: Abandon Thieu and Leave
description: PARIS, Jan. 6The Vietnamese Communists told the United States at the Paris talks today that it could not have its prisoners back until it agreed both to withdraw its forces and to abandon the Saigon regime of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Dr. King's Followers Modify His Approach in Their Continuing Pursuit of Social Change
description: ATLANTAThe survivors of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. are still searching for the answers he died looking for.

title: XAVIER VALLAT, AIDE TO PETAIN, DIES AT 81
description: PARIS, Jan. 6Xavier Vallat, who was Marshal Philippe Petam's first Commissioner for Jewish Questions, died today at Annonay, in Southern France at the age of 81.

title: The Market Takes Over
description: The discipline of the market place is proving, more effective than price controls in combating inflation steel. Customer resistance, coupled with competition from lowercost foreign steel and from such domestic rivals as prestressed concrete, plastics and fiberglas, has forced the major steel companies to roll back some of the price boosts authorized less than a month ago by the Price Commission.

title: Odom of A's Shot, But Hurler Escapes Permanent Injury
description: MACON, Ga. Jan. 6 (AP).A wouldbe burglar shot John (Blue Moon) Odom twice at close range today, but the Oakland Athletics pitcher apparently suffered no permanent injury.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe new Asia policy of the United States is inextricably involved in the old Asia policy that shaped up eater World War II but was most clearly articulated by Foster Dulles during the Eisenhower Administration.

title: Retail Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Department of Commerce reported today that retail store sales for the week ended Jan. 1 were an estimated $7.281billion, an increase of 9 per cent above the $6.695billion sales for the corresponding week last year. Total department store sales for the latest week were an estimated $722million, 10 per cent above the $655million sales for the same period last year.

title: Environment: The Cost Is to Care
description: ANCHORAGE, AlaskaThere arc those in business who say we cannot afford to care. These are the ones who, knowingly or unknowingly, would destroy both the environment and business itself.

title: Youths Rape Woman in Park
description: A 21yearold woman was raped by two youths who followed her into a ladies room near Bethesda Fountain in Central Park at. 9 A.M. yesterday. The police said they were looking for two young white males in their mid20's in the assault, which did not involve robbery.

title: Networks Giving Democrats Reply Time on State of Union
description: The major broadcasting networks will give the Democratic Congressional leadership an opportunity to reply to President Nixon's State of the Union message Jan. 20, network spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty In a Midwest Hijacking
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (UPI) Everett L. Holt, 25 years old, of Indianapolis, pleaded not guilty today to charges stemming from the Christmas eve hijacking of a Northwest Airlines flight from Minneapolis.

title: New Group Will Seek Convention Delegate Reforms
description: Stewart R. Mott, the politically active philanthropist, announced yesterday, the formation of People Politics, a, committee that will raise funds for oiganizations seeking. greater reptesentation of women, blacks and youths at this'year's national political conventions.

title: Tuna Boats Head for Ecuadorand Possible Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Thirty United States tuna boats were reported moving today from Panama and San Diego, Calif., toward the coast of Ecuador as the new yellowfin tuna season gets under way. Last year United States, ships caught $17million worth of tuna off Ecuador and Peru.

title: Bombs Over Thanhhoa
description: LONDON  We visited Thanhhoa Province in September of last year. A large part of North Vietnam was under water owing to the overflowing of the Red River during the monsoon; the floods were the worst since 1885.

title: Gibson Assails City Council in Newark
description: NEWARK, Jan. 6A longfestering political dispute between Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and the ninemember City Council broke into the open today as the city's financial problems continued to mount.

title: Surrender on 42d Street
description: The recent episode of a smalltime bank robber, cornered on 42d Street near Times Square by two brave and conscientious bank employes but set free by hostile crowd of hoodlums, puts the spotlight on an untenable situation. The fact that a criminal could be chased for more than two blocks in broad daylight in busy and.notoriously crimeprone area without encountering a police officer, can only lead the ordinary citizen to reconsider the wisdom of walking there at all.

title: DR. SHELDON MYERS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 6Dr. Sheldon S. Myers, chairman of the mathematics department, test development division of the Educational Testing Service, died yesterday of a heart attack in Princeton Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 111 Madison Street.

title: Advertising:
description: When the people who run and advise the Ivy League alumni magazines decided it was time to get a new national advertising representative they went about it much as an advertiser might seek out an agency.

title: OUTOFTOWNERS GIVE TO NEEDIEST Some of 388 Contributors Specify Who Is to Benefit
Notes on People
description: Erik Bruhn, who was scheduled to dance with American Ballet Theater in its current season here until he was taken ill last week, announced yesterday that he was retiring from his performing career.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR DENOUNCES BOMB AS INHUMAN
description: Mayor Lindsay criticized as inhuman yesterday the American use of a land clearing bomb in Vietnam that, he said, was as powerful as a small atomic bomb.

title: ROLFE TO REJOIN RANGERS SUNDAY
description: Dale Rolfe has just about recovered from his unwanted Christmas present, and chances are good that he will return to the Rangers lineup for Sunday's game against Los Angeles at Madison Square Garden.

title: WHITE MOTOR PLANS 1,320JOB CUTBACK
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 (UPI)The White Motor Corporation announced today it would phase out operitions of its MinneapolisMoline farmmachinery division this year, with the elimination of 1,320 Jobs.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PEACEABLE KINGDOM, By Jan de Hartog. 677 pages. Atheneum. 10.

title: HOOVER SAYS TAPS GAIN CONVICTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, 'said today that conviction of gangsters had increased and much of the credit had to be given to evidence gleaned from electronic surveillance devices.

title: Monetary Change Urged
description: DETROIT,. Jan. 6 (UPI)The United States and its trading partners must restructure the world's monetary system if world inflation is to be brought under control, Henry Ford 2d said today.

title: Price Commission Chief Hails Steel Cut
description: C. Jackson Grayson Jr., chairman of the Price Commission, said yesterday he was delighted with the rollback of steel prices that was inaugurated Wednesday by the United States Steel Corporation and followed yesterday by a number of other steelmakers.

title: Advertising:
description: McCannErickson officially, announced yesterday that Richard S. Lessler, chairman of Grey Advertising, will be joining McCann on Jan. 17 as vice chairman.

title: THEATER REVIEW SET FOR SALE AT TIMES
description: The New York Times Theater Reviews, comprising more than 21,000 complete reviews republished in eight volumes, are now available at the Library and Information Services Division of The Times, 229 West 43d Street. The twovolume index to the set, which sells for $850, will be published in March.

title: M'CARTHY TO RUN IN PRIMARY HERE
description: Declaring that all his competitors for the Democratic Presidential nomination look like losers, Eugene J. McCarthy, a 1968 loser himself, announced yesterday that he would field a slate of delegate candidates in New York's June 20 Presidential primary.

title: 3 in Penn Central Case Freed on $50,000 Bail
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) The former financial chairman of the Penn Central Transportation Company and a business associate were freed here today on $50,000 bail each on charges of conspiring to divert more than $21million from the railroad's treasury for themselves and others.

title: It's a Wonderful Town
description: The chorus of voices crying out against the daytoday living and working in Manhattan is increasing. I have to admit I've been one of the voices.

title: CONDORS DEFEATED BY SQUIRES, 137130
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 6 (AP)The Virginia Squires survived a 43point effort by Pittsburgh's Bob Verga and defeated the Condors for the seventh time in seven meetings, 137130, in the American Basketball Association tonight.

title: ANTITRUST ACTION IN CEREAL STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Claiming that cereals take too much of the breakfast dollar, the Federal Trade Commission staff has recommended landmark antitrust suit, aimed at breaking up the Kellogg Company and General Mills, Inc.

title: Keating Held Not Unhappy Over Leak of Policy Cable
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 6Sources close to Ambassador Kenneth B. Keating indicated today that he was not unhappy about the disclosure of his secret cablegram to Washington taking issue with American policy on the IndianPakistani war.

title: Miss Struthers Gains
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 6 (AP)  Mary Struthers I of La Jolla, Calif., advanced today to the women's singles semifinals of the Auckland tennis championships with a 62 63 victory over New Zealand's June Fraser.

title: Meehan, Performer, Outshines Meehan, Writer of Song Lyrics
description: Eight or 10 years ago, Danny Meehan was a dazzling singer and dancer in nightclubs, a wrapup of showbusiness history who could remind listeners of Garland, Jolson, Gene Kelly and Sinatra all in the space of a single song and still come out with some qualities that were his own. He had bounced his way through numerous flop shows and finally made it on Broadway and made it bigin Funny Girl, although there was a girl in that show named Barbra Streisand who slightly overshadowed him. Still, despite that shadow, Mr. Meehan was noticed.

title: Pullout Hits Saigon Plaque Business
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6  The small shops that have had a booming business making commemorative plaques for sale to Americans are falling on hard times.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL COMPLEX CALLED SNAKE PIT
description: The Queens Medical Center, the largest municipal hospital in the borough, was called a snake pit yesterday by Queens Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. after he toured the institution for two hours, accompanied by the director of the hospital and another Councilman.

title: Political Philanthropist Stewart Rawlings Mott
description: His health is good, he points out on his biographical fact sheet, his draft status IY, and he is a bachelor with type AB+ blood. What Stewart Rawlings Mott does not and does not need toinclude on the fact sheet is his financial status: annual income in the neighborhood of $1million. Mr. Mott, 34 years old, announced yesterday that he was setting up a political fundraising committee known as People Politics. His own contribution, at least for openers, was $100,000, out of a total of $500,000 he hopes to raise. $1million. Mr. Mott, 34 years old, announced yesterday that he was setting up a political fund raising committee known as People Politics. His own contribution, at least for openers, was $100,000, out of a total of $500,000 he hopes to raise.

title: DUAL AUTHORITY OF A.E.C. SCORED
description: Six environmental organizations filed a lawsuit in a Federal court yesterday to challenge the constitutionality of legislation giving the Atomic Energy Commission authority both to promote and to regulate the nuclear industry.

title: EastWest Troop Cuts
description: President Nixon's disclosure to Chancellor Brandt that he would discuss troop reductions in Europe when he goes to Moscow in May reinforces a growing feeling that EastWest talks on the subject are seriously stalled. Mr. Nixon assured the West Germans, nervous after his many unilateral economic and diplomatic surprises since July, that he would not strike a separate bargain with the Russian on military cutbacks. But the real question right now apparently is less what kind of bargain to reach than how to get negotiations under way at all.

title: Stanton, in Letter to Congress, Opposes Accord on Cable TV
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System voiced vigorous objection yesterday to the Nov. 10 agreement that was designed to conciliate broadcasters and cable television operators.

title: SEARCHERS REACH PERU CRASH SITE
description: PUCALLPA, Peru, Jan. 6 (UPI)A Peruvian Air Force helicopter landed today at the wreckage of a domestic airliner that crashed on Christmas Eve with 92 persons aboard. The helicopter crew reported no signs of life.

title: Printer Rejects Newspaper
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 6 (AP) A printing company has refused to publish, the latest issue of Take Over, an underground newspaper here, because it believes the paper is obscene, Mark Knops, its editor, said today. The issue turned down by Port Publications, Inc., of Port Washington, deals with homosexuality, Mr. Knops said. The newspaper is being printed in Chicago.

title: Shiny and Silent Test Train Gets Vote of Straphangers
description: Somewhere these days on the 720 miles of subway tracks that wind throughout the city, there is a shiny, clean, new train with good lighting, doors that go ping ping before they close and ark interior so quiet that, at times, the rustle of a newspaper can be heard 10 seats away.

title: 9 COMPANIES ASKED TO BID ON NEW JET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The Air Force offered nine companies otday a chance to compete in developing a new lowcost, lightweight jet fighter plane.

title: HIGHER L.I. FARE STIRS OPPOSITION
description: MINEOLA, LI., Jan. 6Long Island Rail Road commuters, faced with an almost certain fare increase of 20 per cent on an average trip, starting Feb. 1, reacted today in customary fashion with annoyance, frustration and resignation.

title: NELSON L. PAGE
description: STANFORD, Conn., Jan. 6Nelson L. Page, civic leader and founder of an architectural firm that bears his name, died today at Stamford Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at Mansfield Avenue, Darien.

title: Heart Fund Gets $70,000
description: The Jack KriendlerCharlie Berns Foundation presented check for $70,000 yesterday to the New York Heart Association in behalf of the 1972 Heart Fund campaign.

title: KNICKS TO OPPOSE SLUMPING 76ERS
description: After achieving a satisfactory split of two games in a homeandhome series earlier this week against the Milwaukee Bucks, the champions of the National Basketball Association, the Knicks will face opposition of a far less potent caliber tonight against the 176ers in Philadelphia.

title: Nixon Meeting With Sato In Effort to Rebuild Trust
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 6  President Nixon and Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan began two days of meetings here today in an effort to rebuild the, sense of confidence between the two nations, which has been greatly diluted over the last six months.

title: Sharp Welfare Rise Predicted in City
description: A steady rise in the city's welfare rolls to a record total of 1,340,000 cases by June, 1973one of every six New Yorkerswas forecast yesterday by the Human Resources Administration.

title: CHILEAN MINISTER CENSURED BY HOUSE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan (UPI)The Chilean Chamber of Deputies censured Interior Minister Jose Toha tonight, forcing his suspension from the Cabinet pending Senate action.

title: Upsala Is Victor, 8077
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. (AP)  Upsala defeated Elizabethtown, 8077, in basketball tonight. Dan Woodard of Elizabethtown was high scorer with 21 points.

title: Liguori One Foot From Munich
description: Marty Liguori got out of bed yestereday and gently lowered his left foot to the floor of his Philadelphia apartment. For the first time in months, he said, he could walk on the foot without pain.

title: Dr Howard F. Shattuck Dead; Internist and Professor Was 84
description: Dr. Howard F. Shattuck, an internist who served as president of the Medical Board of Roosevelt Hospital from 1947 to 1948 and as clinical professor of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia from 1936 to 1952, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 84 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Sales of Savings Bonds Fell Daring December
description: Sales of E and H bonds last month totaled $439million while redemptions plus interest payments came to $429million, it was reported yesterday by the Treasury ,Department in Washington. This compared with sales of $457million and redemption and interest payments of $400million in November.

title: MISS TUERO WINS, GAINS SEMIFINALS
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 6 (AP)Linda Tuero of Metaire, La., the only American left in the Sugar tennis tournament, gained the semifinals today with a 63, 60 triumph over Greta Delport of South Africa.

title: Slopes Will Be covered By Snow (and Skiers)
description: The best overall conditions of the season are expected to prevail throughout the North Country this weekend. As a result, skiers probably will be all over the whiteblanketed landscape in their search for top sport. Aware that such bright prospects mean that skiing's clientele will be well distributed and that it might cost his area some customers, Orvil Slutzky of Hunter Mountain, nevertheless, expressed delight yesterday over the highly promising picture.

title: Reagan Calls for an Overhaul of School Financing
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP)Gov. Ronald Reagan told the California Legislature today that he would hold the line on state spending and taxes in 1972. He also said that he wanted sweeping reform of public school financing and that he would close San Quentin Prison.

title: Agreement Averts A Strike by 9,800 At Nursing Homes
description: A strike by 9,800 employes of 91 proprietary nursing homes was averted early today when a union representing the employes reached a contract agreement with the Metropolitan New York Nursing Home Association.

title: TV: Zoom, Bright Fun and Games for Ages 7 to 12
description: If there is one area in which the record of public television sparkles, it is in programing for children. While the commercial networks juggle cartoons, advertising excuses, noble theories and expensive disasters, the Public Broadcasting Service is able to offer Sesame Street, The Electric Company, Misterogers Neighborhood and now, beginning this Sunday at 7 P.M. a weekly halfhour series called Zoom.

title: WALDHEIM UPHOLDS THANT ON NEWSMEN
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 6 (Reuters)  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim declined today to reinstate two Chinese Nationalist correspondents whose accreditation was withdrawn last month by his predecessor, U Thant.

title: Long Tieng a Ghost Town
description: VIENTIANE Laos, Jan. 6(AP)Long Tiengthe once secret espionage and guerrilla base in northern Laos,  is al ghost town.

title: Bhutto Would Visit Dacca As a Step to Revive Unity
description: LARKANA, Pakistan, Jan. President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said today that he was prepared to go to Dacca if it would help keep East Bengal a part of Pakistan.

title: Joseph Morecraft Jr., 81, Dies; Led Jersey Turnpike Authority
description: DUNELLEN, N. J., Jan. 6 Joseph Morecraft Jr., a member of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority since 1954 and its chairman from 1959 to 1970, died Tuesday. He was 81 years old and lived here.

title: SOVIET SIX GETS 5 GOALS EARLY, DEFEATS U.S.,114
description: Playing checkers with the puck, the Soviet Union's national hockey team moved to an 114 victory over the United States last night in the visitors Madison Square Garden debut before 14,823 fans.

title: DR. ROBERT BUSH, PSYCHOLOGIST, 51
description: Dr. Robert R. Bush, professor of psychology and former chairman of the Department of Psychology at Columbia University, was found dead Wednesday in his apartment at 142 West End Avenue. He was 51 years old.

title: NEW HAVEN LINE PLANS A 20% RISE
description: The 26,500 commuters who ride the Penn Central's New Haven Division trains  many of whom are still angry over selective fare increases that took effect last Saturdaywere told yesterday that they faced a further acrosstheboard rise of 20 per cent.

title: 1971 compensation Up 9% For A.M.C.'s Top Officers
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP)The American Motors Corporation, which recovered from a deep loss to an $11.2million profit last year, increased compensation to its top officers by 9 per cent in 1971.

title: CLOSED TRIAL WON BY 2D DEFENDANT
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Jan. 6 Citing as a precedent the recent trial of Carmine J. Persico, which was closed to the public, an alleged arsonist here has just won the right to a closed trial of his own.

title: F.C.C. Member Is Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Richard E. Wiley, a lawyer from Northbrook, Ill., has been sworn in as a member of the Federal Communications Commission for a term that will expire in 1977.

title: Citing Rule Breaches, N. A. S. D. Disciplines 7 Firms, 19 Others
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc , which regulates the overthecounter market, announced today that it had disciplined seven firms and 19 persons for allegedly violating its rules of fair practice.

title: Market Place: Expert's View Of Aero Issues
description: Who's that petite woman carrying seven boxes of used Size 12 dresses from Bergdorf Goodman's to the Good Will box?

title: Security Pacific Reports
description: Security Pacific National Bank, the nation's 10th largest bank, announced yesterday that its operating income for the fourth quarter of 1971 declined to $13,104,351, or 64 cents a share, from $16,440,707, or 80 cents a share in the year ago period.

title: Connor Urges Delay On CleanWater Bill
description: John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, charged yesterday that a waterquality bill pending in Congress would damage the United States economy. He urged that waterpollution legislation be taken out of the inevitable politics of a national election year.

title: Thomas B. Shortman, 71, Dead; Headed Service Employes Union
description: UNION, N. J., Jan. 6Thomas B. Shortman, president of Local 32B, Service Employes International Union, A.F.L.C.I.O., died today, apparently of a heart ailment, at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He was 71 years old.

title: Meskill Acts on AtomSub Incident
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 6A minor accident involving a nuclearpowered submarine that on Dec. 29 discharged 500 gallons of atomicreactor coolant into the Thames River here has raised a larger issue: the accountability of the military to the civilian environment in which it operates.

title: ENOCH R. NEEDLES, DESIGNED BRIDGES Partner in Large Consulting Engineering Firm Dies
description: Enoch R. Needles, retired principal partner of Howard, Needles, Tammen & Bergendoff, consulting engineers of New York, died Wednesday in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in New Vernon, N. J.

title: South African Officer Killed
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 6A South African police sergeant was killed and three policemen were injured by a land mine in the Caprivi Strip, the police announced here today. The strip is at the northeast corner of SouthWest Africa and borders on Angola, Zambia, Botswana and Rhodesia. It is administered by the South African Government.

title: U.S.Hong Kong Pact Set
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 6 (AP)Limits on the growth of exports of manmade fibers and woolen textiles to the United States from the four major East Asian producing countries were completed today, when Hong Kong and the United States signed a formal agreement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Are Arrested in IND In Protest Over Fare
description: Nine men and time women were arrested by Transit Authority police detectives at the IND subway station at 34th Street and the Avenue of the Americas last night after they allegedly urged riders to jufnp turnstiles and not pay the fare.

title: 2,320 ON RELIEF IN STATE GOT JOBS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6A total of 2,320 welfare recipients found jobs during November, and 4,335 persons were removed from the relief rolls for failing to accept work after being deemed employable, Governor Rockefeller's office reported today.

title: Mrs. Booth Retains Lead With 143 in Florida Golf
description: SEBRING, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP)Mrs. Jane Bastanchury Booth of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., shot a 75 today for a tworound total of 143 and a fivestroke lead in the Harder Hall invitation golf tournament.

title: St. Anselm's Elects Abbot
description: MANCHESTER, N. FL, Jan. 6 (AP)  The Right Rev. Joseph Gerry today was elected abbot of St. Anselm's Abbey and chancellor of St. Anselm's College. The Benedictine monks selected Father Gerry, 45 years old, to replace the Right Rev. Gerald McCarthy, 59, who resigned from the positions at the Roman Catholic institution on Dec. 27 for health reasons.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Protection of Small IceAge Fish Gives Hope That Even Man Can Survive
description: At first glance, the effort to save the Devil's Hole pupfish from extinction seems absurd. After all, of what value are a few small creatures that have managed to survive in a small pool left over from the Ice Age?

title: Waiting for Mujib, Bengalis Delay Key Decisions
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan.  The name of this game is waiting for the Sheik, diplomat remarked today as he looked out his office window at a stream of cars and buses, each with a large picture of Sheik Mujibur Rahman on its front windshield.

title: WITNESS RELEASED IN MYSTERY DEATH
description: Jean Litz was released from Civil Jail last night after being held there for 35 days as material witness in the death of a doctor's 30yearold medical assistant.

title: Rodriguez Cards 66 Again
description: SAN JUAN, Jan. 6 (AP)Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez carded a course record sixunderpar 66 for the second straight day to win the 10th Dorado Beach proamateur golf tournament today with a 204 score. Jesus Gonzalez and Bob Watson of New Rochelle, N. Y., finished in a tic for second at 212.

title: WARRIORS CAPTURE 4TH IN ROW, 119115
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 6 (UPI)Torrid shooting by Nate Thurmond and Jeff Mullins led the Golden State Warriors to their fourth straight victory tonight, a 119115 decision over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: THOUSANDS DELAYED IN IND DERAILMENT
description: Five cars of a 10 car D express train derailed yesterday as it headed downtown out of the IND station at Columbus Circle. Two persons were slightly injured and subway service was disrupted into the evening rush hour, delaying thousands headed downtown and for Brooklyn.

title: DR. ANTHONY CIOCCO, BIOMETRICIAN, DIES
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6Dr. Anthony Ciocco, professor of biostatistics at the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health, died yesterday here. His age was 63.

title: QUEENS BUS UNION REJECTS CONTRACT
description: The Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 1056, which represents 1,700 Transit Authority bus drivers and maintenance workers in Queens, voted yesterday to reject the contract agreed upon New Year's Day by the Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority.

title: TROOPERS PRAISED FOR ATTICA ACTION
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6Russell G. Oswald, the state's Commissioner of Correctional Services, has offered praise for the bravery and restraint of the state policemen who stormed the Attica Correctional Facility last Sept. 13 and put down a fiveday inmate rebellion with a loss of 43 lives.

title: U.S. COURT CLEARS LAZARD FUND SALE
description: A proposed, $1million settlement of litigation arising from the sale by Lazard Freres & Co. of the Lazard Fund, Inc., in 1967 was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Murray I. Gurfein.

title: Jersey Orders Yearly Test For CarExhaust Pollution
description: TRENTON, Jan. 6Regula tions requiring drivers to get their cars inspected once a year for exhaust pollution were promulgated here today by New Jersey environmental authorities.

title: City Will Move to Prevent a Ban on Abortions
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that in the immediate future, at leastthere would be no disruption of abortion services at the municipal hospitals.

title: GIOVANNI FALCK, 71, STEEL MAKER, DEAD
description: ROME, Jan. 6  Giovanni Falck, who for 22 years headed one of Italy's largest iron and steel concerns, died at his home in Milan today after a threemonth illness. He was 71 years old.

title: MUSKIE BIDS U.S. GET OUT OF WAR
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 6 Senator Edmund S. Muskie declared here tonight that it was time for the United States to withdraw completely from South Vietnam regardless o the consequences.

title: BRUINS WIN,52, AND LEAD IN EAST
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 6 (UPI) Phil Esposito, Fred Stanfield and John McKenzie scored powerplay goals tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 52, to extend their unbeaten string to 11 games and move into first place in the East Division of the National Hockey League for the first time this season.

title: Nations Cautious on Bangladesh
description: UNITED NATIONS, NY., Jan. 6  Governments are following a cautious policy on recognition of Bangladesh, the new nation proclaimed by Bengali separatists in East Pakistan.

title: A U.S. TV INTERVIEW USED IN SOVIET TRIAL
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6A Moscow newspaper said today that an American television interview was presented as prosecution evidence against a Soviet dissident sentenced yesterday to seven years deprivation of freedom and five years enforced residence.

title: Whitney's Eye on Envoy's Post
description: Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney announced yesterday that although he doesn't want to be Ambassador to Spain nowa post he hasn't been offeredhe hoped he would still be considered after the November election so that I would have four years to devote to it.

title: PAY BOARD SETS AEROSPACE LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6  The Pay Board decided today to give the aerospace industry one week without interference to begin voluntary renegotiation of the wage contracts rejected by the board yesterday.

title: APRIL TARGET SEEN FOR MISSILES CURB
description: VIENNA, Jan. 6The United States and the Soviet Union reportedly plan to continue negotiations here for three and a half months, if necessary, in an effort to agree on a treaty limiting strategic nuclear weapons before President Nixon's visit to Moscow next spring.

title: Drinking at 18 Is Barred
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. (AP)The House of Representatives yesterday defeated measure that would have lowered Pennsylvania's legal drinking age to 18. By overwhelming margins, the House approved 31 measures Tuesday and yesterday that extend adult duties and priviliges to 18yearolds. But the most controversial proposal in the package, the drinking bill, was turned back 125 to 63.

title: How to Beat the Tolls (and Eat Up Gas)
description: Armed with a little ingenuity  and a good deal of timeit is possible to drive almost anywhere within four boroughs of New York and Nassau and Westchester Counties and avoid both the tolls that were increased Wednesday and the tolls that were not.

title: Concept of Space Shuttle Points To Cape Kennedy for Launching
description: The space shuttle concept endorsed by President Nixon makes it all but certain that Cape Kennedy, Fla., will be the launching base for the new rocket plane.

title: YALE'S PROBATION LIFTED BY N.C.A.A.
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 6The twoyear probation imposed upon Yale's varsity sports program as the result of the Langer Case was quietly lifted yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council.

title: MATT CLARK, ARTIST FOR MAGAZINES, 68
description: Matt Clark, a magazine illustrator, died yesterday of heart attack in New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 400 East 55th Street.

title: Stage: Narrow Road to Deep North
description: Perhaps I was wrong about Edward Bond's Narrow Road to the Deep North, for we all make mistakes. The play made its New York debut at the Vivian Beaumont Theater last night and I found it distressingly tedious. This is fair enough opinion  even the paying audience appeared to be faintly soporific  but it hardly coincides with my previously expressed views on the play. Was I wrong in the first place, or is merely the Lincoln Center Repertory Company wrong in the second? Let discuss this.fant destined to grow up as Shogotyrant, hero, man of action, Perhaps he should have killed it thenbut he proceeded northward on his lean, cold journey to enlightenment. Where then was his responsibility?

title: Jackson, in Florida, Seeks Wallace Vote
description: APALACHICOLA, Fla., Jan. 6 Senator Henry M. Jackson has invaded northern Florida's Wallace country in an attempt to make a strong showing in the state's Democratic, primary March 14.

title: Gatehouse Is Named National Horse Show President
description: Woodrow G. (Woody) Gatehouse, who worked his way up from the stable committee, yesterday was elected the 15th president of the National Horse Show at the annual meeting of the organization's board of directors.

title: Winning Jersey Numbers
description: ECHELON, N. J., Jan, 6 (UPI) The winning number chosen here today in the state's weekly lottery is 103163. The semifinal number in the $2,50 lottery is 9134 and the semifinal number in the 50cent millionaire lottery is 924,

title: Blues Subdue Flyers, 32, After Fighting With Fans
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) The St. Louis Blues rallied for three goals in the final period tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Flyers, 32, in a meleefilled National Hockey League game at the Spectrum.

title: Bottler Fights a Trend, Pleads for Returnables
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa.  When the trucks of the Chokola Beverage Company make their rounds delivering soft drinks here, they carry a message on a prominent blue bumper stickerFor Earth's Sake Buy Returnables.

title: Trial Lawyers in State Assail NoFault Car Insurance Plan
description: A public debate equal to that which erupted over the trans portation bond issue was predicted by the New York State Trial Lawyers Association. yesterday as it opened its campaign against the nofault auto insurance plan.

title: F.T.C. Urges Free Air Time For Answers to Some TV Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Federal Trade Commission said today that radio and television stations should be required to provide free time for the broadcasting of replies to commercials that raise issues of current public importance.

title: SHULTZ REPORTS NEW NIXON BUDGET ASKS NO SALES TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6President Nixon's budget chief said today that there would be no proposal for a valueadded tax"a form of Federal sales taxin the President's new budget.

title: INDIAN OCEAN ROLE IS PLANNED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Defense Department said today that the Navy would conduct periodic operations in the Indian Ocean to help establish an American presence in a new area of strategic rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union.than stationing a permanent surface force in the ocean, would continue to send in patrols, but larger ones and more frequently.

title: Flamingos Flock to Sinai, a Safe Haven in Truce
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 6In 17 months of truce between Israel and Egypt, the flamingos of the eastern Mediterranean have moved in to make the salt marshes along the nowplacid Suez Canal their own lush nesting ground.

title: French in a U.S. Venture
description: PARIS, Jan. 6  One of France's largest companies, Saint  Gobain  Pont  a Mousson, announced today that with its higher valued francs, after the monetary settlement last month, it is pumping $20million into an American company, Certainteed Products.

title: Plywood Seeking Temple
description: U. S. Plywood Champion Papers, Inc., announced yesterday it had signed an agreement in principle to acquire Temple Industries, Inc., a manufacturer of wood building materials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rain Puts Off Play
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP)  Heavy rain prevented play in the New South Wales 'state tennis championship at the White City Stadium today.

title: Fares Proposed  By New Haven
description: Following is a chart showing rates proposed yesterday for riders on the Penn Centres New Haven commuter division between Grand Central Terminal and points in Westchester County and Connecticut. The examples shown are rates for monthly commuter and 10ride tickets, the most commonly used tickets on the line:

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market continued to move forward yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Three More in Race
description: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 6 (AP) Representative John M. Ashbrook, a conservative Republican of Ohio, filed today in the Presidential primary.

title: Samuels Asks 3Pronged Drive To Treat Drug Addicts in City
description: Charging that the country's attitudes toward narcotics addicts were inhumane and stupid, Howard J. Samuels called on the Federal, state and city governments last night to finance and begin programs to place every addict in New York City who wants treatment under care by 1974.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Accepts Invitation
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has accepted an invitation to visit Bangladesh, official sources said today. No date has been set. The invitation was conveyed by the Bangladesh fore'gn minister, Abdus Samad Azad, who arrived last night on the first official visit to India by a Bangladesh representative.

title: 4YEAR TERM GIVEN TO ROCK PROMOTER
description: Raymond Filiberti, the chief promoter for the aborted 1970 Powder Ridge rock festival, was sentenced to four years in jail yesterday for lying to the state Attorney General's office about his role in the proceedings,

title: Police Raid Queens Smut Stock Twice in a Day
description: Criminal Court Judge Peter J. McQuillan yesterday visited the alreadyraided Queens warehouse of what the police called the largest distributor of pornography to the Times Square area to determine what additional materials could be seized.

title: Soviet Building New Siberian Railroad
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6The Soviet Union announced the start of construction today on a key Siberian railroad that may open the way to closer economic cooperation with Japan in the development of. natural resources.

title: State U. Gets Grant To Develop a Plan For 3Year Degree
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6  Ernest L. Boyer, Chancellor of the State University, today announced the receipt of a $343,760 grant from the Carnegie Corporation for the development of experimental timeshortened baccalaureatedegree courses at four of the university's campuses.

title: Birth of Child on Moon Foreseen by von Braun
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) Dr. Wernher von Braun predicted today that the moon would be colonizedand a baby born therewithin the next 29 years.

title: Books of The Times
description: VOYEUR VOYANT. A Portrait of LoultiFerdlnand Celine. By Erika Ostrovsky. 398 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $10.

title: Kehlet Is Replacing Bruhn
description: Neils Kehlet, a star of the Royal Danish Ballet, will replace Erik Bruhn in the following performances by the American Ballet Theater: Coppelia, tomorrow (evening); La Fille Mal Gardee, Jan. 14 evening) and Jan. 16 (matinee). In addition, he will appear with Eleanor D'Antuono in Don Quixote Pas de Deux on Wednesday. Mr. Kehlet will be performing as guest artist.

title: Chinese Drop AntiImperialist From Peking Hospital's Name
description: PEKING, Jan. 6 (Reuters)The AntiImperialist Hospital here has been renamed the Capital Hospital, in another symbolic relaxation of the hardline politics of the Chinese Cultural Revolution.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose 0.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The Commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industiral materials rose to 108.2 from 107.3 last week.

title: Three Anchormen Appraise TV News: It Could Be Better
description: It should be a bit more investigative. It is doing more documentary  type coverage than ever. It is in a dull period, as are its print colleagues, at the moment.

title: Public, in Poll, Says That a Family of 4 Needs $127 a Week
description: The American public's estimate of the cost of maintaining a minimal standard of living in 1971 has not increased significantly over its figure for 1970, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Soviet Six Wins Cup
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 6 (AP)The Soviet team, Spartak of Moscow, won the international Ahearne Cup hockey tournament tonight by defeating the Gault Hornets of Canada in the final game, 95.

title: Bronx Youth Is Arrested In Death of Elderly Man
description: A 17yearold Bronx youth was arrested yesterday in connection with the death Wednesday of an elderly building superintendent who was found bound and gagged in the basement of his apartment building at 356 St. Ann's Avenue, the police said.

title: DockPay Offer Accepted Byl.L.A.W Wage Committee
description: The Atlantic Coast Wagescale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association recommended last night that members accept a manageme'nt offer that would increase the basic dockworker pay scale from the present $4.60 an hour to $6.10 an hour over a threeyear period.

title: No Invitation, Official Says
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 6 (AP)A spokesman for Bangladesh said today that President Bhutto's offer to go to Dacca for conciliatory talks was meaningless because he had not been invited.

title: 2 WOMEN ACCUSE on OF SWINDLE
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation began a fullscale investigation yesterday of charges by a Brooklyn woman that OTB clerks swindled her out of winning $3,180.20 superfecta ticket.

title: SHAKER PLEDGES HIS AID IN YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Jan. 6  With a thousand Yonkers teachers shouting Alioto must go and Tice is nice from the City Hall parking lot, Albert Shanker, president of the United Teachers of New York State and the New York City United Federation of Teachers, today pledged his organizations financial and emotional support of the school strike here, now in its fourth day.

title: Fine Chinese Food From Many Areas
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Punter's Suit Against Cowboys Blocked
description: DALLAS, Jan. 6 (UPI)The Dallas Cowboys won a Super Bowl skirmish today, but it was in the courts and not on the football field.

title: NO RISE SEEN IN U.S. IN OIL EXPLORATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The nation's oil industry, though aided by import controls and tax benefits, has not responded as expected by expanding exploration for oil in the United States, a Congressionally commissioned study concluded to day.

title: Merger Announcements Declined 10% Last Year
description: Merger announcements declined 10 per cent last year to 4,635 from 5,152 in 1970, W. T. Grimm & Co., specialists in mergers and acquisitions, announced yesterday.

title: Atlantic Richfield Is Moving Division From City to Coast
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it was moving the headquarters of its products division and a substantial number of its corporate staff personnel from New York City to Los Angeles.

title: Scribner Rejects SchoolPairing Failure Report
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner issued a report yesterday that appeared to show that the City's controversial schoolpairing plan, begun in 1964, had failed to produce racial integration.

title: RIVA RIDGE FIRST ON HANDICAP LIST Meadow's Colt Is Given Top Weight for Experimental
description: As expected, Meadow Stable's Riva Ridge was topweighted in the annual Experimental Free Handicap evaluation released yesterday by The Jockey Club.

title: Paris Museum Honors Man Ray With Art Display
description: PARIS, Jan. 6Europe is honoring Man Ray, and so, after the Netherlands and prior to Denmark, the French National Museum of Modern Art is opening here this week with an impressive survey of his work.

title: Peoples Party to Convene In Florida After Democrats
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fia., Jan. 6 The Peoples party, a coalition of peace, freedom and other minority political parties, will hold its national nominating convention in Miami Beach few days after the close of the Democratic National Convention in July.

title: 7 Children Die in Blaze
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. (AP)Seven children, ranging in age from 2 months to eight years, lost their lives in an early morning fire today. Six of the dead were the children of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Johnson. The seventh child was the son of Mrs. Shirley Turner.

title: Samuel McLaughlin, 100, Dies; Led General Motors of Canada
description: OSHAWA, Ontario, Jan. 6 R. Samuel McLaughlin, chairman of the board of General Motors of Canada, died at his home here today. He was 100 years old.

title: JAY BROAD PLAY TO BOW IN APRIL
description: A Conflict of Interest, new play by Jay Broad, described as dealing with contemporary powerseekers in our Government, will be presented on Broadway in April by Robert S. Fishko and John A. Prescott, Jerry Adler is the director.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Grain Prices Decline as India Cuts Back Orders
description: Prices of wheat, soybean and soybean oil futures declined on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday when it became known that India had decided not to take delivery this year on about 400,000 tons of small grains she had contracted for in 1971.

title: EVANS PRODUCTS SETS PROFIT MARK
description: The Evans Products Company achieved record results in 1971 with earnings up more than 55 per cent and revenues 22 per cent ahead of 1970, Monford A. Orloff, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.

title: Bridge: Brilliancy a Sometime Thing; Experts Work to Get Results
description: Many beginners suffer from the delusion, perhaps fostered by bridge columnists, that the life of an expert is one long round of imaginative bids and spectacular plays. The truth is that the expert gets results by bidding accurately, playing carefully and taking full advantage of his opponents errors.

title: The Nixon Court': A Premature Label?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The swearingin tomorrow of Lewis F. Powell Jr. and William H. Rehnquist as Associate Supreme Court Justices will inevitably prompt many Americans to considerwith varying degrees of satisfaction and chagrin  whether President Nixon has finally turned the Court in the direction that he desires, Mr. Nixon's first two appointees, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Justice Harry A. Blackmun, have agreed on all but six of the 138 cases decided since they have been on the Court together. They haye anchored the right wing of the Court so consistently that the appointment of two more Nixon appointees could well create a dominant, cohesive Nixon bloc on the Court.

title: National City Bank Is Accused Of Bias by ExWoman Employe
description: The First National City Bank and two of its vice presidents have been charged with sex discrimination by a former woman employe.

title: Advertising:
description: After almost 25 years in medical advertising, Joseph Goodyear of Ted Bates is taking a powder.

title: Harry A. Bruno Weds Mrs. Witten
description: WEST ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan, 6Mrs. Evelyn Denny Witten of New York, widow of Louis A. Witten, a radio broadcaster, was married here this afternoon to Harry Augustine Bruno of Montauk. L. I., a pioneer public relations counsel specializing in aviation. The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. John Denny, brother of the bride, and rector of the church.

title: Witness Tells of Early Data on I.T.T.
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 6  The former Corporation Counsel of this city testified in Superior Court here today that former Connecticut Insurance Commissioner William R. Cotter had told him, three or four days before Mr. Cotter announced his decision, that he planned to approve the merger of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company into the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: John Berryman, Poet, Is Dead; Won the Pulitzer Prize in 1966
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 7John Berryman, one of the nation's leading poets, jumped to his death from a bridge over the Mississippi River here today, A witness reported to University of Minnesota police that the 57yearold professor had walked to the rail of the bridge and jumped about 100 feet to the west bank of the river.

title: N.G.A.A. PRESENTS PRIZE TO HOLLAND;Former Cornell End Cited for Distinguished Career
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 7Dr. Jerome H. (Brud) Holland, the United States Ambassador to Sweden, received the sixth, Theodore Roosevelt Award from the National Collegiate Athletic, Association today.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange has issued its latest weekly report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. This week the New York Stock Exchange did not issue a report on insiders trading.

title: Rural Aid Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)The Agriculture Department announced today state shares of a $55.5million increase in 1972 funds for the Rural Environmental Assistance Program. The sums included Connecticut, $112,000; New Jersey, $179,000, and New York, $1,273,000.

title: Equal Time Plea Rejected
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System has turned down the Democratic party's request for equal broadcast time to reply to President Nixon's television interview last Sunday, United Press International reported. C.B.S. said, however, that it would honor the Democrats request for equal time to answer the President's State of the Union message later this month.

title: ILLEGALITY IS SEEN ON KAISER SHARES
description: TORONTO, Jan. 7The Ontario Securities Commission serted today that some officers or directors of Kaiser sources, Ltd., were indirect, beneficial owners of the company's stock and had failed to report their trading in shares as required by law.

title: Both Sides Rest Cases In Suit on I.T.T. Merger
description: Both sides in the civil action brought against the Hartford Fire Insurance Company merger into the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation rested their cases in Superior Court in Hartford Thursday evening.

title: Muskie, in Florida Speech Scores Government Secrecy
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 7 (UPI)Senator Edmund S. Muskie called today for a national government in the sunshine law so that the public will not have to depend on stolen secret papers to tell them what their President is doing.

title: State to Check for Violations Of New DetergentSale Law
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7State Environmental Commissioner Henry L. Diamond today ordered the 240 uniformed enforcement officers of the department into retail stores across the state to check on possible sales of highphosphate detergents and improperly labeled detergents.

title: MRS. BODIL KOCH, DANISH OFFICIAL
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 7 (Reuters)Mrs. Bodil Koch, a former Minister of Ecclesiastical Affairs, died here today at the age of 68.

title: STOCK PRICES UP BY A THIN MARGIN
20 Years in Hijacking
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 7 (UPI)  A former West Virginia coal miner, labeled a harmless old man by Federal Judge Oren E. Lewis, was sentenced today to two concurrent 20year prison terms in connection with the June hijacking of an airliner flying from Charleston, W. Va., to Newark. Glen Elmo Riggs, 58 years old, was convicted of air piracy and interfering with an airplane crew member in the performance of his duties by Federal District Court jury Nov. 29.

title: I.L.A. Prepares to Vote on Wage Offer
description: The leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association has set the end of this month or the beginning of next month as the target date by which members will be asked to vote on a new wage offer, union sources said yesterday.

title: PUBLIC TV VEXED BY SALARY REPORT
description: The propriety of paying high salaries and fees to newsmen performers in public television continues to vex the noncommercial medium at its point of greatest vulnerability the local station operation.

title: STAFFORD VICTOR IN VERMONT RACE
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. (UPI)Vermont's interim Senator, Robert T. Stafford, a Republican, won the right in a special election today to fill the remaining five years of the term of the late Senator Winston L. Prouty.

title: Motorists Begin Adjustment To Bridge and Tunnel Tolls
description: Motorists began to adjust to the new tolls on Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority facilities yesterday, but there were still many outoftown truck drivers who held up traffic while they dug into their pockets to pay the toll increases.

title: SUGAR FUTURES DROP FOR 2D DAY
description: Sugar futures prices dropped yesterday for the second day in a row after having advanced as much as 30 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). However, the trading was not so intense as during the previous day, when declines hit the daily limit of 50 points.

title: Market Place: Sheep and Goats Of 1971 Stocks
Bethlehem Cuts Prices
description: Trade sources said yesterday that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had matched recent price cuts of $5 a ton on some steelsheet products announced by the United States Steel Corporation and followed by most other major steelmakers. A spokesman for Bethlehem declined to comment.

title: DIGGS IS DENIED VISA BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  A black member of Congress enlisted the aid of the State Department today in seeking to make the South African Government reconsider its decision denying him a visa to SouthWest Africa.

title: Ox Ridge Poloists Win
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 7The Ox Ridge Hunt Club's polo team scored 8 goals in the third chukker tonight and went on to defeat the British Pony Club's squad, 2110, at the Ox Ridge indoor arena. Reid Graham of Ox Ridge scored 9 goals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon's method of winding down the war recalls the story of how the frog got out of the well; which was by climbing up two feet during the day and sliding back three feet during the night. As more and more of our ground troops are brought home, the more vulnerable are those that remain in South Vietnam. Hence the more vigorously, even viciously, must we intensify the attack in order to protect them. This is one official explanation of the recent heavy bombing of North Vietnam.

title: That Man of Peace, the Rev. Paisley
description: DUBLINOn the basis that the darkest hour comes before the dawn, the present situation alone in Northern Ireland would seem to indicate that the dawn must be.near. As many as thirty people killed in a week and the Official I.R.A. (Marxist Wing), which has hitherto restricted its activities to giving bloodcurdling press conferences, getting in on the act by shooting a 70yearold Unionist Senator who inconsiderately put up a resistance when the decent men called to blow up his home.

title: JOEY HARRIS
description: Joey Harris, corporate secretary of the Advertising Research Foundation, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Stamford, Conn., after suffering a heart attack recently. She was 43 years old.

title: 2 WITH BABY FORCE JET TO FLY TO CUBA
description: TAMPA, Fla., aJn. 7 (AP)A California flight was hijacked to Cuba today by a woman with a baby and a man with a shotgun. The hijackers ordered the Pacific Southwest Airlines jet flown to Havana after a stop at Tampa, where they vainly sought a plane capable of taking them to Africa.

title: PENNSYLVANIA BLAST HURTS 22 IN HOSPITAL
description: McKEESPORT, Pa., Jan. 7 (UPI)A boiler explosion destroyed a threestory trick annex to the McKeesport Hospital today, injuring 22 of the 45 maintenance and administrative employes inside the building. None of the hospital's 500 patient's was hurt.

title: RAYMOND GUNNISON; LED BROOKLYN EAGLE
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 7Raymond M. Gunnison, who had been publisher and vice president of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle in the early thirties, succeeding his father, Herbert, died yesterday at a convalescent home in Menlo Park. He was 84 years old.

title: Pub Owner Slain in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, Jan. 8 (UPI)  A wealthy Protestant pub owner was shot to death by gunmen just before dawn today at his suburban Lowwood Park home. Gerald Woods, owner of the downtown Belfast pub, was the 209th person slain in three years of violence in Northern Ireland.

title: U. S. Copter Kills Vietnamese
description: SAIGON, Jan. 7 (UPI)The United States command reported today that an American helicopter had accidentally opened fire on South Vietnamese troops in the Central Highlands yesterday, killing one soldier and wounding five.

title: New Envoy to Canada Is Appointed by Peking
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 7 (Canadian Press)  China has informed Canada that her next ambassador in Ottawa will be Yao Kuang, whose last appointment was as ambassador to Poland, Government sources said today.

title: Victory in Central Park
description: The decision to abandon plans for the construction of the Fire Department's new communications system Central Park is more than a victory for those who have carried on the battle against this unwarranted encroachment. It is it triumph of those rational civic forces who insist that municipal decisionmaking should not be an exclusive bureaucratic game of chess.

title: Notes on Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Senator James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate who unseated a Republican Senator a year ago, apparently is building bridges to the Republican party organization back in New York.

title: Coach of Blues, 3 Players Accused of Assault in Fight
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7 (UPI)Sidney Salomon Jr., president of the St. Louis Blues, said today he would fight the criminal charges placed against his coach and three players in Philadelphia following a wild brawl last night at the end of the second period of a BluesFlyers hockey game.

title: HENRY SCHECHTER
description: Henry Schechter, a former partner in the S. H. Pomerance Company, a customs brokerage firm, died Thursday in an automobile accident in Brooklyn. He was 69 years old and lived at 2310 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Youth Attacks School Dean
description: Donald Kelliher, dean of boys at Morris High School in the Bronx, was beaten yesterday by a boy when, he told the police, he sought to check the youth's identity papers. Mr. Kelliher, who was knocked to the floor, was taken to the Lincoln Hospital, where he was discharged after an examination established that he had suffered a slight concussion. Two policemen on duty at the Morris High School arrested the I7yearold attacker, identified as Jose Strong, 1804 Harrison Avenue, and charged him with assault.

title: Johnson Is Leader Rolling Into Finals Of Garden Bowling
G.E. to Close Cleveland Unit
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (UPI)The General Electric Company has decided to close its vacuumcleaner factory in Cleveland April 1, making 500 persons idle. The company said it saw no way to keep the plant operating without a substantial loss.

title: Mohr Identity Uncertain
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (UPI) "Christopher Charles Mohr, the man who rented the safedeposit boxes in New York, Chicago and San Francisco where bombs were found today, may be a fictitious name for several persons, according to the police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Job Opportunities Cited In Textiles and Apparel
description: There has been a lack of awareness that the textile and apparel trades are a good source of jobs, Lawrence F. Davenport, chairman of the National Advisory Council on Vocational Education, said here yeSterday.

title: REALTY MAN SLAIN ON THE EAST SIDE
description: Peter Detmold, an East Side realestate broker, and member of his local community board, was stabbed to death Thursday night on the stairway of the fivestory Walkup in which he lived at 229 East. 48th Street, near Third Avenue.

title: Fireman Accused of Taking $25 to Overlook Violations
description: A fireman assigned to the fire prevention division here was arrested yesterday on extortion and bribery charges for allegedly taking $25 to overlook fire violations.

title: STEINBERG OFFERS. THREE PIANO WORKS
description: Michael Steinberg is one of those pianists about whom it is difficult to write. He is an able, intelligent performer, whose flashes of insight are never sustained enough to lift him above I the level of so many other pianists. His program in Town Hall Thursday night was limited to three largescale works, Beethoven's Op. 101 Sonata, Brahms's Handel Variations and Chopin's 24 Preludes. Getting through these difficult pieces competently was to Mr. Steinberg's credit; so was a kind of selfeffacement before the composer's intentions.

title: U. S. L.T. A. Faults Women's Lob on Fees
description: Women's Lob, the highly successful professional tennis tour that began as symbol of protest, is on another course with the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

title: Indictment of Federal Grand Juries
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  The grand jury sits in secret, a practice begun to protect the innocent. But the moderndress version makes the secrecy strikingly reminiscent of the oath ex officio procedure which for time threatened to still the first stirrings of the adversary system, the pre sumption of innocence and the right of public trial. The evils which were disowned in the creation of the right to a fair trial are, in fact, quite at home in the grand jury room: there is no right to notice of the scope and nature of the crimes being investigated; there is no confrontation of the witnesses who have led the trail of the investigation to the witnesses doorstep and, collaterally, there is no possibility, much less a right, to crossexamine those witnesses. In essence there is trial in secret, and by inquiry.

title: 'Glass Houses':Jennifer O'Neill Stars at Local Theaters
description: Because of the monomaniacal intensity of the sexual hunger that motivates almost everyone in the film, Alexander Singer's "Glass Houses" looks very much like a put-ona rather high-class one, as a matter of factof the old-fashioned, soft-core pornographic movies that the more technical, less Freudian-oriented hard-core features have since rendered obsolete.Kim, as beautiful and rapacious a teen-ager as ever entered a middle-aged moviemaker's fantasies, has what used to be called an unnatural desire for her father, Victor, a bored Los Angeles businessman.
