description: The Manhattan College indoor track and field team will be a strong challenger Wednesday in the 81st Annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior tittle meet at the 102d Engineers Armory, Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street. The games will gel under way at 7 P.M.

title: Music
description: IT takes those of a certain age to remember the excitement attendant upon the New York premiere of Virgil Thomson's Four Saints in Three Acts. The world premiere had taken place in Hartford on Feb. 7, 1934, and some of the New York papers had sent critics and reporters. Lucius Beebe of The Herald Tribune covered the premiere as a society event, as indeed it was, and told his readers that a young man had had the temerity to wear pale green trousers with his dinner jacket. (Lucius, thou shouldst etc.) Bewildered reports about the opera appeared in the New York press. But not until it opened at the 44th Street Theater, on Feb. 20, did Four Saints get the full treatment.

title: Mishap to Sabich Helps Nindl Take Pro Slalom
description: MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Jan. 8The International Ski Racers Association's troupe was back at a familiar stand today as 40 professionals  most of them reared in Europe's high countrysought chunks of a $20,000 purse offered during the twoday program at this popular Green Mountain resort.

title: Miss Macchi is Not GreatYet
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8Probably the only reason skiing's latest sensation doesn't say things like gee whiz is that she's French.

title: A EUROPEAN DRIVE ON CHOLERA URGED
description: GENEVA, Jan, 8  The World Health Organization has warned that Europe should be ready to repel further invasions of cholera this year.

title: Holy Cross Upsets Fordham
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 8 Holy Cross, shooting a sizzling 61 per cent from the floor, upset favored Fordham tonight, 7168, at the Worcester Auditorium before a crowd of 2,700.

title: R. W. Lavender, Inventor; Installed Navy's 1st Radar
description: WARRENSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP)  Raymond W. Lavender, an inventor who directed the first installation of radar on a Navy ship  the carrier Enterprise  died yesterday at Glens Falls Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ROSLYN, L. I.  A cold, biting breeze whipped in from the harbor inlet in Roslyn and a dozen ducks, looking for all the world at a distance like a string of (loosened pearls, bobbed on the waters of nearby sunlit Silver Lake.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 8 (UPI)The Buffalo Braves snapped a 12game losing streak tonight and continued the Cincinnati Royals string to 13 games with a 9787 victory.

title: A Man May Retire But Not Slow Down
description: NEW ORLEANSI get up every morning wondering what I am going to do this day and before noon I am so far behind that I can't stop for lunch. I am retired.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON President Nixon's new budget, due in two weeks, will show outlays for fiscal 1973 of $246to247billion, according to reliable current information.

title: Skicountry casual
description: The exterior of this cedarclad Vermont house echoes familiar New England forms with its shed roofs and austere angles. But inside  it's something else again. Architect Hobart Betts created a verticality and openness that the saltbox builders could never achieve. The honse steps dawn a slope in six staggered levels (see plan, below left). The playroom, children's and guest rooms are on the lower levels. Upstairs in the adult areas the spaces flow, in, out, up, down and around. The dining room and kitchen overlook the lodgelike living room; the loft bedroom does the same. Balcony railings, high enough for privacy, giveasenseof enclosurewithoutdestroying thefeeling of space:

title: Mutual Funds Need MoreThan Sales
description: The mutual fund business is fond of saying that shares are soldt not bought, a reference to, the large number of potential customers who know little. about funds and invest in them only when prodded.

title: Amber Pudding Triumphs Along With Blonde Lady
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (AP)  Amber Pudding and Blonde Lady won the two divisions of the sixfurlong Pan Zareta Stakes at the Fair Grounds today.

title: Tokyo Plans Radio System To Warn Schools of Smog
description: TOKYO, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  The Tokyo metropolitan government is considering establishing radio links with most of the city's schools to provide an early warning against socalled photochemical, or white smog.

title: Newark Patrolman Killed In Gun Duel With Detective
description: NEWARK, Jan, 8  A 39yearold. patrolman, who was on sick leave after having been mugged a month ago was shot to death by another policeman whom he had wounded during a gun duel at the Ivy Hill Park Apartments early today.

title: The Nation; Announcements:; Why Must They Act Out That Old Charade?
description: WASHINGTON  It was the week of the announcement. It wasn't quite as bad as Art Buchwald, the humorist, would have had us believe when he reported the new born candidacy of Archibad Partridge of Cranberry Falls, Kans., the onemillionth Democratic hopeful of the year. But it was a mildly absurd week all the same.

title: But Doubt Nags American People
description: WASHINGTONThe economists and the big businessmen may be predicting a great year for business and wageearners but on the assembly line and in the shopping centers, the American people aren't so sure.

title: Time Inc. Asks Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI)  Time Inc. asked today that the council's decision be reconsidered in public hearings.

title: U.S. Energy Still Abundant, but Costly
description: The energy business is changing. New ways are being sought to deliver the kind of power that has driven this nation to its preeminent post in the world.

title: Woman Gets School Post
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UPI)  Dr. Virginia R. Meehan, acting president of Southwest College, has been named president of the school  the first time a woman headed a public institution of higher education in Chicago. She had been acting president since June 22, 1971.

title: The High Cost of Medicine
description: SEATTLEWhen Mrs. Brown walked out of a hospital here recently after six weeks of care for a nearfatal attack of appendicitis, it took 33 pages to itemize her bill, which totaled $15,000equivalent to her husband's salary forone year.

title: Flyers Tie Leafs, 22
description: TORONTO, Jan. 8 (UPI)Simon Nolet's 14th goal of the season helped the Philadelphia Flyers rally to a 22 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

title: Mrs. Nixon Picnics in Rain Forest and the Rains Fall
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. (UPI)  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon spent the last full day of her West African tour on a jungle picnic today with President Felix HouphouetBoigny and other officials.

title: Debra White Fiancee Of Ronald B. Weekes
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 8  Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. White have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Debra LaVerne White, to Ronald Bismarck Weekes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Weekes of Bridgetown, Barbados.

title: Connors Upsets Graebner, 62, 75, in Semifinals of Baltimore Indoor Tennis
description: TOWSON, Md., Jan. 8 (AP)Jimmy Connors, the 19yearold Californian, upset topseeded Clark Graebner of New York, 62, 75, to reach the final of the $7,500 Baltimore International indoor tennis tournament tonight. This is the first major event on the United States winter circuit.

title: SYRACUSE BEATS ST. JOHN'S, 8683
description: Led by Greg KohIs, Syracuse turned back St. John's, 8683, before 4,707 tonight at Alumni Hall in Jamaica.

title: Orange   Disorienting But Human Comedy'.
description: STANLEY KUBRICK's ninth film, A Clockwork Orange, which has just won the New York Film Critics Award as the best film of 1971, is a brilliant and dangerous work, but it is dangerous in a way that brilliant things sometimes are.

title: Taking Medical System's Pulse
description: WASHINGTON  Health expenditures in 1970 amounted to $67billion, or 7 per cent of the gross national product, yet, despite the enormity of that sum, the medical industry remains fragmented.

title: Art
description: WILLEM de KOONING was born in Holland in 1904. Between 1916 and 1924 he received a thorough training at the Rotterdam Academy. In 1925 he came to America. He did odd jobs, met and was influenced by Arshile Gorky, was involved in the WPA Artists Project and, by the midthirties, was painting highkeyed biomorphic abstractions. The rest, as they say, is history. By 1950 he was enshrined in notoriety, with Jackson Pollock, as one of the two (perhaps mad) geniuses of American avantgarde painting.Figures in Landscapes, some of his finest work.

title: Lindsay Calls Rivals Peace Hypocrites
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 8  Mayor Lindsay charged today that some of his Democratic opponents were hypocritical in opposing the Vietnam war now after voting year after year to support the war In Congress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A reading of the Dec. 5 Real Estate section would lead one to believe that proprietors of small neighborhood stores are being oppressed. The article Lease Can Be a Time Bomb would lead the average reader to believe exactly what it appears you want the reader to absorbthat the landlord is an ogre with no heart.

title: Union Five in Romp
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Jan. 8 (AP)Union College's basketball team walloped Queens University of Kingston, Ontario, 9346, today.

title: Pentagon Reports Reversal In Rising Heroin Use Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The Pentagon's chief medical officer said yesterday the military had reversed a rising rate of heroin use among servicemen.

title: Sports of The Times
description: This is an annual service that is offered to all customers without any charge. What could be embarrassing, though, is that this free package isn't worth anything anyway. But at least the price is right, andwho knows?maybe some of the predictions are right, too. Let's take a quick look.

title: THE WEEK'S OPENINGS
description: ICE CAPADES  Tuesday, Madison Sor. Garden, 7:30.

title: KFAR TOY SCORES IN MALIBU STAKES
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP) Bil!rick Stables Kfar Toy survived Autobiography's stretch run to win by a nose in the $46,250 first division of the Malibu Stakes today at Santa Anita.

title: Minister Says Iran Won't Block Traffic In the Persian Gulf
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 8  Iran's Foreign Minister pledged today that his Government would not use its strategic position to block freedom of transit in the Persian Gulf.

title: White House Took Steps to Stop Leaks Months Before Anderson Disclosures
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The columnist Jack Anderson has been able to disclose secret memoranda concerning National Security Council meetings recently despite White House steps months ago to prevent leaks to reporters and to insure the secrecy of council proceedings.

title: Army Quintet Wins, 9173
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8Army received 38 points from its backcourt duo of Bob Sherwin and John O'Maley as it defeated Rochester tonight, 9173. The victory evened Army's wonlost record at 55, while Rochester suffered its fifth loss in nine games.

title: A.E.C. Head Denies Agency Will Reduce Stress on Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)  The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission denied today that his agency was dropping stress on weaponry. Instead, he said, emphasis will be placed on the practical in both weapons and peaceful uses of the atom.

title: Engineers Look at Life
description: AMERICAN engineers, caught in a severe unemployment squeeze, are trying to sell their skills to the cities, to environmental and other groups who are supporting the amorphous concept of a better quality of life, rather than continued growth.

title: The Heroin Babies: Going Cold Turkey At Birth
description: THE baby lies in an incubator, its body hooked up to ma chines. A thermometer taped to its skin records its temperature. A feeding tube runs down one nostril. Another line is linked to a device that will alert the staff if the infant stops breathing.

title: ACTION PREDICTED ON LOST PAY RISES
description: A member of the Federal Pay Board says that he expects the panel to act soon, possibly as early as this week, to allow at least partial recovery of scheduled wage increases that workers lost in the 90day wageprice freeze that ended Nov. 14.

title: For R. &
description: IN RESEARCH and developmentthe driving force behind most scientific and industrial endeavorthe emphasis has shifted from research to development, as a result of the economic slowdown.

title: Carrier Pilots Off Vietnam Still Eager for Action
description: ABOARD U.S.S. CORAL SEA, in the South China Sea, Jan. 7,  The Indochina war and its complexities seem far away from this thousandfoot long floating air base. What matters to the hundred or so pilots aboard is not the policies of Washington and Hanoi but years of training for and masculine pride in a dangerous and exacting profession.

title: Mujib's Statement and Excerpts From News Session
description: LONDON, Jan. 8  Following is the text of a statement made in London today by Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and excerpts from the transcript of the news conference that followed. They were recorded by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Bullets Down Hawks
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 8 (UPI)Jack Mann scored 29 points, the game high, in pacing the Baltimore Bullets to their fifth straight victory tonight by a 110102 score over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn Scott Wed To Donald Piper Jr.
description: Miss Carolyn Roberts Scott and Donald Franklyn Piper Jr. were married here yesterday morning at the Pinnacle Club, of which the bride's father is general manager. The Rev. Arthur Barton of the Christ United Methodist Church of New Rochelle, N. Y., performed the ceremony.

title: AUSTRALIA PLEASED BY U. S. NAVAL MOVE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 8  Commenting on the assignment of an American naval force to a permanent station in the Indian Ocean, Defense Minister, David Fairbairn said in Canberra yesterday that Australia was concerned over the increasing Soviet naval activity in those waters.

title: A Lament For Pakistan
description: PAKISTAN was the impossible dream that failed. It was a doomed attempt to bind together two totally disparate sections of Asia, separated not only by language, custom, economics, politics and tradition but also by 1,000 miles of alien territory. The only cement it could rely upon was religion. And in less than 25 years religion proved unequal to the task.

title: Mining Wall Street Campaign Lode
description: The wealthy men of Wall Street will be digging deeply into their bank accounts once again this Presidential election year to finance the campaigns of politicians throughout the land.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Art
description: Y this time, no doubt, all our museums have totted up their 1971 attendance figures for presentation to whatever boards arid committees reward them for their service to the public. They're a serious matter, these attendance figures, in much the same way as the Nielsen ratings are serious matters in another form of public entertainment. And counted along with the people who have come to museums to learn from what they see, there will be the looseenders, the blankeyed wanderers, the semiconscious, the schoolchildren (a very important figure) being exposed to culture. that may or may not take, as well as all those gentle young people garbed as members of a caste that, as a special instance, has settled on the Cloisters as the perfect spot for pot.

title: Rosalie R. Hodes Lawyer's Fiancee
description: UNION, N. J., Jan. 8  Mrs. Ann Hodes has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rosalie R. Hodes, to Stephen M. Fields, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Fields of New York.

title: Boy Deplored in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  Roman Catholics in Rhodesia have been urged not to use the term boy when addressing Africans. A pamphlet produced at the request of the Catholic bishops conference said, We all have names.

title: American Indian Activists Winning Bureau Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  President Nixon's doctrine of selfdetermination for the American Indian is finally moving toward implementation after a long and bitter power struggle within the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: $1Million for Animals
description: DENVER, Jan. 8 (UPI)  A Denver society matron who died last month at the age of 80 willed $1million of her estate to a nonprofit organization that shelters homeless animals. Mrs. Charlotte Barbour left the money to the Denver Dumb Friends League.

title: Court Delays New Standard for Retreaded Tires
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  A Federal safety standard for retreaded automobile tires, more than four years in the making, has been further delayed by litigation challenging its legality.

title: Sue E. Journer Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Caesar B. journer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sue Ellen Journer, to Norman N. Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Weiss. Both families reside in the Bronx. A June wedding is planned.

title: Marycoleen Kelly Wed to Lieut. Corndr. Donald Eaton, Pilot
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Jan. 8  Miss Marycoleen Kelly and Lieut. Comdr. Donald R. Eaton, U.S.N., were married this afternoon In the Chapel of the Good Shepherd of the Naval Air Station, Oceana. Lieut. Michael P. O'Neal, Navy Chaplain Corps, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Et Al.
description: A black exmarine's account of his Southern upbringing, his Vietnam experiences and his desertion after being wounded and sent back to Japan. A hard, clear portrayal of how racism and a bad war led one man to change from a dedicated marine to a political exile in Sweden.

title: Computers Keeping Nation Competitive
description: The computer has been describedpossibly with slight exaggeration  as America's greatest longrange asset.

title: Yale Polo Team Wins, 225, From British Polo Clubs
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8Yale scored 11 goals in the first chukker and went on to defeat the touring British Pony Clubs polo team, 225, today at the Yale indoor arena.

title: NIXON MOVES CALLED SPUR TO COAST JOBS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)  A consultant on West Coast unemployment told President Nixon today that recent Government steps would create 90,000 new jobs in California, particularly in the aerospace and related industries.

title: Licensing Of Horne Repairers Is Begun
description: MINEOLA, L. L,Help has finally arrived for the homeowner stranded by the handy home improvement manwith tiles still plunking down from a new shower stall, a remodeled kitchen without a stove, half a dormer and a hole in the roof.

title: Gold Cup Hydroplane Race Returns to Detroit
description: Despite last year's rise to prominence by Madison, Indiana's spectacular handling (and winning) of the Gold Cup, unlimited hydroplanes most prestigious event will return to the shores of the Detroit River this season.

title: The young magician trying his tricks
description: For some years now, Vladimir Nabokov has been presenting the pleasant spectacle of a writer expanding at both ends  frontally, from the brow of the present, with each new novel in English, while one by one his Russian novels, in filial translations edited paternally, emerge from behind the hill of the past. In Glory, or Podvig (The Exploit), as it once was, the final one of these, it is strange, and oddly warming, to find the experienced ironist in one of his first bouts with his own talent and its lifelong preoccupations. With emotion still limpidly trying on its first masks, memory with its jointures melting but still plain, and people still somewhat conventionally islanded in their own solitudes, not yet so clearly caught in the necromancer's palm.

title: The World
description: President Nixon's aides were busy, In Peking last week ironing out arrangements for his visit to the Chinese capital next month. But the Presidential party may not be the only American group in China at that time.

title: Labor Aims at Pay Curb in Its Nixon Ambush
description: Workers' doubts about the equity of the Nixon Administration's wage and price stabilization program appear to have united organized labor end helped to crystalize its major 1972 political goal.

title: At Cloisters, the Play Was the Thing, but Supper Was Fun, Too
description: More than 230 members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and their guests braved a rainy, windswept night last week to attend An Evening at The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: There is a fashion shoe manufacturer in New York that has yet to sell a pair of shoes or boots to a shoe store or a shoe department. The reason: the.company sells only to boutiques or specialty shops and has become a principal resource for small retailers who need a coordinated line of leather goods.

title: For Ages 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10..; The Children's War; By Theodore Taylor. 166 pp. Doubleday. $3.95. (Ages 10 to 13)
description: Taut, terse novel about 12yearold Dory Scofield in the Japanese occupation of the Aleutians in 1942. The narrative centers on emotions felt and bonds made and severed: the boy loses his teacher, his zeal for weapons, his childhood. The strongest element is his relationship with an old taciturn Eskimo hunter whom he idolizes,.yet in one of several heartbreaking scenes calls, coward. Like the bond between Phillip and an old West Indian, Timothy, in The Cay, the author's previous novel, , this friendship is achieved between two cultures and two age levels.

title: Harvard Fraternity to Act
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Jan. 8 (AP)  The Harvard chapter of Phi Delta Kappa, the international education fraternity, has voted to withdraw from the fraternity until women are admitted.

title: Christine Petze Becomes Bride
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 8  Miss Christine Frances Petze and Richard Alden Burr were married here this afternoon in a Quaker ceremony performed at the Wilmington Monthly Meeting of Friends.

title: Bulls Turn Back Knicks, 113108
description: The Knicks got off to a torrid start in the first period last night, but cooled off the rest of the way, losing to the Chicago Bulls, 113108, before 19,588 fans at Madison Square Garden. The defeat was the third straight for the Knicks after a seven. game winning streak.

title: January
description: January drives a man in upon himself and tests his mettle. It is the coldest month, the darkest, and sometimes the snowiest. Now comes the time when the rocks have lost the last of their autumn warmth and the earth heaves with deepbiting frost. Now the seep among the stones becomes the ice lever that pries ridges apart.

title: Wake Forest Picks Harper
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Jan. 8 (AP)Wake Forest University named its defensive coordinator, Tom Harper, to succeed Cal Stoll as head football coach today. Stoll resigned yesterday to become head coach at the University of Minnesota.

title: Education
description: The publicschool teachers strike that began in Yonkers last week appeared to be small potatoes on the national school scene which has seen hundreds of strikes during the past years of teacher militancy, The system's 30,000 pupils, for example, are only slightly more than are enrolled in any of New York City's 31 community districts. Yet, there was wide agreement that one of the key itsues in the Yonkers dispute  contractual limitation ofclass size  is the pacesetter for teachercontract negotiations across the country.

title: For Ages 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10...; Lions and Lobsters And Foxes and Frogs; Fables From Aesop by Ennis Rees. Illustrated by Edward Gorey. Unpaged. Young Scott Books. $4.50. (Ages 6 to 9)
description: Still another retelling of Aesop; this time in uptodate colloquial verse. The 17 fables come from the author's larger collection published a few years ago, Fables From Aesop. Unfortunately these versions meander and seldom make their point; and the verse (uneven in meter, forced in rhyme) lacks punch. But the accompanying illustrations are handsome, full of visual wit and lively animals romping through pages designed to look like a medieval manuscript.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: At 5:28 P.M. Nov. 9, 1965, I.esidents of New York City and neighboring communities ran headon into an energy gap. For a brief period, the electricity being consumed exceeded the amount capable of being supplied.

title: Son for Mrs. Gibson
description: A son was born Dec. 20 to Mr. and Mrs. James Percy Gibson of Mexico City in the American British Cowdry Hospital there. Mrs. Gibson is the former Miss Carolyn Stevens Lutz of Darien, Conn.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EPITOR:

title: Et Al.
description: The columnist, William S. White, offers a pithy study of the leadership qualities of Truman, Senator Taft, Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Johnson. A kind of profiles in courage. The responsibles of Mr. White's title are national leaders who seize upon some transcendent cause and work effectively to forward it. In other words these men saw their duty and did it, disregarding temptations to temporize. Mr. White now, as always, writes well; but this is not important history.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe choicest bits of the White House's secret strategy sessions on the PakistanIndia fuss had already been published in Jack Anderson's syndicated columnread by an estimated 45 million muckhungry Americans  when Presidential aide Henry Kissinger decided that the best way to fight back was to say that his statements had suffered distortion by being printed out of context.

title: Canarsie Drug Center: Unwanted Waif
description: The Canarsie Youth Center, which provides therapy for neighborhood teenagers prone to narcotics use, says it is having a hard time finding a home.

title: Business Discovers Women
description: ON the subject of women, American business is acting like a 40yearold bachelor under famkly and friends pressure to get married. Almost every major corporation that cares about its public image is actively, if not desperately, casting about for suitable women candidates for nomination to the board of directors or senior management. This eagerness is certain to grow as the season for annual stockholder meetings approaches, since explanations are bound be demanded if the chairman does not have felicito,us news to announce.

title: C.C.N.Y. Stops Queens, 9769
description: City College, using a 32 zone defense, recorded a 9769 victory over Queens last night at the victors Wingate Gymnasium. C.C.N.Y. scored 19 straight points to gain a 235 advantage and widened the gap to as much as 43 points in the second half. C.C.N.Y., now with a wonlost record of 75, was led by John Graviano's 23 points. Queens mark dropped to 55.

title: MALTA'S PRELATE REPORTS TO POPE
description: ROME, Jan. 8  The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Malta, the Most Rev. Sir Michael Gonzi, reported to Pope Paul VI today on the situation in his island, where an airlift to evacuate the families of British military personnel began this morning.

title: PEAK FORM SHOWN BY ROSTROPOVICH
description: Many musicians play their instruments consummately, but only a starry few at any time possess the secret of infecting an audience with their own passion for music. Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet cellist, performs that feat of magic regularly, and he did so once more at Philharmonic Hall on Friday night in spite of a peculiar program that might have been purposely chosen to test his necromantic powers.

title: Institute To Coordinate Research on Car Safety
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8 (AP)  The Society of Automotive Engineers announced yesterday that it had created a Vehicle Research Institute to coordinate industry, government and academic research on auto safety.

title: Unit Seeks More Voice on Church Rule
description: The Orthodox Church in America, the nation's newest denomination, has voiced concern over its lack of voting power in the councils of Eastern Orthodoxy in this country.

title: Mrs. Frankel Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Frankel on Dec. 25 in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Frankel is the former Miss Sharyn Gwen Dickman, daughter of Mrs..Paul Christented of New York. The child, the couple's third, has been named Andrew David. His father is a partner in Loeb Rhoades 8e Co., investment banking firm.

title: OfficeHolders Endorse Providence Dog Show
description: The Providence County Kennel Club's 75th allbreed match at the CranitonStreet Armory in Providence,. R.I., today has drawn a distinguished list of trophy donors.

title: MICRONESIA PLAN PRODUCES RIFTS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 8  Broad differences between Micronesian leaders and American negotiators over the terms of a proposed political union of the 2,141 island and atolls of Micronesia with the United States have been disclosed in a transcript of the latest discussions, issued by the White House.

title: The Last Word
description: In one of our last 1971 issues, two full pages were devoted to our annual celebration of the year's .'books of special significance. Each of those seven titles, chosen by a majority staff vote, was granted permanent shelfroom in our library, by virtue of content and literary excellence. Today's feuilleton will discuss seven specimens of a far different stripe, also published in 1971. Seven novels whose literary quotient (with one exception) was minimal, though their collective entertainment clout was enormous. Seven fun houses, built by master carpenters who instinctively reject such tricky lollybeams as the Zeitgeist and the dichotomy of the sensibility. In short, seven Big Best Sellers that earned an alwayssuspect label several times over.

title: Columbia's Tennis Looks Better With Libby Keefer on the Scene
description: There was something about the blond, blueeyed girl that made an impression.

title: Home Improvement
description: A HANDY and extremely versatile multipurpose maintenance product that every home mechanic, do it yourselfer, or costconscious homeowner and apartment dweller will find many uses for is an aerosol spray Can of one of the various brands of moisturedisplacing, penetrating type, nongreasy lubricants that are now available in most hardware stores and in practically all auto accessory stores.

title: Bridge
description: BRIDGE, like the Bible, has its seven deadly sins, and two of them, gluttony and sloth, happen to appear in both. The glutton and the sloth were in opposition on the diagramed deal, which was reported many years ago by the late M. Harrison Gray, one of the world's great playerwriters.

title: Funeral Held for 104 Killed In Crash on Island off Spain
description: IBIZA, Spain, Jan, 8 (Reuters)  The 104 victims of the crash of a Spanish airliner yesterday on a mistshrouded peak on this Mediterranean island were buried today at a mass funeral.

title: BUCKS SET BACK PISTONS, 136119
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8 (AP) Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 36 points tonight despite missing the whole second quarter because of foul trouble, and led the Milwaukee Bucks to a 136119 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Despite Need, Few Want To Be Maids Or Butlers
description: THERE has been a marked increase in the number of applicants for residential and food service jobs during the last year, along with a notable decrease in job openings, It is an employers market everything from household help, waiters and waitresses to building maintenance men.

Ezra Austern, a landlord with buildings on the Lower East Side and in Harlem, asked in the daily Letters to the Editor section what causes slums, and answered with Calvinist certainty that it is persons wanting in discipline and moral restraints, and disrespectful of the rights and property of others. This is selfserving nonsense.

title: U.S. Aid Still Flows to India Despite CutOff, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The United States is continuing to send relief supplies to India for the approximately nine million East Pakistani refugees still there  despite a marked reluctance by many Administration officials to talk about it.

title: Travel Notes: Beleaguered Shrines, King Tut to London, Lake Placid Games
description: AFTER briefly taking a back seat to antiwar demonstrators at more than a halfdozen of America's most hallowed national shrines in recent weeks, tourists have returned in greater force than ever, according to the National Park Service. No fewer than seven national shrines in New York, Philadelphia and Washington were either seized or picketed by antiwar demonstrators in the waning days of 1971, and all emerged unscathed and with their prestige enhanced. In addition to the Statue of Liberty, the shrines included Independence Hall and the Betsy Ross House in Philadelphia, the Jefferson and Lincoln Memorials, the White House and the nation's Capitol in Washington. The Vietnam Veterans Against the War demonstrated at these national shrines to focus attention on their cause, a Park Service spokesman declared, and now that things have quieted downs the stature of the shrines in the minds of the public has seemed to increased. Tourists want to be associated with an event of historical significance and they are flocking to the Statue of Liberty and the Lincoln and Jefferson Memorials so they can say, I was there a dayor a week or a monthafter the demonstrations.' In light of this, would the Park Service welcome new demonstrations? We have stepped up security around the clock with additional plainclothesmen and uniformed police to avoid further incidents, the Park Service spokesman said.

title: The Doctor Is on Run Again.
description: Dr. Delano Meriwether will begin a new runforfun track and field season this week, but his uniform will remain the samewhite hospital Tshirt, tight yellow swim trunks and striped suspenders.

title: Et Al.
description: The perfect Nichols and May psychotherapy reader. Everything from soup to nutsFreudian, Jungian, humanistic, Gestalt, behavioral, group.... The Interviewer is a naive therapist herself, acting like a bunny with freshmansocialworker enthusiasm. The Experts are almost uniformly selfparodistic. The last chapter on Nude Marathon is an inadvertent camp masterpiece. There are some responsible practitioners represented in the book; but, really, a great and noble discovery like psychotherapy deserves better.

Halfway through the performance the curtain rang down, the management appeared to apologize, and the audience was sent home, possibly to come again at some later time. The amplifying system had broken down.

They're sending us all the way to eastern bloody Canada!

title: Metropolitan Briefs

Manes of Queens yesterday called for decentralization of the city government, with more power to county officials and Borough Presidents, as a means to obtain services and social justice for our citizens. Mr. Manes, in an inaugural speech on the steps of the Queens Borough Hall, said that many of the city's problems are caused by an archaic City Charter which fosters a feeling of estrangement rather than confidence, a sense of despair, rather than hope.

Two people died in a crash yesterday outside Valladolid, about 100 miles north of Madrid.

title: Renee and Joe Are at It Again
description: RENEE TAYLOR and Joseph Bologna certainly know how to keep ruccess all in the family. The zanily talented Mr. and Mrs. B. were responsible for the screenplay of Lovers and Other Strangers, one of 1970'5 most popular comedies. And, as anyone who has stood on line recently at the Beekman or Paramount can testify, their newest comedy, Made for Each Other (in which they also star as a pair of slightly lunatic lovers), is one of the current season's happiest hits.

title: Et Al.
description: A critical look at the life of the ordinary G.I.the pawn of the title. He is cozened and lied to by recruiting personnel, depersonalized in boot or basic training, turned into a killer and denied his rights as a citizen. The author based his contentions on interviews with a hundred of the military, mostly on the West Coast. He adds somehistory of army justice, treatment of dissenters, C.O.'s, etc. He doesn't mention recent changes in Army basic training, but it would have been too early to tell about their effectiveness. Nothing new here, but well done.

title: Recordings
description: THE latest recording of Ur. Ballo in Maschera (3 disks, London OSA1398) has the virtues of loth youth and maturity, and what combination could be more suitable to this masterpiece from Verdi's middle period? With Luciano Pavarotti, Sherrill Milnes and Helen Donath, London has entrusted Riccardo, Renato and Oscar to three of the most promising singers of our decade, and with Renata Tebaldi and Regina Resnik it has chosen to endow Amelia and Ulrica with the, vocal wisdom that years of experience can bring. The balance generally works quite well and should please enthusiasts for the relatively new as well as loyalists to established stars. This is a very satisfying pressing in all aspectssoloists, treatment of orchestra and chorus, and quality of recorded sound.

The celebration is certain to be even more ecstatic when the Sheik, who was released yesterday and flown to London, actually returns to his adoring people  possibly today or tomorrow.

Published initially in the Cambridge Review, the text of these two addresses has now been gathered into this small book.

title: The Nation; Peace Corps:; Why Are They Picking On Us?
description: WASHINGTON  A pale winter sun slanted across Lafayette park, castIng thin ribbons of light into an office across from the White House. On this afternoon of Dec. 20 Joseph H. Blatchford, the youthful director of Action, the volunteer agency that includes the Peace Corps, was pacing back and forth angrily, running his fingers through his modishlylong hair. Three days before, Congress had passed a continuing resolution slashing his $82million operating budget by $10million.

title: A Protestant, Jew and Catholic on Jews
description: If politics is too important to be left to politicians and religion too significant to be entrusted entirely to theologians, it follows  illogically perhaps  that the study of Jewish politics and religion should not be limited to Jewish scholars. As a matter of fact, at the beginning of the 19th century, Leopold Zunz who virtually singlehanded created the Science of Judaism, the critical study of Jewish history, literature and institutions, pleaded for the inclusion of Judaic studies in German universities, but in vain. Not until our century has the situation begun to change for the better. Judaic studies are taking their place among the humanities and social sciences in colleges and universities, with increasing numbers of Christian scholars developing substantial competence in the field.

title: OutofWork Executives

description: Sled dog racing, which started in this area on an informal basis four years ago, has spread and meets now are being conducted in Pennsylvania and Virginia, as well as in New Jersey and on Long Island.

title: For Ages 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10...; Now or Never; The Fight Against Pollution. By D. S. Halacy, Jr. Illustrated. 203 pp. Four Winds Press. $5.95. (Ages 12 and Up)
description: Useful advice and guidance for young activists. Of all the books now available on our endangered natural environment, this is one of the most complete and impressive. Although the encyclopedic approach runs the risk of overstuffed monotonybesides being crammed with hard facts there are quotations from Hippocrates to W. D. Howells and Lyndon Baines Johnsonthe overall effect is a quiet, substantial argument that justifies the urgency of the title.

title: ROSENBLOOM SET TO SWITCH COLTS
description: Carroll Rosenbloom, the owner of the Baltimore Colts, was reported yesterday as ready to move the team out of Baltimore after the 1972 season.

title: Fire Destroys Galileo Home
description: PADUA, Italy, Jan. 8 (UPI)  Fire today destroyed a 14thcentury building that was the home of Galileo. The building was Galileo's residence when he was a professor of physics at Padua University from 15921610.

title: I Pakistani Jail Riot Ends; 300 Are Said to Escape
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. (Reuters)  A jail riot, believed to be the worst in Pakistanis history, ended this afternoon at the Karachi jail after the prisoners were told that their genuine grievances would be heard.

title: Beirut Bans Mock Uniforms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. (Reuters)  The Lebanese Army command has banned the sale and wearing of mock uniforms with military insignia  a recent fashion among young people in the city. The command issued a statement warning offenders they risked jail or fines.

title: Miss Tuero Bows
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Bob Hewitt won the Western Province open tennis title today by defeating Francois Jauffret of France in the final, 36, 63, 64.

title: Making New Wine in Old Bottles

title: LatinAid Bank's Loans Grew To a Record Level Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 9 The Inter  American Development Bank announced today a small increase in its lending volume last year to the record total of $653.2million in loans. In addition the bank made technical assistance grants of $6million.

title: A Slogan of More for Less Is Just Not Enough
description: Yearend inventories of public higher education have sounded the same for the last two decades. The slogan? More is better. For years our great universities depended on large enrollment increases and an expanding economy for their growth in both quantity and quality.

title: Ballet: Coppelia Twice
description: The American Ballet Theater's Coppelia is the answer to the rest of the world's Nutcracker. It is that fortunate and rare thing children's ballet for people who do not even like children  a child's ballet that even W.C. Fields could take to his heart. On Saturday at the City Center, the Ballet Theater revived its version, in Enrique Martinez's most persuasive staging, starting Natha Makarova and Ivan Nagy in the afternoon and Carla Fracci and Niels Kehlet in the evening. Both casts made a dull January day into something brighter.

title: SOME PIERRE LOOT FOUND IN DETROIT
description: An estimated $750,000 worth of jewelry stolen from the Pierre Hotel a week ago was recovered yesterday in Detroit, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced last night.

title: Opposition to Rhodesia Accord Grows
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 9A feeling that black political opposition may wreck the recently concluded BritishRhodesian independence agreement is emerging here.

title: Something Basic Is Changing In N. Y. City's High Schools
description: A new impulse toward reform, quite different from any in the past, is now being felt in the high schools of New York City.

title: The Queen Whose First Dress Was BattleshipGray
description: Among the hundreds of thousands who sailed on the Queen Elizabeth in her 28 years of plying the Atlantic, and the millions of others who saw her on her way, few were able to think of the Cunard liner as just a ship.

title: Colleges Using Imagination To Spend Less, Offer More
description: A period of crisis such as the financial threat that now hovers over our educational institutions often turns out to be a period of reform. Some imaginative new plans are now being applied that may eventually help to alleviate the financial problems while strengthening the structure of higher education.

title: A U.S. Plan for Education Renewal
description: American education is in urgent need of reform, President Nixon declared in 1970. His charge has been echoed by virtually all responsible educational leaders, teacher organizations, and local school board members

title: Marcia Weiner, F.M. Comins Jr. Marry in Jersey
description: CRESSKILL, N. J., Jan. 9 Miss Marcia Susan Weiner and Frederic M. Combs jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Comins of New York and Deal, were married here this afternoon in the Tammy Brook Country Club by Rabbi Irwin M. Blank. The bride's parents ,are Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Weiner of Upper Saddle River and Fort Lee,

title: MRS. HAGGE, ON 211, WINS BURDINE GOLF
Indians in Dacca Meet First Signs of Resentment
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan, 9The green  uniformed shoppers throng the bazaars every day. They have bought up all the Americamade razor blades and lipsticks in the pharmacies. They have purchased all the Britishmade fabric in the clothing store, and they have cleaned out all the Japanese cameras and tape recorders.

title: Lindsay Modifies Position on Marijuana
description: MIAMI, Jan. 9Mayor Lindsay, who told college students yesterday that he favored elimination of criminal penalties for possession of marijuana, modified his position today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (Reuters) A dinner for 500 guests in honor of Menachem Begin, leader of the Opposition Herut party in Israel, was canceled shortly after he arrived here today by the Royal Garden Hotel because of threatening phone calls.

title: Student Aid Grows
description: The goal of guaranteeing a college education for all capable high school graduates, regardless of ability to pay, is still over the horizon, despite a growing number of scholarships, loans, grants, workstudy programs and jobs.

title: Floating School Planned
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Jan. 10 The Queen, the biggest passenger liner ever built, was brought to Hong Kong last July to be converted into a floating campus and was rechristened Seawise University. She was due. to begin her new career this year.

title: PUBLISHERS INSIST BOOK IS AUTHENTIC
description: The McGrawHill Book Company and Life magazine asserted yesterday that they intended to proceed with publication in March of the authentic autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, despite the billionaire's denunciation of the book as a fraud.

title: German Writers Rallying to Word Producers Union
description: HAMBURG, West Germany West Germany's writers two years ago founded a union. In time, it enlisted 2,000 duespaying authors and set out to define, and to defend, their hitherto neglected coin mon interests. Prominent writers joined in the cam paign. Heinrich Boll, the bestselling author among serious German novelists and at present chairman of the International Pen Club, called for an end to modesty among his fellow writers. Rolf Hochhuth, the controversial playwright, drew public attention to the sad fate of many oncefamous, aging writers now half forgotten and deprived of all oldage funds.

title: Panamanians Nark AntiU.S. Riot of 64 With Peaceful Rally
description: PANAMA CITY, Jan. 9  A Government  sanctioned and closely controlled memorial observance for 22 Panamanians killed in the Canal Zone riots of 1964 took place here today without incident.

title: Morrisania Doctors Show the Hospital's Inadequacies to 2 Public Officials
description: Two public officials touring Morrisania Hospital yesterday discovered a newly renovated maternity ward with no patients. Nurses were not available in the 331bed municipal institution to staff the ward, one of two in the hospital that meet state standards.

title: Italian Government Is Expected To Resign in the Next Few Days
description: ROME, Jan. 9  The 17monthold Government of Premier Emilio Colombo is expected to resign in the next few days, opening a crisis that may be long and inconclusive,

title: STEEL GAINS FAIL TO ANCHOR PRICES
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9, 1972Demand for steel was rising last week but not fast enough to produce price stability.

title: Ohio Plan Would Let Collegians Pay Later
description: Ohio has a firm commitment to the concept of providing higher education for as many of its citizens as possible. In the last few years, however, it has become increasingly apparent that Ohio's higher educational system is in serious difficulty.

title: Voucher Plan May Be Tested
description: At least three school districts Seattle, Wash., and San Francisco and Alum Rock (San Jose), Calif.may soon be experimenting With the voucher system for financing education. But there are maor ifs in each case.

title: Scientist Is Convinced The Voice Is Authentic
description: Dr. Lawrence Kersta, president of Voiceprint I aboratories of Somerville, N. J., was asked on Saturday to compare the recordings of Friday night's interview with Howard Hughes's testimony before a United States Senate subcommittee in 1947.

title: School Unions Expanding In Field of Higher Education
description: Teacher strikes, protest demonstrations and contract talks are so much a part of the daytoday news that it IS easy to forget that it was not always so. Ten years ago today, there was not one single collective bargaining contract in American public education. Nor was there a single state in the nation in which teachers had the legal right to be represented by an organization of their own choice or in which the teachers organization had the right to negotiate with their employers on salaries and conditions.

title: L.I. Wife of a War Prisoner Continues 75Month Vigil
3 Good Samaritans Injured
description: DANVERS, Mass., Jan. 9 (UPI) Three persons who came to the aid of an accident victim were struck by a hitandrun driver today. The police said that Ronald Dill, 35 years old, of Brokline; Richard Ryan, 26, of Danvers, and Barbara O'Brien, 42, also of Danvers, were hit by a white station wagon on U.S. Route 1 when they left their cars to aid Paul Raney, 24, of Lynn, the victim of an earlier accident. Mr. Raney and Mr. Dill were in critical condition.

title: Advertising:
description: Faced with pending legislation in various parts of the country that could affect their operations, members of the United States Brewers Association have anted up for a multimillion dollar advertising campaign to fight one of the nation's favorite pastimeslittering.

title: Soviet Craft Detect Hot Spot on Mars
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9Soviet scientists reported today that two spacecraft orbiting Mars had detected a hot spot on the planet. They also disclosed that the upper atmosphere of Mars had been found to resemble that of Venus rather than that of the earth.

title: NASTASE VICTOR IN TENNIS FINAL
description: TOWSON, Md., Jan. 9 (AP) Secondseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, bothered by an aching back, rallied to defeat Jimmy Connors 16, 64, 76, today in the final of the $7,500 Baltimore International indoor tennis championships at Towson State College.

title: 200 BLACK WOMEN HAVE DIALOGUE
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9More than 200 black women from all over the country gathered here this weekend to have dialogue over the kinds of concerns that they feel distinguish their interests from those of the white women's liberation movement.

title: No Backlash or Ecology
description: On the environmental front, 1971 was, superficially at least, something of a comedown. Where the very word environment, like motherhood or Americanism, had been almost enough to assure passage of a bill the year before, a certain coolness was discernible in 1971 both in Administration circles and in Congress. Secretary of Commerce Stans articulated the change when he urged industry and Government to go slow in trying to restore the country's air, land and water: We must weigh environmental goals against economic reality and say Wait a minute or there might be an environmental backlash.

title: Overcame Paralysis of Legs
description: In the process of learning to walk all over again". at 18 years of age, as he was forced by the paralysis of both legs to do, Ted Shawn took steps beyond walking to the dance. By that he narrowly missed a life of declamation as a Methodist minister and went on to become a prime force in shaping modern dance in America.

title: Monetary Fund Devises Paper Gold Revaluation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 9The International Monetary Fund has devised. an intricate legal scheme whose practical effect is to upvalue Special Drawings Rights, or 'paper gold", against the United States dollar.

title: Mrs. Nixon Ends African Trip; Welcomed Home by President
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 9  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon left Africa this morning after an exhausting oneweek goodwill tour in which she hugged dozens of children, watched hundreds of tribal dancers and shook thousands of hands.

title: Red Smith The Highly Irregular Mr. Holmes
description: The Baker Street Irregulars, who are dedicated to the proposition that Mr. Sherlock Holmes was the best and wisest man of his time, held their annual dinner the other night to celebrate the Master's 118th birthday. The usual toasts were drunk, with the usual reverence. It was a happy occasion, and yet a little sad because the Irregulars, scholars though they be, do not realize that it is a false god they serve.

title: Women on the Campus Find a Weapon

description: ALBANYIn a short time the 1972 Legislature will begin to receive chapters of a voluminous document that its drafters hope will be the source for sweeping overhaul of the state's entire elementary and secondary education system.

description: America's institutions of public higher education are caught in a cross fire of conflicting pressures. They are expected to educate more students and in more imaginative ways, but to accomplish this with less money.

description: PARIS, Jan. 9 (AP)  Paul Elvstrom, the Danish sailing champion, has been named to head the 1974 French challenge for the America's Cup, the Paris Sailing Club announced today. Elvstrom is a fourtime Olympic gold medalist and seventime world champion.

title: Muskie's Rights Stance
description: MIAMI, Jan. 9If Senator Edmund S. Muskie is to, convince American voters that his presence in the White House would inspire their capacity to work together once we talk to one another and understand each other, he may have to prove it first to black voters in Florida's March 14 Presidential primary. The Senator from Maine used that phrase and others like it in an attempt last Tuesday, when he declared his candidacy for the Democratic nomination, to strike a tone of humanistic leadership in contrast to what he regards as President Nixon's record of benign neglect of civil and human rights. But Mr. Muskie was still being haunted by the memory of comment he made four months ago that he could not pick Negro running mate because the ticket would be unelectable.

You've got to have some recreation in life, said the tall man in the fedora who was watching television. Hey, don't use our names, get that? Or they'll come and arrest us again.

White, in his article on New Year's Eve, asked why it is that an Englishman is unhappy until he has explained America. He wrote that he seldom meets Americans who are tensed up because they have yet to explain England.

Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Ambassador, assisted by Cantor Max Rubin. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schulman of Pair Lawn and Mr, and Mrs, Mortimer S. Schofield of New York.

Mr. Godwin, whose right arm and other leg were severed in the crash, died at Norfolk General Hospital, where he had been in critical condition since the accident Wednesday.

The straphanger, now forced to pay 35 cents ride, and threatened by additional fare hikes in the future, may take comfort from the fact that the commuter, too, is victim of a public service concept that operates with equal harshness, equal incompetence and equal arrogance for all.

description: I've developed a new philosophy, reads the sign in the principal's office. I only dread one day at a time.

title: Visit to Vietnam: I.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.A few months ago I was in Saigon with an American student delegation. My most moving experience there was meeting 21 prisoners at a reception center in a Buddhist pagoda, all of whom had been released within the preceding two to three weeks. They had been in prison from three to fifteen years. About half of them were out of the tiger cages on Con Son Island. Themarks of suffering were visible upon them. One had been totally blinded by what we were told is a disciplinary device at Con Son: throwing lime down on the prisoners. One had lost a leg. Several had difficulty walking.

title: Needed: Candor and Consent
description: From the strategic viewpoint it makes good sense for the United States to maintain a modest naval task force in the Persian Gulf, as it has done for twenty years. What concerns us about the new arrangement for permanent American naval station on Bahrain is the same problem that bothers Senator Case of New Jersey and four of his Foreign Relations Committee colleagues.

title: Hawaii Avoids Disparities
description: There are no spending disparities among districts in Hawaii because it has only one district. It is the only state that does not rely on local property taxes for public education. The system seems to work quite well:

title: FOE OF NAZIS WINS PRIZE FOR POETRY

title: Shaper of the Dance
description: Ted Shawn helped change America's view of dancing. Shawn was a remarkable innovator, as a dancer himself, as a teacher, as an educator and as the founder and director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. He was one of the prime influences on American dance, not only in helping to shape its actual technique and methodology, but also in helping it win national acceptance as a ma jor art form. Shawn, like many dancers of his generation, started to dance as therapy. His studies of ballet and ballroom dancing led him to the conclusion that America needed a new way of dancing. In his youth he studied theology, and he was destined for the ministry. All his life he remained something of a preacher, a proselytizer, a man with an unshakable sense of mission.

title: ' Eagle in a Cage':Exile of Napoleon Is Subject of Romance
description: The esthetic question of how to create a historical romance can sometimes, at least in the movies, be parboiled down to the generally practical problems of (a) how to outface history and (b) how to introduce romance. There have been some good, even some great, movies built out of such evasive exploitation. But Fielder Cook's "Eagle in a Cage," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater and which purports to deal with Napoleon's ultimate exile on St. Helena, isn't among them.The film sees Napoleon during his last years as essentially a dashing figure, tall, lean, athletic, in wonderful shape except for the pesky stomach condition that is rapidly killing him. Despite certain consolations on St. Helena he keeps plotting his escape.He is driven partly by a need for action, partly by love of power, but mostly by that sense of personal destiny that may afflict some figures in history but that absolutely obsesses figures in movie history.It is a sense that is commonly shared by everybody else, by the great man's enemies ("I make you realize how small you are," Napoleon taunts his jailer, the petty Sir Hudson Lowe) as well as his admirers, and that tends to mess up every aspect of his life. "That's right! Attack! That's your greatest talent, isn't it," complains the wife of his most loyal follower, Count Bertrand, when what she wants from Napoleon is a little tenderness in bed.Which brings up the subject of romance, the substance of the tempestuous days and torrid nights on St. Helena, skinny dipping with Mme. Bertrand (the conditions of Napoleon's incarceration sometimes suggest Acapulco  before it went commercial) or mastering the hot-blooded young Betsy Balcombe.Now, Betsy Balcombe, unlike Mme. Bertrand, was in fact the historical Napoleon's friend on St. Helena. But while the history books describe her as a spirited girl of 14, the movie makes her an emotionally precocious 16, played by an actress of 24 (Georgina Hale) with a kind of mature intensity that argues for at least 30 years' experience on the stage. No wonder there is so much fire between them  from their big seduction scene near the end to their incredibly portentous meeting near the beginning, with my favorite line in the movie: Napoleon's "Have a bonbon."It should be obvious that the film-maker's imagination working at this level will create roles to tax the most imaginative of actors. But from his awesome cast, with a few exceptions, what he generally gets is a fairly professional elaboration of clichs. Neither Kenneth Haigh's Napoleon nor Billie Whitelaw's Fanny Bertrand quite escapes the embarrassments of the dialogue. But both Georgina Hale and Michael Williams as the young Irish doctor, O'Meara, though inappropriate, seem reasonably alive.Sir John Gielgud, however, seems wholly alive; and if there is any excuse for "Eagle in a Cage," it is surely in its indulging his portrayal of unreconstructed old age. He plays a Lord Sissal, an emissary from London with a plan for Napoleon's return to France at the head of a puppet government.Of course, the plan falls through, but before it does Sir John has filled the screen with his glorious grimaces, has wonderfully insulted his companion of years, Sir Ralph Richardson as Lowe, and has demonstrated that for the movies there is nothing in the pageant of human history to match the triumphant cackle from an old man's mouth, the malicious glimmer in his eyes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese 'Vampire Doll' Opens at Bijou
description: There are precious few vampire thrillers of merit. Last season yielded one pip from France, "Daughters of Darkness," with the old tooth-and-fang theme artistically coiled around a Lesbian fugue.And so, on Saturday, did "The Vampire Doll" from Japan, wedged in among all the samurai sword-swingers at the Bijou Theater. This one, too, works just fine, from the opening shot, as the color camera peers through a rainswept wind-shield to a remote country house, with stately, rumbling harpsichord music  or the Oriental equivalent.Twenty minutes or so later, several things are very evident, after the first visitor disappears and two comely young people drive out to find him. Somebody has had a good look at Hitchcock's "Psycho."Secondly, while the director, Michio Yamamoto, also has the master's economy, he tells his grisly story with a cool, taciturn detachment all his own. Don't be fooled by what seems a conventional staging. There is plenty lurking around the bend, some of it hair-raising.Finally, the picture is exceptionally well-written, with a denouement that is fascinating andwell, almost credible. The acting is on a par with the rest. Unfortunately, the theater could supply only the skimpiest of credits on Saturday, so credit can't be allotted proportionately.The English titles are finewhat you can see of them, through nobody's fault. For here again we have a case of white-lettered translations appearing time after time on white garb or light backgrounds. And this is one of those pictures where every word counts."The Vampire Doll," a tight, toothsome thriller that makes a little go a long way.

title: Agnew Says U.S. Is Ending Radical Permissiveness
description: COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., Jan. 9 (UPI)Vice President Agnew said today that the nation was emerging from what he described as the temporary insanity of the nineteensixties. He gave the Nixon Administra tion much of the credit for the recovery.

title: Widow of Dr. King Hopes Center Will Keep His Philosophy Alive
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 9  In bulding on Beckwith Street here a number of visitors spent the afternoon today with the memory of the Rev Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Howard Hughes Tells of His Life In a 3,000Mile Phone Interview
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9A disembodied voice identified as that of Howard Robards Hughes, the billionaire who has been one of the world's most mysterious personalities, has sounded out of more than a decade of obscurity to deny the authenticity of a forthcoming purported autobiography and to discuss candidly many other aspects of his life.

title: Where Have All The Sitins Gone?
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.Sometimes this year's college seniors, the weary survi. vors of the Class of 72 sound like old folks. As they sit and reminisce of bygone era it is a wrench to realize the memories they are sifting fondly are only three or four years old.

title: C. A. McDevitt Jr. Weds Robin Chalk
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Jan. 9 The marriage of Miss Robin Kim Chalk, a senior at the University of Hartford, to Charles Austin McDevitt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDevitt of Philadelphia and Sea Isle, N. J., took place here today. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Howard Chalk, managing director of Chalk, Nissen, Hanft, Inc., an advertising agency in New York, and Mrs. Chalk.

title: Eleanor D'Antuono Casts Impish Spell In Happy  Coppelia
description: In Coppelia, one man's unhaPpiness is a town's joy as the spell of Dr. Coppelius's doll is broken and young love triumphs. Adroitly mixing buoyant charm and naughtiness yesterday afternoon, Eleanor D'Antuono created a victorious Swanilda whose impish pouting became transformed into delirious marriage smiles in the American Ballet Theater's production at the City Center.

title: Welcomed in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Mrs. Nixon was welcomed home this evening by her family and a crowd of about 1,000 that included Cabinet members and other Government officials.

title: Phone Call Cost $360
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP)The Howard Hughes phone call will cost about $360, the Pacific Telephone Company said today. Officials derived the figure from the length of the stationtostation call. A spokesman for the Hughes Tool Company said the National Broadcasting Company, which set up the 160minute interview, would pay for the call. N.B.C. comment was not immediately available.

title: White House Denies Credibility Gap During IndiaPakistan War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Nixon Administration, con cerned over charges that it lied to the American public during

title: Can Courts and Money Do It?
description: Two years ago, writing in The Times's annual education supplement, I contended that the crucial phase in solving a problem is the process by which comes to be defined. I distinguished between two kinds of problems in the area of social policy. First there are those that involve the aggregation of sufficient support in the political system to bring about a change in public policy. Second there are those in which social goals are fairly well agreed upon but where administrators lack the knowledge to achieve them. I called the first political problems, the second knowledge problems.

title: SmallScale Protest Is Big on Columbia Campus
description: Often these days I find myself standing perplexed before the large window of my office in Low Library looking out over the Columbia campus and watching students hurry to class. Little more than a year ago this scene was dominated by large angry crowds in the College Walk. Now they are gone.

title: Refugees in Quangtri Begin Shift to South
description: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, Jan. 9The refugees, many of them barefoot, stood on the shiny airstrip early yesterday morning holding clumsy bundles and shivering babies and looking fearful of the big American airplanes and the long voyage ahead.

title: Respite for the Library
description: The encouraging response by individuals and major corporations to the desperate appeal of the New York Public Library will allow the science arid technology research division to reopen on January 17 after a threeweek shutdown for lack of operating funds.

title: BIG THAI B52 BASE REPORTED ATTACKED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, Jan. 10 (AP)A Thai military spokesman said that terrorist commandos today attacked the big ThaiUnited States B52 bomber base at Utapao, 90 miles south of Bangkok. Two B52's were reported damage.

title: N.Y.U. Faces Critical Issues
description: New York University dramatizes several critical issues In higher education: the crucial but difficult role of the urban university, the financial crisis in private higher education, the effort to break the traditional academic lockStep.cent are New York State residents. Of the 11,000 undergraduates, 75 per cent are New York State residents. Of 10,000 in adult education, 85 per cent reside in the state. There can be no doubt that New York University provides substantial public service to this state as well as to the nation.

title: Music: Israeli Orchestra
description: The Israel Chamber Orchestra, which made its first American tour three years ago, is back for a second one and played at Hunter College Playhouse Saturday night.

title: Patman Criticizes Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) Wright Patman, i na letter to Attorney General John N. Mitchell released over the weekend, asks why the Justice Department has not prosecuted any former officials of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad. Mr. Patman, Texas Democrat and chairman of the House Banking Committee, noted that the Philadelphia district attorney had charged two former Penn Central officials and a third man with conspiracy to defraud the line.

title: Museum Rift Was Developing a Year
description: Although John B. Hightower's departure as director of the Museum of Modern Art last week seemed dramatically sudden to his artworld colleagues outside the museum, it had been building over a long time.

title: Saigon Investigates Attack By Terrorist That Killed 9
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (AP)The South Vietnamese Government began an investigation today Into one of the worst terrorist attacks of the war. Authorities said that of the more than 100 casualties, some might have been killed or injured by being trampled in the panic that followed a grenade explosion.

title: Fear and Necessity Spur Reform Drive
description: People and institutions resist change. Only fear and economic necessity therefore tend to set in motion the kind of critical review that brings about reform. In the last year, both fear and economic necessity exerted strong pressure on American education. As a result, this period of frantic and occasionally desperate belttightening has also become a time of thoughtful analysis and reform.

title: GAMBLING JUSTICE CONDEMNED HERE
description: The State Commission of Investigation accused the Police Department and the Criminal Courts here yesterday of utter failure to enforce the antigambling laws in New York City.

title: A 60c Fare Seen By 74 Unless U.S. And State Aid City
description: A member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the 35cent fare on the city's subways and buses would have to be raisea to 60 cents in two years unless massive Federal and state aid was obtained.

title: Harris Urges Cereal Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) Senator Fred R. Harris urged the Federal Trade Commission today to start antitrust actions against the nation's two largest cereal processors, the Kellogg Company and General Mills, Inc. The Oklahoma Democrat gave his views in a letter to the F.T.C. chairman.

title: Man Robbed TwiceOf $240 and of 35 Cents
description: After reporting a holdup in which two men stole $240 from him on a downtown Brooklyn street last night, a 50yearold man was robbed by two other men who took the 35 cents the police had given him for subway fare home.

title: Wesley Ruggles, Director, Dead; His Cimarron Won Oscar in 31
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 Wesley Ruggles, the motionpidttire director, died last night in Santa Monica Convalescent H4spital, after having suffered a stroke. He was 84 years old andlived in Beverly Hills.

title: 100 on Argentine Train Robbed by Armed Team
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Jan. 9 (Reuters)A group believed to be guerrillas held up a train bound for this Argentine resort today and robbed more than 100 passengers of cash and jewelry before escaping, the police said.

title: King Frederik Gains
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 9 (AP)Doctors reported continued improvement today in the condition of King Frederik IX, who suffered a heart attack last Monday.

title: 4th Fatality in Buffalo Fire
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 9 (UPI)  A Cheektowaga man died today of burns he suffered in an explosion and fire at the Pillsbury flour mill here a week ago. Vincent Donnelly, 53 years old, died in Emergency Hospital. His death was the fourth attributed to the explosion. One other worker is missing.

title: Faulkner Papers Are Found At His Mississippi Home
description: OXFORD, Miss., Jan. 9 (AP)Manuscripts by the late William Faulkner, the Nobel Prizewinning novelist, were discovered in his home while it was being readied for termite treatment, University of Mississippi officials reported on Friday.

title: CHIEFS WIN, 4136; 2 PLAYERS INJURED
description: The Chiefs defeated the Bombers, 4136, yesterday in an International Roller. Derby League game before 10,611 at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Electric Company, a New Light for Learning
description: About 12 weeks ago the electric company was to many Americans just another term for the local power company. To many adults it probably still is, but to growing thousands of grade school students 'The Electric Company has since become one of the day's brighter half hours.

title: The New Pragmatism
description: Six months have now passed since President Nixon astonished the world by announcing that he would visit Peking. The trip has not yet taken place, but the passage of time has only reinforced the original impression of the extraordinary importance of the renewed SinoAmerican dialogue.

title: John Fabrizi, 58, Headed Ontario County Democrats
description: CLIFTON SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP)John Fabrizi, the Ontario County Democratic party chairman and one of four vice chairmen of the Democratic state organization, died of a heart attack today at his home in nearby Orleans. He was 58 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Freighter With 34 Men Feared Last Off Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 9 (Reuters)An African freighter, the 7,840ton Dona Anita, with a crew of 34, was feared sunk with all hands today in stormy North Pacific waters west of Vancouver Island.

title: Stanford Head Backs Radical's Ouster
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. Dr. Richard W. Lyman, Stanford University's president, confirmed today the dismissal of a radical professor who was accused by the university of inciting campus disruptions last February.

title: Turnaround at Tufts
description: From 1968 to 1971while higher education generally was drifting into its financial depression  Tufts University in Medford, Mass., performed the remarkable feat of converting a $1.2million operating deficit into a $13,500 surplus.

title: Authorities in Ulster Say They Foiled a Jail Escape
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 9 (AP)Soldiers and the police followed up a tip today and foiled what they said was a planned escape at Crumlin Jail.

title: Foundations Seed Projects
description: Foundation giving for education last year was dominated by a $100million Ford Foundation grant for a sixyear program to improve limited number of private Negro colleges and to provide minority students with Individual study awards.

title: MRS. PETER KIHSS SR.
description: Mrs. Peter Kihss Sr., mother of Peter Kihss, a reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday at her home, 18618 Avon Road, Jamaica Estates, Queens. She was 87 years old. Her late husband was an automobile dealer. Surviving also are two grandchildren.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 9The fascination of Jack Anderson's papers lies less in their substance than in the decisional process they (Otiose. President Nixon's bias in the IndiaPakistan crisis had hardly been a secret. But no outsider heretofore ha had such an authentic glimpse of the way this Presidents foreign policy is made and carried out.

title: Democratic Rules Reform Ending FavoriteSon Bids
Fund Executive Expects Corner to Be Turned in 1972
description: Thomas A. Martin, 41, is executive vice president of Anchor Corporation, which serves as investment adviser and underwriter for six mutual funds with assets totaling around $2billion. In an interview last week with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times, Mr. Martin commented on various aspects of the mutual fund scene, both past and present. Excerpts from their conversation follow:

description: BASKETBALL

title: Clothes That Look Expensive and Are
description: Despite all the belt tightening, there's still room for clothes that look expensive and are.

title: Rector of Justin In a Harder Time
description: GROTON, Mass.  Cotty Peabody is a great man, in his way. What I really resent is that my graduates are not more different from his. For all my emphasis on the humanities and his on God, we both turn out stockbrokers!

title: India Welcomes Mujib
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, Jan. 10 (AP)Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Bengali leader, landed here this morning on his way to a hero's welcome in Dacca, East Pakistan,

title: Canadians Test Equity Plan
description: The Canadian province of New Brunswick has attempted to eliminate the inequities of local school financing by shifting the responsibility from the towns to the central government.

title: There's Hard Work Before These Virginians Can Eat That Ham
description: MARKHAM, Va.The first snow in Fauquier County had fallen too early and too heavily. Ordinarily, Mrs. Jim Arbogast said, we'd have one cc two hogs on the pole by this time.

title: Japan Stirs Asian Resentment In Aggressive Business Drive
On CounterCulture and OvertheCounter Culture
description: Suitemates in B7 at Wellheeled U., Mike, Charles, Tim and Tim's girl are great readersbut it's not contemporary poetry or fiction that turns them on. Mike is absorbed in St. Theresa for course credit (Spanish XX: Versions of Mystical Experience"). Charles is into linguistic theory as a way of grappling with his personal version of the knots problem defined by R. S. Laing. Tim's girl is a yoga freak, and as for Timat the moment he's on the prowl for book his welleducated parents can read that will challenge their conviction that antirationalism is just another name for drugs. (Last vacation he left Richard Alpert's Be Here Now around the house and scared the old folks silly.)

title: Some Remembrances of P. S. 999
description: A look backward across time at a New York City public school about 25 years ago evokes the inevitable comparisons, Those were the halycon days before teacher strikes, parent boycotts, anger and violence.

title: Books of The Times
description: FROM THE ROOF OP AFRICA. By C. W. Nicol. 362 pages. Illustrated. Knopf: $16.

title: Connally Forecasts Gains By Economy on All Fronts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Treasury Secretary John B. Connally is forecasting an excellent economy for 1972 with forward movement on all fronts and with the DowJones industrial average reaching a new high. We'll break 1,000 this year, maybe 1,100, Mr. Connally told reporters aboard President Nixon's jetliner late last night.
