description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESSMEN BEGIN TALKS IN BRUSSELS
description: BRUSSELS, Tan. 9 (UP)Fourteen members of the House Ways and Means Committee arrived from Paris today, and began a series of meetings to acquaint themselves with the European Common Market.

title: Four Children Die in Fire
description: HOGANSVILLE, Ga., Jan. (UPI)Four children were killed and another was hospitalized today when fire swept through the small, woodframe house where they were sleeping. The dead children were identified as Timmy Mickfield, 3 months old; Soto Roberson, 4 months, Tommy Roberson, years, and Susie Lee Banks, 13. Ronnie Banks, 13, was hospitalized.

title: See, Hear, Taste, Smell Used In New Urban Planning Method
description: Upper East Siders and city planners would grope, sniff, listen, search and taste their way together through the neighborhood under an approach to urban planning for which Federal funds are being sought.

title: Woman Killed by Runaway Car; 7 Others Die in Accidents Here
description: A Brooklyn woman leaving church with her two sans was killed yesterday when another parishioner's car went out of control and went onto the sidewalk.

description: WASHINGTON  PerforMance contracting sounded to many, just a year ago, like brilliantly promising solution to the problem of slow learn. ing at inner city schools.

title: Shostakovich's 15th, A 4Part Symphony, Praised in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 9Dmitri Shostakovich's newest symphony, the 15th, had its premiere last night before gala audience in the great hall of the Conservatory.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Newsmen's Conversation With Howard R. Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 Following are excerpts from a transcript of a conversation between a group of newsmen and, by telephone from 3,000 miles away, a voice identified as that of Howard R. Hughes. Participants were James Bacon of the Hearst Newspapers, Marvin Miles of The Los Angeles Times. Vernon Scott of United Press International, Roy Neal of the National Broadcasting Company, Gene Handsaher of The Associated Press, Wayne Thomis of The Chicago Tribune and Gladwin Hill of The New York Times.

title: Enemy is Said to Report Death of 2 U.S. Airmen
description: Mrs. Cora M. Weiss of the Bronx, cochairman of the Committee of Liaison with Families of Servicemen Detained in North Vietnam, said here yesterday that she had been informed by North Vietnam that Capt. Lawrence Gene Stoltz and First Lieut. Dale Francis Koons of the Air Force were dead. A photograph of their identification cards and other items released by North Vietnam was published yesterday in The New: York Times.

title: State Hearings Here Hold Hint of Politics
description: Since formation of the state commission to investigate New York City government, state officials have consistently denied that its actions would be politically motivated.

title: Prostitutes Assist Police ht Capture Of Robbery Suspect
description: Detectives seized a 23yearold man shortly before sunrise yesterday and accused him of robbing an offduty correction officer in the Bronx and later raping and robbing a woman in a midtown hotel. The police were looking for the man because of complaints from Times Square area prostitutes, who said a man with a policeman's shield was threatening them.

title: Two Sides of Tenure
description: Drastic cuts in public funding, mounting operating deficits and widespread discontent among students, the public and many legislators have added fuel to a growing debate over the validity of the tenure system.

title: FLOW OF IMPORTS TO U.S. CONTINUES
description: President Nixon's efforts to improve the balance of payments by holding down imports have been largely ignored by domestic corporations, which are continuing to buy large quantities of imported commodities and merchandise.

Cutbacks in the City May Be Only a Prelude to More Economies
Young Trustees Gain Influence
description: Once a month, JeanLouis d'Heilly, a softspoken graduate student at the New School for Social Research, undergoes a metamorphosis.

title: LAW ON MENTALLY ILL IS UPHELD BY COURT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, has upheld a lowercourt ruling that sections of state law pertaining to the confinement of mentally ill persons were constitutional.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, will formally announce tomorrow that he will make another attempt to win the Presidency.

title: John Serrano Jr., et aL, and School Tax Equality
description: LOS ANGELESAbout this time five years ago, John Serrano Jr. was called in by the principal of the school in the MexicanAmerican barrio of East Los Angeles where his two young sons were in first and second grades. You've got a couple of very bright kids  get them out of East L.A. schools if you want to give them a chance, the principal told him bluntly.

title: Ted Shawn Is Dead; Led Modern Dance To Stature as Art
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 9Ted Shawn, considered to be the father of Modern dance, died here this morning at the age of 80.

title: Spaniel Club's Best Goes To D.J., English Springer
Lyons Tops Sadler
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 9Dudley Lyons of the New York Athletic Club won the Luckenback Memorial Invitation squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club today, defeating Fred Sadler of New Haven in the final, 1510, 1510, 1510.

title: KENNETH PATCHEN DIES AT AGE OF 60
description: PALO ALTO. Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)Kenneth Patchen, the poet who pioneered poetry reading to the accompaniment of jazz music in the nineteenfifties, died at his home here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: Mayors'
description: Ten years ago the United Federation of Teachers and the New York City Board of Education signed the first labor contract covering public school instructors in a major city.

title: G.G.BLATTMACHR, 63, A LAWYER, TEACHER
description: George G. Blattmachr, a founding member of the Manhattan law firm that is now Wynn, Blattmachr, Campbell & Milas, died Saturday in the Plainview division of Nassau County Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived at 180 Hilton Avenue in Hempstead,

title: Budget Crises Spur Reappraisal Of Basic Goals
description: American education, after more than a decade heady expansion, is being shaken by a pervasive financial crisis that is prompting a broad reappraisal of what schools and colleges are doing  and why.

title: Test Run of a Turbo Train Called Success by Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Amtrak officials expressed satisfaction tonight with preliminary data on a roundtrip test run of its turbo train from Washington to Parkersburg, W. Va.

title: $400Million Deficit at Close Of Fiscal Year Seen by Levitt
description: ALBANYJan. 9  State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that despite the approval of an emergency fiscal program by the Legislature last week, the state would still have a cash deficit of $400million at the end of the current fiscal year, next March 31.

title: Wanted: A System Of Finance
description: The new depression in education causing a reexamination of the sources of funding for our schools and colleges. The funding roles of local, state and national governments, as well as of private individuals and agencies, are being reassessed, and many, old assumptions about who should pay for formal education are being called into question.

title: BENGALI ASSERTS ANY AID FROM U.S. MIGHT BE TAINTED
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9The designated foreign minister of Bangladesh, the nation proclaimed by the East Pakistan separatists; said today that his government viewed the United States as an enemy of yesterday from whom it would hesitate to take any future aid because `,there might be some poison in it.

title: RAMBLERS REVIVE MUSIC OF SOUTH
description: After an absence of three and a half years, the New Lost City Ramblers brought their goodtime, oldtime music back to New York yesterday at two concerts for the Bluegrass Club of New York at St. Catherine of Siena Auditorium, 420 East 69th Street.

title: Births
description: WEISSMr & Mrs. Stephen Weiss of Pur. chase, N.Y. anaunce the birth of daughter Jocelyn Stephens on January 1972 In Greenwich Hospital.

title: Charles Washburn, Theater Publicist And Author, Dead
description: Charles Washburn, author, playwright and veteran press agent, died yesterday at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived in North Bergen, N. J.

title: A Church and a Prison Exchanging Services
description: DANBURY, Conn., Jan. (AP)  Ten inmates at the Federal Correctional Institution here participated today in the prison's first service exchange with a church, prison officials said.

title: Peking Confirms Atom Test
description: PEKING, Jan. 9 (Agence France  Presse)  China confirmed today that she carried out a nuclear test on Friday.

title: Reaction Is Mixed on Varsity Freshmen
description: George Raveling has a reputation for being one of the finest college basketball recruiters in the nation. For seven years, the 33yearold Raveling helped build Villanova into a national power and for the last three years he has shifted his base of operation to Maryland, which has national aspirations.

title: Political Subsidy
description: Even before he officially announced his candidacy for reelection last week, President Nixon had been out bidding for the hardhat vote. His recent visit to a San Diego shipyard provided the occasion for promising a huge Federal handout to subsidize construction of oil tankers in American yards.

description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL GOTTLIEB
description: Paul Gottlieb, who with his wife, Trudi, formerly ran the Ritz Plaza Caterers, Park Avenue and 81st Street, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 521 Park Avenue.

title: Productivity is in Eye of the Beholder
description: Each year there are certain hot words or catchphrases on the lips of the multitudes working in education. For example, reassess and retrench, parameters and reordering of priorities all have hadand continue to havetheir days of heady popularity.

title: City Chauffeur Arrested With Marijuana in Car
description: The chauffeur for the city's Acting Commissioner of Air Resorces was arrested last night in Brooklyn with two other men when police found two handfuls of marijuana in the Commissioner's official limousine.

title: Compliance With PricePosting Rule Grows Here
description: In dry cleaners and hardware stores in Manhattan's middle income and upperIncome areas, in bakeries and fancy delicatessens, the baseperiod price list required under the Federal price stabilization program is gradually making its appearance.

title: FLOYD JEFFERSON, 93, TEXTILE MERCHANT
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. Floyd Wellman Jefferson, retired textile merchant who had been a leader in New York civic affairs, died yesterdays at his home, 25 Doubling Road. His age was 93.

title: Kialoa II Leads Yacht Race
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 9 (AP)Kialoa II, far in the lead, seemed likely tonight to set a record in the I,500mile ocean yacht race from Hobart, Tasmania, to Auckland. She was only 245 miles from the northern tip of New Zealand and, if the weather holds fair, she could reach Auckland by Tuesday.

description: A group from the City Plan ning Commission traveled to the Upper West Side last night to ask community residents what they thought of the city's development plans for their neighborhood.

title: PAY UNIT TO NAME SOME VIOLATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The Government announced to day that it would name publicly some violators of the wage price standards and that it might disclose to the source of a complaint the outcome of its investigation.

title: GAINS CONTINUE ON OMEX AND OTC
description: The upward trend on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market continued yesterday as prices in both markets advanced in active trading.

description: LONDON, Jan. 10Britain held to a firm line today on withdrawal of her forces from Malta, but hints of American intervention raised hopes for a settlement of the angry dispute.

title: Cubs Put Jenkins In $100,000 Class
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI) Ferguson Jenkins, the Na tional League's topwinning pitcher last season, signed a twoyear contract with the Chicago Cubs today calling for more than $100,000 each year.

description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Jan. 10 (AP)Furman broke away from a tenacious Manhattan defense to score a 10595 victory in overtime tonight.

title: LARRIE O'FARRELL
description: Larrie O'Farrell, whose col umn Buying Wisely was na tionally distributed by the Bet ter Business Bureau, died of pneumonia yesterday in Red lands, Calif. She was 42 years old.

title: Vanderbilt on Top
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 10 (AP)Vanderbilt played a torrid first half and defeated Flor ida, 10487, in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: Man in the News
description: When Clifford Irving was 6 years old, his first story, Mother Duck Died, was published in a summer camp magazine. Years later, he described it as macabre Freudian stuff, but noted that it had caused little stir. Now, at the age of 41, Mr. Irving is the author of eight books, has trav eled extensively over the world and has experi mented with a variety of life styles in a search not for controversy but for what he calls basic truths in life.

title: 1.8 Million Refugees Return
description: CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Almost 1.8 million of the 10 million Bengali refu gees who fled from their home land to India have returned home, the Indian Refugee Relief Commissioner, B. K. Bhatta charjee, said today.

title: Security Council Session in Africa Expected Despite U.N. Financial Problems

description: GLORY. By Vladimir Nabokov. 205 pages. Mc GrawHill. $6.95.

title: Fears of Tet Drive Are Rising in Saigon
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Jan. 9  There are firm indica tions that the 12,000man Viet namese Airborne Division will be sent to the Central Highlands soon to counter what high American and Vietnamese offi cials say is an imminent Com munist offensive. However, many field officers here on the scene express doubt that such an offensive will take place.

title: 3 FOUND IN HOTEL, HIDING WITH LOOT
description: Three burglars were found in hiding last night at the Berk shir Hotel at Madison Avenue and 52d Street after the police locked the doors to the 21story hotel for more than an hour and made a floorbyfloor search.

title: Bridge: Bidding Modification Is Needed For PartScore Play at Rubber
description: The full in bridge activity here during Christmas and the New Year affected not only the tournament players but also the rubber bridge enthusiasts, two groups that to some extent overlap.

title: Emil Teichert, 74, Leader In Socialist Labor Party
description: Emil F. Teichert, the Social ist Labor party's candidate for the Vice Presidency in 1936, died Sunday at his upstate home in Lake Hill, N. Y. He was 74 years old and lived at 135 Terrace View Avenue here.

title: AfroArt Coloring Book: From Project to Profit
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10Stu dents at Highland Park Col lege, an inner city community college with a 95 per cent black enrollment, have at tracted attention here and in Cleveland and Chicago be cause of an African art color ing book that they have published.

title: News Group Admits Women
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10 (AP)An other bastion of male exclu sivity fell today when the New York State Legislative Corre spondents' Association voted to invite appropriate women to its annual show and dinner and to allow women members to perform. No audible dissent was evident as members of the organization broke a tradition dating to the beginning of the century.

title: News Analysis
description: Rankandfile revolts like last Friday's sickout by 1,300 mem bers of the Transport Workers Union are nothing new to the organization. Matthew Guinan, the union's international presi dent since 1966, and his prede cessor, the late Michael J. Quill, often have had to return from tough negotiating sessions with the Transit Author ity and deal with members who were angry because more was not ex acted at the bar gaining table. The two men, both tough feisty Irishmen, in evitably prevailed in such up risings.

title: Tornado Strikes Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 10 (UPI) One man was killed and seven persons were injured today by a tornado that touched down twice in the Atlanta area. There was also extensive property damage.

title: JEWELER IS INDICTED IN $7MILLION THEFT
description: A man identified as a part owner of a Brooklyn jewelry concern was indicted yester day by a Bronx grand jury on charges of criminal possession of stolen property, allegedly seven $1million United States treasury bills.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? MUSIC ONLY A CLUE
description: The Evening of Jazzfolkma that was presented at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night pro duced a partial explanation of that mysterious word in its title. There was jazz played by quin tets led by Joe Newman and Eddie Bonnemere. And there was a folk element in Bill Lee's presentation of excerpts from his folk festival, One Mile East, with his bass violin choir. But Ma? Apparently she didn't make it.

title: 7 IN HARRISBURG WIN PLEA ON LAWYERS
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 10 (AP)Each of seven of eight of the Harrisburg Eight defend ants has been granted permis sion to have several trial law yers. The eighth, John T. Glick, said he wanted no law yer because the most effective counsel for myself is to repre sent myself.

title: ZULU SHOW HEADED FOR THEATER IN U.S.
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 10A former South African beauty queen, now mar ried to an American theatrical producer, plans to present Umabathaa Zulu version of Macbethat an openair amphitheater in Los Angeles and perhaps elsewhere in the United States.

title: WALTER M. HALLE, 67; HEADED STORE CHAIN
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 Wal ter Murphy Halle, retired board chairman and chief executive officer of the Halle Bros. Co. department store chain, died to day at his home in Waite Hill. He was 67 years old.

title: Humphrey Joins the Race; Asks U.S. to End War Now
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10Senator Hubert H. Humphrey formally announced his candidacy for President today with a declaration that our most urgent immediate need is to end the war in Southeast Asiaand to do it now.

title: Weekend in Country Calms Washington H. S. Tempers
description: NETCONG, N.J., Jan. 10 Bernardo Madera did not fight with Clarke Erskine here yesterday. And Jose Rod riguez did not fight with Jef frey Stein, either.

title: Advertising:
description: Now that it's been around for nine months and is billing at an annual rate of $2.5 million, Communications House and the men who founded it are ready to com municate.

title: 12 FROM U.S. GROUP PLAN VISIT TO CHINA
description: Twelve Americans associated with a citizens group on China policy will enter China on Sat urday for a monthlong visit at the invitation of the People's Institute for Foreign Relations in Peking.

title: Body Found in Queens Fire
description: The body of an unidentified man was found last night by firemen fighting a twoalarm blaze that heavily damaged a threestory frame apartment house in the Far Rockaway sec tion of Queens.

title: Advertising:
description: When asked to comment on a proposal last week by the Federal Trade Commission that broadcasters be re quired to air counterclaims to certain advertising they are running, Peter W. Allport, president of the Association of National Advertisers, said: If they wish to deprive the public of free television, they're on the right track.

title: Yonkers Teachers And School Aides Gain in Pact Talks
description: YONKERS, Tuesday, Jan. 11 Representatives of the Board of Education and the striking Yonkers Federation of Teachers reported that they had just about reached agreement on nonsalary items by late yester day afternoon and that they were ready to concentrate on salary matters.

title: ARCHER'S 66 WINS PLAYOFF ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP) George Archer shot a five underpar 66 and won by two strokes from Dave Hill and Tommy Aaron today in their 18hole playoff for the title in the Glen CampbellLos Angeles open golf tournament.

title: The Howard Hughes Puzzle
description: To anyone who remembers the argument between the Soviet Government and Life magazine over Nikita Khrushchev's alleged memoirs, there is inevitably a feel ing of dj vu about the present battle over Howard Hughes' alleged autobiography. In both cases the central figure was unreachable directly; Mr. Khrushchev because of the Kremlin's restrictions on access and Mr. Hughes because of his unusual isolation.

title: Return of the Minnesota Twins
description: It is hard to recall today that Eugene McCarthy and Hubert Humphrey were once amiable colleagues in the Senate from Minnesota. In 1960, Mr. McCarthy was one of the managers of the first Humphrey Presidential bid and four years later they were polite rivals for the job of Lyndon Johnson's running mate. They are now open antagonists in another struggle for the Presidency. Mr. McCarthy having declared on behalf of the party rebels and outsiders, Senator Humphrey yesterday came for ward as the candidate of the party's rather battered establishment.

title: BUILDERS TO TEST NEW CASTLE CODE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10A group of Westchester County builders is suing the town of New Castle to have the town's zoning ordinance declared un constitutional on the ground that it deprives them of the right of lawfully carrying on their trade by prohibiting the construction of multifamily housing.

title: Notes on People
description: Philadelphia's new mayor, Frank L. Rizzo, says that per haps the city should have our own electric chair. Noting that Pennsylvania's electric chair was dismantled last year on orders of Fred Peak er, the former Attorney Gen eral, Mr. Rizzo, a former po lice commissioner, said that maybe the state needed a lo cal option law on capital punishment.

title: Liner France on Cruise That May Include China
description: With an elegance befitting the grande dame of the ocean and an itinerary which many of her 1,150 passengers would have been hardpressed to trace on the map, the France sailed out of New York just before midnight yesterday on a 91day cruise that will take her to 27 ports around the world, pos sibly including mainland China.

title: Author Says Voice Was Not Hughes's
description: Clifford Irving, the author involved in the Howard Hughes autobiography controversy, as serted yesterday that the voice heard by newsmen in a tele phone interview last week was not that of Howard Hughes.

title: A.B.C. Will Place Privately $50Million in 7% Notes
description: American Broadcasting Com panies, Inc., has reached an agreement in principle for the private placement with a group of institutional investors of $50million aggregate amount of 20year 7 per cent subordi nated notes with 10year war rants to purchase common stock of A.B.C., it was announced yesterday.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA ANNOUNCES DEATH OF CHEN YI
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Jan. 11Chen Yi, a top Communist military commander during the Chinese civil war and later For eign Minister of China for 10 years, died of cancer in Peking last Thursday, the Peking radio announced. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Steps In After Russian Slashes Himself Here
description: A Soviet student who slashed his throat and wrists as he was being escorted to Kennedy International Airport for return to Moscow on Sunday was re ported in the custody of Soviet consular officials here yester day.

title: IND Train Derailed on Bridge Here
description: One car of a D train en route from Brooklyn to Manhat tan was derailed yesterday morning on the Manhattan Bridge. As the train crawled off the bridge toward the Grand Street station, pieces of the bridge structure and of the de railed car fell to the busy bridge roadway, forcing the po lice to close some lanes for most of the day.

title: Pakistani Patriarch Jailed
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 10 (AP)The Government or dered the jailing today of Lieut. Gen. Khan Habibullah Khan, patriarch of one of Pakistan's 22 richest families and head of Gandhara Industries. An an nouncement said he had been moved from house arrest in Peshawar to Haripu Jail under a martiallaw regulation bar ring statements against the Government.

title: MRS. LEWIS CLARK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Mrs. Anne Covington Clark, wife of Lewis Clark, a retired Foreign Service officer, died of cancer on Friday at their home in Carmel, Calif. She was 66 years old.

title: JEREMIAH F. DORNEY
description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 10 Jeremiah F. Dorney, who was chief of police here from 1933 to 1950, died Saturday after a long illness at the age of 83. He lived in Southbury.

title: George Cox Jr., Whose PTBoat Evacuated MacArthur, Is Dead
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP)George E. Cox Jr., who as a Naval Reserve ensign skippered the PTboat that car ried Gen. Douglas MacArthur from the doomed Corregidor fortress in the Philippines to the safety of Mindanao in March, 1942, died yesterday of a heart attack in a hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: 50c Lottery a SellOut, State Lifts Ticket Total
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10 (AP) Faced with an apparent sell out of the new 50cent tick ets during the first week, state lottery officials have ordered an additional one million tickets printed for sale during the second week beginning Wednesday.

title: Sports Clothes by Elke Sommer Coming East
description: There are some flippy new tennis dresses in town, bear ing names like Janet and Dinah and Ruby and Chewy. Those happen to be the real life names of some friends of the designers, who also, of course, named two of the dresses after themselves: Elke and Joianna.

title: Production of Steel Increased by 7.4% In Week to Jan. 8
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 8 totaled 2,152,000 net tons, the American iron and Steel Institute reported yester day. This was a gain of 7.4 per cent over the 2,004,000 tons produced in the previous week.

title: Kentucky Romps, 10476
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 10 (UPI)Kentucky, paced by Jim Andrews's 34 points and Tom Parker's 28, kept its Southeast ern Conference record unblem ished tonight with a 10476 rout of Mississippi State.

title: Bankers Trust Increases Profit 15.6% in Quarter
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterday a 15.6 per cent increase in fourthquarter profits before security transactions that wiped out a ninemonth decline and allowed the concern to post a gain for 1971.

title: G.M. Sets Annual Meeting
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP)Gen eral Motors announced today that it will hold its 1972 annual meeting of stockholders in De troit's Cobo Hall May 19.

title: Sato Returns to Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Premier Sato returned home to day from his meeting with President Nixon in California and asserted that the confer ence had convinced him that closer partnership between the way to peace in Asia and the world. He flew back to Tokyo in a chartered Japan Air Lines plane.

title: U.S. Rules Gold Is Exempt From PriceControl Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The Treasury Department de clared today that gold was ex empt from President Nixon's pricecontrol program. In a let ter to 1,300 dealers authorized to buy and hold gold, the agency said the Secretary of the Treasury was the only one who could regulate the price for such industrial uses as jewelry and dentistry.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ADVANCE UNIT BACK FROM CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) A 25man advance party for President Nixon's trip to Peking returned home today, and mem bers declared they had received excellent cooperation from the Chinese.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Congressmen Study E.E.C.'s Value Tax
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 10  The Nixon Administration has re vived its interest in a value added tax, Representative John W. Byrnes of Wisconsin, the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Com mittee, said today.

title: Bermuda Trackman Loses Girl, Finds Place to Run at C.W. Post
description: The story line is familiar: Boy meets girl in sunny trop ical setting, boy flips over girl, girl says let's get together sometime back at school, boy accepts challenge then loses girl to outsider.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10When the sun finally burst through the clouds to flood the practice field of the Dallas Cowboys this morning, everything was warm and pleasant except Duane Thomas. But at least the rebellious ball carrying marvel condescended to make a personal appear ance on the Super Bowl scene, and all the Cowboy rooters sighed with relief because this was a definite plus.

title: WYMAN ASSAILED IN THE ASSEMBLY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10  The State Commissioner of Social Services, George K. Wyman, already in a tenuous position in the Rockefeller administra tion, was attacked in the State Assembly today for alleged wasteful management.

title: GLAMOUR ISSUES LEAD STOCK RALLY
description: Stock prices displayed some thing of their familiar bounce yesterday, even though leading market averages finished the day with small losses. The DowJones industrial average dipped 2.41 points to 907.96 after a midsession loss of 8 points.

title: Ecuador Seizes U.S. Boat
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI)An Ecuadorian gunboat seized an American tuna fish ing vessel today, the American Tunaboat Association reported. It was the second tuna boat seized by Ecuador this year.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNCIL ACCUSES GIBSON OF DECEIT
description: NEWARK, Jan. 10A ma jority of the Newark City Coun cil members today charged that Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson was trying to build a blockby block political organization with funds from a proposed Model Cities grant.

title: Willowbrook Budget Cut Also Hurts the Parents
description: After the redhaired tod dler had gone through the crayons, gleefully demolished the paper, and then stolen a potato chip, she trudged over to the coffee table where she spotted a Plexiglas cube lined with snapshots.

title: Lindsay Due Back Tonight After Stumping in Florida
description: Mayor Lindsay will return to the city tonight after spending five days in Florida campaign ing for the Democratic Presi dential nomination.

title: G.E. Is Planning to Close Buffalo Transistor Plant
description: The General Electric Com pany continued its phasing out at the manufacture of elec tronic components with the an nouncement yesterday that it planned to close its transistor plant at Buffalo by the end of the year.

title: If you are tired of New York, you must be tired of life.
description: Ever since my arrival here about a year ago, the most difficult question for me to answer has been: Why did youhow could youleave London for New York? When I am asked this on the air I stare blankly into the micro phone and am apt to give a totally in adequate reply.

title: Ship Contract Scored as $3Million Gift
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Navy was charged by a fresh man Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee today with having presented Litton Industries, Inc., with a $3million gift by changing the delivery dates on five am phibious assault ships being built at the conglomerate's ship yard in Mississippi.

title: ExWhite House Adviser Assails Oil Import Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 A former White House adviser castigated United States oil im port restrictions today as a drain America first policy.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frank J. Nunlist, former Assistant Postmaster General, has been named chairman of the Pantasote Company, succeeding the late Charles A. Wyman. J. Keith Louden has been named chairman of the executive committee, and James H. Goss, chairman of the finance committee.

title: Market Place: Broker Views Brokers' Stocks
description: Here you are an investor, right? You've bought stocks in this group and that and, ever restless, you're looking around for something new.

title: FLIP OF COIN DECIDES N.B.A. ALLSTAR SPOT
description: Butch Beard of the Cleveland Cavaliers can thank a coin flip for his spot on the East's squad for the 22d annual National Basketball Association AllStar game on Jan. 18 in Los Angeles.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: American Motors Lays Off 1,700
description: KENOSHA, Wis., Jan. 10 (Reuters)The American Mo tors Corporation said today that it was suspending production of Hornet and Gremlin car models for one week starting today and that 1,700 workers would be temporarily laid off.

title: PAKISTANIS BOYCOTT CONFERENCE IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Jan. 10  Pakistan today boycotted the opening session of a conference that 63 African and Asian nations were scheduled to attend because a fourman delegation from the secessionist Bangladesh gov ernment proclaimed in East Pakistan was present.

title: U.S. Study Warns Cigarettes Imperil Nonsmokers, Too
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The hazards of cigarette smok ing may fall on the smoker and the nonsmoker alike, although by no means in equal amounts, according to a Government re port made public today.

title: BERNARD J. LEDDY, JUDGE IN VERMONT
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 10 Judge Bernard J. Leddy of the Federal District of Vermont died yesterday of a heart at tack at his home. His age was 61.

title: 4 IN BATON ROUGE ARE SLAIN IN CLASH
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 10 Two white deputy sheriffs and two young blacks were shot and killed and 31 persons were injured today in a wild exchange of gunfire that erupt ed when the police moved to clear a city street of an im promptu black militant rally.

title: PROXMIRE CRITICIZES FEDERAL SUBSIDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Sen ator William Proxmire, releas ing a Joint Economic Commit tee study indicating that Fed eral subsidies cost the nation at least $63billion in fiscal year 1970, asserted today that the subsidy system seems to be out of control.

title: Soviet Releases Photo of Its First Atomic Reactor
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10The So viet Union has released what is believed to be the first photo graphs of the longsecret atomic pile that sustained the Rus sians' first chain reaction at the dawn of the nuclear era.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS STOCK CONVICTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Supreme Court let stand today lowercourt opinions that investment  company officials who profit from private, inside deals in securities handled by their concerns are punishable under a previously untested 30yearold law.

title: RESTRICTED STOCK UNDER NEW RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission, after four years of study and controversy, put into effect today a new Rule 144, changing the standards and procedures under which restricted stock may be sold.

title: 2 CHINESE TEAMS TO TOUR CANADA
description: The Globe and Mail, Toronto

title: Gift House for Chief Justice Snagged in Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 It has been two years since G. Howland Chase, a retired Washington lawyer, set out to give the Federal Govern ment his $340,000 mansion, plus $500,000 to maintain it, as an official residence for the Chief Justice of the United States.

title: R.P.I. Six Routs Princeton As Donahoe Stars, 60
description: TROY, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP) Rensselaer Polytech's harddriv ing hockey team shut out Princeton, 60, tonight, with John Donahoe scoring one goal and adding two assists to lead the Engineers.

title: SHEIK NIB HOME; 500,000 GIVE HIM ROUSING WELCOME
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 10 Sheik Mujibur Rahman re ceived a tumultuous, trium phant welcome today from a crowd of half a million Ben galis as he returned to his native land for the first time since he was arrested nine months ago by the Pakistani authorities.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Retail Meeting Warned on Consumer
description: Merchants convening here from all parts of the country were told yesterday that their business this year was in for some difficult times, not so much from any questionable sales potential but from an aroused, disillusioned and highly pragmatic consumer.

title: New Freshman Rule Expected To Aid New York College Fives
description: The return of disillusioned players from outoftown col leges, fewer scholarships and more selective recruiting with less reliance on players from the junior colleges. Those were the consequences of the new freshman rule predicted by metropolitan basketball coaches yesterday at the weekly writers' luncheon.

title: Agents Seize More Heroin In Miami Apartment Raid
description: MIAMI, Jan. 10 (AP)Fed eral agents who seized a record $47million worth of heroin last week raided an apartment here tonight and found $25million worth of heroin hidden under a bed.

title: Japan's Envoy Warns U.S. Of Risks in Trip to Peking
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Japanese Ambassador to the United States, Nobuhiko Ushiba, warned today that President Nixon's trip to China next month might be the beginning of a process of unraveling our mutual security in the Far East.

title: Empty Tanker Splits and Sinks at Port Jefferson Dock
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Jan, 10A 34,000ton oil tanker split in half and sank as she was pulling away from the dock at Port Jefferson harbor this morning.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NAGS HEAD, N. C. Crouching in a duck blind be side me before dawn, our guide, Jimmy Curling, whispered ur gently, Take him! He's a gad wall.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: Now that the 33game win ning streak has ended for the Los Angeles Lakers, perhaps their situation can be put back into perspective.

title: Chairman Is Elected by Cities Service
description: The Cities Service Company announced yesterday that Rob ert V. Sellers had been elected chairman and chief executive officer.

title: New Retreat Expected
description: VIENTIANE, Jan. 10 (UPI) Government military sources said tonight that Laotian Gov ernment troops were preparing to abandon Ban Nhik, a key Government position 18 miles east of Pakse, the main com mercial town in southern Laos.

title: An Art Form As American As Apple Pie
description: Early last month, Rhea Goodman took stock of the quiltfilled rooms in her New York apartment and her Southampton house.

title: Strike by British Coal Miners Is Forcing Closing of Schools
description: LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) Britain's coal strike forced the closing of 17 English schools today and threatened to shut down scores more in Wales.

title: PENTAGON REPORTS AMMUNITION THEFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 10 (AP) The Pentagon says that 40 incidents involving thefts of arms, ammunition and explo sives occurred in a fivemonth span during shipments through the states last year.

title: CLAYTON HOLLINGER, HELD U.S. POST HERE
description: Clayton D. Hollinger, a law yer who retired last year as a United States Commissioner for the Southern District of New York, presiding at arraign ments and setting bail in Federal cases, died Sunday at his home, 4915 Broadway. He was 66 years old.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices of CocoaBean Futures Rise
description: Buying  based on higher cocoabean grindings in the fourth quarter of 1971brought prices of cocoabean futures up by the trading limit of 1 cent a pound on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday.

title: 7 C.B.S. Men at Seminar
description: Seven top executives of the Columbia Broadcasting System's News Division will attend the second news media meeting of the Columbia Journalism Alum ni tomorrow night at 7:30 at the Lincoln Center Library of the Performing Arts, 111 Am sterdam Avenue. The executives are Richard Salant, Bill Leonard, Gordon Manning, Sanford Soco low, Burton Benjamin, Ed Joyce and Lou Adler.

title: PRISON BILLS FILL HOPPER IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10With more than 85 bills dealing with prisoners' rights, parole, sen tencing and prison facilities in the hopper, the Legislature met today and adjourned within a hour.

title: Wilkins Says Muskie Is Probably Right In Stand Against a Black Running Mate
description: Roy Wilkins, executive di rector of the National Associa tion for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that Senator Edmund S. Muskie was probably right in his as sessment that the nation's voters would not support a na tional ticket with a black nomi nee for Vice President on it.

title: South Dakota Hopefuls Rushing Into the Race for Mundt's Seat
description: PIERRE, S. D., Jan. 10 (AP) For more than two years, Sen ator Karl E. Mundt has been ab sent from the Senate, the vic tim of a stroke that has left the South Dakota Republican virtually helpless.

title: City Police Dispute the F.B.I. Over Breaking of Pierre Case
description: Federal authorities yesterday claimed credit for breaking the Pierre Hotel robbery case and took legal action against one of the suspects.

title: Handwriting and Language Are Called Keys to Authenticating Hughes Book
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 Life magazine and the McGraw Hill Book Company are relying on two areas of proof regard ing the authenticity of the con troversial book about Howard R. Hughes, information from a variety of sources showed to day.

title: CAHILL INDICATES HE WILL SUPPORT STATE INCOME TAX
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10In a clear signal that he is ready to fight for a state income tax this year, Gov. William T. Cahill will ask the Legislature tomor row to approve a reshaping of what he described as New Jersey's unfair and outmoded tax system, which relies on local property levies.

title: Ward Randol, ExHead of Center For Exploration Here, Dies at 75
description: Ward Randol, special proj ects officer and former execu tive director of the World Cen ter for Exploration and the Ex plorers Club, died Saturday of a heart attack in White Plains Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Exiles in Canada Wary of Amnesty Bill
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10Ameri cans who fled here to avoid service in Vietnam, already un certain because of the diffi culty of finding jobs, have a new quandary: whether to re turn home if Congress approved an amnesty. And the proposal itself appears to be making jobs harder to find.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: 32 in State Tennis Field
description: Entries close next Monday for the New York State men's in door tennis championship at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy. Harry Hopman, tour nament chairman, said yester day the draw would be limited to 32.

title: Black Mayor in Carolina to Run for Congress
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 10 Howard Lee, first black may or of a major North Carolina community, hopes to become the first black Congressman from the old Confederacy since George H. White of North Caro lina in 1901.

title: Army Seeking to Reform System of Service Clubs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The Army announced today a move to reform the manage ment of its worldwide service club and open mess system in which, a Senate investigation committee has charged, cor ruption, criminality and moral compromise have flourished.

title: TEENAGER SOUGHT IN WALL ST. THEFT
description: A youth described as being about 16 years old snatched a manila envelope containing $4,308,000 worth of securities from a Wall Street bank mes senger in the crowded financial district yesterday morning and made a getaway in a waiting car.

title: I'd Be Happy to See Mr. Nixon
description: PEKINGIn prerevolutionary China there was a white colonnaded building in Peking that served as the French Embassy. Now, in early winter, it stands in leafbare spacious grounds, a quieter place than before, the work ing headquarters of Cambodia's Prince Sihanouk, whose Royal Government of National Union operates with one foot in the Chinese capital and the other in the intensively bombed areas of northeast Cambodia.

title: Navy Releases First Pictures of a Solar Flare From Sun's Far Side
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Navy scientists released to day the first pictures ever taken of a solar flare that spouted from the side of the sun facing away from the earth.

title: Dr. W. E. Boutelle, 63, Head Of a Jersey Guidance Clinic
description: PITTSTOWN, N. J., Jan. 10 Dr. William E. Boutelle, director of the Somerset County Guid ance Clinic and a past president of the New Jersey Neuropsychi atric Association, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home here. He was 63 years old.

title: Fire on Elizabeth To Be Investigated Amid Arson Hints
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 10 (UPI) Hong Kong authorities and insurance company investi gators announced today that they would begin an investi gation into the cause of the fire that destroyed the liner Queen Elizabeth in Hong Kong Harbor this weekend.

title: Mrs. Louis Moore, 79, Dead; Led Birth Control League
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 10 Mrs. Allison Pierce Moore, for mer president of the Florence Crittenton League and chair man 36 years ago of the Ameri can Birth Control League, and wife of Louis deB. Moore, re tired president of Tiffany & Co., died yesterday at their home on Sandy Hill Road. She was 79 years old.

title: NIAGARA DEFEATS L.I.U. FIVE, 7670
description: Niagara's basketball team withstood a Long Island Uni versity rally to gain a 7670 victory last night, its 11th straight, on the loser's court in Brooklyn. The Purple Eagles are unbeaten since their opening game.

title: Drug Conferences Set
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 10 William Cahn, president of the National District Attorneys As sociation and District Attorney of Nassau Couny, announced today that the association would sponsor its fourth National In stiute on Narcotics and Dan gerous Drugs. The conferences are scheduled for San Fran cisco, Feb. 1317, and for Chi cago April 1620.

title: POLICY ON REFUGEES SCORED BY KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that thousands of Cuban refugees had been set adrift on welfare by being hastily resettled out of Miami.

title: Firms Accused of Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The United States Steel Cor poration and the North Star Coal Company were charged today with violating the 1899 Refuse Act by spilling pollu tants into major waterways near Pittsburgh, Attorney Gen eral John N. Mitchell an nounced.

title: EARLY BIRD SERIES OFF TO FAST START
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 10 The 6yearold Canny Choice gave notice that he is the one to beat for top laurels in the Early Bird series at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: U.S.Japan: Summit or Nadir?
description: The five summit conferences just held with the United States' most important partners abroad, culminating in talks with Japan's leaders, have provided a partial anti dote to the goitalone policies that have poisoned the country's alliances since July. But the limited results of the NixonSato meeting in San Clemente suggest that, in Japan's case, the malaise stirred by last year's Nixon shocks will not be quickly dissipated. A major, continu ing effort will be needed just to prevent further deteriora tion in America's most vital Pacific relationship.

title: PARAGUAY SETS BAIL IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 10 (UPI)A judge ordered bail set at $330,000 today for Au guste Joseph Ricord, accused of heading a vast international narcotics empire. It was be lieved the highest bond ever set in this country's history.

title: 9 Democrats Now Listed In Pennsylvania Primary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Seven Democratic Presidential candidates served notice today that they intend to enter Penn sylvania's April 25 primary by filing notices of intent with the Secretary of the Common wealth in Harrisburg.

title: Mrs. Sun Yatsen Hails Plans for Nixon's Trip
description: PEKING, Jan. 10 (Reuters) Mrs. Sun Yatsen, widow of the founder of modern China and Deputy Chairman of the People's Republic said in an article published today that President Nixon's plan to visit China had aroused ex citement throughout the world.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS SCHOOLS MERGED IN RICHMOND AREA
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 10The public schools of the city of Richmond and those of two suburban counties were told by a Federal judge here today that they would be ordered to merge into one metropolitan unit before next September to end an increasing pattern of unequal and segregated edu cation.

title: Israeli Court Gives Custody Of Child to Jersey Mother
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Acknowledging the unique circumstances of the case and a mother's love for her child, the Israeli Supreme Court has granted a New Jersey woman custody of her 3yearold son and permitted her to fly him to the United States.

title: Protecting Stanford's Freedom
description: The recommendation by a sevenman faculty advisory board at Stanford University that a tenured professor be dismissed for repeatedly inciting students to the use of illegal coercion and violence is a matter of utmost gravity for the nation's academic community. If the Board of Trustees follows suit, this would be the first such step by a major university in the context of recent campus unrest.

title: Pride and Confidence Lift Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 10The Milwaukee Bucks, the defend ing champions of the National Basketball Association, a proud and talented group of athletes, felt keen pleasure yesterday when they topped the Los An geles Lakers, 120104, here and ended the Lakers' astounding 33game winning streak.

title: TRUCKER CHARGED WITH TAX FRAUD
description: A trucking corporation exec utive was accused yesterday of criminal conspiracy to defraud the Government of substantial income taxes by creating a phantom payroll that listed seven men as salaried employes.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: About Pro Hockey
description: In the wake of Jean Ra telle's 5point performance Sunday night that earned him the National Hockey League's midseason scoring title, many questions arose yesterday regarding the role of the official scorer.

title: Fire in London Hilton
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 11 (Reuters)Some 20 guests at London's plush Hilton Hotel overlooking Hyde Park were evacuated early today when fire broke out in a suite on the 22d floor. The guests, many of them wearing night clothes, huddled in the hotel entrance hall and groundfloor public rooms as firemen wearing breathing apparatus brought the blaze under control.

title: Newsmen's Notes and Film Are Returned by Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 10The Pakistani Government today returned news film and documents seized last March 27 from foreign correspond ents after they were expelled from East Pakistan.

title: Cowboy Guard Keeps File on Foes
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 10  The Dallas Cowboys, who rep resent one half of the Super Bowl's confrontation on Sun day, arrived here last night and today they renewed their prep arations to play the Miami Dol phins.

title: Russel of France Breaks Leg After Cup Slalom Run
description: BERCHTESGADEN, West Ger many, Jan. 10Roger Rossat Mignod, who gained a place on the French Olympic skiing team after Patrick Russel broke a leg crashing beyond the finish line, showed he deserved his ticket to Sapporo, Japan, by capturing a World Cup giant slalom to clay.

title: A Vietcong Attack 6 Miles From Saigon Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10 (Reuters)A Vietcong attack within six miles of downtown Saigon was reported today by the South Vietnamese command.

title: Bill Rates Drop Sharply; Reserve in Market Again
description: Interest rates, appearing to be almost freefalling, dropped dramatically yesterday, and the rate on threemonth Treasury bills fell below 3 per cent for the first time in eight and a half years.

title: AKSEL LARSEN DEAD; DANISH COMMUNIST
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 11 (AP)Aksel Larsen, long time leader of the Danish Com munist party until his expul sion as a revisionist in 1953, died in Copenhagen hospital to day. He was 74 years old.

title: 3 Held in Tijuana Drug Raid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reu ters)Three Mexicans are un der arrest in Tijuana, Mexico, following a MexicanAmerican investigation and raid that un covered six tons of marijuana worth $2.5million at street prices, Attorney General John Mitchell announced today.

title: RETAIL SALES UP FROM A YEAR AGO
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Re tail sales in December were up from the yearearlier level but down compared with Novem ber sales, after allowance for normal seasonal trends.

title: After Two Decades of War, Laotians Can See No End
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 10 The strains of a war that has gone on intermittently for more than 20 years are every where evident in the Laotian capital.

title: Bank Aide Killed in Holdup
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 10 (AP)A gunman killed the manager of a suburban bank in a holdup this afternoon, and escaped with $18,000 to $20, 000. A bank official said that the slain man was Stanley T. Irish, 62 years old, of Webber villa. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said that he had been shot twice in the back.

title: Alioto Backs Humphrey
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (AP)Mayor Joseph L. Alioto, who nominated Mr. Humphrey for President in 1968, endorsed the Minnesota Senator's candi dacy for the Democratic Presi dential nomination today.

title: Rockingham Park Forced To Stop Sunday Racing
description: SALEM, N. H., Jan. 10 (AP) Rockingham Park officials have announced there would be no Sunday racing during the next winterspring meeting.

title: City Presents Air Quality Plan; Differs From State's Proposals
description: New York City presented its own plan yesterday for meeting Federal air quality standards for motor vehicle emissions. It differed sharply from proposals put forward last week by the state.

title: Auburn Downs Georgia
description: AUBURN, Ala., Jan. 10 (AP) Auburn, behind the scoring of Jim Retseck and the re bounding of 7foot Ernie Magri, trimmed the Georgia Bulldogs 9993 tonight in a Southeastern Conference battle.

title: Tass Is Raised to Ministry
description: MOSCOW Jan. 10 (AP)  The Soviet Union's official press agency, Tass, has been raised in the bureaucratic structure to a state committee and its director, Leonid M. Za myatin, given ministerial rank. In the Soviet bureaucracy ministries and state commit tees have roughly equal rank.

title: HUGH W. ROBERTSON, WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP)  Hugh W. Robertson, former editor and vice presi dent of Westchester County Publishers, predecessor of WestchesterRockland News papers, died yesterday in Mor ton Plant Hosypital. He was 83 years old.

title: Foreign Policy Report Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) The White House said today that President Nixon plans to deliver a major foreign policy report to Congress in early February before he departs on his journey to China.

title: TV Violence Held  Unharmful to Youth
description: The office of the United States Surgeon General has found that violence in tele vision programing does not have an adverse effect on the majority of the nation's youth but may influence small groups of youngsters predisposed by many factors to aggressive be havior.

title: Screen: Mizoguchi's 'Utamaro' of 1946:Late Director's Work Opens at New Yorker Artist Is Portrayed by Minnosuke Bando
description: If you want to know how we really treat what people like to call "the art form of our times," you may consider the case of one of that art form's very greatest practitioners, the late Kenji Mizoguchi, who made more than 40 movies after the advent of sound (his career in silents began in 1923), only seven of which have had theatrical release in New York City. Since these seven, beginning with the magnificent "Life of O'Haru," all date from the few years before Mizoguchi's death in 1956, I suppose a significant step backward has been taken with the premiere of "Utamaro and His Five Women," which was made in 1946 and which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater.The year 1946 is important because postwar difficulties explain some minor flaws in the film's technical quality, and because the story created major difficulties with the American occupation authorities, who were not happy at seeing any Japanese historical subject matter. However, Mizoguchi's theme is profoundly egalitarian, and his story from the life of Kitagawa Utamaro (1753-1806), an artist famous for his life-like depictions of beautiful women, is in one sense a celebration of human freedom that goes beyond even the freedom of a popular art.In general, the film moves from constraint to freedom, from the painfully gorgeous procession of court ladies against a background of blossoming cherry trees with which it opens ("Like a Harunobu painting!" exclaims a passer-by, thus identifying the style that Utamaro helped suppiant) to the veritable cascade of prints inspired by a single tragic passion with which it ends.But this movement is by no means simple. For the freedom of Utamaro the artist (Minnosuke Bando) is paralleled and in a sense surpassed by the greater freedom of his favorite model; the courtesan Okita (Kinuyo Tanaka), whose disordered lifeshe ultimately kills an unfaithful loverhas its own pathetic and wasteful grandeur.Yet Okita is wrong when she hopes to possess her lover rather than to rest content with some moments of his love. And Utamaro is right because he loves no one woman, nor all women, nor even the refinement of his art, but rather the vitality of the image that is always in movement, always passing out of view. Once he tries to create a real flesh-and-blood painting, a cartoon to be tattooed on the back of a beautiful courtesan. But the girl runs away, a love flight, taking her tattoo with herthe flesh-and-blood painting wholly subservient to the demands of actual flesh and blood.One could schematize "Utamaro and His Five Women" on a scale of relative freedom of will and desire. Such a scheme would be complex (there are five representative women, and several more men) and useful, for the film is, among other things, the exercise of an exceptionally active and intricate intelligence.But the beauty of Mizoguchi's filmmaking is even more strikingand not, of course, separable from the beauty of his conception. His subdued performances, his eye-level camera (in contrast with the straining for unusual perspective typical of so much Japanese moviemaking) photographing into a depth of field that is virtually a test of vision for the audienceeverything contributes to a reasonable balance that evokes a rich classicism. It is a classicism of open awareness, and it values every romantic impulse that it chooses not to follow, preferring instead to sttay with what it understands to be the sustaining rhythms of the world.

title: NASA Outlines Plans on Space Shuttle; Commercial Gains and Sorties Foreseen
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 10 De velopment of the reusable space shuttle should usher in an era of more extensive commercial exploitation of space and in an era of more extensive com mercial exploitation of space and in which scientists could accompany their own experi ments into orbit in a module called a sortie can.

title: Some Meat Prices Here Rose During 90Day Freeze Period
description: The Federal Government's price reports for 73 retail food items sold in stores here in November showed that the prices of 27 of them were in creased during the recent 90 day price freeze.

title: Transit: Are the Tracks Clear?
description: To the Editor:

title: First Loss for W. Virginia
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (AP) Pitt knocked West Virginia from the ranks of the unbeaten tonight, downing the Moun taineers, 9176.

title: Common Cause to Test The Convention System
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Common Cause assert ed today that the process by which national parties pick Presidential candidates was controlled by the boys in the back room, and announced a program to challenge the system.

title: COPPERWELD GETS REGAL TUBE UNIT
description: The Copperweld Steel Com pany announced yesterday it had acquired the Regal tube division of the LearSiegler Company for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: FRAN extra money as tax preparer. See Page 29. FIC Tax??

title: BedfordStuyvesant Bank Robbed of $10,000 by 3 Men
description: Three masked bandits forced 25 persons to lie on the floor of the Bankers Trust Company branch in the BedfordStuy vesant section of Brooklyn yes terday morning while they rifled five cash drawers of more than $10,000, stole $1,255 from a woman customer and dis armed the uniformed guard.

title: OIL CONCERNS OFFER A RISE IN PAYMENTS
description: GENEVA, Jan. 10The major Western oil companies offered today to reimburse the oilpro ducing countries for the higher prices they are having to pay for imported goods as a result of the devaluation of the United States dollar.

title: L.B.J. Exhorts Cowboys, But Has No Play for Them
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10  Despite his loyalty to the Dallas Cowboys in the Super Bowl game, Lyndon B. Johnson will refrain from suggesting any plays to their coach, Tom Lan dry, for use Sunday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: JUSTICES TO WEIGH BAN ON MARXISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of the section of the McCarran Walter Act of 1952 that per mits the Government to bar foreign Marxists from visiting the United States.

title: 7th Fleet Task Force Ends Patrol in the Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The United States Navy task force led by the nuclearpow ered carrier Enterprise sailed out of the Indian Ocean today after a month of patrol duty begun during the IndianPakis tani war, the Defense Depart ment announced.

title: Visit to Vietnam: II
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.When I went to Saigon with an American student delegation, one of the things most on my mind was to connect with Catholic opinion there. There are about forty million Catholics in the United States, many of whom think that a main object of the war in Vietnam is to protect Catholics from Communists. My first intimation that this may not be the whole story was a statement issued Oct. 15, 1969, signed by 93 Catholic Vietnamese living in Europe and a great number of Catholics in Vietnam whose names cannot be opportunely published.

title: Woolworth Sales Rose In December and All 1971
description: The F. W. Woolworth Com pany reported yesterday a 10.9 per cent increase in sales vol ume for 1971, to a record $2, 802,401,905. Woolworth said the year was capped by a 13.6 per cent rise in December sales, to $461,496,790 from $406,094,835 in December 1970.

title: Local School Board 10 in Bronx Warns of Loss of More Whites
description: A community school board in the Bronx asserted yesterday that the proposed studentat tendance zone for the new John F. Kennedy High School would lead to a further ero sion of the white population of the city.

title: Rise Set for Nylon And Carpet Prices
description: Price increases were an nounced yesterday in some grades of nylon, woven and tufted carpets and plumbing and heating products.

title: Odyssey House Director Favors Compulsory Curing of Addicts
description: Firmly grasping two opposing horns of one of the many philo sophical dilemmas surrounding drugs and addiction, Dr. Judi anne DensenGerber said yes terday that she personally be lieved marijuana should be le galized to preserve respect for the law and that heroin addicts should be committed by the state for three to five years of compulsory rehabilitation.

title: D. L. MERRITT, WROTE LIMERICK ON PELICAN
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 10 (AP) Dixon Lanier Merritt, editor, historian and poet who was known as the dean of Tennes see newspapermen, died yes terday after a long Illness. He was 92 years old.

title: City Museum Gets Birthday Presents
description: The Museum of the City of New York gave itself a 40th anniversary party yesterday, complete with wine punch, tea and a lively threeman combo belting out soft rock. The guests, greeted by the museum's director, Joseph V. Noble, were members and their friends, and some of them came bearing gifts.

title: Wounded Being Exchanged By Indians and Pakistanis
description: GENEVA, Jan. 10 (UPI)The International Red Cross said to day that India and Pakistan would complete an exchange of wounded prisoners within 10 days.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Fell at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Gov ernment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities.

title: Bernstein's Mass to Play at Met For 4 Weeks Starting June 26
description: Leonard Bernstein's Mass, the controversial work that opened the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Wash ington last September, will play the Metropolitan Opera House for four weeks starting June 26, it was learned yesterday.

title: 1,160,000 Whites Left the City And Tristate Region in 1960's
description: The 31county, tristate met ropolitan region centered on New York City had a net out ward migration of 160,000 to 205,000 whites during the nine teen sixties, according to a new analysis of 1970 figures.

title: Dance: The Subtle Poetry of Othello
description: Jos Limn's The Moor's Pavane is one of the very few entirely successful reali zations of Shakespeare in dance terms. It tells the story of Othello, almost vestigially, expressing it within the confines of a for mal dance. More significant ly, it tells the poetry of Othello.

title: TV: American Conservatives Confront 1972
description: If nothing else, the televi sion interviewdiscussion for mat can be flexible. Last week Channel 13's A Mur row Retrospective provided a few glimpses of some early techniques, including the on screen communication via telephone. Murrow was seen picking up a telephone in the TV studio and then, on a monitor, President Eisen hower was seen picking up his end of the line on some golf course.

title: Al Goodman, Orchestra Leader At Stage and Radio Shows, Dies
description: Al Goodman, who waved his baton for many stars of the stage and radio in the 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday morning in Mount Sinai hospi tal after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: G.M. to Add 3,900 Workers
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10  The General Motors Corporation said today it would add 3,900 to its work force in the first quarter to add 15,500 cars to its monthly production. This would be a 3 per cent to 4 per cent increase in output.

title: President Plans to Limit ClearCutting in National Forests; Timber Men Are Disturbed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The White House is planning to is sue an Executive order limiting clearcutting  the wholesale cutting of treesin the national forests.

title: 2,000 Schoolchildren Here Memorialize Dr. King
description: I remember him well, said 14yearold DeOtis Williams. If Dr. King would have stayed, there wouldn't have been that much crime and ad dicts. He would have been our leader and brought all the black people together.

title: Providence Tops Villanova
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 10 (UPI)Marvin Barnes and Lar ry Ketvirtis scored 22 points each in leading Providence to a 7669 triumph over Villanova tonight.

title: Jersey Bus Line is Sold
description: NEWARK, Jan, 10 (UPI) The InterCity Bus Company, the state's second largest bus service, was sold today for $3.8 million after being held in trust for more than four years, fol lowing a bankruptcy suit filed Aug. 1, 1967. United States Dis trict Court Judge Lawrence A. Whipple approved the sale. The company was bought jointly by the State and Transport of New Jersey

title: Mujib, Stopping in New Delhi, Vows Eternal Amity With India
description: NEW DELHI Jan. 10  Sheik Mujibur Rahman told cheering Indian throngs today that his country and theirs would be bound in eternal friendship as brothers.

title: PROFIT DETAILS LISTED BY SWIFT
description: Swift & Co. has listed for the first time in its annual report a breakdown of profits derived from its major busi ness activties in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30.

title: CHARLES ANGULO, 81; LAWYER SINCE 1914
description: Charles Angulo, a retired lawyer who specialized in handling the legal problems of foreign individuals and corpora tions in the United States, died yesterday in Martha Jefferson Hospital, Charlottesville, Va. He was 81 years old.

title: Magazine on Poet's Craft Carves a Niche
description: The New York Quarterly, a magazine devoted entirely to the publishing of contempo rary poetry and the problems of the poet, has just finished its second year (a total of eight issues) and is well launched on its third. To any number of people, this may not seem like a cosmic event. Nevertheless, at a time when several respectable literary magazines have gone under and others are in the process of doing so, the continuance of The New York Quarterly is worth notice.

title: A PRISON INQUIRY OPENS IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Jan. 10An inves tigation into reports of prison brutality in eastern France opened here today in what ad vocates of reform hope will be the first step toward a ma jor overhaul of the French pen itentiary system.

title: Israeli Troops Attack 2 Camps in Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Tuesday, Jan. 11 (UPI)Israel said today that her troops raided two Arab guerrilla camps inside Lebanon during the night, blowing up four buildings and killing an unknown number of guerrillas.

title: IN THE NATION
description: In Rome, city officials have just completed an experiment during which, for nine days, fares were eliminated on the Eternal City's buses. Nearer home, in Atlanta, the bus fare is being reduced from forty to fifteen cents, with an accompanying increase in the city sales tax.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2Cent Sales Tax Urged For New Rochelle

title: SOUTH AFRICA PLANS TO END LABOR BONDS
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 10 (ReutersSouth Africa announced today that she would abolish the contract la bor system in SouthWest Africa, after a month of crip pling strikes by some 13,000 laborers of the Ovambo tribe.

title: PARUN BEATS FAULK IN AUCKLAND FINAL
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 10 (AP)Onny Parun, the New Zealand Davis Cup player, won the final of the Auckland tennis championship today by overcoming Steve Faulk of New Orleans, 26, 67, 75, 64, 64. The match lasted 2 hours 50 minutes.

title: GUSSIE KLEIMAN, 47; HARLEM SIX LAWYER
description: Gussie Kleiman, a lawyer who was involved in the de fense of some of the Harlem Six, died Saturday night in the New York Infirmary after a short illness. Miss Kleiman, who had been married to and di vorced from Dr. Sidney H. Joffe, was 47 years old and lived at 44 East 67th Street.

title: 3 Struck Base, Thais Say
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10 (AP)  The Thai Government announced today that at least three guerrillas were involved in this morning's attack on the B52 base at Utapao, 90 miles south of here, in which two of the planes were damaged.

title: Israeli Rightist, in Britain, Is Critical on Cancellation
description: LONDON, Jan. 10Menahem Begin, leader of Israel's right wing Herut party and the Oppo sition Gahal bloc in the Knesset, today blamed British fascists and Arab groups for protests and threats that led the Royal Garden Hotel to cancel a ban quet and rally planned for him.

title: New Lord & Taylor Team Plans Expansion
description: New major stores in Dallas and Houston in 1974 and 1975 are on the drawing boards at Lord & Taylor, rep resenting the furthest thrust in a new expansion plan by the New Yorkbased retailer. The plan calls for seven new stores in the next four years.

title: Everett Ruskay Dies at 54; A Long Island Civic Leader
description: WOODMERE, L.I., Jan. 10 Everett S. Ruskay, president of Don Juan Sportswear, Inc., in New York City, died today of cancer at his home, 170 Lefferts Road. His age was 54.

title: Andre Clavier Is Dead at 77; A Pioneer in Microwave Radio
description: Andr G. Clavier, a pioneer in microwave radio communi cation, who directed the world's first successful demonstration of microwave radio transmis sion across the English Chan nel in 1931, died Sunday in Hollywood, Fla., where he spent the winter. He was 77 years old and lived in Ventnor City, N. J.

title: N.Y.R.A. President Calls OTB Killer In Canada Speech
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Jan. 10 (AP)The New York City Offtrack Betting Cor poration could kill racing in New York State and result in sharply reduced state tax rev enues, the president of the New York Racing Association said here today.

title: HERBERT BUETOW, MANUFACTURER, 73
description: ST. PAUL, Jan, 10 (AP) Herbert P. Buetow, former president and a director of Minnesota Mining and Manu facturing Company, died Satur day night of a heart attack. His age was 73.

title: Pennsylvania Asks F.C.C. To Reconsider on A.T. & T.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The State of Pennsylvania peti tioned the Federal Communica tions Commission today to re consider the decision last month in which it abandoned an investigation of the Amer ican Telephone and Telegraph Company's interstate rates on the ground that the F.C.C. lacked an adequate staff for the job.

title: College Plan For Queens Is Rejected
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10Citing the state fiscal crisis, Gov ernor Rockefeller has disap proved plans for a $62.5 million campus for York College, the youngest of the City University's nine senior colleges. The campus was to have been built in a rundown area of Jamaica, Queens, by 1975.

title: A dvertising:
description: Since November Barry Gray, the radio personality, has been selling municipal bonds for Paragon Securities on Channels 2 and 4.

title: Proxmire Says U.S. Favors Big Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today the Treasury Department is discriminating in favor of the nation's largest banks in mak ing interestfree deposits of Government funds.

title: Royals' Drought Ends
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 11 (UPI)  Sam Lacey sank a jump shot from the key with seven sec onds left in an abbreviated overtime period tonight as the Cincinnati Royals ended a 14 game losing streak with a 109 107 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: Art Songs, 4 Big Fans And More
description: It was one of those ear nestly ecumenical concerts where the Blue and the Gray meet for a picnic on the battlefield, where the classi cal lamb lies down with the popculture lionwhere, to be more precise, Mozart and Beethoven embrace John Lennon and Yoko Ono. At one moment, a soprano was singing art songs; a moment later, Mr. Lennon was zap ping the audience with a flashlight. A chamber or chestra, young but topnotch and dressed in colorful everyday motley, played a snippet of Handel, Mozart's Linz Symphony and a Mo zart horn concerto; Joseph Eger, the conductor and horn soloist, wore white tie and tails.

title: Recognition by Bulgaria
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)Bul garia has recognized Bangla desh as an independent sov ereign state, President Todor Zhivkov announced today.

title: Yepremian and Clark Back on Beam
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 As a rookie five seasons ago, Garo Yepremian slapped his cheek to stop it from twitch ing. In his ninth season two months ago, Mike Clark let the pressure defeat me in a duel for his job.

title: TATE'S LONG JUMP PACES A.A.U. MEET
description: Competing for the first time in the current indoor season, Norm Tate and Bob Beamon finished first and third, respec tively, in the long jump, while Mike McDermott scored his third double of the year in the 16pound shotput and 35pound weight throw and Bud William son set a meet record in the pole vault.

title: Notes on People
description: In the 22 years he has been general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Sir Rud olf Bing has savored his rep utation as an acidtongued, sometimes terribletempered martinet.

title: PROFIT IS FORECAST FOR AIRLINES IN 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The Air Transport Associa tion said today the scheduled airline industry started a re versal last year from heavy losses sustained in 1970 and should earn a profit this year.

title: U.S. Loan to Assist a Private Dominican Resort
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The Agency for International Development is lending $126, 422 to provide a swimming pool filter system, a diving board, underwater lights and restaurant and bar equipment for a privately owned hotel in the Dominican Republic.

title: Head of Teamsters Rules Out Affiliation With A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: The president of the Inter national Brotherhood of Team sters said yesterday that his union had no intention of re affiliating with the A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISA few years ago Maurice Couve de Murville, an eminent French statesman who has served his country both as Foreign Minister and Premier, complained to me that it was im possible to talk confidentially with American leaders. The reason, he said, was that they immediately made mem oranda of such conversations and dis tributed them in Washington and al lied capitals. Often these subsequent ly leaked to the press.

title: LEGISLATORS FIRM ON PAROCHIAL AID
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  The Leg islature and Governor Rockefel ler are expected to try to find another way to provide the $33million in state funds that would have gone to parochial schools this year under a 1971 law declared unconstitutional today by a threejudge Federal Court.

title: New 50c Lottery Is Catching On
description: The lunchhour crowds of brokers, secretaries, lawyers and insurance executives thronged around Louie De Santis newsstand at a cramped corner of Fulton and William Streets at noon yes terday.

title: Freeing of Galley Urged
description: MACON, Ga., Jan. 11 (UPI)  Mayor Ronnie Thompson, noting the recent release of James R. Hoffa, former head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, sent President Nixon a telegram today asking that First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr. be freed. The lieutenant was convicted of murder in con nection with the killings of South Vietnamese civilians at the hamlet of Mylai in 1968.

title: Books of The Times
description: NORTH. By LouisFerdinand Cline. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 454 pages. A Seymour Lawrence book: Delacorte. $10.

title: Chicago Exchange Elects
description: Michael Weinberg Jr. has been elected to a oneyear term as chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, it was an nounced yesterday. Mr. Wein berg succeeds Leo Melamed, who had been chairman for the past three years and will continue as a member of the board. Mr. Weinberg, 46 years old, is treasurer of Weinberg Bros. & Co., commodity brokers, and operators of coldstorage warehouses in Chicago.
