description: In view of the fact that skiing originally depended on nature's generosity in produc ing white flakes, the snow running sport keeps drifting closer and closer to our ma chine age.

title: City Police Changing Enforcement in Gambling and Narcotics, With Purpose of Focusing on Major Dealers
description: The Police Department is rack ically shifting its enforcement in two key crime areasgam bling and smalltime narcotics pushersand placing its great est emphasis on major narcotics dealers.

title: Fred H. Weaver Dead at 56; Served U. of North Carolina
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 12 Fred H. Weaver, former vice president for university rela tions of the University of North Carolina, died Saturday while playing tennis in New Delhi, where he had been Ford Foun dation project adviser for edu cational administration since 1968. He was 56 years old.

title: Niland Is Confident Cowboys Will Win
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 The switchboard at the Hil ton Inn, the motel way out by the airport where the Dallas Cowboys are in resi dence prior to their Super Bowl game with the Miami Dolphins on Sunday, will not give out the room numbers of the players. But the calls leak through nevertheless.

title: Personal Finance
description: Mrs. Ann Clegg has a co operative apartment for sale in Rye, N.Y., for $65,000. But she has discovered that some people who can afford to pay the money she's ask ing really don't know what a coop is or how to raise the money to pay for it.

title: McGovern and Humphrey Score Cutback in Food Stamp Outlay
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Two Democratic Presidential candidates sharply assailed to day the Nixon Administration for withholding $202million in spending for the food stamp program, the chief Federal antihunger effort.

title: BAIL IS REQUESTED BY ANGELA DAVIS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 (UPI)Angela Davis, appearing thin after 15 months in jail, ap pealed personally to a Federal judge today to free her on bail during her forthcoming trial on murder charges.

title: Sulphite Pulp Mill to Close In Dispute Over Pollution
description: EVERETT, Wash., Jan. 12 (AP)Weyerhauser Company will close its sulphite pulp mill here rather than go further in trying to meet pollution control requirements.

title: Salvation Army Commander To Retire From Post Jan. 28
description: Commissioner Edward Carey, national commander of the Salvation Army in the United States, will retire on Jan. 28, it was announced yesterday.

title: Advertising:
description: Not content with having a niche for seven years in the Associated Business Publica tions Advertising Effective ness Hall of Fame, James P. Kelley, amiable director of advertising for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, has gone on to be elected a vice president of the com pany.

title: Crowd Beats Kaunda's Rival
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 12Sl mon M. Kapwepwe, the former Vice President of Zambia who leads the United Progressive party in opposition to President Kenneth D. Kaunda, was beaten by a crowd on a street here today. He fled to a nearby hos pital, where he was treated for a cut forehead and bruises. Most other leaders of Mr. Ka pwepwe's party were arrested three months ago on the Pres dent's orders, but have not yet been put on trial.

title: Study Hints Prenatal Stress Can Curb Masculinity
description: Experiments with rats indi cate that severe stress during pregnancy can block the nor mal behavioral development of male offspring and, in effect, demasculinize them.

title: Books of The Times
description: We have here, in film star David Niven's account of his life and times, the first juicy allday lollipop of the new book season. Oh, perhaps sonic readers will find it a touch the English side, espe cially in the early parts, where young Niven, horrible little boy, is bouncing from school to school, and later trying to make a go of a career as an Army of ficer. But even here there are Nessie the cockney prostitute (who used to picnic with the 14yearold Niven at one of his schools) and Trubshawe the compleat ec centric (see gentleman with mustache and floral crown in illustration), not to men tion Mr. Niven's racy wit and fine sense of the absurd. And everywhere else in the book there are successes, heartbreaks, comedies, glamorous names, more glamor ous names and insidey Hollywood gossip, not to mention much more of Mr. Niven's racy wit and fine sense of the absurd. All in all, an amusing story with plenty of outloud laughs, and I would leave it at that and spend the rest of this column entertaining you with Niven anecdotes but for the fact that most of the best ones simply can't be printed here.

title: HIGH SCHOOL COED, IS SLAIN UPSTATE
description: UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) A 19yearold high school sen ior, the daughter of a teacher and niece of a Utica police lieutenant, was found dead to day in a wooded ravine. She was bound by the wrists and neck to a tree.

title: Utilities Corp. Names Aides
description: The International Utilities Corporation has named J. G. Rubenstein executive vice presi dent and John E. Maybin group vice president of utilities, effec tive Feb. 7. Both are newly created posts. John T. Jackson will continue as the senior vice president. Both Mr. Rubenstein and Mr. Jackson were elected to the board in December.

title: PAIR OF PROBLEMS RESOLVED BY OTB
description: At about the same time yes terday, the Offtrack Betting Corporation averted one prob lem, involving human labor, and solved another, involving me chanical labor.

title: H. G. Warner Weds Lucille Schulberg
description: The marriage of Miss Lu cille Edith Schulbcrg, a writ er, to Henry Goldsmith War ner, a widower and senior partner of Henry Warner & Co., certified public account ants here, took place at the Carlyle Hotel last evening. Rabbi Hugo Gryn of the West London Synagogue in Eng land performed the ceremony.

title: Louis Schwartz, Waiter, Dies; Sold $9Million in War Bonds
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 12 (AP) Louis G. Schwartz, who as a waiter in New York sold $9 million in war bonds in World War II, died of a stroke on Sunday. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Steel Layoffs Set
description: The United States Steel Cor poration confirmed in Pittsburgh yesterday that it was making substantial cutbacks in plant engineering forces at some of its mills.

title: Californian to Quit House
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP)Representative H. Allen Smith of California, the rank ing Republican on the House Rules Committee, said today that he would retire next Jan uary after 16 years in the House of Representatives. Mr. Smith, 62 years old, said in a statement that he and his wife want to come home, have more time with our family and live a more relaxed, normal life.

title: HERBERT STERNAU, INSURANCE AIDE
description: Herbert Sternau, a New York and Washington insurance ex ecutive, died yesterday at his home, 5 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: BYRON T. HACKER SR.
description: HAMDEN, Conn., Jan. 12 Byron T. Hacker Sr., retired executive director of the Chil dren's Center here, died yester day in the Veterans Hospital, West Haven. He was 78 years old.

title: Allende Program Faces Test in Two Elections Sunday
description: LINARES, Chile, Jan. 9Li nares Province is one of the two electoral battlegrounds where the votersmore than 200,000 men and womenwill say on Sunday whether they favor or oppose the oneyearold social ization program of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Merger News
description: The American Research, and Development Corporation, a venturecapital investment com pany, announced yesterday a plan to distribute to its share holders its 45 per cent interest in the Digital Equipment Corpo ration and then merge into Tex tron, Inc. The value of the dis tribution of its 4.6 million shares of Digital, a computer manu facturer, would be more than $350 million, based on yesterday's closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange. Each A.R.D. stock holder would receive three quarters of a share of Digital under the proposed plan.

title: No De Jure Segregation
description: The ruling by Federal District Judge Robert R. Mer hige Jr. that the predominantly black school district of Richmond must merge with two predominantly white adjoining counties is the first judicial attempt to deseg regate schools by removing the barriers that separate a city from its suburbs.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 12 (AP)  Demonstrators burst through police lines and at tacked British symbols in Val letta tonight in a violent show of support for Prime Minister Mintoff's decision to order British forces off this Mediter ranean island by midnight Friday.

title: Loose Money in Wall Street
description: One of the marvels of a trilliondollar economy is that It's so easy to get rich quick, if you don't care how you do it. This week a 19yearold college student built up a shortlived $200,000 account with stock brokers without putting up a cent in cash. And a 16yearold high school student, or dropout, snatched a manila envelope holding $4.3 Million worth of securi ties from a 68yearold Wall Street messenger. In Dickens' day, Fagin's children snatched handkerchiefs and purses.

title: LABOR EXTORTION LAID TO 7 HERE
description: An associate of Carmine J. Persico, three labor union of ficials and three other men were charged yesterday with conspiring to use violence and extortion to compel a Brooklyn corporation to rehire 10 dis missed employes.

title: U.S. WRIT WILL CURB COLGATE ON PATENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent judgment in United States District Court in Chicago today prohibiting the Colgate  Palmolive Company from using certain United States patents to allocate customers or markets in the sale of iron dextran through restrictive patent licensing agreements.

title: MARGARET BROWNE, PORTRAIT PAINTER
description: Margaret Fitzhugh Browne, a portraitist, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Beverly, Mass. She was 87 years old and lived in Boston and Anniss quam, Mass.

title: NEW COMPOUND USED TO DIAGNOSE DISEASE
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 12 (AP)The development of a radioactive compound that can diagnose adrenal gland diseases has been developed by the Uni versity of Michigan's division of nuclear medicine.

title: What's Piper Laurie Doing Now? For One Thing, Baking Bread
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.When Rosetta Jacobs was a little girl in Detroit, she used to play in the back of her grand father's bakery, but that idyllic period didn't last long enough for her to learn much about the family trade.

title: AUSTERITY DRIVE IS STARTED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has initiated an economy campaign aimed at saving $6million for the finan cially troubled Unitd Nations. The new Secretary General out lined his financial strategy in a memorandum sent to 20 de partment heads.

title: Entire 2,400Man Cambodian Brigade Flees Posts and Deserts
description: TAYNINH, Vietnam, Jan. 12 (UPI)A unit of the Cambo dian Army has been disbanded by common consent of its 2,400 officers and menall of whom deserted their post in a Cambo dian rubber plantation, changed to civilian clothes and scattered into South Vietnam.

title: Glenn Turner: A Franchiser With Flamboyance
description: Glenn W. Turner does not do business in the ordinary way.

title: Serebrier Is Guest Conductor With the Training Orchestra
description: The Tuesday night concert of the National Orchestral Associa tion was special in two ways. It presented Jose Serebrier as guest conductor in the training orchestra's first conducting award event, and it offered a concert performance of a short, littleknown opera by Tchaikov sky called Iolanthe.

title: Earthquake Rocks Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Thursday, Jan. 13 (UPI)A strong earth quake hit central Chile early today, causing widespread panic. However, no damage or injuries were reported. The quake was centered in Villa Alemana, about 50 miles north west of Santiago. An earth quake in the same area in July killed 84 persons.

title: SEALS TURN BACK NORTH STARS, 20
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 12 (UPI) Gilles Meloche's second shutout of the season and goals by Carol Vadnais and Ivan Boldirev sparked the California Seals to a 20 victory tonight over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Market Place: LittleGuy View Of Commissions
description: Nov that those 100share trades are making a come back on the ticker tapea sure sign the Little Guy is back in the marketit's time to think about those com mission charges again.

title: Representative Scheuer Is Held Briefly by the Police in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12Repre sentative James H. Scheuer of the Bronx, who has been tour ing Soviet educational institu tions with a Congressional study group, was briefly de tained by the Moscow police this evening as he was visiting a Jewish family that has been refused emigration to Israel.

title: No Subsidy for Church Schools
description: The special threejudge Federal court which declared unconstitutional the state's direct subsidy for parochial schools called the violation so obvious that there was no need for any reexamination of the 1971 law.

title: Coast Dock Talk Held
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 (UPI)A brief negotiating ses sion between shippers and West Coast longshoremen ended to day with no report of progress. An official of the International Longshoremen's and Ware housemen's Union said the waterfront strike would prob ably resume Monday.

title: Abandonment of Federal Housing Blights Inner Cities
description: CHICAGOThe square, brick apartment buildings called Woodlawn Gardens stand like military pillboxes along both sides of Cottage Grove Avenue, survivors of a strange process of burning and abandonment that has ravaged block after block of adjacent housing.

title: JOHN DRURY, AUTHOR AND FEATURE WRITER
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (UPI) John Drury, author of many books and a former feature writer for The Chicago Daily News, died yesterday at the age of 73. He is survived by a sister.

title: Cleveland Press Is Robbed
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 (UPI) Three men, armed with re volvers and wearing ski masks, brake through a fire door at The Cleveland Press last night, climbed over two partitions into the cashier's office and robbed the office of more than $40,000. They surprised a pay roll cashier, William Davies, and a truck driver, and locked the two in a safe.

title: Trade Talks Resume
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 United StatesJapan trade talks resumed today with no detailed report of progress.

title: MARION R, TRABUE, PENN STATE DEAN
description: Dr. Marion R. Trabue, dean emeritus of the College of Edu cation at Pennsylvania State University and a well known educator, died Tuesday in a nursing home at Annandale, Va. He was 81 years old.

title: MSGR. W. J. DUFFY,68, A PASTOR IN JERSEY
description: HOHOKUS, N. J., Jan. 12 Msgr. William J. Duffy, pastor of St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church and a former headmas ter of Seton Hall Preparatory Scizol, died today in his rec tory, 340 Franklin Turnpike.

title: U.S. INDIANS WIN MORE SELFRULE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Administration announced today a redirection of policy and programs designed to give American Indians more con trol of their own affairs.

title: Plager Out 10 Days
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (UPI) The St. Louis Blues said today that Bob Plager, a defenseman, will be out of action for about 10 days with a broken rib.

title: Paris Denies Plan For Military Return To Atlantic Alliance
description: PARIS, Jan. 12President Pompidou was officially de scribed today as hilarious at the thought that France might return to the Atlantic alliance's military organization.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Preparatory Committee for Conference on Human Envi ronment, Intergovernmental Working Group of Declara tion on Human Environment 3 P. M.

title: MALTA'S ARCHBISHOP TELLS OF MEDIATION
description: ROME, Jan. 12The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Malta, the Most Rev. Sir Michael Gonzi, said today that the United States and Italy were leading in efforts by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to prevent a British withdrawal from his island in a dispute over payment for use of bases.

title: $15Million Urged For Arts in State
description: Despite the state's fiscal crisis, the New York State Commission on Cultural Re sources yesterday recom mended that the Legislature appropriate more than $15 million this year for the State Arts Council.

title: Israeli Ends London Visit
description: LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) Menachem Begin, the Israeli rightwing politician, left Lon don for Israel today amid heavy security precautions and said his controversial visit to Brit ain had been fruitful.

title: Negro Is Alabama Judge
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 12 (UPI)A lawyer long active in civil rights cases is Birming ham's first black city judge. Peter Hall, 59 years old, was named by the City Council yes terday to fill a vacancy on the city Recorders Court bench left by the death of Judge Edward L. Rose.

title: Crosby to Aid Arthritis Drive
description: The Arthritis Foundation an nounced yesterday that Bing Crosby has been named nation al campaign chairman for the foundation's 1972 fundraising drives. Charles B. Harding, chairman of the board of the foundation, said Mr. Crosby, who has had arthritis himself for several years, will lead an intensified effort to speed vic tory over a disease that afflicts more than 17 million people in the United States.

title: COOPER BETTERS FREESTYLE MARK
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 12 (AP)Brad Cooper, a 17year old Australian swimming in a steady rain, set a world record for the 800meter freestyle of 8 minutes 23.8 seconds today.

title: Mrs. Robson Elected
description: DENVER, Jan. 12Mrs. Alan R. Robson of West Chester, Pa., today was reelected president of the American Hackney Horse Society at the organization's annual meeting at the Hilton Hotel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AID FOR COLLEGES AT RECORD LEVEL
description: State legislatures appropri ated a record $7,704,462,000 in 197172 to finance the operat ing budgets of colleges and uni versities, according to a study published by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: OwnerDrivers Offer a Program To End Chaos in Taxi Business
description: An express taxi shuttle service and government loans to help the underprivileged purchase taxi medallions were among the highlights of a sug gested program to improve cab service announced yesterday by the ownerdriver segment of the city's taxi industry.

title: RESERVE'S ACTION HALTS RATE RISES
description: The credit markets, a little shaky after their doubletime advance of the last few days, once again got a helping hand from the Federal Reserve yes terday.

title: Juvenile Sleepwear Goes Up in Flames In Consumers Test
description: With the help of Betty Fur ness, officials of Consumers Union set fire to a collection of children's pajamas and nightgowns at the Welfare Is land Fire Department facility yesterday to demonstrate their charges that virtually all juve nile sleepwear was flammable and dangerous.

title: Networks Say They Eliminated Most Violent Children's Shows
description: The major television net works said yesterday that they had eliminated most of the real ly violent children's programs prior to the completion of a Government study on the ef fects of TV violence on chil dren.

title: Kerner Arraignment Set
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (UPI) Otto Kerner, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals, and four others indicted with him on charges involving al leged race track stock deals while Mr. Kerner was Governor of Illinois will be arraigned on Jan. 20, it was announced today.

title: Plant Conversion Is Due
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 12The General Motors plant north of Montreal is to be converted from the production of Pontiacs to the exclusive manufacture of the small Vega car.

title: Cincinnati Wins, 108107
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 (UPI) Tom Van Arsdale hit a 15 foot jump shot with three sec onds left tonight to give the Cincinnati Royals a 108107 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in the National Basket ball Association.

title: LAIRD ASKS NIXON FOR MORE ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Nixon Administration, reacting to what it considers to be the slow pace of the strategic arms limitation talks, is considering asking Congress for a $250 million supplemental appropria tion in the defense budget, principally to step up strategic programs.

title: Police Marijuana Grower Draws 5 Years in Prison
description: A policeman who was sus pended last summer after he was found growing marijuana behind a stationhouse stable in Central Park was sentenced by Supreme Court Justice John Leahy in Queens yesterday to five years in prison.

title: Bhutto Still Hopes for Talks
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 12  Pakistan's President, Zul fikar Ali Bhutto, made it known through a spokesman today that he still expected to hold talks with Sheik Mujib, despite the Bengali leader's in sistence that no ties exist be tween Pakistan and Bangla desh.

title: Dyce Leads All the Way in Winning A.A.U. Mile Run
description: As it does for so many run ners, the mile has begun to excite Byron Dyce, one of the world's finest halfmilers.

title: Gifts to Neediest By Queens Pupils Help Unify School
description: Students at Junior High School 210 in Ozone Park, Queens, put aside rivalries that in the past had led to violence and disorder, and joined in a weeklong drive last month to raise funds for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Taking charge of the program themselves, the students raised $165.19, part of the $17,144.74 in contributions recorded yes terday.

title: Sheik Mujib Takes Prime Ministership; Appoints a Cabinet
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 12 In a day of swift and complex political maneuvers, Sheik Mujibur Rahman changed his position from President to Prime Minister today, adopted a provisional Constitution and shuffled his Cabinet.

title: Oil Talks in Geneva On New Increases Take Calmer Tone
description: GENEVA, Jan. 12A spokes man for the oilproducing coun tries predicted tonight that ne gotiations on their demand for increased payments from the major Western oil companies would require another couple of days.

title: College Sports Notes
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's 66th annual convention will be re membered as the Freshman Conventionthe gathering that allowed firstyear college athletes to participate on varsity football and basket ball teams. But it was also a noteworthy convention because of its de cisions in two other important areas. First, the member colleges consistently refused to go along with the usually persuasive N.C.A.A. Council by turning down its recommendations on many issues, particularly the call for a special convention to consider rising costs of ath letic programs.

title: $7.6BILLION BUDGET PROPOSED BY REAGAN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 12 Gov. Ronald Reagan presented a $7.6billion 197273 state bud get to the Legislature today and predicted a vigorous economic recovery.

title: Severe Cold in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (UPI) The temperature here fell to 11 degrees below zero today, the coldest this winter. A further drop was predicted.

title: Trend Toward Long Hair Trimming Barbers in State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP)The barber is becoming an endan gered species in New York State.

title: SECOND PRICE RISE ON '72 MODEL CARS GRANTED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The automobile industry won the Government's permission today for a second round of price in creases on 1972 models, this one to pay for new safety equip ment and improved antipollu tion devices.

title: SOVIET ART SHOW OPENS IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the So viet Minister of Culture, appar ently concerned over possible Jewish Defense League activity, called today on the American people and Government to pro tect the valuable Soviet arts and crafts exhibition that opened in the Corcoran gallery of art tonight.

title: 76ers Lose to Braves
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) Bob Kauffman sank a pair of free throws with two sec onds left tonight to lift the Buffalo Braves to a 111109 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Hartke Predicts Victory In New Hampshire Test
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12By the soft light of electric can dles, Senator Vance Hartke to day gave seven Washington cor respondents a first look at his Presidential campaign.

title: 6 Hurt and 8 Arrested as Phone Strikers Rampage in Midtown
description: At least six persons were re ported injured and eight others were arrested yesterday when more than a thousand telephone workers, on strike for half a year, marched a winding course through midtown streets, over turning and smashing telephone company equipment along the way.

title: ANTHONY PINTO, 88, EXENGINEER OF OTIS
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 12 Anthony Pinto, retired chief engineer of the Otis Elevator Company, died yester day in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 121 Melrose Drive.

title: South Africa Flies Extra Policemen to Area of Strike by 13,000 Black Miners
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 12Police reinforce ments were flown today to the northern part of SouthWest Africa, where 13,000 Ovambo tribesmen are striking to try to force the South African Gov ernment to alter the contract labor system.

title: Sex Boutique: Middle Ground Between Drugstore Approach and Smut Shop
description: Like the chickenortheegg controversy, no one is really sure which came first: The boutique fad or the socalled sexual revolution. At any rate, one of the newest out growths of these two sixties phenomena is what is called the sex boutique. By any of its other names (love bou tique, pleasure palace, sex shop) it is still the same: A store that dispenses the paraphernalia of what the media call the new morality. The shops, which have sprung up around the country, and in Canada, too, generally sell water beds, sleepwear, mood lights, erotic art, aphrodisiacs, lubri cants, birth control devices, artificial sex vibrators, love manuals and adult games.

title: Stage: Peerce as Tevye Met Tenor and Cantor Gives Fiddler a More Operatic, More Jewish Aspect
description: Every time I see Fiddler on the Roof and believe me I have seen Fiddler so many times by now that it is almost an orchestra to me I am amazed at its con tinued freshness. This is the greatest achievement of the American musical theater, and it remains as warm and as vital today as when it was new and we were all hardly out of adolescence.

title: Belgrade Arrests 11 Accused of Plotting Croatian Secession
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12Eleven prominent intellec tuals, members of Yugoslavia's Croatian minority, were arrest ed yesterday in Zagreb, Cro atia's capital. Their arrest was the most radical police action undertaken in Yugoslavia in re cent years.

title: Cruise Business Is Riding High Despite the Waves of Recession
description: Although there is a flat ness in other parts of the economy, the cruise business is bubbling over.

title: Expert Tells Tale of 2 Authors
description: Prof. Edgar Johnson of City College leaves the school this week after 45 years there, 20 in the company of two distinguished nonalumni, Charles Dickens and Sir Walter Scott.

title: Gentele to Open Season With Staging of Carmen
description: Goeran Gentele, the Met ropolitan Opera's incoming general manager, will direct the premiere production of his first season next fall, Carmen. Leonard Bernstein will conduct the opening night, Sept. 16, and other autumn performances of the Bizet opera, which will have scenery by Josef Svoboda, a Czechoslovak designer who will be making his Metro politan debut. Marilyn Horne will sing the title part, with James McCracken as Don Jos.

title: OTC AND AMEX CONTINUE GAINS
description: The recent strong advance on the American Stock Ex change and in the overthe counter market slowed yester day, although most issues end ed with gains in heavy trading.

title: PACT IS REACHED ON CITY HOSPITALS
description: About 16,000 nonprofessional workers in 18 municipal hospi tals and some Department of Social Services facilities will receive raises ranging from $1,800 to $1,950 over three years in a new contract with the city that was announced yesterday.

title: Backers of NEGRO Occupy N.A.A.C.P. Offices in Housing Rift
description: One black group occupied the offices of another yester day in a dispute involving scattersite housing and its im pact on the black community. The sitin began shortly before 10 A.M. when 30 members and supporters of the National Economic Growth and Recon struction Organization (NEGRO) entered the offices of the Na tional Association for the Advancement of Colored Peo ple, at 1790 Broadway. They ejected employes and took over the telephone switchboard in what they called an inter ruption and occupation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockaway's Residents Living in Fear of Muggers and Burglars
description: One elderly woman has pur chased a dummy that she has dressed like a policeman. She seats it in the car beside her when she is shopping and, at home, places it near her apart ment door.

title: GAINS REPORTED BY HIRAM WALKER
description: Hiram WalkerGooderham & Worts, Ltd., a large distiller of whisky and gin and maker of California wines, reported yes terday increased sales and earnings for its first fiscal quar ter ended Nov. 30.

title: News of Dogs
description: Dog owners were warned by Rogers Caras yesterday they must join a giant edu cation program to inform the public of the responsibilities of owning a pet, or face drastic legislation. The radio and television personality, addressing the monthly meet ing of the Dog Fanciers Clubat the McAlpin Hotel, predicted that unless a strong movement was initiated in communities, nodogs would be permitted by law within cities in 30 years.

title: Our Society Is Still Sick
description: A few days ago Vladimir K. Buhovslzy, a Soviet dissident, was convicted in Moscow on charges of antiSoviet agitation and sentenced to seven years in prison and five years of exile. Here are excerpts from his closing address to the court, as reported by Reuters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REGIME IN GHANA REPORTED OUSTED
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Thursday, Jan. 13The Ghana radio an nounced today that army of ficers had seized power in Ghana and Prime Minister Kofi A. Busia had been dismissed from office.

title: Shrimp and Lobster Tails Hijacked on 11th Avenue
description: A refrigerator truck was hi jacked in lower Manhattan yes terday morning by three men wearing ski masks shortly after its driver had taken on a 10,000 pound load of frozen shrimp and lobster tails valued at $40.000.

title: Benjamin March Dead at 52; Wrote Industrial Textbooks
description: Benjamin March, an author of industrial textbooks, died Tuesday at the Beth Abraham Home and Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 52 years old.

title: Music: Rubinstein's Way
description: One of the world's favorite octogenarians, Artur Rubin stein, lent his services to the pension fund concert of the New York Philharmonic Tuesday evening. That ges ture helped bring $45,000 into the pension fund cof fers. Mr. Rubinstein, never one to take things easy, undertook to play nothing less than the Brahms B flat Piano Concerto, followed by the Rachmaninoff Second. It was a good night's work for any pianist of any age. To open the program there was Beethoven's Coriolanus Overture.

title: Gwen Verdon Is Cast in Drama By Horrigan Opening March 7
description: Gwen Verdon, who made her mark on Broadway in mu sicals, has been signed to star in Children, Children, a play by Jack Horrigan, which has been described as a thriller.

title: Soviet Skater Wins Trophy In Italian Speed Events
description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 12 (AP)Valery Muratov of the Soviet Union won the Doria Trophy international speed skating competition today after placing second in the 1,000meter race.

title: Bridge: Tri  State Regionals Play Opens Today at Grossinger
description: In spite of the wintry weather that usually accom panies it, the TriState Re gional Tournament, which begins today at Grossinger, N.Y., generally attracts more New York enthusiasts than any other event outside the metropolital area. The sched ule is:

title: COPPER FUTURES HIGHER AT CLOSE
description: Prices of copper commodity futures rose 60100 cents a pound yesterday on the Com modity Exchange in New York. The market closed steady, re flecting a tight scrap copper market and improved industrial demand for the metal.

title: Thousands Flee Krek Area
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 12 (AP)About 3,000 families were reported today to have fled the Krek region of eastern Cambodia in the wake of first a South Vietnamese and then a Cambodian pullout from that strongpoint on Route 7.

title: Rouen Finally Decides on Memorial to St. Joan
description: PARIS, Jan. 12After half a century of dithering and debate, the town fathers of Rouen have chosen the dar ingly modern over the tra ditional in architectural repa ration to Joan of Arc, who was burned as a heretic there in 1431.

title: Defiance in Zululand
description: The legislative assembly of Zululand has unexpectedly rejected the customary oath of allegiance to the parent white Government of South Africa. This is a dramatic departure from the docile behavior expected of a new Bantustan legislature set up under South Africa's drastic policy of separate development for the different racial groups living in the Republic.

title: CURFEW RETAINED BY BATON ROUGE
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 12 A tight curfew was main tained in this racially tense city two days after two black men and two white deputies were slain in a shootout.

title: Yonkers City Manager to Quit in Clash
description: YONKERS, Jan. 12  City Manager Seymour Scher, saying he viewed a City Council re quest to reinstate the Police Commissioner as a vote of no confidence, announced today that he would resign in 30 days.

title: Fletcher Gets Atlanta Job
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 12 (UPI)  Cliff Fletcher, formerly of the St. Louis Blues, was named today as general manager of Atlanta's new team in the National Hockey League.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 12 (AP)  Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., who has been be low par recently, advanced to the fourth round of the Durban international tennis tournament today by beating Donna Judge of South Africa, 62, 63.

title: Open Enrollment Period Sought To Aid Young Voters in Primary
description: ALBANY, Jan. 12An open enrollment period for the June primary and streamlined forms and procedures that would let registration boards go onto college campuses to assist po tential voters have been pro posed in a series of bills an nounced here today.

title: 12 Killed as Police Battle Dominican Guerrilla Gang
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Jan. 12 (AP) Hundreds of police and troops used small arms, bazookas and mortars in a daylong battle today with a gang of leftists wanted for bank robbery. Eight policemen and four gunmen were killed, and the shootout at a cave outside Santo Do mingo touched off riots in the city.

title: Architects Trained by Wright Will Design FactoryBuilt Homes
description: The country's largest pro ducer of factorybuilt housing has commissioned the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation to de sign its entire line of homes.

title: Hijacking Suspect Held
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 12 (UPI)Donald L. Coleman, 24 years old, of Downers Grove, Ill., who is charged with air craft piracy and interference with flight attendants in con nection with an abortive at tempt to hijack an American Airlines Boeing 707 going from Chicago to San Francisco Dec. 26, has been committed to a mental institution for 60 days. Federal District Judge Willis W. Ritter ordered him committed yesterday after a hearing to determine his sanity.

title: IN THE NATION
description: If it survives appeal, a Federal Dis trict Court decision in the Richmond, Va., school case will prove not just historic but cataclysmic, with more and wider practical impact even than the 1954 decision that started school desegregation.

title: General Telephone, Chase and I.B.M. Elect Officers
description: Three of the nation's major corporations announced execu tive realignments yesterday.

title: Alumni of EastWest Center in Hawaii Are Holding Influential Posts in Asia
description: HONOLULUA list of grad uates compiled recently by the 11yearold Center for Cultural and Technical Interchange Be tween East and West, a State Department educational project better known as the EastWest Center, included the director of a national developmental re search program in Thailand, the chief meteorologist of India and the principal officer of the national science authority in Indonesia.

title: Michigan May Hold Primary
description: LANSING, Mich., Jan. 12 (UPI)Gov. William G. Milliken proposed today a May 9 Pres idential primary for Michigan with ground rules that strat egists from both parties have said they could accept.

title: 2 Pistols Found in Belfast Jail In Cell of Suspected Terrorists
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 12Two pistols were found today in a cell of a Belfast jail occupied by two prisoners awaiting trial on arms charges.

title: Notes on People
description: Recognizing the progress In bank group operations in recent years and desiring to insure continuity of manage ment for the future, the executive directors of the World Bank voted unani mously to reappoint Robert S. McNamara as president for another fiveyear term.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A newly organized, volunteer group of lobbyists and con cerned parents began an inves tigation yesterday into over crowding and understaffing at the Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded on Staten Island.

title: WALLACE ENTERS PRIMARY TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will announce his candidacy as a Democrat in Florida's March 14 Presidential primary at a news conference tomorrow in Tallahassee, the state capital.

title: Press Party of 80 to Accompany Nixon; Chou Says Table Tennis Team Would Like to Visit in Spring
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 President Nixon's trip to China will be covered by a contingent of 80 American newspapermen, broadcasters and technical per sonnel, the White House an nounced today.

title: Mohawk Airlines Will Pass Installment on Debentures
description: Mohawk Airlines, Inc. an nounced yesterday it would not pay the installment of interest due Jan. 15 on its 6 per cent convertible subordinated deben tures because continuing de faults on its senior debt pro hibits such payment. The car rier also passed the Jan. 15 and July 15, 1971, interest payments for the same reason.

title: Man in the News
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 Rudolph A. Peterson is a banker who built his career on organizational abilitya skill that has not served him well since retirement two years ago as president of the Bank of America.

title: Truck and 8 Cars Collide
description: WILMINGTON, Mass., Jan. 12 (AP)A tank truck jackknifed on Interstate 93 today, spilling 4,100 gallons of gasoline that caused collisions involving eight cars. No injuries were reported.

title: House Committee Urges Trade Ties In Brussels Talks
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 12 The House Ways and Means Com mittee, which has basic juris diction over trade and tax leg islation, completed its first trip outside the United States to day and made a strong declara tion of support for a united Europe and for closer interna tional trade ties.

title: Railroads Told to Plan Link Between Rome and Its Airport
description: ROME, Jan. 12The Gov ernment ordered the state railroads today to submit within this month a detailed plan to create a rail link be tween Leonardo da Vinci In ternational Airport at Fi umcino and the center of Rome.

title: Websters, Father And Son, Soloists In Clarion Concert
description: Because no government has yet decreed an inheritance tax that covers the matter, it is still possible for parents to pass on musical talent to their children. And they still do, as an audience at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday night can attest. The two soloists in a Clarion Con certs program led by Newell Jenkins were Beveridge Web ster, the pianist, and his son, Michael, who has matured into one of the most accomplished clarinetists one could hope to hear.

title: Sluggish Council
description: The City Council remains less responsive to the City Charter and to the citizens of the city of New York than to the county leaders of the Democratic party who continue to exert an unhealthy and negative influence on the local lawmaking process. These are the backroom wheelerdealers who look upon the public treasury as a private watering place for their faithful.

title: Straus Is Critical Of Suburban Stress By Retailing Group
description: Jack I. Straus, executive committee chairman of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., yesterday sharply criticized the retail ing industry's stress on sub urban stores at the expense of stores in the city.

title: Expos With High Hopes, Choose a Pitcher, 610
description: The Cleveland Indians had the first selection in baseball's winter freeagent draft yester day, but the Montreal Expos had the biggest.

title: Headquarters Denies Report
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, Jan. 13 (UPI) Officers at the Cambodian 22d Brigade headquarters here denied reports from Saigon that their unit had been disbanded following the withdrawal from Krek. But the officers did say the men were scattered and that some apparently had not left the Krek area.

title: Executive Changes
description: John D. Foley has been elected senior vice presi dent of the Pantasote Company.

title: Mrs. George Churchill, 104
description: Mrs. George A. H. Churchill, the former Mary Franklin King, a prominent society woman, died on Monday at her estate, 104 Rumson Road, Rumson, N. J. she was 104 years old and formerly lived at 580 Park Avenue. Her husband, who died in 1029, had it seat on the New York Exchange and several other exchanges. Mrs. Church ill leaves two sons, George of New York and Harold of ?? N.J.

title: Opening a Store, They Found, Is a Good Way to Meet People
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y. Some people have all the luck. For instance, there's Anthony and Laurie Garo fano, a couple of newlyweds who looked for an apartment and lucked into a country carriage house with swim ming pool privileges on the side.

title: Insurance Groups Renamed
description: USLIFE Title Insurance Com pany of New York is the new name of the InterCounty Title Guaranty and Mortgage Com pany, USLIFE Corporation said yesterday. Dallas Title and Guaranty Company has been renamed USLIFE Title Insur ance Company of Dallas.

title: U.S. Is Pressing Argentina On Extradition in Drug Case
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Diplomatic sources said today that four United States Congressmen met with Paraguayan diplomats in a new effort to win the extradition of Auguste Joseph Ricord, al leged to be the mastermind of an international narcotics ring.

title: ROBERT CHRISTESEN GIVES LIEDER RECITAL
description: Lieder singing being such a difficult and subtle art, it is rare that young performers find it a suitable means of expres sion. They may give songs the benefit of a fine voice, careful phrasing and clear enunciation of the words without getting inside the music and communi cating its special emotional power.

title: Austrian Girl Takes Cup Downhill Race
description: BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 7/2  Annemarie Proell broke Francoise Macchi's streak of four straight World Cup skiing victories today by winning a downhill race in absurd fash ion.

title: Rights Lawyers Hail Richmond Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Lawyers who won a landmark school desegregation decision Monday in the Federal District Court in Richmond, Va., told a news conference here today that their victory would have vast significance for the entire na tion, but particularly for North ern cities.

title: Couple Realizing Dream at Met
description: If dreams do not come true, then tonight at 8 the conces sionaire's daughter from Kan sas City and the fireman's son from Gary, Ind.  who fell in love when they sang together nearly 20 years ago in the Southwill not step out on the stage of the Met ropolitan Opera as costars of the Biblical epic, Samson. et Dalila.

title: Green Light for No Fault
description: The chances for enactment at Albany of no fault automobile insurance now seem vastly improved if only because state legislators who have just had to vote higher taxes for reduced services need something positive they can boast about in an election year. No fault automobile insurance does not cost money; on the con trary, it saves money.

title: JONES SET DOWN FOR THREE MONTHS
description: The American Horse Shows Association yesterday suspend ed one trainer and fined two others for violations of the group's drug rules.

title: TEACHERS SETTLE YONKERS STRIKE
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Thurs day, January 13A tentative agreement on terms to settle the 10day teachers' strike in Yonkers was announced here this morning by the Yonkers Board of Education president and Mayor Alfred Del Bello. Mr. Del Bello said the city's 1,859 teachers would return to work this morning.

title: Leafs, Kings Play 11 Tie
description: TORONTO, Jan. 12 (UPI) Paul Henderson scored his 23d goal of the season with 5:33 remaining in the third period tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs tied the Los Angeles Kings, 11.

title: St. Peter's Wins, 9880
description: JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 12 (AP)St. Peter's defeated East Carolina, 9880, tonight on a lategame scoring spree after a battle on even terms. The vic tors' Ted Martiniuk was the game's high scorer with 31 points.

title: Alleged Attackers of Innis's Son Taken From School and Beaten
description: An officer and a member of Harlem CORE were charged yesterday with kidnapping two students from their high school and whipping them with coat hangers and rubber hoses at a CORE office because the stu dents allegedly roughed up the son of Roy Innis, the CORE director.

title: Couple Killed in Accident
description: HARTWELL, Ga. Jan. 12 (AP)The bodies of a young couple, missing since the week before Christmas, have been recovered from the Hartwell Dam Reservoir, apparent vic tims of a traffic accident. Lieut. Thomas K. Phillips, 24, and his 22yearold wife Susan, a for mer Miss Delaware, died when their car plunged off Interstate 85.

title: Hat Business Sold
description: Koracorp Industries, Inc., a diversified apparel and textile company, has agreed to acquire the hat business of H.C.A. In dustries, Inc., the nation's larg est men's headwear manufac turer.

title: Rifts in French Opposition Frustrate Coalition Efforts
description: PARIS, Jan. 12  France's three major oppositions groups are giving the Gaullistdomi nated majority reasons for opti mism about winning the next legislative elections.

title: Soviet Liberalizing Hinted if West Acts
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 13A polit ically prominent Soviet writer was reported today to have suggested that Moscow would relax its restrictions on political dissidents and emigration if Western radio stations beamed toward the Soviet Union ceased what he described as antiSoviet propaganda.

title: The Psychological Side Effects of Vasectomy
description: LEICESTER, Mass.  A few weeks ago at a benefit auction for the Ameri can Civil Liberties Union chapter in Seattle, one of the items auctioned off was a vasectomy. It went for $50 the full operation for half the price, according to the auctioneer, a lawyer and state director for the A.C.L.U.

title: Prime Minister Mujib Also Will Head 4 Bangladesh Ministries
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 13 (AP)  Sheik Mujibur Rahman took over four Cabinet posts today in addition to his main job of Prime Minister of the newly proclaimed nation of Ban gladesh.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Although the waiting lines at ski lifts grow longer each year, there is also an in creasing interest in ski tour ing and snowshoeing, which require no mechanical hill climbing aids.

title: Directors of F.D.I.C. Disagreed On Bank Merger in California
description: Merger News

title: ARGUMENT DATE SET IN FUND LAWSUITS
description: A Federal Judge yesterday scheduled oral argument for Feb. 3 in three joined lawsuits that accuse the British Home, Secretary, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York, andothers of securities violations involving the Real Estate Fund of America, Ltd.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hughes Files Suit Here to Block Publication of Autobiography
description: A suit seeking to halt pub lication of the purported auto biography of Howard R. Hughes was filed in Manhattan State Supreme Court yesterday on behalf of the billionaire industrialist.

title: Kennedy Won't Be Delegate To Democratic Convention
description: BOSTON, Jan. 13Senator Eaward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight that he would not be a delegate to the National Democratic Con vention because that could be interpreted as a move to make him a Presidential candidate.

title: 3 Community Board Representatives to Take Part in Negotiations for School Contracts
description: The Board of Education has agreed to let representatives of the city's 31 community school boards participate in forthcom ing contract negotiations with unions representing teachers and other school employes.

title: NETS WIN, 11094, AS BARRY HITS 35
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 13The New York Nets shot their way into third place in the American Basketball As sociation's Eastern Division to night with a 11094 victory over the Floridians, the previ ous tenant.

title: Earle Arundel Dies at 65; PepCom Industries Officer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Earle Edwin Arundel, a vice president and director of Pep Com Industries, Inc., one of the largest producers of PepsiCola, died yesterday at his home in McLean, Va. His age was 65.

title: Books of The Times
description: Maurice Pater, Member of Parliament, had the kind of honesty that bored every one because it crowded almost everything else out of his personality, It had become his job to stand up and say things no one else wanted to because they were so obvious. When the two major parties were deadlocked, he could be counted on torecapitulate both sides of the ques tion without prej udice, to fill a furious silence with a deadly fair ness that made the other members too comatose to go on fighting. This was why, on the eve of the sixday war, an Arab lobby in London tried to bribe Pater to come over to their cause, The govern ment was evenly divided on the ArabIsraell Issue, and Pater, ofcourse, remained in the middle, saying things such as Great wrongs have been done by each side to the other. If this non entity, who had never ventured what could properly be called a personal opinion, could be persuaded to support the Arabs, he would be listened to. He couldn't even qualify for mistrust, and his stodginess was so very British that it had a ring of authenticity.

title: Shadows Cloud World of Ronald Kaufman
description: Federal authorities describe Ronald Kaufman as probably armed and dangerous, and are looking for him in connec tion with one of the more flam boyant criminal undertakings of recent years. But friends and associates describe him in quite other termsquiet, intense, but softspoken, more a hangeron than an activist.

title: Stockholm Conference in Danger
description: A cloud already bigger than a man's hand threatens to compromise seriously the work of the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment scheduled for Stockholm next June.

title: VIOLENCE FLARES IN MALTA CAPITAL
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 13 (AP)Supporters of Prime Min ister Dom Mintoff stoned the office of a proBritish news paper last night, roughed up an Opposition leader's son and spat on a statue of Queen Victoria as the deadline neared for Mr. Mintoff's order for eviction of British forces.

title: Legacy of Nkrumah
description: From the day it took office in a heady restoration of democracy 28 months ago, the Government of Ghana was shackled by a problem endemic to developing countries: huge foreign debts with crippling carrying charges. Prime Minister Busia had to cope with the legacy of Kwame Nkrumah, who led Ghana into inde pendence in 1957 with $400 million in foreign reserves and left it with a foreign debt of $600 million at the time he was ousted in 1966.

title: A. & P. Cuts Its Dividend To 20 Cents From 32
description: Reflecting its net loss in the third fiscal quarter ended last November, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company cut its quarterly dividend yesterday to 20 cents a share from 32 cents. It was the first time the company had re duced the dividend since it became publicly owned in 1959, when the directors initi ated the payout at 20 cents a share.

title: Hill Joins Oilers' Staff
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Bill Peterson, head coach of the Houston Oilers, named King Hill, a pro quarterback for 12 years, as a special as sistant coach today.

title: GAIN IS FORECAST AT TRANSAMERICA
description: Transamerica Corporation, the multimartcet service organ zation based in San Francisco estimates its 1971 earnings at about 94 cents a share, accord ing to John R. Beckett, chair man and president, meeting here yesterday with securities analysts.

title: Bhutto Warns of Break With Nations That Recognize Bangladesh
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 13  President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto warned today that any country hastily recognizing the new government of Bangladesh would be likely to face a break in relations by Pakistan.

title: Port Jersey Development Could Cut Brooklyn Jobs
description: The development of a new containership port in Jersey City and the agreement of a consortium of five Japanese lines to berth seven new ves sels there could cost the Brook lyn waterfront as many as 1,000 jobs.

title: Japan to Spend More on Arms, Welfare

title: Books of The Times
description: In spite of what the title of Ellis Rivkin's book suggests, it appears to this reader as an attempt to answer an ageold ques tion, one that has intrigued Jews and non Jews alike. How did these small nomadic tribes, wandering in and out of the wastes and greenery of Palestine, meet the chal lenge of change and decay and survive as a separate entity down the cen turies? Especially how did they do it after the destruc tion of the second temple in 70 A.D. and the dispersion of the inhabitants? For then these people had no land, no church, no physical center and no visible machinery to keep them intact and whole. The obvious answer is that they were held by the strength of an idea, and that their allegiance to it transcended the power of kings and emperors to break it. What Mr. Rivkin does is define that idea and show how it developed and how it served under conditions and in ages beyond the com prehension of those who formulated it in the first place.

title: Britain Asked to Halve Her Population And Save the Environment to Survive
description: LONDON, Jan. 13  Thirty three leading scientists warned today that to avoid a world en vironmental catastrophe Britain must soon stop building roads, tax the use of power and raw materials and eventually cut her population by half.

He bequeathed his home, La Louque, near Paris, to Miss Mlier, who was his closest companion in the months preceding his death. Also re membered in the will were two nephews, two former sec retaries, several servants and numerous charities.

title: Portrait of Miss Davis, Revolutionary
description: The student-made documentary titled "Angela Davis: Portrait of a Revolutionary" was made prior to the imprisonment of its controversial heroine, whose scheduled trial for murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy is due in a few weeks.Even if this were not so, this crude but telling film close-up of the black avowed Communist and ardent foe of capitalistic societyits structure and its flawswould make engrossing viewing. The 60-minute movie was assembled by Yolande du Luart and a team of other film students at the University of California at Los Angeles, where Miss Davis's outspoken utterances, as a teacher and a protester, first got her in hot, capitalistic water. The movie is being shown through Wednesday at the Whitney Museum.The picture opens with a glimpse of Miss Davis, already a controversial figure, high up and peering through bars at the local Women's House of Detention, as street supporters rally outside.The rest of the footage backtracks and fills in her explosive career as a political leftist. She is never at a loss for words, and we get a distinct impression of force and sincerity as she gives interviews, addresses political meetings, holds informal discussions and finally leads a crowd of protesters into the courtroom at San Rafael, Calif.And what is Miss Davis like close up? Handsome, almost strikingly so, with a graceful, informal demeanor and an easy, beautiful smile. Miss Davis also has a sense of humor, at least in the informal classroom scene where she analyzes the hierarchical dominance of one large American corporation.In the most winning moment of the film, we see her alone at night in her Los Angeles apartment. She is silent, purposefully scribbling with a pen, one arm casually propping her bent head.But Miss Davis is seldom silent, at least in this picture, once she gets going with a torrent of words, whether denouncing the United States Government or "prison injustice" in her homeland. Asked whether Communism has succeeded entirely in countries like Russia and Cuba, Miss Davis said that it would not "as long as there's one capitalistic country left."On the steps of Los Angeles City Hall, Miss Davis informs a roaring crowd, assembled to protest the arrest of Black Panthers, of a "national conspiracy of genocide to murder every black in the land." She asserts "our constitutional right to bear arms to defend ourselves."Whether or not you agree with Miss Davis's assertions, this film is impressive.The ProgramANGELA DAVIS: PORTRAIT OF A REVOLUTIONARY, a documentary by Yolande du Luart, 60 minutes. At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street. Film showings daily at noon, 2 and 4 P.M., also at 3 P.M. tomorrow and on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

Total retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $7,271,000, 000, an increase of 6 per cent from the $6.834,000,000 sales for the period last year.

title: Liberation: A Simultaneous Happening
description: LOS ANGELESIn the forties I wrote despairingly in my diary: Wo man will be the last one on earth to find independence and to find strength in herself. I was judging from the lives of women around me, and from my own. But I was wrong. Several developments accelerated the growth and expansion of woman. One was psychoanalysis, which gave her self confidence and guidance in the cre ation of herself as an individual. That was the inner journey that I (and many other women) took. That was the inner journey which women are responding to in the reading of my diaries. They write me: You affirmed life, affirmed womanhood, affirmed the creative process. You have brought to consciousness in a unique way, the multilevel of woman.

title: Alabama Storm Kills 4 in Trailers

title: Canali on Mars

title: HARPSICHORDISTS TURN THE TABLES
description: Ever since its invention shortly after 1700, the piano has been stealing music orig inally composed for its smaller voiced ancestors, the harpsi chord especially. Now, the tables are turning. Not content with reclaiming their own music, harpsichord players are busily appropriating piano music for their plucked instru ment. Who knows where this may end? A Society to Save the Pianoforte may have to be formed to protect the great black beast from the increas ingly bold predator.

title: Mercury Climbs to 62, Then Takes a Sharp Dip
description: New Yorkers went to bed to the taste of spring last night hut, the weatherman said, they would wake up this morning to the more normal bite of winter.

title: CZECH ROUNDUPS IN '71 REPORTED
description: ATHENS, Jan. 10An in formed Czechoslovak source has received word from reli able sources in Prague of two major series of political arrests in Czechoslovakia in the clos ing weeks of last year. The number of those arrested was put at several hundred.

title: Air Customs Top Port's
description: Largely because of the long shore strike last fall, Federal customs collections at Kennedy International Airport have ex ceeded for the first time the receipts at the New York Cus tom House. Fred R. Boyett, re gional commissioner, reported yesterday that November cus toms collections totaled $69 million at Kennedy and $40.2 million at the Custom House.

title: Edwin L. Weisl Sr., Key Democrat, Dies
description: Edwin L. Weisl Sr., one of former President Lyndon B. Johnson's closest friends and a former Democratic National committeeman from this state, died yesterday at the home of Henry Hathaway, the movie di rector, at Bel Air, a Los An geles suburb.

title: Nicklaus's 66 Leads by 3 Shots
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13Jack Nicklaus, with a 66, led the opening round of the Bing Crosby tournament today in golf considered normal for him. But while the weather was delightful it wasn't regarded as typical. The three courses along the Pacific Ocean were dry from lack of rain, fog or snow that usually prevail at this event.

title: Advertising:
description: A couple of Cincinnati ad vertising men dropped by yesterday to show us the $100million idea they had donated the day before to the United States Postal Serv ice in Washington.

title: ' The Cowboys':Wayne Stars in Rydell Work at Music Hall
description: "Is it going to be like this every day  even on Sundays?" asks the exhausted 14-year-old cowhand at the end of the first day of their cattle drive through what John Wayne has described as "400 miles of the meanest country of the West."Answers the older boy simply: "There ain't no Sundays west of Omaha."No Western with a line as lovely as that one can be completely terrible, but you quickly realize that Mark Rydell's "The Cowboys" has no intention of being as honest as you would like it to be, and, indeed, as it might have been had Mr. Rydell and his screenwriters stuck to what seems to have been their original idea. This is a Western seen through the eyes of a group of boys, 11 through 15, who, by a stroke of the kind of glorious fortune that visits young boys in juvenile fiction, suddenly find themselves as real cowhands in a real cattle drive in the Old West."Gee willikers," one is tempted to expostulate, "what a capital opportunity for adventure!"It all starts when old Wil Anderson (John Wayne), whose own sons have died after having gone mysteriously "wrong" in the distant past, finds that his regular ranch hands have deserted him to rush off on a gold hunt. Faced with the necessity of getting several thousand head of cattle to market, Wil takes on a dozen school boys as his hands.You immediately know that a numbingly contemporary, adult sensibility is at work when one of the boys turns out to be Jewish, when another turns out to be the half-caste son of a Mexican whore, and when Roscoe Lee Browne, whose diction is only slightly less melifluous than Sir John Gielgud's, turns up as the chuck-wagon cook. This cattle drive seems to have been organized not in desperation, but to conform to some odd Appellate Court decision.Even this might be tolerable, had the movie then allowed its youngsters some degree of juvenile reality, but they are constantly being wrenched into attitudes imposed on them by the adults. I was amused when the boys get into big Duke's liquor closet and become roaring drunk, and somewhat amused by their close brush with sex, in the forms of some extraordinarily pretty whores they just happen to come upon in the wilderness (on their way, no doubt, to a Miss Universe contest), but the finale, in which the boys slaughter a band of cattle rustlers, is simply ridiculous. It isn't that I believe children to be necessarily humane creatures (Mark Twain cured me of that myth), but that the brutality is all too easily, and witlessly effected.Wayne is, of course, marvelously indestructible and he has become, an almost perfect father figure, without whom "The Cowboys" would be even more ludicrous than it actually is, despite the fine Western camerawork of Robert Surtees and the excellent supporting performances by people like Slim Pickens, Bruce Dern (as an outlaw) and Colleen Dewhurst, as the exceptionally merry madame on a trail to nowhere.It is typical of the movie's little frauds that it makes a great point of having old Wil announce that he is 60 years old and not what he used to be, although big Duke is on the far side of 65, and showing it with style. So why, for heaven's sake, does the movie make him wear a toupee? "The Cowboys," which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, is so flecked with minor dishonesties that you come to recognize it as a sort of Formica Western, something that amounts to a parody of the real thing.

title: BUSINESS TO RAISE 1972 OUTLAYS 9.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  Business plans to increase in vestment in plant and equip ment by 9.1 per cent this year over 1971, the Commerce De partment and Securities and Ex change Commission reported today.

title: Britain's Trade Gains
description: LONDON, Jan. 13Britain achieved a record $767million surplus of exports over imports in 1971, according to year end figures published today by the Department of Trade and Industry.

title: POPE BIDS AGENCIES COORDINATE ON AID
description: ROME, Jan. 13Pope Paul VI exhorted Roman Catholic relief agencies throughout the world today to avoid operating at cross purposes.

title: Innis's Son Arrested for Role In Pointing Out His Assailants
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts had 15yearold Alexander Innis arrested yester day for what he said was the youth's role in the kidnapping and beating of two fellow high school students.

title: Persico and CoDefendants Lose Appeal for New Trial
description: Carmine J. Persico, the reputed Mafia figure, and three codefendants convicted in a Brooklyn hijacking case, lost an appeal for a new trial in a discision here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Wallace Joins Florida Race as Democrat
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 13 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama formally began a race for the Presidency today by entering the Florida pri mary as a Democrat. He re fused, however, to rule out the possibility that he would head a thirdparty movement in November.

title: The Adventurer
description: As certain as heat lightning or the clacketyclack of crickets on a summer night, Gov. George C. Wallace has signaled the coming of another Presidential election year by announcing his candidacy. Never a man to run one campaign when two are possible, Mr. Wallace intends to run in the spring primaries as a Democrat as he did in 1964 and, in all probability, run again in the fall as the nominee of his own American Independent party as he did in 1968.

title: Patti Hogan Defeated
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 13 (AP)Secondseeded Linda Tuero of Metaire, La., ad vanced to the semifinals of the National Sugar tennis tourna ment today, defeating top seeded Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., 60, 63.

title: Chaplin May Attend Oscar Ceremony
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 13 The Academy of Motion Pic ture Arts and Sciences an nounced today that Charles Chaplin had agreed to come to Hollywood to accept a special citation at the an nual Academy Awards pres entation.

title: NATO Offer Reported Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (Reu ters)Diplomatic sources said today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies, con cerned about the possible ex pansion of Soviet influence in the Mediterranean, have agreed at a Brussels meeting to offer Malta about $33million to pre serve naval bases on the island.

title: Facts on Ghana Republic
description: Vital StatisticsThe Republic of Ghana, a nation of 92,099 square miles situated on the west coast of Africa, has a population of 8,545,561 people, chiefly of black Sudanese stock, whose per capita income is $262. The illiteracy rate is about 75 per cent, and the life expectancy is about 45 years. The na tion's gross national product was $2.32billion in 1970.

title: 17 AIRLINES AGREE TO CUT POLLUTION
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yester day that 17 airlines had signed a courtapproved agreement to install antipollution devices by Dec. 31, 1972, on jets equipped with Pratt and Whitney JT8D engines and using airports in the slate.

title: KEINO BACK IN U.S., A SURPRISE ENTRY IN MARYLAND MILE
description: Kipchoge Keino is back in the united States to celebrate a 32d birthday and to see where I am in a training program for the Olympic Games.

title: STOP BUCKETING, BROKERS WARNED
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 13  The Securities and Exchange Commission warned brokers today against the practice known as bucketingthat is, telling a customer that the broker has bought a security for him, as instructed, when the broker actually has not done so.

title: Baton Rouge Lifts Curfew; National Guard to Go Home
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 13 (AP) Mayor W. W. Dumas lifted today a curfew that was clamped on this capital city after a bloody gunfight Mon day. He said that the National Guard would go home immedi ately.

Israel Cocoa Company, was reelected vice president of the association; Theo J. Preis werk, vice president of Produce Unitrade, Inc., was elected treasurer, and Edwin H. Lind Curacao Trading Company, berg, vice president of the Inc., was elected secretary.

title: New Moon Data Sifted For Nuggets of Theory
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13  More than 600 lunar scientists met here this week and spoke of many things: Of hot spots and moonquakes, parentless lead and Genesis beans.

title: Ginny May Gains Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Record sales of $3.5billion in mortgagebacked securities of the Government National Mortgage Association were forecast for 1972 today by Woodward Kingman, Ginny May president.

The changes will go into effect shortly.

title: DISMISSAL IS DENIED IN PENNSY AIDE CASE

Spencer, president of First National City Bank, told an Explorers Club environ mental dinner last night.

description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 13The New York Knicks, carrying a four  game losing streak, worked out this afternoon at International Sports Arena in preparation for their National Basketball Association game there tomorrow night against the Golden State Warriors.

description: YONKERS, Jan. 13 Yon kers teachers ratified a new contract this morning and returned to work, ending a strike that had effectively shut down the city's 43 schools since Jan. 3.

title: Bridge: Restaurant in Village Joins Trend Toward Morning Game
description: Bridge players are tradi tionally night birds, and many experts who are not tied to office hours refuse to surface before midday. But in recent years there has been a slight swing toward earlier rising.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 On the day two months ago when Joe Frazier signed for his title defense here Satur day night against Terry Daniels, he glanced across a room at the unknown 25 yearold challenger and sneered.

description: Free subway rides were available last night for hun dreds of Wall Street workers after two men and a girl chained open two of six exit gates at the BMT station at Broad and Wall Streets at the start of the rush hour.

description: YOUGHAL, IrelandYour contribu tor Honor Tracy finds material for humor in the plight of Belfast. With such a sense of the comical it is a pity she was not around to get some giggles out of, say, the Watts riots, or the events at Kent State.

description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Jan. 14 Suffolk County's Labor Com missioner today announced a, new Federal emergency appro priation to fight unemployment here and then bitterly attacked it as too small.

description: Henry J. Nave, president of the White Motor Company, an nounced yesterday he was tak ing early retirement and resign ing as an officer and director of the company.

title: Oil Nations Ask an 8.57% Rise In Payments at Geneva Talks

title: Curtain Going Up
description: There are two ways for a city to die. It can fail to provide shelter and the dignity of a livelihood, and it can lose the creative force that makes it central to men's existence. Without the first, no city can survive. Without the second, no city is great.

title: Lindsay, in Arizona, Seeks A Share of 25 Delegates
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 14 Mayor Lindsay opened a drive here tonight for a share of Ari zona's 25 delegates to the Dem ocratic National Convention.

title: Swedes Are Angry
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  The reaction to the South African readmission was swift and divided. In Johannesburg, Owen Williams, the tennis pro moter, said he was delighted and the president of the South African Lawn Tennis Union, Alf Chalmers, said any nonwhite player in South Africa would be given a chance to win a spot on the team.

title: Moscow Expels Scheuer; Cites Improper Activities
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14The So viet Government ordered the expulsion of Representative James H. Scheuer of the Bronx today, accusing him of im proper activities. The United States promptly termed the ac tion a grave step not helpful to relations.

title: Rodgers Undergoes Surgery
description: OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 14 (UPI) Johnny Rodgers, Nebraska's allAmerican flanker, said today that he had undergone surgery to correct an old injury to his right thumb and for treatment of several other ailments. He said that he injured the thumb while playing basketball in the summer of 1969.

title: BRANDT'S ACCORDS IN EAST GAIN IN BONN
description: BONN, West Germany, Jan. 14West Germany's goodwill treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland easily cleared their first parliamentary hurdles in the upper house of Parliament today.

title: NILAND'S ATTACK: ALL HOLDS BARRED
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14  Bob Heinz, the big Miami tackle who will be playing in the Su per Bowl here on Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, is going to get a clean game from his opponent across the scrim mage line, John Niland, who will be wearing a jersey one size too small for good reason.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH AS Cowens STARS
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)Dave Cowens scored 26 points and tied a career high with 28 re bounds tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 10894 vic tory over the Detroit Pistons in the National Basketball As sociation.

title: Slaying of 2 City Policemen Laid to at Least 5 Persons
description: At least five persons and per haps more, the police now be lieve, shot and killed two city patrolmen outside the Colonial Park housing project in Har lem last May 29.

title: 30Year Term in Heroin Sale of 1/73 Oz.
description: A 23yearold narcotics ad dict described by defense and prosecuting attorneys as a sick man who needs treat ment was sentenced in a Bronx court yesterday to a maximum penalty of 30 years in prison for selling oneseventythird of an ounce of heroin last summer to police undercover agents.

title: Accountants Find Confusion Persists On Phase 2 Details
description: Many of the accountants who advise the nation's businessmen on how to conform to Phase Two of the Nixon economic program appeared yesterday be still mired in confusion.

title: Aetna Chooses New Chief In Executive Revamping
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, in a major revamp ing of its top executive eche lon, yesterday named John H. Filer, a 47yearold executive vice president, to become the company's new chairman and chief executive officer, effec tive July 1.

title: Frederik of Denmark Dies; Margrethe to Be Queen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 14King Frederik IX of Denmark died tonight at the Copenhagen municipal hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Hawaii U. Uses Satellite System For Pacific Education Network
description: HONOLULUA new meth od of longdistance educa tional exchange by radio has been developed at the Univer sity of Hawaii, using an arti ficial earth satellite to convey information instantaneously by voice, print and pictures between classrooms, labora tories or libraries in different countries.

title: A Day in the Life of Nonstop Housewife
description: Sometime, somehow, the other day, between guest teaching an elementary school art class, ministering to an ill daughter at home, making lunch and sending her son off to kindergarten, driving into Manhattan to check an ex hibit of her paintings, taking her son to a birthday party, cooking dinner for the fam ily and presiding over an eve ning meeting of the Queens community board, Mrs. Janet Langsam found time to take her other daughter shopping, pick up library books for the sick daughter and round up some support on the tele phone for the proposed new Queens cultural center, of which she is an ad hoc board member.

title: Rhodesian African Council Denies Link to Disorders

title: Peking Asks U.N to Halt Taiwan Aid

title: Long Tieng Reported Circled

title: Telephone Strikers Demonstrate Against Management Workers

Kissinger's ef forts during the height of the IndianPakistani war to aid the Pakistani cause, instead of re maining neutral, according to a newly published account of a secret White House strategy session.

title: The Talk of Edlington
description: EDLINGTON, England, Jan. 12In the workingmen's club along Bungalow Road, oppo site Jim's Bingo and the pin ball machines in Penny Lane, the miners and some of their wives gathered for an other session of beer, darts, talk and laughs. The ladies' dart teamBunny, Lil, Nell, Rose, Ann and Helen  are trouncing the men, Derek, Fred, Allan, Jim, Tom and Eddie. A few blocks away, the York shire Main Colliery, operat ing since 1911, sits idle; its winding gear, for carrying miners a half mile below ground, is at full stop. For the 1,745 miners who work the Mainalong with 280,000 colleagues across the coun tryare staying at home in Britain's first national miners strike in 46 years.

title: Hanging of Blacks Flag in Jersey Schools Argued
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14  The black liberation flag was pic tured today as both an inno cent symbol designed to inspire young black students to learn and the banner of black revo lutionaries bent on fomenting trouble between whites and blacks in the Newark school system.

title: Suns Halt Cavaliers
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 (AP) Neal Walk scored 14 points and grabbed seven rebounds in the first period to help the Phoenix Suns to a 117107 vic tory over the Cleveland Cava liers tonight.

title: RECORD BUDGET SET BY CHICAGO UTILITY
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday in Chicago a record construc tion budget of about $3billion for 1972 through 1976.
