The an nouncement was made in con nection with the filing of a registration statement covering a previously announced $200 million rights offering of com mon stock and warrants to stockholders.

title: MOTORCYCLE GANG HELD IN BURGLARY
description: Ten members of the World's End motorcycle gang of Ozone Park, Queens, were arrested yesterday on charges of bur glarizing a Brooklyn ware house of $340,000 worth of women's raincoats.

title: LINDSAY REPORTS GAINS IN HOUSING
description: Mayor Lindsay reported yes terday that more cityassisted housing was begun here during 1971 than ever before.

title: U.S. Reacts in a Low Key To Expulsion of Scheuer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  The Nixon Administration made a relatively lowkey re sponse today to the Soviet Union's order expelling Repre sentative James H. Scheuer.

title: Nixon Makes No Bones About Accepting Award
description: DALLAS, Jan. 14 (UPI) President Nixon today ac cepted the Bonehead of The Year award in the spirit in which it is given  in good humor.

title: Rhythm, Instrumental Trio, Is Heard at Maisonette
description: An instrumental trio from Boston called Rhythm served up a mixture of jump and soul at the weekly session of Jazz Adventures yesterday after noon at the Maisonette of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel.

title: Time to Ring Off
description: Desperation seems to be taking over among striking employes of the New York Telephone Company after six months on the picket line in a strike that never was well justified. Yesterday's march through midtown by over 400 strikers was nonviolent, in contrast to the rampage earlier in the week when phone booth windows were smashed and a company car overturned. But the marchers curses and their warnings of trouble in larger demonstrations planned for next week betoken a danger ous mood of frustration.

title: ValueTax Fraud Curbed in France
description: PARIS, Jan. 14Antiracket squads have started cracking down on a flourishing business in France of supplying false in voices to industrialists to bilk the tax authorities.

title: Protests Flare Anew as So. Africa Is Reinstated by Davis Cup Leaders
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 South Africa, barred from the Davis Cup tennis competition for the last two years, was readmitted today and organizations op posed to the country's policy of racial segregation (apart heid) announced immediately that demonstrations would be mounted at matches involving the South Africans.

title: Why Can't They Be Like Us?
description: I am very disappointed with what I see at Ithaca now. I graduated in June, 1970. Now everyone seems to be more serious, their lives are duller. Friends who were always willing to come over Friday night to drink wine and to watch a horror movie on tele vision spend their time studying.

title: Baton Rouge Schools Shut
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 14 (AP)  Public and private schools shut down here today in the wake of rumor and ten sion stemming from last Mon day's gunfight between the po lice and militant blacks. The school board gave no reason for the public school holiday. High school athletic events were canceled and private and parochial schools joined the closing.

title: Carolina Power & Light
description: The Carolina Power & Light Company reported yesterday gains in revenues and net in come for the fourth quarter and full calendar year. The prelim inary report placed revenues at $67,152,920 for the three months ended Dec. 31, 1971. This compared with $51,990,686 a year earlier.

title: FRANK E. JAMROZY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 14 Frank E. Jamrozy, former City Court judge and a practicing lawyer for more than half a century, died today at St. Joseph Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 188 Ber rian Road.

title: 2 Seek to Avoid Grand Jury In Pentagon Papers Inquiry
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Noam Chomsky, professor of linguistics at Massachusetts In stitute of Technology, and Ralph Stavins of the Institute of Pol icy Studies, filed motions in Federal court today seeking to bar their appearances before a grand jury next Tuesday in vestigating the distribution of the Pentagon papers.

title: Happy Woman Umpire Eager to Cry, Play Ball
description: On Thursday, New York State's Court of Appeals gave Mrs. Bernice Gera, a 40year old Jackson Heights, Queens, housewife, the right to call play ball as an umpire in organized baseball.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislator on the Go James Haas Scheuer
description: Man in the News

title: Oklahoma Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) President Nixon designated Oklahoma a major disaster area today because of severe storms and floods last month in the southeastern section of the state.

title: Thomas to Lead the Boston
description: Because of William Stein berg's illness, Michael Tilson Thomas will substitute for him as conductor of tonight's con cert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. The program has been changed and will offer Stravinsky's Sym phony for Winds: Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1, with Misha Dichter as soloist, and Brahms's Symphony No. 4. The program by Zino Francescatti and Robert Casadesus sched uled for tonight in Alice Tully Hall has been canceled because of the former's illness. Refunds will be available at the box office.

title: SILVER AND COPPER
description: Steady trade and commis sionhouse buying helped ad vance price about 3.5 cents an ounce on the Commodity Ex change in New York. The ex change's copper futures were  cent to 0.55 cents a pound higher.

title: Learning Filmmakingand Much More
description: Purple drama. Bananapeel comedy. Wry social com ment. Realistic reporting. And all of it being filmed or edited by about 150 young devotees of filmmaking who are participants in the Film Clubthree narrow store fronts on a dingy strip of Rivington Street between Chrystie Street and the Bow ery.

title: Bucks, W. Germany, Win In European Ice Dancing
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Jan. 14 (UPI)Angelika and Erik Buck of West Germany won the icedancing gold medal in the European figureskating cham pionships tonight.

title: Adelphi Graduate Student Held in Alleged Bomb Plot
description: A graduate student in ad vanced chemistry at Adelphi University was held yesterday in $250,000 bail on charges he planned to blow up a Defense Department facility in Garden City, L. I., to protest the con tinuing war in Vietnam.

title: Wells, Out of Prison, Told to Sell Cadillac
description: OAKLAND, Calif. (AP), Jan. 14Warren Wells, for mer wide receiver of the Oakland Raiders, was re turned from state prison to day and placed on three year probation. Superior Court Judge Leonard Dieden said Wells, as a condition of probation, would be com mitted for an indeterminate period to the Oakland fa cility of Synanon, a drug and alcoholic rehabilitation center, and would not be permitted to quit the pro gram.

title: 6 Reported Injured in Chilean Election Violence
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 14 Six persons were reported wounded early today in a shoot ing incident as the campaign for Sunday's legislative byelec tions drew to a close.

title: Dance:Fille Mal Gardee
description: American Ballet Theater's new production of La Fille Mal Garde suffers from a total lack of subtlety but also makes quick recovery through the actual perfor mances by its dancers.

title: Art Downtown: Constructionist Shifts
description: The constructionist Naum Gabo said that the content of his sculptures lay in them selves devoid of outside ref erences. The same could be said for the metal creations of Kenneth Snelson, a contem porary constructionist whose frameworks of anodized alu minum tubes held in space by stainless steel cables are fa ??. As the work of Gabo, the content of Mr. Snelson's works lies in their structure, the form that is revealed through the structure and the space that is defined by it.

title: Art: The Classical Essence of a Loner
description: Back in the heyday of the New York School when the nowdefunct Tanager Gallery was the 10th Street waystop to fame and fortune uptown, you might now and then see there a figurative drawing or painting so exquisitely disci plined as to rebuke the com petitive hysteria of the sur rounding company. Lennart Anderson, who is now show ing a beautiful group of drawings at Graham, 1014 Madison at 70th Street, was a loner at Tanager and he is still a loner today, even though circumstances have made him a focal point in the return to figurative art.

title: A.M.C. CUT LOWERS WEEKLY CAR OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 14 (AP)  A cutback by the American Mo tors Corporation caused a slight decline in United States auto production this week, the trade paper Automotive News report ed yesterday.

title: Israel Raids Lebanon 3d Time in Week
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 14  Is raeli troops staged another re prisal raid into southern Leba non last night, and the new Israeli Chief of Staff warned today that further reprisals would follow if Palestinian guerrillas were allowed to use Lebanese territory for contin ued raids on Israel.

title: Bank Profit Drop Listed for Quarter By Manufacturers
description: The Manufacturers Han over Corporation reported yesterday declines in earn ings before securities trans actions for the fourth quarter and for the year ended Dec. 31, compared with results for the corresponding peri ods a year ago.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST CITES SLAIN POLICE
description: The 11 New York City police men who lost their lives last year while performing their duties were remembered by Mrs. Rose Zittwitz of this city as she contributed $10 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Accords With Market Set; Norway and Ireland to Join
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 14Norway and the European Common Market reached agreement to night on the problem of pro tecting Norwegian fisheries after Norway joins the Euro pean group. At the same time, Ireland accepted a quota that will be applied to its sugar pro ducers by the market.

title: Butz Expects Gain by Farmers And Smaller Food Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, asserted today that American farmers would have the third highest net income in their history this year while American consumers would pay only slightly higher prices for food.

title: U.S. Jet Apparently Destroys Missile Unit Just North of DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP)A United States jet fighterbomber attacked a mo bile enemymissile unit today only three miles north of the demilitarized zone, which straddles the border between the two Vietnams.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 14On this side of the Atlantic the affair of the Anderson papers evokes the usual bewilderment about American habits. How can a great country conduct foreign policy when the official apparatus is ignored and angry bureaucrats then make open war through the press?

title: Pros Set Mark, But Bow
description: TORONTO, Jan. 14 (UPI) Memphis scored a leaguerecord 52 points in the last quarter tonight, but the Indiana Pacers, led by George McGin nis's 31 points, amassed a suf ficient lead to defeat the Pros, 135120, at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: MRS. KING GAINS IN COAST TENNIS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (UPI)Mrs. Billie, Jean King, two surprising Australians and a Briton make up the field for tonight's semifinals in the $17, 000 British Motors tennis tournament at the Civic Audi torium.

title: GEORGE T. MINASIAN
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Jan. 14 George T. Minasian, a retired executive or the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and a leader in the air pollution control field, died Wednesday at his home, 104 Clark Street, alter a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Managing Editor Named
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 14 (AP) The appointment of Lee Can ning as managing editor of The Minneapolis Star was an nounced yesterday. Mr. Can ning, formerly assistant manag ing editor, replaced Robert C. King, named editor of the news paper earlier in the week. Glenn Speidel, news editor since 1969, was named assis tant managing editor.

title: Antiques: Clock Display Stresses European Forms
description: Clock collectors will be tempted to apply press agent superlatives to the ex hibition on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art under the properly intellec tual title Northern European Clocks in New York Collec tions.

title: RapidTransit Study Is Begun in Newark
description: Newark's Planning Depart ment has started exploring the feasibility of expanding the tiny rapidtransit system in Newark into the blighted heart of the city and redevel oping and revitalizing what ever route might be chosen for an extension.

title: U.N. Council Will Meet In Ethiopia Jan. 28Feb. 4
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14The Security Council has decided to hold a special session between Jan. 28 and Feb. 4 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

title: Striking British Miners Picket Power Stations
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) New moves by Britain's 280, 000 striking coal miners to day threatened fuel supplies to about 30 major power sta tions generating electricity for millions of homes in Lon don and southeast England.

title: MAURICE STOLLERMAN
description: Dr. Maurice Stollerman, a national representative of B'nai B'rith and a former superinten dent of Miriam Hospital and the Jewish Children's Home of Rhode Island, both in Provid ence, died yesterday of a heart attack here. He was 64 years old and lived at 222 Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although Natives of My Person starts as a standard sex and saber novela mysterious sailing ship fully provisioned creeps out to sea without the approval or even the knowledge of the reigning power it is not. And although I liked the book and enjoyed especially the felicity with which it was written, I'll concede that it is not a book for everyone's palate. It has something of the brooding quality of Benito Cereno, crossed with Captain Blood. It has room for inex haustible sword play, hand to hand encounters, and romance under soft West Indian skies. But all the drama is interior drama; the clash of wills replaces the clash (and even the sound) of and the savageries of an ocean voyage are reduced to the psychological burdens each man carries within him. It's almost as No Exit was being performed on a stage designed for Mutiny on the Bounty.

title: Murphy Reports Decrease of 6.2% In Serious Crime
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy reported yesterday that the number of serious crimes committed in the city in November was 6.2 per cent less than a year earlier and said he was optimistic that the crime rate was slowly being reduced.

title: Mechanical Failure Cuts Power in Most of Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 14(UPI) A mechanical failure at Tel Aviv's central power sta tion blacked out most of Is rael tonight for nearly two hours.

title: Music: A Counterpoint
description: Bruno Maderna, the out spoken Italian avantgardist, made his debut Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic, but his pro gram was anything but avantgarde. The only 20th tury work was Alban Berg's concert aria, Der Wein, and that was composed more than 40 years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: '71 WAS BIG YEAR FOR HORSE SHOWS
description: DENVER, Jan. 14The pres ident of the American Horse Shows Association said today that the organization had sanc tioned 959 events last year, the largest number in Its 55year history.

title: JOEYS BYRD WINS PACE AT WESTBURY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 14 Joeys Byrd registered his third straight victory of the season in taking the feature race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Record Corn Crop Listed for Year; Figures Revised
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Agriculture Department is sued today a revised report on 1971 crop production showing farmers last year harvested record corn crop of 5,540,253, 000 bushels, up 35 per cent from 1970.

title: State Court Prohibits Magazine From Publishing Hughes Data
description: A temporary order prohibit ing the Ladies Home Journal from printing alleged inter views with Howard R. Hughes in its February issue was ob tained in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday by Hughes interests.

title: Lacey Sparks Royals
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals, sparked by Nate Archibald's 43 points, won their third straight game tonight as they defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 126102, for their longest winning streak of the season. The Royals had lost 14 straight games before the winning streak.

title: TEAMSTER MERGER WITH I.L W.U. SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) A merger agreement has re portedly been reached by the teamsters and the West Coast longshoremen's union.

title: Her Wrap Dresses Resemble Kimono
description: Hiroko gave a little party to celebrate her first show room recently. All her friends came wearing their newest Hiroko dresses, just as if it were a big couture opening.

title: Ballet Shifts Premieres
description: The New York City Ballet has announced several changes in the dates of its premieres. Chopiniana will be give next Thursday in place of Water mill, Jerome Robbins's new ballet. Watermill will be given on Feb. 3.

title: A.E.C. to Build a Reactor Creating Power and Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The Atomic Energy Commission an nounced today plans for build ing the nation's first large fast breeder nuclear power plant as the first major step in a multi billiondollar program aimed at meeting American energy de mands well into the 21st cen tury.

title: Petrie Saves Blazers
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 14 (AP) Geoff Petrie hit a 16foot jump shot with two seconds left to night to give the Portland Trail Blazers a 102100 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: Text of Memo on IndianPakistan War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Following is the text of a memorandum on a meeting of a National Security Coun cil committee on Indian Pakistani hostilities, made public today by the columnist Jack Anderson:

title: Willard S. Irle, Specialist At Stock Exchange Here
description: Willard S. Irle, a member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1930 to 1965, who served as a specialist on the floor of the exchange during most, of his career, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Med ical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in the Delmonico Hotel.

title: NASHVILLE PAPER SOLD TO GANNETT
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 14  Pur chase of The Nashville Banner, a sixdayaweek afternoon daily, by the Gannett news paper chain was announced to day by Banner and Gannett ex ecutives.

title: Amex and OTC Up in Active Trading
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market yesterday resumed their recent upward trend as both lists gained in active trading.

title: Insurance Units Merge
description: Commercial Credit Company, a diversified financial concern, said yesterday that Farmers and Bankers Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary, had been merged into American Health and Life Insurance Corn pany, another subsidiary.

title: U.N. Names Relief Aide
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14Faruk N. Berkol, a Turkish career diplomat, has been ap pointed the United Nations first disaster relief coordinator. The post was created last month to enable a United Na tions official with rank of undersecretary general to as sist governments in cases of disaster. Mr. Berkol, who is 54 years old, has been serving as Turkey's Ambassador to Bel gium.

title: NEW ERA DAWNING IN FLORIDA RACING
description: MIAMI, Jan. 14  Whipping around this town's pelmlined expressways, a gambler can't go more than a few miles with out seeing an arrow pointing to a racetrack, a dog track or a jaialai fronton.

title: Schranz First in Austrian Downhill; Three Americans Finish in Top 10
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 14Karl Schranz, who it some times seems is as old as these hills, won another race today, but there was some other, more surprising maturity shown at the AlbergKandahar downhill race.

title: Virginia to Appeal on Schools
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 14 (AP) The State Board of Education voted today to appeal the Rich mondarea school consolidation order issued Monday by Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. in United States District Court. The board acted by a 6to4 vote after a meeting with the Virginia At torney General, Andrew P. Mil ler, who represents the state in the issue.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX OF PRICES SURGED DURING DECEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Wholesale prices resumed their rise as expected in December, the first full month after the freeze, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Quota on Traffic Tickets Is Assailed by P.B.A Head
description: The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association dis closed yesterday that a traffic ticket quota system had been established in a West Side pre cinct.

title: FLEET CABS SEEK TWOWAY RADIOS
description: The fleet taxicab industry plans to ask the city's permis sion to set up a twoway radio dispatching systema move it says would improve service to the public, particularly in resi dential areas.

title: STOCKS INCH UP ON A LATE RALLY
description: Glamours, golds and airline stocks moved higher yesterday in a drifting market that pro duced a mild rally in the final half hour. The DowJones in dustrial average edged up 1.50 points to 906.68.

title: British Leyland Motor
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Britain's biggest auto group, the British Leyland Motor Corpora tion, today reported better than expected profits.

title: 2 Held as Leaders of International Ring Counterfeiting $150 to $2,500 Watches
description: An international ring of counterfeiters specializing in the wholesale production of phony Omega watches so closely re sembling the $150 to $2,500 originals that even jewelers were deceived was disclosed yester day after two alleged leaders of the ring were arrested.

title: Women in H.E.W. Seek Higher Status
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14A group of women in the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare made more than 100 recommendations today for im proving the status of women both inside the department and in areas of national activity for which the department has re sponsibility.

title: Capital Punishment: No Deterrent
description: PRINCETON, N. J.An author was once said to be qualified as an expert on murder and capital punishment be cause he had talked with over one hundred murderers. I too have talked with over a hundred murderers. There fore, I submit that I too am an expert on murder and capital punishment.

title: Leaders of Coup Tighten Their Control on Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 14The army officers who took over this West African nation in a coup d'tat yesterday morning moved today to consolidate their con troal amid signs that the quick, clean takeover had been widely successful.

title: Murphy Denounces Civil Service
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy denounced the Civil Service system yesterday as a handcuff inhibiting the pro motion of strong leaders to the rank of captain and announced that he had instituted a six month probationary period for sergeants, lieutenants and cap tains.

title: 3 Types of Cancers in Humans Linked to Animal Cancer Virus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Chemical links between three types of human cancer and three viruses known to cause comparable types of cancer in animals have been found by a team of scientists at Colum bia University.

title: Notes on Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 When President Nixon looks to Congress for support of his legislative program he ob viously cannot count too much on the New Yorkers.

title: Brazil's Old College Try: 600,000 Fighting to Enter
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 14 All this week, in baking sta diums and sweltering audi toriums, 600,000 Brazilian students have been taking col lege entrance examinations to try to guarantee their chances for the good life. In all of the country's colleges there is room for only onethird of the appli cants.

title: Bucks Wallop Bulls
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 14 (AP) The shooting of Kareeml AbdulJabbar and a tough de fense helped the Milwaukee Bucks to a 10477 victory to night over their chief chal lengers, the Chicago Bulls.

title: Humphrey Charges Into Florida Drive
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 14  For a couple of days in this quiet corner of Florida this week it seemed that Hubert H. Humphrey, one of the 10 or more Democratic candidates in the March 14 Presidential pri mary, was everywhere.

title: O'Brien Says Vote for Wallace Is Vote for the Republican Ticket
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 14  Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, opened today a frontal assault on the Presidential candidacy of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, all but reading him out of the party.

title: SAVINGS RATE CUT TO 4% BY CITY BANK
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday it would cut by onehalf per cent to 4 per cent the rate it pays on regular savings accounts, ef fective Feb. 1.

title: A TV REPORTER SHOT IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14Ron Po rambo, a television reporter and author of a book about the 1967 race riots here, was shot and wounded in both thighs here early this morning.

title: Japanese Ship Carrying Oil Goes Aground Off Cape May
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., Jan. 14 (UPI)A Japanese freighter whose captain had died while the ship was at sea went aground today about 15 miles southeast of here, after the first mate tried to navigate the ship into the Delaware River, the Coast Guard said.

title: Keino Wins National Invitation Mile in Speedy 3:59.4
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 14Almost effortless, without serious speed or stamina work outs, Kipchoge Keino shattered 4 minutes in the mile for the first time indoors tonight.

title: Judy Schwomeyer And Sladky Hold Ice Dancing Lead
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 Judy Schwomeyer of Indian apolis and Jim Sladky of Sol vay, N.Y., moved steadily to ward their fifth straight gold dance title in the United States championship. But, unlike other probable figureskating cham pions, they will not compete in the Olympic Games.

title: Grayson Chides Officials For Talking of Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The chairman of the Price Commis sion, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., said today that speculation by high Government officials about an early end to economic con trols might be damaging to the entire stabilization effort.

title: Cougars Down Floridians
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan 14 (AP)Carolina won its second game in a row as Jim Mc Daniels, a rookie, scored 14 of his 30 points in the final period tonight to pull the Cougars away from a Floridians rally for a 10598 victory.

title: January, the Time of Fire
description: JANESVILLE, Wis,January is the valley of winter, a depression in the year when the northern earth lies dead, buried in the clammy grip of snow and ice.

title: The Violent Strain
description: A preliminary report of the Surgeon General's study of the effect on children of violence on television has predictably run into immediate controversy. The issue is understandably emotioncharged. Parents who see the blood and gore to which their children are so regularly exposed form their own strong views entirely inde pendent of any scientific studies.

title: Olmsted Will Be Honored Around Country
description: Frederick Law Olmsted, who turned 840 hideous acres of piggeries and goat runs, squatter's shacks and glacial grooves Into Central Park, will be honored this year as the nation's first major environmentalist and urban planner.

title: More Muskie Support
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination will be endorsed Monday by three United States Senators and by three leading Democrats in Ohio.

title: U.S. Reports Attache Was Beaten in Latvia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The State Department ac knowledged today that an Air Force officer, serving as an assistant air attach at the United States Embassy in Moscow, was beaten by a group of civilians at the Riga Airport in Latvia on Jan. 5.

title: A New Government Is Formed in Croatia; judiciary Is Purged
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 14 (Reuters)  The Yugoslav Re public of Croatia announced the formation of a new gov ernment tonight and a purge of the judiciary following charg es of counterrevolutionary ac tivity in the republic, the of ficial press agency Tanyug re ported.

title: CAVENHAM SEEKS A GROCERY CHAIN
description: Cavenham, Ltd., announced yesterday in London that it is making a ?? ($210, 375,000) takeover bid for Allied Suppliers, Ltd., a British wholesale and retail grocery chain with 1,700 stores.

title: Jacklin and Nicklaus Set Golf Pace by Shot at 140
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14Tony Jacklin of England drew even with Jack Nicklaus today with a 70 and a 36hole score of 140 in the Bing Crosby golf tourney.

title: 32YearOld Man Shot to Death In a Restaurant on 42d Street
description: A 32yearold man was shot and killed last night in a crowded restaurant on West 42d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakers Rally to Win
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers over came a 13point deficit in the second period tonight and went on to beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 135121.

title: Market Place: ExRep Reflects On Specialists
description: Justin E. Mamis is a 42 yearold owner of a coop on Riverside Drive, a published novelist, a solidly built form er minor league second base man, and an exregistered rep who once wrote a market advisory letter and now plans to publish one of his own.

title: U.S. TO INCREASE SUGAR SUPPLIES
description: In an attempt to slow the rise of rawsugar prices, the Agriculture Department or dered yesterday a 200,000ton expansion of its 1972 sugar marketing quota, to 11.8 mil lion tons.

title: Community Relations of Minority Police Discussed
description: A call for the restoration of a law requiring New York City policemen to live in the city was among five resolutions passed yesterday at the close of a threeday seminar on black and Puerto Rican policemen and minority communities.

title: German Symphony for King
description: BERLIN, Jan. 14A Sym phony dedicated to Dr. King was given its premiere per formance tonight in Dresden, East Germany, the East Ger man news agency ADN re ported. The work was per formed by the Dresden Sym phony Orchestra. Friedrich Schenker, 30 years old, of Leipzig composed the sym phony, which was his first publicly performed work, the news agency said.

title: State Warns Pharmacies To Comply on Price Posting
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP)The State Board of Pharmacy today instructed pharmacies to com ply with the Federal Price Corn mission's priceposting regula tions.

title: The Idea Is to Save the Housing That Is There
description: The bitter conflict stirred by the Forest Hills public housing project raises grave questions of public hous ing policy. The problem is epitomized by Percy Sutton's question: Where do black people and Puerto Rican people turn if they want to change their lives and not forever be restricted to the ghetto?

title: Naive Painting Shown at Modern Art
description: The latest in the Museum of Modern Art's inhouse ex hibitions, a series or eco nomically assembled shows or works owned by the mu seum, is Naive Painting From the Museum Colic lion,' a group of 30 canvases from the 100 or so it has in this charming genre.

title: CATHOLICS TO HEAR ANGLICAN PRIMATE
description: The Most Rev. Michael Ram sey, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, will preach at St. Patrick's Cathedral one week from tomorrow.

title: Sea Disposal Of Sewage Restrained
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14Fifteen Jersey shore communities were temporarily restrained today by a Federal judge from emptying their sewage sludgeholding tanks into the Atlantic Ocean. The annual flushing of the beachfront tanks had been scheduled to begin Monday.

title: Warriors Defeat Knicks For 8th in Row, 115111
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 14Pulling away in the second half when Nate Thurmond, their center, started hitting from outside and Jim Barnett and Jeff Mullins, their guards, started driving through, the Golden State War riors defeated the New York Knicks, 115111, before a crowd of 6,304 at the Sport Arena tonight.

title: Canada Inflow $76Million In Quarter on Securities
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 14 (Canadian Press)  There was a net in flow of $76million into Canada in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1971, in international trad ing in longterm portfolio secu rities, the Canadian statistics Bureau responded today. This was an increase from an inflow of $43million in the second quarter of 1971, and in sharp contrast to an outflow of $159 million in the third quarter of 1970.

title: ' Cisco Pike':Tale of Has-Been Rock Star Opens at Forum
description: It's gotten to the point that whenever a movie starts with long-shots of its hero walking down city streets, which are photographed through zoom lenses, accompanied by soft rock music on the soundtrack, it takes all the discipline I can muster to keep from immediately walking out of the theater into my own streets and into my own life. The banality of such mood footage is usually an absolutely accurate indication of the banality of the drama that is to follow.Such is the beginning of Bill L. Norton's first feature film, "Cisco Pike," the sad and solemn story of a has-been rock star (Kris Kristofferson) who is blackmailed by a crooked narcotics agent (Gene Hackman) into disposing of $10,000 worth of Acapulco gold in 53 hours.Although "Cisco Pike" is better than, say, "The Magic Garden of Stanley Sweetheart," "Getting Straight," "Making It" and a couple of dozen other movies that start in the same way, it's not really that much better and, like those movies, it finally boils down to the terrible fact that the fiction in the foreground is no match for the realism of the found objects in the background. If you're like me, you survive these films by reading the mesages that enter the eye peripherally, as street signs and billboards, as the data on gasoline pumps, and as neon invitations to eat and drink, to enjoy, to park, to wash, and, especially, to try. All life, as Robert Frost did not say, is an accumulation of tries.Which is not to say much about "Cisco Pike"because there isn't much to say about it except that Kristofferson seems to be a much more interesting rock performer than an actor, and that Karen Black, who plays his mistress, has become so familiar to movie audiences that it's now impossible to accept her as a dumb broad. She is too intelligent, and it shows. Viva, who was pregnant when the film was made, plays an eccentric Los Angeles character who is pregnant, with no huge amount of skill.Gene Hackman, who was named the best actor of 1971 by the New York film Critics for his role in "The French Connection," would probably be more effective as the ratty cop if the movie were good which it isn't. "Cisco Pike" opened at a number of theaters here yesterday on a double bill with "Machine Gun McCain," an Italian movie shot mostly in Los Angeles and Las Vegas, which also isn't much good, but at least it doesn't leave you with reading time on your hands.

title: Nyquist Overrules Local School Unit
description: State Education Commis sioner Ewald B. Nyquist, turning down an appeal brought by a decentralized New York City school board, ruled yesterday that substi tute teachers must be dis missed before probationary teachers with regular status are let go because of budget cuts.

title: Brooklyn: No Place For Minnesota Child
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 14A judge in Minneapolis has ruled that Brooklyn is not a desirable place for a child reared in Minnesota to grow up, even though the particu lar neighborhood proposed may be reasonably good.

title: Pentagon Papers Coverage Wins Award for The Times
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 The University of Arizona's John Peter Zenger Award for distinguished service to free dom of the press and the peo ple's right to know was pre sented to The New York Times tonight for its publication of the Pentagon papers last June.

title: Senator Buckley in Manila
description: MANILA, Jan. 14 (AP)Sen ator James L. Buckley, Conserv ativeRepublican of New York, arrived in Manila today on the first part of a tour of eight Asian nations. He will discuss with Asian leaders President Nixon's new China policy, as well as American defense and security arrangement in the re gions.

title: SETTLEMENT ACCORD IN TSAI CASE IS SET
description: Nine former shareholders of the Tsai Management and Re search Corporation, invest ment adviser to the Manhattan Fund, have agreed to pay $1 million in stock of the CNA Financial Corporation to the mutual fund in settlement of suits against the management company by six stockholders of the fund.

title: Executive Changes
description: Thomas G. Labrecque, 33 years old, has been promoted to senior vice president in the portifolio and investment banking department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A.

title: I.B.M. Increases Profits For 20th Consecutive Year
description: The International Business Machines Corporation in 1971 registered its 20th consecutive year of increased profits and its second consecutive year in which net income from over seas ?? earnings from the United States.

title: FRAZIERDANIELS JUST PRELIMINARY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14  Ten months and a week after clearing his title to the heavy weight championship of the world by whipping Muhammed Ali in one of the gaudiest pro motions ever, Joe Frazier returns to the ring tomorrow night to play second fiddle to a pair of football teams.

title: Study Doubts That Smoking Causes Smaller Babies
description: BERKELEY, Jan. 14  A mother's basic personality type, rather than the fact that she smokes cigarettes, may be re sponsible for the excessively high incidence of lowbirth weight babies born to mothers who smoke, a professor of bio statistics at the University of California has found.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS PLANNING LAYOFFS
description: NEW LONDON, Conn. Jan. 14 The General Dynamics Cor poration announced today a cutback in its publicaffairs staff in four major divisions and eight subsidiaries in the United States and Canada.

title: LongRunning Feud Erupts at Krupp
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Jan. 14A longrunning, behindthe scene feud between two top managers of the Krupp indus trial empire has finally erupted in the open with an announce ment by Gunter Vogelsang, the concern's managing director, that he will leave his one mil lion markayear post at the end of 1972.

title: Lebanese on Alert
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14 Premier Saeb Salam said that the Lebanese armed forces about 15,000 troops  were placed on the alert today fol lowing the warning to Lebanon by General Elazar.

title: Construction Work At Forest Hills Site Results in Flooding
description: Residents in the Forest Hills section of Queens had a new reason to be upset yesterday about a lowincome housing project being built in their mid dleincome area.

title: Minimum Wage in State Now Due Household Help
description: Effective today, 120,000 house hold workers in New York State come under a new mini mumwage law and must be paid at or above the state's hourly minimum of $1.85 $14.80 for an eighthour day or $74 for a 40hour week.

title: NEW B.B.C. SERIES DISSECTS EMPIRE
description: LONDON, Jan. 14The Brit ish Broadcasting Corporation has begun a 13part television series on the British Empire a halfproud, halfmocking look at Britain's imperial past  with high hopes that it will be as well received and as widely seen in the United States as its Civilisation and Forsyte Saga series.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Superior Court judge in Jersey City struck down North Bergen's rent control ordinance yesterday, declaring that only he State Legislature had the power to enact rentcontrol regulations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Raytheon Given Contracts
description: The Raytheon Company re ported yesterday receipts of three contracts totaling $71.3 million for production work on the improved Hawk airdefense missile system. The award, from the Army Missile Command Redstone Arsenal in Alabama, included $36.8million for im proved Hawk missiles, $31.2 million for groundsupport equipment and $3.3million for engineering services. The pro duction work will be performed at Raytheon's Andover, Mass., plant.

title: Singing and Playing By Buzzy Linhart Show Versatility
description: The singer  instrumentalist Buzzy Linhart, appearing at Folk City this week, does al most everything well. He sings the blues, he sings folk music, he scats jazz and plays the guitar, he pounds out drum solos and plays improvisations on the vibes. Multitalented is a good description, but the old enigma of the jackofalltrades keeps rearing its ugly head.

title: MUJIB RESENTFUL OF NIXON'S POLICY
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 14 Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of the Bengali regime that has taken over East Pakis tan, declared today that I have strong resentment against the American Government for its support of the Pakistanis against whom his people re belled.

title: A 'Kingdom in the Clouds' for Children
description: Xerox has done it again, importing a nice movie for children  a Hungarian-made live-action fairy tale called "Kingdom in the Clouds."Equipped with dubbed English, the picture played weekend matinees in Rockland County last week. Today and tomorrow it moves into numerous neighborhood showcases for early shows in Nassau, Suffolk, Queens and Brooklyn. Next weekend it blankets Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.The Xerox Corporation again is to be commended for conscientiously putting some decent entertainment for children onto movie screens that seem to be getting bluer and bluer. Some of these features for youngsters from abroad, where producers at least bother, are wooden, unimaginative duds, baited with the label of a familiar fairy tale. By the time they get here, with slapdash English dubbing, they arc fast-buck horrors. The kids should picket.The Xerox film unit has been carefully selective so far. The second import in its series last November, "The Magic of the Kite," was a charmer, made in Paris and Peking. So is this new one from Hungary  and where will Xerox shop next?On film, a live-action fantasy pitched to a young level can lumber like an uneasy elephant. This one moves at a simple, graceful clip as a noble youth of yore treks over the mountains to find a mythical kingdom of eternal life.By any standards, the picture is beautiful to look at, with lavish, exotic costumes and a stunning sweep of never-never land that blends deep, natural, panoramas and artistic interiors. The English dubbing is quite good, fortunately, as the handsome hero encounters such fairy-tale staples as a beautiful princess, a talking horse, a slimy, green-tinted witch and his arch-enemy, the Prince of Liars.The pace gets a little stiff and starchy inside the ornate palace, where royalty glides around like molasses. But the middle third clatters like a slam-bang Western, including some fighting that small boys should relish. No gushing blood here. Parents can relax.The musical score is lovely and lyrical on cue, and ripely thumping when it should be, with the horse-bound hero streaking away like good old Hopalong. Finally, the tale ends with a sensible, earthy twist that all ages might ponder: reality beats dreamland.Adults should enjoy this exotic eyeful, too. But let's rejoice that Xerox has stretched a hand overseas to the Budapest Film Studios and picked itself a plum for the children. This is their hour and a half.

title: December Margin Debt Up
description: Aggregate debt in margin accounts held by member firms of the New York Stock Ex change increased by a record $490million in December to $5.4billion due mainly to a reduction Dec. 6 in the Federal Reserve Board's margin require ments from 65 to 55 per cent, the exchange reported. The number of margin accounts in creased by 25,000 during the month to 675,000.

title: Neighbors Back Writer of Hughes Book
description: IBIZA, Spain, Jan. 14What ever Howard Hughesor the voice that speaks for him on the telephonemay say, Clif ford Irving's friends here have no doubt that his interviews with the billionaire were genu ine.

title: Oil Gelled to Cut Spillage From Tankers
description: Patents of the Week

title: Lottery Tickets Recycled
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14 (AP)The New Jersey Lottery Commission said today that, unsold lottery tickets were being recycled and used for building construction fiberboard. The tickets are sent to the Homasote Company of Trenton and ground into paper pulp for refabricating.

title: The Laos Danger
description: The seesaw war in Laos has annually brought a winter dryseason advance by the Communist forces toward the Governmentheld Mekong Valley along the Thailand border. Later, under pressure from American air power and airsupplied Lao and Meo ground troops, the Communists usually have pulled back again to shorter lines of supply in the rainy season, when mud and washouts have made a morass of ground routes. This scenario has repeated itself with minor variations virtually every year.

title: SQUIRES TOP NETS 4TH STRAIGHT TIME
description: HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 14 Charlie Scott and Julius Erving, a pair of New Yorkers, led the Virginia Squires to a 114104 victory over the Nets in an American Basketball Associa tion game tonight, snapping the Nets threegame winning streak.

title: Pennsy Would Drop Some Leased Lines
description: Trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company rec ommended yesterday in a re port to the United States Dis trict Court in Philadelphia that some of its leased lines be con tinued and others be disaf firmed, while decisions for some others be postponed.

title: East Germany Eases Czechoslovakia Visits
description: BERLIN, Jan. 14  East Germany opened its borders for unrestricted travel to neighboring Czechoslovakia today in a move designed to restore freedom of movement between those two East bloc countries.

title: Graebner Reaches Final
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 14 (Reuters)Jim Connors of Bellville, Ill., playing his first tournament as a professional, advanced to the final of the Jacksonville indoor tennis event by defeating Jaimie Fillol of Chile, 75, 75.

title: JUDGE IN BAY STATE RESIGNS UNDER FIRE
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14judge Ed ward J. DeSaulnier Jr., denying that he was guilty of accepting a bribe, resigned today from the Massachusetts Superior Court.

title: W. H. Grimes, ExWall St. Journal Editor, Dies
description: William H. Grimes, a former editor of The Wall Street Jour nal who won a Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing in 1946, died yesterday of respiratory failure at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. Mr. Grimes, who re tired in 1961, was 79 years old.

title: Mrs. King Visits 2,000 Inmates on Rikers Island
description: In a program honoring the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his widow, Mrs. Coretta King, told inmates of the Adoles cent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island yesterday:

title: Welcome to Miss Furtseva
description: Last Wednesday proved a black day for the Soviet and American image makers who are trying to improve Moscow's public relations stance here. Soviet Culture Minister Yelcaterina A. Furtseva, the highest ranking Soviet woman, was to hold a Washington press conference In connection with a Soviet art exhibition and to be the guest of honor at a State Department luncheon.

title: Denmark's New Queen, A Linguist and Athlete
description: Even in infancy, Princess Margrethe was a special source of pride and an object of affection in Denmark. Her birth a week after the Nazi Invasion in 1940 lifted hopes at home, and her early outings with her mother, Queen Ingrid, became a symbol of faith in the coun try and the royal family during the occupation.

title: Notes on People
description: Edward Bennett Williams, the trial lawyer who has de fended several major figures, including James R. Hoffa, will represent Judge Otto Kerner in his trial on charges of income tax evasion, con spiracy, mail fraud, bribery and perjury.

title: Congress, Returning, Tuesday, Faces a Heavy, Complex Workload
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The 92d Congress returns Tuesday for an electionyear session, facing an immediate backlog of controversial business as it struggles anew with the under lying, persistent problems of re viving a domestic economy and readjusting a postwar foreign policy.

title: Sled Heat Won in Bitter Cold
description: ELY, Minn., Jan. 15 (AP) Dick Moulton of Center Harbor, N. H., took a 30 second lead today after the first heat in the allAmerican championship sled dog races run in tempertures dipping to 30 degrees below zero.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Shell's Move Two Years and $35Million Later
description: HOUSTON  When Gilda Coleman returned from her recent Christmas vacation trip to New York, she brought with her a dozen loaves of Italian bread to store in her freezer. Italian bread isn't easily come by here any more than are the cozy Italian and French res taurants and swinging singles bars in which Gotham abounds.

title: The Diary of Anas Nin
description: Anas Nin is one of the most extraordinary and unconven tional writers of this century. Her vast diary, which encom passes some 50 years of human relationships, resembles no other in the history of letters, and as a novelist she has been distinctly catalytic. With her direct knowledge of the me chanics of psychoanalysis, she conveyed the even flow of un censored speech in a series of prose writings which constitute one continuous novel. Collected under the title, Cities of the Interior, these writings in fic tion are so detached from his torical epoch, and the topog raphy of her inner spaces so remote from the naturalistic landscapes of her fellow novel ists of the 1940's and 1950's that they might well have been left untouched as a legacy for future generations, had not the publication of her diaries, be ginning in 1966, brought her into full public view, earned her a sizable American audi ence, and a particularly remark able popularity with younger readers.

title: Study Finds Editorials Stress the Environment
description: A survey of 20,904 edi torial in five leading Ameri can newspapers over a 12 month period shows that the environment was the major domestic issue of editorial concern.

title: Art
description: TEN years ago the Sid ney Janis Gallery mounted an exhibition called New Realists, which effectively launched the Pop Art movement on the New York art market. Now the same gallery has organ ized another large show, this one called SharpFocus Real ism, in yet another attempt to blitz the art market and make history. The first of these events was, as all the world knows, a howling suc cess. It was also, as so many successes are nowadays, a very great disaster. Not since the Pyrrhic victories of the PreRaphaelites in Victorian England had the taste and standards of the professional art world been so radically debased. For a sizable portion of the art public, the whole notion of artistic seriousness was alteredaltered down wards, it must be said, to a level where an insidious fa cetiousness and frivolity could pass muster as an atti tude of high endeavor.

title: Nassau's OTB Should Be Out of Starting Gate Soon
description: MINEOLA, L. I,  The Nassau County Board of Su pervisors is expected to ap prove tomorrow a system of offtrack wagering proposed by County Executive Ralph G. Caso.

title: Reader's Report
description: If you can't get down South this winter, here's a ray of in stant sunshine, compounded by a veteran sunshine specialist. Put yourself in the heart of the Cadell country, a storybook English landscape abounding in crotchety characters and eter nal verities. Here, among the hedgerows and horseflesh, headstrong Stacey Marsh is go ing to marry Mr. Right. But who will it be? Jules Charbonniere, her sophisticated French fianc? Or Nigel Quest, the gentleman farmer who raises horses on adjoining acreage? (No two men could be more unlikeone fair, conventional, citybred; the other dark, complex, a country man.)

title: They Like to Find Fault With Their Bosses
description: They're fashion models, but outside of Seventh Avenue few people know their faces, let alone their names.

title: What Code of Values Can We Teach Our Children Now?
description: AMERICAN children today are suffering from widespread par ent failure. By their words and actions, many fathers and mothers make it clear that they are almost paralyzed by uncertainty. Old standards of behavior no longer seem to apply. Parents find it hard to know what to expect of their off spring. Many of them are in conflict as to what their own values are. Others think they know but lack the confidence to impose discipline in behalf of their values. Worst of all are those parents who doubt whether they have the right to structure a child's attitudes, beliefs and conduct.

title: Pro Bidder Captures Second Straight Stakes at Bowie and Returns $8.40
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 15Dee and Gee Stables' Pro Bidder, a $4,000 yearling purchase for Grover G. (Buddy) Delp of Laurel, Md., won his second consecutive stakes victory at Bowie race course today, cap turing the $29,650 Bowie Handi cap.

title: MRS. ALBERT SMILEY
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Jan. 15 Mrs. Mabel Craven Smiley, wi dow of Albert K. Smiley, an owner of the Mohonk Mountain House on Lake Mohonk, died yesterday in the New Paltz Nursing Home. Her age was 88.

title: Israel Honors Einstein
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 15 (Reut ers)A portrait of Albert Ein stein appears on one of two new Israeli banknotes that went into circulation this week, and the other note bears a portrait of the state's first President, Dr. Chaim Weizman.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: NEW ORLEANSToday's football game in this Mardi Gras city is expected to attract more than 50,000 visitors who will contribute some $10million to the local economy.

title: BIG CRAFT SCARCE IN FLEET OF 1,300
description: PARIS, Jan. 15The Salon International de la Navigation de Plaisancewhich translates loosely from the French into boat showopened to the public here today.

title: Philip N. Youtz Is Dead at 76; Museum Director and Inventor
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif., Jan. 15Philip N. Youtz, former di rector of the Brooklyn Museum, died here Wednesday at the age of 76.

title: Police Report They Know Slayer in Colombo Case
description: The police know who killed Jerome A. Johnson, the man who they say shot Joseph A. Colombo Sr. last June, accord ing to Chief of Detectives Al bert A. Seedman.

title: 76ers Defeat Pistons
description: DETROIT, Jan. 15 (AP)  Bob Rule scored 25 points to night to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 131121 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LISBON, Jan. 15 (AP)A Lisbon court sentenced four men to prison today after con victing them of belonging to the Portuguese Communist party. The party is illegal in Portugal.

title: COMMERCE AGENCY CITES STATE GAINS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15  Despite the continuing recession and an unemployment rate that had averaged 5.7 per cent, the State Department of Commerce re ported this week that it had generated an estimated $20.3 million in new tax revenues for the state through promotion of travel industrial development, international commerce and job incentive programs.

title: KENT STATE STUDY SCORES MICHENER
description: KENT, Ohio, Jan 15A Kent State University professor has accused James A. Michener, the novelist, of making numerous errors in his book about the slaying of four Kent State stu dents by National Guardsmen.

title: Italy's Government Quits, Will Stay as Caretaker
description: ROME, Jan. 15The Govern ment of Premier Emilio Colom bo resigned today because of strains within the centerleft coalition on which it was based.

title: Bangladesh Picks Its Anthem: My Golden Bengal by Tagore
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  The newly pro claimed state of Bangladesh has adopted as its anthem a patri otic song by the Nobel Prize poet Rabindranath Tagore. The sung is titled Amar Sonar Bengal (My Golden Bengal).

title: Richard Hunnewell Marries Mrs. Julie Desloge Haggerty
description: Mrs. Julie Desloge Hag gerty of Locust Valley, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard Farns worth Hunnewell of New York and Locust Valley. The ceremony was performed in St. James' Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. John B. Coburn, the rector, assisted by the Rev. G. O'Neill, a Jesuit priest.

title: Laird Captures Walk
description: LONDON, Jan. 15 (UPI)Ron Laird of the New York Athletic Club scored a decisive victory today in the metropolitan po lice sevenmile road walking race with a time of 50 minutes 11 seconds at East Moseley, Surrey.

title: MANHATTAN TOPS ARMY TRACKMEN
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 15 Manhattan made its first dual meet of the indoor track season a winning one today as the Jaspers defeated Army, 6850.

title: New Orleans' Role as Super Host Is a Big Act
JUROR WASTAGE TO BE DISCUSSED
description: Armed with statistics show ing that well over a million dollars was paid in the last fiscal year to prospective jurors who never saw the inside of a courtroom, the ranking Federal judges here have just sum moned every Federal district judge in Manhattan and Brook lyn to a daylong workshop on the subject of juror wastage.

title: Six Dodgers Sign for '72
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers have announced their first con tract signings of 1972, six players including Claude Os teen, Tommy John and Pete Richert, lefthanded pitchers. Also signed were, Tim Johnson, Lee Lacy and Dave Lopes, in fielders.

title: The Nation
description: Alexander Innis, the 16yearold son of CORE director Roy Innis, got caught up in the law of the blackboard jungle last week.

title: Television
description: IT'S another of those smoldering desiresyou know, like the one where the great tragedian finally groans and lets it all hang out: What I've really wanted all along is to make people laugh! Well, what Jack Lemmon really wants, you see, is to be able to sit down at the piano and play for the world numbers like Love Walked In, Lady Be Good and I've Got a Crush on Youall by George Gershwin, of course. Lemmon re sponds to Gershwin tunes the way rock fans roar for Grand Funk Railroad.

title: George A. Round, 82, Dies; An Automotive Engineer
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 15George A. Round, chief automotive engineer with the SoconyVacuum Oil Company (now the Mobil Oil Corporation) from 1939 to 1954, and later a consultant, died today at the Todd Nursing Home. He was 82 years old and lived in North Haven.

title: The World
description: Representative James H. Scheuer of the Bronx is known on Capitol Hill as a hard, sometimes abrasive worker whose energetic pur suit of issues he supports occasionally has led him in to brushes with authorities. So it was not a complete surprise last week when he tangled with Soviet officials.

title: Metreveli Gains Final
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 15 (AP)Alex Metreveli, the So viet Union champion, easily beat Patrice Dominguez of France, 61, 63, today to ad vance to the final of the Tas manian open tennis champion ships.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Art Notes
description: IT was the kind of holiday present no one really needs. Shortly before Christmas (Dec. 23), John Hightower, director of the Museum of Modern Art, was told by board chairman David Rockefeller that he should vacate the $50,000 a year post, and scarcely had the New Year's bells stopped pealing (Jan. 5, to be precise), when the board's executive committee asked Hightower for his resignation. Still, at that, he'd outstayed by near ly a year his predecessor, Bates Lowry, dismissed by the same board in 1969 after a tenure of less than 10 months.

title: The Resumption of Publication By Newark News Being Pressed
description: NEWARK, Jan. 15  Critical negotiations are scheduled here next week in an attempt to re solve the remaining problems that have delayed resumption of publication of The Evening News here.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISSoviet Foreign policy was singularly successful during 1971. In the Middle East it reaffirmed a strong position that might have been weak ened by Nasser's death and the sub sequent Egyptian power struggle.

title: Ted Shawn 18911972
description: THE death of Ted Shawn shortly after his 80th birthday brings to an end a whole era in American dance. Shawn, to gether with his wife, the late Ruth St. Denis, was largely responsible for the creation of American moderndance.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: If you're watching a game show, an Oscar telecast, a commercial promoting a con test or a sweepstakes on NBCTV, rest assured that Jack D. Samuels or one of his air marshals is lurking behind the scenes somewhere.

title: Ford, Franklin Help Purdue Pin 8574 Loss on Illinois
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 15 (AP)Bob Ford and Bill Frank lin combined for 49 points and sparked a secondhalf rally today that enabled Purdue to beat Illinois, 85.74, in a Big Ten basketball game.

title: Eating His Way Onto the Olympic Team
description: Cottage cheese, yogurt or diet colas are not likely to be found in the refrigerator of Mike McDermott's home in Yonkers. Despite his 6 foot2inch, 270pound frame, McDermott, New York Uni versity's premier track and field weight man, wants to gain 30 more pounds by June.

title: Trials Sought in East
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  Bengali intellec tuals today launched a cam paign for signatures in support of a demand that commanders of the Pakistani Army in the East he brought to trial for war crimes.

title: Jersey Link Eases Plight Of Drivers
description: PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 15 Completion of a 0.7mile piece of Interstate Route 80 is easing auto commuting be tween the George Washington Bridge and northwestern New Jersey suburbs.

title: Georgia A. Toomey Is Engaged to Wed
description: GOLDSBORO, N. C., Jan. 15  Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Ralph Toomey have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Georgia Ann Toomey, to Richard Jeff rey Wieler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Newman Wieler of Manhasset, L. I. The wed ding is planned for April in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church here.

title: List, $5.60, Triumphant In Super Bowl Handicap
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (AP) List took the inside rail on the final turn today and won the $20,000 Super Bowl Handi cap at the New Orleans Fair Grounds by 3 lengths.

title: Huge Atom Smasher Sought on L.I.
description: UPTON, L. I. Within four months, Brookhaven Na tional Laboratories intends to ask for $55million to build the world's largest atom smasher, a 100,000billion electronvolt monster that would be nearly 70 times larger than the most power ful now in operation.

title: Mintoff Cheered on Return
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Thousands of cheer ing, chanting Maltese gave Prime Minister Mintoff a hero's welcome when he returned to night.

title: Campaign Opened
description: The oldline businessmen of West 57th Street are mounting a campaign against what they regard as the in cipient debauch of their fash ionable shopping area.

title: Public Hearings Slated By Albany Committees
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15Follow ing are public hearings sched uled for the near future by committees of the Senate and and the Assembly:

title: Criminals At Large
description: Dorothy Sayers was many things besides a writer of detective fiction. She was a medievalist, a Latinist, a trans lator of Dante, a poet, a stu dent of Christianity. Probably she would have preferred to be remembered for those ef forts. Just as Sir Arthur Sul livan was somewhat ashamed of the Savoy operettas and wanted to be remembered for his grand opera, Ivanhoe. Or just as Sir Isaac Newton would gladly have surrendered all of his mathematics to prove the existence of God. But it is as the creator of Lord Peter Wimsey that Miss Sayers will be cherished. Her stories featur ing that amiable, snobbish, rich, hedonistic and alarmingly in telligent peer have entertained millions since they first started coming out in 1923. Sayers wrote about a dozen Wimsey novels, and he also appeared in three collections of short stories.

title: Mrs. Rees Weds Otis T. Bradley, A Stockbroker
description: Mrs. Robin Adair Rees, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mason Rees of Rye, N. Y., was married at the Colony Club here yesterday to Otis T. Bradley, a senior vice president and director of Spencer Trask & Co., Inc., stockbrokers. The Rev. Nor man Stanton of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony in the presence of members of the immediate families.

title: Dave Anderson
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15  He speaks quietly, knowingly, as if he were a pro fessor. And he speaks precisely, the way he runs pass patterns.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 62
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (AP) Pete Mahovlich, Claude Larose and Jacques Lamaire contrib uted two goals each as the Montreal Canadians defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 62, tonight.

title: Not Quite Roughing It on the Gold Coast
description: My husband and I were awakened by gunshots close to our home on a recent Sunday morning. We were not surprised. We hear shots every weekend and are cautious about taking a walk any dis tance from the house.

title: Traffic, Housing Headaches of Munich Olympics
description: German officials reported this weekend that everything was on schedule for the sum mer Olympic Games in Munichincluding the head aches of tickets, traffic and housing.

title: The Peaceable Kingdom
description: Jan de Hartog, who has set sail in many fields, is now journeying into the windy seas of historical fiction. He has decked out his novel with tra ditional furnishings, com fortable settings, and some times lavish accommodations of narrative. The skill of the skipper at the helm of this novel is a marvel (and a mixed blessing) to observe, for the long journey he provides is a moving story without ever the upset of intellectual urgency. The Peaceable King dom is the first of two vol umes recreating the great experiment of Quaker life. This volume is set in England in 165253 and Pennsylvania in 175555.

title: Kurds Fighting in Iraq
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 15 (AP)  Kurdish rebels clashed with Iraqi Government troops in the last two days, and 36 troops and 10 Kurdish guerril las were killed, reports reach ing here said today.

title: Toyota Gets Chinese Order
description: TOKYO, Jan. 15 (Reuters) Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest auto manufacturer, has announced an export order from China for 50 Jeep?? van trucks.

title: The Nation
description: BATON ROUGE, La.On they came in a ragged phalanx, their black shoes drumming on the rainlacquered street, kicking rubble and refuse from their path. On they marched, orange slickers whipped by the wind, weapons held firmly across the chest, plastic face shields blunting their features into anonymity beneath the helmets.

title: Rockets Halt Cavaliers
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Calvin Murphy got 7 of Hous ton's last 9 points tonight, breaking a 103103 tie and sparking the Rockets to a 112109 victory over the Cleve land Cavaliers.

title: Canucks Top Seals, 43
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Jan. 15 (AP)The Van couver Canucks forged a two goal lead early in the third pe riod and then held on to edge the California Golden Seals, 43, tonight.

title: The Truman Doctrine and The Origins of McCarthyism
description: Those who lose in the ballot box or on the battlefield carry their case to the court of history. It is an ancient and honorable form of appeal which has enlivened the writing of history for centuries. In the United States today, the revulsion against the Vietnam war and against some of the wider military and political involvements of this country around the world has produced an audience for revisionist historical studies which argue the case for old minority viewpoints.

title: NAVY'S RALLY DOWNS AIR FORCE, 55 TO 53
description: ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 15 (AP) Gary Carter sank two free throws with 26 seconds to play today to give Navy a 5553 vic tory over Air Force.

title: Legislators Laud Cumberland Hospital
description: Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn received a passing grade yesterday from two legis lators who have been investi gating and consistently criticiz ing the municipal hospitals.

title: DELAY SUGGESTED ON PENSION BILLS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15  A new state pension commission urged today that Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature take no action on a jam of controversial public pension bills until the commissioners were able to scrutinize each measure for its longrange effect on the tax payers.

title: Follmer Joins Wood's Racing LineUp
description: George Follmer, one of the most versatile drivers in American racing, has signed up with Roy Wood's Ameri can Racing Associates to compete in the entire nine race schedule of the $500,000 L.&M. Continental 5000 Championship. An unusual aspect of the campaign is that A.R.A. elect ed to buy its car, a RepcoMatich, in Australia rath er than shop for one in Europe or build one in this country.

title: Meeting Planned On Environment
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.A workshop on the state's plan to conform to the Federal Clean Air Act of 1970 will be held Thursday by the Long Island Environmental Council.

title: Bridge
description: BRIDGE experts as a group can hardly be said to belong to the swinging generation, but all of them swing from time to time. Swinging, whether in life or bridge, consists of eccentric and extravagant con duct calculated to surprise and dis turb those whose course is firmly set in routine and traditional paths.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWhether or not the Indochinese war becomes a major issue between the Republicans and Demo crats next fall, one thing is obvious: Vietnam will almost certainly play a major role in the Democrats' struggle for their party's nomination.

title: Uniform Traffic Controls
description: The automobile has long ceased to be a mere local conveyance and has instead become the major vehicle of Interstate and crosscontinental traffic. It is therefore essential to move as rapidly as possible toward national regulations aimed at protecting both drivers themselves and the walking and riding public in general.

title: Gardens
description: AWEE bit more sunshine now and a yearning for spring set the right mood for some flowers. One of the simplest bulbs to flower indoors is the tender tazetta narcissus commonly called paperwhite, shown at left. Bulbs are inexpensive. To grow them, obtain a shallow bowl that will hold pebbles and about five bulbs. Set the bulbs with the bottoms sup ported in the pebbles leav ing the top two thirds ex posed. Fill the bowl with enough water to touch the bottom of the bulbs and set it in a closet for about a week until roots form. Check every few days to be sure there is sufficient water. Then bring the bowl into the sunshine.

title: Chess
description: THE annual world junior cham pionship tournament, won this year by the 19yearold Swiss player Werner Hug, is an event that always attracts worldwide atten tion. Its winners are potentially future grandmasters, and even world cham pions. In fact, current world champion Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union was once the junior champion, as were grandmasters Boris Ivkov and Bruno Parma of Yugoslavia, Father William Lombardy of the U.S., Anatoll Karpov of the U.S. S. R., Oscar Panno of Argentina and Florian Gheorghiu of Roumania.

title: Book Review
description: SUPER. BOWL. By Marty Ral bovsky. 208 pages. Associated FeaturesHawthorn Books, Inc. $7.95.

title: Miss Alicia Zintl Is Betrothed
description: WILMINGTON, Del. Jan. 5Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Kiley McCune of Wilmington have announced the engagement of Mrs. McCune's daughter, Miss Alicia Zintl of Boston and Wilmington, to Edwin Larson Russell of New York. He is the son of. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Fortune Russell of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Miss Kathleen Louise Joyce Bride
description: ANDOVER, N. Y., Jan. 15  Miss Kathleen Louise Joyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Joyce, and George Francis Biondo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Biondo of Ossining and Mon tauk Point, L. I., were married today in the Blessed Sacra ment Roman Catholic Church here by the Rev. Joseph S. Fiori.

title: List of Potential Challengers for America's Cup Is Reduced to Three Nations
description: Three countries remain in the running as potenatial challen gers to the United States for the America's Cup series in 1974. The Royal Thames Yacht Club of Britain, the official chal longer, will contest that right with Australia and France, with all trials being conducted off Newport, R.I.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LONDON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Scotland Yard warned Conserv ative members of Parliament today to be on guard against bombs in the mail and set up security checks on mail and parcels sent to the House of Commons and Government ministers.

title: Mrs. Behrens Has Son
description: A son was horn to Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Behrens of New York on Dec. 30 at the LyingIn Hospital in Boston. Mrs. Behrens is the former Miss Katherine Marcus of Scranton, Pa., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Marcus of Santa Barbara, Calif. The child, the couple's second son, is named Jack Louis. His father is cofounder of Insti tutional Networks Corpora tion (Instinct), computerized securities trading system.

title: Mansfield to Oppose Nixon On Space Shuttle Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Senator Mike Mansfield, Dem ocrat of Montana, the majority leader, signaled a major elec tionyear fight over the $5.5 billion space shuttle program in Congress by announcing to day that he would oppose it as a misplacing of priorities.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Goodrich, Lakers' Other Guard, Is an AllStar, Too
description: When the starting West team is introduced Tuesday night at the 22d National Basketball Association East West AllStar game at the Forum in Los Angeles, Laker fans will save their cheers for their own Jerry West and Gail Goodrich. It will be one of the few times in All Star game history that back court men from the same team have been named as starters.

title: The Winter Birds
description: Any winter is a difficult time for birds, but they make no complaint. When we have to spend a few hours out side on a zero day we put on sweaters, extra socks, outer coat, muffler, cap, mittens and boots. But the birds that feed in the dooryard merely fluff their feathers and welcome all the nutritious food they can find. And most of them survive unless a sleet storm locks away their food and coats their feathers.

title: Miss Bethanne L'Hommedieu Betrothed
description: SYOSSET, L.I. Jan. 15 Mrs. Roy R. Stewart of Syosset and Harvey H. L'Hommedieu of Pelham Manor, N.Y have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bethanne L'Hommedieu, to Richard Duffy of Oyster Bay, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ber nard J. Duffy of Locust Val ley. A June wedding is planned.

title: Hindu Refugees Back in Dacca Find Themselves Without Homes or the Means of Earning a Living
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 15 Hari Pada Nag held his hands on his head and looked at the charred wall of his house. He had just come back from a refugee camp in India, where he had fled in March with his wief and three daughters.

title: TOP E.C.A.C. COACHES, PLAYERS TO BE CITED
description: The three players who were named 1971 players of the year in their divisions by the Eastern College Athletic Conference and the two coaches named Eastern coach of the year in the univer sity and college divisions by the Football Writers Association of New York will be honored to morrow at a reception at the New York University Club, 123 West 43d Street, beginning at 5 P.M.

title: Auto Makers Backed On PollutionAct Plea
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 15A Congressional ef fort to modify portions of the Clean Air Act of 1970 took root yesterday at a Western White House conference after the automobile industry warned that it could not meet the Government's unrealis tic standards for reducing exhaust emissions.

title: NIXONSATO TALKS DISAPPOINT JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Jan. 15The meet ing between President Nixon and Premier Eisaku Sato has disappointed many shades of Japanese opinion with its limited results.

title: 11 U.S. Track Stars Are in Olympic Limbo
description: A professional track and field tour that never left the start ing blocks has threatened the Olympic eligibility of 11 United States athletes, including such goldmedal prospects as Lee Evans, Jay Silvester, Norman Tate, George Woods and Dave Smith.

title: Mrs. Eva Sanderson Child, Aide at Friendship House
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 15Mrs. Eva Sanderson Child, who served as executive secre tary of the former Friendship House in New York, an Ameri canization and assimilation center for refugees of World War II, died Thursday in the Memorial Center for Women. Her age was 76.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Temperatures Plummet, Bringing a Bit of Snow
description: Temperatures in the metro politan area plunged last night to the lowest level of the winter, the National Weather Service reported, bringing a few snow flurries in the city and chilling gusts of up to 33 miles an hour.

title: VIRGINIA SUFFERS FIRST LOSS, 8579
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 15 (AP)  Thirdranked North Carolina outscored previously unbeaten Virginia, 194, over a sevenminute span late in the second half today and downed the Cavaliers, 8579, in a battle of Atlantic Coast Conference basketball powers.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reader's Report
description: Robert Beylen's admirable misadventure novel returns to a limbo of history: early 1941 in North Africa. Names like Gen eral Wavell and Marshal Grazi ani are part of a background that is as heavy with atmos phere as dust in a sandstorm. And in the foreground, three archetypes of war fiction race through a classic chase at maximum velocity.

title: Resignation Requested
description: A man of even feeble sensibility who had been found guilty on eight counts of bribery, conspiracy and perjury might be expected to resign from the Congress of the United States without waiting to be asked. One who long considered himself a guardian of the capital city's morals as member of the District of Columbia committee might be expected to do a quick and quiet vanishing act. But Representative John Dowdy of Texas does not plan to quit until he has exhausted all appeals.

title: Alan Delsman Weds Barbara Edwards
description: Miss Barbara Lynn Ed wards, daughter of Comdr. Richard T. Edwards, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Edwards of Freeport and Greenport, L. I., was married yesterday after noon to Alan Mark Delsman in the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights by the Rev. Donald McKinney.

title: The Winter Of Man
