description: PHILADELPHIA  We fear, re marked an Eskimo shaman respond ing to a religious question from the explorer Knud Rasmussen some fifty years ago. We fear the cold and the things we do not understand. But most of all we fear the doings of the heedless ones among ourselves.

title: Maine G.O.P. Aides Concerned About Mrs. Smith's Senate Seat
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 15  There is a growing concern, among Pepuhlicans here that their last hold on national of fice, the Senate seat of Mar garet Chase Smith, is in jeop ardy this year.

title: Even the Elevator Has a Chandelier
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L. I.Cecil B. DeMille would have loved it. Set in a wood ed area on several acres of land, the Huntington Town House could be mistaken from the outside for a glorified country club with its curving driveways and coachlighted, canopied entryways.

title: Uranium: Bad Times
description: The uranium industry has more than its share of prob lems these days.

title: These Mothers of Families Take Law School in Their Stride
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  If it weren't for reliable baby sitters and understanding husbands, Hofstra Uni versity's Law School would lose half of its women stu dents and two of its three women professors.

title: Paula Youngs Plans Nuptials
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 15The engagement of Miss Paula Youngs to Rich ard Weir 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weir Jr. of Locust Val ley, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Youngs, parents of the bridetobe.

title: Students Clash on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 15 (AP)  High school students for and against the Cypriote President, Archbishop Makari os, clashed in several towns on this island today during demon strations for enosis, or union with Greece.

title: Siege Reported Broken
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 15 (UPI)Laotian reinforcements flown into Long Tieng this week have broken out of the beleaguered military complex and retaken the Skyline Ridge two miles to the north, in formed military sources said today.

title: Boat Show Will Open NineDay Run on Saturday
description: The booming billiondollar pleasure boating industry will stage the first major introduc tion of its 1972 products at the National Boat Show, that be gins here next Saturday. The $5million display of boats, en gins and accessories will con tinue through Jan. 30.

title: The Nation
description: Ma Bell, Go to Hell, chanted more than a thousand angry telephone work ers as they went on a rampage through midtown Manhattan last Wednesday. After leaving a noontime rally outside Governor Rockefeller's 55th Street of fice, they snarled traffic, engaged in scuffles with policeduring which six persons were injured and eight ar restedand overturned and smashed telephone company equipment.

title: New York
description: A reporter who covered the New Jersey Government confided once how hs stayed ahead of his competitors. I subscribe to the Albany paper, he said. You can bet on itanything they do up there turns up in Trenton a year or two later.

title: State Study Deplores System of Justice
description: The Joint Legislative Com mittee on Crime told Gover nor Rockefeller yesterday that a fourth of all inmates in the state prisons believed with rea son that they were victims of a mindless, undirected and corrupt system of criminal justice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW DELAY HINTED FOR ANGELA DAVIS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 The possibility arose today of another delay in the murder kidnapping trial of Angela Davis, which is scheduled to start in two weeks.

title: Fight Tickets Tomorrow
description: Tickets for the heavyweight fight between Floyd Patterson and Oscar Bonavena at Madi son Square Garden on Feb. 11 will go on sale tomorrow at 10 A.M. Tickets may be purchased either at the Garden or through all Ticketron outlets. They are scaled at $30, $20, $15, $10 and $8.

title: Real Cleveland Indian Assails Club Symbol
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 (AP) Russell C. Means, director of the Cleveland American Indian Center, said today the symbol used by the Cleveland Indians was racist, degrad ing and demeaning to the American Indian and that he would file a lawsuit to halt use of the symbol.

title: Television
description: WE'LL get back to Erich and Bella later, folks, but now I want you all to meet a great guy who's just got to be one of the world's greatest ex perts on the primitive tribes of the Philippines. Six months ago the only life he knew was in the rain forests of Mindanao; now, thanks to the miracles of modern technol ogy, he's here on our TV stage tonight. Folks, I'd like you to say hello to Ogg, the Stone Age man. [Applause]

title: D. HAROLD OLIVER
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)D. Harold Oliver, former White House reporter and political writer for The As sociated Press, died at his home here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Savannah Is Stationed At Home Port in New Role
description: SAVANNAH. Ga., Jan. 15 The N. S. Savannah, the world's first nuclearpow ered Merchant vessel, was turned over to her home port city today to become a public attraction.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. Jan. 15 A junior guard, Bob Sherwin, scored a career high of 34 points in leading Army to an 8771 victory over Scranton here tonight.

title: Miss Ihnken Engaged
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Jan. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Milken have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Barbara Jean Ihn ken, to Robert Edwin Ahl schlager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Henry Ahlschlager of Huntington. The wedding is planned for Aug. 19 in St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor. Both Miss Ihnken and her fianc attended the University of Rhode Island. She is a junior at the University of Massa chusetts, where her fianc is doing graduate work at the School of Business Adminis tration.

title: Recruiting Military for Industry
description: Just as military recruiters attempt to convince young men to enter the service, a growing number of corporate recruiters are luring them with job offers when their service days end.

title: Straight from Marrakesh
description: When Paula Wolfert's husband was working for the United Nations in Morocco, she was working, tooaccumulating a repertoire of Arabian recipes. One of the most unusual dishes she learned to make in Marrakesh is bastila. A typically spicy concoction, it's chicken with onions and garlic, spices that range from ginger to saffron, lemon juice, almonds and eggs all layered and wrapped in thin pastry and dusted with cinnamon and sugar. Moroccans make it in a tobsil, a copper and tin pan, over a charcoal fire. And they tear it apart and eat it with their fingers. Americans can make it in a layercake pan and use a knife and forkif they insist.

title: Miss Judith Moynahan Affianced
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 15The engagement of Miss Judith Merrill Moynahan, a 1971 graduate of Springfield (Mass.) College, to William Andrew Dado, who expects to be graduated from Spring field this June, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Moynahan of Riverside.

title: DebtRidden Chile Is Reported to Get Soviet Offer of $50Million in Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Sen ior officials said here today that the Soviet Union had offered Chile $50million in credits within the last three weeks. They were unable to give de tails about the unpublicized of fer, which was reportedly made indirectly through Sovietcon trolled European banks.

title: Wald of Harvard in Peking
description: TOKYO, Jan. 15 (AP)Dr. George Wald, professor of bi ology at Harvard since 1935, arrived in Peking today at the invitation of the Chinese People's Association for Friend ship with Foreign Countries, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported. Mr. Wald, 65 years old, shared in the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1967.

title: Tax Parley Called Feb. 6
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Citizens' protest groups from every state have been asked to join in a National Election Year Conference on Taxes to be held here Feb. 6. Howard Bahem, president of the United Taxpayers of America, said Thursday that leaders of 348 citizens groups had been in vited.

title: Child to the Schoenfelds
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Schoen feld of Brooklyn on Dec. 30 in the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: George Gee, Hockey Player On Black Hawks, Red Wings
description: WYANDOTTE, Mich., Jan. 15 (UPI)  George Gee, a former player with the Chicago Black Hawks and Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, collapsed and died last night while participating in a Red Wings oldtimers's game. He lived in suburban Detroit.

title: FOOTBALL ON TV IN A MINOR KEY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (AP)The Miami Dolphins and Dallas Cowboys will be play ing for top prize of $15,000 each in tomorrow's Super Bowl. But tomorrow will also offer an opportunity to see guys who play for $150 a game and a $5 bonus for getting the quarterback.

title: Country Inns: A Quiet Revival
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.  It's a funny thing said the Berkshire Travel ler, a jovial, bearded fellow. Now that we are preparing to leave the 20th century, people seem to want to hold on to the 19th.

title: Priscilla Ann Griffiths Affianced
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 15Dr. Daniel E. Griffiths, dean of the New York Uni versity School of Education, and Mrs. Griffiths have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Ann Griffiths, to William Bailey Russel. He is the son of Mrs. William Steward Russel Jr. of Houston and the late Mr. Russel.

title: Six Nations Agree to Reduce 1972 Tuna Catch in Pacific
description: TOKYO, Jan. 15 (AP)Six nations of the InterAmerican Tropical Tuna Commission have agreed to an overall catch quota of 120,000 short tons of yellowfin tuna in the eastern Pacific for 1972, com mission officials said yesterday.

title: Overseas Air Fares Due to Rise by 7% Under Devaluation
description: GENEVA, Jan. 15  Interna tional air fares calculated in dollars will be raised as much as 7 per cent as a result of last month's realignment of world currencies, the International Air Transport Association an nounced today.

title: Bob Griese, left, and Don Shula
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15The rival coaches in the Super Bowl, Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys and Don Shula of the Miami Dolphins, are also capital ists with that rare quality of their vo cation, security. Both have stock inter ests in the teams they coach and it would be difficult to imagine them ever being discharged for failure to win.

title: Lew Williams Driving For a First
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15Black athletes have achieved fame in many sports, but comparatively few fans are besieging Donald Norman, Boysie Mitchell, Marion Tolson and other Negro reinsmen with re quests for their autographs.

title: San Diego Fears Hard Stand by G.O.P. on Protests
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 15City officials here are concerned that the Nixon Administration will not be tolerant enough, of radical demonstrators at the Republican National Convention next August.

title: Anniversaries Births Engagements Marriages
description: Anniversaries Births Engagements Marriages

title: The Nation
description: The confrontation took place at Kennedy International Airport Wednes day night. Eyeball to eyeball, Soviet and American officials debated the question: Should Merab Kurashvili, a 36yearold Soviet civil engineer, be interviewed in the airport office of the Immigration and Naturalization Serv ices or in the Pan American first class lounge?

title: Iran Ousts Kuwait in Soccer
description: ATHENS, Jan. 15 (AP)Iran beat Kuwait, 20, today in an Olympic Games soccor elimin ation round and qualified to play South Korea. The first half was scoreless.

title: Master Plan Is Assailed At Meeting In Brooklyn
description: Hundreds of Williamsburg and Greenpoint residents cheered denunciations of the city's master plan for their area at a planning commis sion hearing last week.

title: STANLEY HELLER
description: Stanley Heller, senior partner in Stanley Heller & Co., stock brokers, died yesterday at his home, 26 East 63d Street. He was 78 years old.

title: Charlotte Is Awarded 2d Minor League Nine
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 15 (AP)  A baseball first was achieved yesterday when Charlotte gained a second minor league team. The Class A Western Carolinas League accepted the Charlotte Twins.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies
description: SHE'S Pandora Gold, from the Bronx. She's got a Jewish mother who's hung up on astrology instead of MahJongg, and a father whose, taste for babes doesn't run to his own he likes 'em stacked. While her mother predicts theatrical stardom for her dar ling, Panda spends her childhood study ing Rita Hayworth movies and, at 19, embarks on a string of love affairs with men who use her up and spit her out. There's a Chinese (his wife is a political prisoner, so they mustn't trouble her about anything petty, like divorce), a homosexual (he has a guy moving in as Panda's moving out'Take care of him, she charges the new arrival), an English man who tells her he's got a cold in his head when what he's really got is two popsies in his bed.

title: Van Nostrand Gains Final
description: BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 8 King Van Nostrand of Bright waters, L.I., the topseeded player, advanced to the final of the Suffolk County indoor tennis championship today by defeating Dirk Dugan of Ham burg, N.Y., 65, 63, at the Bay Way Tennis Club.

title: U.S. Orthodox Rabbis Planning Pastoral Work in Israel to Promote Religious Relevance in Daily Life
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 15An in fluential organization of Ameri can Orthodox rabbis, concerned about the apparent decline in prestige and effectiveness of Israeli religious authorities, is preparing programs of techni cal assistance aimed at en hancing the Jewish religion in Israel.

title: MORTON ACTS TO END COYOTE POISONINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, says that he will soon send Congress leg islation that would end his de partment's controversial pro gram of killing predator ani mals  particularly coyotes  by widespread use of poison.

title: The Victory Of Vittorio De Sica
description: WE were all guilty, says Vittorio De Sica, som berly recalling the days of Mussolini and the systematic murder of Italian Jews. That period was the blackest page in the history of mankind. Yet, today in Italy there are many fascists young people who do not believe what it was like then. And, unfortunately, there are many old people who have forgotten. That is why I felt I must make The Garden of the FinziContinisas an act of atonement and as a warning.

title: Profit Hazard
description: The cigarette industry has yet another problem that is bothering it, almost as much as its longtime dilemma re sulting from the health and smoking controversy that be gan in 1964, when the Sur geon General's report linked cigarette smoking with can cer.

title: Gen. John W. Persons, 72; Was 32 Years in Air Force
description: ELGIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Jan. 15Maj. Gen. John W. Persons, U.S.A.F., died in a military hospital here yester day. He was 72 years old.

title: Washington Panel Adopts Plan to Disperse LowCost Housing in Suburbs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 A fairshare plan to disperse federally subsidized lowcost housing throughout the sub urbs, reversing the pattern of concentration in the District of Columbia, was adopted this week with the blessing of Fed eral housing officials.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Will high unem ployment defeat Richard Nixon at the polls this year? A number of Demo cratic politicians are reasonably con vinced that the answer is yes. But now that the full report on the job situation for 1971 is at hand, and the consensus forecast for 1972 is fairly well established, an objective analysis can be made.

title: PLAYING OF DIXIE BACKED BY COURT
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15  The song Dixie was described this week by the United States Court of Appeals here as one of the most frolicking of our national songs, known and loved throughout the world, rather than a badge of slavery.

title: JOHNSON TAKES DENVER BOWLING
description: DENVER, Jan. 15 (AP)Don Johnson of Akron, Ohio, notched the 19th championship of his career today when he defeated Johnny Petraglia of Brooklyn, 218213 in the final of the $50,000 Denver open bowling tournament.

title: Critiques of two critics
description: John Aldridge is so impeccably well mannered a critic, so cool of intelli gence, so level of gaze, so in com mand of his business, that only a procacious and finicky reviewer could say that he is less than a very distinguished writer indeed.

title: EDUCATION TRUST IS PROPOSED HERE
description: A plan for a health educa tion trustin which a student could get his professional school training free but then be re quired to make an annual pay ment into a binding trust to finance his profession's schools has been circulated by the acting chief administrator of the State University's College of Optometry.

title: YOUTH OF ARIZONA WOOED BY LINDSAY
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Jan. 15 Mayor Lindsay of New York urged the youth of the nation today to put aside any bitter ness or frustration they might harbor because of the Vietnam war or domestic problems and play a full role in the political process.

title: Charge Against 9 Blacks In Baton Rouge Called False
description: BATON ROUGE, La, Jan. 15 (UPI)The attorney for one of nine Negroes charged with murder in connection with a gun battle Monday in which four persons were killed said today that the charges against the men had been fabricated.

title: Misses Lynn, Holmes, Murray Picked for U.S. Figure Skating Team
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 15 After winning her fourth straight senior women's title last night, Janet Lynn of Rock ford, Ill., arrived at the Long Beach Arena early this morn ing. She was not there for more training but to watch the senior men compete in school figures, perhaps sympathizing with them now that she is through with that phase for this competition.

title: Margrethe Proclaimed Queen of Denmark in Brief Ceremony at Palace
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Princess Margrethe, 31 years old, was proclaimed Denmark's sov ereign today as Premier Jens Otto Krag declared from a palace balcony: Frederik the Ninth is deadLong live Queen Margrethe the Sec ond!

title: MISS GOULD SETS BRITISH RECORD
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 (AP) Shane Gould of Aus tralia shattered the British Commonwealth record tonight and came within ninetenths of a second of the world record in a women's 200meter indi vidual swim medley.

title: Facts on Super Bowl Contest
description: Title at StakeWorld profes sional football championship.

title: Clement Moore 2d Weds Miss Yinkey
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 15 St. Catherine of Siena Ro man Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Eliza beth Woods Yinkey to Cle ment Clarke Moore 2d. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William D. Thomp son, assisted by the Rev. Carl D. Reimers. A recep tion was held at Meadow lands in Darien.

title: Soo Locks May Extend Season Beyond Jan. 31
description: SAULT SAINTE MARIE, Mich., Jan. 15 (AP)The Winter Navigation Board, composed of 11 Federal agencies, concluded a three day field observation this week amid indications that this year's navigation season might extend beyond the scheduled closing on Jan. 31.

title: INSURANCE COUNCIL APPOINTED BY STATE
description: Seven members were named last week to a Consumers Ad visory Council that will help the New York State Insurance De partment evaluate the state's insurance rating law passed in 1969.

title: Cities and States Mark Dr. King's 43d Birthday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was observed in scattered cities across the nation yes terday with commemorative speeches and gatherings, The Associated Press reported.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Tennessee Judge Seeks To Overrule Busing Order
description: CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 15 (AP)A state judge has sought to overrule a Federal judge by ordering the city to step spend ing money to carry out a deseg regation busing order of the Federal District Court.

title: Books:
description: THE REGULATED CON SUMER. By Mary Bennett Peterson. Nash Publishing, Los Angeles. 271 pages. $7.95.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Track Meet Starts Friday
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 15 (AP) The Seventh Annual N.A.I.A. March of Dimes indoor track and field championships will be held in the Kansas City Munic ipal Auditorium Friday and Saturday.

title: Nixon Cites Blood Donors
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) President Nixon, taking note this week of January as Na tional Volunteer Blood Donor Month, praised those who gave and urged other to follow their inspiring example. In a state ment to the American Associa tion of Blood Banks, he said: Theirs is an offering for which there is no substitute, and which annually helps restore to good health countless fellow citizens.

title: St. John's Routs SophomoreStudded St. Francis, 11255, as Cluess Stars
description: St. John's concluded the first half of its basketball season on the cheerful note of a record 11255 victory over longtime neighbor and rival St. Francis last night.

title: Lynn Nightingale Wins Title In Canadian Junior Skating
description: LONDON, Ontario, Jan. 15 (UPI) Lynn Nightingale of Ottawa staged a brilliant free skating performance today to win the Canadian Junior Wom en's skating crown.

title: Books:
description: JANE'S MAJOR COMPA NIES OF EUROPE. Seventh Edition. McGrawHill. $30.

title: In Step With Art On the Sidewalks Of Portugal
description: THE Portuguese not only keep their sidewalks scrubbed but embellish them to please the eye. This tradition, which dates at least to Roman times, survives because Portugal retains a large pool of skilled craftsmen and a native love of decorative detail.

title: PssstHere Come the Superspies
description: WORLD WAR II is back and Leo Kerz has got it. The producer of such distinguished theatrical ventures as Rhinoceros and ?? has decided to make his movie production debut with The Game of the Foxes, based on the book by Ladislas Farago which created a ma jor controversy in Europe and is being published here by David McKay. As you've probably heard, the story is a true onebased on British records and captured Nazi documentsabout Eng lish intelligence agents who misled the German High Command into thinking the Allies would invade through Bel gium rather than Normandy. Kerz is now working on a ?? with Farago, who also wrote Patton, and he expects to start filming in England and Germany in February.

title: British Abortions Double
description: LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP)The number of legal abortions in Britain almost doubled in the past year to 140,000. At least one pregnancy in seven in Eng land and Wales ends in abor tion, official data show.

title: China's Leaders Welcome Delegates Returning From U.N.
Lots of fanciful animals and lots of youthful problems
description: In Jose Aruego's picture  book world carabaos dance whimsically with tails held like the trains of ladies' gowns, while turtles balance on their horns. Aruego's jungles are inhabited by purple elephants and brownnosed lions, prancing with snakes, butterflies, owls and alliga tors in fields of yellow and orange flowers.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon's commitment to use his appointive powers to set the Supreme Court on the path of strict construction has already borne fruit in a surprising areathe interpre tation of the securities laws. The Court's startling decision in an insider trading case raises the possibility that the justices may be headed in a direction Mr. Nixon never foresaw on issues quite unre lated to crime in the streets.

title: Inability to Stem Drug Traffic In Panama Vexes U.S. Officials
description: PANAMA, Tan. 13It could be hidden almost anywhere in the rope locker of a rusty freighter, in the attach case of a seemingly respectable diplo mat, in the uniform of an air line stewardess.

title: Miss Nkomo Wed to Dr. Edwin Moyo
description: United Nations representa tives and civil rights leaders were among the many per sons who filled the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family for the marriage here yesterday of Miss Regina Nkomo to Dr. Edwin Moyo.

title: COLUMBIA DOWNS CORNELL BY 8774
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 15  Spearheaded by a tight zone de fense and the scoring of Foley Jones and Dan Kelly, Columbia overwhelmed Cornell, 8774, to night at Barton Hall.

title: Miss Miranda Has Nuptials
description: STOWE, Vt., Jan. 15Miss Georgiana O. Miranda of Montpelier, an assistant At torney General for Vermont, was married here this after noon to William Bruce Bjorn lund, of East Montpelier, Deputy State Commissioner of Personnel.

title: Muskie Raises $150,000, A Record, at Maine Dinner
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 15 Nearly 700 supporters of United States Senator Edmund S. Mus kie turned out here last night for a dinner that raised about $150,000 for his Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: Bicentennial Commercialism Scored
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15 Dismayed by what they called rampant commercialism, rep resentatives from New York and New Jersey threatened to day to secede from the Bicen tennial Council of the 13 Origi nal States unless the group tightened its policy of en dorsing commercial products.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Prize Is Not Prized
description: Stuart Silk won an unusual automobile in a raffle drawing recently. Marsteller Incorpo rated, an advertising agency, decided to celebrate its 20th anniversary by giving away a 1951 Frazer to commemorate the year the agency opened its doors. Mr. Silk's comment on seeing the car was, It's the ugliest thing I ever saw!

title: Humphrey Plans to Enter 8 Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey announced today that he would enter Presidential primaries in eight states: Florida, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Nebraska, Maryland, New Jersey and Cali fornia.

title: Rae Downes Bride Of Charles Koshetz
description: Miss Rae Elizabeth Downes and Charles S. Koshetz, re porters for The Jersey Jour nal in Jersey City, were mar ried here yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel by Rabbi Eugene J. Sack of Brooklyn.

title: Courses and Lectures
description: THE annual program of the Horticultural So ciety of New York Inc. lists lectures, courses and flower shows for the year. Copies of it may be obtained from the headquarters, 128 West 58th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019. The society is a nonprofit educational organ ization supported by contri butions, membership dues and the New York State Council on the Arts. Member ship is open to anyone in terested in gardening.

title: MASTER'S THESIS GIVER AS CONCERT
description: A master's degree thesis is an unlikely item to encounter at a concert, but the Manhattan School of Music Orchestra pre sented one in its Friday night program in Borden Auditorium. It was Joel I. Brickman's Thou sands of Days, which not only helped the composer to get his degree but also won a school composition contest.

title: Bruhn  A Great Dancer Retires
description: ERIK BRUHN was a dancer of pure pas sion. He danced like a man possessed, but a man possessed by Apollo rather than Dionysus. When a great dancer retires, some thing of dance itself dies. Bruhn, who announced his retirement earlier this month, was the greatest male clas sical dancer of his time. He was the perfect stylist and the perfect prince. Over the quarter century or so of his careerhe is now 43 years oldhe has been associated with many companies and has had successes all over the world.

title: U.A.W. UNIT OPPOSES BACKING MUSKIE NOW
description: DETOIT, Jan. 15The exec utive board of the United Auto Workers rejected yesterday an effort to grant an early en dorsement to Senator Edmund S. Muskie for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Reader's Report
description: In this safari through the game preserves of Kruger National Park, the visiting predators ex hibit greater savagery than the resident hyenas, baboons, croc odiles and other carnivores. Meanest of the tourists on this sixday jaunt is a slip of a girl named Vicky Lehman, a mas seuse in private life. Vicky has eyes for an older woman's lover, a strapping, guitarplay ing lout named Dan Readeand on the road to Bulawayo and Ladysmith, she has a chance to do her damndest.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Now Just a minute, Hubert Humphrey:

title: Music
description: ROME.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: QUITO, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Three American tuna boats were seized today for fishing within the 200mile territorial limits. The Defense Minister, Luis Robles Plaza, identified the boats as the Armstrong, the city of Lisbon and the Puritan, all based in California.

title: K.G.B. Said to Raid Homes in Moscow Of Eight Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (AP) Reliable sources said today that the secret police had raided the homes of eight Mos cow dissidents, including the son of a prominent victim of a Stalin purge.

title: Alfred E. McMillan, 71, Executive of Carl Byoir
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15  Alfred E. McMillan, who was executive vice presi dent of Carl Byoir & Associates, New Yorkbased international publicrelations concern, at his retirement in 1968, died today of a heart attack in St. Mary's Hospital. He was 71 years old and had lived here since his retirement. He formerly made his home in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Lebanese Troops Told to Resist Any Attack by Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 Premier Saeb Saiam said today that orders had been issued to Lebanon's armed forces to fight off any Israeli attack against his country.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Stamps
description: LOCKED away in the vaults of the United Nations Postal Ad ministration are some 2,500,000 95cent postage stamps, hopefully replicas of the 95cent stamp that went on sale at the United Nations on Jan. 5.

title: Horse Show News
description: DENVER, Jan. 15  The West neither begins nor ends here, but if they're not care ful, it might someday start close to the Pacific Ocean.

title: Italy's Mineral Water Is Given Low Marks
description: ROME, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Itallians by the millions scorn local water supplies and use expensive bottled water be cause they believe it is more healthful. Or they did, until this week.

title: Coins
description: THE first Crown coin since decimalization has been struck for Gibraltar by the Royal Mint and was released sev eral days ago, it was an nounced by Spink & Son, Ltd., of London, the com pany appointed as world agent for distribution of this issue.

title: Arbitration Is Proposed In Jewish Centers' Strike
description: Negotiators in a dispute in ?? workers at some 20 Jewish community centers in the city agreed yesterday to submit outstanding issues to binding arbitration.

title: U.C.L.A. WALLOPS CALIFORNIA, 8243
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 (UPI) Bill Walton scored 20 points and grabbed 21 rebounds today to lear No. 1ranked University of California, Los Angeles, to an 8243 romp over California in a Pacific Eight basketball game.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Duck Farewell
description: Pitch pines moaned and tossed the black night and rain rattled against the win dows of my bedroom when I awakened at 3 A.M. on the last day of the sea duck hunting season in Massachu setts.

title: Medals Mark Okinawa Shift
description: TOKYO, Jan. 15 (AP)A de partment store has started sell ing medals of 51 per cent silver and 49 per cent gold to com memorate the forthcoming transfer of Okinawa from United States to Japanese rule.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: San Antonio, Tex.Johnny Mor eno, 124 pounds, San Antonio, out pointed Juan Cantu, 120, Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, 10 rounds; Tony Moreno, 115, San Antonio, knocked out Arturo Vasquez, 113, Monterrey, Mexico, 2.

title: Scramble Expected Among Aspirants for Brooklyn Seat on School Board
description: Even if the State Legisla ture extends the life of the current Board of Education for another yearas now ap pears likelyBrooklyn will need a new representative on the city board, and the selec tion of the new member is likely to set in motion a scramble among aspirants to the important post.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Robert M. Gardiner, presi dent of Reynolds Securities, Inc., was seated at his lunch eon club in Wall Street the other day when an acquaint ance approached and said:

title: Seaton Hall Defeats Iona
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 16 Frank Zelesnik and Ken House led Seton Hall to a 6761 victory over Iona tonight. Zeles nik led both teams with 25 points. Jim Riches was high for Iona with 16.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: TROY, N. Y., Jan. 15 (AP) Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute outscored Providence, 75, to night as the Engineers extended their winning streak to five games.

title: Janet Visconti Plans Nuptials
description: LONGMEADOW, Mass., Jan. 15Miss Janet Kathryn Vis conti and Thomas A. Caputo of New York have made plans to be married June 25 in Longmeadow. The future bride is director of the Multi Handicapped Services at the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind in the Bronx, New York, where her fiance is director of athletics.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: SOME INSIDER TRADING penalties can be avoided if the stock is sold in two separate transactions, the Su preme Court ruled. The 4.3 decision turned on a narrow reading of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and repre sented a reversal of a longterm trend of court opinions on the matter of insider trading. However, an attempt to overturn the decision through legislation seemed prob able.  The S.E.C. put into effect a new rule changing the standards and procedures under which restricted stock may be sold. The Supreme Court let stand court opinions that investmentcompany officials who profit from private, inside deals in securities handled by their concerns are punishable under a previously untested 30yearold law.  Two directors of the Bush Foundation of St. Paul sued 10 other directors for $39.75million, accusing them of stock manipulations and conflicts of interest in violation of Federal regulations.

title: ARMY WINS ON GOAL WITH 0:26 LEFT, 76
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 15 Jeff Woloshyn, a freshman center, fired a low 17foot slap shot into the net with 26 seconds to play tonight to give Army's hockey team a 76 vic tory over American Interna tional College.

title: Council Weighs Disclosure of City Contract Terms
description: Claiming that city labor con tracts often contain expensive hidden clauses that may not come to light until months after the agreements are reached, City Councilmen are preparing legislation to require prompt total disclosure of terms.

title: PRINCETON VOTES TO REVIVE R.O.T.C.
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 15 The Princeton University board of trustees, which 18 months ago voted to sever the school's ties with the Reserve Officer Training Corps program as of June, 1972, voted today to permit military training to remain on campus as an extra curricular activity.

title: Two Ships Crash Off Odessa
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 15 (UPI)A Soviet cargo vessel and a Bulgarian tanker collided in dense fog off the Soviet port of Odessa Thursday and nine men aboard the Bulgarian ship were lost, Bulgaria's official news agency reported today. No details were given of cas ualties aboard the Soviet ship.

title: FOUR KNOCKDOWNS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15  Terry Daniels will have to look elsewhere for the money to buy the New York Giants. For the better part of three minutes to night, the young man who used to play football for Southern Methodist clung to the notion that he could win the heavy weight championship of the world and thus earn enough swag to become an owner in the National Football League.

title: Some Typical Country Inns
description: Like everything else, some inns are better than others, and some are no good at all. While Norman T. Simpson, the Berkshire Trav eller, declines to name favorites (My favorite country inn is the one I'm in at the moment), he cites a number about which he has received compliments. Following are some of them, with Simpson's comments:

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: P.S.C. Is Pessimistic on Plans To Raise Power Output in State
description: The Public Service Commis sion said yesterday that, despite Consolidated Edison's asser tions to the contrary, it was highly unlikely that the com pany's new Indian Point nu clearpower plant would be ready by next summer.

title: After TitoWho Can Keep Together The Serbs, Croats, Slovenes, Macedonians, Bosnian Moslems, Albanians, Hungarians and Montenegrins?
description: BELGRADE.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The future form of public school financing in the United States may be the im mediate question raised by recent decisions of the courts but the underlying implica tions of the judicial decisions bring into question as well the constitutionality of all functions of local govern ment dependent for financing on the property tax resources of taxing districts of unequal wealth.

title: A Tree Falls, but Who Hears?
description: Several weeks ago, the Pres idential Commission on Fi nancial Structure and Regu lation gave the White House its blueprint for a sweeping overhaul of the na tion's money markets to meet the needs of the sev enties and eighties.

title: The World
description: The Bay of Bengal has not seen the last of the American aircraft carrier Enterprise. She may have returned last week to the Philippine Sea. And no doubt many of the 20 or so Soviet warships presently in the Indian Ocean will soon be on their way to some shore leave in Vladivostok.

title: The Nation
description: Nineteenyearold Abraham H. Treff was chatting with friends at his home in Philadelphia last November when Ralph Nader's name came up. The question: Could just anybody play the role of consumer advocate?

title: Music
description: MARILYN HORNE is 38 years old today, and she is two years ahead of herself. In a 1970 in terview, she said, When I'm 40, I'll go into Wagner roles I'll start with Sieglinde. Well, on Wednes day night at Carnegie Hall, she will sing Sieglinde in a concert version of the first act of Die Walkre, with William Steinberg and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra.

title: Fellow Student Weds Susan Jane McDonald
description: BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Jan. 15  Miss Susan Jane McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Mc Donald of Armonk, was mar ried here this afternoon to Lemuel Skidmore 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Skidmore Jr. of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Thomas H. 1lugart performed the ceremony in the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: 30  Year Sentence Strongly Criticized By vanden Heuvel
description: William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, yesterday de nounced a 30year prison sen tence handed down by a Bronx judge on Friday to a 23year old narcotics addict convicted of selling oneseventythird of an ounce of heroin last summer to undercover police agents.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: In the Swim With Dolphins
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15Shortly before the Miami football players checked into their Super Bowl hotel last Sunday, a phone call came from a dilatory reporter who had missed them at the airport.

title: 2 Boys Relay Teams Set Meet Marks; 2 Others Foul Out
description: Doug Terry, Boys High School coach, had his first team in the 880yard relay disquali fied at the second annual Dr. Martin Luther King schoolboy track meet yesterday because the team passed the baton out of the exchange zone.

title: THE GREAT MONEY GAME
description: THE Great Money Game, a wick edly simple $3.6billion hunt for prophetic verities devised by the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been under way almost two years. For Wall Street it has been an extended moment of truth: the first major search for answers to the curiously neglected question, Who Really Knows?

title: Egypt Expects to Reorient the Home Front for War
description: CAIRO, Jan. 15The priority tasks of the new Cabinet ex pected to be named here in the next day or two will be to reorient the Egyptian economy toward more production and less consumption, to curb mid dleclass privileges and to re verse an erosion of respect for authority.

title: Southern Intellectuals' Parley Scorns North as Guide
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 14if a gathering here this week was any indication, Southern intel lectuals have almost abandoned the North as a fit model for imitation in any field, from human rights to the building of cities.

title: SOLDIERS ATTACKED BY MOBS IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 15 (UPI)British soldiers were attacked by women and youths in Belfast today when they raided suspected hideouts of the outlawed Irish Republi can Army and arrested 22 men.

title: COLONELS SUBDUE CONDORS, 123115
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 15 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels pulled away in the third quar ter and went on to defeat the Pittsburgh Condors, 123115, tonight in an American Basket ball Association game.

title: Princess Edward de Lobkowicz Wed to John GrisYold, Broker
description: In the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Princess Edward Joseph de Lobkowicz, the former Anita Lihme of Chicago, was married to John C. Griswold, a senior vice president and a director of Eastman Dillon, Union Se curities & Co., Inc., invest ment bankers and brokers.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS A 197273 BUDGET TO HOLD THE LINE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15Governor Rockefeller will send to the Legislature tomorrow a hold theline, nogrowth budget of $7.9billion for the 197273 fis cal year.

title: Lots of fanciful animals and lots of youthful problems
description: THEN AGAIN, MAYBE I WON'T. By Judy Blume. (Bradbury, $4.95.) Whether she is writing about fe male or male sexual awakening, and whatever other adolescent problems, Judy Blume is on target. Her under standing of young people is sympa thetic and psychologically sound; her skill engages the reader in human drama without ever resorting to melo drama. Then Again, Maybe I Won't is the story of 13yearold Tony Migli one's adjustments to his own growing sexuality and to the difficulties of being a member of an upwardly mo bile family. Tony would have had his sexual problems (what does a boy do when he becomes sexually excited while doing a math problem on the blackboard?) even if the Miglione family had remained in Jer sey City.

title: HERDER FIRM SOLD TO M'GRAWHILL
description: The New York publishing house of Herder and Herder has been sold to McGrawHill Rook Company for an undis closed amount by its German parent company, Verlag Herder, of Freiburg.

title: Photography
description: REGISTRATION is now going on at the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street New York, N.Y. 10010, for a wide range of evening photograph courses that will be offered during the Spring term which begins on Jan. 31. Varying from a number of different courses in Basic Photography, through courses on SelfDis covery in Photography, Photo Graphics and Beyond the Ba sics, the curriculum also in cludes courses on marketing, creativity in photography, and classes which explore the es thetic aspects of the medium. Tuition ranges from $100 to $125 for each course. For catalogue and information write the schol at the above address, or call (212) 679 7350, extension 51.

title: Coast Dock Talks Are Resumed In the Face of a Strike Deadline
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 15 (AP)  Faced with a Monday morning strike deadline, West Coast employers and longshore men resumed bargaining today.

title: Hamilton Says State Is Ruining City U.
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton declared yesterday that the city was facing what looks to us to be a pretty con certed campaign to dismember and destroy City University as a result of state moves.

title: Neely Takes Net Title
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 15 (AP)Armistead Neely of Tampa, Fla., battled Steve Faulk of Madisonville, La., for two hours today before winning the men's single title of the North Island lawn tennis cham pionships, 76, 64, 75.

title: Has Movie Violence Gone Too Far?
description: FOR possibly better, but probably worse, we are in the midst of a new zapplopstabsplatter era of movie violence of unprecedented explicitness. Not so many years ago, the camera, like a worried friend, used to avert its gaze just before the awful thing happened. In the old Ronald Col man version of A Tale of Two Cities, we watched with a mixture of admira tion (for his heroism) and horror (at his fate) while Sidney Carton's neck was fitted into the grooved guillotine chopping block. The camera, however, was already scanning a peaceful eter nity in some painted clouds above the guillotine at the moment the blade whizzed down. Today, who knows?

title: OHIO STATE DOWNS MICHIGAN BY 8473
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 15 (AP)  Ohio State, relying mainly on the scoring of Allan Hornyak and Luke Witte de feated Michigan, 8473, today for its 12th straight Big Ten victory.

title: Business Index Rises
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 345.7 from 340.8 a week earlier. A year ago it was 352.7.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Art
description: TWO careers: that of a young German woman, the painter Paula Modcrsohn  Becker, whose career lasted little more than a decade (she died in 1907, at the age of 30, shortly after giving birth to a daughter. Her reported deathbed remark, What a shame, sums up the blighted promise of her career.); and that of an American sculptor, the late Robert Laurent, one of the firstwave American modernists whose career seems to have stretched well beyond his minor but solid achievements. An exhibition of ModersohnBecker's paint ings, drawings and prints is currently on view at La Bootie, 1042 Madison Ave nue; a memorial exhibition of Laurent's sculpture  he died in Maine in 1970 at the age of 80  has been in stalled at the Kraushaar Gal leries, 1055 Madison Avenue. Aside from the fact that they represent the tragic ends of the spectrum among those who devote their lives to art, there is no other reason to connect the pair.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The No. 1 Sport? It's Now Football
description: At a time when television experts are predicting that some 65 million United States viewers will watch today's Super Bowl game, the latest Gallup Poll revealed yester day that football had now become America's No. 1 spec tator sport.

title: SCHEUER DECRIES OUSTER BY SOVIET
description: LONDON, Jan. 15Repre sentative James H. Scheuer, the Bronx Democrat expelled from the Soviet Union on the ground of improper activities, said here tonight that his ouster was pointless and irrational. The step apparently was designed to discourage Americans from private contacts with Soviet citizens.

title: Asthma Sufferers Are Finding Relief in a Sanatorium 700 Feet Down in a Salt Mine
description: WIELICZKA, Poland  No body is quite sure why, but asthma sufferers and other victims of respiratory ailments are being cured here in a sec tion of an ancient salt mine serving as a sanatorium.

title: A Watch on the Loch For the Shy, Warty, Slimy Nessie
description: INVERNESS, ScotlandYou're not like most Americans with all their cameras and fancy lenses, one of my wife's cousins told me approv ingly last fall during three days of hand shaking in Glasgow.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 15 (UPI) Duquesne, staving off two secondhalf rallies, managed to hang on today for a 9691 deci sion over St. Bonaventure be fore 5,279 fans.

title: Major surgery
description: Once there was an enormous duplex Park Avenue apartment so large that one floor was de voted mostly to servants' quarters and storage. When it was con verted into two onefloor apart ments, the family that bought the servants' floor was confronted with a disorganized maze of rooms and closets. Their solution to gut the space and start al most fresh. The resultan airy, spacious, threezone apartment. Architect Gabriel Sedlis tucked away the family bedrooms in the back. He created a working complex of kitchen, a huge gym like playroom and a puttering room for adults. The third zone occupying the choice space over looking Park Avenueconsists of the apartment's public areas (shown). The architect centered the living room between the din ing room and library and empha sized the luxurious feeling of generous space.

title: Modular Financing
description: LOS ANGELES  The American Home Industries Corporation thinks it has found the answer to the fi nancing problems that have stymied much of the under capitalized factorybuilt hous ing industry.

title: Cavorting Over the Coral With Some Scaly Friends
description: THE sloop, Ocoee, is resting on what appears to be a wrinkled sheet of glass above a polkadotted floor. Aside from a pair of frigate birds wheeling over Petit Bateau (one of the Tobago Cays in the Grena dines), no other life can be seen. It is hard to believe that just a few hundred yards to the east and a couple of feet down, swarming around a coral reef, lives what a marine guide describes as by far the gaudiest, most varied, and most luxurious fauna  on earth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Meetings With Ecuador On Tuna Are Inconclusive
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 15 (Reuters)A toplevel United States delegation left here last night for home after three days of talks with Ecuadorian offi cials without reaching agree ment on the tunafishing dis pute between the two coun tries.

title: Sing a Lusty Chantey for X Seamen
description: The X Seamens Institute is not at all what its name suggests. It is not an insti tute and it includes in its ranks only one person who has been to sea.

title: TEMPLE SUBDUES FORDHAM, 7560
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (AP) Joe Newman scored 17 of his 23 points in the second half to lead Temple to a 7560 victory over Fordham tonight.

title: Many Airline Pilots Commute From West Coast as Layoffs Alter Schedules
description: When Franklin Soare, a 37yearold United Air Lines pilot, pulls out of his drive way and heads for work, he begins a commuting trip that spans 2,425 miles  from Seattle to New York City.

title: News of Dogs
description: It was Ladies Day at the Suffolk County Fish and Game Association's field trial in Suffolk County Park, South Haven, L. I., last Sun day. Bitches swept all four places, with a German Short haired pointer, Tip's Lady Nip finishing first and win ning the Long Island Birddog of the Year. trophy. The mas sive cup is a per petual prize, but the dog's name and that of her owner, Ceasar Riboldi of Elmont, L. I., will be en graved on it.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Snowmold has been serious on some Northeastern lawns, especially on Long Island. Dyrene fungicide is a good preventive applied during the winter months. Follow carefully package directions.  There are water heaters available to keep water for birds from freezing.  Toss out paperwhite narcissus bulbs when flowers fade.

title: PHONE COMPANY SEEKING REVENUE
description: The New York Telephone Company is upgrading its in formation service, with the hope of getting permission to charge most of such calls throughout the state for the first time.

title: Brave of the Year: Aaron
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 15, (UPI) The Atlanta Braves outfielder, Hank Aaron, who last year hit a careerhigh 47 home runs, has been named Brave of the year for 1971 by the Atlanta chapter of the Baseball Writers Asso ciation of America.

title: A Robbery Suspect Dies Trying to Flee Hospital
description: A suspect recovering from a chest wound inflicted in a holdup of an East Village liquor store last month fell to his death as he tried to escape from a secondfloor ward at Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon.

title: Recordings
description: LOOKI view myself as a minority of one. And I see all the rest of the people in the world as their own minorities of one. So if I can say some thing honest about my feelings and thoughts and problems as a minority of one, then won't it be meaningful to all the other individual minori ties of one? The voice belongs to Dory Previn, whose third solo album, Reflections in A Mud Puddle/Taps, Tremors and Time Steps (United Ar tists UAS5536), was recent ly issued.

title: By Bus Across Desert Tracks To Meet a Moroccan Artisan
description: TAROUDANT, MoroccoThey are the most honest and hospitable people I have ever known, the people who live in the Sous Val ley, the southwestern part of Morocco below Marrakesh, the part in which this city of Taroudant is situated. The people of the Sous Valley do not cheat; they do not steal, and they welcome the visitor as one of their own, as a traveler on this earth, one of the play things which Allah has made out of mud and breathed life into to amuse Himself and will someday let crumble.

title: A distaste for permissiveness, a taste for cool
description: Only Richard Brautigan could write so lyrically of the healing force of ice in the blood, or the quirky peace of the supercool. From the brilliant novels, Trout Fishing in America and In Watermelon Sugar to this first collection, Revenge of the Lawn: Stories 19621970, Brautigan has written sublimely of the way misery can turn into a joke, or anguish into a deadpan anecdote. For all Brautigan's characters are trout fishermen fishing for cool, freezing away every psychic ache, or looking for that cold, hard alloy Brautigan calls trout steel. Imagine Pitts burgh, Brautigan asks in Trout Fishing in America, made out of trout steel, the clear snow  filled river acting as foundry and heat. For Brautigan is the prophet of cities built out of ice rather than fire, of an America whose emblem would be no wargod eagle, but an elusive cold fish.

title: Bangladesh:
description: DACCA  The last cheers welcoming Sheik Mujibur Rahman back from nine months' imprisonment in West Pakistan had barely died down last week when the Bengali leader moved swiftly to consolidate his con trol over the new Bangla desh Government.

title: 4 of 5 Big Bread Companies Adopt a 5Delivery Week
description: Delivery of bread to stores in the New York City area on Mondays has been eliminated this week by four of the five principal companies. The fifth, the makers of Silvercup Bread in Long Island City, is expect ed to follow suit soon.

title: Travel Notes: European Trains Improve Service; London Transit Fares Increase
description: THE International Union of Railways (U.I.C.), which concerns itself primarily with the op eration of European rail roads, is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a notable improvement in service on the European rails, espe cially on intercity networks. (Amtrak, meanwhile, still struggles; the company cur tailed service between Buf falo, Cleveland and Chicago last week.) Here is a brief sampling of recent improve ments American tourists can take advantage of:

title: Mrs. Nelson Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Nel son on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Nelson is the former Miss Nanci L. Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Martin of South port, Conn. The child, whose father is assistant to the cir culation director of The New York Times, has been named Jennifer.

title: Fairfield Tops St. Peter's
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 15  Dave Bradley scored an un contested layup with 39 sec onds remaining to give Fair field an 8382 victory over St. Peter's before 1,555 fans to night at the Jersey City Arm ory. Bradley had a gamehigh 28 points on 13 for 27 from the floor and 2 for 3 from the foul line.

title: Visitor Finds Hanoi Cautious on P.O.W Data
description: The following article, on the Vietnam prisonerofwar issue and other questions, was writ ten for The Associated Press by an American lawyer who has handled civilrights matters and servicemen's cases. He recently spent a week in Hanoi, where he had lengthy discussions with leaders of a Governmentspon sored group dealing with Amer ican affairs.

title: Critiques of two critics
description: A book on poetry and politics wouldn't have been a likely project for a serious critic 20 years ago. In America the reigning orthodoxy con signed both the poet and his inter preter to a realm of pure form that chastely removed them from un seemly intercourse with the worka day world. Meanwhile in France no less political an animal than Sartre, in a stirring manifesto on the social responsibility of the writer, had spe cifically (and bizarrely) exempted the poet and abandoned him to a verbal no man's land of inwardness and selfexpression. Even the best Marx ian criticism, which had already con tributed brilliantly to the study of the novel, seemed unable to establish that poets too lived palpably In The World.

title: Reader's Report
description: James Lee Burke is a gifted stylist who can transmit a sense of urgency and authenticity to regional subject matter. His pre vious book dramatized the plight of some Kentucky miners caught in a lockoutand, de spite this conventional pattern, Mr. Burke never sacrificed his characters' identities to their cause. This novel, alas, is not as successful.

title: Fifty Years of Insulin
description: Fifty years ago this month, an 11yearold boy, Leonard Thompson, lay in Toronto General Hospital waiting to die of diabetes. He weighed only 65 pounds, gaunt testi mony to the starvation diet doctors then employed as the only known means to delaybrieflythe victory of this killer disease. Leonard Thompson's case was to prove a medical milestone, however. He became the first diabetic patient to receive insulin, then newly discovered by Dr. Frederick G. Banting and Charles H. Best. Young Thomp son's prompt improvement, release from the hospital and ability to live a normal life constituted the first miracle in this field, a miracle repeated millions of times since for diabetics in all countries.

title: Thanks, on behalf of a generation of fearful virgins
description: In the 1950's when I was a virgin, there was only one book around that was really informative about sex: Love Without Fear by Eustace Chesser. I and my similarly inexperi enced cohorts pored over that book as rabbinical students pore over the Tal mud. One section in particular was the focus of our studies: In a chap ter titled How to Manage the Sex Act there was a fourpage section which graphically described 11 posi tions of intercourse. Actually de scribed them. Told you what to put where and everything. Incredible. Well, we all owe Dr. Chesser an eternal debt of gratitude, and the fact that it took several years from the time most of us memorized his 11 positions to the time we actually got around to trying them out is cer tainly not his fault.

title: LEONARD DOVE
description: Leonard Dove, an artist, illus trator and cartoonist who had done a number of covers for The New Yorker in the nine teentwenties and thirties, died of a heart attack Friday at his home, the Gramercy Hotel, 137 East 24th Street. He was 64 years old. He had also contrib uted cartoons to Collier's, Look and other magazines.

title: For English, It Must Be Muskie
description: WASHINGTONYeah Yeah Have you ever met Muskie? At some point there we're going to be riding in the car, why don't you ride with us and we can talk? That's fine That's fine.

title: Sudden Death Will Settle Super Bowl Tie
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 The Super Bowl game be tween the Miami Dolphins and the Dallas Cowboys will he played to a suddendeath finish if the teams are tied at the end of regulation 60 minutes.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Gabriella Langendorff buys a sandwich for her lunch at the Homestead Gourmet Shop in Forest Hills, Queens, before taking the subway into Mahattan to work.

title: Schranz First in Downhill Again
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 15Karl Schranz today won his second downhill race in two days on a pair of superskis manufactured by the company in which he is a director.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Buckminster Fuller Save Us?
description: Yes: In Jorge Luis Borges's story called The Aleph, a house in Buenos Aires contains in its cellar, toward the right of the riser on the 19th step from the floor, nothing less than The Aleph, which is a point in space that contains all other points. It is little more than an inch in dia meter, and contains, as you gaze into it, literally everything: tigers, pistons, bisons, tides, armies, a Persian astro labe, all the ants on the planet.

title: College Sports Notes
description: This year's class of high school seniors probably won't be playing varsity football for Dear Old Siwash U. next fall just because the National Collegiate Athletic Associa tion has given permission to major colleges to use fresh men on the varsity football team starting next fall. Thefinal decision will be up to the var ious college ath letic conferences, such as the Big Ten, Southeastern, Big Eight and to the indi vidual colleges. The N.C.A.A. freshmen rule is permissive and not mandatory.

title: Russian Defects in Canaries
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, Jan. 15 (AP)The police re ported that Alej Mesoltov, a 27 yearold Russian oceanograph ic engineer, asked for political asylum today on Grand Canary Island. They said he arrived Thursday aboard the fishing vessel Belogorsk.

title: Keller Equals Top Time In Swiss Speed Skating
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 15 (AP)Erhard Keller of West Germany skated to a 38second clocking in the 500 meters to day, equaling the pending world record, in a speed skating race.

title: A distaste for permissiveness, a taste for cool
description: As soon as the outlines of this ut terly contemporary novel begin to emerge one can see that it is essen tially an adaptation of the old moral fable about the Pied Piper. Decked with scenes of youthful riot and the disarray of middle age, the essential fable has been revamped to express Amis's distaste for permissiveness and all its consequences. For satiric ends the cast of characters has been adroitly shaped to expose a sort of folie  deux in which youth and an aging misleader of youth contribute equally to the mischief.

title: State's Code on Uniform Credit Scored by Consumer Advocates
description: Leading consumer advocates mounted a new attack yester day on the proposed state uniform consumer credit code, which, they charged, would repeal state laws protecting borrowers and installment pur chasers under the guise of codifying the statutes.

title: KFAR TOV VICTOR IN COAST STAKES
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 15 (UPI)Favored Kfar Tov closed with a rush in the stretch today to capture the 34th running of the $57,960 San Carlos Handi cap for the sprint championship of the Santa Anita meeting.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Today, education is perhaps the most im portant function of state and local govern ments. Compulsory school attendance laws and the great expenditures for education both demonstrate our recognition of the importance of education to our democratic society. It is required in the performance of our most basic public responsibilities, even service in the armed forces it is the very foundation of good citizenship.

title: Bonn Contributes to U.N.
description: GENEVA, Jan. 15Receipt of a contribution of $305,000 from the West German Government to the United Nations fund for drug abuse control was an nounced this week.

title: Integration Is Rising in Southern Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15A survey of 76 urban school dis tricts by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare shows a dramatic increase in racial integration in a number of Southern cities.

title: Stock Fund Sought to Aid Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan 15 Gov. Luis. A. Ferr proposed last night the creation of a pub lic venture capital fund as a novel approach toward improv ing'the island's sagging econ omy.

title: CORE Opposes Order Merging Virginia School
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 15 (AP) The Congress of Racial Equality said today that a Federal court decision ordering the merger of predominantly Negro Richmond public schools with the over whelmingly white schools in two neighboring counties was not in the best interest of black people.

title: CUTS IN SERVICES LOOM IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 15Detroit is facing major cutbacks in city services, particularly in recre ational and cultural activities, because of a continuing money crisis.

title: New York Man Claims World KiteFlying Mark
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)  A 69yearold man claimed a world record today when he flew 50 kites and an empty cham pagne bottle on a single, handheld line.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: RESTRAINT LIFTED AGAINST MAGAZINE
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice vacated yesterday his own order of the day before re straining the Ladies' Home Journal from distributing an issue containing purported in terviews with Howard R. Hughes.

title: Medicine/Science
description: There may come a time when the offer of a cigarette to a friend will be considered a hostile act. Some thing like saying: Here, pal, have a drag. It can give you heart disease, lung cancer or just knock you out.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Medicine/Science
description: It is more than a coincidence that two of the great monarchs of mari time passenger service between New York and Europe met their end in al most identical manners. Both the Queen Elizabeth, largest passenger liner ever built, now lying forlornly on her side in Hong Kong harbor, (see above), and the Normandie, which rolled over alongside her pier in New York in 1942, caught fire while being refitted. The question asked last week: Why do these large vessels capsize?

title: Two Women Attack And Rob Jerseyan Outside Hotel Here
description: A 24yearold New Jersey man was assaulted and robbed by two women in front of the Americana Hotel early yester day morning, the police reported.

title: Museum Names Assistant
description: Dr. Thomas D. Nicholson, di rector of the American Museum of Natural History, has an nounced the naming of Dr. Jerome G. Rozen Jr. to the newly created post of deputy director of the museum. Doctor Rozen was chairman of the museum's department of en tomology and curator of hy menoptera, the latter involving the study of such gauzewinged insects as bees and wasps.

title: Belgian Mercy Killer Freed
description: LIEGE Belgium Jan. 15 (AP) A local court has acquitted a man who strangled his wife to relieve her of suffering, Jean Picquereau, 74 years old, had nursed his wife, Suzanne, since 1969, when cerebral ?? incapacitated her. But he said he decided to kill her and turn himself over to the police when the disease caused her unbear able pain and a mental break down.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stamps
description: SWITZERLAND on Feb. 17 will postally com memorate two events: the 25th anniversary of Swissair's first transAtlantic flight, which was in honor of the Centenary Internation al Philatelic Exhibition (CI PEX) here at the longgone Grand Central Palace, and the 50th anniversary of its predecessor Ad Astra flight by Henri Pillichody in June, 1922, between Zurich and Nuremberg, Germany, a pio neer international commer cial flight.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Singer Faces Jail Term
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 15 (UP1) Johnny Paycheck, the country music singer, faces an 11 month, 29day sentence in the Metro Workhouse beginning March 1 for passing a worthless check. Criminal Court Judge Allen R. Corneilius Jr. denied a petition for a sus pended sentence yesterday. Mr. Paycheck, 33 years old, whose real name is Donald ?? Lytle, pleaded guilty Nov. 24 to passing a worthless $100.

title: SCHOOL PERIL SEEN FOR HANDICAPPED
description: Many speakers at hearings conducted last week by the Mayor's Advisory Committee on the Handicapped expressed fear that special education pro grams for 40,000 handicapped children might be reduced or eliminated by further decen tralization of the public school system.

title: Student Who Won $850,000 After Pool Accident Is Dead
description: Jonathan Boyce, the 24year old college student who was awarded $850,000 in a negli gence suit last October, died yesterday at the Instiute of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine.

title: Squires Down Rockets
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 15 (AP) Julius Erving scored 25 points and grabbed 22 rebounds to night to pace the Virginia Squires to a 116107 victory over Denver.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: THIS WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE wave of euphoria that has welled up among investors since Thanksgiving subsided a bit last week but continued to roll along even though a slight crosscurrent of concern was developing again over the international economic situation and some elements of the domestic business picture.

title: Housing Curb in Carolina
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 15 The Federal Government will not approve subsidies for any proposed housing projects in North Carolina that exceeds about 50 units, barring excep tional circumstances, accord ing to a new policy.

title: Miss Sherry Beth Gottesmann Affianced
description: MILLBURN, N. J., Jan. 15 Miss Sherry Beth Gottes mann, a secretary at Jeffer son Medical College in Philadelphia, and Michael Podolsky, a sophomore at that medical school, will be married here March 12.

title: HUGHESNIXON TIES DESCRIBED IN BOOK
description: A $205,000 transaction 15 years ago with Richard M. Nix on's family is among the recol lections of political dealings that appear in a purported auto biography of Howard Hughes, according to executives of Mc GrawHill Book Company.

title: Circus Leopard Has Twins
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 15 (UPI)The American Circus announced the birth of twin leopard cubs this week in what it called the first such birth in a circus menagerie.

title: HENLEY HILL DEAD; EDITOR AT TRIBUNE
description: Henley Hill, for many years a senior editor at the old New York Herald Tribune, died Thursday in Los Angeles, it was learned here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

description: On the last page but one of Visionary Cities: The Arcology of Paolo Soleri (Praeger Publishers), assembled by Don ald Wall, there appears the following module of orotund assertion:

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONSeven years ago, Judge J. Skelly Wright, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis trict of Columbia, delivered a lecture at New York University that raised the eyebrows of the judicial commu nity.

title: New York Bar Group Urges U.S. Inquiry on War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has asked the President and Congress to con vene an inquiry into what it said was compelling evidence that serious breaches of the law of war have been committed by all parties in the Indochina war.

title: Nancy Reynolds To Be the Bride Of M. J. Whelan
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 15Mr. and Mrs. Warren Reynolds have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Nancy Jay Reynolds, to Martin James Whelan of New York. He is the son of Mrs. John M. Whelan of Phil adelphia and the late Mr. Whelan.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Johnson Bowler of Year; Petraglia in Second Place
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) Pastfinishing Don Johnson of Akron, Ohio, edged the leading moneywinner, Johnny Petrag lia of Brooklyn in a hot voting battle for 1971 bowler of the year, announced today by the Bowling Writers' Association of America.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: ENEMY ADVANCES SAM LAUNCHERS CLOSE TO BORDER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15North Vietnam has moved its mobile missile launchers closer to South Vietnam's northern frontier than ever be fore, leading to new engage ments with United States fight ers within three miles of the border.

title: Pullout on Controls?
description: When President Nixon junked his floundering eco nomic game plan in favor of wageprice controls last August, the immediate shock effect sent the President's political stock soaring. Now that many in business and labor are chafing under the inescapable irritations and inequities of a controlled economy, hints are coming front the White House that decontrol may be in pros pect before the voters go to the polls this fall.

title: Want to Murder the Vivian Beaumont? Here's How
description: THERE is a small group of people, headed by Dore schary, working with dedication to save the present regime at the Vivian Beaumont. There is another small group of peo ple, headed by Jules Irving, working with equal dedi cation to kill it. As of Nar row Road to the Deep North, Mr. Irving is winning.

title: Columbia Reports Gifts and Bequests Rose by $2Million
description: Columbia University received nearly $2million more in gifts and bequests between July and November than it did in the same period in 1970, according to university officials.

title: BEAUKINS SCORES IN TROPICAL RACE
description: MIAMI, Jan. 15Uncertainty over the future complexion of Florida horse racing continued to stir speculation here today as Tropical Park came to what al most surely is the end of its 41 year existence as a thorough bred track.

title: An Alleged Top Communist Gets 21 Years in Madrid
description: MADRID, Jan. 15 (AP) Luis Lucio Lobato, 51 years a member of the executive committee and the Central Committee of the Spanish Communist party, bas been sentenced to 21 years in prison for illegal association and ille gal propaganda, press reports said today.

title: Andrew Stewart of Lawrence U. Fiance of Alison Weston Magee
description: Miss Alison Weston Magee and Andrew Stewart, gradu ates of the Kent School and students at Lawrence Univer sity in Appleton, Wis., plan to be married in June.

title: Hodges's Indiana Home Names Bridge for Him
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 15 (AP)  The Indiana Senate has passed a resolution to call a nameless bridge over White River on Indiana 57 in southwestern Indiana the Gil Hodges Bridge in honor of the manager of the New York Mets.

title: Catholic Faith and Fiction
description: Wilfrid Sheed recently wrote here: It could be that Catholicism in its current dither strikes even some of its own members as a harmless aberration and can for the time be ing raise its head safely in books. If so, there is historical comedy in the making. For others are taking Catholics very seriously indeedby their definition of the serious.

title: JAMES CAPTURES PACE SERIES RACE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 15A New Zealand  bred, named James, a 9yearold gelding, made his first start in this coun try a winning one tonight. Com peting in the Early Bird Pacing Series at Roosevelt Raceway under the guidance of Del Insko, James took the onemile race by 1 lengths. Direct Sammy was second, with Royal Society next.

title: The World
description: VIENNAWe don't want a dancing congress, Soviet and American arms negotiators told their Austrian hosts in an effort to avoid the lavish cere mony and festive socializing that ac companied the historic Congress of Vienna in 1815. However historic their own efforts to put a ceiling on the nuclear arms race, the men from Mos cow and Washington wanted to be left alone to labor in secret.

title: Rioting Shatters Nancy Prison, Sixth French Outburst in Week
description: PARIS, Jan. 15France's troubleridden penitentiary sys tem was hit today by a rebel lion that wrecked a large part of the Nancy prison. It took riot policemen seven hours to subdue the prisoners.

title: CHARLES I. M'GUFFIE
description: Charles Irving MacGuffie, an electrical engineer who was a past president of the American Welding Society, died Friday of a heart attack in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 68 years old.

title: Gardens
description: EVEN a person indiffer ert to nature's beauties would notice Santo lina chamaecyparissus, a shrubby plant or small sub shrub, one to two feet high with aromatic, lightgrey foli age. Santolina also has the name lavender cotton.

title: Dance: City Ballet Gives Printemps
description: Once upon a time when the New York City Ballet was bad it was bad in the grand manner. The premiere of Printemps on Thursday sank into obivion with a sad deflationary air, A surprising lot of people booed its chore ographer at the curtain call. It won't help.

title: South Vietnam Division Chief Is Reported Being Replaced
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 (AP)Government sources reported today that South Viet nam was replacing the com mander of an army division in the threatened Central High lands, in a continuing shakeup of senior military officials.

title: Ullstrad vs. Polk: The Cupcake Incident
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.British Dory Race Slated Here Tuesday
description: The National Boat Show dory races, which were in itiated in 1970, between the British and the United States boating industries are sched uled for their third duel Tues day. The prize is four and onehalf gold sovereigns put into competition by the British and it is held by the Americans.

title: Love Sparks Bulls
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) Chicago's Bob Love, hobbled by a bad leg in the last five con tests, returned to form tonight with a 32point performance in leading the Bulls to a 120100 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Nixon Works on Messages; Plans Super Bowl Time Out
description: THURMONT, Md., Jan. 15 (AP)As a chill wind whipped light snow flurries through the wooded mountains, President Nixon worked today in the se clusion of his Camp David re ?? on a set of messages he Will be sending Congress within the next month.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH we seem to be making little or no progress in controlling our environment  es pecially the quality of the air we brearneoutside our home we have been able to do a great deal to control our indoor environment. Not only do we have automatic heating and air conditioning systems to control the tempbrature of our indoor air, we also have electric humidifiers and de humidifiers to control its moisture content (relative humidity). In addition, there are now also electronic air cleaners available which can be installed to filter out practically all airborne pollu tion  dust, dirt, pollen, smoke and even odors in most cases.

title: Williams Breaking Barriers in Bowling
description: When Bobby Williams was asked whether he thought many people would be watch ing him bowl on television last Saturday in the final round of the $100,000 Bowl ing Proprietors' Association of America United States Open, his answer was unas suming.

title: LASTMINUTE GOAL TOPS RANGERS, 43
