title: Royals on Top, 128108
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M., Jan. 16 (AP)Nate Archibald scored 41 points and was credited with 16 assists tonight in pacing the Cincinnati Royals to a 128108 triumph over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 16 (AP)Alex Metreveli of the So viet Union won the men's sin gles title in the Tasmanian open today by defeating Wanaro Ngodrella of France, 62, 64, 63.

title: Mrs. King Beats Miss Melville in Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Berkeley, Calif., rallied in both sets last night and posted a 76, 76 victory over Kerry Melville of Australia in the final of the $17,000 British Motor Car tennis tournament.

title: Strike Halts El Al Flights
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 16 (AP) Maintenance workers for El Al, the Israeli airline, grounded 15 flights today during a 24 hour warning strike for higher pay and improved bene fits.

title: Anna Moffo's Recital Marked By Wide Range of Vocal Works
description: Anna Moffo is a striking woman with a natural sense of theater, which gave her song recital at Carnegie Hall yester day afternoon a kind of pro spective flair and glamour. The soprano's program, moreover, held more than ordinary in terest, embracing Handel, Mahler, Richard Strauss, Verdi, Debussy, Donizetti and Benin. Inasmuch as Miss Moffo ap proached each song Intelligently and with a good deal of sen sitivity to its moods and mean ings, her work Invariably com manded respect.

title: Sidky Is Named to Head A Militant Cairo Cabinet
description: CAIRO, Jan. 16  President Anwar elSadat today named a new Premier, Dr. Aziz Sidky, to succeed the 71yearold Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi as the first step in a campaign to mobilize the home front for total con frontation with Israel.

title: New Signal System Aids Holland Tunnel Traffic
description: A new signal system to permit control of individual lanes in the Holland Tunnel went into operation at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Lincoln MacVeagh Dies at 81; An Ambassador for 20 Years
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 16 Lincoln MacViagh, former Am bassador to Spain, Greece and other countries, died last night at a nursing home in Adelphi, Md. He was 81 years old.

title: AUGERT OF FRANCE WINS CUP SLALOM
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria Jan. 16  Champion meets girl. Champion teaches girl. Girl becomes champion. Two cham pions will marry.

title: Nicklaus Takes Crosby Tourney On Extra Hole
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 16The young mod golfer, John Miller, tried to stop Jack Nicklaus but he couldn't do it today. In a suddendeath play off that lasted one hole, Nick laus ran in an 18foot birdie putt to win the Bing Crosby tourney and begin his 1972 campaign with a stunning vic tory over the Pebble Beach course.

title: Welfare Role of Industry Varies Widely in Europe
description: The strong role of govern ments in programs to benefit workers has had a varying effect on industries in Italy, France and Britain.

title: Ali To Box Eight Rounds In White Plans Tonight
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 16 The former world heavyweight boxing champion, Muhammad Ali, will fight an eightround exhibition tomorrow night night against Alonzo Johnson on his 30th birthday.

title: 4 DEAD, 10 MISSING IN BLAZE IN HOTEL
description: TYRONE, Pa., Jan. 16 (AP) Four persons were killed, at least 10 others were missing and feared dead and 33 were injured today in an explosion and fire at the Pennsylvania Hotel, the authorities said.

title: Chilean Opposition Wins 2 Elections in Test of Allende's Socialist Program
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 16 The united antiMarxist oppo sition decisively defeated the leftwing coalition of President Savador Allende Gossens in two legislative byelections to day.

title: UNSOLD BACKLOGS SLOW BOND SALES
description: The credit markets face a tough week. They have moved so fast this year that they have left investors behind, and soon something may have to give way.

title: New Publishers Emphasize Social Concern
description: Whether business can be so cially responsible without los ing money is still being debated. But two young publishing ven turesone a new quarterly journal, the other a quartet of magazines for young profes sionalsindicate faith in the profitability of preaching the message of corporate social concern.

title: Twins Sign Tovar, Blyleven
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 16Cesar Tovar, infielder, and Bert Blyleven, pitcher, signed 1972 contracts with the Minne sota Twins today.

title: City Cuts Red Tape in Welfare Cases
description: New socalled bypass pro cedures to speed the closing of welfare cases under the state's sixmonthold workrelief pro gram were announced yester day by the city's Human Re sources Administrator.

title: Hawk's Beat Stars, 32
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (UPI) Bobby Hull, the Chicago Black Hawks' best scorer, and Keith Magnuson and Jerry Korab, tallied tonight in a 32 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Church of Ascension Names Pastor
description: The Church of the Ascen sion, one of the city's land mark Episcopal parishes, has a new rector. The announce ment was made yesterday by E. A. G. Manton, senior war den of the Gothicrevival edi fice at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Marin's Tipin Wins
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 16 (AP) Jack Marin scored on a tipin with nine seconds remaining to give the Baltimore Bullets a 107104 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: Paula Brandi Bride on L.I.
description: GREENPORT, L. I., Jan 16 Miss Paula Brandi was married here this afternoon to Paul S. Berger, a summa cum laude graduate of Har vard College. Justice of the Peace Louis H. Demarest per formed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Custo dio A. Brandi, parents of the bride.

title: CLIFFORD IS NAMED IN HUGHES DISPUTE
description: The name of Clark Clifford, a former Secretary of Defense, was introduced yesterday into the growing controversy over a purported autobiography of Howard Hughes.

title: Stars Bow, 110102
description: DENVER, Jan. 16 (AP) Dave Robisch and Chuck Wil liams sparked the Denver Rockets to a 110102 victory over the Utah Stars tonight.

title: Yevtushenko to Head Bill of Bards at Garden Jan.
description: An attempt to lift poetry reading in America to the scale of a public rally, and almost to the scale of a sports event, will be made here Jan. 28 when the Rus sian poet Yevgeny Yevtu shenko and others appear in the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

title: C.B.S. Survey Puts Muskie 310 Delegates From Victory
description: A national survey by C.B.S. News to estimate the probable firstballot support of candi dates for the Democratic. Na tional Convention indicates that Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine will have 1,199 delegate votes, only 310 votes short of victory, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Opens Second Camp For Suspected Terrorists
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 16 (AP)A second intern ment camp was opened in Northern Ireland today to hold the growing number of sus pected terrorists seized in army raids and held without trial.

title: Kahan, 70, Makes Debut on Mandolin In Classical Recital
description: Although we rarely think of the mandolin as a classical in strument, it once had an im pressive list of musical patrons, including Beethoven, who wrote a Sonatina for it, and Mozart, who specified a mandolin ac companiment for the Serenade Deli vieni in Don Giovanni. There is a Vivaldi Concerto for two mandolins, and scorings for it in sundry works by Handel, Gretry, Verdi and Mahler.

title: U.S. SAYS ITS JETS ENCOUNTERED MIG OVER NORTH LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16  United States jet fighters met a North Vietnam ese MIG21 over northern Laos for the first time this year, but the enemy plane fled with a barrage of airtoair mis siles exploding harmlessly at its tail, the United States com mand reported today.

title: Prohibitive Day Care
description: The controversy over the state's fee structure for chil dren who are enrolled in New York City's publicly assisted daycare centers is a rerun of the national debate over the Child Development program which President Nixon vetoed late last year. The payment scale imposed by the New York State Department of Social Services has the same effect as the Administration's policy of turning day care into a mere adjunct of welfare.

title: Mixed Feelings About a Detergent Ban
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.The ban on the sale of detergents in Suffolk County was de signed to improve the coun ty's underground water sup ply, but for, Eileen Reynolds of Smithtown, the 10month old law has made doing laun dry a nuisance.

title: Dallas Routs Miami in Super Bowl, 243
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 The Dallas Cowboys com pleted the trip to a Super Bowl championship today, a voyage they had begun but never finished five straight times before. The Cowboys were methodical and merci less as they turned back the Miami Dolphins, 243, in what amounted to a rout.

title: Life and Politics
description: LONDON, Jan. 16Anyone who re flects these days on the relationship of man and earth must eventually find himself operating at two levels of awareness.

title: Harry T. Immerman, Engineer Who Led The Moles, Dies at 81
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 16Harry T. Immerman, retired chief engineer and vice presi dent of Spencer White & Pren tis, Inc., of New York, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 554 Forest Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16On the Miami Dolphins' eighth play from scrimmage, Paul Dryden Warfield ran a downandin pattern from his wide flanker position, and history quivered in the throes of creation. Lee Roy Jordan, the Dallas Cowboys' middle linebacker, was helping Mel Renfro cover Miami's gifted receiver as Bob.Griese cocked his throwing arm. The pass was high. Warfield leapt, but could only wave at the ball.

title: Oil Spill Mars Beaches Along L.I. North Shore
description: ROCKY POINT, L.I., Jan. 16 Heavy, black fuel oil, from an unkown source washed ashore on beaches along a 25mile stretch of Long Island's North Shore this weekend.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 16 (AP) Janice Metcalf of Claremont, Calif., won the women's singles today in the Pacific Coast in door tennis tourament. She de feated Ann Kiyamura of San Mateo, Calif., 64, 64.

title: I.T.T. Plans Acquisition
description: Hancock Industries, a Michi gan autoparts maker, said yes terday it had signed a tentative agreement for its acquisition by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for 275, 339 shares of I.T.T. common stock. At the closing price of I.T.T. on Friday of $58.75, the deal would be valued at $16.18 million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: William Benswanger, ExHead Of Pittsburgh Pirates, Dies at 79
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16Wil Ilan E. Benswanger, former president of the Pittsburgh Baseball Club, died last night in Allegheny General Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: If Girls Want to Be Barbers They Can Practice on Balloons
description: Lucille Lo Prete, a 19 yearold with an infectious giggle, picked up a straight edged razor the other morn ing and started to shave a yellow balloon covered with lather, A balloon? Balloon shaving, she explained, is part of the new course she is taking at the Robert Fi ance Hair Design Institute at 4 West 31st Street.

title: Brandt Says Friendliness In the U.S. Impressed Him
description: BONN, Jan. 16Chancellor Willy Brandt, just returned from a twoweek vacation in the United States following talks with President Nixon, was so impressed with the helpfulness and friendliness and inner strength of Americans he met at the grassroots level that he wants to tell West Germans about it.

title: Military Tests Find Most Use of Drugs Is by Vietnam G.I.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Results of the urine tests for drug use conducted by the armed services, and made avail able today, indicate that the drug problem is largely con fined to the Army and to Viet nam.

title: RUSSIANS PROLONG SYRIAN PORT CALL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 16 A visit by units of the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean to the Syrian port of Latakia has played havoc with Arab trade and affected international ship ping in this area.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutter Rockaway Is Leaving Memories in Her Wake
description: When an old Coast Guard cutter retires, what does her crew remember her most for? In the case of the Rockaway, it will probably be things like female oceanographers, the experience of plowing through a Communist  bloc fishing fleet and her captain's hobby.

title: TV Masses Its Resources for Nixon's China Visit
description: Television coverage of Presi dent Nixon's visit to the Chi nese mainland on Feb. 21 will be done predominantly on a pool basis via satellite with some individual commentary by network anchormen. The chances are, according to com munications experts, that China will join the growing list of countries having permanent ac cess to satellite TV service.

title: ROME'S BUS TEST A POLITICAL ISSUE
description: ROME, Jan. 16A nofare transit project, tested for nine days here recently, seemed on its way to becoming a hot po litical issue today.

title: DEFINING OF POOR IS A PHASE 2 ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16A confrontation is developing between the Cost of Living Council on one hand and mem bers of Congress, together with some labor unions on the other, over a definition of who is to be considered poor under Phase Two controls.

title: Hanoi Units Said to Quit Cambodian Temple City
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 16 (Reuters)More than half the North Vietnamese troops stationed in the tem ple city of Angkor in north west Cambodia have left the 1,000yearold ruins to fight elsewhere, military sources said today.

title: Public Invited to PhoneIn In Democrats' Reply to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) The public is being asked to participate in the Democrats' answer to President Nixon's State of the Union Message by joining in a fournetwork tele vision broadcast.

title: Carrington Gains 3d Round, In Tennis Qualifying Event
description: Art Carrington of Elizabeth, N. J., led the advance of favor ites into the third round of the Clean Air Classic tennis qualifying tournament yester day at the 145th Street armory. Carrington, seeded third, de feated Kevin Lynn, 75, 63.

title: Battle In Southern Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  Two battalions of Laotian Govern ment troops, totaling about 800 men, have been encircled by enemy forces and are under continuing attack about 25 miles east of Pakse, in southern Laos, military sources said here today.

title: Neighborhood Voice in City Rule Is Being Studied by State Panel
description: A plan to govern the city through elected, neighborhood councils and local district exec utives, as well as City Hall, is taking shape in Governor Rock efeller's task force on city structure.

title: BRIDGET TRIUMPHS AT OX RIDGE SHOW
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 16 Bridget, an aged brown mare owned by the Alpine Farms of Troy, N. Y., and handled by Dan Kelley, captured both open jumper classes at the twoday Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor horse show, which ended today.

title: Coast Dock Talks Continue With Strike Set for Today
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 (UPI)With tomorrow's strike deadline drawing close, nego tiators held crucial talks tonight on a contract that could avert resumption of the West Coast longshoremen's walkout.

title: Heads Heart Association
description: The American Heart Associa tion announced yesterday the election of Ross Reid as board chairman. Mr. Reid, who has been a member of the board since 1960, is vice president, general counsel and secretary of the Squibb Corporation. In 1971 he received the associa tion's highest award to a volun teer, the Gold Heart Award.

title: Russians May Be Building a Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 United States military analysts said today that they believed the Soviet Union might be building its first aircraft carrier.

title: Film on Dr. King to Be Offered For TV in April as a Memorial
description: A filmed documentary on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be offered to television stations around the country for presentation by the highest bidders during the week of April 2. The entire proceeds from the sale of the film will go to a memorial fund for the slain civilrights leader headed by his widow, Mrs. Coretta King. Dr. King's birthday was commemorated last Satur day.

title: Notes on People
description: JeanPaul Sartre, the phi losopher, was officially charged with slandering the French police.

title: Landgrebe Gave Out Booklets
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Representative Landgrebe said today that he gave away 10 little religious booklets in the shops of Moscow last week.

title: Sinyavsky Is Said to Be Living Quietly in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17  Andrei D. Sinyavsky, the literary critic and author sentenced in 1966 to seven years at hard labor, has reportedly been quietly allowed to return to Moscow.

title: Ionesco Talks of His Latest, Macbett
description: PARISEugne Ionesco, a dean of the Theater of the Absurd and a freshman in the Acadmie Frangaise, is about to unveil his 16th or 17th playhe is not sure which. In keeping with his new dignity, he calls it a melodrama of classic inspira tion, but in keeping with his profound pessimism, it is also a horror comedy about the tyranny of power, as Rhinoceros is about the tyranny of conformism.

title: COUNCILMEN WARY OF TAXI PROPOSAL
description: Members of the City Council Consumer Affairs Committee were reported yesterday to have voiced widespread criticism of a proposed law to regulate the taxi industry.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Frost flowers melted off store windows and New Yorkers doffed their mufflers as the bitter cold that had struck the metropolitan area Sunday mod erated yesterday.

title: Iraq, in Oil Talks, Says 3 Companies Balk at Demands
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 Iraq has accused three Western oil companies, with whom she is carrying out negotiations in Baghdad, of intransigence and of refusal to meet our legit mate demands.

title: State Begins Spot Checks of Detergents in Stores
description: To the surprise of some startled store managers, the state began yesterday to en force its new law limiting the amount of phosphate allowed in detergents.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17  For the last halfdozen years there was a strong belief in many areas that the Dallas Cowboys were the best team in football. But no one could prove it because the bottom kept falling out of every argument since the team from Texas lost each convincer. On at least two occasions the frustration struck in closing seconds and Dallas was labeled a chokeup club that folded under pressure. It now is obvious that the reason for Dallas failure in the past was that it didn't have aquarterback with the total skills to direct it to the big one. But the Cowboys have one now in Roger Staubach. He is a dandy, a rather extraordinary individual who over came huge odds even to gain his firststring job and then wound up as the most valuableplayer in the game. In the Super Bowl a year ago, Staubach didn't see action for even one play. Tom Landry, the Cowboy coach, was not ready to trust the destinies of his team to a man of such limited experience. So he went with Craig Morton, who made it close and that doesn't count. It was so close, that Dallas was beaten by Balti more, 1613, on a field goal in the final seconds.

title: VOTE INQUIRY HITS JUSTICE AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  A House Judiciary subcommit tee, in a unanimous report, de clared today that the Justice Department had not properly enforced the Federal Voting Rights Act in 26 Mississippi counties to prevent discrimina tion against black voters.

title: Italy's President Begins Tedious Hunt for Premier
description: ROME, Jan. 17 President Giovanni Leone, the short and witty Neapolitan who has just moved into the baroque gran deur of the Quirinal Palace, set out today on a laborious search for the premier of Italy's 33d cabinet since the fall of Fascism.

title: Scientists for McGovern
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)  Twenty scientists, including four Nobel Prize winners, have formed a group called Scientists for George McGovern, the Sen ator's Massachusetts campaign headquarters announced today.

title: Xerox Earnings Hit Peak
description: The Xerox Corporation achieved record revenues and earnings in 1971 for the 20th consecutive year, although the percentage increases have been declining in the last few years, according to the report issued yesterday from Stamford, Conn., headquarters.

title: Acts to Halt Disorder Among the Bengalis
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 17 Sheik Mujibur Rahman ordered all former Bengali guerrilla fighters today to surrender their arms to Government agents within 10 days.

title: Comrade Flintstone
description: When the Russians crushed the Hungarian rising in 1956, they could hardly have foreseen that the ultimate invader of Hungary would be the bourgeois influence of television. Always big on entertainment, the Hungarians have taken to TV with such enthusiasm that there are now two million sets for the population of ten million. Since Hungarian programs are far too scarce to fill the voracious schedule, American programs have been pour ing into the vacuum tube at a rate that might once have horrified a cultural commissar.

title: Britain and Market Reach Final Agreement on Entry
description: BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Jan. 18 British and Common Market officials completed negotiations early today to make Britain a member of the sixnation Euro pean trade bloc and pave the way for entry by Denmark, Ireland and Norway.

title: BRADFORD BOOBIS
description: Bradford Boobis, an artist, died of a heart attack Sunday on the way to Roosevelt Hospi tal. He was 43 years old and lived at 415 Central Park West.

title: BALDRIDGE LOBELL SCORES BY A NOSE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 17 Baldridge Lobell closed with a rush to win the $6,000 Bellaire Pace tonight at Roosevelt Race way. The margin was a nose over Shiaway Frosty, who took the place by a nose over Can dios.

title: 2 Held Without Bail in a Bribe Linked to East Harlem Slaying
description: Two men accused of bribing three policemen in connection with an East Harlem murder were held without bail yester day in State Supreme Court here after the judge was told that the District Attorney is concerned about the security of his witnesses.

title: Keino to Race Ryun
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (UPI) Kip Keino of Kenya has ac cepted an invitation to oppose Jim Ryun in the mile of the Sunkist invitation indoor track meet Saturday night: the meet director, Al Franken, announced today.

title: SavetheSeals Wildlife Group Names Fur Industry in Libel Suits
description: Friends of Animals, Inc., filed a $1million libel suit yes terday against the fur industry and its trade union council.

title: U.S. HEALTH BILE $75BILLION IN 71
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Americans spent over $75bil lion on their health care in the fiscal year 1971 at a rate of increase that was double that of both the cost of living and the gross national product.

title: Port Aide to Resign
description: John R. Wiley, director of aviation for the Port of New York Authority for the last 17 years, will retire on Feb. 1. Matthias E. Lukens, acting ex ecutive director of the bistate agency, said Neal R. Montanus, deputy director of aviation, will succeed Mr. Wiley, who will teach at the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION UP BY 7.4% IN WEEK
description: Steel production last week totaled 2,312,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 7.4 per cent from 2,152,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

title: U.S. SUES TO BAR WELLS FARGO TIE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The Justice Department, filed suit today seeking to block the merger of two of the nation's largest commeroial banks Wells Fargo of San Francisco and the First Western Bank and Trust Company of Los Angeles.

title: Uruguayan Honors Mitrione
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Mrs. Daniel A. Mitrione of Richmond, Ind., widow of the toreign aid adviser who was killed by Uruguayan terrorists in 1970, was given a plaque today by a police official from Uruguay. The plaque, presented by Alberto Becona Barizo of the Montivideo Police Depart ment, praises Mr. Mitrione as a victim of terrorism.

title: LAWMAKERS COOL TO ALBANY BUDGET
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17Governor Rockefeller's proposed $7.9 billion budget elicited little criticism and less praise in the Legislature today, as the law makers put in their first work ing day of the regular 1972 session.

title: Columbia's Navarro Receives Sheehan Award as East's Top Coach
description: Frank Navarro, whose Columbia football team won six games in 1971, was pre sented the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Trophy last night as the East's major college coach of the year.

title: 9% of 38,555 City U. Freshmen Are Getting Aid From Welfare
description: Nearly 9 per cent of the current freshmen at City Uni versity3,390 out of 38,555 who entered last September are welfare recipients, accord ing to a study that became available yesterday.

title: PETER DALTON DEAD; SCULPTOR WAS 77
description: Peter Dalton, a sculptor who won several awards for his art, died Friday of cardiac arrest in Pasadena, Calif., where he spent the winter. He was 77 years old and lived at Grand View, Ny ack, N.Y.

title: Shift at Illinois Central
description: Changes in toplevel man agement were announced yes terday by Eli Lilly & Co., a major producer of ethical drugs, and by the Mutual Bene fit Life Insurance Company, the nation's 14th largest insurance company.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17We went to New York. Everything was gigantic, overstated, melodramatic, infuriating, magnificent and Incomparable, includ ing the price of meals in restaurants. After a long term in Washington, it was momentarily quite wonderfula little intoxicating, as the anarchy of freedom must be to a man fresh out of prison.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I have just finished reading the let ters devoted to Transit: Are the Tracks Clear? [Jan. 11.]

title: KOOSMAN A VICTIM OF METS' PHASE I
description: The New York Mets opened the fiscal year on a noninfla tionary note yesterday when they signed their first player, Jerry Koosman, at a cut in pay.

title: YIELDS ADVANCE IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The credit markets, which forged ahead to low interest rate levels last week, took a step back yesterday.

title: EDWARD THORNLEY OF SMELTING FIRM
description: Edward William Thornley, re tired vice president of the American Smelting and Refin ing Company, died Saturday at his home, 16 Plymouth Road, Glen Rock, N. J. He was 84 years old.

title: Methodists Urged To Give $6Million To Black Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17A special study commission rec ommended today that the United Methodist Church pro vide $6million annually to help the denomination's 12 black colleges meet their mounting financial problems.

title: 1,500 at Services In Harlem Church For King's Birthday
description: An overflow crowd of more than 1,500 people gathered at the Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem yesterday for an interfaith service to com memorate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Eightyone public schools re portedly closed in honor of Dr. King.

title: Square Staubach Gives Credit to Spiritual Values
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 Roger Staubach brought a new dimension today to the image of a Super Bowl star a square dimension.

title: Bengali Wives Raped in War Are Said to Face Ostracism
description: GENEVA, Jan. 17 (AP)  A church relief official reported today that about 200,000 Ben gali wives who were raped by Pakistani soldiers during the war in East Pakistan last month were now ostracized by the Moslem communities and had virtually no place to turn to.

title: Heart Patients and Aged Warned on Climate Shift
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 A leading medical journal has warned editorially that sudden moves between cold and warm climates can be extremely hazardous for elderly people and patients with heart dis ease which is the leading killer of Americans.

title: Spock Plans Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The People's party announced today that Dr. Benjamin Spook would campaign in New Hamp shire to seek 1,000 signatures necessary to put his name on the state's Presidential ballot in November.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS STRIKE IN CANADA; ALL FIELDS CLOSED
description: Air traffic controllers through out Canada went on strike yesterday, closing the coun try's 116 airports to all but emergency flights and forcing the rerouting of hundreds of international flights that nor mally use Canadian airspace.

title: Scheuer Denies Charges
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 17Representative Scheuer said in a telephone interview in Belfast tonight that the Izvestia accusations were absolute malarkey.

title: Uncertain State Budget
description: The budget Governor Rockefeller has submitted to the State Legislature can best be described as uncertain. The figures add up to $7.9 billion, the same as those in the budget for the current fiscal year; and the neat accountant's columns of revenues and expenditures exactly balance each other. But this is a deceptive bal ance. There is trouble with the estimates of both rev enues and expenditures.

title: Betty Smith, Author, Dies at 75; Wrote Tree Grows in Brooklyn
description: SHELTON, Conn., Jan. 17 Betty Smith, author of the 1943 best seller A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, died at a convales cent home here today of pneu monia. She was 75 years old.

title: DELTEC SEES PROFIT FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: Deltec International, Ltd., en gaged in investment banking, meat packing and sugar mills, expects to be in the black in its first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, Clarence Dauphinot, president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting here. In the corresponding three months last year the company had a loss of $2,234,000 on revenues of $4,852,000.

title: Ghana Is Promised Eventual Elections
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 17 Col. I. K. Acheampong prom ised today that he and his fellow officers would relinquish control of Ghana to a demo cratically elected government as soon as circumstances per mit.

title: 6 DRAFT FOES ASSAIL U.S. AMNESTY PLANS
description: TORONTO, Jan. 17A panel of six Americans who described themselves as war resisters in Canada said today that they opposed the current amnesty proposals in the United States.

title: THEATERS' PACT ON PAY EXTENDED
description: The Limited Gross Agree ment, under which Broadway producers may obtain financial and working concessions from labor unions and the Dramatists Guild provided that the weekly grosses for their shows are limited to $25,000, has been ex tended through June 30 of this year.

title: IN THE NATION
description: White House Press Secretary Ronald L. Ziegler says President Nixon is working on the fifth or sixth draft of his State of the Union Message, and no wonder. If history is a guide, that message ought also to provide his basic platform for reelection.

title: Teachers End Strike Threat
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17Chicago's public school teachers voted today to cancel a citywide strike scheduled for tomorrow in a dispute with the Board of Education over economy meas ures that violated the union's contract.

title: Fiat Sales Increase
description: Sales of Fiat, S.P.A., topped $3billion in 1971 for the first time, the company reported yesterday. Fiat, Italy's largest auto manufacturer, sold 1,589, 000 vehicles last year, up 39, 000 from 1970. Sales totaled $3,088,737,000, up 5 per cent.

title: Fare Rise Plan by L.I.R.R. Assailed at Hearing Here
description: Unreasonable fare increases  some as high as 130 per centthe elimination of several forms of discount tickets, poor service and discrimination against lowincome riders were among the accusations yester day at a public hearing on pro posed fare increases on the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Zayyat Sees Jarring
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17Dr. Mohammed H. elZay yat, who is returning to Cairo to become Minister of State for Information, spent 35 min utes here today with Dr. Gun nar V. Jarring, the United Na tions special representative for the Middle East. He told news men that there were no new developments.

title: Coconut Desiccators Celebrating Their Trade
description: The Association of Philip pine Coconut Desiccators convened a twoday sym posium, a kind of coconut convention, in the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

title: BIG BOARD RALLIES AS DOW GAINS 4.44
description: The stock market got off to a slow start yesterday, but prices rallied in the final hour to close at their highest level of the session.

title: Books of The Times
description: Iris Murdoch used to teach philosophy, and it seems to have left her with a taste for toying with people's fates. In her novels, she is like a metaphysical practical joker, connecting her characters in such wanton and improbable ways that their lives seem no more than a series of freak ish and passionate accidents. She takes a special pleasure in frustrating any attempt at rational proceedings, as if these were only the delusions of grandeur of a con ceited animal. As a result, her people are often reduced to puppets in a philosophical Punch and Judy show, and while we may be amused, we are not convinced. Those of us who can still feel stubborn purpose, persistent as a toothache, throbbing in us, may even take offense at Miss Murdoch's eschatological flippancy.

title: W.H.A. Franchise Is Tentatively Set To Play in Garden
description: A full slate of 39 playing dates in Madison Square Gar den for next season has been offered to the New York fran chise in the fledgling World. Hockey Association and accept ed conditionally by Richard I. Wood, head of the franchise.

title: Witty Performance By Todd Bolender In a Robbins Ballet
description: Jerome Robbins's The Con cert is a genuinely funny ballet, and Todd Bolender is a witty and amusing dancer. The two were reunited Sunday after noon at the State Theater in a hilarious performance of the work as Mr. Bolender paid a guest visit to New York City Ballet.

title: DR. E. A. ROBINSON, RUTGERS CHAIRMAN
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 17Dr. Edward A. Robinson, chairman of the classical lan guages department at the Newark campus of Rutgers University since its formation in 1964, died of cardiac failure on Saturday in Overlook Hospi tal, Summit. He was 61 years old and lived at 276 Winthrop Terrace.

title: Justices to Rule on Busing at Schools Outside South
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The Supreme Court agreed to day to rule for the first time on the busing of school chil dren to reduce segregation in large cities outside the South.

title: Kennedy Says President Has Failed To Carry Out Promise of America
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, sounding very much like the Presidential candidate that he insists he is not, accused the Nixon Administration tonight of failing to carry out the bright promise of the American na tion.

title: Shop Talk
description: For years, Fred Leighton Imports, Ltd., has been syn onymous with Mexican fashions. True, the two stores  one in Greenwich Vil lage at 177 Mac Dougal Street, the other at 857 Lexington Avenue (65th Street) still stock a variety of be guiling Mexican fare, but added to it now is a fasci nating array of fashions and jewelry from all around the world. There are antique Greek vests, lively with handembroidery, that the store transforms into winter coats with the addition of Persian lamb ($225); magnificently embroidered Rumanian shifts (from $95); velvetlined capes from Spain ($145); caftans from India; dresses from Tur key; and a collection of re vamped Rumanian gypsy gear that was made for modern day boots.

title: Allied Chemical Corp.
description: The Allied Chemical Corpo ration estimated its 1971 profit before extraordinary credits at $1.87 a share and at $2 a share after the credits, a preliminary statement disclosed yesterday. This would mean a profit of about $51,530,108, up about 50 per cent from $43,062,000, or $1.56 a share, in 1970, before extraordinary gain, and $2.47 a share after the credit of 91 cents a share.

title: Taiwan Girls Are Wearing Out Basket
description: The Ya Tung girl's basket ball team of Taiwan, which has proved to be not only inscrutable but also unstop pable, winds up its brief New York tour tonight by taking on the Chuckles at 8 o'clock at the Pace College gymna sium.

title: OLYMPIC CHAMPION TO SWITCH EVENTS
description: Larry James is uncertain about the mood of black Ameri can track and field athletes for the Olympic Games this sum mer.

title: Moscow Sharply Rebukes Leading Economic Institute
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17The So viet Communist party disclosed today that it had issued a se vere reprimand to the nation's leading institute of economic re search for laxity in adhering to the party line.

title: EGYPT CRITICIZES U.S. ARMS ACCORD
description: CAIRO, Jan. 17Egypt's offi cial spokesman indicated a sharpening hostility toward the United States today as the country's new Premier, Dr. Aziz Sidky, put together a Cabinet for mobilization of the home front and intensive economic development.

title: Dockers' Strike Resumes On Coast After Talks Fail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 West Coast longshoremen went out on strike again this morn ing on the order of Harry Bridges, their leader, who acted in the face of threatened Federal intervention.

title: CONVICTS TO BE TOLD DATES FOR RELEASE
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI) The Adult authority voted 6 to 2 today to give every California convict a tentative release date so he can learn and earn his way out of prison.

title: STATE ASKS CHECK ON MONEYSWORTH
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's Consumer Frauds Bureau went to court yesterday against the consumer newslet ter Moneysworth, charging that its halfprice subscription offer may well be false, deceptive and misleading.

title: U.S. Plywood
description: Reflecting the increased re sults of the building materials and furnishings fields, U.S. Ply woodChampion Papers, Inc., raised earnings 21 per cent last year on a sales gain of 10.6 per cent, the annual report dis closed yesterday. Paper and al lied products had disappointing results, especially in the final two months of the year, the company said.

title: STEVENS UPHOLDS KENNEDY CENTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the board of the Kennedy Cen ter for the Performing, Arts, denied today that the $70mil lion building project had been mismanaged and said it was the best bargain the U. S. Government ever had.

title: CHARLES K. DICKSON
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 17Charles K. Dickson, long a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 73 years old. Mr. Dickson was a senior partner in the firm of Auchincloss, Parker & Redpath in New York City until his re tirement in 1969.

title: Teachers Postpone Strike Threatened For Port Chester
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 17A strike deadline set for this morning by the 268mem ber teachers union against eight public schools here was postponed today for 24 hours.

title: The Stage: Carmilla
description: When I first reviewed Wil ford Leach's Carmilla about a year ago, it was labeled a workinprogress, but actually the only thing unfinished about this Gothic chamber musical was the film accom panying and embellishing the narrative. It started to go up in flames during the perform ance, heightening the hor ror of the evening.

title: In Puerto Rican Artists Show, a Goal
description: Nine Puerto Rican artists have staged a welcomed in vasion of the New York headquarters of the Associ ated Councils of the Arts, 1564 Broadway. Hanging their paintings, photographs, wall sculptures and prints at the A.C.A.'s invitation, they have turned the offices into a firsttime art gallery that they hope will focus public attention on the work of Puerto Rican artists in New York.

title: ToolSteel Prices to Rise
description: The Carpenter Technology Corporation announced yester day that it would raise prices by 5 per cent on highalloy tool steels, and by 7 per cent to 8 per cent on lowalloy tool steels, effective Feb. 1. The company said the increases were the same that it had planned last August, which were canceled by the price freeze.

title: Some Send More Than One Gift To the Neediest Cases Fund
description: Although my husband and I sent a check earlier, we decided at year's end that we would like to make an additional contribution, wrote Mrs. Edward Kimball of Upper Montclair, N.J. The accompanying check for $500 was one of 315 contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, total ing $12,795.25, recorded yesterday.

title: Coast Guard Sleuth Traces Sea Polluters
description: SUNKEN MEADOW, L. I., Jan. 17Donald Alberts is a master sleuth who last year cracked more than 95 per cent of his cases.

title: Canada's Trade Surplus Off
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 17 (Reuters) Canada's 1971 merchandise trade surplus was $2,244,000, 000, Statistics Canada re ported today. This was down 25 per cent from $2,952,000,000 in 1970, a record. The 1971 trade surplus with the United States was 1,203,000,000, the agency said.

title: The American Condition
description: An election, like a hanging, powerfully concentrates a man's mind. When President Nixon reviews the state of the nation on Thursday before the returning Demo craticcontrolled Congress, both he and his audience will be keenly aware of the date which they have with the voters in November.

title: Kennedy Removes Name
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP)Senator Edward M. Ken nedy formally removed his name from Florida's March 14 Presidential primary ballot to day, saying his intention not to be a candidate was without qualification.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frank S. Sax has been named president of Abbey Rents, a nationwide renter of party and convalescent equipment.

title: SOVIET CONDEMNS 3 U.S. LEGISLATORS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17The So viet Government newspaper Iz vestia today accused members of a group of Congressmen, in cluding Representative James H. Scheuer of The Bronx, of subversive activities while on an official tour of educational institutions.

title: Open Admissions Are Revised To Prevent Ghettoized Colleges
description: The Board of Education re; solved last night to achieve a more equitable distribution of freshmen needing remedial work among the 19 colleges of the City University of New York next fall.

title: A CIVIC LEADER DIES AT QUEENS MEETING
description: A Staten Island civic leader collapsed while addressing a I meeting in Forest Hills, Queens, last night and died minutes later in an ambulance on the way to a nearby hospital.

title: Dance: Fille mal Gardee
description: Presumably Ballet Thea ter's new production of La Fille mal Garde was largely inspired by the presence of Natalia Makarova and Carla Fracci in the company. These twin but different charmers have already set their indi vidual seals upon the heroine of Copplia, and can now move on to Lise, the ill protected daughter of this funny old ballet's title.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Championship Won by AltmanLed Group
description: The Swiss Team Cham pionship that ended the Tri State Regional Champion ships at Grossinger, N.Y., Sunday was won not unex pectedly by the Precision team that won the last two Spingold National Team titles.

title: Cabinet in Israel Approves Record $4Billion Budget
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 (Reu ters)The Israeli Cabinet today approved a record budget of $4.03billion for the new fiscal year beginning April 1, nearly 15 per cent more than the cur rent fiscal year. About 40 per cent is earmarked for military expenditures.

title: WEST FIVE PICKED OVER EAST STARS
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 With the West squad heavily favored because of a size ad vantage at center, the top players in the National Basketball As sociation gathered here today for tomorrow night's 22d annual EastWest AllStar Game.

title: Always Trouble on the Docks
description: The renewal yesterday of last year's hundredday long shore strike in Pacific Coast ports reflects a triple break downin the processes of collective bargaining, in the effectiveness of the nation's statutory safeguards against strike emergencies and in the credibility of Federal wage controls.

title: COMMITMENT SET BY SUGAR GROUP
description: The executive committee of the International Sugar Organ ization ended a fiveday meeting with the announcement in Lon don yesterday that it would enforce its supply commitment clause at midnight, London time.

title: LISBON PROPOSES CHANGE IN AFRICA
description: LISBON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) Portugal has announced pro posals to designate her African provinces of Angola and Mo zambique as states and to allow them greater autonomy with out affecting the unity of the nation.

title: DEATH PENALTIES ARGUED IN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Attorneys for two convicted murderers and two convicted rapists asked the Supreme Court today to strike down their death sentences as cruel and unusual punishment and therefore unconstitutional.

title: ELECTION CHEERS FOES OF ALLENDE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 17 The victories of opposition can didates in two legislative by elections have brought a mo ment of euphoria to Chile's antiMarxists and a probable cabinet reorganization for Pres ident Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP IN DECEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  In dustrial production ended 1971 on a strong upward note, though part of the reason was a resumption of work in the coal mines, the Federal Re serve Board reported today.

title: U.S.L.T.A. TO ASK DELAY ON S.AFRICA
description: The United States opposed the recent reinstatement of South Africa to the Davis Cup and will ask South Africa to withdraw from the interna tional competition for at least this year, officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association disclosed yesterday.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Goldenson Is Chairman
description: Elton H. Rule, a 53yearold former Californian, was ap pointed president yesterday of American Broadcasting Com panies, Inc., in the beginning of a gradual transition of the company's affairs to younger men.

title: SEPARATE TRIAL SET BY BERRIGAN JUDGE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 17 (UPI)  United States District Judge R. Dixon Herman ruled today that one of the defend ants in the Berrigan conspiracy case be tried separately from the seven other defendants.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As usual, New Yorkers rang in the new year with Guy Lombardo and in creased subway fares. Whenever the transit contract expires, so does Mayor Lindsay's budget. But this year we had an additional treat. Bridge and tunnel tolls were also raised.

title: Landry May Trade Thomas; Star's Silence Stirs Tension
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 Tom Landry, the coach of the Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, indicated today that Duane Thomas would be traded if the controversial running back insists on main taining his virtual silence and aloof attiude.

title: Phone Company in Jersey Files New Rate Schedule With P.U.C.
description: NEWARK, Jan. 17  The New Jersey Bell Telephone Com pany has filed new rate sched ules with the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to bring in the $48.5million a year in new revenues the P.U.C has approved.

title: Rep. Rosenthal Attacks U.S. Policy on Madrid
description: MADRID, Jan. 17 Official United States support for the Spanish regime and neglect of the Spanish democratic opposi tion was sharply criticized today by the chairman of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee.

title: Walled Rooms Do Not a School Make
description: No special decorations  just the usual red carpeting, smokedglass mirrors, golden sconces and crystal chande lierswere in evidence when Dr. Harvey B. Scribner ar rived at the Public School 26 Annex in the Bronx yester day morning.

title: U.S. Declines Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Charles W. Bray 3d, the State Department spokesman, said to day that there would be no immediate comment on Repre sentative Rosenthal's state ments.

title: Coyote Hunters Lure Prey by Whistling Like a Dying Jackrabbit
description: ARTESIA, N. M., Jan. 17A deep chill lay on the New Mexico prairies this past weekend.

title: Bhutto Offers Title to Sheik
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 17President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan offered to day to cede leadership of his nation to Sheik Mujibur Rah man if that would reunite the eastern wing with West Pak istan.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 17(Reuters) The Australian open tennis championships may lose their main sponsor as a result of the dispute between the International Lawn Tennis Federation and the World Championships Tennis contract professionals.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said otday that Mr. Kaufman obtained a passport in San Francisco during the week of Dec. 20.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration received a $66million addition to a previously award ed Navy contract for longlead work on P3C aircraft, a land based longrange antisubmarine patrol plane, it was announced yesterday.

title: EDWARD F. FISHER, AUTO BODY MAKER
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17Edward F. Fisher, last survivor of the seven brothers who developed the Fisher Body Company into the auto body division of the General Motors Corporation, died today at the age of 80.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
NIXON ACTS TO END SECURITY LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 President Nixon has instructed his subordinates to make strong er efforts to prevent leaks of information on national secu rity matters, the White House said today.

title: Zambian President Assails U. S. Policy In Southern Africa
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 17 President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia criticized United States policy toward the whitedomi nated countries of southern Af rica today and warned that it would have a crucial effect on future AfricanAmerican rela tions.

title: White House Contract Given Without Bidding
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The White House ac knowledged today that a computer concern controlled by H. Ross Perot, a Texas millionaire and a friend of President Nixon, received without competitive bidding a $62,000 contract for work for the President's Domestic Council.

title: Ralston Purina
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (AP) Sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, were the highest quarterly re sults reported in the history of the Ralston Purina Company.

title: STATE WON'T FIGHT SCHOOL AID DECISION
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that the state would not appeal to the United States Su preme Court a ruling last week by three Federal judges that state law providing $33 million in state funds to parochial schools was unconstitutional.

title: RESERVE UNIT VOTED MODERATE GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in October to seek moderate growth in the various mone tary aggregates but rejected an aggressive move in that di rection, it was disclosed today.

title: Battle in Laos Said to Continue
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 17 (UPI)  Government sources said today that Laotian soldiers were still engaged in handto hand fighting with enemy forces for control of the ridge overlooking the key base at Long Tieng, southwest of the Plaine of Jarres.

title: Hearings to Weigh TV Violence Study
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Senator John O. Pastore indi cated today he was planning public hearings to clarify the Surgeon General's tentative and limited conclusions on the relationship between television and violence. The 300page re port was formally released this morning.

title: Six Private Bus Concerns in City To Raise Fares From 25c to 35c
description: The 25cent rare on six pri vate bus lines in the city, as well as the $1 fare on some express buses from outlying residential districts into Man hattan will have to be raised, the city's Director of Franchises said yesterday.

title: Furniture Prices Up 2 to 5% in Spring Line
description: Furnitureminded consum ers will find that they will be paying from 2 to 5 per cent more for new lines this spring as a result of numer ous changes instituted by producers since Phase Two went into effect.

title: 100 Protest Proposal to Extend Dump in the Croton Point Park
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 17About 100 protesters, many of them mothers with preschool children, gathered at dawn on a frozen field here this morning in an effort to block bulldozers from digging up part of a county park for a garbagedisposal landfill oper ation.

title: Library Division Reopens
description: Despite a $1.2million deficit, the main public library on Fifth Avenue reopened its sci ence and technology division yesterday, largely because of private contributions. The divi sion, which has one of the finest collections of its type in the world, with more than 700,000 books and documents, had been closed several weeks ago as an economy measure.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach's bil lings and sales for its last fiscal year were off 2.5 per cent, mostly because of the loss of the AlkaSeltzer busi ness, according to the agency. But the gross income was up.

title: Odetta and Rochester Ensemble Join in Carnegie Hall Program
description: Pop music and a symphony orchestra met headon Sunday night at Carnegie Hall in a pro gram titled Symphonic Soul. If everyone came out of the encounter a bit battered musi cally, they also managed to produce some pleasant sounds.

title: The Talk of New York
description: The probability distribu tion for the parameters of controversy in the life of the chairman of the statistics de partment at Bernard Baruch College is a mean zero. But the Alabama Legislature has introduced a noisy variable.

title: Amex and OvertheCounter Stocks Rise in Price
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market turned in strong performances yesterday as both lists made good advances in ac tive trading.

title: Representative to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) Representative W. R. Hull Jr., Democrat of Missouri, an nounced today that he will re tire from the House at the end of the 1972 session. Mr. Hull, 65 years old, will have completed 18 years of service.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: QUINCY, Mass., Jan. 17 Once in a while, when the roar of traffic on the high way a half mile away sub sided, we could hear the sound of the falling tide sucking seaward over vast mussel beds.

title: Death Penalty Statute Is Voided By 61 Vote in Jersey High Court
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17  The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down the state's death penalty today.

title: Where Girls Go to Leave Drugs Behind
description: GARRISON, N.Y.The community wasn't happy when the Rev. John Ben ton took over the 23room mansion set high on a hilltop here.

title: India Reports Return Of 3 Million Refugees
description: CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 17 (UPI)The number of East Bengali refugees that have been repatriated to East Paki stan has passed the three mil lion mark, or about onethird the total refugee population in India, the Ministry of Re habilitation said today.

title: Bank America Lifts Profit;
description: The nation's largest banking organization, the Bank America Corporation, reported yester day a 6.2 per cent gain in fourthquarter earnings before security transactions, but three bankholding companies in New York reported profit declines.

title: Basketball Poll COACHES' RATINGS
description: The top 20, with votes figured on a 10987654321 basis for first through 10th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost rec ords through games of last Saturday:

title: Foe's Supply Trail in Laos Pounded by U.S. Aircraft
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (AP)United States warplanes flew more than 200 strikes today against North Vietnamese supply routes and depots in Laos as part of an intensified campaign against reported enemy preparations for an offensive.

title: TEXTILE IMPORTERS WILL GET REFUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)  Importers will receive re funds for deposits made to cover the 10 per cent import surcharge for textiles shipped to the United States on or after Oct. 1, Treasury Secre tary John B. Connally said to day.

title: Macy's Sales Top $1Billion In a Year for the First Time
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., an nounced yesterday that its sales passed the $1billion level for the first time during the 52week period ended Jan. 8. The sales gain in reaching this mark was 8.1 per cent over the total for the compara tive yearearlier period.

title: Defense in Harlem Slaying Trial Rests After Calling One Witness
description: The case of four young men accused of having killed a Har lem shopkeeper in April, 1964, is expected to go to the jury this week.

title: To Employers, Bachelors Seem More Eligible These Days
description: The path to the executive suite has been dotted with roadblocks for the single man over 35, whose bache lor status often provokes questions about his stability and the inevitable kidding about his supposedly swing ing life style.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Jan. 11:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There's one institution which cur rently has the means to raise funds in the very large amounts required to provide, organize and operate mass transit facilities of the magnitude and complexity so urgently needed in the metropolitan area. That institution is the Port of New York Authority.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With reference to your Dec. 27 and 28 editorials The Farm Revolution, I am in complete accord that the pres ervation of the family owned and operated farm should be the top pri ority in our nation's agricultural policy. However, I believe that a much deeper understanding of the farm problem by both city and farm people is needed if we are indeed going to preserve the family farm.

title: Daisy Ashford Is Dead at 90; Wrote Young Visiters at 9
description: NORWICH, England, Jan. 17 (AP)  Daisy Ashford, who wrote a bestseller when she was 9 years old, died at the home of a daughter during the weekend, She was 90 years old and had given up her writing career when she was 13.

title: Dolphins Cheered in Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17 (UPI)Enthu siastic Miami Dolphins fans cheered their heroes tonight as the players arrived from New Orleans. Coach Don Shula told them he was bitterly disap pointed by the loss to Dallas. He felt the Dolphins had failed to play the type of football the fans expected. The crowd re plied, No, No.

title: A PHONE RATE RISE OF 9% ON AVERAGE GRANTED IN STATE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17The Pub lic Service Commission today approved a $160million in crease in telephone rates, averaging about 9 per cent more statewide for the consumer.

title: Air Force Black Cadets Display Culture
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 17They had eaten black eyed peas, cornbread and collard greens. They had danced to the black man's music, studied his art and watched his films.

title: S.E.C. TO GET VIEWS OF 6 STOCK GROUPS
description: Six major organizations in the securities industry have joined forces to make recom mendations to the Securities and Exchange Commission on the treatment of customers' credit balances and on the segregation of securities at brokerage firms.

title: A. C. Spectorsky,Playboy Aide, Author of Exurbanites, Dead
description: CHRISTIANSTED, Virgin Islands, Jan. 17 (AP)A. C. Spectorsky, associate publisher of Playboy magazine, died to day in a St. Croix hospital. He was 61 years old. Burial was at sea.

title: 23 Accused of Smuggling 1,500 Lbs. of Heroin Here
description: Twentythree men were charged here yesterday with smuggling 1,500 pounds of heroin into the United States during the last two years in one of the largest narcotics op erations ever uncovered.

title: He Tells Full Story of Arrest and Detention
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 16 He kissed his weeping wife and children goodby, telling them what they knew too wellthat he might never return. Then the West Pakistani soldiers prodded him down the stairs, hitting him from behind with their rifle butts. He reached their jeep and then, in a reflex of habit and defiance, said: I have forgotten my pipe and tobacco. I must have my pipe and tobacco!

title: Students Clash With the Police in Madrid
description: MADRID, Jan. 17Madrid's two universities were paralyzed today as striking students fought policemen on campus and held lightning demonstra tions in various parts of the city.

title: The Economic Future: II
description: WASHINGTON  The longerterm projection, published by the Council of Economic Advisers in January, 1969, and repeated last year, was that in the period aheadup to 1976 the average annual growth of real G.N.P. would be slightly above 4 per cent. If true, this would present an obvious improvement over the actual longterm performance of the economy. In the last twenty years the growth rate has averaged 3.7 per cent.

title: SOUTHERN COMPANY SEES '71 DROP IN NET
description: The Southern Company's consolidated net income for 1971 slipped to an estimated $96million, or $1.71 a share, from the 1970 net income of $100.7million, or $1.94, Alvin W. Vogtle Jr., president, dis closed yesterday.

title: SEMIFINAL PAIRINGS SET FOR DAVIS CUP
description: LONDON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) The draw for the interzone semifinals in the 1972 Davis Cup tennis tournament was an nounced today.

title: SUSPECTS IN ULSTER FLEE PRISON VESSEL
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 17Seven detained men escaped from a prison ship in Belfast harbor tonight by swim ming to shore and hijacking a bus, a Government spokesman said.

title: BACHE PRESIDENT SEES RECORD NET
description: Bache & Co., Inc., the na tion's secondlargest investment concern, probably will report record earnings for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, according to Harry A. Jacobs Jr., presi dent.

title: Won Instant Acclaim
description: The courtyard tree that little Francie Nolan watched for sea son after season from her tenement's fire escape and the teeming squalor of the Wil liamsburg streets in which Betty Smith placed her heroine shadowed and shaded the novelist's professional and pri vate life.

title: 350 Soviet Jews Arrive in Israel on El Al 747 Jet
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 17 (UPI) An El Al jet ferried 350 So viet Jews to Israel today. It was the biggest single group of Soviet Jewish immigrants ever to fly to what they con sider to be their homeland. Debarking, the arrivals shouted, Shalom to wait ing relatives, some of them in tears.

title: Bobby Allison Honored
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 17 Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., who won 10 races last season on the Grand National circuit of the National Associ ation for Stock Car Auto Rac ing, was honored here tonight as auto racing's driver of the year. The occasion was the an nual awards dinner of the Na tional Motorsports Press Asso ciation.

title: Times Receives Letter Warning Of Bombs in Safe Deposit Boxes
description: The New York Times has be latedly received a copy of a let ter made public 10 days ago telling of the placement of long fuse time bombs in safe deposit boxes in nine banks in New York, Chicago and San Fran cisco.

title: Two Soviet Fishing Vessels Are Seized by Coast Guard
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 17 (AP) Two Soviet fishing vessels, one bearing the commander of an 80ship fleet, were seized today by the United States Coast Guard near St. Matthew's Island in the Bering Sea.

title: White House to Press Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The White House said today it would press Congress for legislation to end the West Coast dock strike.

title: Book Sales Soar for a Fable of a Seagull
description: Published 15 months ago to no notice or advertising, a photographically illustrated 93page adult table with a curious history has become one of the country's most eagerly bought books. It is Jonathan Livingston Sea gull, and it has sold 142,500 copies to date at $4.95 each.

title: ALI CELEBRATES BIRTHDAY IN RING
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 17At prices as inflated as his once trim belly, Muhammad All re turned to New York tonight for a pair of threeround exhibi tions against a sparring partner, Alonzo Johnson, and a 6foot 7inch Philadelphian named Spi der Owens.

title: The Economic Future: II
description: WASHINGTONThe single sixyear Presidential term could very easily become an instrument to disrupt one of society's most important ecological systemsthe relationship of political forces which sustains the national unity.

title: FINO URGES ?? TO AID DRUG FIGHT
description: State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino of the Bronx called on his colleagues on the judiciary yesterday to join him in a crusade to impose maxi mum sentences on small fry narcotics pushers as a means of cutting off the outlets of major drug dealers.

title: 1,000 Cars Tagged On the West Side After Police Order
description: The police of the West 100th Street station house handed out about 1,000 tickets for illegal parking in a heavily populated portion of the Upper West Side over the weekend, it was dis closed last night.

title: Insiders Give Trading Reports On Kaiser Steel Canadian Unit
description: TORONTO, Jan. 17The On tario Securities Commission re ceived today insider trading reports from 18 officers or directors of Kaiser Resources Ltd., a British Columbia coal mining venture, and its parent the Kaiser Steel Corporation of Oakland, Calif.

title: Dollar Sets New Lows On European Markets
description: LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP)The dollar slumped to new lows in Europe today amid signs that devaluation a month ago had failed to restore confidence in the currency.

title: Subpoena in Inquiry On Pentagon Papers Withdrawn by U.S.
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The Federal Government said today that it had withdrawn its sub poena of the financial records of the Unitarian Universalist Association in connection with a grand jury investigation of the distribution of the Pentagon papers.

title: Donegan to Retire May 1 After 21 Years as Bishop
description: The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan announced last night that he would retire May 1 after 21 years as Bishop of the 10county Episcopal Diocese of New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dustoffs Will Be in Vietnam as Long as G.I.'s Are
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17  The dustoffs, un armed Army helicopters that evacuate wounded Ameri can and South Vietnamese soldiers while giving them emergency treatment, will be in Vietnam as long as there are any United States troops here.

title: Incumbent Nixon Still Faces a Difficult Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Nixon enters his campaign for reelection with all the advantages of incum bency but still burdened by the fact that he is a minority President leading a minority party.

title: Merger News
description: The Southern Railway Com pany announced yesterday that it had reached an understand ing looking toward a taxfree acquisition of the Norfolk Southern Railway Company, one of the few remaining in dependent carriers in the South. The Norfolk Southern would be merged into one ormore of Southern Railway's subsidi aries. The Norfolk Southern operates approximately 625 miles of railroad insoutheastern Virginia and in the eastern and Piedmont areas of North Carolina between Norfolk, Va., and Charlotte, N. C.

title: HUGHES AIDE ASKS U.S. TAX INQUIRY
description: The chief counsel of the Hughes Tool Company asked the Internal Revenue Service yesterday to investigate the al leged payment of about $650, 000 from the McGrawHill Book Company in checks made out to H. R. Hughes and said How ard R. Hughes would not pay taxes on it because he had not received it.

title: REED CHAMBERS, WORLD WAR I ACE
description: Reed M. Chambers, a World War I ace who retired in 1968 as chairman of United States Aviation Underwriters, which manages the U.S. Aircraft In surance Group, died on Sunday aboard his yacht at St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands. He was 77 years old.

title: McCracken a Director At Kresge, Intertype
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17 (AP) Paul W. McCracken, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Ad visers, was elected today to the boards of directors of the S. S. Kresge Company in Detroit and the Harris Intertype Corporation in Cleveland.

title: Swaziland to Ban Immoral Sex Between Races
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 17Swaziland, large ly surrounded by racialsegre gationist South Africa, is planning to follow her neigh bor's lead in banning immoral sex between blacks and whites.

title: Colgate to Raise Tuition
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 17 Colgate University announced today that it would raise its tuition by $79 next year. The present annual tuition is $2,855.

title: Construction Foreman Dies In Manhole Blast Here
description: A New York Telephone Com pany construction foreman died in a fire yesterday in a man hole at 178th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, the Fire De partment reported.

title: JAPAN WELCOMES PEKING TRADE BIDS
description: TOKYO, Jan. 17  Reports that China is interested in doing business with Japan's state owned railroad system and her automobile industry received a favorable response from Japa nese officials today.

title: I.R.S. Spot Checks Show TwoThirds Of Stores Violate PricePosting Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  About twothirds of the retail establishments inspected by the Internal Revenue Service dur ing the last two weeks were in violation of Government price posting regulations, a spokes man for the service reported today.

title: Muskie Wins Support of Senator Hughes of Iowa
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa, who gave up his own bid for the Democratic Presi dential nomination last sum mer, announced today that he would support Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: 30% Rise in Absenteeism Laid To Flu, Other Respiratory Ills
description: An upsurge of influenza and other respiratory diseases was blamed yesterday for a 30 per cent increase in absenteeism at the city's schools, offices and factories.

title: Market Place: Should A.T.&T. Be Broken Up?
description: Is American Telephone profitblighted and thus a poor performer in the stock market? Sol Hyman of Brook lyn doesn't believe it. He writes:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your criticism of the Administra tion's Peterson Report was well founded. However, what you over looked was that the whole Nixon New Economic Policy and Peterson's Coun cil of International Economic Policy are the result of the Presidential Commission on International Trade and Investment Policy, whose July report was embargoed until last Sept. 13.

title: 2 OFFICIALS DIFFER OVER CIVIL SERVICE
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's denunciation of the Civil Service system last week as inhibiting the promotion of strong senior officers was criti cized yesterday by a former highranking police official and lauded by a high suburban po lice commander.

title: Methadone Poisonings of Young Are Causing Doctors Concern
description: With methadone maintenance programs spreading rapidly across the country, some med ical authorities are becoming concerned over an apparently small but disquieting phenome non: the sometims fatal poison ing of children who swallow their parents' methadone, which is often premixed in fruit drinks and stored in the refrigerator.

title: Chicago Plans Market For Currency Trading
description: Chicago Mercantile Ex change members yesterday approved the organization of a new exchange, to be known as the International Money Market of the Chicago Mer cantile Exchange, for the pur pose of trading in foreign currency.

title: Minnie Obermeier, 52 Years In the City School System
description: Minnie Obermeier, an assist ant superintendent of schools here from 1939 until her retire ment in 1953, died yesterday in the Riverdale Nursing Home at the age of 88.

title: A Too ClearCut Decision
description: A laudable effort by the Council on Environmental Quality to curb clearcutting in the national forests has suffered an embarrassingly quick death. Three days after it became known that the C.E.Q. had proposed an Execu tive order laying down certain limitations on the prac tice of clearcutting, that agency itself was obliged to announce that the proposal had been dropped.

title: Gulfstream Opens in Glory That Once Was Hialecih's
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 17  After 25 years of legal wrangling, Gulfstream Park finally began getting some royal patronage today to match the splendor of its 500 royal palm trees.

title: Equipment Failure Leads Bethlehem to Lay Off 600
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17 (AP)  The Bethlehem Steel Corpora tion laid off 600 workers at its nearby Lackawanna mill today because of an equipment break down.

title: Advertising:
description: There's nothing quite like a visit to a medically oriented ad agency to begin the week.

title: ULSTER PARADES BANNED FOR YEAR
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 18In a move that out raged militant Protestants, the Northern Ireland Government today ordered a oneyear ban on all parades.

title: U.S. Acts to Block Amphetamines From Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs took action today against what it called the largest exporter of amphe tamines in an effort to curb the heavy illicit return flow of the drug from Mexico into this country.

title: Wallace Gets Spot On Florida Ballot; Rep. Mills Omitted
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP)  George C. Wallace, cautioned not to play games with Democrats, was approved tonight for inclusion in a 10 man Democratic field on the March 14 Presidential primary ballot in Florida.

title: Advertising:
description: If you want to become an instant publisher in the mass magazine field why don't you talk to Robert A. Joyce. No. You better wait a couple of years in case his idea doesn't work.

title: Police Halt 2 Protests Against Zionist Parley
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 (UPI) Policemen broke up to demonstrations and arrested 30 persons today before the opening of the 28th Zionist Congress here.

title: The Dance: Eccentrique
description: ECCENTRIQUE, (Premiere). Choreog raphy, Eliot Feld; music, Igor Stravin sky; scenery, Oliver Smith; costumes, Frank Thompson; lighting, Jennifer Tipton; conductor, Akira Endo. Pre sented by the American Ballet Theater at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Teachers in Port Chester Go on Strike
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 18The Port Chester Teachers Association went on strike this ?? after 14 months of ne gotiationsincluding a final 33 hours of nonstop bargaining ?? to produce a contract settlement.

title: PRICE RISE IS SET BY DOW CHEMICAL
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would raise prices for certain of its plastic resins used in a variety of engineered parts by a range of 0.50 cent to 0.75 cent a pound, in railcar quantities, ef fective Feb. 15.

title: BRUINS' CHEEVERS STOPS BLUES, 20
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (UPI) Gerry Cheevers blanked the St. Louis blues tonight for his first shutout of the season and goals by Don Marcotte and Phil Esposito gave the Boston Bruins a 20 victory.

title: Sad State of the State
description: The state of New York State, if one can judge from Governor Rockefeller himself, is tired and disappointed. The Governor's annual message depicts the state as burdened with problems that it cannot possibly solve and costs that it cannot continue to bear.

title: Burroughs Sets Mark Sperry Net Slips
description: It was a busy day in the elec tronic data processing industry yesterday as the Burroughs Cor poration announced record earn ings for 1971. the Sperry Rand Corporation reported a decline in profits for the fiscal third quarter and fiscal ninemonth periods and Honeywell, Inc., in troduced a major new comput er family.

title: Shoemaker, Pineda Draw Suspensions at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker and Al varo Pineda, jockeys, Were sus pended for five racing days by Santa Anita's stewards today for failing to keep a straight course in races Saturday.

title: 12 Bodies Found After Fire
description: TYRONE, Pa., Jan. 18 (AP) The bodies of 12 persons, in cluding nine found today, have been pulled from beneath the rubble of the Pennsylvania Hotel, which was destroyed by fire on Sunday.

title: Jan Usiny, Czech Aide, Dies; Jailed by Fascists and Reds
description: Word was received yesterday of the death on Jan. 8 of Jan Usiny, the former Vice Premier of Czechoslovakia, who was ar rested and imprisoned by both the Fascist and Communist re gimes. He died in the village of Raksa, in northeastern Czecho slovakia, at the age of 75.

title: ROSS BAGDASARIAN, ACTOR, SONG WRITER
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP)Ross Bagdasarian, an actor and song writer best known for Come ona My House and The Chipmunk Song, died Sunday at his home here. He was 52 years old.

title: Cindy Nelson Injures Hip in Downhill And Loses Bid to Compete in Olympics
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland Jan. 18The Olympic torch went out for two more skiers today.

title: Roosa Sees Gradual Currency Reflow
description: Robert V. Roosa, a former Under Secretary of the Treas ury for Monetary Affairs, said yesterday that he expected the reflow of dollars to the United States to reach between $5 billion and $10billion by the end of the year as a result of last month's realignment of international currencies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefellers Offer 38 Homes On Estate for Sale to Tenants
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan, 18In a possible prelude to the transformation of one of the nation's last great estates, 38 homes on the Rockefeller family preserve in Pocantico Hills have been offered for sale to their present occu pants, mostly Rockefeller friends and employes who now rent.

title: Article 1  No Title
