description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (AP) Denying that there is a So viet Jewish problem, Rus sia's controlled press stepped up its campaign today against the 28th Zionist Congress in Jerusalem. Tass, the Soviet press agency, called the con ference a provocation against the Soviet state.

title: Football and Baseball Stars Limber Up Damaged Knees for $30,000 Golf Event
description: Three of the most cele brated damaged knees got together here yesterday to beat the drums for a golf tournament. But their owners Joe Namath, John Unitas and Tommie Ageetook the occasion to promise that they would be back in ac tion next season in their own sports.

title: Zionists Divided as Parley Opens
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 Seventyfive years after Theo dor Herzl assembled a band of Jewish idealists in Switzerland for the first Zionist congress, Zionism has become many things to many people.

title: BIG UNION READY TO BACK MUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Senator Edmund S. Muskie is scheduled to get his first major labor union endorsement for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation tomorrow when the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Em ployes comes out for him.

title: Bishop C. AsapansaJohnson Of Bethel Church on ?? 81
description: Bishop C. AsapansaJohnson, pastor of Bethel Community Church on Staten Island and a former president of the Inter denominational Ministers Meet ing of Greater New York, died Sunday in St. Francis Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived at 29 Livingston Ave nue on Staten Island.

title: Rhodesian Blacks Again Violently Protest White Rule
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 18Blacks staged violent dem onstrations for the third day to day in the industrial city of Gwelo, and officials there said a black youth died of chest in juries suffeized in a fall while fleeing the police.

title: Sugar Futures Fall in Trading Dominated by StopLoss Selling
description: Prices of world No. 11 sugar futurea declined by from 10 points to 32 points yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Ekchange as trading was dominated by stoploss selling. A point is a hundredth of a cent.

title: STANLEY PRAGER, DIRECTOR, WAS 54
description: Stanley Prager, director of Come Blow Your Horn and many other plays for Broad way and television, died yes terday on a business trip to Los Angeles. He was 54 years old and lived at 210 West 90th Street.

title: Work on Waterfront Terminal Ahead of Second Target Date
description: An official of the company supervising construction of the city's new cargo terminal on the Brooklyn waterfront said yesterday that work was about a month ahead of schedule.The terminal, designed to handle both container and con ventional breakbulk vessels, had been scheduled for com pletion by midJuly. Joseph Byrne, executive vice president of the Northeast Marine Ter minal Company, Inc., said yes terday, that the hope now was that the installation would be finished by June 15.

title: Electronics Group Asks Freer Trade
description: Leading executives in the United States consumer elec tronics business announced yesterday the creation of an in dustrywide committee to seek Government action on the re loyal of barriers to fair inter national trade.

title: Text of Mayor's Statement on Governor
description: Following is the text of a statement by Mayor Lindsay on Governor Rockefeller's State of the State message:

title: Militant Dock Leader Harry Renton Bridges
description: Man in the News

title: A Private U.S. Agency To Aid Bengali Students
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 18 The International Rescue Committee, a private Amer ican relief organization, has made plans to spend a million dollars and possibly more to help the Bengali intellectual community recover from the shattering effects of the struggle against West Paki stan.

title: DOWDY, CONVICTED, TO LEAVE POLITICS
description: ATHENS, Tex., Jan. 18Rep resentative John Dowdy, Demo crat, bowed out of elective pol itics today when he wrote friends he would not be a can didate for reelection. He is completing his 11th term.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill exempting 33,000 elderly households under the city's rentcontrol program from scheduled rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent. The bill was passed unanimously two weeks ago by the City Council.

title: STUDENTS IN MADRID PROTEST FOR 2D DAY
description: MADRID, Jan. 18 (AP)Pro testing students pelted police with stones, blocked traffic and smashed windows today for the second day in a row. Officials of the University of Madrid met to consider closing the institu tion.

title: Crafts Museum Wanted Some Ideas, and Public Supplied Them
description: For 10 days earlier this month, a large yellow and orange poster outside the Museum of Contemporary Crafts proclaimed: Jdeas Wanted.

title: Gloria Swanson Stars as a Visitor
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 18 Gloria Swanson did a lunchtime guest shot at the Actors Fund Home here to day. Her visit was something of a cross between a reunion with nearcontemporaries and a health department inspec tion.

title: Buckley Lands in Cambodia For 2 Days of Fact Finding
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  Senator James Buckley, ConservativeRepubli can of New York, arrived here today on a twoday visit dur ing a private factfinding tour of Asia.

title: Bhutto a Whirlwind on Mission To Restore a Shattered Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 18  Blending the styles of shrewd diplomat, benevolent despot and circus barker, Zul fikar Ali Bhutto has showered a glittering trail of oratory across Pakistan during his first month as President, hoping to breathe life into a demoralized nation.

title: Newfoundland Chief Sworn
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Jan. 18 (Canadian Press) Frank Moores, 38 years old, was sworn today as Premier of Newfoundland as his Conserva tives took over the provincialgovernment for the first time since Newfoundland joined Can ada in 1949. Earlier, Joseph R. Smallwood, the Liberal Pre mier since 1949, resigned. His party narrowly lost an election, in October.

title: 2 Youths Charged With Plot to Poison Water of Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18The po lice arrested two youths here today and charged them with conspiracy to commit murder by plotting to poison the city's drinking water and spread deadly diseases throughout the Midwest.

title: Army Tightens Training; Jogging Is In, Beer Is Out
description: FORT MONROE, Va., Jan. 18 After a brief experiment in liberalization, the Army has de cided to tighten up again on its eightweek basic training course, that oncehidebound device used to transform soft, sloppy civilians into hardened, disciplined warriors.

title: Italy's Designers Decide to Play It Safe and Send Those Wild Styles to the Attic
description: ROME, Jan. 18At any time of year, Rome is a love ly place to visit, but the peo ple who live here insist life gets fairly dull in the win ter.

title: Bridge: Two Tall Partners Combine Skill With Exceptional Height
description: A world record for the tall est bridge partnership was set last week in the Tri State Regional Championships when Jim Linhart of New York, height 6 feet 9 inches, played with Harry Stappen beck of Uniondale, L. I., 611, in the Men's Pair event. On the diagramed deal they were apparently the only pair to make a contract with the NorthSouth cards.

title: GOLAR RESPONDS TO PROJECT FOES
description: Simeon Golar, chairman of the city's Housing Authority, promised yesterday that care ful screening of tenants for the controversial lowincome project in Forest Hills, Queens, would hold the welfare cases there to less than half the average for the city's projects and would not injure the mid dleclass neighborhood.

title: KENNEDY BIDS U.N, HELP IN INDOCHINA
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy proposed last night that the United Nations be requested to undertake a systematic effort to restore and rehabilitate the people of North and South Viet nam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: ExRep. Harold O. Lovre, 67; Was Unseated by McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  Former Representative Harold O. Lovre, Republican of South Dakota, died last night of cancer at a suburban nursing home. He was 67 years old.

title: Job Market Is Improving For the College Graduate
description: The worst decline in job openings for college graduates since the Depression of the nineteenthirties appears to have ended.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe strategic importance of Malta is measured differently by every interested nation. For Britain the is land lost much value when the British Empire was dismantled and London ceased believing that God was an Eng lishman and the road to India must be kept open.

title: CLEAN AIR TENNIS GETS A TOP FIELD
description: Vitas Gerulaitis has no vi sions of joining Jim Connors and other young American play ers who are ditching college tennis careers for the new rich es of the pro circuit.

title: 8 INDICTED BY CITY IN LOAN SCANDALS
description: The former director of the Municipal Loan Fund and seven borrowers have been in dicted by a New York County grand jury.

title: BIG BOARD SHOWS A BROAD ADVANCE
description: The stock market surged ahead yesterday in active trad ing and closed with solid and widespread gains.

title: Books of The Times
description: GOSHAWK SQUADRON. By Derek Robinson. 246 pages. Viking. $6.95.

title: LESLIE JACOBS JUNGER
description: Mrs. Leslie Jacobs Junger, a commercial artist and illustra tor of children's books and the wife of Morton Junger, head of an advertising concern, died Monday of cancer in Beth Is rael Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived at 151 East 83d Street.

title: Isaacs Named Sports Editor
description: GARDEN CITY, Jan. 18 (AP)Stan Isaacs, a reporter and columnist for Newsday since 1954, has been named sports editor of the suburban New York daily. He replaces Dick Clemente, who is moving to Florida. Al Cohn, Newsday's entertainment editor since 1970, has been named Sunday sports editor.

title: Fresh Effort on Malta
description: The good offices of the Atlantic Alliance, in the form of SecretaryGeneral Joseph Luns, plus some gentle pressures on Britain by the United States and others, have produced a new round of negotiations with Malta. It is too early, however, to assess the chances for agree ment allowing continued use of military facilities on Malta by Britain and NATO andvastly more impor tant the denial of those facilities to the Soviet Union.

title: KENNEDY CRITICIZED FOR ATTACK ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) Republicans struck back to day at Senator Edward M. Ken nedy for his attack yesterday on President Nixon and his record.

title: U.S. Reports MIG Attack on jets Over Laos Failed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Jan. 18 (AP)  The United States command reported to day that two North Vietnamese MIG jets darted across the border into Laos yesterday and fired three missiles at two American fighterbombers but missed.

title: Drums of Chemicals Washed Ashore Alarm Britons
description: LONDON, Jan. 18Scores of drums of potentially dangerous chemicals have been washing ashore on Britain's southwest coast, causing alarm among residents and concern in Lon don.

title: Effectiveness of Flu Shots Now Discounted by Expert on Viruses
description: If you haven't been hit by the A strain yetor another of the influenza and respira tory viruses flitting abouta flu shot is probably not nec essary, a Health Department expert said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CIGARETTE ADS UP IN PUBLICATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Cigarette manufacturers tripled their expenditures for newspa per, magazine and outdoor ad vertising last year, shifting more than $132million from radio and television.

title: SUPERFECTA PAYS RECORD $13,680
description: WESTBURY, L, I., Jan. 18 A record superfecta of $13,680 featured the proceedings at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. John T. Ace finished first in the eighth race, the event on which the superfecta is based. His win price was $26.60 and he was driven by Robert Bostic.

title: DE ZAYAS FEATURES LUTE AND THEMORRO
description: Earlier this season, Rodrigo de Zayas gave two concerts using the many Renaissance lutes in his collection. On Mon day, in his third and last pro gram in Tully Hall, he per formed on a German baroque lute and a late16thcentury theorbo.

title: BankAmerica Proposes 2for1 Stock Split
description: Earnings reports by major banking organizations, which have been wrestling with a growing squeeze on profits, continued yesterday to show a mixed pattern for the fourth quarter of 1971.

title: Athens Says Former Leaders Will Not Be Allowed to Return to Politics, Even If Elections Are Held
description: ATHENS, Jan. 18The Gov ernment's chief spokesman said tonight that the leaders of Greek political parties, made inactive since the military coup of 1967, would not be allowed to return to political life even if elections were held.

title: G.E. Aide Cautions On Peril to Power
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 18A former head of the Na tional Aeronautics and Space Administration told 100 leaders of the electricutility industry here today that there was an alarming parallel between what happened in recent years to the railroad industry and what could happen to the power business.

title: Notes on People
description: William L. Waller was sworn in yesterday as Mis sissippi's 56th Governor in ceremonies on the steps of the Capitol in Jackson. He promised a progressive ad ministration aimed at giving the Magnolia State a new measure of national promi nence. It is my goal that Mississippi will be as popular and respected as any state at the end of these four years, said Mr. Waller. He was sworn in by state Supreme Court Judge Tom Brady, who achieved noto riety in the South in the nineteenfifties with a book called Black Monday, an attack on the United States Supreme Court's 1954 school desegregation decision.

title: Auschwitz Gas Chambers' Designer on Trial in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Jan. 18Walter Dejaco, who designed and built the gas chambers and cremation furnaces in Ausch witzBirkenau, the largest Nazi death camp in occupied Poland, went on trial before an Austrian jury here today. The 63yearold former SS officer, an architect by pro fession, was first denounced to the Austrian authorities in June, 1961, but continued to live in Reutte, in the Tyrol, where he worked in his fields for almost 10 years before being taken into custody. Dejaco and his former aide, Fritz Karl Ertl, 64, are ac cused of direct complicity in the premeditated and vi cious murder of three mil lion European Jews between 1941 and 1945. In addition, Dejaco is said to have com mitted several individual mur ders. The maximum sentence in Austria is life imprisonment, the death penalty having been abolished. Both defendants pleaded not guilty.

title: Sickle Cell Tests Begun in High School By a Group of Black Medical Students
description: A group of black students of medicine and nursing, who be gan working enthusiastically last fall to set up a high school based screening program for sickle cell anemia, began testing yesterday.

title: Pros Win in Last Second
description: DALLAS, Tan. 18 (AP) Charlie Williams, who scored 39 points, hit a layup with a second left to push the Mem phis Pros to a 9694 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals to night.

title: DATA SAID TO PUT MYLAI TOLL AT 347
description: Seymour Hersh, the Pulitzer Prizewinning journalist who first wrote in detail about the massacre of civilians at Mylai 4, has reported that, according to Army documents, 347 men, women and children were killed in the South Vietnamese hamlet by American troops. The usually accepted figure had been under 200.

title: ARNOLD von BORSIG
description: Arnold von Borsig, a photog rapher, who specialized in art and nature subjects, died Fri day of a heart attack in Lenox Hill. Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 53 West 74th Street.

title: Volcker Unperturbed by Money Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The Treasury's top monetary official said today he saw no reason for concern at the re cent weakening of the dollar against some foreign curren cies in the foreign exchange markets.

title: Congress, Back With Heavy Schedule, Is Off to a Fast Start
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The 92d Congress reconvened today with the Democratic lead ers of the House and Senate striking the common theme that legislating should be placed ahead of politicking.

title: The Gloves Are Off
description: News Analysis

title: The Rivers of England
description: Over the next five years the British Government plans to revive for England and Wales something of Thames's translucent stream, Shakespeare's own Avon and the babbling Wye. It is fitting that this comprehensive and coherent program to restore a nation's riversat a cost of $3.8 billionshould take place in the country that launched the Industrial Revolution. For it was that vast upheaval that was in time to bring desolation to so many of the lovely waterways of the world.

title: WASTE IS DENIED ON ROTHKO ESTATE
description: The three executors of the estate of the late Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter who committed suicide in 1970, responded yesterday to a petition charging that they conspired with a promi nent art gallery to defraud and waste the assets of the artists estate.

title: POLICE SCRUTINY OF RADICALS RISES
description: Because the conduct or rhe toric of some political groups may pose a threat to life, property or governmental ad ministration, the New York Police Department in recent years has increased the use of undercover agents to infiltrate such groups.

title: Lucas Upset Here, 76, 63
description: Warren Lucas, the second seeded player, was upset by Harold Mollens, 76, 63, in the third round of the Clean Air Classic qualifying tournament at the 145th Street armory here yesterday. Steve Gottlieb, another seeded player, lost to Chuck Blackwell, 61, 62.

title: TAIPEI ASSAILS PLAN TO END AID FROM U.N.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 18 (UPI) Nationalist China condemned as outrageous today a Chi nese Communist demand that the United Nations end all aid to Taiwan.

title: Knapp Unit Witness Indicted for Perjury
description: A towtruck operator who was acclaimed last October for his testimony before the Knapp Commsision about police cor ruption was indicted on per jury charges here yesterday for his accusations against two patrolmen.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach has found an acquisition in Ha waii and Foote, Cone & Bel ding has found one in Puerto Rico. Well, at least the weather's right for it.

title: Sad Plan for Colleges
description: Recession and austerity confront the state's public and private colleges and universities with the same critical fiscal problems. The threat of disaster may tech nically take different shapebudget cuts for public institutions and deficits for private onesbut the ulti mate consequence for both is a decline in quality, restricted educational opportunities and even the specter of bankruptcy.

title: Legal Maneuvers Delay GravelEllsberg Inquiry Another Week
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18The Fed eral grand jury investigation into the release and publication of the Pentagon papers became bogged down again today in a tangle of new legal maneuvers by four recalcitrant witnesses and by Senator Mike Gravel and Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISFascism was a movement of extreme nationalism. It no longer exists in Europe because we have passed beyond narrow nationalism to the making of European union. Fascism was also an explosion against intol erable human conditions of the twen ties and thirties. Servicemen returned from the trendies of the first war with a promise from Lloyd George of a land fit for heroes to live in. Instead they got unemployment and the slums. My generation felt betrayed, and they were right.

title: VANDERBILT DOWNS CORNELL BY 10180
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 18 (AP) Vanderbilt overwhelmed Cor nell, 10180, in an interconfer ence basketball game tonight.

title: Pacers Top Condors, 130116
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18 (AP) The Indiana Pacers defeated the Pittsburgh Condors, 130 116, tonight despite George Thompson's gamehigh total of 30 points.

title: Paint Poison Curb Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) Senators Edward M. Ken nedy, Democrat of Massachu setts, and Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, proposed ligislation today to combat leadbased paint poison ingan affliction that kills 200 children and cripples thousands of others each year.

title: Whither U.S. Economy?
description: Economic Analysis

title: HARRY C. FRANCE, 81, FINANCE COLUMNIST
description: Harry C. France, who wrote a syndicated weekly financial column used by 150 newspa pers, died Monday night at his home, 186 Riverside Drive, after a brief illness. He was 81 years old.

title: NEWARK WILL CUT PAYROLLS BY 379
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18The city will lay off 379 employes by May 5 and curtail some serv ices to balance a $97.5million municipal operation budget pro posed for 1972, but city offi cials said current problems were simply a forerunner of what they termed a looming financial disaster in 1973.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Jury in Chicago Indicts Suspect in BankBomb Plot
description: CHICAGO. Jan. 18 (AP) Ronald Kaufman, an Army pri vate with a doctorate degree from Stanford University who is absent without official leave, was indicted today by a Fed eral grand jury in connection with attempts to bomb three Chicago banks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nastase, Richey Win
description: LONDON, Jan. 18 (Reuters) ?? Nastase of Rumania, the topseeded player, took the first step toward the $7,500 top prize with an easy victory in the $33,400 Rothman's interna tional tennis tournament at Royal Albert Hall tonight.

title: Faulk, Neely Victors
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 18 (AP)Four American men advanced and three lost in the second round of the New Zealand tennis championships today.

title: 3 SKYLAB CREWS CHOSEN BY NASA
description: The astronaut crews for Sky lab, the nation's postApollo, experimental space station project, were announced yes terday by the National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TUCSON, Ariz.Since I came West in the spring, I have been watching the progressive growth of a great white scar on the face of the Santa Rita Mountains south of here.

title: COURT HALTS BOOK ON LIFE OF HUGHES
description: A book publisher was tem porarily enjoined yesterday in State Supreme Court from dis tributing a purported autobiog raphy of Howard R. Hughes pending a hearing later in the week.

title: U.S. and Soviet to Continue Talks for Increased Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 After two weeks of relatively unpublicized talks, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to continue dis cussions on expanding trade when the Soviet Foreign Trade Minister, Nikolai S. Patolichev, visits Washington.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Jan. 19, 1972
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. to discuss meeting of the Council in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Aparthe 10:30 A.M.

title: BRIGHT CONTRAST IN CELLO RECITAL
description: It is slightly more than 20 years since Leonard Rose left the New York Philharmonic and struck out on a career as a solo cellist, chamber musician and teacher. By now, Mr. Rose is a fixture of our concert scene. However, a fixture can give light when it is plugged in properly, and there was con siderable musical light shed by the cellist and his piano ac companist, Samuel Sanders, at their Town Hall recital Monday night, particularly when they plugged into Beethoven.

title: Key Proposals
description: New York City  Governor Rockefeller proposed new structure and government for the city, alleging that as things now stand there is no actual control over the func tioning of city government de spite the almost total central ization of power in City Hall.

title: Canada Bars Hunting of Seals by Plane or Ship in'72
description: OTAWA, Jan. 18The Gov ernment today banned for a year most babyseal hunting in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The hunts have long been deplored by humane societies in and out of Canada.

title: Improved Auto Bumpers Are Graded Low in Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety said today that bump ers advertised as improved by manufacturers of some 1972 model automobiles provided little protection against costly damage in lowspeed crashes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SADAT BIDS CABINET PLAN WAR ECONOMY
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18President Anwar elSadat instructed his new Cabinet, under Premier Aziz Sidky, today to take im mediate measures to draft a war economy program for Egypt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BOND PRICES DIP FOR SECOND DAY
description: The credit markets, shoved this way and that yesterday by conflicting forces, ended the day with a loss for the second day in a row.

title: Amex Listing Is Sought
description: The American Plan Corpora tion, a diversified insurance organization, told security ana lysts in Philadelphia yesterday that it had applied for a listing on the American Stock Ex change. It said trading was expected to start in February.

title: CENSUS IS BARRED BY QUEENS BOARD
description: A community school district in central Queens has refused to participate in a census in which the Commission on Hu man Rights is seeking racial and ethnic information on the 379,000 employes in all branch es of city government.

title: Earnings Down 10% at Caterpillar Tractor
description: Reflecting faltering sales in some foreign countries, earn ings of the Caterpillar Tractor Company declined 10.8 per cent last year from the 1970 level, the company reported yester day.

title: LAOTIAN DEFENSE IS SAID TO STIFFEN
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 18 North Vietnamese troops who have been staging attacks in the Long Tieng area of north ern Laos since New Year's Eve are reported to have been en countering increasing pressure in recent days from the Lao tian defenders.

title: 3 Temporary Plant Closings To Idle 19,000 at Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation announced today it will close temporarily three plants and idle some 19,000 employes in order to balance production with inven tories.

title: Concert Artists Guild to Mark Its 20th Anniversary
description: To be precise, the young soprano was not unknown when she auditioned for the Concert Artists Guild on April 28, 1956according to her application, she had made her Carnegie Hall debut some years earlier, at age 10, danc ing with the Mary Bruce Starbuds. But the singer who came to that audition was otherwise unheralded, a Hunter College student head ing toward a career teaching Romance languages. She left the audition a semifinal win ner, and thus a minor some body with one foot planted on a ladder that has carried her to the Metropolitan Opera and international celebrity.

title: Court Upholds State On School Financing
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Westchester Coun ty has dismissed the first legal challenge to the consti tutionality of the public school financing system in the state.

title: Financial Pressure in '72 Foreseen by Economist
description: The economy's chances for a spectacular thrust forward this year will be restrained by continuing pressure on finan cial markets, a leading econo mist said yesterday.

title: SOVIET ART BOOM CAUSES A CRUSH
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18  Soviet cultural authorities expressed concern today that an atten dance explosion in the na tion's art galleries was imperil ing valuable exhibits, and they called for a more modern ap proach to museum design and management.

title: Coast Shipowners to Bar Arms Cargo at Struck Ports
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (AP)West Coast shipowners imposed a ban today on mili tary shipments, including guns and ammunition for Vietnam, because of the renewed Pacific Coast dock strike.

title: Vornado's FourWeek Sales Show Drop From '70 Period
description: Vornado, Inc., the diversi fied retailing concern, reported yesterday that sales for the four weeks ended Jan. 2 fell to $104,602,000, including leased department sales of $5,020,000. Sales for the com parable period which ended Dec. 27, 1970 were $113,360, 000, including leased depart ment sales of $6,073,000.

title: Texas Delays Oil Quota
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 18The Texas Railroad Commission de layed today, possibly for a week, the setting of oil allow ables for February. The action was taken, the commission said, to make further studies.

title: Marlborough to Marry Mrs. Canfield
description: The 10th Duke of Marlbor ough will marry, Mrs. Laura Charteris Canfield, widow of Michael Temple Canfield, in a civil ceremony in London next Wednesday.

title: Angered Lindsay Decries False, Unworthy Attack
description: Mayor Lindsay assailed Gov ernor Rockefeller yesterday as a tool of the White House in the politics of 1972 and ac cused the Governor of using his State of the State message to open President Nixon's re election campaign with a false and unworthy attack on the city and himself.

title: 500 ATTEND RITES FOR EDWIN WEISL
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson and Mrs. Johnson were among nearly 500 mourners yesterday at the funeral service here for Edwin L. Weisl Sr., lawyer, civic and philanthropic leader and former Democratic national committeeman.

title: U.S. Craft Was Set to Fire To Halt Soviet Fishing Boat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18A United States Coast Guard icebreaker obtained permission to fire warning shots to stop a Soviet vessel from escaping capture in the Bering Sea this morning, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Chicago Exchange Elects
description: Owen H. Nichols has been reelected to serve a second term as chairman of the Chi cago Board of Trade, dealer in grain and other commodity futures, and Frederick G. Uhl mann was elected vice chair man. Mr. Nichols is first vice president of Mitchell, Hutchins & Co., Inc., commodity and stock brokers. Mr. Uhlmann is first vice president of H. Hentz & Co., commodity and stock brokers.

title: Market Place:
description: When Jay and Arnold Wells decided to buy back the controlling interest in their hospital television rent al business, the two execu tives little realized how new disclosure rules and a sensi tive stock market would complicate their efforts.

title: Waldheim to See Nixon
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 18 Secretary General Kurt Wald heim will go to Washington Monday for conferences with President Nixon, Secretary of State William P. Rogers and a number of Senators and Rep resentatives, it was announced here today. Among the subjects to be discussed is the choice of an American to succeed the late Dr. Ralph J. Bunche as Under Secretary General.

title: Inquiry on Cancer Project
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The General Accounting Of fice will investigate the use of Federal funds for a University of Cincinnati project that uses nuclear radiation in the treat ment of human cancer patients. A spokesman for the agency said that the investigation would be made at the request of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachussets.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Northwestern Financial In vestors, a new real estate in vestment trust, yesterday of fered 1.35 million units, con sisting of one share of benefi cial interest plus one warrant, at $20. Shields & Co. and Wheat, First Securities man aged the syndicate.

title: EXCHANGES PLAN NATIONAL SYSTEM
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) Representatives of the na tion's major stock exchanges met here today and decided to work together toward a na tional coordinated market sys tem to take over from the cur rent decentralized system.

title: French Will Supply Arms to Lebanese; Accord Due Friday
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 France is to supply Lebanon with arms under an agreement reached here.

title: Loews Signs a Contract to Sell Hotels Ambassador in Chicago
description: Merger News

title: Excerpts From the Message by Governor Rockefeller on the State of the State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Following are ex cerpts from the message by Governor Rockefeller on the State of the State to the Legislature. An abbreviated version was delivered on radio and television.

title: Jerry West's Shot With Second to Go Downs East in AllStar Game, 112110
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 Jerry West's 21foot jump shot with one second to play provided a spectacular finish and gave the West a 112110 victory over the East tonight in the 22d annual National Basket ball Association AllStar game.

title: Medina Rebuts Hersh
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (AP) Former Capt. Ernest L. Medina, Lieutenant Calley's command ing officer, told the Atlanta Constitution today that he saw nothing in the Peers report to justify Seymour Hersh's con tention.

title: TV: Watching Thomas to Astaire to Hope to Bunker
description: Duane Thomas. Fred Astaire, Bob Hope, Archie Bunker. Put them all to gether, and they spell tele vision over the last few days.

title: G.M. Requests a Delay On Emission Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation has asked the En vironmental Protection Agen cy to extend for one year the 1975 deadline to meet auto emission control standards in the 1970 Clean Air Act.

title: U.S. PLANS RESCUE OF $1BILLION BANK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Government announced today a plan of financial assistance to keep in operation a large Detroit bank that was other wise facing the possibility of failure.

title: 60,000 Truants Linked To Crime by School Union
description: More than 60,000 of the 200, 000 city pupils who are absent daily from school wander the streets and contribute to the incidence of molestations, mug gings and other crimes, a Board of Education budget hearing was told yesterday.

title: Harold Mercer Cole Dies at 66; Was a Dewey Aide in Thirties
description: Harold Mercer Cole, a part ner in the law firm of Cole & Dietz who was active in poli tics and business, died yester day morning at St. Luke's Hos pital after a long illness. Mr. Cole, who lived at the Union League Club, 38 East 37th Street, was 66 years old.

title: BUDD, SPRINTER, IS HOSPITALIZED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) Frank Budd, once recognized as the world's fastest human, is hospitalized with a severe kid ney disorder.

title: NORTH STARS TIED BY GOLDEN SEALS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 18 (AP)Carol Vadnais blasted in a powerplay goal from the point at 13:20 of the third pe riod as the California Golden Seals tied the Minnesota North Stars, 11, tonight and extended the North Stars' National Hock ey League victoryless streak to six games.

title: 14 Drivers Top $100,000 in '71 Earnings
description: About Motor Sports

title: Governor Proposes Furloughs for Some Prisoners as Part of Reform Program
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Governor Rockefeller today proposed home furloughs for carefully selected state prisoners and the use of citizenobservers to monitor prison conditions as part of a reform program that emphasizes lowcost changes.

title: NETS WIN, 123102, FROM FLORIDIANS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 18Ollie Taylor, Billy Paultz and Johnny Baum pro vided the spark in the second half as the Nets beat the Flori dians, 123102, in an American Basketball Association game before 5,371 at Island Garden tonight.

title: Thomas Misses Drill; Pro Bowl Drops Him
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (UPI)Duane Thomas, whose rushing led the Dallas Cow boys to their Super Bowl vic tory over the Miami Dolphins Sunday, failed to report for practice today for next Sun day's Pro Bowl game and was dropped from the National Conference squad.

title: Court Says City Tenant Must Get Rid of Dog
description: A grandmother living in a public housing project in a highcrime area of the Low er East Side was told yes terday to get rid of her watchdog within six months.

title: City Aides Let Kin Buy Tickets to Aurelio Fete to Avert Legal Ban
description: A number of top city officials are looking for ways to ac quire $50 and $100 tickets to a fundraising affair next Tues day for Mayor Lindsay's cam paign for the Democratic Pres idential nomination without ?? a City Charter ban on political contributions by gov ernment employes.

title: I.R.S. OPENS DRIVE TO CITE VIOLATORS ON PRICE POSTING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Internal Revenue Service is conducting a fullscale cam paign this week against viola tors of retail priceposting re quirements and intends to seek legal action against the bulk of them, it was announced to day.

title: 2 BILLS ASK FUNDS FOR A.T. & T. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Two liberal Democrats sought today to pressure the Federal Communications Commission into reopening an investigation of rate practices of the Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: American Crew Registers Victory Over Britain by 30 Feet in BoatShow Dory Race Here
description: The National Boat Show Dory race, which got under way to the roar of a cannon echoing through the canyons of lower Manhattan, was won by the American crew yester day in the East River off the South Street Seaport Mu seum's pier.

title: The Talk of Compton, Calif.
description: COMPTON, Calif.  Once they called this city the Hub. Little signs around the town boasted of it. Politicians al ways said it. And just about everyone believed it.

title: What Price Controls?
description: Now that the price freeze is a puddle, New Yorkers are looking vainly for some evidence that Phase Two will ever bring surcease from an avalanche of increases in costs basic to the family budget.

title: GRINNELL MORRIS, 84, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Grinnell Morris, a founding officer in the investment bank ing concern of F. Eberstadt & Co., died on Sunday in Venice, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Sutton, ??

title: Hungarian Seeks New Theatrical Forms
description: BUDAPESTPeter Halasz is a ?? bearded theater director with a monumental contempt for the standard forms of the legitimate stage, or even those of Budapest's avantgarde thea ter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginians Cheer Plan To Kill Starling Flock
description: RADFORD, Va., Jan. 18 (AP)The City Council has agreed to allow a flock of starlings to be sprayed with a detergent mixture that will keep the birds from fluffing their feathers to keep warm and will thus cause them to die of exposure.

title: GAINS CONTINUE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market continued to move higher yesterday in very active trading.

title: Rochelle Hudson, Film Actress In 1930's and 40's, Dead at 57
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Jan. 18 (UPI)Rochelle Hudson, a movie actress of the thirties and early forties, was found dead late yesterday in her home at the Palm Desert Country Club.

title: S.E.C. SUIT ACCUSES INVESTMENT GROUP
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 18 (AP)  The United Financial Group, Inc., an overseas in vestment company, has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of de frauding its investors.

title: Selling of President Will Be Musical
description: A musical version of the Joe McGinniss bestselling book, The Selling of the President, an account of how Richard Nixon's image was presented to the public on television during the 1968 Presidential campaign, will be presented on March 28 at the Shubert Theater.

title: NEW DRUG AGENCY TO FIGHT PUSHERS ON LOWER LEVELS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Administration is preparing a new program to cope with traffickers on the intermediate level and in the street retail trade in narcotic drugs, ac cording to Government sources. It will be headed by Myles J. Ambrose, now the Commis sioner of Customs.

title: ROCCO G. SCIOSCIA
description: Rocco G. Scioscia, a lawyer, died on Monday in St. Barna bas Hospital, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 22055 46th Avenue, Bayside, Queens.

title: Cherchez le Boxeur
description: Sports of The Times

title: Cigarettes Said to Aid Racketeers
description: A spokesman for the na tional tobacco industry told the State Commission of In vestigation yesterday that illegal profits from cigarette smuggling into New York State were being used to finance similar underworld operations in other parts of the country.

title: MALTESE WILL GET NATO OFFER TODAY
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 18The North Atlantic Council agreed today on a new package offer to Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta for continued use of the Mediterranean island's bases.

title: Kennedy Asks Withdrawal
description: LONDON, Jan. 18Senator Edward M. Kennedy said to night that the British Govern ment should end the internment of suspected terrorists In North ern Ireland, abolish the provin cial Government, and take steps toward the unification of Ireland.

title: Rate Against Mark Advances Smartly
description: PARIS, Jan. 18The dollar looked more robust in the Eu ropean financial centers today following a week of deteriora tion that raised doubts about the durability of the Dec. 18 currency realignment.

title: In the Soviet Union, She's the Highest Ranking Woman
description: The highest ranking wo man in the Soviet Union strode briskly into the sit ting room of her suite at the Plaza Hotel and said that America was just as she had expected it would be.

title: Willsey Resigns His Post As California Head Coach
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 18 Ray Willsey, head football coach at the University of Cali fornia, resigned last night.

title: Technicians Join Walkout Of Canada Air Controllers
description: Canada's transportation crisis deepened yesterday as 2,200 Government communications technicians joined the 1,450 air traffic controllers who went on strike on Sunday.

title: KOUFAX REACHES NEW MILESTONE
description: It seems only yesterday that Willie Davis dropped those fly balls to make Sandy Koufax a loser in the last game he pitched.

title: Top Winners Named For Final $1 Lottery
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18 (UPI)A Lewis County pair won one of two $100,000 top prizes in the final $1 state lottery ticket drawing.

title: Mercy Flights Made
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 18A spokes man for Nordair, which serves the eastern Arctic from Mon treal, said today that the air controllers' association had agreed to handle mercy flights or those needed to take food or other essential supplies to remote regions.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 (AP)Billy Traynor scored 35 points, including 15 in a row from the freethrow line, as Dartmouth beat Harvard to night, 9486, in an Ivy League basketball game.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Greenwich Savings Bank, one of the oldest and largest banks in the U. S., has elected William S. Brennen, its president, to the additional posts of chairman of the board and chief executive officer. He succeeds Earl Harkness, who retires after 29 years of service but continues as a consultant.

title: '71 Housing Starts 7% Above '50 High
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Housing construction topped a record, year with a record month in December the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: The Vietnam Trap
description: The United States end North Viet nam are now trapping one another in a tragic military situation, which bene fits neither side, and might be resolved to the benefit of both by a fairly modest compromise.

title: Nine Killed When Private Plane Hits Pole in Fog
description: VICTORIA, Tex., Jan. 18 (UPI)  A private jet carrying nine persons, including the president of one of the largest leather companies in the na tion, struck a utility pole while trying to land in a thick fog today, exploded and burned. All aboard were killed.

title: Tighter Soviet Internal Security Is Seen
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18Western diplomats believe that the So viet Union is tightening inter nal security and seeking to shore up ideological vigilance among Soviet citizens to offset, possible side effects of its pol icy of relaxing tensions with the West.

title: CONNALLY IS LINKED TO OIL AID FOR NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  Senator Fred R. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma, has testified he thinks former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas was involved in convincing a group of Texas oil millionaires they should switch financial support in 1968 from the Demo cratic Presidential candidate, Hubert H. Humphrey, to the Republican, Richard M. Nixon.

title: $2Billion Program On Mortgages Slated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Reuters)  The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Preston Martin, outlined today a $2billion purchase program for conven tional mortgages to accom modate sellers of nonguar anteed, noninsured mortgage loans.

title: GOVERNOR ASSAILS LINDSAY REGIME; ASKS STATE TO TAKE OVER CITY U.; MAYOR CALLS HIM A TOOL OF NIXON
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Governor Rockefeller proposed today a new structure and government for New York City in a State of the State message that also suggested that an oldline po litical machine could run the city better than Mayor Lindsay.

title: NoFault Insurance, Crime Control And PowerSupply Rise Get Priority
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18  In his State of the State message to the Legislature today, Governor Rockefeller proposed three ma jor programs  nofault auto mobile insurance, crime control through court reform and a plan for increasing electrical power supplies in the state as part of his 1972 priority leg islative package.

title: The Shadow of Limited Wars
description: These are excerpts from an editorial in The Times of London.

title: Commission's Recall Asked
description: LONDON, Jan. 18The ar rest of Mr. Todd sharpened de mands by the Opposition Labor party for the recall of the Pearce Commission. Harold Wil son, the party leader, and senior colleagues conferred with Prime Minister Heath and senior Cabinet ministers tonight and told them that the arrests called into question the whole basis of the conditions under which the commission was operating.

title: Mujib Grants Amnesty to All Convicted in Military Trials
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Sheik Mujibur Rah man, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, today ordered am nesty for all persons convicted by summary and special mili tary courts while the territory was under East Pakistan mar tial law administration.

title: Voters' Support Urged By Mrs. Gandhi's Party
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 18Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party issued a pol icy statement today for the elections in March for the legislative bodies of 12 In dian states and 4 union terri tories administered by the central Government.

title: Warner Bros and Filmation Plan 10 Animated Features
description: Warner Bros., which has not made featurelength animated films, according to company sources, has joined with Filma tion, Inc., producers of animat ed subjects for television, to make 10 animated features on noted themes for showing in theaters and subsequently on TV screens.

title: Malcolm, a Black, Named Correction Chief by Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ap pointed the city's first black Correction Commissioner, Ben jamin J. Malcolm, a veteran parole and correction official, who pledged to make the city's embattled and overcrowded prisons more humane places.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Crave Privacy, You Can Find It Even on July 4
description: Despite this line in The Cruising Guide to the Chesa peake I hope the armchair cruisers among you who dream of next summer's trip will keep in mind some of our experiences that contra dict the statement and plan accordingly.

title: Mrs. DeWitt Millhauser, 80, Widow of RCA Executive
description: Mrs. Margaret Schaffner Millhauser, widow of DeWitt Millhauser who was chairman of the finance committee of the Radio Corporation of America, died yesterday in University Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 2 East 61st Street.

title: U.S. Says 2 Soviet Fishing Boats Agree to Be Taken to Navy Base
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 After refusing to move for more than 24 hours, two Soviet fish ing vessels reportedly agreed late today to sail under escort to a United States naval base to face charges of violating American fishing rules.

title: GRINNELL MARTIN, 84, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Grinnell Martin, a founding officer in the investment bank ing concern of F. Eberstadt & Co., died on Sunday in Venice, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Sutton, Vt.

title: Sluggish Recovery
description: Business is still recovering slowly from the recession. In December, industrial output rose seventenths of 1 per cent, but nearly half the rise was due to the increase in coal output after last fall's strike. Industrial produc tion went up only 3 per cent in the past yearand is still 3.7 per cent below its peak in 1969.

title: PRAVDA ATTACKS U.S. MIDEAST ROLE
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19 Pravda implied today that the United States was undercutting the United Nations peacemaking efforts in the Middle East just as the mission of the United Nations representative, Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, was being revived.

title: Skiers Arriving by Air At French Alps Resort
description: News of Skiing

title: Illinois Primary Filings Close; 3 Democrats Vie for 170 Votes
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19  Three Democratic Presidential candi dates were given a chance to day to win some of the 170 Illinois delegates to the Demo cratic National Convention as filings closed for the March 21 primary.

title: Who Expects Justice?
description: A little more than a year ago Dr. Arthur James Kraus, a teacher who had been the victim of a peculiarly raw deal at the City College of New York in 1933, received what amounted to a belated apology, plus a pension, from the New York State Legislature.

title: Actors Sail to Block Island Without a Rehearsal
description: The dawn didn't break bright with promise. It crept out of the night only to find its way blocked by an eerie, clinging radiation fog. Horns and bells from tugs, ships and shore points set up an intermittent cacophony of warnings.

title: AMEX LETS TRADING RESUME IN 3 ISSUES
description: The American Stock Ex change permitted trading to re sume yesterday in shares of the Interphoto Corporation, the Ox ford Electric Corporation and Argus; Inc., after a clarifying statement had been issued by management.

title: What of Phase Three? Business Leader and Unionist Disagree
description: A leading businessman and a top labor official addressed the prestigious Economic Club of New York last nightwith each recommending a post Phase Two program that many members of the audience found surprising.

title: Chess: 2 International Masters Tie For First in Polish Tourney
description: The ninth annual tourna ment in memory of Akiba Rubinstein, held recently at Polanica Zdroj, Poland, re sulted in a tie for first be tween two international mas tersHelmut Pfleger of West Germany and N. Spiridonov of Bulgaria, both of whom scored 9 points out of 15.

title: Treatment of Children in State Facilities Is Decried
description: The treatment of seriously disturbed and delinquent chil dren by voluntary agencies and state facilities was severely criticized yesterday in a report published by the National Council on Crime and Delin quency.

title: F.D.A. Orders Salt Labels To Say if Iodide Is Inside
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Food and Drug Admin istration said today that it would order all table salt labels to specify whether the product contains iodide. In addition, the agency said it would weigh a suggestion that all salt be re quired to contain iodide, which combats goiter.

title: HARRY STACKELL, 88, BRONX COUNTY JUDGE
description: Harry Stackell, a County Judge in the Bronx for 24 years, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 88 years old and was active in a law partnership with his son. He resided at 353 West 57 Street.

title: Chen Yi's Successor as Foreign Minister Named
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Jan., 20Chi Pengfei, a former army medical officer who be came a diplomat, has been ap pointed China's Foreign Minis ter. He succeeds Chen Yi, who died in Peking earlier this month at the age of 71.

title: Peckinpah's Straw Dogs Starring Hoffman Arrives
description: This is where I live, says David (Dustin Hoffman), the ordinarily loving, mildman nered mathematician, to the thugs who want to invade his home. This is me! I will not allow violence against this house!

title: Architects Deny They Knew Auschwitz Camp's Purpose
description: VIENNA, Jan. 19 (UPI)Two Austrian architects who built the Auschwitz gas chambers in which three million Jews died testified today that they did not know what the buildings were to be used for.

title: TV: World of Lorraine Hansberry
description: Lorraine Hansberry, the playwright, died of cancer in 1965, at the age of 34. To Be Young, Gifted and Black began a successful stage ca reer with an Off Broadway production in 1969. Subtitled Lorraine Hansberry in Her Own Words, it was compiled or adapted from the vari ous writings of the black writer by Robert Nemiroff, her husband.

title: Feminists Rate Democratic Vote Record in House Over G.O.P.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Democratic members of the House of Representatives, taken as a group, have a better vot ing record than Republicans do on issues of interest to women, according to a leading feminist publication.

title: 2 Accused of Robbing Taxi By Impersonating Policemen
description: A cab driver's complaint that he was shaken down by two plainclothes policemen has led to the arrest of two Queens men on charges of impersonat ing policemen, robbery and grand larceny.

title: Advertising:
description: Despite valiant lastditch efforts at financial fence mending, Lennon & Newell has lost the Florida Citrus Commission business billing some $7million.

title: Up From the Ranks
description: Man in the News

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and Ameri can Stock Exchanges yester day issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, direc tors and officers of listed com panies. The reports include the following:

title: Yankees Get Callison From Cabs for a Look
description: The New York Yankees acquired John Callison from the Chicago Cubs yesterday and said they would try the 32yearold lefthanded hitter as a pinchhitter and reserve outfielder.

title: Olympiad FundRaising Game Bridge:Set for Tonight at 121 Centers
description: The expense of sending teams to international cham pionships is a heavy burden for national bridge organiza tions throughout the world. The American Contract Bridge League, relatively wealthy by the standards of the rest of the world, solves this problem by an annual fundraising game.

title: DayCare Truce Ends SitIn at Lindsay Center
description: Three hundred and fifty women, children and daycare workers took over Mayor Lindsay's Presidential cam paign headquarters for three hours yesterday, leaving only after the Mayor agreed to defy o state order limiting eligibility for government financed day care.

title: Hull Still Holding Out in HikingOut Case on Barnegat Bay
description: C.H.J. Hull of Morrisville, Pa., Is a sailor in the eye of a legal, stormand perhaps even of a landmark case: New Jersey has found him guilty of having sailed his sailboat in what virtually all sailors consider the right way.

title: Art Dealer, Reaching 50, Flies 700 to Paris Party
description: Calling himself a nice little merchant from Atlantic City,Reese Palley, the art dealer, loaded more than 700 friends and acquaintances into two chartered 747 jets at Kennedy International air port last night for a fourday 50th birthday partyin Paris.

title: BankAmericard to Chase; Operating Net Is Off 3.3%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced plans yesterday for the absorption of its UniCard into the BankAmericard credit card system, a move that will provide its 2 million card hold ers with immediate national and international coverage.

title: French Cabinet Orders a Series of Prison Reforms
description: PARIS, Jan. 19The Cabinet reacted today to a wave of un rest in French prisons with a series of reforms, coupled with a warning that discipline would be tightened.

title: LAWYER ACCUSED OF BRIBE ATTEMPT
description: A lawyer who served four years as an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with at tempting to bribe two patrol men to fix a narcotics case.

title: SCHILLER ASKS TIME BE EXTENDED TO U.S.
description: BONN, Jan. 19  West Ger many's Economics and Finance Minister, Karl Schiller, told parliament today that the Unit ed States must be given time to improve its balanceofpay ments situation following last year's realignment of world currencies.

title: 5 Borough Presidents Seek Vote in November on Decentralization
description: The five Borough Presidents agreed yesterday to seek a com mon front to decentralize more city services, voicing a hope that this could be achieved by referendum next November.

title: East Pakistan, Despite Its Problems, Is Showing Strong Signs of New Life
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 19 Earth is freshly turned and the fields are planted with rice. Agile village men can again be seen in the tops of the coconut palms, legs wrapped around the trunks, as they tap the sap to make palm toddy, a potent country liquor. Little girls area going to school once more, their scrubbed faces free of fear.

title: Quota Precinct Writes 1,294 Tickets in Day
description: Pressing their controversial parkingticket offensive, the police of the 24th Precinct, on the Upper West Side, issued 1,294 summonses, a record, on Tuesday, compared with 16 on Jan. 1.

title: PACE WILL MATCH TWO 14YEAROLDS
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 19 A match race between Clan Raider and Air New Zealand, in which the world senior pacing championship will be decided, will be held at Roose velt Raceway on Friday night, Feb. 4.

title: 11 SENATORS URGE A PULLOUT DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Senate Democratic Policy Com mittee revived the Vietnam is sue in the Senate today by adopting a resolution calling on the President to withdraw all United States forces from Indo china within six months, con tingent upon the release of prisoners of war.

title: New MunicipalBond Fund Offers $50Million Issue
description: A new taxexempt municipal bond fund reached the market yesterday with the offering of 50,000 units with a principal value for $50million. The fund, First Monthly Payment Series, is described as the first to make payments monthly in stead of semiannually.

title: Ohio Fire Kills 4 in Family
description: CELINA, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI) Four members of one family died today in a fire that de stroyed their home near here. The victims were identified as Mrs. Shirley Lunt and three of her children, Christine, 10 years old; Jennifer, 6, and Jeffrey, 3.

title: JOHN CHAPMAN, 71, DRAMA CRITIC, DIES
description: John Chapman, who became drama critic emeritus of The Daily News after 51 years in the field of criticism, died last evening in the Westport (Conn.) Manor, a convalescent home. He was 71 years old and had been the paper's drama critic for 25 years.

title: McGovern Offers a Plan To Cut Defense Outlays
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 19 Senator George McGovern pro posed today a $54,8billion al ternative defense budget that he said would replace fat with muscle in a stronger na tional security system and cut military spending by a third.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Internal Revenue Service turned over to United States Attorneys yesterday for civil litigation the cases of 41 retail stores in the New York area accused of failing to comply with the price stabilization pro gram's base price posting re quirements.

title: Jarring Talks with Tekoah
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19(AP) Ambassador Gunnar V. Jarring held his second meet ing in six days today with the Israeli delegate to the United Nations, Yosef Tekoah.

title: Output of Aluminum Fell in U.S. in 1971
description: Primary aluminum production in this country last year slipped to 3,925,242 tons from the 3,976,148 tons turned out in 1970, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday.

title: EMIL FROESCHELS, SPEECH EXPERT, 87
description: Dr. Emil Froeschels, an in ternationallyknown physician and teacher in the field of speech and vocal science, died Tuesday in the Wickersham Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in the Dover Hotel, 687 Lexington Avenue.

title: TRINIDAD IS FESTIVE DESPITE TROUBLES
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 18Trinidad is entering the Carnival season in a festive spirit despite a growing epi demic of poliomyelitis5 dead and 131 cases reportedand a threemonthold state of emer gency that prohibits demonstra tionsexcept Carnival.

title: GEORGE MITCHELL, ACTOR, DEAD AT 67
description: George Mitchell, a Broadway and Hollywood actor, died in his sleep in Washington on Tuesday. He lived in Grand view, N. Y.

title: British Explorer Group Unravels Yukon's Mysteries
description: Two missionsone to un ravel the mystery of a strange valley and the other to go by water from the remote for ests of the Yukon to the United States borderwere accomplished by a group of British explorers in the wild Northwest territories of Canada in 1971. The vast territory of British Columbia had not been navigated by river from border to border before.

title: Theater: Zesty Wanted
description: There is a fine, lovely and lyric madness at the Cherry Lane Theater. It is called Wanted, it is by David Ep stein and Al Carmines, and, at last, it restores the art of the musical to the Off Broad way theater. This is a musi cal that is new, engrossing and has a surging vitality that takes all before it. I rec ommend it wholeheartedly.

title: RESTRAINT URGED ON CREDIT RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends said to day it expects lenders to be aggressive in passing on promptly to the borrower the benefits of reduced costs of funds available in the credit markets.

title: Court Orders Voting in Districts Vetoed by Reagan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 19 California's Supreme Court has ruled that Congressional elections this year be held in re apportioned districts designated in a bill adopted by the State Legislature but vetoed by Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: Link Set by German and Dutch Mills
description: DORTMUND, West Germany, Jan. 19A row of West Ger man steel magnates facing a crowd of newsmen here yester day broke out in hearty laugh ter when someone suggested that their new cooperative ven ture with a Dutch company be named the AntiJapan com pany.

title: SAUL REINFELD, 68, A LIQUOR IMPORTER
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 19Saul Reinfeld, president of Joseph H. Reinfeld, Inc., and the Baxter Warehouse Corpo ration, liquor wholesalers in Union, died yesterday in Carls bad, Calif. He was 68 years old and made his home here.

title: British Strike Talks Begin
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) Striking coalminers and Brit ain's coal industry management met today, giving the first signs of a break in the dead lock that has led to a tenday miners strike and violence on the picket lines. The talks broke off after three hours.

title: SHIP LINES REVERSE BAN ON ARMS CARGO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP)  The Pacific Maritime Association reversed itself to day and ordered its member shipowners to begin handling military cargo immediately at struck West Coast ports, ac cording to Edmund Flynn, president of the association.

title: RealtyTax Financing of Schools In Jersey Ruled Unconstitutional
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 19  A State Superior Court judge ruled here today that New Jersey's system of financing publicschool education through local property taxes was un constitutional.

title: PRICES ON BONDS AGAIN MOVE DOWN
description: The credit markets, unhappy about the prospect of a $40bil lion Federal deficit, grew de cidedly more pessimistic yes terday. Bond prices dropped for the third day in a row, and interest rates rose.

title: Reserve's Member Banks Given More Authority for Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board said today it would give expanded authority to Federal Reserve banks to expedite han dling of applications received under the Bank Holding Com pany Act.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. Sets Standby Credit In Special Drawing Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The International Monetary Fund announced today a standby credit denominated for the first time in Special Drawing Rights instead of United States dollars.

title: Allende, Criticizing Nixon, Says Chile Can Dictate Her Own Laws
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 (UPI) President Salvador Al lende Gossens tonight criticized President Nixon's warning that the United States would take punitive measures against na tions that expropriate private American holdings without com pensation.

title: PETTY WILL DRIVE FOR GRANA TELLI
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) Andy Granatelli and Richard Petty joined forces today in a stock car racing deal that is understood to have cost Grana telli about $1million.

title: CITY UNIT REJECTS SURVEY ON REFUSE
description: The city's Environmental Pro tection Administration con tended yesterday that the city would save no money by turn ing the Sanitation Depart ment's refusecollection duties over to private carters.

title: Security Council's Meeting In Africa to Cost $139,500
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19The Security Council agreed without a formal vote today to hold a special meet ing in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from Jan. 28 to Feb. 4.

title: C.I.A. Aided Laos Base Hit Hard
description: LONG TIENG, Laos, Jan. 19 The longsecret military base maintained here by the United States Central Intelligence Agency to help Laotian irregu lars battle the North Vietna mese is badly damaged and has been put out of effective ac tion by the Communists even though the Laotians have re occupied most of a high ridge that commands it.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Washington State Gets More Aid From Japan
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 19 (UPI)Japan made today its second delivery of food to the state of Washington, which has one of the highest un employment rates in the coun try.

title: Brahms Is Played Sumptuously By the Philadelphia Orchestra
description: It was a good idea on the part of Eugene Ormandy to preface Brahms's Fourth Sym phony with the composer's Tragic Overture in the Phila delphia Orchestra's Tuesday night concert in Philharmonic Hall. The somber mood of the overture set the right atmos phere for the most austere of the Brahms symphonies, and the feeling of continuity worked to the advantage of both pieces.

title: College Sports Notes.
description: As a result of strong prod ding recently from Louis J. Lefkowitz, New York State Attorney General; Rutgers University, and Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey, the National Football Foundation may finally begin construc tion of its Hall of Fame build ing by late spring. Al Twitchell, Rutgers ath letic director, said yesterday that the university expect ed to sign a 99 year lease with the foundation on Jan. 28 for use of the building site on the Rutgers campus in New Brunswick, N. J. Ground was first broken for this building as long ago as 1966, but nothing else materialized and the project became known as the mythical hall of fame.

title: LockheedGeorgia Will Close 4 Plants
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Jan. 19 (AP)The LockheedGeorgia Company announced today it would cease production in the near future at subassembly plants in four states because of declining work on the C5 Galaxy program.

title: Accident Toll
description: The President is required by law to deliver an annual message to Congress on the economic health of the nation. It is strange that there is no requirement for a similar separate report on the equally important physical health of the nation. The potential usefulness of such a docu mentfor both policymaking and public understanding was recently exemplified at the state level by a report on the health of New Yorkers issued by the State Health Commissioner, Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham.

title: CONTROLS LIFTED FOR MOST STORES AND SOME RENTALS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  More than 40 per cent of the rental housing and threefourths of the retail establishments in the country were freed from economic controls by the Gov ernment today.

title: Nixon's Visit to China Will Be Telecast Live
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 When President Nixon sets foot in Peking on Feb. 21, his his toric step will be televised in stantlyvia a $1.6million trail er in the Chinese capital, an Intelsat satellite in the Pa cific sky, a communications station in Jamesburg, Calif., and a transcontinental cable to New Yorkinto millions of American living rooms.

title: Plan for City U. Fee And State Control Is Reported on Way
description: A special commission that is studying the financing of higher education in the state will rec ommend the charging of tuition fees at the City University and substantial increases in the fees at the State University, accord ing to members of the com mission and other sources.

title: STOCK RALLY CUTS DOW LOSS T0 2.26
description: Stock prices sagged yester day on profit taking, but the market bounced back to re cover the hulk of its losses be fore the final bell.

title: PRICES ON AMEX ARE MOSTLY DOWN
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthe counter market finished mostly lower yesterday although a late rally erased some of the earlier losses in active trading.

title: Campaign Spending Curb Is Sent to Nixon by House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Legislation to impose the first Presidential campaign spending limits in history was approved by the House today and sent to President Nixon. The vote was 334 to 19.

title: Mrs. Green Urged for Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) A Georgia Congressman to day proposed Representative Edith Green of Oregon for Vice President on the Democratic ticket. Representative Jack Brinkley said that Mrs. Green was eminently qualified.

title: Personal Finance
description: What happens to a New Yorker who drives to Florida for the sun and is involved in an auto accident?

title: A Highly Satisfactory Election
description: Sports of The Times

title: Movement Into Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 19 (AP)The Cambodian high command said today that two or three new North Vietnamese regiments, totaling 5,000 to 10,000 troops, had moved down the Ho Chi Minh trail into Cambodia.

title: White House Said to Delay Steps to Spur Soviet Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans has made farreaching proposals to President Nixon for expanding trade with the Soviet Union, wellplaced Administra tion sources said today, but so far they have been shelved pending further improvement in the SovietAmerican political climate.

title: CANADA'S AIR STRIKE MAKES 14,000 IDLE
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 19 (AP)The strike by Canada's 1,600 union air traffic controllers has put more than 14,000 people out of work, snagged travel plans for tens of thousands and is causing airline losses of more than $1.5million a day, of ficials reported today.

title: Shoe Industry Glum on Hides
description: New limits on Argentine hide exports could force up shoe prices in this country, the American Footwear Industries Association dedared yesterday.

title: Memphis to Set Guidelines For Use of Police Weapons
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 19 (UPI) Mayor Wyeth Chandler prom ised today, to set immediate guidelines for use of police weapons following the third shooting death of a young black by the Memphis police in two weeks.

title: FIRE AT CON ED CUTS PENN STATION POWER
description: A fire at a Consolidated Edi son generating station last night ruptured electrical power fed to Pennsylvania Station and halted incoming and outgoing Penn Central and Long Island Rail Road trains for more than an hour.

title: Horse That Followed Kennedy Coffin Ages Friskily
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Black Jack, the spirited, rider less horse that followed the coffin of John F. Kennedy to the grave and symbolized the lost young leader to millions of watching Americans, domi nated, his birthday party today.

title: Dodger Pitcher, 36, Youngest to Enter Shrine
description: Sandy Koufax, Yogi Berra and Early Wynn were elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yes terday in the heaviest voting in the 35year history of the poll.

title: Waterbury Officials Planning for First CATV City
description: The first effort to wire up an entire city for cable tele vision will be undertaken in Waterbury, Conn., as a non profit project by a group of church leaders, businessmen and local citizens.

title: Protests Halt U.N. Meeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19Twenty women who said they were Ukrainian American mothers broke up a meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council's Committee on Nongovernmen tal Organizations today with chanted demands for freedom of intellectuals arrested in the Ukraine.

title: They're Having a Pier 6 Ball in New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. There hasn't been a good brawl at the Pier 6 Marina since John Caruso and Andy George took over the 130 berth facility on New Ro chelle Creek last summer.

title: CharterFlight Battle
description: News Analysis

title: Graebner, Gonzales Score in London
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Clark Graebner of New York brushed aside fiery Bob Hewitt of South Africa, 63, 63, in the $33,400 Rothman's international, tennis tournament today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Agreement to Cover 3Year Period
description: TOKYO, Jan. 19The Japa nese steel industry has wrapped up the major issues in a new threeyear program to curb export growth to the Unit ed States.

title: State U. Suspends 150 Projects Valued at Total of $215Million
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19The State University Construction Fund today announced the suspen sion of 150 projects valued at $215million involving class room space and dormitories.

title: Barbara Cochran Third, Her Best Showing
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 19Two slaloms ago, Bar bara Cochran was eighth. Last week, she was fifth, and today the quiet little blonde from Richmond, Vt., was third. Im provement like that is promis ingthe next scheduled slalom is Feb. 11 at Sapporo, Japan.

title: NEWARK PRESSMEN REJECT PROPOSAL
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19  James Schofield, president of Local 8 of the International Pressmen's Union, said today that mem bers had overwhelmingly turned down a proposed agree ment under which some press men formerly employed by The Evening News of Newark would work for The Newark StarLedger.

title: Fordham Sets Back Seton Hall As Pirates 2dHall Rally Fails
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 19Seton Hall, trailing by 17 points late in the opening half, pulled to within three points in the closing minutes of the game before bowing to Ford ham University, 8174, before 3,200 fans in Walsh Auditori um tonight.

title: 4 Americans Triumph
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 19 (AP)Dick Knight of Bellevue, Wash., and Armistead Neely of Tampa, Fla., moved into the quarterfinals of the New Zealand open tennis cham pionships today. Mona Schallau of Iowa City and Ann Lebedeff of San Marcos, Calif., won sec ondround matches.

title: TREVINO IS NAMED ATHLETE OF YEAR
description: Lee Trevino, a professional golfer whose style is unortho dox, was selected yesterday as the Male Athlete of the Year by The Associated Press.

title: STATE TO EXTEND JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19  The State Department of Labor an nounced today that it had signed an agreement with the Federal Government that would provide an additional 13 weeks of emergency unemployment benefits for an estimated total of 50,000 to 60,000 people in the state.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane BernbachCan ada, eightyears old and up to $8million in billings, now has its first president, Ed ward D. Brown, who has been general manager there since June, 1970.

title: Symington Terms Some AWeapons In Asia Insecure
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Senator Stuart Symington sug gested today that some Ameri can nuclear weapons stationed in the Far East were not being properly protected against mis use or seizure.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: PRESS SEC. WANTED. Must be able to ride a horse, Write TWO ?? BY SEA, 159 Bleccker Street, N.Y.C. (Advt)

title: Stopping Defense Ships
description: The eagerness of ship operators to speed White House intervention in the unreasonable longshore strike that has again shut down all West Coast ports is easy to understand. But that eagerness provided no excuse for the concerted decision of employers in this highly subsidized industry to refuse military cargo for Vietnam, especially since the whole point of maritime subsidies is national defense.

title: Israeli Import:ishke Goes to War' Opens at Mayfair
description: George Ovadia's "Fishke ???es to War" is an Israeli ???medy that, according to American distributor, out ???ssed "Love Story" in Is-???l. I have long felt that ???ve Story" was under ???ed by most American ???vie critics, and now I ???could have to add, by Is???li audiences as well. For ???en in the context of Israeli ??? production (not, from ???at I have seen, the artistic ???ry of the Middle East), ???ishke Goes to War" must ???ape at least close to the ???ysmal bottom.Fishke doesn't exactly go war. He goes into the re???rves for a while so as not be separated from his pal ???hmil, like Fishke, a Ha???ic Jew, who has been ???ed up for training.Despite his total and pre???table ineptness Fishke ???kes a great soldier, and ???en the time comes for a ???aliatory raid against a ???nd of Arab guerrillas he ??? his friends get to in???de Jordan so as to bring ???ck the guerrilla leader ???ve.Much of what follows takes ???ce inside an Arab niglit-???b, where the raiders, aided a beautiful singer, a ???ewess from England, held force," collect their man. ???ey also fraternize a bit ???th the local talent, belly ???ncers mostly, and so as not to blow their Arab disguises the Israelis begin speaking in English. At this point the film's titles, which had been running in Hebrew and English, take off after some special logic of their own and become Hebrew and French.But for the most part "Fishke Goes to War" goes crazy in less engaging ways.
