Solo Moshe plays Fishke with a high-pitched voice, a mincing manner, and a standard skyward look of tender exasperation that is, I think, supposed to produce laughter, if only because it is so full of laughter-begging clues.I suspect a similar intention with the general treatment of the Hasidim, all of whom of are aggressively odd (if lovable) and who typically come not from Israel but from the old countryPoland, New York City, or the like."Fishke Goes to War" opened yesterday at the May-fair Theater, where it will play together with a live musical review starring Jo Amar.

title: IN THE NATION
description: At first glance, it might appear that Governor Nelson Rockefeller, by pro posing both court and prison reforms in his State of the State message, had made a substantial attack on the deficiencies of New York's criminal justice system. At second glance, his proposals appear to conflict to the point of canceling each other out.

title: Striving to Keep Rome in Fashion Game
description: ROME, Jan. 19Pino Lan cetti was the hero of the day in the fashion showings here. His collection was Chinese. Heinz Riva provided another one of those goodforpri vatecustomers shows. His clothes were postBalen ciaga. OgnibeneZendman mined the same lode Yves Saint Laurent discovered a year ago. The collection had the trollop look.

title: TREVINO, ARCHER IN TUCSON GOLF
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 19 Show business and profession al golf have formed a firmer partnership in a desert setting here. The $150,000 Dean Mar tin Tucson open starts tomor row as the Hollywood enter tainer becomes officially affili ated with the event for the first time.

title: 4th Quarter a Record
description: The American Electric Power Company yesterday reported new highs in earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1971. Donald C. Cook, chairman and president, placed finalquarter earnings at $34,839,000, or 58 cents a share. This was the highest earnings in any quarter in the company's history and 14.8 per cent higher than the $30,338,000, or 57 cents a share, reported in the like period of 1970. The average shares out standing in the period were 59.5million, or 11.6 per cent more than a year earlier.

title: 3 Blasts Rock Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Jan. 20 (Reuters)Three bomb blasts, one of them at the Al gerian Embassy, rocked Beirut early today. First reports said no one had been injured. The Algerian Embassy was badly damaged. The two other bombs exploded at an office building.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 5Cent Rise in Cigarette Tax Approved by Oregon Voters
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan, 19 Oregon voters narrowly ap proved yesterday a 5cent in crease in the cigarette tax.

title: Michigan State 72 Victor
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 19 (AP)  The University of Michigan took an early lead tonight with a firstperiod goal but the Michigan State hockey team quickly started a surge that beat the Wolverines, 72.

title: Goodrich Sets Iran Growth
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI),  The International B. F. Good rich Company announced to day the start of a multimillion dollar expansion program at its tire plant in Iran. Goodrich said production capacity would be doubled when the expansion is complete at the end of 1972.

title: BEGUILING SINGING FROM A SOPRANO
description: The scourge and dread of anyone who attends a couple of hundred concerts a year, as a reviewer does, is the singer who rattles off each piece in much the same way, as if call ing out subway stops. Now and then, a genuine musician steps up, however, and shows what singing is really about. Anna Chornodolska, who took part in a split recital at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, was one of the rare ones.

title: Newburgh City Manager Suspends Police Chief
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 19 The chief of police, a high ranking detective and a patrol man were suspended indefinite ly here today.

title: Major Integration Test Confronts U.S. in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Suddenly, the White House, Congress and the Supreme Court are speeding toward a series of critical decisions over the snarled issues of education, desegregation and busing.

title: National Orchestra of Belgium Makes Debut Here
description: It used to be that the Brahms First was the gradu ation piece for a visiting orchestra making its New York debut, Every orchestra and every conductor wanted to be measured against the Brahms C minor. No longer. Mahler is giltedged these daysany Mahler.

title: Alitalia to Serve Washington
description: ROME, Jan. 19 (UPI)  The Italian airline Alitalia said to day it had been granted landing rights in Washington, starting May 1. Alitalia said it would operate three flights weekly from Rome to Washington via Milan and Boston. It said this would raise the number of United States cities served by Alitalia to six and the number of weekly flights to 43.

title: Hughes Aides Ask a Hearing to Show Hoax
description: Attorneys for Howard R. Hughes asked a State Supreme Court justice yesterday for a hearing at which they said wit nesses could be produced to prove that a purported autobi ography of the industrialist was a hoax.

title: Some Government Policies Are Called Inflationary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Three economists with differing economic and political philoso phies agreed today that many of the Government's own ac tions and policies were making inflation worse by reducing the extent to which businesses may compete.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Buckley in Bangkok for Talk
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 19 (UPI)Senator James L. Buck ley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, arrived here today to talk to Thai leaders about President Nixon's trip to Peking next month. Mr. Buckley, now on the fourth leg of his South east Asian tour, said that he had come to Indochina to find out for himself what was hap pening and also to assess re action to President Nixon's visit.

title: L.I.R.R. Negotiations Pressed to Avert Strike Today
description: Negotiators for the Long Is land Rail Road and the United Transportation Union pressed their efforts yesterday to work out an agreement that would avert a strike threatened for 4 P.M. today.

title: Sea Ray Boat Plants Growing With Profits
description: Sea Ray Boats of Phoenix and Oxford, Mich., which has one of the largest displays on the first floor of the boat show also has two of the largest, most modern manu facturing facilities in the in dustry.

title: Michael Rabin, Violinist, Dead; Made Carnegie Hall Debut at 13
description: Michael Rabin, a violin virtu oso who at 35 could look back on two decades in which he traveled some 700,000 miles to play before millions on six con tinents, died suddently last night at his home, 185 West End Avenue.

title: Study Finds L.I. Industry Diversifying
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Jan. 19 More than 125 new indus tries relocated on Long Is land from other sites last year, a major step in diver sification away from the areo spaceoriented economy, in which cutbacks had spelled economic trouble for the re gion over the last several years.

title: Grayson Will Explain the Phase Two Program to Varied Groups
description: C. Jackson Grayson Jr., the chairman of the Price Commis sion, said yesterday that he was concerned about public acceptance of Phase Two and about future compliance with its rules, and had scheduled an eightcity tour of the country to explain the program to con sumers and industrial and re tail groups.

title: RHODESIAN BLACKS EXPAND PROTESTS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 19Black youths here looted shops and stoned cars, injuring at least 10 persons, as violent protests against the recent RhodesianBritish political set tlement spread within a mile of the center of this capital city.

title: At Long Last, a GasTurbine Boat That's Quiet, Clean, Cheap, Safe
description: For some time, engineers and knowledgeable boatmen have been wondering why it has taken so long for pleas ure boats to be powered by an engine that is vibration less, silent, ecologically clean, safe and operates at low cost.

title: Nixon Seeking $78Million Arts Budget
description: President Nixon will ask Con gress to appropriate $78million for the arts and humanities in the budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1973.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19One of the most expensive things wrought in this country since the automobile is a large body of people who cannot write let ters. This group ranges in age from about 13 to, oh, maybe 25. Its mem bers are, in some respects, well edu cated.

title: Cats and Rare Meat Are Linked to Birth Defects
description: The National Foundation March of Dimes has warned that eating rare or raw meat or handling cat feces during pregnancy may result in a parasitic infection that can seriously damage the unborn child.

title: Phone Service Disrupted
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 19 (AP)A strike against the Puerto Rico Telephone Com pany severely affected service, particularly in metropolitan San Juan, in its second day today.

title: Legless Sailor Surmounts Handicap
description: Anyone who has nibbled at the lure of boating and found the bait to his pleasure will stoutly defend the time and money spent on the water.

title: JUDGE DENIES DELAY ON RICHMOND ORDER
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 19A United States District Court judge here denied today county and state requests to delay im plementation of his order for consolidation of predominantly black Richmond public schools with those of the predominantly white schools in two of the city's suburban counties.

title: NIXON ANNOUNCES TOUGH U.S. STAND ON EXPROPRIATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Nixon announced to day that the United States would now follow a tougher attitude toward foreign coun tries that expropriate private American holdings without ade quate and swift compensation.

title: Davis Trial Delayed Again
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI)Judge Richard E. Arna son delayed again today the start of the Angela Davis trial on charges of murder, kidnap ping and conspiracy by agree ing to begin hearings on sev eral defense motions Jan. 31, the day he previously had set for the start of the trial.

title: A WarmUp Bout
description: News Analysis

title: Now Listen to a Firefighter's Plea
description: During my firefighting career I've been blown from the roof of a blazing pier, have had the man next to me on a hose line gasp and die as we tried to advance into a burning tenement, have had a woman relieve herself as we carried her down an aerial ladder from a blazing Harlem tenement in a snowstorm.

title: Mafia Families Called Involved In Cigarette Smuggling Racket
description: Members of several Mafia fam ilies were identified here yes terday at a State Commission of Investigation hearing as in volved in the smuggling of un taxed cigarettes into New York and their sale in vending ma chines owned by the under world.

title: Cougars Top Floridians
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 19 (AP)The Carolina Cougars held off a late surge by the Floridians to take a 108104 victory tonight.

title: Jurists Condemn Accord
description: GENEVA, Jan. 19The Inter national Commission of juristscondemned as inadequate to day the protection accorded black Rhodesians by the pro jected settlement with Britain.

title: Football Player With a Business to Fall Back On
description: On the football field this season, Garo Yepremian gained fame as a tiebreaker. But in the basement of his Miami home, he turns into tiemaker.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DEVIL IN THE FIRE. By John W. Aldridge. 364 pages. A Harper's Magazine Press Book. $12.50.

title: PRISON CHIEF BARS FLORIDA CONVICTS
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 19 (UPI)  The corrections direc tor of Florida, in an unprece dented and probably illegal move, refused today to admit any new convicts into the state prisons because of overcrowd ing.

title: Scheuer Meets Dublin M.P.'s
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 19 (UPI)Rep resentative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of the Bronx, visited Parliament today and met mem bers of the Irish Republic's op position parties. Mr. Scheuer who arrived here after a 48 hour stay in Belfast, was ex pelled from the Soviet Unior last Friday.

title: Swedish Fancier Cautions on Being KennelBlind
description: News of Dogs

title: Yevtushenko Arrives
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko arrived at Kennedy International Air port last night for a fourweek tour during which he will read his poetry from South Carolina to Minnesota. The Soviet writer, saying he came as a poet, not a politician, added that he was very glad to once again come to the United States. He will appear Jan. 28 at Madison Square Garden with several American poets.

title: Aime J. Forand Is Dead at 76; Served 22 Years in the House
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Jan, 19 Anne J. Forand, retired Rhode Island Democratic Congress man whose sponsorship of Medicare legislation was a high point: in his 22 years as a United States Representative, died last night of a heart at tack in his home in Boca Raton, Fla, where he had lived for four years. He was 76 years old.

title: Charges Trim Profit
description: Santa Fe Industries, Inc., the parent holding company of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway, reported yesterday that its net income for 1971 fell to $33,143,000, or $1.31 a share, from $40,216,000, or $1.59 a share, in the preceding year.

title: ExEnvoy in G.O.P. Race For New Hampshire Chief
description: CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 19  Robert C. Hill, who resigned earlier this month as United States Ambassador to Spain, declared today his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Hamp shire.

title: Stars Wallop Pros
description: SALT LAK CITY, Jan. 19 (AP)Zelmo Beaty scored 28 points tonight to lead the Utah Stars to a 143118 victory over the Memphis Pros.

title: 3 UTILITIES PLANNING $700MILLION OUTLAY
description: Three utilities in Michigan, Minnesota and Idaho announced yesterday plans for spending more than $700million on ex pansion budgets this year.

title: Inquiry Set on Liner Fire
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 19 (UPI) The Hong Kong Government announced today that a court would be set up to investigate the Jan. 9 fire that destroyed the 82,600ton Seawise Univer sity, which formerly was the luxury liner Queen Elizabeth.

title: Notes on People
description: For some weeks, Senator Jacob K. Javits had been ballyhooing his intention of making the Navy unhappy by nominating the first fe male midshipman for the Naval Academy at Annapolis. Only this week Mr. Javits an nounced he would make his nominee's name known next Tuesday, and her identity was shrouded in secrecy. But Mr. Javits has been up staged by Representative Jack McDonald of Michigan, who has nominated Valerie Schoen, a freshman at the University of Michigan, as the first girl plebe.

title: Sandy Hook: 90% Booked Up for 72
description: SEA BRIGHT, N.J., A re cent survey of marinas at Sandy Hook indicates that dock space is scarce, slips 90 per cent rented for the 1972 season and expanding facilities in the area not enough to keep up with in creasing demands.

title: Kaufman Is Indicted Here In Bomb Plot on 3 Banks
description: A Federal grand jury indicted Ronald Kaufman of Milwaukee yesterday on charges of placing bombs in safedeposit boxes at three banks in Manhattan.

title: Stars Clip Wings, 41
description: DETROIT, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Doug Mohns fed three Minne sota scores tonight as the North Stars broke a sixgame victory less streak with a 41 triumph over the Red Wings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine Democrat to Quit
description: LINCOLN, Me., Jan. 19 (AP) Maine's Democratic national committeewoman, Mrs. Faye L. Broderick, said today that she would not be a candidate for reelection to the commit tee.

title: ContinentalWilliams Deal
description: The Continental Oil Com pany and the Williams Com panies yesterday announced they have agreed in principle on the sale by Continental of its plant foods business in North America to Williams. The companies said a purchase agreement is being prepared and negotiations are proceed ing favorably. Execution of the purchase agreement is ex pected on Feb. 1.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert M. Flanagan and Richard R. Hayes have been promoted to executive vice presidents and Bogert A. Hansen to senior vice president of Dean Witter & Co., Inc.

title: CANADIENS BEAT MAPLE LEAFS, 10
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 19 (UPI) Pete Mahovlich scored with two seconds left to play tonight to give Montreal a 10 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and extend the Canadiens un beaten home string to 21 games this season in the National Hockey League.

title: Bolt, Vivat!, Author, Ponders History
description: Vivat! Vivat Regina!, which opens tonight at the Broadhurst Theater, is Robert Bolt's first play on Broadway since A Man for All Seasons in 1961. Both are historical dramas about larger  than  life figures. Vivat! deals with Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots, Seasons with Thomas More.

title: Happiness at the Coliseum: Boats, People and Smiles
description: Never mind boat sizes, the smiles are bigger this year. What a pleasant change, everyone smiling, rubbing his hands and impatiently awaiting Satur day's opening of the 62d National Boat Show at the Coliseum.

title: Canucks Crush Penguins, 61
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 (UPI)  The Vancouver Canucks snapped a 11 tie with four goals early in the third period tonight and went on to rout the Pittsburgh Penguins, 61.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Daniel McConville, Jr. Birthday greetings from Frances, Jane, Fun McConville. Advt.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Carolina Power and Light Company raised an indicated $54.75million with the sale yes terday of 2 million common shares at $27.37 each. Merrill Lynch managed the offering for the concern, based in Raleigh, N. C.

title: Free Courses Given By Power Squadron
description: The United States Power Squadrons give weekly free courses to anyone over the age of 16. Courses consist of 10. to 12 classes, depending on the unit. Advanced in struction is also included for members of seamanship, elec tronics and sail, at some locations. Times are 8 P.M., unless otherwise noted.

title: Gains Reported as Malta Talks Resume
description: ROME, Jan. 19Talks on the use of military bases in Malta by British and allied forces re sumed here today, and some progress toward an agreement was reported.

title: Stanford Votes on Ouster
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Tan. 19 (UPI)  Stanford University students voted today in a ref erendum on the recommended dismissal of a revolutionary professor, H. Bruce Franklin. The twoday vote was ordered by the Student Senate. A fac ulty advisory board recom mended the dismissal after finding Mr. Franklin guilty of inciting violence. The university president, Richard Lyman, con curred. The board of trustees will meet on the matter Satur day.

title: Rhodesian Pact in Jeopardy
description: Britain's projected settlement with Rhodesia has been jeopardized by violent protests against its terms from the black community and, even more, by the panicky reaction to these protests of the white minority Govern ment in Salisbury. The arrest of former Prime Minister Garfield Todd, a man of great gentleness, clearly capable only of nonviolent protest against the regime's racist policies, has offended even rightwing British Tories most anxious for a settlement.

title: Enough to Make Your Head Spin
description: It was a story in The Times last April 4 that did it. Headlined Long Island Boatmen Angered and Confused, the article outlined local frustration caused by the state's holdingtank law, which had been repeatedly postponed since 1966 but then suddenly was going to be enforced.

title: 4 Newspapers in Florida Purchased by The Times
description: The New York Times has purchased four small Florida newspapers from William L. Matthew and O. L. Taylor.

title: 2 SIDES ARE CLOSER IN OIL PRICE TALKS
description: GENEVA, Jan. 19The ma jor Western oil companies sub mitted a new proposal, said to be quite near the latest offer by the producing countries, when negotiations resumed to day on increased payments to make up for the devaluation of the dollar.

title: PENTAGON IS SILENT ON MYLAI CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 19A spokesman for the Pentagon declined today to comment on renewed charges that the Army had covered up the massacre at Mylai in South Vietnam in 1968. Jerry W. Friedheim, the Defense Department spokes man, said our legal officers feel public comment at this time is inappropriate because the Calley case is still pending review.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Apts to rentshare  exch. 1,000's listed In this week's Apartment Mart. At News stand today Advance copies 7093331. Advt.

title: State of Union Speech To Be on TV Today
description: President Nixon's State of the Union Message before a joint session of Congress will be broadcast live at 12:30 P.M. today on television and radio.

title: WILE BURTIN, 63, EXHIBIT DESIGNER
description: Will Burtin, a designer of exhibits, particularly visual ex planations of scientific matter, died of cancer Tuesday night in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Stony Point, N. Y.

title: Jersey Consumer Division Condemns Practices of Highway Eyeglass Centers
description: TRENTON, Jan. 19  High way eyeglass centers that give customers quickie eye exam inations, inaccurate prescrip tions and improper tenses came under fire today by the New Jersey Division of Consumer Protection.

title: Muskie Is Endorsed by Gotbaum; Lindsay Urged to Give Up Race
description: Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Mu nicipal Workers, which has 95, 000 members in this city, en dorsed Senator Edmund A. Muskie yesterday for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination and urged Mayor Lindsay to withdraw from the race.

title: Together,' a Sex Documentary, Arrives
description: Sex isn't everything. Understanding and love make sex "the ultimate human experience," according to a lad of drivel, slapped together as a movie, titled "Together." It arrived here yesterday, in a blanket showcase looking, from Boston. The production Code has stamped on "X" on it, and surely the libel in this case stands for excruciating. "D" for dull would have been better.This is the latest of those color documentaries rigged as a helpful aide to "the mystery of man and woman," while drooling over nudity, various intertwinings and, in this case, one act of oral sex. Most of it seems a commercial brochure for a "retreat" for young people on Long Island run by a sexual therapist named "Dr. Currey." At least that's what it sounds like.Droning away various platitudes about sex, the goateed, wide-eyed doctor at least keeps his shirt on. That much we're spared.

title: Kennedy to Study Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, an nounced today that he would conduct public hearings on the extent of the Government's electronic surveillance without court authorization. He is chairman of the Senate ad ministrative practice and pro cedure subcommittee.

title: U.S. Says Jet Shot Down MIG Over North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19The United States command announced that a Navy Phan tom jet shot down an enemy MIG21 deep inside North Viet nam today. It was the first MIG reported downed in 22 months.

title: Advertising:
description: Every once in a while an ad agency goes to seed. Less frequently do seeds go to ad agencies, but today is one of those days. After 30 years with Flagler & Nelson of Buffalo, the W. Atlee Bur pee Company is switching its seedhouse advertising ac count to Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Reluctant Ad Man Turns To Chartering Business
description: Who else but an adver tising executive would come up with the slogan Barter for Charter.

title: Brooklyn Scatter Housing Stirs a Clash at Hearing
description: Accusations of racism were exchanged yesterday at a City Planning Commission hearing on a lowincome scattersite housing project in Brooklyn.

title: National Guard Battalions From 11 States Are Manning 27 Missile Sites in Air Defense System
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. Eleven battalions of the Na tional Guard, representing as many states, have taken over an important share of the de fense of the continental United States from air attack.

title: Phone Union Chief Explains Rejection of Company Offer
description: Joseph A. Beirne, president of the Communications Workers of America, told union officials representing the state's 35,000 striking telephone craftsmen yesterday that contract propos als advanced by the New York Telephone Company Jan. 7 were so meager they were rejected out of hand.

title: Rockets Beat Chaps, 11692
description: DENVER, Jan. 19 (AP)The Denver Rockets rallied for 71 points in the second half behind Ralph Simpson and Dave Rob isch to defeat the Dallas Chap arrals, 11692, tonight.

title: Market Place:
description: The stock market has had a nice fling nowthe Dow Jones industrial average is up about 100 points since the day before Thanksgiving, when the current feast be gan.

title: Catamaran Challenges Australia For a Cup
description: The United States, which has yet to win, will challenge Australia for the In ternational Catamaran Challenge Tro phy starting Feb. 12 in Victoria, Aus tralia. Contested in Class C catamarans, the fouroutofseven series, known as the Little America's Cup, will be a match race between Weathercock of the United States and an Australian boat yet to be chosen.

title: DIAMOND FUTURES TRADED IN WEST
description: For the first time in the his tory of commodity exchanges, diamond futures were traded yesterday on the West Coast Commodity Exchange in Los Angeles; an event the exchange had spent months preparing for.

title: Schoonmaker Is Honored
description: James M. (Ding) Schoonmaker 2d of Miami, who posted five straight victories in the preOlym pic Star Class regatta in Kiel, Ger many, has been named the Martini & Rossi yachtsman of the year for 1971.

title: The New Army Grows Older
description: The Army, less than a year after announcing that recruits would be given, if not egg in their beer, at least beer in their barracks, is ringing down the curtain on its strange interlude. In fact, it is literally pulling down the curtains which briefly adorned the barracks, along with partitions that offered some privacy to privates. The olive drab dormitory is once again the order of the day.

title: Health Services Agency Names 22 Places With Code Violations
description: Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, yesterday released the names of 22 restaurants and food re tailers that had been found, after two inspections and an administrative bearing, to have failed to correct serious viola tions of the Health Code.

title: Murphy, in Test, Assigns Patrolman to Home Precinct
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has extended his yearold experimental neigh borhood police team concept a step further and has assigned a patrolman to the 34th Pre cinct, which includes the upper Manhattan neighborhood in which the patrolman grew up and still makes his home.

title: CITY WIDENS BAN ON BIAS OVER SEX
description: The City's Human Rights Commission ruled yesterday that the city's ban on discrimi nation based on sex applied to such public accommoda tions and facilities as hotels and residences for men or women only, to Ladies Day tickets to ball games and to cutrate drinks for women in bars.

title: Labor Department to Fund 10 Minority Worker Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Labor Department an nounced today that it would provide funds within the next 30 days to support home town plans developed in 10 acres to hire and train mi nority workers in construction crafts.

title: 3,805 on Relief at Work Under New Law
description: Only 1,805 employable welfare recipients are working in city agencies under a new state law that has required such employ ables since August to work out the amount of their relief grants, a city report showed yes terday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Those who wish to know more about fishing for trout are invited to attend an eightweek school sponsored by the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited.

title: Hawks Sink Seals, 20
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Bobby Hull netted his 32d and 33d goals of the season and Tony Esposito earned his fourth shutout tonight in a 20 victory for the Chicago Black Hawks over the California Gol den Seals.

title: U.S. Survey Reports 24 Million Have Tried Smoking Marijuana
description: About 24 million Americans have tried marijuana but only about a third, of that number use it regularly, a toplevel drug investigator estimated last night in a preview of a report to the nation.

title: Rangers Gain 51 Victory Over Kings As Fairbairn Registers Pair of Goals
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19The New York Rangers didn't quite reach their quota, but did well enough in beating the Los An geles Kings, 51, before 7,814 at the Forum tonight. The victory moved them within two points of the firstplace Boston Bruins, who have played one more game.

title: W. K. Hicks of Jets Seized In Harlem on Gun Charge
description: W. K. Hicks, member of the New York football Jets, was arrested last night at a restau rant in Harlem and charged with illegal possession of a loaded 22caliber pistol.

title: Nina Means the World To Two L.I. Families
description: Nina, a schooner that won the 1928 transAtlantic race to Spain and numerous other ocean races, has been pur chased by two families and a bachelor from Long Island. They plan to use the yacht for world travel.

title: Farm Subsidy Administrator Cleared on Payment Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI)A staff report of the Senate Agriculture Committee cleared the administrator of the Federal farm subsidy pro gram today in the improper payment of checks to hundreds of cotton farmers in Kern County, Calif., where the offi cial owns a farm.

title: Willie Wood Retires
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 19 (AP)Willie Wood, a fivetime allpro defensive back with the Green Bay Packers, is retiring to become a defensive backfield coach for the San Diego Charg ers, the Packers announced today.

title: Savings Association Elects
description: George A. Mooney, president of the Washington Heights Federal Savings and Loan As sociation, announced yesterday that Richard H. Grant, director of research, will take on the added duties of senior vice president and secretary, and Richard J. Stewart will become vice president in charge of the mortgage servicing depart ment, Raymond J. Donnelly will become assistant secretary in the mortgage department and Thomas G. Falk has been named assistant treasurer and manager of the 149th Street branch office.

title: OSLO FISHERIES AIDE SPURNS MARKET PACT
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 19 (Reu ters)Fisheries Minister knut Hoem has refused to sign his country's accession treaties to the European Common Market, dealing a severe blow to Pre mier Trygve Bratteli's campaign for public support for Nor way's entry.

title: SQUIRES CONQUER COLONELS, 138132
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19 (AP) Charlie Scott scored 46 points tonight as the Virginia Squires beat Kentucky, 138132, in an American Basketball Associa tion game and snapped the Colonels 10game winning streak.

title: Sadat Says He Won't Bow to Students
description: CAIRO, Jan. 19President Anwar elSadat said today that he would not submit to any pressure group after students had staged the first major cam pus demonstrations in more than three years.

title: New Soviet Generator, Seen as Future Source of Energy, Is Hailed
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19 Soviet technicians have hailed the successful operation of the world's first industrial magneto hydrodynamic generator, one of the new sources of electricity that is viewed by some as a future supply of energy.

title: Foster Begins a Recital Series By Three Pianists Who Teach
description: A series of three Tully Hall, recitals by pianists who teach at Indiana University  Sid ney Foster, Abbey Simon and Jorge Bolet  began Tuesday night with the appearance of Mr. Foster.

title: London Sends an Aide
description: LONDON, Jan. 19The Brit ish Government alarmed by developments in Rhodesia, sent a special representative to Salisbury today.

title: Dance: Sharing a Wealth of Talent
description: A full house at the Brook lyn Academy of Music was on hand Tuesday night to applaud the Murray Louis Dance Company and the Al win Nikolais Dance Theater. It was the first time the two dance groups have appeared on the same program. This new sharing of the wealth of talent, that iswas an un qualified success.

title: In Private Homes of New Orleans, the Best of Creole Cooking
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 The Super Bowl game over and Mardi Gras nearly a month away, people here have turned their minds to the city's favorite sport eating.

title: GUILD AND A.P. REACH A TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: The Wire Service Guild and The Associated Press have reached tentative agreement on a new twoyear contract rais ing the top minimum pay for experienced newsmen and pho tographers to $300 in three stages. The current top mini mum is $252.

title: Stanton Proposes Debates On Campuses by Nominees
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 19 (AP)Dr. Frank. Stanton, vice chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System last night proposed a series of college campus debates by the major parties Presidential nominees as a way to get the candidates together on the broadcast media without vio lating Federal equaltime re strictions.

title: Forest Hills Collegian Winner of Scholarship
description: Susan Hallie Wiener of Forest Hills, Queens, is the winner of the $500 Thomas Fleming Day Scholarship Award for 1971.

title: G.M. PLEA DENIED ON 75 STANDARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 William D. Ruckelshaus, admin istrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, rejected to day as legally insufficient a request of the General Motors Corporation for a year's post ponement of the emissions standards for 1975 model cars required by the 1970 Clean Air Act.

title: CHARLES REHNER, 67, OF PLUMBING FIRM
description: Charles K. Rehner, founder in 1937 of C. K. Rehner, Inc., a plumbing concern in Elmhurst, Queens, died Monday evening at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 6561 Saunders Street, Rego Park, Queens.

title: Klansman Hurt in a March
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (UPI)The Imperial Wizard of the New Orleans Ku Klux Klan was injured slightly today by, three brickwielding blacks dur ing a march commemorating the birthday of Robert E. Lee. H. Roswell Thompson, a peren nial candidate for public office, was dressed in Klan regalia when the attack took place near a statue of Lee. Arrested were James N. Smith and Rus sel Wyman both 21 years old and from New Orleans. A third fled.

title: Panoramic Photo of Mars Shows a 300Mile Canyon
description: Mariner 9 has transmitted a panoramic photograph of Mars showing a vast chasm with branching canyons resembling a network of dry river beds  features hitherto unseen on the planet.

title: ATEST SAID TO YIELD USEFUL QUAKE DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Government said today that recorded earth tremors from the huge underground nu clear blast at Amchitka Island last November had yielded in formation that could help to predict and even mitigate nat ural earthquakes.

title: IRVING WEINER
description: Irving Weiner, manager of the release print control department of Universal Pictures, a division of Universal City Studios, Inc., died apparently of a heart at tack Tuesday. He was 58 years old and lived at 7 Fanwood Road, Huntington Station, L. I.

title: PENN SETS BACK VILLANOVA 7464
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19  Phil Hankinson and Corky Calhoun combined for 44 points tonight to lead Pennsylvania to a 7464 victory over Villanova, before 9,223 in the Palestra.

title: Is Pace Of Hydro Slowing?
description: DETROITTen races are listed for the unlimited hy droplanes this year, but Lee Schoenith, an active figure in the class for more than 20 years, sees slight chance for improvement in speed for the thunderboats.

title: Mideast Bellicosity
description: Failure to take a decision for war or peace with Israel in December at the end of his muchadvertised year of decision has confronted President Sadat of Egypt with a problem of credibility at home and abroad. He evi dently feels he must justify his inactionand yet restore the threat of a future resort to forceboth to contain his domestic critics and to pressure Israel to negotiate on his terms.

title: I.R.A. Command Broken, Faulkner Says
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 19Prime Minister Brian Faulkner said today that the leadership of the Irish Repub lican Army had been broken and that security in Northern Ireland had sharply improved over the last month.

title: 3 Cochrans Named to U.S. Ski Team
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 19The United States Al pine skiing team may have set a Winter Olympic record today when it named three members of the same family to compete in the Games next month.

title: The Two Messages
description: President Nixon experimented yesterday in presenting two messages to Congress on the State of the Union, one a long, detailed written message and the other a comparatively brief, highly generalized talk. It was not a happy experiment.

title: G.E.'s Chief Impatient With Economy
description: The chairman of the General Electric Company said yesterday that he was impatient with the present economy.

title: Advertising:
description: It may be a little early in the year for you New Yorkarea folks to be thinking about swimming pools, but it's just right for Stanley E. Lebow.

title: Bengali Seamen, Marooned Here by Fear, Tell of West Pakistani Cruelties Aboard Ship
description: On a freezing December day, Mohammad Sabur, a Bengali seaman, slipped away from his ship at a Brooklyn pier because he feared that West Pakistani crew members would kill him.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST MARKS WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Tauber of Chevy Chase, Md., celebrated their 11th wedding anniversary by sending a controbution of $11 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. And John Carrara, an evangelist of Sparta, N.J., wrote; Today is my birthday and I am making a gift of $25 to the Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ALLENDE TO FORM A NEW CABINET
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20President Salvador Allende Gossens accepted the ersignation of his Cabinet today in order to form a new one.

title: New Cabinet in Belgium Is Formed After 75 Days
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 20Premier Gaston Eyskens, announced success today in his efforts to form a Belgian Cabinet. The new Cabinet, formed after 75 days of intensive negotiations, is a continuation of the coalition of Socialists and Social Christians that maintained its position in November's elections.

title: TaxExempts Hit
description: The credit markets continued to slump yesterday, affected chiefly by Treasury Secretary Connally's acknowledging that the Federal budget deficit for fiscal 1972 would be about $40billion.

title: Gateway Park Bill Gains Favor of House Members
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Prospects for House approval of the Gateway national recreation area brightened considerably today when Donald E. Elliott, chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, assured key Representatives that the Federal Government would not have to finance major costs to transport people to the park areas.

title: Black Opposition Imperiling BritishRhodesian Accord
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 20The proposed settlement of Rhodesia's rebellion against Britain is coming under growing pressure caused by unexpectedly strong black opposition to the terms of the agreement by mob violence and by tensions between the white Rhodesian Government and a British factfinding team.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISAndr Malraux, the great French writer, is an outstanding example of the committed artist. It is a clich among younger intellectuals that they should engage themselves in world events and play an active role.

title: The Tempering of Our Pride
description: Q. All your work involves extinct societies or those on the road to extinction. Listening to you now, we would like to ask what practical use they can be for us today.

title: British Economic Theory Goes Awry
description: LONDON  Paradox has hardly ever marked an economy as distinctly as it did Britain's in 1971. Even W.S. Gilbert, that most ingenious paradoxicalist, would have been sated.

title: Legislators Urge Action in Washington on pay Care
description: A group of state legislators suggested yesterday that the only way to save communitycontrolled and Governmentfinanced daycare programs here was to concentrate efforts not on City Hall or Albany but on Washington.

title: Bronx Job Project Funded
description: The Federal Government has earmarked $2,141,485 to finance for another year a concentrated employment program to serve 1,300 people in the South Bronx. The announcement of the new financing was made here last night by Clayton J. Cottrell, regional manpower administrator of the United States Department of Labor. The program is sponsored by the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: LATE DROP ERASES EARLY STOCK RISE
description: Stock prices fell sharply in the final hour of trading yesterday to more than wipe out earlier modest gains.

title: Cindy Is Given Ski Team Regalia
description: INTERLAKEN, Switzerland, Jan. 20The sand slipped slowly and every five minutes Cindy Nelson reached out from her hospital bed and turned the miniature hourglass over.

title: Dance: Murray Louis and Personnae
description: PERSONNAE (New York premiere), choreography, Murray Louis, music, Free Life Communications; costumes, Frank Garcia. With Murray Louis, Michael Ballard, Robert Small and Marcia Wardell. Presented by the Murray Louis Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Reserve Issues Data
description: The Federal Reserve's expansionary credit policy showed signs of accelerating in the weekly banking data made available yesterday.

title: Shettle and Dunn Advance In Court Tennis Doubles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20The local pair of Bill Shettle, an amateur, and Jimmy Dunn, a professional, advanced to the semifinal round of the United States Open court tennis doubles championship today by defeating the Boston team of Philip Stockton, an amateur, and Joe Crane, a professional, by 80, 84, at the Racquet Club.

title: 42,000 Gallons of Oil Spilled Into the Arthur Kill
description: CARTERET, N. J., Jan. 20Fortytwo thousand gallons of oil spilled into the Arthur Kill near here early today after 669foot oceangoing tanker, the Atlantic Prestige, hit a submerged object.

title: Advertising:
description: After what was characterized as a great deal of discussion the National Advertising Review Board at its second meeting yesterday voted to extend its interest beyond truth and accuracy in advertising.

title: An Examination of the Written Message
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Following is a detailed examination of the written State of the Union Message:

title: Berlin in Search for Identity After the Accords
description: BERLINAt the turn of the year, West Berlin was looking for a new political, economic and commercial role in Europe, following the accords reached by the Western allies and the Soviet Union to improve the situation for this Western outpost, isolated deep inside East Germany.

title: BERTRAM MAXWELL, HISTORY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Bertram W. Maxwell, adjunct professor of history and political science at Wagner College fom 1946 to 1967, died here Sunday. He was 81 years old and lived at 81 Charles Street.

title: ARAB LANDS WIN OIL PRICE RAISE
description: GENEVA, Jan. 20The major Western oil companies signed an agreement here tonight under which they will pay at least $700million a year to six producing countries on the Persian Gulf to compensate them for the devaluation of the dollar last December.

title: AIDING LAOTIAN DEFENDERS: An American plane dropping supplies to soldiers Skyline Ridge. It overlooks the military complex at Long Tieng, under attack by enemy.
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 20Concern about the unusually powerful and early Commu nist offensive in Laos has grown so intense that the United States Government has lifted much of the secrecy it maintained over its efforts here and is saying that, far from doing too much, the Americans are doing too little and the Administration may ask for more money.

title: M GOVERN SCORES LINDSAY SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Money, or talk of it, permeated much of the political debate today along the campaign trails of the major aspirants for Presidential nominations.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposal that the State University take over the City University, with the latter dropping its 125yearold freetuition policy, revives an issue that has long separated city officials from the Governor and many upstate legislators.

title: Atheist Is Refused Listing As Israeli Instead of Jew
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 20  A Jewishborn atheist lost his battle today to be recognized officially as Israeli rather than Jewish by nationality.

title: U.S. Lists Missing Men
description: PARIS, Jan. 20 (Reuters)The United States today presented to the Hanoi delegation at the Vietnam peace talks a list of 14 American pilots shot down over North Vietnam and asked why they were not on the North Vietnamese list of United States prisoners of war.

title: Student Demonstrations Continuing in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Jan. 20Egypt's new Premier, Dr. Aziz Sidky, and his wareconomy Cabinet accelerated work today on an austerity and mobilization program as students continued meetings to demand a militant and unequivocal line of action.

title: First Drawing Held In 50Cent Lottery Of New York State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20 (AP)The winning number in the first drawing under New York State's new 50cent weekly lottery was 121077.

title: Edwin Lockwood Strickland of Architects Samples Corp.
description: LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 20Edwin Lockwood Strickland, who retired in 1963 as president of the Architects Samples Corporation, 101 Park Avenue, New York, and as treasurer of Architects Offices, Inc., owner of the Park Avenue building, died here Monday at the age of 94.

title: U.S. ACCUSES AIRCO OF TRUST VIOLATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Justice Department today charged Airco, Inc., of New York City, an industrial metal and glass manufacturing company, with using illegal reciprocal purchasing arrangements in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: New York Port Notes
description: So far as some segments of the shipping industry are concerned, the Sandy Hook Pilots Association of New York and New Jersey is as adept at threading its way into snug legislative harbors at Albany as its members are in guiding deepsea vessels through the Narrows.

title: Let's Buy Australia
description: America, you may not believe this, but a lot of Australians don't like you.

title: Point of View
description: BRUSSELS  It's not realistic to think that we'll take over the place, said Christopher Layton, a 41yearold Englishman who had just moved into the starfishshaped, concreteandglass building at the Place Schuman, but the people here hope we'll find more practical ways to run it.

title: Mines Are Being Closed in the Netherlands
description: THE HAGUEIn the southernmost tip of the Netherlands miners are facing the dilemma long faced by their counterparts in Wales and the Ruhr: mines are being closed and they must find other jobs.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Save Our Stripers, Inc., an organization that has been striving to have the striped bass classified as game fish in New York, continues to exude optimism.

title: Colonels Tie Record Streak
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 20 (AP) The Kentucky Colonels tied an American Basketball Association record tonight with their 10th straight road victory as they built an 11point lead in the final period and withstood a late Virginia Squires rally for a 118115 decision.

title: Trade Issues Stir U.S. and Allies
description: PARISThe scrap between the United States and Western Europe got serious last year, and it is not over yet. Call it what you willa poker game, a chess match, or a shoot'emup at the Group of 10 Corral. What the world saw was the inevitable friction of a period of transition from the postwar era of American hegemony to a new age of blocs, continental superpowers and perhaps even a revival of the East Asia CoProsperity Sphere.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Colonialism11 A.M.

title: Place: How to Create Annual Reports
description: In about two weeks some of the most beautiful photographs ever shot and some of the most carefully chosen words ever graven on costly dullfinish paper in elegant type will begin to find their way into the nation's mailboxes.

title: Agency Rethinking Parts of Report on Markets Delay Possible
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Securities and Exchange Commission has encountered fierce criticism from members of Congress on its plans for restructuring the stock markets. As a result, it is reconsidering major sections of its report on the matter and may be unable to get the report out next week, as originally planned.

title: FLYERS NIP HAWKS IN LATE DRIVE, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) Bill Lesuk slammed in a 12foot goal in the third period as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated Chicago, 32, tonight for their fourth National Hockey League triumph over the Black Hawks in 4 years.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERLaurence L. beloved husband of the late Nettie R., brother of the late Joel, Herbert and Rachel A. Weiss. Laid to rest Thursday, Jan. 20, 1972.

title: Soviet Planners Go West to Shop
description: MOSCOW  While Soviet political leaders try to market their brand of detente with the West this spring, their economic counterparts will be shopping increasingly for Western technology to help power a new fiveyear plan aimed at modernizing Soviet industry and giving the consumer a better break.

title: 16 Air Academy Cadets Guilty In Cheating Inquiry and Resign
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Jan. 20 (UPI)A student court found 16 Air Force Academy cadets guilty of cheating and failing to report violations of the academy's strict honor code today. The cadets resigned, Lieut. Gen. Albert P. Clark, the academy's superintendent, reported tonight at a news conference.

title: Buckley Arrives in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 20 (AP)Senator James L. Buckley of New York arrived here today for an overnight stop on his eightnation factfinding tour in Asia. He said he was trying to gauge the impact on our Asian friends of President Nixon's pending trip to Peking.

title: Bert Hanlon, Composer Of Mississippi, Is Dead
description: Bert Hanlon, composer, author, actor and director, died here Jan. 1. He lived in the Ansonia Hotel.

title: Chile Votes for Democracy
description: The leader of President Allende's Socialist party Chile says defeat of the Government coalition in two Congressional elections last weekend means it must radicalize its program. A much more plausible explanation is that the results demonstrate just the opposite. They indicate that a majority of voters in both districts already have had enough of Dr. Allende's program to construct socialism in Chile.

title: Ruth Adams, Head of Wellesley, Named an Officer of Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 20 Dr. Ruth M. Adams, the president of Wellesley College since 1966, has been appointed a vice president of Dartmouth College, where she is to assist that allmale institution's transition to coeducational status next fall.

title: Nixon Pledges a Drive For Women's Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)President Nixon asked Congress today to broaden the jurisdiction of the Civil Rights Commission to deal with discrimination against women.

title: CURB IS PLANNED IN WELFARE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to bring out welfare reform legislation this year, but minus the annual guaranteed income that President Nixon is seeking.

title: Pollution, a European Problem
description: ROME Nearly everybody here seems to be talking about foul air, dirty water, adulterated food, forest fires or the massacre of birds and animals by throngs of weekend hunters, but only the lower echelons of the Italian judiciary are doing anything about it.

title: Transformer Dumping Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Treasury Department said today that France, Italy, Japan, Switzerland and Britain were dumping large power transformers in the United States (selling them here at a lower price than in the homeland).

title: Britons Join Trek To Work In Germany
description: DUSSELDORFWith West Germany's industry still surging forward in a relatively healthy and robustlooking state, British workers have joined the stream of foreign labor looking for jobs they cannot find at home, and looking sometimes for the more pleasure and experience of working abroad.

title: Nixon Frightened the Bulls Away From the Bourses
description: There is no question that foreign stock exchanges reacted negatively to President Nixon's new economic policy last summer.

title: MRS. JEROME DOYLE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 20 Mrs. Gertrude Cloonan Doyle, wife of Jerome Doyle, a member of the New York City law firm of Cahill, Gordon, Sonnett, Reindel & Ohl, died today in St. Vincent's Hospital, New York, after a brief illness. She was 59 years old and lived at 65 Beach Avenue.

title: Grim Realities in Bangladesh
description: Sheik Mujibur Rahman's order to former Bengali guerrilla fighters to surrender their arms signifies the beginning of the end of the euphoria which has gripped secessionist Bangladesh since the surrender of West Pakistani forces there last month and Mujib's triumphant return ten days ago. The Sheik's new Government in Dacca must now come to grips with the grim realities of an independent Golden Bengal, a ravished Bengal that is rich only in the rhetorical visions of its poets and patriots.

title: Envoy to Bonn Named To No. 2 Pentagon Job
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 20 (AP)Administration sources said tonight that Kenneth Bush, United States Ambassador to West Germany, had been selected for the No. 2 job at the Pentagon.

title: RAIL TRAFFIC OFF; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Jan. 15 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: Books of The Times
description: Christopher Isherwood is lucky. At 68 ho is able to perform an act of piety, make a gesture of reconciliation to his parents he would not have been able to make when they were alive and he was younger. By delving into the diaries of his mother (kept over a period of 70 years) and the letters of his father, he has been able to relive his own life and reCreate theirs. His own comments are puckish and far from reverential, but the book is a memoir that is also an apology.

title: JERSEY SHORTENS RACING MEETINGS AT ATLANTIC CITY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The New Jersey Racing Commission approved today a shift of racing dates from the Atlantic City Track to both Monmouth Park and Freehold Raceway.

title: CITY TAX TO HELP HOSPITALS ASKED
description: Two lawmakers yesterday proposed a city health tax on pernicious substances Cigarettes, gasoline, liquorbeer and electric powerto help support the 18 municipal hospitals.

title: European Nations Fight Inflation, Too
description: Wage and price controls, similar in some cases tb those now in force in the United States, have been widespread in Europe in recent years to fight inflation, but in most instances the controls have had only limited effectiveness.

title: For East Germany, Consumer Products
description: BERLINIn 1971 the new East German Government of Erich Honecker began to cast off its cloak of consumerproduct drabness and recognize that stylish apparel, color TV's and stereo systems are not necessarily contradictory to the Ideologies of this Communist country.

title: Floridians Top Condors
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP)Seldomused Willie Long scored 25 points tonight as the Floridians put on their biggest scoring burst of the year and defeated the Pittsburgh Condors. 138120, in the American Basketball Association.

title: Comecon's Aim: More Integration
description: WARSAW  An economist in Prague was answering questions last summer about the problems of Comecon, the Communist bloc's economic body, when he suddenly offered this example:

title: Marinaro Is Cited Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Washington Touchdown Club will award its college back of the year trophy for the second year in a row to Ed Marinaro, Cornell's recordbreaking running back.

title: With the Swiss BoomProblems
description: GENEVAIt is not quite true that the Swiss are making more money but enjoying it less. They did not make, quite as much last year as they did in 1970, and the slight setback predicted for 1972 is already being felt.

title: Greece Lures Her Rich Sons Home
description: ATHENSThe money has been pouring in from abroad and at home into Greece's shipyards, oil refineries and tourist hotels at such an accelerating rate that in this final year of the muchtrumpeted fiveyear plan, the country's ruling generals may even approach their flashy projections of 1968.

title: STUDENT DISORDERS WORSEN IN MADRID
description: MADRID, Jan. 20 (AP)University students clashed with policemen again today. It was the worst incident since the disorders began four days ago over the suspension of medical students.

title: SEELEY AND NIEVES BOX HERE TONIGHT
description: Walter Seeley of Sayville, L. I., who spends his work time clambering around house roofs and his hobby time punching ring rivals, will meet Jesus (Farajitomeans pigeon) Nieves in the cofeatured 10round featherweight fight in the Felt Forum tonight.

title: Bonn Forecasts Crying Wolf?
description: BONN  One peculiar aspect of most expert forecasts concerning the West German economy for 1972 is that they sound exactly like the predictions made one year ago for 1971: they add up to recession.

title: Abel Urges Efforts to Make Pay Board a Success
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17Making the Pay Board work is preferable to the alternatives that would come if the board failed, I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, says.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a recent letter, Prof. Jeffrey O'Connell, a law professor and leading proponent of no fault insurance, charges that trial lawyers refuse to represent car accident victims unless the other driver has insurance.

title: WITNESSES ASSAIL NEW HAVEN FARES
description: Three dozen angry railroad riders and public officials laced into the New Haven commuter lines of the Penn Central yesterday and into a proposal to increase its fares as much as 160 per cent.

title: Ortiz Stops Rondeau in 4th
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 20 (AP) The former word lightweight champion, Carlos Ortiz, scored a fourthround konckout over Terry Rondeau of Pittsfield, Mass., in a scheduled 10round bout at the Portland Expo Building tonight. Ortiz floored Rondeau once in the third round and twice in the fourth before the referee, Pete Bennett, stopped the fight at 2:36.

title: Drop Is Reported In Short Interest By the Big Board
description: Shortinterest positions on the New York Stock Exchange as of Jan. 14 were 6 per cent below the monthearlier figure, the exchange reported yesterday.

title: Muskie Lining Up Support in the State
description: Confronting Mayor Lindsay on his own political turf, Senator Edmund S. Muskie began yesterday lining up Muskie endorsements by prominent New York Democrats.

title: Canadian Lukens Elects
description: John F. Weaber yesterday was elected president and director of Canadian Lukens, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Lukens Steel Company. He is a member of the parent company's management council.

title: COALITION CALLING A NATIONAL PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20A provisional study group started an effort today to revive a national Spanishspeaking political action coalition. The group announced plans for a national convention in Washington on April 29 and 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The lives lost at Willowbrook State School will not have been wholly wasted if they shock New York State Into farreaching and longoverdue changes in its system of care for the severely mentally retarded and mentally ill. More positions and funds, though absolutely essential, are not the fundamental solution. A revolution in care and training is necessary.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The New York City Department of Health advertised in the November 1971 issue of the Bulletin of the Medical Society of the County of. Queens to the effect that positions are available in the department. The advertisement continued by stating that the department is recruiting to fill several top management jobs. They are particularly anxious to get qualified black or Puerto Rican staff.

title: Growth Cheering France
description: PARIS  The managers of the French economy had some solid reasons for satisfaction last year. They also had reasons for uncertainty in 1972.

title: Transcript of President's Address on State of the Union to Joint Session of Congress
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's address on the State of the Union to a Joint session of Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Croatian Communists Oust 700 As Inciters of Regional Turmoil
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20More than 700 members of the Croatian region's Communist party have resigned, been expelled or relieved of their duties in the last month in a continuing purge of nationalists.

title: Hanoi Cable to Times Discusses P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 North Vietnam has reiterated, in a message to The New York Times, its apparent position that American prisoners will not he released until the Nixon Administration agrees both to withdraw all its forces from South Vietnam and to end its support of the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Black Woman to Run
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)Assemblywoman Yvonne W. Brathwaite, Democrat of Los Angeles, announced today that she would seek to become the first black woman elected to Congress from California.

title: U.S.ISRAELI PACT FOR 18 MORE JETS IS REPORTED NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The United States and Israel are, nearing an agreement under which 18 more F4 Phantom fighterbombers would be delivered starting this spring, probably in March, according to wellplaced administration sources.

title: Brazilian Slaves Flee in 'Ganga Zumba'
description: In "Ganga Zumba," Carlos Diegues, the young Brazilian director, uses a small band of non-professional blacks and whites in a jungle to depict a bloody chapter in his country's history. The story is the flight of sugarcane plantation slaves to an island inhabited by earlier fugitives. The time is 1641.While the picture moves like molasses and the performances amount to crude, self-conscious pantomime, this Engish-subtitled movie, burning with sincerity, is curiously admirable, even haunting. And it does indeed suggest a larger human drama throbbing off-screen in the background.The players behave with a natural dignity. In their midst is a black youth named Antonio Pitanga, whose strong face conveys volumes. Add to this artlessness the simple eloquence of the dialogue, vivifying the cruelty, horror and despair of slavery.Finally, Mr. Diegues's dramatic microcosm is rooted with utter authenticity in the primeval landscape of a background that has been photographed with bleak austerity. You can smell Brazil. Above all, you can feel the people we see here and feel for them.The new film is double-billed with "Angela Davis: Portrait of a Revolutionary" at the New Yorker Theater.

title: Rattenni Acquitted in U. S. Court Of Trying to Bribe I.R.S. Agent
description: Nicholas A. Rattenni, identified by Federal authorities as a Mafia leader in Westchester County, was acquitted yesterday of offering to bribe an Internal Revenue Service agent to gain favorable treatment on his incometax returns.

title: PHILIP H. STROH
description: Philip H. Stroh, assistant vice president in the trust department of the Schroder Trust Company, died Wednesday in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Hasbrouck Heights, N. J.

title: Hijacker of Jet Parachutes In Colorado and Is Seized
description: STERLING, Colo., Jan. 20A young man saying he had a bomb hijacked a jetliner today, obtained two parachutes and a $50,000 ransom, bailed out over Colorado and was then captured near his parachute, silent, mudsplattered and injured.

title: ROCKETS WALLOP ROYALS, 104 TO 87
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 20 (UPI) Elvin Hayes, Stu Lantz and Calvin Murphy combined for 75 points tonight as the Houston Rockets broke a Cincinnati faergame winning streak with a 10487 victory over the Royals in the National Basketball Association.

title: U.S. Trade Balance Held a Possibility
description: The United States has a fighting chance of achieving a trade balance this year, Harold 13. Scott, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for domestic and international business, said yesterday. He was making this statement, he said, despite the estimated $2billion deficit in 1971.

title: People in Europe and Mideast
description: Taxpayers of the world, unite! Or. at least, take heart from the recent  and successful  taxpayers revolt against Decree No. 1943 in Lebanon. The decree raised customs duties on 350 imported items that the Government called luxuries. But Beirut's merchants disagreed and more or less went on strike indefinitely.

title: Cuisine Was Haute, But Now It's Casual
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: PayPriceJob Problems in Europe
description: RISING prices, higher wages, unemployment and fear of recessionthese labor problems, not unfamiliar to the United States, were shared to some degree by most of Western Europe in 1971.

title: With Russian Oil, Marketing Skill
description: Following the visit of Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans to the Soviet Union, many Americans are taking a new look at EastWest trade. Americans are not the only ones contemplating new approaches. The Russians themselves have been engaged in some innovative experiments in international trade. Nowhere is the look newer than in oil.

title: MALTA NEGOTIATORS RUN INTO NEW SNAGS
description: ROME, Jan. 20Negotiations concerning military bases in mill a ran into new difficulties today and a breakdown was barely avoided.

title: Weekend Recipes
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: $75Milliona Year Bookie Ring Raided in Luxury Flat on L.I.
description: Armed with a noknock search warrant and a pair of sledgehammers, Nassau County rackets detectives battered down the door of a luxury apartment in Great Neck Plaza, LI., last night and seized two men and detailed records of an alleged $75millionayear bookmaking operation.

title: The Market: Growth and Discord
description: BRUSSELS  The turning point came during the third week of May last year and was announced in the same gilded, tapestried hall of the Elysee Palace where President Charles de Gaulle vetoed British membership eight years earlier.

title: Hawkins Tallies 40 as Losers Never Lead
description: PHOENIX, Jan. 20One brief challenge midway through the fourth quarter, when they cut a 22point deficit to 10, was the most excitement the New York Knicks could generate tonight as they were beaten by the Phoenix Suns, 130109.

title: SEARS WILL MARKET VIDEOTAPE TV UNITS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it plans to market this year complete videotape television systems for home use. The company demonstrated a complete system25inch color cartridge reecordingplayback attachment and blackandwhite camera with a 100foot cablein the Hotel Pierre.

title: Muskie Calls Nixon's Address Empty
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 Senator Edmund S. Muskie assailed President Nixon's State of the Union Address today as empty of substance and devoid of hope for the troubled American cities.

title: GRUMMAN REPORTS LOSS ON NAVY JETS
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Jan. 20 (AP)  The Grumman Corporation expects to lose about $65million in completing a contract for 86 F14A Tomcat jet fighters and has told the Navy it considers options to buy more of the planes invalid, the company said today.

title: Theater: V ivat Regina!
description: History without tears and without fears is Robert Bolt's stockintrade. Vivat! Vivat Reginal, which arrived with proper pomp and circumstance at the Broadhurst Theater last night is a new and persuasive theatricalization of Elizabeth Tudor and Mary Stuart. The story has been told better, but there is a fascination in this onrush of two destinies and the play triumphs over its failures.

title: U.N. Members Asked for Cash Advance
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim appealed to member nations today for an advance of up to $20million before the end of March.

title: Rogers Reportedly Planning to Cut Intelligence Bureau by a Third
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Senior United States officials said today that Secretary of State William P. Rogers was planning to cut the State Department's intelligence bureau by about a third.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES HIGHER AT CLOSE
description: Prices of soybean and grain futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, with soybeans advancing 2 cents a bushel.

title: Lambert, Smith Kline Up
description: The pharmaceuticalchemical producers fared well last year, judging from results issued yesterday by the WarnerLambert Company, Smith Kline & French Laboratories, Inc., RichardsonMerrell, Inc., and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation.

title: Spain Respects Her Elders
description: MADRIDThe young financier, regarded in international banking circles as one of Spain's most promising businessmen, set himself to disillusion his listener about the role of his contemporaries in Spanish economic life.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Have Been Overlooking Michigan, Which Will Have 132 Votes at Convention
description: LANSING, Mich., Jan. 19Michigan will cast 132 votes at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach next July. It will count for something. But to see the way it has been treated the last few months by the Presidential hopefuls, you would think it was the Canal Zone (three votes).

title: G.O.P. HEAD LAUDS NEWBURGH CHIEF
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 20 Orange County's Republican leader spoke out in praise of Newburgh's newly suspended Police Chief today, but the ranking Democrat here endorsed the suspension as a step toward erasing the city's reputation as a cesspool of crime.

title: Spill on Hudson River
description: COEYMANS, N. Y., Jan. 20 (UPI)Work crews were called out along the Hudson River today to clean up a spill of up to 100,000 gallons of No. 2 fuel oil from a brick plant in this Albany County community.

title: Met Stages a Technological Production of Telleas
description: Those who love Debussy's Toelleas et Mlisande remained after the Wednesdaynight curtain at the Metropolitan Opera to venerate cast, conductor and the other partlcipants in the new production. Those who do not like the opera kept stealing out. After the second act the house looked a quarter empty.

title: Irish Cheddar for Japan
description: DUBLIN  Who knows what the effect will be on the traditional cuisine of Japan, but the Irish dairy industry is delighted that the Japanese seem to be acquiring a taste for Irish cheddar.

title: Appeal Is Made to Allow Specialists to Vie on Floor of Big Board
description: A member of the New York Stock Exchange made a personal but futile appeal yesterday to the exchange's governing board to permit stock specialists to compete with each other on the exchange's trading floor.

title: UN's Exuberant First Lady
description: The new First Lady of the United Nations has begun her unofficial and nonsalaried job with what might seem like two strikes against her: She can't stand the interminable round of diplomatic cocktail parties, and she's no fan of Viennese pastries, either.

title: Catholics in Ulster Refuse to Pay Rent In Growing Protest Over Internment
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 20Mrs. Margaret McCann, a widowed mother of three, sits each morning in a crowded launderette in the bleak Divis Flats, a Roman Catholic housing project.

title: Richey and Graebner Gain Semifinals
description: LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) Cliff Richey and Clark Graebner advanced to the semifinals of the Rothman's international tennis tournament with victories today.

title: Trade Fairs Scheduled Worldwide on Everything From Aviation to Toys
description: More than 1,000 trade fairs and specialized exhibitions have been scheduled during 1972 in more than 60 countries, according to a compilation by the United States Department of Commerce. The following listing is a sampling of the compilation.

title: Faulk and Fort Advance
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 20 (AP)Steve Faulk of Madisonville, La., and John Fort of Santa Monica, Calif., advanced today to the semifinals of the New Zealand tennis championships.

title: 5 Americans Die in Week
description: SAIGON, Jan. 20 (UPI) Five American servicemen were killed in the Indochina war last week, the same number as the week before, United States spokesmen said today.

title: Violent Crime Wave Stirs Debate in West Germany
description: BONN. Jan. 20A wave of violent crime highlighted by the long and intensive bunt for a gang of anarchists has stirred a wide and sometimes strident debate among West Germans.

title: News of Skiing
description: TIGNES, France, Jan. 20Jean Brechu, the young owner of the Ski d'Or, one of the many neat, new hotels in this high Alpine resort, started to search tonight for his contraryminded but adored St. Bernard named Schuls. He found the big dog three hours later. Considering the breathtaking nature of the scenic ski resort, which at 6,900 feet is the highest in the Alps, seldom has a dogit would seembeen better named. But Schuss, a 175pounder, has been a disappointment. For all he segos to care, ho might just as well be living on the Rue de la Paix in Paris.

title: As Europe Grows, Few Here Notice
description: WASHINGTONNot many Americans noticed, and fewer still cheered, when the Common Market voted to enlarge itself last year and found a new measure of, at least tactical, unity in monetary bargaining with the United States. A larger Europe, a more unified Europe, a stronger Europethis had been the great dream behind postwar American foreign policy. But suddenly it seemed a case of either too little and too late or altogether too much of a good thing for overburdened old Uncle Sam.

title: Aftermath of International Currency Upheaval:
description: Five observers of the European economic scene met at the Lasserre Restaurant in Paris on Jan. 3 to examine the currency upheaval of 1971, the preliminary resolution of that crisis in midDecember, and the implications for 1972 and beyond.

title: SWEEP BY 10,1300 OPENED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (AP)Ten thousand or more South Vietnamese troops have reportedly begun a sweep 45 miles northwest of Saigon to disrupt any enemy plans for an offensive near the capital.

title: Wide Technological Drive Planned by Administration
description: Administration sources gave details yesterday of some of the several dozen specific research projects included the program that President Nixon announced he would soon send to Congress for using technology to improve our everyday lives. The projects include:

title: In Middle East, Oil Pays the Way
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Oilproducing countries in the Middle East reaped record revenues last year with the rise in oil production and prices and are expected to do even better in 1972, barring any major confrontation.

title: Miss Goolagong Gains
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP)  Evonne Goolagong, the Wimbledon champion, defeated Kay Walker of Australia, 61, 63, today in the South Australian tennis championships.

title: Retail Sales Adavance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Department of Commerce reported today that total retailstore sales for the week ended Jan. 15 were an estimated $7,180,000,000, an increase of 7 per cent from the $6,720,000,000 for the corresponding week of last year. Departmentstore sales for the latest week were an estimated $652million, an increase of 10 per cent from $595million a year ago.

title: W. McHenry Browne Dead; Hearst Executive 32 Years
description: W. McHenry Browne, a Hearst newspaper executive for 32 years, died Saturday at Lee Memorial Hospital in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 71 years old and lived in Lehigh Acres, Fla.

title: Suit Against Tankers Dismissed
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 20State Supreme Court Justice Thomas M. Stark today dismissed a suit by the village of Port Jefferson against the Consolidated Petroleum Company, seeking to prevent any oil tankers from unloading cargo at that deepwater port.

title: Ecuador Fines U.S. Boat
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 20 (Reuters)Ecuador today fined the skipper of a United States tunafishing boat $58,670 for operating within the 200 miles of territorial waters she claims, the Natural Resources Ministry said. Three United States tuna boats were fined a total of $230,250 for the same reason yesterday.

title: 9 Injured by Bombs
description: NEWRY, Northern Ireland, Jan. 20 (Reuters)Nine people were injured here today in two separate bomb attacks that destroyed an income tax officeand thousands of tax recordsand a boutique.

title: ARMS FOUND IN CAMP FOR I.R.A. SUSPECTS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 20  Improvised weapons and two holes several feet deep were discovered today during a search by 1,000 British troops and Northern Ireland policemen at the Long Kesh internment camp about 12 miles south of here.

title: Internal Struggle Shakes Black Muslims
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 20A violent internal struggle, perhaps the start of a push for change and new leadership, is under way among the nation's Black Muslims.

title: Cops Play Cops n Robbersand Guess Who Wins
