description: Policemen played both sides in a cops and robbers game in the Bayside section of Queens yesterday. And since it was a simulated bank holdup, the cops won.

title: NIXON'S PEACE VOW SCORED BY ELLSBERG
description: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg scoffed last night at the President's promise of a generation of peace, saying, He's winding down the war like he's winding down my indictment.

title: U.S. Pollution Aide Urges Suit Over Dumping in Lake Superior
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, asked the Justice Department today to file suit against the Reserve Mining Company to force the company to stop polluting Lake Superior.

title: Owens and Archer Share Tucson Golf Lead on 65's
description: TUCSON, Jan. 20Charles Owens, an unusual golfer with an unusual style, shared the lead today in the $150,000 Dean MartinTucson open golf tourney with George Archer at 65. Owens, a black professional, is a former United States Army paratrooper.

title: Miss Henning Wins 2 Races In U.S. Speed Skating Trial
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 20 (AP)Anne Henning of Northbrodk, Ill., won two events today as the United States Olymplc speed skating team continued trial runs for the winter Olympic Games next month in Sapporo, Japan.

title: BREZHNEV IS URGED TO FREE DISSIDENT
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20  Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and civilrights advocate, has petitioned the Kremlin for the release of a 29yearold dissident, Vladimir K. Bukovsky, on the ground that his recent trial had not been public and that the defense had been given no opportunity to call its witnesses.

title: St. Francis Five Wins
description: Paced by Kenny Lam and Dennis McDermott, who scored 27 points each, St. Francis College defeated Rollins College of Winter Haven, Fla., 9381, on the winners court in Brooklyn last night. At the half, St. Francis held a 4536 advantage. Dennis Scott had 22 points for Rollins.

title: Phone Company Says Offer For Pact Was Last One
description: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that it hid no further proposals after the reported rejection of its last offer by officials of the Communications Workers of America, which represents the 35,000 telephone craftsmen who have been on strike for more than six months.

title: Perfect Attendance Mark
description: EDMONTON, Alberta (AP)Thorton Graham, 85 years old, is celebrating his 52d year with the Kiwanis Club and has the best Kiwanis attendance record in Canada. He has never missed a meeting. Mr. Graham joined the club as a founding charter member in 1919 with 14 other men. Only he and one other founder are still alive.

title: Amex and OTC Fall for Second Day
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market declined for the second consecutive session in active trading yesterday.

title: ' To Find a Man' Explores Today's Youth
description: Youth hasn't been wasted on the young in "To Find a Man," the new arrival at Columbia II, which intimately scrutinizes the today life-style of New York's affluent adolescents. Under Buzz Kulik's crisp direction, the largely unknown youngsters here are surprisingly cool and efficient in concentrating on the script's thin, but major, premise that abortion is still more of a problem than, say, unsightly pimples.It makes for a hip, sometimes funny and occasionally poignant view of kids under momentary stress. But in stressing the trials of its two principals it is a good deal less than pointed about the all important painful business of growing up.The facets of the sophisticated high schoolers' characters and their awareness of sex are touched on seriocomically but only fleetingly as bright but blameless Andy tries to help pretty, sexy but vacuous Rosalind, whom he adores in his own fashion, get that abortion.To the credit of the with-it dialogue and natural performances, their efforts are starkly realistic and comic. Include among individual scenes that stick in memory a frantic visit to an orthodontist; their explicit and funny attempt at a pregnancy test, and a succession of trips to a city abortion clinic run like a supermarket, a private agency run casually and to a sympathetic, if blunt, doctor.Handling the comparatively brief adult roles with authority are Lloyd Bridges and Phyllis Newman, as Rosalind's newly rich, tense parents; Tom Ewell, as the physician; Tom Bosley, as an understanding druggist, and Antonia Rey, as Andy's dour but compassionate housekeeper.But "To Find a Man" really belongs to its young newcomers, principally through the extremely sensitive portrayal of Andy by a 16-year-old New Rochelle student, Darren O'Connor, and the persuasive characterization of the selfish and superficial Rosalind by 17-year-old Pamela Martin of Westport.They make this youth scene, filmed here and in Dobbs Ferry, refreshingly authentic and occasionally touching, even if "To Find a Man" leaves a viewer wishing they had all been involved in a bigger scene.

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNED BY TEMPLE, 7966
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (UPI)  Ollie Johnson scored 17 points and Joe Newman added 14 and picked off 11 rebounds tonight as Temple defeated St. John's, 7965.

title: Lower Manhattan Master Plan Scored by Local Planning Board
description: Manhattan Community Planning Board 1, which covers lower Manhattan, criticized the city's master plan yesterday as a whole and as it applied to its area.

title: Asian Output A Challenge To Europe, Too
description: WESTERN EUROPE, too, is being burned by the Rising Sun. The industrial competition from Japan, and, to a lesser extent, other Asian countries, which has been producing anguished laments in the United States, is now beginning to give pain to European countries in their own markets.

title: Fund Redemptions Creep Up on Sales
description: The mutual fund industry's, net sales position narrowed further last month to $42.7million, according to Investment Company Institute data published yesterday.

title: Europe Improving Railroads
description: PARISSpeeding from Zurich to Paris the other day in the bar car of the Arbalete, a California professor enjoying his sabbatical on a Eurailpass confided to a fellow American, You know, when it comes to railroad travel, we are an underdeveloped country.

title: Personal Income Climbed $8.9Billion in December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)Personal income of all Americans jumped by $8.9billion in December, the first full month following the wageprice freeze, the Government said today.

title: Turkey: a Crop of Problems
description: ANKARALast year was good for sunflowers, tourists and wheat in Turkey, but it also brought a bumper crop of economic problems, especially for the country's opium farmers, who planted what is supposed to be their final crop at the end of the year.

title: 12 Die in Colombian Truck
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 20 (UPI)Twelve persons were killed and eight injured today when a passengercarrying truck plunged off a cilff near Bucaramanga.

title: Rangers Withhold Puck From All the Kings Men
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 I've never seen anything like it, said Emile Francis, erstwhile goalie, now coach and general manager of the New York Rangers.

title: Interior Department Calls Off the Sale Of Offshore Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Department of the Interior, unable to meet a deadline, called off today a sale of oil and gas leases on more than 300,000 acres in the Gulf of Mexico off eastern Louisiana.

title: Cougars Beaten, 124122, After Strong Rally
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 20Even though they hit on a torrid 58 per cent of their floor shots, the New York Nets were forced to break away from a tie in the final two mmutes tonight to post a 124122 American Basketball Association victory over the Carolina Cougars before a crowd of 4,289 at Island Garden.

title: Alcoa, Reynolds Decline
description: Higher labor costs, the sluggish condition of the general economy and such adverse factors in the aluminum industry as excess productive capacity, brought a decline in the 1971 earnings of the leader, the Aluminum Company of America, and the runnerup, the Reynolds Metals Company, from those of the previous year.

title: Duquesne Triumphs, 8479
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 20 1(AP)  Duquesne University broke open a tight game with (three straight layup baskets and recorded an 8479 victory over Notre Dame tonight. The victory was Duquesne's 11th in 12 outings.

title: Miss Overton Posts Upset
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP)Wendy Overton, a 19yearold from Chevy Chase, Md., upset seventhseeded Judy Dalton of Australia, 61, 62, in the first round of the $17,000 Long Beach women's open today.

title: Pacer Rally Pays Off
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 20 (AP) The Indiana Pacers, trailing at one stage by 16 points, rallied tonight to defeat the Memphis Pros, 109107.

title: Strike Halting Airlines Hits the Canadians Hard
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 20With 53 major airports virtually deserted and 14,000 airline employes laid off, the effects of the fourdayold strike by air traffic controllers spread today to hotels, travel agencies and taxicabs.

title: 10th Head of Johns Hopkins Elected
description: Dr. Steven Muller, a 44yearold political scientist, was elected yesterday the 10th president of Johns Hopkins University.

title: Staubach, Page CoCaptains
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP) Roger Staubach, the Dallas quarterback, and Alan Page, Minnesota defensive tackle, were named cocaptains today of the National Conference AllStars for Sunday's National Football League Pro Bowl.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill that will permit uniformed firemen to engage in political activities. Fire fighters will be permitted now to join political clubs, but are bound by the same restrictions that cover other municipal employes.

title: Inquiry on Swiss Account Holds Up Book on Hughes
description: The McGrawHill Book Company and Life magazine decided yesterday to defer publication of a purported autobig raphy of Howard R. iluglius, pending an investigation of a disputed Swiss hank account alleged to be that of the eccentric billionaire.

title: A Message in Traditional Mold
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The annual State of the Union Message is not normally more than an upbeat rendering of the state of the Presidentexcept in election years, when it also becomes an index of the President's sense of the mood of the voters. President Nixon has honored the tradition on both counts. Contending that there is a national interest that transcends all partisan considerations, Mr. Nixon was faithful also to the tradition that President campaigns best by showing himself to be too busy for politics. That is all part of the game, as it is understood and played by both parties, presumably because the voters like it that way.

title: 505,000 in State Were Without Jobs In December Tally
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20  A total of 505,000 residents of New York State were without jobs in December, the State Department of Labor reported today.

title: Mr. X Tells How He Evaded $844,775 in Cigarette Taxes
description: Taperecorded testimony on the cigarettesmuggling operations of one mancalled Mr. Xrevealed yesterday how he reportedly cheated the state and city of $844,775 in tax revenues.

title: Congress Seems Responsive to Nixon's Appeal to Enact His Legislative Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Despite outspoken criticism by Democratic Presidential candidates, President Nixon, with his State of the Union Message, appeared today to have struck a cooperative response in Congress to his plea for enactment of his basic legislative program.

title: Bridge:
description: In tournament play the right bid may depend upon the quality of the field.

title: New Stance on Expropriation
description: President Nixon's tougher stance on expropriation of American property abroad is probably designed as much to appease Congress as to warn foreign governments. It represents no major change of policy; but Mr. Nixon's clear threat to withhold new economic aid and to oppose loans by international agencies to countries that expropriate without compensation may head off fresh attempts by Congress to tighten existing laws in this area.

title: East Bloc Complaint: U.S. Curbs on Trade
description: I don't think you'll find someone in these days buying complete plants in the United States and paying for them in cash.

title: WESTCHESTER PLAN ON RENT REJECTED
description: The Internal Revenue Service yesterday rejected a proposal for a rent agreement that would have exempted 25,000 housing units in four Westchester County cities and one town from Federal guidelines under Phase Two.

title: Jersey to Add 6% to Settlements To Cut InsuranceTrial Backlog
description: Using heavy interest charges as their tool and court congestion as their excuse, New Jersey's courts are about to embark upon a controversial program aimed at goading insurance companies into quick outofcourt settlements of the thousands of accident suits filed there each year.

title: Austria. All Seems Well
description: VIENNA  It looks as if Austria's dream of the 100 million and one nights will come true, and that would mean $1.5billion in cash, for the nights mentioned are the number tourists are expected to spend in Austria this year.

title: Scheuer Says U.S Official Backed Conduct in Soviet
description: Representative James H. Scheuer met with a State Department official here yesterday and said the official assured him he had done nothing illegal, inappropriate or in bad taste in the Soviet Union, from which he was expelled last week for improper activities.

title: PRUDENTIAL CUTS KEMPER AUTO TIE
description: After less than six months in the auto insurance business, the Prudential Insurance Company decided yesterday to terminate a multimilliondollar contract with the Kemper Insurance Group and to expand on its own.

title: Nixon Aide Attacks the Fair Trade Bill
description: A White House aide warned here yesterday that legislation before Congress could gravely affect the global competitive position of the United States.

title: In Beirut: Exiles, Intrigue and Money
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThis cosmopolitan capital overlooking the Mediterranean is the center of Middle East action. It is the playground of Persian Gulf sheiks and a listening post for international diplomats, foreign correspondents and master spies. It is the money market of the Arab world and the headquarters of many international companies.

title: Paradoxical de Chirico Here for Show
description: Italian artist Giorgio de Chirico has often been given to paradox and contradiction in his work and his life.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to propose to the New York State Legislature that the State Constitution (Art. 4, Sec.1) be amended to limit the tenure of the Governor to no more than two consecutive terms.

title: L.I.R.R. Strike Is Put Off for 10 Days
description: The threatened strike against the Long Island Rail Road was postponed for 10 days yesterday at the request of Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson.

title: Gang's Invasion of House in Riverdale Spurs Plans for Security
description: Shocked by the invasion of a neighbor's home by three armed, masked robbers who sexually assaulted a woman and her daughter, a group of Riverdale homeowners has banded together to take increased security measures.

title: NIXON ASKS NONPARTISAN SUPPORT IN CONGRESS ON PENDING PROGRAM; PROPOSES HIGHER DEFENSE OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Nixon appealed to an electionyear Congress today to set aside partisanship in the interests of high statesmanship and the swift enactment of programs which deal with the urgent priorities for the nation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Gifford Pinchot Jr.'s recent letter concurring with The Times opposition to the Tocks Island Reservoir project conveniently exaggerates its negative aspects and obscures the vast benefits to the region's millions of people.

title: French Charm of 'Smic, Smac, Smoc'
description: Charm in a movie is like bubble bath in a warm tub. A little of it is nice but an overdose can wither the hide of a hippopotamus. Claude Lelouch, the French director ("A Man and a Woman," The Crook"), traffics in so much charm that one is tempted to call for some kind of Federal controls. Save us, commissioner, before we shrivel to death!I say this right off because although I've never been one of Mr. Lelouch's boosters, I like almost everything I know about him, including the fact that he was one of the backers who made Abel Gance's epic "Bonaparte and the Revolution" possible. He is a generous and, apparently, an adventurous man. All of which leads me to his newest comedy, "Smic, Smac, Smoc," which he dedicates to the Lumires, Louis and Auguste, and which he defines as the effort of objective reporters to describe "a charming fiction."It is that (I'm tempted to add, unfortunately)  about three comradely shipyard workers in the south of France, nicknamed Smic, Smac and Smoc, and their fairy-tale adventures when they attempt to give Smoc and his bride, a beautiful bakery worker, a proper wedding trip to St. Tropez in a stolen Mercedes. Actually about half of it (the first half) is delightful before it is overtaken by an acute attack of what a friend of mine used to call "the elfins."Yet the movie deserves our interest, and maybe ever our support. Mr. Lelouch, to whom the commercial cinema has been very good, has attempted to make a first-class film for something on the order of $30,000, shooting it in one week, in 16 millimeter, with synchronized sound and a small, excellent cast. His aim: to break the stranglehold of escalating production costs that not only limit the amount of production, but also effectively precensor the imaginations of filmmakers who feel they must appeal to the widest possible audience."Smic, Smac, Smoc" is itself no major breakthrough as entertainment. However, it represents such an interesting approach to moviemaking that I must admire it, as well as Mr. Lelouch and everyone connected with the venture. This incudes particularly Catherine Allegret, Simone Signoret's apple-cheeked daughter, who plays the bakery girl with the kind of sweetness one hasn't seen much of since silent-movie days, and Amidou, who plays her intensely passionate, Algerian bridegroom who, on their wedding night, seems to have a slight, comic, but momentary pang about a future life without the jolly putains who have sustained him until then.Francis Lai, the man who has composed the music for all of Mr. Lelouch's films, also appears in the movie as a blind minstrel who plays an accordion and simply won't quit."Smic, Smac, Smoc," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, is fairly runny with charm, but it is also a technically first-rate job of moviemaking.

title: SchoolBus Contract Revoked After Investigation of Carrier
description: The Board of Education revoked its contract yesterday pith a small bus company that Carries handicapped pupils, as rin outgrowth of a city investicration into allegedly fraudulent practices by some concerns ti at transport Medicaid patients.

title: An Endangered Species: Engineers
description: Like the brown pelican, the American engineer is in real trouble. His traditional breeding groundthe university campusis no longer a congenial place for him to grow. In maturity, there are fewer and fewer places where he can feed.

title: Three Brooklyn Murderers Sentenced for 70 Crimes
description: State Supreme Court Justice Michael Kern meted out long prison terms yesterday for murders committed in Brooklyn in 1970 by three 23yearold men.

title: A. RHETT DU PONT, 64, OF BROKERAGE FIRM
description: BEAUFORT, S. C., Jan. 20A. Rhett du Pont, a retired executive of Francis I. du Pont & Co., Inc., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Nixon Bids Congress Drop Medicare Coverage Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) President Nixon renewed today his recommendation that Cohgress eliminate the charge to the elderly for doctor fees and similar coverage under Medicare.

title: BOAT SHOW STARTS STAND TOMORROW
description: Like the sun moving in reverse direction, the 62d National Boat Show opens at 10 A.M. tomorrow on the heels of a recordbreaking performance set by the San Francisco Boat Show, the first one in the country this year.

title: Why Magazines Thrive in Europe
description: HAMBURG, Germany Among the many formulas for survival tried by the magazines of Europe, those in West Germany seem to be the surest; the competition from television is So limited that the advertisers have no place else to go.

title: C.B.S. Slipping From Long Daytime TV Lead
description: Daytime television is a woman's world of exquisitely prolonged suffering, greed, hate, abortions, betrayals and young and middleaged love. It is a world with a seemingly endless fascination for some 50 million viewers who together make up a market of more than $300million annually for which the three major networks battle tirelessly. For 17 years, the Columbia Broadcasting System has reigned supreme over that world without serious challenge. Until now.

title: Executive Changes
description: W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday the election of Robert M. Coquillette and Carl N. Graf as executive vice presidents. Both were vice presidents. Mr. Coyuillette will be responsible for corporate administration reporting to the president and Mr. Graf becomes deputy group executive of the company's chemical group. Both men are directors.

title: Luxembourg: Open Arms
description: LUXEMBOURGThis tiny country, which is not quite the size of Rhode Island, has given a warm welcome to the giants of American industry whom it invited here to lessen Luxembourg's dependence upon its famed steel mills.

title: Civil Strife, the Despair of Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandThe poisonous mood of Northern Ireland envelops the daytoday lives of Roman Catholics and Protestants, leaving the economy reeling from one bomb blast to another.

title: As Israel Grows, Her Economy Ails
description: JERUSALEMIn 1971 the guns along Israel's frontiers were silentbut economic pressures were there to take the Place of the military pressureat the top of the nation's worry list.

title: CONNALLY PLACES DEFICIT IN BUDGET AT $40BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally acknowledged to a large audience of businessmen today that the budget deficit in the current fiscal year would be close to $40billion, but he told them that you ought to, be applauding it.

title: Theater: Black Pageant
description: The New Lafayette Theater on Seventh Avenue at 137th Street is one of New York's most admirable cultural enterprises. It is a true community theater, in touch with its audience, and nurturing actors, playwrights and technicians in surroundings that are flexible and stimulating to the theatrical imagination. The stage is surrounded by seats and bleachers, placed at angles and at various heights so that productions assume different shapes, depending on where you sit.

title: Rome: Pants Everywhere
description: ROMEThis is the year Italian women have taken pants to town. They've always worn them in their mountain and seaside resorts and on their yachts, but the hemline controversy just got too much for them. Now they wear pants all the timewith sweaters, blazers, tailored shirts and frilly blouses Lots of women can't remember the last time they wore a skirt  except maybe for evening.

title: Bias Against Jews Charged on Election To Poverty Boards
description: Three city officials were charged yesterday by three City Councilmen with condoning antiSemitism by permitting carefully planned exclusion of Jews from membership on local antipoverty boards.

title: INQUIRY IS BEGUN ON CITY SERVICES
description: The city commission investigating statecity relationships got a head start on its state counterpart yeserday by holding a hearing on government reorganization.

title: OTB Nearly Pays Off On Postrace Wagers
description: An apparent malfunction in the computer locking devices yesterday allowed hundreds of Offtrack Betting Corporation customers at 34 OTB shops to wager on Bowie races that had already been run.

title: Belgian Tax Rise Ahead
description: BRUSSELS  The Belgians faced 1972 with the prospect of sharply increased prices and taxes.

title: U.S. STEEL SEES MORE 1912 RISES
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation made it clear yesterday that prices for a variety of steel products will rise again during 1972, some possibly as soon as Feb.1.

title: Democrats to Answer Nixon on TV Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)Congressional Democrats plan to answer President Nixon's State of the Union Address with a live televised phonein program tomorrow. Five House members and four Senators will serve on the panel. Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri will be anchorman.

title: Volcanoes on the Moon?
description: A lively debate between two distinguished scientists marked the recent Third Lunar Science Conference in Houston. The subject: lunar volcanoes, past and present, Prof. Gary Latham of Columbia argued that volcanism on the moon may be continuing even now. Prof. Thomas Gold of Cornell poohpoohed the whole idea. When experts of such stature disagree, laymen are well advised to remain neutral, though some photos of the moon taken from orbit during the Apollo 15 mission are strongly suggestive of volcanic sites known on earth.

title: Italy Is Plagued By Recession
description: ROMEThe Italian economy is going through a bitterly cold winter, variously described as a deep recession, a structural crisis, or a climate of widespread pessimism.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20President Nixon's State of the Union address is a reminder that most men can easily agree when they concentrate on the objectives and goals of life. Republican and Democrat, Socialist and Communist, Christian, Jew, Moslem and Hindu, all unite in their yearnings for peace, security, equality, and mutual respect in a unified society.

title: WAGNER EXCERPT IS LED BY JOHANOS
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra's concert in Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was to have been conducted by its music director, William Steinberg. The scheduled program included Elgar's Falstaff and the first act of Wagner's Die Walitilre, with Marilyn Horne as Sieglinde, William Cochran as Siegmund and Ara Berberian as Hunding. Mr. Steinberg became ill last week, and his place was taken by Donald Johanos, associate conductor of the orchestra. He kept the Wagner excerpt but replaced the Eiger with Berlioz's Le Corsaire Overture and Witold Lutoslawski's Livre pour Orchestre, which was new here.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas  Marco Gerardo, 157 pounds, San Diego, knocked out Chu Chu Cebroes, 154, Mexico, 3 rounds.

title: Point of View
description: BRUSSELSThe international monetary crisis which was partly settled in Washington last month has seriously affected the European Economic Community. Various speculative conclusions can be drawn from the events leading to the crisis concerning the future of European monetary integration. These, in turn, lead to the principal question: Will movement in this decade toward European monetary union stagnate or progress?

title: Screen:
description: He has a terrible toothache. Dizziness is his medium. He Is perhaps 7 years old, drunk, and adrift on the Bowery. He is played by a remarkable young actor named Jonathan Leeds. And he is the subject, probably the object, and maybe even the hero of For Example, a new film by the conceptual artist Arakawa, with narration by his wife, the writer Madeline Gins. For Example opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum.

title: Books of The Times
description: Richard M. Freeland was born in 1941 and presumably, came of intellectual age in the late 1950's, give or take an adolescence. He received a solid education at Amherst College, the University of Bristol and the University of Pennsylvania (where he wrote the dissertation from which the present book was expanded). He has worked in Washington for two Congressmen. He has been to Vietnam on a United States Information Agency interneship. He has taught history in several institutions. And he is evidently an excellent scholar and researcher. With all these advantages, he has been able to give us an aerial photograph of the past that reveals many perspectives not available to people who experienced World War la and its aftermath on the ground, as it were. So one studies The Truman Doctrine and the Origins of McCarthyism with curiosity and some excitement to understand the history from which we are now trying to awake.

title: SON HELD IN SLAYING OF QUEENS WOMAN
description: Detectives in Queens arrested a 27yearold man with a history of mental illness yesterday in connection with the murder of his mother, who was found decapitated in her Flushing apartment earlier in the day.

title: Sabres Top Canucks, 10
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 20 (UPI)Don Luce scored a firstperiod goal and Roger Crozier gained his second shutout of the season tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Vancouver Canucks, 10.

title: PRECINCT RESCINDS ITS TICKET QUOTAS
description: Declaring that policemen had overresponded, the commander of the 24th Precinct on the Upper West Side yesterday rescinded his controversial order setting minimum quotas for the issuance of summonses.

title: Rites for Rabin Sunday
description: A funeral service for Michael Rabin, the violinist, who died on Wednesday evening at the age of 35, will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amstardam Avenue at 76th Street, on Sunday at noon. Rabin did not die as a result of an epileptic seizure, as was reported by the police. He had no history of epilepsy. Death was attributed to a skull fracture suffered in a fall in his home.

title: Blair, Newest 17Foot Vaulter, Is Set to Test Spectrum Roof
description: Tom Blair, track and field's newest 17foot pole vaulter, says he is having trouble thinking I can keep this up.

title: Endorsed by Williams
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) Senator Muskie picked up his 12th endorsement from fellow members of the Senate today when he won the backing of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Seeing the name of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin is, indeed, like hearing a voice from the past. But your biographical note at the bottom of his Jan. 12 OpEd article, Thirty Years to Build an Ark, does your younger readers a grave disservice.

title: Point of View
description: LONDON  Nineteenseventyone was a year of farreaching change, for Britain no less than for others. We have seen the dramatic set of economic measures announced byPresident Nixon on Aug. 15; the emergence of the People's Republic of China as a member of the United Nations, and agreements in principle over such longstanding problems as West Berlin and Rhodesia.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The man who signed the midget is about to be stuffed, mounted and festooned with a gobbet of hardware for long and meritorious service to baseball. After 26 years, many good deeds and an occasional venial sin as a baseball man, Robert Oscar Fishel, vice president and public relations director of the Yankees, has been tapped by the New York baseball writers for the Bill Slocum Award and will receive same at their annual hogkilling a week from Sunday in the Americana. If the writers had drawn a seine from Peiham Bay Park to Yorkville, they couldn't have caught a happier choice. Nor could they have found a talent scout with a higher batting average. Since he got into the game in 1946, Bob Fishel has signed two individuals to baseball contractsEddie Gaedel, the greatest midget ever to play in the major leagues, and Harry Brecheen, a crafty and gifted pitcher who became a brilliant coach of pitchers. Thus the Fishel batting average stands at 1.000.

title: Notes on People
description: Otto Klemperer, the 87yearold Germanborn conductor, will retire from the concert platform. There will be no fuss and no farewell concert, said a spokesman for the New Philharmonia Orchestra of London. This is as Dr. Klemperer wanted it.

title: TRANSITPACT TALK RESUMED IN BERLIN
description: BERLIN, Jan. 20The governments of East and West Germany resumed negotiations today on a general transport agreement aimed at easing the movement of passengers and goods across the boundary that cuts Germany in two.

title: Apprehension Felt By Scandinavians
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark Balanceofpayments problems, a low level of capital investment, rising unemployment, falling profits, inflation these are some of the problems that have been afflicting Sweden, Denmark, Norway and Finland.

title: War Protest at Capitol Barred During Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)  The police blocked relatives of prisoners of war, the mother of a G.I. killed in Vietnam and several hundred supporters from conducting an endthewar vigil on the Capitol steps during President Nixon's State of the Union Address.

title: Swiss Sled Takes Title
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 20 (Reuters)The Swiss No. 3 team, piloted by Hanruedi Mueller, won the European fourman bobsled championship today with a total time of 4 minutes 58.80 seconds. The West German No. crew, the overnight leader, was second with a total for the four runs of 4.59.51.

title: Soviet Relief Reaches Dacca
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 20 (AP)The first Soviet plane carrying relief supplies for Bangladesh arrived here today, and sources said more relief planes are expected within the next few days.

title: NEIKRUG, CELLIST, PLAYS SON'S WORK
description: The name in big type on the program for the recital at Tully Hall on Wednesday night was that of George Neikrug, the cellist, but the honors of the evening belonged to his son, Marc Neikrug, who had composed the striking new Sonata for Cello and Piano that was given its premiere. He also served as pianist for his father in the recital.

title: Philharmonic Encounter Is Shifted to New School
description: Tonight's Prospective Encounter by the New York Philharmonic has been transferred from Martinson Hall in the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater to the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. The change was made necessary when New York City's Department of Buildings imposed restrictions on the occupancy of Martinson Hall.

title: William Wyckoff Stoothoff, 76, Farmer and Polo Player, Dead
description: MUTTONTOWN, L. I., Jan. 20  William Wyckoff Stoothoff, one of the last of western Long Island's potato farmers whose forebears were among the early Dutch settlers of Manhattan, died yesterday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

title: SCHOOL DECISION HAILED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 20  The New Jersey court order striking down the state's system of financing public school education as unconstitutional was described today as the most important legal victory thus far in the nation in the campaign to achieve education equality for the urban poor.

title: New York City:
description: Ask the commuter who just paid 70 cents to drive through the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel; ask the subway rider who just paid 35 cents for the privilege of riding upon our mass transit system that he hopes will get him to work on time; ask the victim of a mugging from one of our 100,000 drug addicts; ask the students who just learned that their teacher is not going to be there after February due to new budget cuts; ask the taxpayer, laborer, consumer, housewife or shopkeeper if he is tired of New York.

title: New York City:
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Walter V. Carty and The New York Times for publishing an article [OpEd, Jan. 7] about the positive aspects of life in New York City. It's a fantastic place and I'm tired of reading only negative things about my favorite city. Mr. Carty knows what I've only learned since moving to New Jersey: You can take the girl out of the city but you can't take the city out of the girl.

title: Bridge: Required HighCard Points Key Clue to Beginner's Bid
description: A beginner learns that a partnership needs 26 highcard points to justify a game hid. Most tournament players interpret this requirement optimistically: They want to make sure that they reach game with 26, and if in the process they reach a 25point game, they are not unduly concerned.

title: Faulk and Neely Advance
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 21 (AP)Steve Faulk of Madisonville, La., and Armistead Neely of Tampa, Fla., advanced today to the semifinals of the New Zealand tennis championship. They were joined by Onny Parun and Jeff Simpson, New Zealand Davis Cup players.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Connally to the Chamber of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Following are excerpts from a speech delivered yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally before the United States Chamber of Commerce, the transcript of which was released today:

title: Miss Melville Posts Upset
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI)Kerry Melville of Australia upset Virginia Wade of England, the No. 3 seeded player tonight in the $17,000 Long Beach women's pro tennis tournament, 6.2, 75, and reached the semifinals.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Jan. 21 (AP)The Government has announced plans to recognize Bangladesh. Barbados has no diplomatic relations with Pakistan.

title: COUNTY STUDYING NEWARK SHOOTING
description: NEWARK, Jan. 21  Essex County Prosecutor Joseph P. Lordi said today that his office had joined the investigation into the Jan. 14 shooting of Ron Porambo, a television newsman and author of a book about the 1967 race riots here.

title: U. S. Crackdown on Amphetamines Driving Up Prices
description: JUAREZ, Mexico, Jan. 21 A United States Government crackdown on black  market amphetamine operations along the Mexico border is driving up prices here and threatening to increase them elsewhere in the country. But while the move has reduced the illegal inflow, the pills are still readily available for those who really want them.

title: Miss Goolagong Triumphs
description: ADELAIDE, Australia (AP)Evonne Goolagong defeated Janet Young, 67, 75, 61, today after being within two points of defeat three times in the South Australian tennis championships. Miss Goolagong reached the final in which she will meet Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union.

title: Political Strategy Helps Shape Administration's Pesticide Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Howard A, Cohen, who handles Congressional affairs for the Environmental Protection Agency, has put together political strategy for the administration on some controversial environmental bills.

title: State Insurance Aide Quits
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21 (UPI)Jacob B. Underhill, a former newspaperman and onetime assistant press secretary to Governor Rockefeller, has resigned as the first deputy state insurance superintendent to enter private business, it was announced today. In a letter to Superintendent Benjamin R. Schenck, Mr. Underhill said he had planned to leave a year ago, but agreed to stay in the $37,416ayear post to aid in the transition as Mr. Schenck took over from the former Superintendent, Richard Stewart.

title: British Aide's Comment
description: LONDON, Jan. 21Lord Carrington said on his return to London, Before I went I think I said there was a 5050 chance of agreement but after these talks I would put it at rather less.

title: Welfare Maze Traps a Proud Mother
description: Mary Ann Pistorio had the first of her five children when she was not quite 16 and the last just five and a half years later. Immediately then she went looking for work and found a job as a store maid, vacuuming and dusting in a fancy chinaware shop.

title: JAMES P. MURRAY, LONG WITH BOEING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21James P. Murray, a former vice president of Boeing Aircraft who spent more than half a century in the field of aviation, died at his home here last night. He was 79 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: To raise money for subway maintenance and improvements without again raising the fare, I suggest that subway riders in effect become bond buyers and lotteryticket buyers each time they buy subway tokens.

title: Senate Gets Bill to Repeal Campaign Tax Checkoff
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) A bill was introduced in the Senate today to repeal the tax checkoff plan approved by Congress last year to finance Presidential election campaigns.

title: U.S. Indicts 71 Here in Theft Of $8Million in Luxury Autos
description: Seventyone persons were indicted yesterday in a stealacartoorder business that allegedly operated out of an Army and Navy store in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn and sold more than 4,500 luxury autos in the last three years.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21A flattire safety roller was demonstrated for Government and other observers at an airport in Beltsville, Md., this week. At a speed of 70 miles an hour, the driver blew the two lefthand tires of his Cadillac and kept on going without injury. Also this week, the driver, Theodore C. Patecell, an airline pilot, was granted Patent 3,635,273 for the roller. The spectators included three men from the Secret Service and two from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: TakeOver Is Foiled
description: ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., said here yesterday that it had turned back an attempt by an insurgent stockholder group to acquire control of the pleasureboat manufacturing concern.

title: Shop Talk
description: A gallery shop that will serve both as an exhibition hall and retail outlet for many of the major craftsmen in this country opened yesterday at 44 West 53d Street. The shop (formerly occupied by America House) represents the first time the American Crafts Council, a national organization of artists and craftsmen, has provided a retail outlet for its membersas well as offering the growing number of crafts collectors a central place to see and buy objects displayed much as they might be in an informal museum. Among the works of the 43 craftsmen who are represented in this first exhibition and show (it will be changed around the middle of March), there are ceramics and glass (sculpture as well as pots and vases); gold and silver jewelry; woodworking  in small pieces such as bowls as well as in furniture; woven and nonwoven hangings, and several pieces of soft sculpture: figures made of stuffed and painted cloth or of tubular weaving.

title: STUDY ON NEW TAX COULD TAKE A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations plans to take six months to a year to reach its conclusions on the valueadded tax, which President Nixon has asked it to study as a possible alternative to local property taxes for financing public schools.

title: Some Bengali Warriors Seem Reluctant to Heed the Call to Peace
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan 21Now that the shooting part of the struggle has been won, the vast majority of the young Bengali guerrillas who fought for independence against the Pakistani Army are laying down their arms and turning to the jobs of reconstruction. But some seem reluctant to give up their power as military leaders and are resisting the return to the routine and relative anonymity of civilian life.

title: PACT IS DEFERRED BY MCINTYRE MINES
description: TORONTO, Jan. 21McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., whose Alberta coalmining operation has been losing money because of acute production delays said today it has agreed to defer indefinitely the effectiveness of a $1billion sales agreement wtih Japanese steel producers.

title: JUDGE VOIDS TERM OF BLACK MILITANT
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 21 (UPI)Lee Otis Johnson, a black militant sentenced to 30 years for giving an undercover policeman a marijuana cigarette, did not receive a fair trial because of racial tension in Houston, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Fulcher Gets Post
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 21 (AP)Bill Fulcher, a former pro linebacker who just completed his first year as head football coach at the University of Tampa, was named today head coach of Georgia Tech.

title: Gunts Wonder When Their Fighting Became Defensive
description: South Vietnam, Jan. 18  In the field  which means elephant grass, bamboo so thick and so tough a man must hack his way through it and heat that makes it punishing to walk a few hundred yards with an 80pound packthe infantrymen wait for a helicopter that links them to the outside world every three days.

title: Coded Entry in Diary Of Roosevelt Is Read
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Three persons in the Boston area, working independently, have decided that Franklin Delano Roosevelt wrote in code in his diary in Groton, Conn., on Nov. 22, 1903:

title: Mrs. Green Shuns Senate
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 21Representative Edith Green said today that she would not run for the Senate seat held by Mark 0. Hatfield, a Republican.

title: Policy of Attrition Reported Periling 14 Bellevue Wards
description: The director of Bellevue Hospital says he will be forced to close 14 wards containing 20 per cent of the 1,800 beds there in order to comply with an employe attrition policy the city hospital system describes as minor belttightening.

title: 73 DRAFT LOTTERY TO BE HELD FEB. 2
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) The draft lottery for the two million young men reaching age 19 this year will be held Feb. 2, earlier than any of the three previous drawings, the Selective Service System announced today.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Shows Lower Net
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Climical Corporation showed a sharp drop in earnings for 1971 and in the final quarter last year reflecting severely eroded aluminum prices, higher costs and reduced income from nonaluminum activities, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.

title: Suns Beat Supersonics
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 21 (AP)Paul Silas's 24 points and 26 rebounds paced the Phoenix Suns to a 128113 victory over the Seattle Supersonics tonight.

title: Laotians Suffer a Setback Near Base at Long Tieng
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21Counterattacking enemy forces overran some Government positions on a ridge overlooking the Americanbacked base of Long Tieng, and handtohand fighting was reported today for control of the installation.

title: Antiques: A Foretaste Cooper  Hewitt Museum's Display at Show Is Glimpse of Its Collection
description: The loan exhibition from the CooperHewitt Museum at the Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory serves as a good introduction to what the museum will contain when it reopens sometime in 1973. The museum, closed while its new home at the Carnegie Mansion, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, is being refurbished, was once known as the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration.

title: OTB Takes Place Bets For Bowie on Monday
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation, in a move to beef up its handle, will begin taking place bets Monday on Bowie races. OTB will conduct its own place pool, as it has been doing for win betting, exacta wagering and the daily double, which comprises the eighth and ninth races.

title: Reynolds Metals Lifts Cost For AluminumCan Stock
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it had increased the price of aluminumcan stock by an average of 4.2 per cent, effective Jan. 5. The action is permitted under the general increase in ceiling prices granted the company by the Price Commission, a spokesman said, adding that other increases would be announced later.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recent prison uprisings, unfortunate as they may seem, have in a very dramatic way provided the impetus for a massive grassroots look at our criminaljustice system and specifically the failure of our correctional agencies to correct. It is difficult to find fault with those who say that prisons are schools for crime or that correctional institutions should in fact be charged solely with rehabilitating and not penalizing.

title: Madrid Campus Quiet
description: MADRID, Jan. 21 (AP)Students at Madrid University stayed away by the thousands today and the campus was quiet for the first time this week. Police security remained heavy in Madrid as Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the Chief of State, met with his Cabinet, presumably to discuss disorders that began on Monday.

title: New York City:
description: To the Editor: I have lived in both London and New York and some of the world's other major cities, and find New York one of the few places that makes me not so much tired of life as pessimistic about it. The tiredness comes later you stick around long enough.

title: HUGHES BUYS LAND BY LAS VEGAS STRIP
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 21 (AP)Howard R. Hughes, who recently sold some of his extensive Las Vegas holdings, has purchased more land near the Las Vegas Strip.

title: A Patrolman Is Slain in Jersey While Guarding Mental Patient
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, 14. J., Jan. 21A 27yearold patrolman was shot to death near here today in an ambulance in which he was accompanying a man from Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield to the Marlboro State Hospital, a facility for the mentally disturbed in Monmouth County. The, suspect's mother was in the front seat of the ambulance at the time.

title: Coaching Shakeup on Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP)Dave Maggard, the track coach at the University of California, became the school's athletic director today and immediately named Mike White, lured away from rival Stanford, as the Bears head football coach.

title: Six Arrested in Brooklyn Drug Raids
description: A correction officer, a policeman and four other persons were under arrest yesterday on narcotics charges following police raids on the Brooklyn Community Release Center in the Granada Hotel, 268 Ashland Place, and on an apartment at 557 Putnam Avenue, in the BedfordStuyvesant area.

title: Bonn Asks BetterRun Market
description: BONN, Jan. 21  On the eve of a signing ceremony in Brussels expanding the European Common Market to 10 members, from 6, the West Germany Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, said today that steps should be taken to strengthen the operating processes.

title: Bishop Among 55 Killed In Colombia Air Crashes
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 21 (AP)Two Colombian airline crashes killed 55 persons today.

title: Commitment Without Clout
description: President Nixon paid scant attention to the war in Vietnam in his State of the Union messages, perhaps because he genuinely believes he can make that interminable conflict a nonissue in the Presidential campaign. That is most unlikely if the President clings to the policy he briefly reiterated in his written message.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT ROCKETS, 110106
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) John Havlicek and Jo Jo White scored 28 points each tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 110105 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets.

title: Prison Head Shifted
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21 (UPI) J. Leland Casscles, superintendent of the prison at Ossining once known as Sing Sing, today was named superintendent of the Great Meadow Correctional Facility at Comstock. He succeeds Joseph Conboy, who is retiring after 48 years of service in the Corrections Department.

title: Swiss Link Woman To Hughes Funds
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 21 The H. R. Hughes who opened an account in the Swiss Credit Bank here was not the idiosyncratic billionaire but Germanspeaking blonde in her early thirties who used a forged Swiss passport as identification, Swiss banking sources said today.

title: Japan in Agreement On Bond Financing
description: TOKYO, Jan. 21Japan has agreed in principle to yendenominated bond financing by the Australian Government in the Tokyo capital market, Japanese and Australian Government sources have disclosed.

title: Connally Opposes a Bill to Curb Imports
description: Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally expressed strong opposition yesterday to legislation before Congress that would hamper imports into the United States and restrict the freedom of American companies operating overseas.

title: Why I Married an American
description: How did you people meet each other? What decided you to marry a foreigner? I can't remember how many times I ran into these questions when I was an actress with the Shanghai People's Art Theater. Now, just arrived in America, the questions arise again.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Wide circulation is being given to the idea that the State Legislature obliged by the Federal court decision to give equal representation to each borough on the Board of Elections in New York City. This is the position taken by the party organizations to give credence to their frantic attempts at retaining and strengthening their control over the election process.

title: Mrs. Booth and Mrs. Syms Gain Doherty Golf Semifinals
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 21 (UPI)Mrs. Jane Bastanchury Booth advanced to the semifinals of the Doherty challenge cup golf today by defeating Barbara McIntire. But she had to play three extra holes at the Coral Ridge Country Club before she triumphed.

title: Lindsay, in Florida, Challenges Wallace to a Television Debate
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 21  Mayor Lindsay opened a driving attack on Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama today, calling him a symbol of repression, division, segregation and challenging him to a statewide television debate before the Florida Presidential primary March 14.

title: Oregon to Get Disaster Aid
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Ian. 21 (Reuters)President Nixon declared the state of Oregon a major disaster area today, permitting the use of Government funds for relief and recovery from storms and flooding in the state's northwestern area earlier this month.

title: Deaths
description: BIRNBAUMFrieda, beloved wife of Abraham. Devoted mother of Norman and George. Loving grandmother and dear sister. Services Sunday, 11:30 A.M., Hirsch's Chapel, 16/th St. and Jerome Ave., Bronx.

title: Pistons Stop Bullets, 107102
description: DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP)Jimmy Walker, rebounding from his poorest professional game in five seasons last Saturday, paced the Detroit Pistons to a 107102 victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight.

title: Invasion by Aggressive Honeybees Is Feared
description: A vast army of fierce African honeybees, the descendants of 26 accidentally released in Brazil 15 years ago, has spread through much of South America and threatens eventually to invade North America, a committee of experts commissioned by the National Academy of Sciences has found.

title: SKIING RACE WON BY MISS PROM
description: ST. GERVAISE, France, Jan 21 (AP)  Annemarie Proell of Austria won the first leg of a giant slalom today and moved into a position where she could take over the lead in the women's overall World Cup ski standing just before the Winter Olympic Games.

title: Airco Says Trust Suit By U.S. Has No Merit
description: Airco, Inc., said yesterday that although it had not seen a copy of a complaint filed by the Department of Justice charging the company with using illegal purchasing arrangements in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act, the company had cooperated fully in supplying all requested material pertinent to the investigation.

title: Harris Says That CocaCola Overcharges by 3 Cents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) Senator Fred R. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma, accused the CocaCola Company today of overcharging the public 3 cents a bottle on every dime Coke.

title: Isabelle Friedman Is Dead; Consumer Coop Advocate
description: Mrs. Isabelle Berg Friedman, who had been active in the consumers cooperative movement for many years, died yesterday of cancer in the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Hospital in the Bronx. She was 75 years old and lived at 85 Dorchester Road, Manhasset, L. I. She was the wife of Jacob G. Friedman, a tea broker.

title: Snowmobiles Hit the Alps and Opposition
description: PARIS, Jan. 21  France, Austria, Switzerland and other Alpine countries are reacting strongly to the latest menace to life, limb and tranquillitythe snowmobile, which has crossed the Atlantic to invade ski trails in Europe.

title: Croatia's New Leaders Take Softer Line After Crisis There
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 21 Croatia's new Communist party leaders spoke publicly today of the need for moderation in the aftermath of a crisis over nationalism that prompted intervention last month by President Tito.

title: Greeks Don't Want Elections, Deputy Premier Says
description: ATHENS, Jan. 21  Deputy Premier Stylianos Patakos said tonight that after nearly five years of rule by the militarybacked Government of Premier George Papadopoulos, the Greek people were still tired of elections and wanted a rest.to do for Greece in the next five years.

title: Tremblor Hits Los Angeles
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 21 (Reuters)The large earthquake that struck the northern Los Angeles area last Feb. 9 is still sending out aftershocks nearly a year later, the seismological laboratory of the California Institute of Technology said today. A trembler measuring 3.2 on the Richter scale that hit the area this morning was further aftershock, according to the laboratory. The big quake measured 6.8 on the scale.

title: SIDNEY POLANER
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 21 Sidney Polaner, chairman of the board of M. Polaner & Sons of Roseland, manufacturer of food products, died yesterday in St. Bamabas Hospital in Livingston. He was 75 years old and lived at 661 Longview Road.

title: Oil Countries Press Equity Demands
description: GENEVA, Jan. 21The oilproducing countries started their talks today with a dozens, Western oil companies on the new request by the nations for participation in company subsidiaries extracting oil from their territories.

title: U.S. B52 Strikes Continue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 (AP)An intensified bombing campaign by United States B52's continued for the fifth day today with attacks on suspected troop concentrations and supply dumps in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam near the Laotian border.

title: 60,000Gallon Oil Spill Fouls 16 Miles of the Hudson
description: More than 16 miles of the Hudson River south of Albany were covered from shore to shore with 60,000 gallons light fuel oil yesterday.

title: Law Enforcement, Not Quotas
description: The controversial parkingticket blitz by patrolmen on Manhattan's Upper West Side has subsided in the wake of Police Commissioner Murphy's observation that quotas do not solve problems. But, misguided as was the order that each patrolman tag at least fifty or a hundred illegally parked cars a month, the issuance of the ukase did highlight the inexcusable fact that slipshod law enforcement had been the rule not only in going after parking violators but in all phases of police work in that area.

title: Study Finds U.S. Aided By Its Companies Abroad
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21  For some time now, organized labor and big industry have been at loggerheads over whether the growing use of foreign factories by American companies throws American workers out of jobs and aggravates the balanceofpayments problem. The big unknown is what would have happened to the domestic economy had the manufacturers never ventured abroad.

title: Flu Is Widespread In 8 States, Here And in Capital Area
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 21 (AP)Hong Kong flu is beginning to take a toll in the current epidemic, according to the national Communicable Disease Center, which has reported that the disease is widespread in eight states, New York City and the District of Columbia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Jan. 11 on Howard Hughes might have been appropriate in the nineteenthirties but is not of any value in 1972. The only time the public has the right to demand to know about a corporation or a business is when there is some doubt about the legality of that business, and the Government has more than sufficient means to check upon the legal aspects of trusts, interlocking directorates and so on. There is no excuse for the public to demand the right to know about the private life of any individual just because he is wealthy or because he has power.

title: Show of Sculpture in the Heroic Style
description: Affirmations of heroic feeling are not much in evidence nowadays in the new styles of sculpture. Contemporary sculptors lack the requisite rhetoricone might even say, the requisite belief in rhetoric for sustaining heroic emotions, especially where the representation of the human form is a crucial factor. Indeed, the concept of the heroic, insofar as it may be said to persist at all, has passed in recent years from representational sculpture to various modes of abstraction. Most attempts to revive the heroic figure in sculpture have not succeeded.

title: MURPHY UPGRADES 8 IN DEPARTMENT
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy promoted Inspector Anthony V. Bouza to deputy chief inspector yesterday, transferring him from a division command to the Inspections Division and empowering him to investigate the efficiency of any police unit in the city.

title: RAND WILL CLOSE ITS ELMIRA PLANT
description: ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 21They reached the end of the line at Remington Rand's sprawling old typewriter factory here after nearly 37 years of operation when an executive of the parent SperryRand Corporation announced today that all production operations would be phased out by April 1.

title: New York City:
description: To the Editor: I cannot believe Suzanne Haire and I have the same city in mind. I lived in London for eight months and found it to be a beautiful, fascinating, kind and courteous place to reside and raise daughters. One evening my daughter and I attended the opera and took the tube home at 11 P.M. You simply would not do this in New York. We walked through Hyde Park at midnight! Lois CHASE BRODY.

title: Art
description: Among shows worth visiting this week there are a couple at the Metropolitan Museum and another couple a the Whitney. Give me one to keep for my own and I'll take the Metropolitan's collection of 95 drawings acquired during 1969. 70 and 71. Although we keep hearing that the market in old master drawings has dried up for lack of supplies, the Metropolitan manages to keep finding some. True, there are no sensational headliners here (Annibale Caracci's Triton Sounding a Conch Shell might qualify), but the show is full of minor drawings by great draftsmen, such as Salvator Rosa, and brilliant examples from lesser masters such as Giovanni Angelo Canini and Baldassare Franceschini, to mention two who are alluringly represented. There is also a wide range in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: News Analysis
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 20  A week after the military coup d'tat that dissolved one of Africa's few genuine democracies, the army seems to be in complete control of Ghanaboth in the hot, congested capital, where the soldiers are out of sight again, and in the rolling cocoa lands north of here, where the peace was scarcely disturbed at all.

title: Gaines Play Opens at Henry Street
description: Under the name Sunny Jim, J. E. Gaines has acted to great advantage in many plays by Ed Bullins. Gaines is also a playwright, and a work of his called Don't Let It Go to Your Head opened Thursday at the Henry Street Playhouse. Although the play is seriously flawed, it is full of the juices of life. In both of his professions, Gaines is a man of exceptional ability.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Some people are afraid of quiet people. They don't realize that some people are being quiet because they don't know and are listening to learn.

title: Nixon Promotes Admiral
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) President Nixon today assigned Rear Adm. Douglas C. Plate to become commander of the Second (Atlantic.) Fleet, headquartered in Norfolk, Va.

title: Valentino: Styles That Change the Look of Fashion
description: ROME, Jan. 21Take a good long look at all those snugfitting, tightarmhole clothes around. Pretty soon they're going to be obsolete. Loose tops with raglan shoulders and armholes as deep as the waistline are the coming thing. Valentino says so.

title: ExRep. Barry Files on Coast
description: WOODSIDE, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP)Robert R. Barry, 56 years old, a former New York Representative, has announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination to the newly created 17th Congressional District seat. Mr. Barry served three terms until 1964 from Westchester County.

title: Armed Robbery at Hospital
description: An armed robber stole more than $1,000 in petty cash from a security guard at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday. The police said that as the guard, Thomas Rucker, 50 years old, was getting out of his car in the alleyway of a hospital parking lot after returning from a nearby bank, the gunman ordered him to hand over a bag with $1,111.26 and then fled with the money.

title: Heath Gets $93,600 Award
description: STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 21 (AP)  A new Europe is being born, Prime Minister Heath said here today. The expanded Common Market would, he said, make Europe strong in the councils of the world.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 21  After years of repression and stillness, the Africans of Rhodesia have found their voice. Anyone who believes in the integrity of the individual human spirit will be moved by their courage in facing the guns of Ian Smith's policemen and army, in demonstrating, in shouting no to the proposed settlement between Britain and her rebel territory.

title: L.I. Student Killed in Fall
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Jan. 21 (UPI)The Nassau County police said an 18yearold student at C. W. Post College in Brookville, L.I., fell to his death early today from a thirdfloor balcony of the Queens Hail, the dormitory where he lived. The victim, John A. Vitollo of 167 Woodland Drive, East Islip, L. I., was found lying outside the dormitory and was taken to Glen Cove Community Hospital, where he died.

title: Life of Leonardo da Vinci Scheduled on C. B. S.TV
description: The Life of Leonardo da Vinci, a fivepart dramatic series produced in Italy, will be televised this season, probably in midsummer, on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: Submarine Fires Missile
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP)  The nuclear submarine Stonewall Jackson launched a Poseidon missile from beneath the surface of the Atlantic today, hurling the weapon's multiple  warheads package toward a target area more than 2,000 miles away. The Jackson is the 10th submarine to test fire the Poseidon.

title: ADRIAN SELIGMAN STATE COURTS AIDE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21  Adrian Seligman, a lawyer, who retired five years ago as first deputy state reporter of the Law Reporting Bureau of the Court of Appeals, died Monday in Miami Beach, Fla., where he spent the winter. He was 65 years old and lived here.

title: James W. Coulter, 77, Led Burma Road Maintenance
description: PAWLING, N. Y., Jan. 21James W. Coulter, a consulting construction engineer who was in charge of maintenance of the Burma Road, over which supplies were transported to China in World War II, died today in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Split Decision Favors Marquez Over McClendon in 10Rounder
description: Josue Marquez of Caguas, Puerto Rico, was the recipient of sonic generous voting by two of the officials in last night's Felt Forum fight against Doc McClendon of Paterson, N. J.

title: Union Local to Add Blacks
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 21 (AP)Pipefitters Local 120 of Cleveland has agreed to add 275 blacks to its membership, making 17 per cent of the union membership black by the end of 1975. The agreement came yesterday when attorneys for the Justice Department and the union signed a consent order.

title: 'Something Big':Dean Martin Stars in Caper of 1870 West
description: "Something Big," directed by Andrew V. McLaglen and written by James Lee Barrett, is one of those Pop period Westerns that's difficult to dislike even though it's not really very good, and I suspect that the best place to see it is on 42d Street at the New Amsterdam Theater, rather than at any of the dozen or so other, perhaps fancier theaters where it also opened yesterday. Like being stuck on a subway, or bearing witness to a mugging on the other side of the street, watching "Something Big" is a group experience of a contemporary, if secondary, order.It's apparent that all of the various intelligence and talents who worked on the film kneew exactly what they were aiming at. That is, an 1870 Dean Martin Western that utilizes, makes a certain amount of fun of, but doesn't basically disturb the image of the television personality who might best be described as a GP-rated Perry Como.The plot of "Something Big" can't be outlined without ransacking it of every meaning, since what happens is all there is to it. Martin, a transplanted Pennsylvanian, is a sort of failed outlaw, looking for "something big" so he can go back to Pittsburgh and marry a girl he left behind five years before. The something big turns out to be a raid on a famous Mexican outlaw's remote treasury, an operation that requires a Gatling gun, and a woman whom Martin can trade for the gun.The film is not even as complicated as this brief summary might sound, but it involves some quite attractive performers including Brian Keith, Honor Blackman, Carol White [this West is very big on English women, which may be a comment on the recent day when English secretaries were industry status symbols), Ben Johnson, Albert Salmi, Joyce Van Patten and Judi Meredith.Mr. Martin grins his way through it, wearing an extremely handsome, well-cut suede coat. He is the centerpiece of a fiction that occasionally recalls the sentimentality of John Ford, with mock seriousness, as well as the inane cheeriness of those TV Westerns whose heroes never die, but just go into reruns.

title: Jersey and the Prisoners of Ignorance
description: PRINCETON, N. J.For most inmates in New Jersey prisons, there is another prisonits walls more formidable, its confinement more restrictive its sentence harsh and unjust. The walls are the printed word, the confinement is the inability to read, and the sentence has been imposed by a discriminating judgeAmerican education.

title: CRIME AGENCY HALTS FUNDING IN ALABAMA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The Justice Department said today that it was suspending financial support of an Alabamabased program to train policemen as helicopter pilots because of poor results and a question over $100,000 in expenditures.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: All fares are now ridiculous but Jon Caulfield (letter Jan. 7), who claims that a trip for two from downtown Toronto to the airport cost a mere $1.50, as opposed to a $6 fare from La Guardia to Manhattan, is not telling the whole story. For 75 cents, one Torontonian can indeed make this tripbut he does it via subway and a bus, a journey that can take as long as one hour, with a possible stopover in a partially exposed, unheated bus shelter for up to half an hour.

title: Judicial Overkill
description: State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino, in embarking on a personal crusade against narcotics pushers, is apparently determined to use antitank howitzers to kill mosquitoes. In the process he seems prepared to mow down anyone who considers objectionable this method of judicial overkillone manifested in a maximum sentence of thirty years in prison imposed on a smalltime addict for selling a few grains of heroin to an undercover police agent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: How can the Federal Government, state and city allow an increase of 16.7 per cent in subway and bus fares and 100 per cent in toll charges while Phase Two is in effect?

title: Hanoi Bolsters Defenses
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 21 (Agence FrancePresse) Defense preparations against a possible American attack were reported under way today throughout North Vietnam.

title: Warriors Win 10th in Row
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 21 (AP) The Golden State Warriors held off the Atlanta Hawks during the final three minutes tonight to win their 10th Straight game, 113111.

title: Javits CoSponsors Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The dock strike bill was introduced today by Republican Senators Bob Packwood of Oregon and Jacob K. Javits of New York.

title: City Ad Rule Seeks To Protect. Public From Deceptions
description: To help consumers determine the actual price of a product or service in an advertisement, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs has promulgated a regulation requiring that hidden charges or special conditions be printed in nothing smaller than 10point type.

title: Buckley, in Taipei, Seeks To Reassure Nationalists
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 21Continuing his Asian tour, Senator James L. Buckley arrived today in Taipei. He will meet with Chinese Nationalist leaders and deliver a speech Sunday at a World Freedom Day rally sponsored by the Nationalist chapter of the World AntiCommunist League.

title: YUGOSLAV COMPANY TO BUILD U.S. BOATS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 21The Glastron Boat Company, Austin, has agreed with ChromosKatranKetrilan, a leading chemical producer in Yugoslavia, to provide technical assistance in building a glass fiber boat plant in Zagreb.

title: New Safety Rules Proposed By F.D.A. on Electric Toys
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration proposed today new safety standards for electrically operated toys to minimize danger to children from burns, electrical shock and cuts.

title: Indian Leader Sees Typical Snow Job In Federal Efforts
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 21 The new president of the National Congress of American Indians said today that the Administration's new direction in Indian affairs was the typical kind of snow job all too often put over on Indian country.

title: The Talk of Rouvrel
description: ROUVREL, France, Jan. 18 Up to the middle nineteenfifties there were no telephones in this isolated farm village on a plateau in northwestern Picardy, and the villagers carted water home from a communal well.

title: Bucks Rout Cays, 12091
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 21 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks scored the last 10 points of the first half for a 4835 lead tonight, and went on to hand the Cleveland Cavaliers their ninth straight defeat, 12091.

title: Bhutto Said to Set China Trip
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 21 (AP)President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto will visit Peking Jan. 31 for meetings with Chinese leaders, Government sources said today.

title: A WIDENED REA ROLE ASKED IN AIR FREIGHT
description: REA Express, Inc., yesterday asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to expand the shipping agency's role in the shipment of air freight and packages.

title: Market Place:
description: Where does a growing, profitable maker of packaged electronic circuits go to tell its success story? Would you believe Pittsburgh?

title: Da Camera Symphony Plans To Make Debut Next Month
description: The American Symphony Orchestra da Camera, a chamber orchestra drawn from the American Symphony Orchestra, will make its debut at Town Hall with a series of four concerts in February and March.

title: BOAT SHOW OPENS 9DAY RUN TODAY
description: The National Boat Show opens today at 10 A.M. at the Coliseum, but the city's No. 1 hullthumper will not be there. Mayor Lindsay, show officials said yesterday, Is sticking to his campaign trail and forsaking the whitewater action at Columbus Circle.

title: New York City:
description: To the Editor: The excellent article on the joys of New York City brought tears to my eyes, for it can be a most wonderful city.

title: BLUE CROSS TO ASK A 17.9% RATE RISE
description: Greater New York's Blue Cross announced yesterday evening that it would ask the state to approve a 17.9 per cent increase in rates for hospitalization insurance charged to communityrated subscribers, effective May 1.

title: Jersey Paper Discontinues Jack Anderson's Column
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 21 (UPI)The Long Branch Daily Record announced yesterday that it was discontinuing Jack Anderson's Washington column because of the publication of information from purportedly topsecret documents of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Senate Gets Bill to Repeal Campaign Tax Checkoff
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) A bill was introduced in the Senate today to repeal the tax checkoff plan approved by Congress last year to finance Presidential election campaigns.

title: Production of Autos Fell To 158,985 Units in Week
description: DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP)Auto production declined this week to 158,985 scheduled assemblies from the 175,580 last week and 188,982 during the year, according to Automotive News.

title: First Kent State Defendant Is Sentenced to 6 Months
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Jan. 21 (UPI)The first person tried in connection with the 1970 disturbances at Kent State University was sentenced to six months in prison today.

title: New York City:
description: May we take comfort in the fact that Lady Haire has never been a victim of street crimes as have been so many of her present fellow citizens?

title: JAN SPIESS COOK, 72, WRITER AND EDITOR
description: Mrs. Jan Spiess Cook, a writer and editor, died yesterday of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 72 years old and had lived for many years in New York.

title: I.L.A. and Industry Here Agree on Work Rules
description: The International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association tentatively agreed last night to a new set of working conditions in the port, including provisions for tighter policing of the guaranteed annual income.

title: New York City:
description: To the Editor: I was thoroughly appalled and angered by the sentiments of Suzanne Haire [OpEd, Jan. 11]. They are the very sort of feelings, it seems to me, which have caused modem society not only to tolerate the disgraces it has created, but to almost totally ignore them, and if they continue to spread, will almost certainly doom man to live in the hell he has fashioned.

title: Dance Gala Will Include Films and Reminiscences
description: Monday night's gala performance for the benefit of the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library will be composed of films and reminiscences by noted dance figures as well as live performances. The program, which will begin at 8:30 P.M. at the City Center, will run as follows:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again The Times has slanted the truth about the Highway Trust Fund to fit its editorial whims.
