title: Manchester United Bows, 10, to Chelsea and Loses Lead in English Soccer
description: LONDON, Jan. 22 (Reuters) Manchester United's 15week stay atop the English Soccer League's First Division came to an end today when they were beaten, 10, by Chelsea on a 48thminute goal by Peter Osgood.

title: Wanted for Ocean Race: Singlehanded
description: The call is out for more American entries in this year's Observer Singlehanded Transatlantic Race, scheduled for June 17 from Plymouth Sound, England, to Newport, R. 1.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: To the Editor: With regard to the Jan. 18 story, Ali Celebrates Birthday in Ring:

title: Reader's Report
description: The World War I revival in popular fiction is as imponderable as the Civil War epidemic of some years back. Nonetheless, the guns of August continue to boom, the Boche presses on  and, overhead, Fokker triplanes and Sopwith Camels perform their archaic acrobatics. Goshawk Squadron simulates a bit of the air war of 1918. In this minor massacre, its author brilliantly epitomizes the futility of the entire canvas.

title: Seafarer 29Footer Designed for Action
description: Seafarer Yachts, has introduced a 29foot McCurdy & Rhodes design for competitive sailing and cruising. The yacht has a weighted centerboard and new hullform, with low wetted surface, in seeking good downwind performance.

title: Announcements 5000
description: BRETTSCHNEIDERCOOPERMANMr. and Mrs. Bernard Brettschnelder happily announces the ennagcment of their son Kenrirth to Barbara Cooperman, daughter Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Cooperman of Scranton, Pa., December 31, 1911.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Spend three days with Mickey Mouse at Walt Disney World  urges Eastern Air Lines. But Eastern is The Wings of Man. Does Eastern (and Mickey Mouse) allow a woman to travel on such a trip?

title: Licensing Issue Boils Again
description: For a number of years the controversial issue of licensing pleasureboat operators has risen to the surface, lingered for awhile and eventually drifted off. Recently, it has surfaced again, but this time appears to have far greater staying power.

title: MONTANA ECOLOGIST RUNS FOR GOVERNOR
description: HELENA, Mont., Jan. 22Frank H. Dunkle, director of Montana's Fish and Game Department, resigned this week and announced that he would run as a Republican candidate for Governor with emphasis on protection, of Montana's environment.

title: Deaths
description: ANTHONMay, on Jail. 22, 1972, beloved sister of Elsie Anthon. Friends may call at the Universal Chapel, 52d St. and Lexington Ave., Monday, Jan. 24, 1972. A funeral mass will be offered at St. Paul The Apostle Church, 9th Ave. and 59th St., New York City, at 11 A.M. Interment Woodiawn Cemetery, 1 P.M., Tuesday.

title: Legislative Committees Slate Public Hearings
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Following are public hearings scheduled for the near future by committees of the Senate and the Assembly:

title: Steam Bus Is Tested on Coast
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 22 The nation's first steampowered bus in more than 40 years will begin carrying commuters here Monday. It will operate nine hours a day on the 40mile round trip between East Oakland and Berkeley.

title: Boating Forecast: Good Year Ahead, But a Great One?
description: Boating business in 1972 will be good but not great. That's the consensus of representative members of the industry. What they mean is the new year probably will be 12 to 15 per cent better than 1971 but not as good as 1969, which was a great year.

title: The World
description: In seeking to construct socialism in Chile, the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens has been banking on popular support for its action last July in nationalizing the country's copper mines, with their large United States holdings. Yet in a byelection last week in a district that contains a big nationalized mine, the Government candidate was defeated for a Senate seat by an opposition Christian Democrat.

title: Al and Ella Were Good
description: To the Editor: Let's face it: The Super Bowl was a bore and proved once again that too much of what is supposed to be a good thing (weekend after weekend of three games being telecast in a twoday period) can prove its undoing. The best part of the Super Bowl was not the game itselfafter Dallas had gone ahead, 30, the outcome was a foregone conclusionhut the Al HirtElla Fitzgerald halftime rendition of Mack the Knife. That was the only part of the extravaganza that was entitled to instant replay.

title: Marita Silverman Wed
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 22The marriage of Capt. Marita Silverman, Army Nurse Corps, to Lyndon P. Bowden Jr., took place here this morning in the Pioneer International Hotel. Judge Norman Fenton of the Superior Court of Pima County, performed the ceremony. The bride, who is studying for her master's degree in pediatric nursing at the University of Arizona, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour L. Silverman of Chevy Chase, Md. Her husband, a student at Arizona, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. P. Bowden of Phoenix.

title: State Court Backs Liability Under Automobile Warranty
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22 (AP)An automobile manufacturer whose defective product injures persons in another car can be held liable for breach of implied warranty even if no negligence is involved, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has ruled.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I refer to the article (Jan. 16) on the Shell Oil Company's move to Houston. Even more informative was the box entitled View From New York. As a part of that article, New York City's Economic Development Commissioner was quoted:

title: Satellite Put in Orbit; To Relay Nixon Trip
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP)  A new international communications satellite rocketed into a successful preliminary orbit tonight on its way to a stationary outpost high above the Pacific. Among its first assignments will be to relay television pictures of the winter Olympics in Japan and President Nixon's trip to China, both scheduled for February.

title: Brooklyn: A Segregated Town?
description: Sheepshead Bay, the borough south of GreenWood Cemetery, Prospect Park and Church Avenue was more than 90 per centfrequently more than 95 per centwhite.

title: Travel Notes: New Air Fare Pact, Bike Trails, 'Street Singer' Afloat
description: THE zigzag route taken by transAtlantic air fares these last few weeks has just zigged again as a result of the devaluation of the dollar. International air fares based on the dollar will go up by as much as 7 per cent beginning April 1, provided that Air Canada, which has been holding out for a smaller hike, goes along. The 7 per cent increase was agreed upon by all the other major airlines at a meeting in Geneva last week, and the effect of the agreement is that part of the reduction in air fares that travelers thought they were going to enjoy this year as a resvlt of an I.A.T.A. pact last month has already withered away.

title: Nixon Welcomes Treaty
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 22 President Nixon issued a statement today welcoming the signing of the treaty to allow Britain, Ireland, Denmark and Norway into the European community.

title: Persian Gulf Nations Set Deadline in Drive to Buy 20% Shares in Oil Companies
description: GENEVA, Jan. 22The six Persian Gulf oilproducing countries tonight, set the end of February as the deadline for achieving results in their campaign for the right to buy 20 per cent share in 12 oil companies operating on their territory.

title: Trapped in Guayaquil With Nada to Do? See the Vertical Cemetery
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador On my way to the Galapagos Islands, highlyoverrated gaggle of Pacific islands without a single golf course, and infested with lizards, tortoises and oddball birds, I got trapped for a day here in Guayaquil, Ecuador's largest city and the usual jumpingoff place for the Galapagos, whether by sea or air. I use the word trapped because that was what my travel agent said: I'm afraid you're going to be trapped in Guayaquil for a day. Sorry.

title: Miss Sawers To Wed in May
description: Miss Joanne Helen Sawers and Hanno Geart Buning plan to be married in May in Tuxedo Park, N. Y.

title: 8 GREEKS SENTENCED FOR 1969 EXPLOSIONS
description: ATHENS, Jan. 22  Eight young Greeks opposed to their country's militaryhacked Government were sentenced to prison terms of one to nine years by the Athens special military court today for violating the strict law on explosives.

title: Martha McVickar Married on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 Miss Martha Kane McVickar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm McVickar of Kentfield, was married here this afternoon to Robert R. Gerstenkorn of San Anselmo. The Rev. Roland E. Grumm performed the ceremony in St. Paulus Lutheran Church.

title: Angels Appoint Roseboro
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 22 (UPI)John Roseboro, the Los Angeles Dodgers No. 1 catcher for more than a decade, returns to Southern California as bull pen coach for the California Angeles, General Manager Harry Dalton announced today. Roseboro completed his playing career with the Washington Senators in 1970 after two seasons with Minnesota.

title: Townhouses for Poor Draw Fire
description: A proposed scatter  site housing project of threestory townhouses in Brooklyn that has stirred echoes of the continuing controversy in Forest Hills is heading for a City Hall decision.

title: Coast Archbishop Institutes Some Reforms
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22Last month The Tidings, the newspaper of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese here, displayed two frontpage pictures of Archbishop Timothy Manning leading a pilgrimage of 200 priests and laymen to Mexico City.

title: The World
description: There's nothing particularly new about students in Spain being restless. But this year there seem to be two differences from the recent past: The students appear to be better organized, and their protest efforts have centered more specifically on university issues than on broader political questions related to the Government.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Greeks never had a word for it anyway. When those noblest of men staged the first Olympic Games during a full moon in the month Apollonius In 776 B.C., there probably was not a snowflake in sight, not even on those rugged peaks guarding the Ionian Sea. It was a religious festival and an athletic festival. Most of all it was a summer festival, with none of that winter nonsense profaning the original purposes of the Olympics.

title: Van Zandt Does His Thing: Sews Sails
description: OLD MYSTIC, Conn.The yachting shoreline of southeast Connecticut is somnolent at this season. The tarps over the boats on the shore match the woodland: faded gray, brown, dark green and white gone to dun color. Ice edges the puddles between the boat cradles. The Connecticut River, the Mystic and the Thames are abandoned to the professionalstrawlers, draggers and lobstermen that appear only as dark blots on the dazzling gold estuaries.

title: The 62d National Boat Show
description: Nicolette's back in town. So is Robin  and Ding and Jimbo and Kathy  and Kelli and Hilu. They're all here giving the 62d National Boat Show at the Coliseum an added lift.

title: Army Beats Penn State
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. (UPI)Army outscored Penn State 62 in the final 42 onds tonight to register fourth straight victory, 7265.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Why some Americans like to play the role of rich, martyred dunces while traveling in Latin America is somethirq beyond my grasp. Robert J. Dunphy, who wrote an article about gambling in Mexico (Travel section, Dec. 19) is an xample. He complains of the bettitg system at Mexico City's jai alai game and says that only a mathematical genius can figure it out. He deposited 100 pesos to bet on the blue team, and that, he says, was the last he saw of his money, though he grudgingly admits that the reds won. What did he expect? Where in the world does a losing bettor get his money back? He also complained that he was shortchanged on at least three trips to the 10peso window at the Hipodromo de las Americas race track. Would a person keep returning to the window if he was being shortchanged?

title: The World
description: In line with its apartheid policy, South Africa has an Immorality Act which forbids sexual relations, including marriage, between blacks and whites. As a consequence, many white South African men have cultivated the habit of crossing the border into Swaziland on weekends in search of black Swazi women. Vast playgrounds of sex is how one South African newspaper recently described some places in Swaziland.

title: My Wife, My Avocado and Me
description: AT about the time we moved into our present apartment, which was 12 years ago, I got home one day in time to rescue an avocado pit from the garbage following my wife's concoction of a bowl of guacamole. She is one of the best guacamole makers outside Mexico, but has trouble with a husband who can't stand to see an avocado pit go unplanted. Over the years many avocados have come and gone in our family, but the plant from the pit I rescued on this occasion has endured and grown to such an extent that we are now a menage A troismy wife, my avocado, and me. And although my wife in moments of stress says, One of us goesit or me, she backs down when I point out that while she can still get through the door, the avocado can't. It rises 6 feet above its 18inch pot, stretches out 68 inches at the widest part of its irregular mass, and is supported by a trunk 5 inches in circumference.

title: GREECE WILL SELL ISLANDS IN THE SUN
description: ATHENS, Jan. 22  Hundreds of Greek islands will be put up for sale by the Government, which plans to liquidate all stateowned real estate throughout Greece for an estimated $260million to $330million.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe Supreme Court heard arguments last week for the first time on the constitutionality of capital punishmentarguments that may determine the fate of the 700 men and women on the nation's death rows.

title: Minnesota on Top
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 22 (UPI)  Minnesota, led by Clyde Turner's 31 points and Ron Behagen's 23, posted a 6757 triumph over Michigan State tonight.

title: Mean Machine Is Unveiled
description: A limited edition styling version of its popular SeaHorse 65 has been unveiled by Johnson Motors.

title: Miss Henning Will Be Wed
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Jan. 22Miss Martha Jean Henning, a securities analyst with Pershing & Co., New York stockbrokers, plans to be married next month to John Van Voorhies Cockcroft Jr., a lawyer in New York.

title: Sort to Mrs. Constantine
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Jan. 22 A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wells Constantine on Jan. 2 at the Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring.

title: Miss Bryner Wed To Walter Auch Jr.
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 22 Miss Lynne Carrington Bryner was married here at noon today to Walter E. Auch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Auch of Greenwich and Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: David Rickenbacker to Marry Miss Elizabeth B. Hendricks
description: WINCHESTER, Ky., Jan. 22Miss Elizabeth Buckner Hendricks and David Brian Rickenbacker, students at Centre College in Danville, plan to be married on June 17.

title: Television
description: The tube will shine a little brighter this week, thanks the presence of some oldfashioned Hollywood luminaries. Dorothy McGuire, above, acts the head of an eerily uneasy household in She Waits, the CBS Friday night movie at Below, Walter Pidgeon plays doctor to Olivia de Havilland's mentally disturbed patient in The Screaming Woman, suspense film on ABC next Saturday night at 8:30. The bearded Orson Welles tries to ride herd on a gaggle funnymen as host of The ABC Comedy Hour, Wednesday night at 8:30.

title: Nets Game Is Called Off as Condors Fail to Appear
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 22A nearcapacity crowd of more than 6,500 persons was turned away from the Island Garden this afternoon when the American Basketball Association game between the New York Nets and the Pittsburgh Condors was postponed because the Condors failed to appear.

title: Faulk Reaches Final
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 22 (AP)Steve Faulk of Madisonville, La., beat Jeff Simpson of New Zealand, 67, 76, 62, 64, and gained the final of the New Zealand tennis championship today. Onny Parun, the topseeded New Zealander, had to struggle to eliminate Armistead Neely of Tampa, Fla., 36, 26, 63, 63, 63, in the other semifinal.

title: Aid to Coast Quake Victims Forecast at $450Million
description: LOS ANGELES Jan. 22 (AP) Federal aid for victims of the Feb. 9, 1971, earthquake may eventually total more than $450million, an official of the Office of Emergency Preparedness says.

title: OneTon Class Is Wary Over Fear of Changes
description: Although the experiments in One Ton Class racing last year augur well, the momentum of its acceptance was slowed by uncertainty over projected changes in the International Offshore Rule.

title: Amy Rosenberg Wed
description: BETHESDA, Md., Jan. 22 Miss Amy Jo Rosenberg and Michael Joel Bloom were married here today at the Holiday Inn by Rabbi Ian L. Wolk. The bride is the daughter of Dr. Charles A. Rosenberg, director of medical services for the Department of Medicine and Surgery of the Veterans Administration in Washington, and Mrs. Rosenberg. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Bloom of New York, where Mr. Bloom is a motion picture property master and director of special effects for MPO, a production company.

title: U.S. COURT REVISES TEXAS DISTRICTS
description: DALLAS, Jan. 22 (UPI)A three  judge Federal court adopted today a redistriicting plan for Congressionaf districts in Texas.

title: 14 SOCCER TEAMS IN TITLE TOURNEY
description: Fourteen teams of the GermanAmerican Soccer League will battle for the indoor title at the league's 10th annual tournament which will be completed today at the Westchester County Center in White Plains.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: ONLY three weeks of the new year have passed and yet an interesting set of slightly divergent opinions about business prospects has already begun to bob to the surface. It might be no more than a brief spasm of midwinter blues. Before 1972 started, there was overwhelming sentiment among economists that the 12 months ahead would produce a huge expansion of the economyperhaps record growth for a single year. Businessmen, meanwhile, were less sanguine about the outlook.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE Enrron: It is true that procedures for exchanging foreign currency in Algeria are more complicated than in most countries, but not nearly as bad as indicated in Sanche de Gramont's article, Crossing Algeria's Desert Through Rain and Red Tape (Travel section, Dec. 26), and nothing to scare away any visitor. He arrived in El Oued on a Saturday and found the bank closed. That should not have been so surprising! The fact is that, contrary to the tone of the article, Algeria does want foreign tourists. On the coast near Algiers, it has built modern tourist villages, at Zeralda, Moretti and Trpass, which have the Auxuries a westerner expectsplus a bit of exoticism. In the Sahara there is a movable, luxury tenthotel. In places like these the visitor can expect and demand an easy time, but elsewhere one has to accept that society is being shaped in the best interests of the Algerian and that the occasional tourist is of

title: TORRE TO RECEIVE SID MERCER PRIZE
description: Joe Torre was named player of the year yesterday by the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Baby Care Endangered By Lack of Specialists
description: Who will deliver and care for the next generation of American babies?

title: MUSKIE PICKS UP JERSEY BACKERS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22  After months or courtship punctuated with everincreasing doses of political pressure, Senator Edmund S. Muskie began picking up major political prizes in New Jersey this week in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Switzerland Plans to Lift 124Year Ban on Jesuits
description: BERN, Switzerland, Jan. 22 The Swiss Government has announced that it had decided to revoke a 124yearold ban on the Roman Catholic Society of Jesus, which prohibited educational or religious function in Switzerland.

title: Peace: Facts or Promises?
description: President Nixon's State of the Union message promises the nation a generation of peace, but asks it to pay more for defense. The President argues that strong military defenses are the guardians of peace, that peace would be endangered by weakening America and tempting aggressors. Few issues more need the major national debate this one is likely to get both in the Congress and in the campaign.

title: Music
description: THE voice on the telephone sent shivers down the back. It was low, throaty, sexy, vibrant, expressive. How nice that you would like to see me, said the voice. Do come down tomorrow. Only a few hours? I do wish it could be longer. Arrivederci!

title: Woman Angler Gets by With Help of Friends
description: I have to go to the bathroom. What do you mean, . beer can? .

title: OneWay Streets In Brooklyn
description: In a move to reduce traffic congestion in the Mill Basin area of Brookyn, the city's Traffic Department has announced that the following stretches would be made oneway effective next Tuesday:

title: Early Call of April
description: In the midst of winter, no matter whether it is bitterly cold or Aprilmild, whether the snow is deep or the landscape bare and brown, the evidence of spring never far away. The buds are there on the branches, dormant and seemingly huddled against the cold. The insect egg masses are on weed stems and tree trunks, inert but full of the germs of life, waiting only the sun's shift and the day's change. But beyond such relatively subtle signs are the actions now of the squirrel and the owl, which seem to know without a shred of doubt that April will come, and May and June.

title: Oil Rush in Peru
description: LIMA, PeruThis nation of high mountains, stoic Indians and ancient culture has become a major center in the industrialized world's search for energy to power, heat and cool its factories, planes, cars, homes and offices.

title: $160Million Suit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22Six Philadelphia policemen filed a $160million libel suit in Common Pleas Court here this week against The Philadelphia Inquirer and its executive editor, John McMullan.

title: S.L. Echols Marries Miss Eckman
description: WAYNESBORO, Va., Jan. 22Miss Mary Murray Eckman and Stephen Lee Echols of Alexandria, were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Louis H. Fracher.

title: WARRIORS ROMP TO 11TH STRAIGHT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (UPI)Jim Barnett scored 29 points and Nate Thurmond got 22 to lead the Golden State Warriors to their 11th straight victory tonight, a 113106 triumph over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Lauberhorn Race Off
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 22The 42d running of the famous Lauberhorn downhill race was prevented by fog today. The men's event, which would have counted toward the World Cup, will probably he made up after the Winter Olympics next month when the ski circuit moves to North America.

title: Majority Control of Redskins, Passes From the Marshalls
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) The Washington Redskins have purchased 260 shares of the club's stock from the estate of George P. Marshall Sr. for $3million.

title: STATE ASSESSES FOOD VIOLATORS
description: A total of $18,705 was assessed against supermarkets and other food stores in the metropolitan area in the last six months of 1971 because of violations of the Agriculture and Markets Law in the adulteration and mislabeling of food and food products.

title: COLORADO IS COOL TO WINTER GAMES
description: DENVER, Jan. 22The most important thing in the Olympic Games, according to the Olympic Creed, is not the triumph of winning, but the strugglenot to win, but to take part.

title: GARCIA VERSATILE WITH HIS GUITAR
description: Jerry Garcia, one of rock's premier guitarists and a primal energy source for the Grateful Dead, showed up in a slightly different role Friday night at the Academy of Music. He was the guest star with a group led by the West Coast organist Howard Wales.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMWhen the El Al 747 landed at Lydda Airport here last Tuesday morning, it seemed to symbolize what the Israelis see as an exciting new stage in their 23year modern history. The 330 passengers on that particular flight were Jews from the Soviet Uniona record number for any one flightarriving to start new lives in the Jewish homeland.

title: SAMUEL WOOLMAN
description: Samuel Woolman, president and founder of S. Woolman, Inc., 400 Broadway, textile jobbers, died Friday at his home, 7020 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 84 years old.

title: Duty Range Wide On Hudson Patrol
description: STONY POINT, N.Y, The 25 miles of riverfront that is on the Hudson's west shore in Rockland County is policed by the county sheriff's River Patrol from May to October.

title: Men and Machines on Guard at Howard Hughes Suite in Bahamas
description: NASSAU, The Bahamas, Jan. 19The Britannia Beach Hotel on Paradise Island is much like a hundred other resort hotels  until some stranger makes a move toward the northwest end of the top floor.

title: The World
description: The demonstrations at Cairo University last week were the first major campus protest against the Egyptian Government in three years and put students in direct confrontation with President Anwar elSadat.

title: It's Not All Fun and Glamour, Women Secret Service Agents Discover
description: WASHINGTON The trouble with being a woman Secret Service agent is that while there are moments of fun and glamour, there are hours and hours of boredom and drudgery, the young women have told friends.

title: INDIA REARRANGES NORTHEAST REGION
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 22Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has inaugurated three new states and two union territories in India's northeastern region.

title: S.O.R.C. Opens 6 Event Series In Friday Race
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.The Southern Ocean Racing Conference opens its sixrace sailboat series here Friday with the 105mile St. PetersburgtoVenice event.

title: Fiat's Soviet Venture
description: Fiat, S.P.A., Italy's largest producer of autos, is pleased with its deal with the Soviet Union in building the Togliatti automobile factory, according to Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of the company.

title: Nov at Bat for White Sox, Dick Allen
description: What's in a name? Everything, says Richard Anthony Allen, and he has let it be known once and for all that he wants to divest himself of Richie and Rich and become just Dick Allen of the Chicago White Sox.

title: Mrs. Peterson Has Child
description: A daughter was born on Jan. 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Gosta R. Peterson of New York and Amagansett, L. I., at Mount Sinai Hospital here. Mrs. Peterson, fashion editor of The New York Times, is the former Miss Patricia Ann Louis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. R. Louis of Port Washington, L. I. Mr. Peterson is a photographer.

title: Cantilever Survives a Foul, Pays $46 at Narragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 22 (AP)  Cantilever, a 5yearold owned by Walter Goodman of Boston, finished first by 2 lengths and then survived a foul claim today in winning the $2,600 Marathon Handicap at Narragansett Park.

title: Westward the Course of Ecology
description: The picture of a fine sailing ship moving through the oilfilmcovered ocean in a freshening smogfilled breeze is indeed a vision of horror to any sailor. The contrast of the natural beauty of sail against a polluted oceanic background is an extremely powerful one.

title: Profile of Student Drivers
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 22 (UPI)High school students who have high citizenship ratings in school tend to be better drivers than those with poor records, according to a state Department of Motor Vehicles study. The study said poor school adjustment, poor academic achievement, high driving mileage and number of cigarettes smoked were generally connected to young persons frequently involved in accidents and cited for traffic violations.

title: Gillman Starting on New Track After a 36Year Football Stint
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif.  From 1935 to last November, Sid Gillman spent almost all of his waking hours as a football coach, college (Ohio State, Denison, Miami of Ohio, Army and Cincinnati) and professional (Los Angeles Rams and Los Angeles and San Diego Chargers). Now, as a brandnew television executive and (his description) unemployed coach, he is discovering life.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Pessimism has been erased from the fashion picture on Seventh Avenue. Prospects are excellent for 1972, manufacturers say, and many of the leading producers are predicting sizable gains in dollar volume.

title: P.S.C. Aide offers Fiscal Plan to Put Utility Lines Underground
description: A plan to require each electric and telephone company in the state to earmark 2 per cent of its gross revenues for projects to put existing overhead distribution lines underground was formally recommended yesterday by a state Public Service Commission examiner.

title: 2 SCHOOLS SHARE HONORS IN RELAYS
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 22 (AP)  Southern Illinois and Tennessee dominated the 7th annual Tennessee Relays which were completed today. There was no team scoring In the twoday meet.

title: Suit Filed to Invalidate State's Redistricting Plan
description: A suit has been brought in State Supreme Court to invalidate the recent reapportionment of, the State Legislature on the grounds that it was an outrageous example of partisan gerrymandering and that It violated both the Federal and state constitutions.

title: PRICE AND CORELLI IN FORZA AT MET
description: One had every reason to expect that La Forza del destino at the Met Friday night would be a special, highly charged operatic evening. Such was not the case despite the fact that two of the company's superstars, Leontyne Price and Franco Corelli, were appearing for the first time this season  Miss Price has, in fact, been absent from the Met stage for almost two years  and that these roles are especially well tailored for their talents.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Dec. 18 agreement among the Group of 10 was hailed extravagantly by President Nixon as the most significant monetary agreement in the history of the world. It is in the sense that it left the international monetary system in utter shambles, but recognized that multilateral negotiations were urgently needed to reconstruct a system totally different from the one that died, after a long agony, on Aug. 15, 1971.

title: NORTH STARS TOP MAPLE LEAFS, 41
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 22 (AP)Barry Gibbs, his fractured jaw wired shut, set up one score and boomed in a shot from the point tonight to cap Minnesota's threegoal burst in the first period as the North Stars beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 41.

title: Soviet 5Year Plan Made Slow Start in Key Areas
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 22The Soviet Union's current fiveyear plan appeared to be off to a slow start in some key areas last year, according to the annual yearend economic report made public today.

title: Reader's Report
description: The two girls of the title run a stationerystoresodafountain in a Catskill village. Enter Richard, a sleepin helper. First Richard sleeps with Rita, the older sister. (Our lovemaking was exhausting, but it seemed to be the right way to do it at the time.) Then he sleeps with Harriet, the younger sister. Rita puts a dish of cold chicken in Harriet's bed. Somebody becomes pregnant, Nobody eats the chicken.

title: ByPassing the Pay Board
description: The compulsoryarbitration law urged by President Nixon to end the West Coast dock strike points up anew the irresponsibility Congress has shown in ignoring two years of White House calls for a basic overhaul of the nation's inadequate statutory shields against crisis strikes. It is ridiculous to have to concoct patchwork backtowork laws two or three times a year to deal with tieups in vital industries.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article The Boors of Business (Jan. 9) could not have been more timely since I have been going through just such a situation with a local agency.

title: Recordings
description: IF ever an operatic character needed the ministrations of womens liberation less than Leonore, the wife who singlehandedly rescues her husband from death in Beethovens Fidelio, she has yet to be discovered. Her strength, continually questioned, always reaffirmed, has through the years attracted great sopranos, and many of the more recent interpretations of this role are available on records: Birgit Nilsson, Christa Ludwig, Leonie Rysanek and Martha Midi can all be heard in exciting performances, each different, each with its faithful adherents. To this list can now be added the name of Helga Dernesch, who stars in a new release of Fiddle conducted by Herbert von Karajan (3 disks, Angel SCL3773).

title: Larsen Takes Two Races In Title Ice Yachting Regatta
description: BANTAM LAKE, Conn., Jan. 22 John Larsen, in the DN Class, and David Clapp, in the Skeeter Class, were the only double winners today as the Eastern Ice Yachting Associaregatta opened in 12knot breezes.

title: CAST CHANGES SPUR TWO BALLET DEBUTS
description: Cast changes Friday night at the State Theater brought two New York City Ballet dancers into new roles in two Balanchine Ballets. Gelsey Kirkland was the girl in the pas de deux in the Bach Concerto Barocco and Helgi Tomasson appeared as the lone male in the Glazunov Raymonda Variations.

title: Yale's Jauron Is Honored
description: BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP)Dick Jauron, Yale running hack, was honored tonight as the winner of the Nils V. (Swede) Nelson award for sportsmanship on the football field. The Gridiron Club of Boston cited his unselfish conduct and personal sacrifice in willingly switching from halfback to fullback for the good of the team.

title: Mansfield Doubts Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) The Senate Democratic Leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today that he doubted that Congress would approve additional funds for operations in Laos and Cambodia. The Senate wouldn't stand for increased involvement in either of these two countries, he said.

title: Isabel M. Lucom Married In Capital to Robert Clark
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22In St. Alban's Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Isabel Maria Lucom was married to Robert MarvinClark, a special assistant to Senator William E. Brock 3d of Tennessee. The Rev. Robert W. Estill, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe ostensibly independent Pay Board and Price Commission were established by the Nixon Administration to make the rules for Phase Two, and they have easily dominated the news in the 10 weeks that have elapsed since Phase One's 90day freeze ended on Nov. 14.

title: Irving Arrives on Island
description: IBIZA, Spain, Jan. 22Clifford Irving returned here from New York today without an explanation as to why a Zurich bank account ostensibly belonging to Howard Hughes was opened by a woman with the assumed name of H. R. Hughes.

title: Botanical Garden Gets Fund For Wild Flowers Volume
description: The New York Botanical Garden has been awarded a grant of $200,000 by the Andrew W Mellon Foundation to assist with the publication of the sixth and final volume of the New York Botanical Garden's series of hooks, Wild Flowers of the United States.

title: Use of Double Suggested
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP)A former security employe of Howard Hughes said today that Clifford Irving could have been duped by Hughes double, a trick he said he once used to throw newsmen and others off the billionaire's trail.

title: Will the Downtown Store Make a Comeback?
description: ST. LOUIS  One of the South's most respected merchants stared recently at the erratic customer traffic in his store on the city's main shopping street and observed savagely: I'm just sick and tired of spending money fixing up my downtown store.

title: A poet's journal, a strange Western, a novel of quest, a philosopher's fantasy
description: While reading Iris Murdoch, you sometimes forget that she's a philosopher. At times she sounds like a judo expert, a film technician, an antique dealer or a newly paroled nun. But occasionally, it's hard to remember that she's a novelist; many respond to her work as though it were a batch of Rorschach tests. She's had ardent fans, plus many poor reviews, and her fiction ignites quarrels (about sex), accusations (about lacking a sense of wonder) or downright insults (having no sense of humor). Those who like sex, jokes and surprises can become rather defensive about not reveling in Murdoch. They may also feel guiltybecause her ideas and her plots are such good ones.

title: Michigan Wins Minus 4
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 22 (AP)Ernie Johnson scored 22 points and John Lockard 19 today to lead Michigan to an 8379 Big Ten college basketball victory over Northwestern.

title: New spice in town
description: New spices don't just pop up every day of the week, and the recent arrival in this country of green peppercornspoivres vertsfrom Madagascar is, therefore, something of an event. They are soft, unripe forms of what everyone already knows as pepper, but their taste is more subtle and they can be mashed. In Europe, chefs have been experimenting with several new recipes. Here are two, one for ham and one for steak au poivre vert. Add a new spice to your life.

title: A Medical College Sought By Pentagon for Services
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) The Pentagon has asked Congress to create an armed forces medical college and provide $20million in scholarships to get doctors for the armed services.

title: G.I. DEATHS RAISE BOOT CANIP ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Before Pvt. Warren John of the Marine Corps died in a Florida naval hospital last September following rigorous combat training, his family thought that the specter of death lurked thousands of miles away on some remote jungle battlefield.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to add a few cautionary remarks to the excellent recent series of articles by John Herbers on our Federal housing programs. If one were to articulate the decision faced by public officials when considering whether to act to alleviate the housing problem in this country, it would involve certain predictable risks: Some builders could possibly find a way to make excess profits, some mismanagement will probably occur, given the shortage of trained managers, and higher percentage of foreclosures than the conventionally funded projects may be expected.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: for the first time in many years I had the pleasure recently of using the Penn Centralfrom Newark to Boston. It was also the first time in 25 years that I had traveled alone, and I was apprehensive about the journey, bearing in mind that the railroads are often criticized. However, from the minute I boarded the train until I reached my destination (a few minutes ahead of time) everything was done for my comfort. The parlor car steward went out of his way to put me at ease.

title: Medicine
description: As many an American has cause to know, most doctors don't like to make house calls. Government statistics support that observation: In 195758, physicians made about 45.7 million house calls; in 196667, in spite of the population rise, the number of house calls was down to 27.3 million.

title: New Way to Sell Jet Fighters
description: LOS ANGELES  The Northrop Corporation is putting business principles to work in a rarefied atmomosphere  the development of an advanced military airplane. The reason is politics.

title: Russia's Ashkenazy: e Can't (Won't?) Go Home Again
description: WHEN you catch the SovietcumRussian pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy in New York, he is likely to be racing through town for only a swift couple of days. He stays at Central Park South's nesest and poshest hotel, eats around the corner at the Russian Tea Room (on a recent Sunday he had rosolnik giblet soup and sirniki cottage cheese cakes fried in butter and topped with sour cream), plays next door at Carnegie Hall or up a few blocks at Philharmonic Hall, and can he glimpsed in between times window shopping on 57th Street with a Schwann record catalogue in his hand. Or is it a Solzhenitsyn paperback?

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: When making reservations for a transcontinental trip for my wife and twomonthold daughter, I asked an American Airlines agent to reserve a cradle seat. She said that the airline no longer provided them. I asked whether the plane carried piano on board, and she replied most positively, Yes, sir! I believe it is time for the airlines to stop providing gimmicky frills and begin supplying meaningful services such as cradle seats.

title: Censured Judge's Action In Trial Upheld by Justice
description: BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP)A state Supreme Court justice has dismissed the contention that Superior Court Judge Vincent J. Brogna, who has been censored, had no right to order a new trial in a case while Judge Brogna was being investigated by the Supreme Court.

title: LAMPO CAPTURES BOWLING TOURNEY
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 22 (AP)Gus Lampo, a 28yearold exArmy cook from Endicott, N. Y., swept aside four opponents, including the 1971 bowler of the year, Don Johnson, to win the $77,777 Showboat Invitation bowling tournament today.

title: RANGERS BEATEN BY CANUC S, 52, AFTER LONG TRIP
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 22This was not the most propitious moment for a visit to Vancouver, and the 52 defeat the New York Rangers suffered at the hands of the Canucks today was only one of the reasons. Because air tower controllers are on strike throughout Canada, one couldn't get here by plane. The Rangers, who took a 50 decision at Oakland last night, had to fly to Seattle, stay overnight there and take a 3hour bus trip that brought them to the arena only a couple of hours before game time.

title: On the Sound to Publish A New Coastal Magazine
description: On the Sound magazine, which is celebrating its first birthday at the boat show, is also getting set to publish its second monthly magazine, this one to be named On the Shore.

title: British Press Council Opposes Any New Privacy Safeguards
description: LONDON Jan. 22 (AP) Britain's Press Council has told the Government that legislation strengthening citizens rights of privacy might he harmful to the interests of both the public and a free press.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The effort to end high seas fishing for the Atlantic salmon is gaining ground, members of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency (CASE) told a news conference in New York last Friday.

title: The Nation
description: It sounded like nothing so much as a script from TV's Mission Impossible. And with each passing day last week, the mystery deepened: Had novelist Clifford Irving talked to the real Howard Hughes in compiling a purported autobiography of the billionaire industrialist and recluse? If not, just whose voice is on the tape recordings he said he made? Who was the Germanspeaking blonde in her early thirties who opened a Swiss bank account in the name of H. It Hughesan account enriched by three checks from McGrawHill Book Company totaling $650,000? Who withdrew the boodleand where do Mr. Hughes and Mr. Irving fit into the picture? Is it all a gigantic hoax?

title: Wings Top Sabres, 32
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22 (UPI)Tim Ecclestone batted in a 45foot crossice pass by Guy Charron today to cap a thirdperiod comeback that gave the Detroit Red Wings a 32 National Hockey League victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: A Glossary of Tanury
description: For American colleges and universities, a more useful definition of tenure is that provided by Richard H. Peairs, director of the Western regional office in San Francisco of the American Association of University Professors:

title: SULZBERGER VIEWS NIXON AS BEATABLE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP) President Nixon would be in trouble in his bid for reelection if a strong Democratic contender emerged, the president and publisher of The New York Times said today.

title: Soviet Boats Seized by U.S. Arrive at Aleutian Island
description: ADAK ISLAND, Alaska, Jan. 22 (AP)Two Soviet fishing ships that briefly resisted seizure by the Coast Guard five days ago tied up at a United States Navy pier here today to face possible charges of illegal fishing activity in American territorial waters.

title: New Button Cuts Out Sewing
description: A new snapon, interchangeable button system for general apparel and uniforms may, its young inventor believes, be as revolutionary to clothing as the zipper was.

title: Clarkson Beats Yale, 126
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 22Clarkson scored the last nine goals of the game, eight of them in the third period, to turn a 63 deficit into a 126 victory over Yale tonight. It was the 18th successive time Yale has lost to the Golden Knights and dropped the Elis wonlost record to 67. Clarkson. 135 this season, was Ied by Brian Mason, who scored three goals.

title: Operation Eros Seeks Eviction of Prostitutes
description: The shades are permanently down at the Aristo Hotel. But now there is joylicit joyon West 44th Street because the Aristo's special brand of nightlife  prostitutionhas come to a timely end.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: In Does the Club Mediterranee Live Up to Its Titillating Legend? (Travel section, Jan. 8), criticism was made of American Express, its promoter and booking agent in this country. Club Med does have a few faults, but it would surprise me if American Express were responsible for them. Perhaps the only fault that it can be accused of rightly Is creating the very image that has attracted to the club's villages the less interesting and less adventuresome vacationers complained of in the article. This image threatens to change an organization with flavor and appeal into just another antiseptic resort for underactive Americans. Until then, however, for thousands of veteran members like myself, Club Med's villages will continue to be beautifully unpretentious, unprogramed, totally sociable andyesswinging.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: THE magic word is touch from Esalen to Guggenheim. The little gesture that was once so innocuous has assumed gospel proportions and is now reigning at the Upper East Side touch spectacle.

title: Apologia Without Apology
description: I didn't have to destroy the Unitarian Jewish Temple with its Unitarian rabbi on Euclid Avenue in Cleveland. I simply left it. No real need after World War II to crusade for sexual permission: simply do it. In the same way, the literary life was no longer an aristocratic hobbyist's preserve in which a Midwestern Sherwood Anderson or a Dreiser always felt like an outlander. Even the black or Jewish writer could just come to New York and say, l'm here, and find a public avid for novelty, whether he brought little or much novelty. At midcentury the black writer or the Jew still offered the touch of strange which audiences required; but soon their role as purveyor of oddness and revolt would be taken by angry women, fighting homosexuals, Chicanos, Puerto Ricans, Indians, with the Eskimos yet to be heard from.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I.There's everything from soup to nuts here. Shopping centers abound. East Main Street has aquarium, tuxedo rental, paperbook and furniture stores. And off the 307yearold township's beaten track are some fine, smaller establishments.

title: The Nation
description: The jet had eased to a stop on the tarmac at Newark Airport when the stewardess announced its arrival in the New York metropolitan area. The announcement didn't sit well with one of the passengers, Gov. William T. Cahill, who steamed off the plane and filed a vigorous protest with airline officials.

title: Reader's Report
description: On Dec. 1, 1842, the son of the Secretary of War in Tyler's Cabinet was hanged at sea. His crime was the alleged plotting of a mutiny on the Navy brig Somers, to which he was assigned as a midshipman. This historical item is made into a chilling, engrossing novel by Henry Carlisle, based on the private papers of the ship's surgeon. Dr. Leacock entertained doubts as to the justice of the punishment. He demurred at the fondness of the ship's commander for indiscriminate flogging, and he saw Philip Spencer, the banged midshipman, more as a wayward boy than a mutineer. (Leacock was a suicide shortly after the Somers returned to the Brooklyn Navy Yard.)

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE CORPORATION announced a plan to make emergency loans of up to $60million to the Bank of the Commonwealth in Detroit, which otherwise faced the possibility of failure.

title: Grumman Features Two 20Foot Canoes
description: Sharing honors as queen of Grumman's fleet of allaluminum canoes are a pair of 20footers, available in two slightly different versions.

title: Art Notes
description: NO doubt about it, this is the year of the aged Old Master. Last fall, Picasso's 90th birthday generated a spate of trihutory exhibitions. The Metropolitan Museum has just bestowed a show on 83yearold Josef Albers, and will do the same this spring for Jacques Lipchitz, 81. Now the New York Cultural Center (on Columbus Circle) has opened an exhibition devoted to the work of 83yearold Giorgio de Chirico, the celebrated Italian metaphysical artist whose mysterious, provocative early works, done between 1911 and 1919, foreshadowed much of modern painting.

title: Brooklyn Through English Eyes
description: In 1959 Daniel P. Moynihan dined me at Gage and Toliner on shad roe and bacon (it became an addiction, every year since I've returned in March to eat shad roe) and then walked me around Brooklyn Heights and guided me across the Bridge. I was staggered. Again and again I was hit by the sheer beauty of New York as I had been in the winter of 1944 when I first saw Manhattan from the deck of the Queen Mary. True, the downtown skyline was more beautiful then, the skyscrapers were more elegant, less crowded, but even now who would ever tire of walking as I do, day after day, along the Esplanade and staring and staring across the river. Sharply one realizes how waterborne New York is, a Venice of the Atlantic, no more American than Venice is Italian; cosmopolitan, moneyhaunted, the weirdest city in the world, the only one that looks truly of the twentieth century.

title: Signs of a Tourist Revival Cheer Puerto Ricans
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 22 A few signs that the tourist industry In Puerto Rico may be rebounding after a prolonged slump are prompting fresh hope and enthusiasm among government leaders and some hotel men on this Caribbean island.

title: HoweNoll Doubles Victors In U.S. Title Court Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 The local team of Sam Howe, amateur, and Eddie Noll, professional, won the United States open court tennis doubles championship today by 46, 46, 65, 63, 64 from the defending titleholders, Alastair B. Martin and Gene Scott, New York amateurs, at the Racquet Club.

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: To the Editor: The Pontchartrain is one of America's few remaining familyowned and managed hotels and you would have to know my father and me as well as our hotel to fully understand our great distress on reading the column, The Super Weekend, written by Dave Anderson in the Jan. 15 New York Times.

title: Plenty of Water Room Left
description: Of the more than 44 million boatmen in 1971, the number of registered boats totaled just over 8,814,000. This indicates American waterways aren't nearly as crowded as our nation's highways.

title: The Most Wanted Player
description: It's a long way from Barranquilla, Colombia, to 682 Jerome Street, a small frame house next to a junkyard in the East New York section of Brooklyn. It's a longer way from 682 Jerome Street to the Harvard Club.

title: Synthetics Still Being Refined
description: Synthetics, which have virtually pushed natural fibers off boats as far as boatmen are concerned, are still being improved, and the New York Boat Show will see the introduction of refinements in both nylon and Dacron lines.

title: Maureen Quinn Bride Of Frederic Clausen
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 22  St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Maureen Anne Quinn to Frederic King Clausen. The Rev. James P. Sheridan performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Elwood Healy, pastor of St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Collingwood, N. J.

title: HARLEM SIX JURY TO GET CASE SOON
On Weeding Out Needs
description: Weed on the propeller of an outboard motor will cause it to vibrate or cavitate. Run at reduced throttle when weeds are thick. Shift to reverse periodically to clear weeds from the propeller. Clear the propeller completely of weeds before resuming speed in deep water.

title: Exchange Fees Exempted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) The Cost of Living Council announced today that fees charged for trading securities on security exchanges regulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission would be exempted from price controls when the commission certified that the fees were consistent with the economic stabilization program.

title: Agnew Set to Quicken Political Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Vice President Agnew, who has been keeping a rather low profile in recent months, is expected to accelerate his speaking schedule and his thrusts at the Democratic opposition, beginning with the annual Lincoln Day observances in February.

title: PATRICK A. DELUCA, STAMFORD LEADER
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 22Patrick A. Deluca, civic leader and founder and president of the Deluca Construction Company of this city, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived on Starin Drive, Westover Park.

title: Lion's Victim Gets Sum
description: VENTURA, Calif., Jan. 22 (Reuters)Zoltan Hargitay, the 12yearold son of Jayne Mansfield, the late actress, and Mickey Hargitay, actor, has been awarded $10,000 for being mauled by a lion in an amusement park six years ago. The Ventura County Superior Court approved an outofcourt settlement between the boy and the amusement park, Jungleland, now bankrupt.

title: Trim Boat Recommended
description: For best boat and motor performance, a boat should be in trim. Passengers and equipment should be distributed in the boat so that the craft rides evenly balanced, fore and aft and side to side. Stern loading should be favored on planing boats to raise the bow slightly.

title: Miss Proell Wins, Captures Cup Lead
description: ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 22Annemarie Proell of Aus tria flashed over a course made tricky by spots of ice and patches of fog and won the St. Gervais giant slalom today. The victory gave her the lead in the women's World Cup ski standing.

title: GUERRILLA BANDS HARASS COLOMBIA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 22 (AP)Bands of roving guerrillas have begun the new year with a series of terrorist attacks and political harangues to captive audiences.

title: ElectionYear Miracle
description: For decades an accepted verity of politics has been that Congress would never seriously try to curb campaign spending in an election year. The House of Representatives last week happily buried that particular bit of conventional wisdom; it now remains only for President Nixon to sign this major step toward financial decency in the American electoral process.

title: CandyStore Alumni Honor the Boss
description: Back in the nineteenfifties Sheldon Reinish, then known to his friends as Wolfman, and Jack Shamah, who was nicknamed the Mole, hung out with their buddies at Iry and Jack's luncheonette and candy store on Bay Parkway, holding Cokedrinking contests and coming to grips with adolescence.

title: Rev. Allan Chalmers, 74, Dies; Led the Broadway Tabernacle
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 23The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, minister of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle in New York from 1930 to 1948, died here today. He was 74 years old and lived in Kennebunkport.

title: Big Eight to Use Freshmen
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 23 (AP)The Big Eight Conference voted today to make freshmen eligible for varsity competition in football and basketball beginning next season.

title: Seoul Tries to Surpass North
description: SEOUL, South KoreaOfficials here hope that the completion of the national fiveyear economic plan last year will help the country surpass North Korea in almost all fields of the economy, including heavy industry, in which the South is far behind.

title: Canterbury Preaches in St. Patrick's And is Applauded by the Worshipers
description: The Most Rev. Michael Ramsey, 100th Archbishop of Canterbury, warned yesterday of a new division cleaving Christendom.

title: Rev. G. Elson Ruff, Editor Of The Lutheran, Is Dead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23The Rev. G. Elson Ruff, editor since 1945 of The Lutheran, twicemonthly magazine of the Lutheran Church in America, died yesterday at his residence. He was 67 years old.

title: Nixon's SALT Choice
description: President Nixon's latest effort to slow the nuclear weapons race by stepping it up, this time with a new submarine missile system, poses familiar danger. Experience shows that bargaining chips of this kind, instead of being bargained away, tend to pile up and even complicate negotiations. Since the start of the SovietAmerican strategic arms limitation talks (SALT) in 1969, each side has added a hydrogen warhead a day to its arsenal, a total of 800.

title: High Interest Rates Brake Korean Business
description: SEOUL, South Korea Back in 1965, with South Korea shy of funds for economic development, and with inflation rampant, the Government doubled the interest rate on savings to 30 per cent to attract money into banks.

title: Yevtushenko RehearsalNew Vista
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23Yevgeny Aleksandrovich Yevtushenko, the Russian poet, went into rehearsal here today for his poetry spectacular in the Felt Forum of the Madison Square Garden Center in New York on Friday night. The event could draw as many as 10,000 listeners for two performances in that 5,000seat arena.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDONThe Ladies fresh from tea at Fortnum and Mason often wander across Piccadilly Circus for a peek at the exhibits of the Royal Academy of Arts a fortress of solemn tradition that avantgarde artists have long termed ossified and rigidly established. For years the Academy has offered Institutional Art that ranged from dull figurative paintings to dull academic ab stractions.

title: The Conscience of America
description: Citing compelling evidence that serious breaches of the laws of war have been committed by all parties in Indochina, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has urged President Nixon to appoint a national commission to study American observance the laws of war in Indochina.

title: NoFault Poll Results Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23A poll indicating that most automobile accident victims in Massachusetts are unhappy with the state's nofault insurance law has raised a harsh new issue in the spreading nofault controversy.

title: Justice Department, in 1961, Studied Hughes Loan to Nixon Kin
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23In the spring of 1961, the Kennedy Administration studied and discarded the possibility of prosecuting members of the Nixon family or Howard R. Hughes for criminal law violations that might have occurred in the loan of $205,000 from the industrialist to the present President's relatives in late 1956.

title: Bruins, Sabres Tie, 33
description: BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP)Dallas Smith scored on a screen shot from the blue line midway through the final period today as the Boston Bruins salvaged a 33 National Hockey League tie with the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Thailand Misses Yankee Dollar
description: BANGKOK, ThailandThe neon signs on Patpong Road here are bright and beckoning and business in the bars is still good despite the departure of 16,000 American servicemen from Thailand over the last two years. But in country towns like Korat and Takhli and Sattaheap, lights that formerly signaled Drinks and Girls and Special Massage have been switched off. The bars are closed and the massage parlors are empty.

title: DR. MYRON A. GREEN
description: Dr. Myron A. Green, a dentist here for 55 years until his retirement in 1964, who was founder and former president of the Bronx County Dental Society, died yesterday in Lebanon Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 1749 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Hope Is Rising In New Zealand
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand An economic cloud, suspended over New Zealand for more than a decade, was lifted in 1971 with Britain's move toward the European Economic Community. The country still has plenty to Worry about in the year ahead, but one major disaster has been averted.

title: Crusading Forerunner of Women's Lib
description: It was 1916 and young Jeannette Rankin of Missoula, Mont., had no Betty Friedans to tell her that she was enslaved, no consciousnessraising groups to liberate her ego. She just knew there was something wrong with the way society was treating its women, so she did the boldest thing she could think of: She ran for the House of Representatives and won in a victory that ended the male monopoly in Congress.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Breed of Easy Riders Roars In
description: The new breed of leather boys will be spinning their wheels tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the second Yamaha Silver Cup motorcycle races will be staged over the concrete floor.

title: McCloskey Resuming Drive
description: KEENE, N.H., Jan. 23 (AP) Representative Paul N. McCloskey, Jr., Republican of California, is to resume his New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign here, tomorrow, after suspending it for the weekend when he came down with the flu.

title: Ousted Teacher Stays at Post
description: STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 23 (UPI)Prof. H. Bruce Franklin, dismissed for allegedly fomenting campus violence, said today that he would continue to teach at Stanford University while appealing his dismissal. The 37yearold revolutionary, an associate professor of English, was ousted yesterday by a 20to2 vote of the Stanford Trustees.

title: Recruits From Junior Colleges Do AboutFace for Minnesota
description: While many college coaches continue to debate the validity of the new rule that permits the use of freshmen for varsity competition, score another plus for junior college recruiting as a provider of instant help. Ron Behagen, Clyde Turner and Bob Knix, all junfor college transfers, have done wonders for Minnesota, a usual Big Ten college basketball patsy.

title: Singapore Markets Labor
description: SINGAPORE  This small island state with no natural resources except the vigor of its 2.1 million people gave increased attention In 1971 to the question of raising the technical skill of its labor force to attract more highly sophisticated industries.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 23  Irreverent thought at the ceremony celebrating the signing of the Treaty of Brussels: How much better they would have done it in Londonthe people who manage Trooping the Color or put on state funerals. There would have been sable and silver instead of the dreary modernity of this conference hall, with its walls of genuine veneer and its orangecovered pedestal chairs.

title: Peking's Delegates at U.N. Call In Translators for Criticism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23 A number of the United Nations Chinese translators are shaken over an incident in which Peking's delegates criticized their work and advised them to improve it.

title: Brydges Skeptical That Wyman Could Win State Senate Support
description: Earl W. Brydges, the State Senate majority leader, indicated yesterday that the chances were dim that the Senate would support, the reappointment of George K. Wyman es Commissioner of Social Services.

title: Tenants in City to Get Rent Increase Notices
description: Tenants of the city's 1.2 million rentcontrolled apartments will start getting this weekahe first notices for rent increasesup to 71/2 per cent and mostly retroactive to Jan. 1 under the city's maximum base rent system. The mailings will go on for about six weeks, and the increases will be collectible with the next month's rent. Benjamin Altman, Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner, said yesterday that no increase had been granted unless the owner certified that all serious or rentimpairing violations had been corrected as well as 80 per cent of other violations outstanding Jan. 1 under the Housing Code.

title: Wallace Bars Debate With Lindsay for Now
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that he had not made up his mind whether to accept Mayor Lindsay's challenge for a onehour, mantoman debate before the March 14 Florida primary.

title: India Determined To Remain Viable
description: NEW DELHIWhen Prime Minister Indira Gandhi says defiantly that her country can live without foreign aid, what she probably means is that for the present, India can withstand the recent cutoff of dollars, marks and yen.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Russian seaman with terminal cancer, en route to the United States for a flight back to the Soviet Union, died at sea yesterday three hours before his ship was to have met Coast Guard cutter at the entrance to New York Harbor.

title: City Hall Notes
description: The men who sit around the horseshoeshaped table in the Board of Estimate chamber during public sessions and cross examine scores of city officials and other supplicants for city funds, are seldom members of the board. The board members meet in private on the eve of the public sessions to work out votes that are rarely changed by the aides who sit in for them at the biweekly public meetings.

title: British Unit Should Go, Paper in Rhodesia Says
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan, 23 (Agence FrancePresse)Britain's Pearce Commission, testing acceptability of the BritishRhodesian settlement that would increase the blacks political rights, should return home, The Sunday Mail said here today.

title: $ 1Million Experiment at School in Houston, With Communication the Key, Aims at Making Integration Work
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 23The Abraham Lincoln Junior and Senior High School had representative Henry B. Gonzalez over for a recent fiesta.

title: JOHN H. KRAFT DIES; FOOD CONCERN HEAD
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (UPI)John H. Kraft, a founder of Kraft Foods, died last night at home near here. He was 80 years old.

title: SCOTS GUARDS WIN CHEERS AT GARDEN
description: The Scots Guards came to New York over the weekend receiving loud cheers inside the Felt Forum and just as vocal jeers outside from pickets protesting the British regiment's role in Northern Island.

title: Point of View
description: TOKYOLast November Tokyo department store put 21 race horses on sale at a nearby vacant lot and sold eight of them at prices averaging $15,000 apiece.

title: But Federal Reserve Is Likely to Try to Hold Markets Steady
description: The bond market, which last week had its worst setback since September, now pessimistically believes that interest rates are headed higher.

title: Pfizer Unit Elects
description: Robert D. Royer has been elected chairman and president of Pfizer International. Formerly a vice president of the parent company and execuitive vice president of the international operations, he succeeds Byran R. Carmichael, who has resigned. The latter becomes president of WarnerLambert International and a senior vice president of WarnerLambert Company, the parent organization.

title: Greek ExAide, Out of Jail and Ill, Scorns Regime
description: ATHENS, Jan. 23The most prominent political prisoner in Greece was granted a oneyear interruption of his fourandahalfyear sentence yesterday to try to regain his broken health.

title: Destruction of 2 Enemy Gun Sites in DMZ by U.S. F4's Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 (AP)United States fighterbombers knocked out two enemy antiaircraft guns and damaged another in strikes inside the demilitarized zone yesterday, the United States command announced today.

title: 11 Rightists Arrested at Hotel
description: TOKYO, Jan. 23 (AP)Policemen arrested 11 Japanese rightists today when they tried to storm into a downtown hotel where Foreign Minister Gromyko was staying. The Japanese Foreign Ministry said that Mr. Gromyko and his wife, already in bed for the night, had been unaware of the incident.

title: Engagements
description: FRASERGROSEThe engagement is announced between Simon Fraser, Master of Lovat, and Virginia, daughter of Mr. & Mrs. David Grose, of 49 Elystan Street, London, SW3.

title: Illness Triggers Many Changes In Cast of Met's Meistersinger
description: Given an onslaught of influenza and other maladies to which opera performers are prone, the announced lineup for the Metropolitan Opera's performance of Wagner's Die Meistersinger on Saturday night underwent several unexpected changes. The net result was that Ignace Strasfogel conducted the work for the first time (replacing Thomas Schlppers), Rudolf Knoll took the part of Beckmesser for the first time with the company, Paul Franke sang his first Vogelgesang, and first appearances of the season in the work were made by Mildred Miller (Magdalene), Charles Anthony (David) and John Macurdy (Pogner).

title: COST OF SECRECY TO U.S. ESTIMATED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The staff of the House subcommittee on Foreign Operations and Government Information has been told that the cost to the taxpayers of Government secretkeeping runs $60million to $80million a year.

title: NEW RADAR LINK GUARDS 3 COASTS
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  A new radar network designed to detect the launching and the point of impact of ballistic missiles fired from submarines is now being operated on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts.

title: How Kuala Lumpur Avoids Rat Race
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia The capital of Malaysia, is belatedly about to become a city, but visitors who have been captivated by its rural charm should not be unduly alarmed. The transition will be a nominal one and will not immediately produce any significant changes within the capital or in the lives of its halfmillion inhabitants.

title: Saigon: Withdrawal Pains
description: SAIGON, South VietnamFor the Americans in Vietnam, 1971 was the year that American troop strength began to show the effects of withdrawal  down from 337,000 to fewer than 160,000 at the end of the year.

title: Miss Lillian Kahan Wed to Avram Stein
description: Miss Lillian o. Kahan and Avram Stein were married last evening in the Grand Ballroom of the Roosevelt. Rabbi Sherman Siff performed the ceremony and Rabbi Joseph Tirnauer assisted.

title: Inflation and Job Loss in Australia
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaYou can bank on Australia, said fullpage advertisements inserted by Australia's largest private bank in newspapers throughout the country during Christmas week.

title: More Federal Funds Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The National Association of Educational Broadcasters has asked for greatly increased Federal support of public educational radio and television.

title: An Appraisal
description: Not exactly buried in the Federal budget being introduced by President Nixon today is a $126,108,000 item for the country's largest and most controversial building projectthe new headquarters for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, It is hard to bury a building occupying 2,535,000 square feet and an entire block of Pennsylvania Avenue, even though three stories of it are underground and the sign on the site identifies it only as anonymous Federal construction. Eleven stories and 160 feet more of the building are now rising between 9th and 10th Streets, opposite the Justice Department and the Federal Triangle and back to E Street, for the avenue's most conspicuous monument since the Federal Triangle was constructed.

title: JOHN J. COADY
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 23John J. Coady, who retired last year as manager of the New York office of the Security Insurance Group of Hartford, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 66.

title: Pope Says Drive for Unity Of Christians Hasn't Halted
description: ROME, Jan. 23Pope Paul VI said today that the drive for Christian unity had not come to a halt. Perhaps the drive for a superficial, sentimental ecumenism has, the Pope told a crowd in St. Peter's Square in an address before giving his customary Sunday blessing, but not that of an ecumenism based on sincere research and on common prayer.

title: G.M: TIRE BRAND: IDEA IS EXPLORED
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23The General Motors Corporation is actively considering putting its own name brand tires on automobiles.

title: Man In the News
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23When he was a graduate student of economics at Harvard University after World War II, Aziz Sidky, Egypt's new Premier; wrote a doctoral dissertation on what then seemed an improbable theme the prospects for industrial transformation of his poor and predominantly agricult ural homeland. Dr. Sidky returned to Egypt in 1951, a year before the revolution against King Farouk, to accept a teaching post at the University of Alexandria. Two years later he joined the revolutionary regime as a planning adviser in the Premier's office. His vision of an industrialized Egypt quickly attracted the attention of Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, who was eager to free Egypt of foreign economic control and to make the country a self  sufficient Industrial power.

title: Canadiens Tie Penguins, 3 to 3, On Lemaire Goal in 3d Period
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (AP)A powerplay goal by Jacques Lemaire, hooked through a welter of bodies lying in the goal crease, gave the Montreal Canadiens a 33 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Point of View
description: DURING most of this century a little advertised but vital link between this country and Japan has been the use by Japanese trading companies of the commodity futures markets in New York and Chicago. Knowledgeable traders have used the futures markets in such commodities as wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans, sugar and metals to hedge their commitments.

title: Container Port For Singapore
description: SINGAPORE  Chinese here like to recount that, when a young British naval officer named Stamford Raffles was exploring the tip of the Malay Peninsula in January, 1819, it was a certain Choa Ahchee, a carpenter from China, who led the first landing party and reported back on the friendliness of the natives and the suitability, of the site as a trading port.

title: 5 Ski Jumpers Selected For U.S. Olympic Squad
description: LEAVENWORTH, Wash., Jan. 23 (UPI)Five men who will represent the United States in ski jumping competition at the Winter Olympics in Sapporo, Japan, next month were chosen during competition yesterday.

title: The Key to Dining Out in New Orleans: Ignore Menu and Listen to Waiter
description: NEW ORLEANS  Travelers to Paris can decide where to eat by simply consulting the Guide Michelin, which classes the city's restaurants in an orderly threestar system. But New Orleans, which once was a French city, cannot be systematized. Its better restaurants, bastions of a great regional cuisine, rise and fall like soufflds.

title: Magazine's Description
description: A description of the woman who gave her name as Helga Hughes appears in this week's issue of Time magazine. It also describes her as a blonde, and adds that the woman later withdrew the money from the bank.

title: Point of View
description: AS a new era in SinoAmerican relations dawns, the United States businessman who hopes to trade with the Peoples Republic of China must bear in mind that Peking is not just another version of Main Street with pagodas. There are considerable differences in the history, culture and perspective of the two societies; the traveler or trader, on either side, who does not recognize and understand these differences will be severely handicapped.

title: Woman, Black and Student: All Directors of Philadelphia Bank
description: When the board of directors of the First Pennsylvania Corporation meets on Thursday in the City of Brotherly Love, three of the plush chairs around the table will be filled by individuals whose presence might raise a few eyebrows at other major publiclyowned companies.

title: Eurobond Market Slows as Currency Doubts Begin to Revive
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 23Under the double weight of renewed whispers of currency unrest and a lessthan distinguished newissue calendar, the straight dollar Eurobond market is calming considerably.

title: Aborigines of Australia Are Suddenly Militants
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 23 The sudden emergence of a militant blackpower movement among dissatisfied young aborigines is stirring Australia.

title: RYEN WINS AGAIN IN SKI JUMPING
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 23The king of the ski jumping hill here is 21yearold Thorbjorn Ryen of Staten Island, who won his sixth straight tournament and second jumpoff honor today to remain unbeaten this year.

title: FLORIDIANS LOSE TO NETS BY 116105
description: MIAMI, Jan. 23Rick Barry and Billy Paultz combined for 21 points in the fourth quarter to help the Nets pull away from the Floridians tonight for a 116105 victory. Barry made 10 and Paultz 11.

title: KENNEDY STATUS AN OREGON ISSUE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 23In 22 of the 23 Presidential primary states, as things now stand, Senator Edward M. Kennedy's name will be missing from the ballot because he intends to file affidavits of noncandidacy.

title: III Lucchesi Satisfactory
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Jan. 23 (UPI)Frank Lucchesi, manager of the Philadelphia, Phillies was reported in satisfactory condition at Mills Memorial Hospital today after he suffered what doctors called a slight touch of pneumonia.

title: Neighbors Fight Hospitals Expansion
description: Neighbors of bedpan alley their name for the string of hospital complexes in lower Manhattanare banding together to coordinate campaigns against the plans of the hospitals to demolish apartment buildings for staff housing projects and parking lots.

title: 2 Hurt in Escape Attempt
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 23 (AP)  One prisoner was wounded by guards gunfire and another apparently stabbed by other inmates today during an unsuccessful escape attempt at Ohio Penitentiary,

title: North Korea Said to Do Well
description: TOKYOThe economy of North Korea made considerable progress during 1971, according to diplomatic sources in Tokyo.

title: Buckley, in Taipei, Hails Nationalist Fortitude
