description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 23Senator James L. Buckley of New York, addressing 15,000 people at a World Freedom Day rally here, congratulated the Chinese Nationalists today for what he called the fortitude and resolve they have shown since their expulsion from the United Nations.

title: New New Boat Show is in the Works For Fall at World's Fair Marina
description: With unexpected mild weather and huge crowds, as expected, at the National Boat Show yesterday, it was hardly a surprise when the sponsors of the show announced a new outdoor, Inthewater National Boat Show for next October.

title: MANSFIELD URGING WIDER PEACE TALK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, called today for enlargement of the Vietnam peace talks to include the problems of Laos and Cambodia and suggested that the talks be held at some place closer to Southeast Asia than Paris.

title: PETTY CAPTURES STOCK CAR RACE
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 23Richard Petty got the 1972 stockcar season off to a stirring start today by winning the Winston Western 500or, as it turned out because of the fog, the Winston Western 390.38on the road course of Riverside International Raceway. He drove a 1972 Plymouth.

title: Japan Enters New Era
description: TOKYO  The Japanese economy In 1971 divided neatly into two partsthat before Aug. 15 and that after. The Japanese economy for 1972, in the words of a Japanese banker, is harder to predict than the weather.

title: KARNIK KEVORKIAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23Karnik Kevorkian, who edited and published the Armenianlanguage weekly newspaper Groong here from 1919 to 1962, died today in Haverford Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Drexel Hill.

title: Miss Wellborn Wed to Officer
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 23Miss Maxine Bethune Wellborn, daughter of Mrs. William Bethune Wellborn and the late Mr. Wellborn, was married here last evening to Lieut. Comdr. Robert H. Shaw Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. Shaw of Falls Church, Va., and the late Mrs. Shaw. The Rev. Dr. Wilson Sneed performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: TRADE SUGGESTED IN CITY POWERS
description: A tradeoff  extra executive powers for the Borough Presidents in exchange for the transfer of their budgetary power to the City Councilhas been suggested as part of the current political ferment over restructuring of the city government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your issue of Dec. 30 carried an OpEd article by Conor Cruise O'Brien captioned The Right to Secede. Permit me to refer to the opening paragraph of this article.

title: PRECISION SHOWN BY YOUNG MEZZO
description: Presiding over a concert of rarely heard vocalchamber pieces at Town Hall Saturday afternoon, Susan ReidParsons proved to be both a versatile singer and an intelligent mu sician. The young mezzo already has impressive technical resources at her command her production is secure over the full range, her intonation is precise, her diction goodand if she has yet to open up completely as an interpretive artist, the husky, naturally expressive beauty of her voice was reason enough to enjoy her program.

title: Advertising:
description: Bob Dolobowsky has bought out his partners in Warren, Muller, Dolobowsky.

title: Afghan Floods Kill Five
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 23 (AP)About 1,200 houses were washed away, at least five persons were killed and thousands of cattle perished in Farah, 500 miles southwest of here, in heavy floods last Thursday, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Cunningham Quits. Post At Chicago Art Institute
description: Charles C. Cunningham, director of the Art Institutb of Chicago since 1966, has resigned, effective Aug. 31, 1972. He is the third director to resign from a major museum in the last six weeks.

title: Bullets Rout Royals
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 (UPI)Nate Archibald scored 28 points, Archie Clarke 26 and Stan Love 23 tonight as the Baltimore Bullets trounced the Cincinnati Royals, 132101.

title: MOUNTED TROT WON BY TIDALIUM PELO
description: PARIS, Jan. 23  Tidalium Plo, carrying a jockey on his back, today won the world championship of mounted trotting at Vincennes.

title: Grornyko, in Tokyo, Voices Hope for Closer Relations
description: TOKYO, Jan. 23Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived in Tokyo today for consultations and expressed hope for furthering friendly relations between Japan and the Soviet Union.

title: Point of View
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong's zesty, exportoriented economy continued to grow in 1971 but jolting developments affecting the colony's world trade caused a moderate slowdown that seemed likely to carry on into 1972.

title: Coalition Starts Drive to Bar TakeOver of City U. by State
description: A coalition of community groups began a drive yesterday to thwart a proposed takeover of the City University by the state and an increase in public college tuition.

title: Asian Nations Seek SelfReliance
description: HONG KONGBuffeted by strong and unexpected winds of change in 1971, the nations of Asia found an anchor in the theme of selfreliance. Adam Malik, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, spoke for many countries wnen he said: We must rely on ourselves to develop our country.

title: A.F.C. Stars Win, 2613, in Pro Bowl
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (AP)Jan Stenerud, the Kansas City Chief's placekicker and the goat of pro football's longest game last month, kicked four field goals today as the American Conference AllStars beat the National Conference, 26.13, in the 22d annual National Football League Pro Bowl.

title: Bengalis Land a Vast Cemetery
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 23 On this graveyard, we shall build our golden Bengal. So reads a cardboard sign hung on a flagpole in the city of Khulna.

title: MOST COMMUNITIES IN JERSEY FACING SCHOOLAID LOSS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23More than half of New Jersey's 567 communities face the loss of $100million or more in state school aid under a court order striking down the state's system of financing publicschool education.

title: NEW BROKER FEES TO GO INTO EFFECT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Government gave the final goahead over the weekend to the longplanned change in sales commissions on stock transactions, but the new schedule of commissions will probably not go into effect before about March 1.

title: Nearly 100 India Deaths Laid to Drink at Party
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 (AP) Nearly 100 people were reported to have died over the weekend of bootlegged liquor they drank at a wedding party.

title: College Study Ties Student Aid To Parents Lifetime Earnings
description: Parents future lifetime earnings, as well as their current income, should help determine how much financial aid college students need, a special study panel appointed by the College Entrance Examination Board has recommended.

title: Swiss Police Hunt A Woman as Link To Hughes Checks
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Monday, Jan. 24A warrant has gone out for a Helga Hughes, described as a 31yearold, slim brunette with hair down to her shoulders, in connection with $650,000 in bank deposits in the Howard Hughes  McGrawHill affair, the Zurich Canton police said this morning.

title: Mrs. Louis Aronson Is Dead; Widow of Ronson's Founder
description: Mrs. Mabel Brownell Aronson, widow of Louis V. Aronson, the inventor of lighters who founded the Ronson Corporation, died yesterday at her apartment in the Drake Hotel. She was 88 years old.

title: Two Pirates Signed for 72
description: PITTSBURGH, Jam 23 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates have signed Jose Pagan and Luke Walker to 1972 contracts, the club announced today. Pagan batted 241 in 57 games last season and Walker won 10 games and lost 8.

title: Housing: A Worldwide Scarcity
description: WHILE achieving exceptional economic growth through recent years, Japan has also developed a housing shortage estimated at several million officially units.

title: The Return of a Native I:
description: BERKELEY, Calif.An American returning to China after 26 years comes with different eyes. Absent since before the Communists won the country, he cannot but remember China as used to be.

title: Panama's Leader Worries U.S. With Warning on Canal Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the National Guard commander who controls Panama, has privately warned the United States that he intends to publish in the next few days details of the deadlocked negotiations on a new canal treaty.

title: James Clawson Roop Dies at 84; Former U. S. Budget Director
description: James Clawson Roop, director of the budget under President Hoover and later treasurer and vice president of Pan American Airways, died yesterday in a Fairfield, Conn., nursing home. He was 84 years old and had lived for many years in New Canaan, Conn., where he had been vice president of the Planning Commission.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERBenjamin, on January 23, 1972, beloved husband of Rose, devoted father of Kermit, Barbara ingber and Carol Alpert; loving grandfather. Services Monday, P. M. The Riverside Westchester, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, N. Y.ANTHONMay, on Jan. 22, 1972, beloved sister of Elsie Anthon. Friends may call at the Universal Chapel, 52d St. and Lexington Ave., Monday, Jan. 24, 1972. A funeral mass will be offered at St. Paul The Apostle Church, 9th Ave. and 59th St., New York City, at 11 A.M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, 1 P.M., Tuesday.ANZALONEEmella, on Jan. 21, 1972, beloved wife of the late Antonio (Founder of of Seagoing Uniform Corp.), devoted mother of Margaret Delle, Donne, Mark, Eunice Mirenda, Carmela Maceroli, Anthony, Louis & Helen, also survived by eight grandchildren and 13 greatgrandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Anselm's R. C. Church, Tuesday, 9:30 A.M. intombment Holy Cross Cemetery. Reposing at her residence, 8220 Narrows Ave. DIRECTOR A. Vigilante & Sons.

title: BARBER GAINS TIE IN GOLF WITH A 65
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 23 George Archer, who says he doesn't like 18hole playoffs in golf, found himself in another one today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor; I was very much interested in your recent editorial concerning Federal waterpollution control legislation. I completely agree with the main point of the editorial, namely, that this legislation should not be made a political football.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 15 editorial Time to Ring Off was a continuation of The Times biased position throughout the long New York Telephone strike. You are highly critical of the actions of the frustrated strikers, but never mention the provocation by New York Telephone management.

title: How to Get Along: Sony and CBS
description: TOKYOAmerican and Japanese companies can be good partners in Japan only if they take into account the exceptional local conditions, or so runs the rule at the Sony Corporation, one of the most dynamic Japanese companies of the postwar era.

title: News Analysis
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 23Superficially, it was a time of paradox in Rhodesia.

title: Point of View
description: TOKYOA marked decline in export and domestic ship contracts in 1971 brought about by the revaluation of the yen and a sagging trend is threatening Japan's leadership in the world's shipbuilding.

title: Point of View
description: WASHINGTON  In September of 1971, Prime Minister In dria Gandhi of India announced that her Government did not plan to import any grain from the United States in 1972. Indeed, India was in the embarrassing position of not being able to take all of the wheat requested of the United States early in 1971 under its food aid program. For those accustomed to thinking of India as eternally dependent on food imports, the notion that she might be hovering on the brink of cereal selfsufficiency comes as a surprise if not a shock.

title: A Camp That's a Home Away From Home
description: MOUNT TREMPER, N. Y.,  Adam Galef is an 11yearold with a pixie face and a slender, alwaysinmotion body. Ask him what he'd like to be when he grows up and, without a second's hesitation, he answers that he'll become a great skier.

title: South Pole Greetings
description: SOUTH POLE STATION, Antarctica Here at the bottom of the world the experts of thirteen nations are busily cooperating in a project designed for the benefit of all mankind.

title: PIANIST AND FLUTIST SHARE A PROGRAM
description: Two promising young talents, Daniel Hill (piano) and Patricia Spencer (flute), shared a program in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night. Mr. Hill led off his half of the proceedings with Copland's Piano Variations, which he played with splashy yet ironfirm technique, warm tone and a good sense of the work's special sonority.

title: Higueras Wins Tennis Final
description: FREEPORT, Bahamas, Jan. 23Topseeded Jose Higueras of Spain defeated his countryman, Jos Moreno, today in the final of the Lucayan Towers international junior tennis tourney. The scores were 86, 64. Higueras and Moreno won the doubles, defeating Aeon Joubert and Bernie Mitton, 64, 61 63.

title: Bangladesh: The Birth of a Nation
description: BOMBAY, India  The question bothering many economists and political analysts, both in and out of government, now is just how much money and effort it is going to take to build a new nation from scratch and then keep it alive and healthy.

title: Hawks Maravich Pours In 35 To Help Defeat Bucks, 118113
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Pete Maravich and Lou Hudson combined for 66 points today to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 118113 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: RyunKeino Mile SubOlympian
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 Jim Ryun may be on his way back, but his first victory of 1972 was something less than Olympian.

title: EGYPT'S PREMIER PEACES ECONOMY ON A WAR FOOTING
description: Egypt's Home Front Is Placed On a War Footing by Premier ness to meet with the students after their threeweek semesterend vacation, a sitin was continuing at Cairo University.

title: Sunrise in Ovamboland
description: South Africa's grip on SouthWest Africa (Namibia) has been shaken by an unexpected and unprecedented event that is certain to affect the course of Prime Minister Vorster's separate development policy. More than 13,000 Ovambo workers in the developed white area struck last month against a contractlabor system they called a form of slavery. They halted the vital coppermining industry, paralyzed commerce and crippled public services in the capital of Windhoek.

title: Barker, Brent and Reiner Are Victors in State Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 23Rod Brent, Bob Barker and Gary Reiner led the advance of favorites at the start of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: Presbytery Starts Drive To Help the Needy Here
description: The Rev. David Denison Cockcroft, new Moderator of the Presbytery of New York City, announced yesterday that the body had opened a oneyear, $4million fundraising campaign to help provide housing and social services to underprivileged New Yorkers.

title: Soviet Releases Compiler Of White Book on Writers
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  Aleksandr Ginzburg, sentenced in 1968 for antiSoviet activities, returned to Moscow yesterday after completing his fiveyear term, his friends reported. Mr. Ginzburg's sentence, began with the date of his arrest in 1967.

title: Driverless Snowmobile Kills Boy, Hurts 4 Fans
description: EAGLE RIVER, Wis., Jan. 23 (AP)A snowmobile went out of control, crashed through a fence and killed a 6yearold boy during the Eagle River World Series Snowmobile Derby today.

title: HOUSING AID SEEN FOR ELDERLY HERE
description: A legislative conference on problems of middleincome housing heard a forecast yesterday that state legislation was likely this year to cut rents or carrying charges for poor older citizens by increasing tax abatement on their apartments, to 100 per cent.

title: Hard Road Ahead For Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistanas a defeated and demoralized nation; what had been West and East Pakistan had become two separate countries, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG, METREVELI SCORE
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 23 (UPI)Evonne Goolagong of Australia and Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union captured the singles titles today in the South Australian tennis championships.

title: Chess: Zaitsev, Soviet Grandmaster, Is Dead at the Age of 36
description: Word has been received of the unexpected death of the Soviet grandmaster Alexander Zaitsev. He was 36 years old.

title: Biharis Begin to Leave Big Bengali Jute Mill
description: NARAYANGANJ, Pakistan, Jan. 23 (AP)Thirty thousand Biharis, beleaguered for more than a month in the world's largest jute mill here, began moving out this weekend under police and Indian Army protection.

title: Search Goes On for Three Who Shot Trenton Policemen
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23Extra crews of policemen were on duty today in the search for three young men who wounded two Trenton policemen in a gun battle last night.

title: Red Wings Beat Blues
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UPI)Third  period goals by Guy Charron, Al Karlander and Red Berenson led the Detroit Red Wings to a 31 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: Sports of The Times
description: They were fishing Toledo Bend, an 85mile lake created by damming the Sabine River on the LouisianaTexas border, and the man driving the boat wore a bruise the sin of a dinner plate on his belly.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The present controversy over who is to blame for bankruptcy of New York's system of justice may bemuse the city's besieged citizenry, but it will bring them small solace. Those who have spent considerable time and effort in this particular vineyard hear a longfamiliar sound of fury, signifying little or nothing.

title: One Killed, 7 Injured in 5 Fires; One Blaze Arson, 2 Suspicioul
description: One man was killed and six fireman and a resident in one of the buildings were injured yesterday in five fires. Two of the blazes were labeled suspicious by fire officials and another was called arson.

title: Israel Delays Acceptance
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23Premier Golda Meir today delayed Israel's official acceptance of an American peace initiative for at least a week, while her diplomatic aides iron nut the precise wording of understandings between the United States and Israel about the negotiating procedures to be followed.

title: READING MACHINE IS CITED IN HOAX
description: The city's Consumer Affairs Department charged yesterday that a New Jersey sales concern had sold $400 teaching machines to scores of Roman Catholic parents here over the last two years by exploiting fears for their children's success in school and using fraudulently obtained testimonials from priests and nuns.

title: Nassau Delays Americans In an Apparent Reprisal
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 23 (Routers)Some 200 American tourists were delayed nearly three hours last night at Nassau International Airport in what was believed to be a reprisal by a Bahamas Government minister who had been searched by United States customs officials in Miami.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 23 (AP)Topseeded Onny Parun of New Zealand defeated Steve Faulk of Madisonville, La., 36, 76, 6.3, 76 today in the final of the New Zealand tennis championships.

title: TEXTILE PRICE RISES MAY GAIN APPROVAL
description: The head of the food and textile division of the Price Commission, Burton French, has authorized apparel manufacturers to increase their prices above present authorized levels for merchandise to be delivered after April 1 when such price increases can be justified on the basis of anticipated cost increases.

title: Laos on Edge of Uncertainty
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  This country has seen wars come and go, but it seems that the fighting, in some form, will continue for a long time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 4 editorial Hostages in Hanoi unfortunately added to the superficiality characteristic of much comment on the P.O.W. issue. Apart from the merits of political figures, it is vital to an understanding of what is at stake for the victims that difficulties which the North Vietnamese and many Americans choose to ignore be understood and considered.

title: Congressman Accuses Peking's U.N. Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (Reuters)China's delegation to the United Nations was accused today of threatening and intimidating Chinese members of the Secretariat.

title: Indonesia's Black Gold
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia The large stuffed tiger that stands outside the office of Lieut. Gen. Ibnu Sutowo, head of Pertamina, the stateowned oil enterprise, is a fitting symbol for the man who has put a tiger into the tank of Indonesia's economy.

title: U.S. AGENCY BARS WHARFAGE FEES
description: The Federal Maritime Commission has ruled against proposed charges for wharfage and cargohandling that would have cost shippers to the Port of New York an additional $4 a ton.

title: ROCKETS DEFEAT PISTONS, 109107
description: today which brougnt the Houston Rockets a 109107 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: A Japanese School In Australia
description: SYDNEY  An Australian journalist back home in Sydney after a threeyear assignment in Tokyo was recently surprised to find himself in a railroad car with a large party of chattering Japanese children, immaculately dressed in the blue and white uniforms that are standard wear for students in Japan.

title: ADAM F. LONG DIES; EXNEWSMAN 73
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 23Adam F. Long, a veteran newspaper man, who retired as a rewrite man from The New York Times in 1965, died today at his home, 27 Montfort Road. His age was 73.

title: Brain Drain Hits Manila
description: MANILAThe bonds existing between many people here and the United States are increasingly manifested in the steady flow of Filipino emigrants to the United States, many of them professionally skilled.

title: Reese Turns Back Poor
description: RYE, N. Y. Jan. 23John Reese of New York, the national champion, won the 30th annual Apawamis Club invitation squash racquets tournament today by beating Tom Poor of Boston, 1510, 1510, 156, in the final.

title: Black Hawks Win, 40
description: Black Hawks Win, 40

title: Train Derailed in Oklahoma
description: GUTHRIE, Okla., Jan. 23 (UPI)Twentyone cars of a Santa Fe Railroad freight train derailed one and a half miles south of here shortly before noon today. Railroad officials said there were no injuries. No cause of the derailment was given.

title: CONVICTION RATE REPORTED HIGHER
description: A report that 95 per cent of the Federal indictments here result in convictions was issued yesterday by United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.

title: Stars Down Kings, 53
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 23 (AP)The Minnesota North Stars extended their domination over the Los Angeles Kings to 12 straight games tonight by scoring a 53 victory.

title: Mongolia Stresses Soviet Ties
description: MOSCOWThe Mongolian Peoples Republic, as Outer Mongolia is officially known, harvested a record grain crop last year, but the mainstay of the nation's economy stockherding fell short of expectations.

title: ValueAdded Tax? An Advocate Gives A Few Arguments
description: The adoption in the United States of a valueadded tax may shortly become both economically sound and politically salable, according to a leading taxation specialist and proponent of the valueadded levy.

title: $40 Billion of Red Ink
description: Secretary of the Treasury Connally has told an audience of businessmen that, instead of criticizing the deficit of nearly $40 billion in the current Federal budget, you ought to be applauding it. His argument was that the Government needs to supply some fiscal stimulus when there are five million people unemployed.

title: B.B.C. Also Loser in Mile
description: LOS ANGELES Jan. 23 (UPI) A British Broadcasting Corporation film crew reported today that a film they shot of last night's Jim RyunKip Keino mile race was stolen. They called the footage priceless.

title: More Accord Than Split
description: The towering irony in the demeaning personal feud between Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller is that, basically, they agree on the essentials of governmental reform. Having wrestled separately with many of the same problems, the Mayor at City Hall and the Governor at Albany, they come away with remarkably similar recommendations for achieving solutions.

title: Nepal in Search of an Identity
description: KATMANDU, Nepal Visitors to this remote kingdom nestled in the Himalayas come away with the feeling that Nepal is going through an identity crisis.

title: ST. JOHN'S WINS FROM VILLANOVA
description: Richie Lyons, who missed his first five shots and hit on only three of 11 tries yesterday, made his third successful shot one of the biggest of his career as he scored from 20 feet out with three seconds remaining to give St. John's a 7169 victory over Villanova.

title: Businessmen Hopeful
description: KARACHI, PakistanBusinessmen are not unoptimistic about finding alternative markets for their manufactured goods and raw materials that were once exported to East Pakistan, and making adjustments in their import requirements of goods that used to come from there. The changeover should not be too painful.

title: Point of View
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The political setbacks of 1971 do not appear to have ruffled Taiwan, but the surface calm masks an uneasiness about the future of the Chinese Nationalistheld island.

title: Dance: LouisNikolais
description: FOREPLAY (World Premiere). Choreography, sound score, costumes and lighting design, Alwin Nikolais. Presented by the Nikolais Dance Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. With Richard Ammon, Lisbeth Beanoid, Rob Esposito, Bill Groves, Lynn Levine, Suzanne McDemield, Gerald Otte, Anne Marie Mower, Karen Gladys Roman, James Teeters and Fred Timm.One and one can occasionally make more than two. The combination at the Brooklyn Academy of Music of the Murray Louis Dance Company and the Nikolais Dance Theater is most potent. The two companies together  and the Louis is historically derived from the Nikolais  do offer a dance balance that is most rewarding.

title: Reforming the Legislature
description: Stephen Solarz, a young Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn, is growing old with frustration in his battle to get legislative procedural changes adopted Albany. Undaunted, he plans to renew his efforts by introducing a series of reform resolutions today.

title: Foe Consolidates Gain
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Communist forces have begun moving tanks and trucks along Route 7 from the Plaine des Jarres to the key road junction of Phou Khoun, about 110 miles north of here, military sources said today.

title: Joan Vanderbeck Bride of Robert Viau
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 23 Miss Joan Diane Vanderbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Vanderbeck, was married here this afternoon to Robert Paul Viau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Viau of Central Falls, R. I. The Rev. Mary Greene, a Congregational minister, and the Rev. Gary Balcom, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Amid Crime, Guard Industry Thrives
description: The large American city has become like an armed camp. Shopkeepers and ordinary citizens fight gun duels with holdup men and intruders in their homes. The streets are empty at night, cab drivers huddle behind bulletproof shields, and some of the world's largest corporations protect their property and employes as though they were under siege.

title: Books of The Times
description: ZOO. OR LETTERS NOT ABOUT LOVE. By Viktor Sliftloyalty. Edited and translated from the Russian by Richard Sheldon. 152 pages. Cornell University Press. $7.95.

title: STEWART CAPTURES GRAND PRIX OPENER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23 (AP) Jackie Stewart of Scotland, leading all the way in a TyrrellFord, won the Argentine Grand Prix for Formula One cars. The 197mile race was the first competition of the 12race 1972 Grand Prix season.

title: Environmentalists Meet To Seek Unity in Politics
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23More than 300 representatives of the state's leading environmental groups met here this weekend to forge a unified political weapon out of what have been diverse interests.

title: WATERFRONT GROUP BACKED ON LICENSING
description: The Waterfront Commission has disclosed that the Appellate Division in Manhattan had unanimously upheld the action of the commission in denying a license to a waterfront company because of its associations with organized crime.

title: AllTatar Show Hit in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23Moscow has been playing host to a songanddance ensemble from the Soviet Union's Tatar Republic, and the city's Tatar community has been flocking to its performances.

title: 13 MORE ARRESTED IN MARINE PROTEST
description: GEORGETOWN, Me., Jan. 23 The state police arrested today 13 more persons protesting the use of Reid State Park by the Marines for coldweather training.

title: M'NAMARA IN INDIA TO ASSESS AID NEEDS
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23Robert S. McNamara, President of the World Bank, arrived here tonight on a fourday visit to study India's aid requirements.

title: JOB TEST SPEEDED FOR RELIEF PEOPLE
description: Another speedup in the city's processing of its welfare problems was announced yesterday, reportedly cutting down to two weeks instead of a previous five months the time needed to check out clients claims that they can't work for medical reasons.

title: 11 Station Heads Seek LongTerm Public TV Funds
description: The chairmen of 11 of the largest public broadcasting, stations have met informally for the first time and agreed to become active In seeking longrange financing of noncommercial television.

title: Knicks Down Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 23Ahead by 20 points at halftime and by 15 with only 4 minutes 5 seconds to play, the New York Knicks had to make a desperate stand in the last few seconds to preserve a 10199 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle SuperSonics this morning.

title: Far East Shuns PayCost Curbs
description: Wage and price controls of the type recently instituted by the United States are not widely used in the Far East, but Japan, the region's most ireportant industrial nation, has a deftly guided economy that is finetuned by the Government without formal controls.

title: Asian Leaders Discuss Investment Goals
description: Ian Stewart, representing The New York Times, was host in Singapore on Dec. 7 to four of Southeast Asia's industrial and commercial leaders.

title: Celtics Beat Blazers
description: BOSTON; Jan. 22 (APBoston's John Havlicek moved into 11th place among the N.B.A.'s career scoring leaders tonight by scoring 24 points and leading the Celtics to a 115105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Shopping in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  One of the colorful, traditional aspects of Hong Kong that refuses to die with modernization is the retailing pattern of small shops, fixed and mobile street venders and cluttered, odoriferous openair food markets.

title: Liberals in Florida And Pennsylvania Favor McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 I Senator George McGovern's Presidential candidacy won endorsements this weekend from state conventions of liberal Democrats in Pennsylvania and Florida.

title: A Victory for Day Care
description: Governor Rockefeller has broken the impasse that threatened the city's daycare centers with a disastrous loss of state and Federal subsidies. The liberalization of the Present fee structure for poor families above the welfare level, ordered by Mr. Rockefeller, should avert a confrontation between the city and Albany. Beyond the immediate compromise, the Governor has promised to ask Washington to allow eligibility for lowcost day care to be determined by residence in poverty areas, rather than by income.

title: OVERHAUL URGED FOR HOUSE WORK
description: Household employment in its present form has failed both the woman Who does the houseworkusually poor and black and the working woman who needs it most and often cannot afford it, the city's Human Rights Commissioner told the Bronx Chapter of Household Technicians yesterday.

title: Clapp Wins Ice Yachting In SkeeterClass Boat
description: BANTAM LAKES, Conn. Jan. 23David Clapp captured the Eastern Ice Yachting Association championship today in his new SkeeterClass boat.

title: ELIZABETH WINNER IN INDOOR SOCCER
description: Elizabeth of New Jersey won four shortened games, including a 31 victory over New York Hota in the finale yesterday, to take the annual GermanAmerican Soccer League indoor tourney for the first time.

title: Belgians Charge Woman In Throwing of Ink at Heath
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 23, (Reuters) MarieLouise Kwiatkowski, a 31yearold German woman who threw ink at Prime Minister Heath yesterday, has been charged with assault on a head of government, informed sources said here today.

title: Advertising:
description: Lennen & Newell, badly shaken by the announcement last Wednesday that it would be losing the Florida Citrus Commission account, received two more blows before the week ended. Lorillard and National Distillers will also be leaving.

title: Khan Captures Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 23Sharif Khan of Toronto captured the North American open squash racquets title for the fourth consecutive year with a 1512, 1316, 159, 159 victory over Vic Niederhoffer of New York in the final today.

title: Subsidized Housing Rise In Suburbs Alarms Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Investors and builders in the growing subsidized housing field are increasingly sponsoring projects in the suburbs and avoiding the troubled inner cities, according to a broad range of authorities on the subject.

title: Dr. Kermit Osserman, 62, Dies; Authority on Myasthenia Gra uis
description: Dr. Kermit E. Osserman, a leading authority on the treatment of myasthenia gravis, a chronic neuromuscular disease with which 50,000 Americans are afflicted, died Saturday, night in Roosevelt Hospital of a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived at 59 East 96th Street.

title: Auto Steel Orders Disappointing Mills
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 Steel producers were disappointed last week by the initial orders of automobile companies for March delivery. These early bookings were up from January and February orders, but there was not the decisive improvement steel men had hoped for.

title: S.C.L.C.Names Chicago Aide
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) The Rev. C. T. Vivian was named permanent director of The Chicago chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference today. The Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, national president of S.C.L.C., announced the appointment of Mr. Vivian, who has been interim director of the Chicago organization.

title: LAOS AIDE TERMS LOSSES GENOCIDE
description: PAKSE, Laos, Jan. 23North Vietnam's dryseason offensive has plunged Laos into the severest fighting and heaviest losses she has known, Sisouk na Champassak, the Defense Minister, has disclosed.

title: Teacher Strike Reflects Port Chester's Slippage
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 23When people see South Main Street, they say, Isn't Port Chester terrible, and when they drive through the nice sections of town they say, This must be Greenwich, according to Frederick Kowalski, the Superintendent of Schools.

title: Two Trotters Honored Here
description: Speedy Crown, the trotter of the year, and Marlu Pride, champion 4yearold trotter of 1971, were honored yesterday at a meeting of the Metropolitan Area of New York City Chapter of the United States Trotting Association.

title: Most Customers Ignore Posted Base Price Lists
description: Baseprice lists, posted in food and department stores across the country at the order of the Price Commission, are being widely ignored by shoppers.

title: Forest Hills Project Is Debated With Fury in TV Presentation
description: Proponents and opponents of the lowincome housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, engaged yesterday in heated argument, during which they challenged one another's credibility and introduced or tried to minimize the issue of racism.

title: Broker Asserts Dow Index May Hit 1,000 by Midyear
description: QUESTION: What is your overall view of the domestic economy?

title: Cochran Takes 3d Place In Slalom Won by
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 23In a town where the most exciting thing besides skiing is a hotel room sign that says, Please do not feed the blackbirdsthey are liable to become noisy, one World Cup race was held today and one was not. In the confusion, the United States Alpine team rediscovered another Cochran.

title: Bridge: Experiment Allows Team To Use All Six Members
description: A team of six really amounts to a team of four with two alternates. Until last week, no one had considered the possibility of playing a match between teams of six with all players playing throughout. A successful experiment was made last Wednesday at the Mayfair House of Bridge, following a schedule devised by Charles Wei, inventor of the Precision System.

title: The Talk of Harrisburg, Pa.
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 23 We have a wonderful group of judges. There are a lot of crooks around here but the judges are good. Dix [Federal District Judge R. Dixon Herman] is one of my boys. And he's intelligent. We made him County Solicitor. M. Harvey Taylor the 95yearold retired political boss of Dauphin County (Harrisburg), was discussing the local political and social scene on the eve of the trial of the Harrisburg Seven, who have been charged with conspiring to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security affairs, as a hostage for ending the war in Vietnam; to blow up the heating systems of Federal buildings in Washington, and to vandalize draft records in nine states.

title: New Music Series Dips Into the Old, Too
description: Lincoln Center's New and Newer Music took a few detours into old and older music at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, but there was enough novelty to enable the series to hold its franchise. Dennis Kam's Ad Hoc (1971), in its first New York performance, obviously upheld the theme, as did Elliott Carter's Canon for Three (1971), a first performance anywhere. And no one is going to disqualify Morton Feldman's Madam Press Died Last Week, another first New York performance, simply because it was written as long ago as 1970.

title: Rival Delegates Likely in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 23The Democrats of Mississippi, warring as usual, became the first in the nation yesterday to begin the process of selecting the delegates who will choose the Democratic nominee for President this summer.

title: 2 SENATE LEADERS FAVOR BUSING AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate said in separate interviews today that they would oppose legislation that would forbid the use of Federal funds to pay for busing children out of their neighborhoods to integrate schools.

title: MAKSOUD G. KALFAIAN
description: Maksoud G. Kalfaian, president of D. Kalfaian and Son, Inc., Brooklyn oriental rug dealers, died Saturday in the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 82 years old and lived at 170 84th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Personal Finance: Buying Insurance
description: At a time when prices generally have been going up, seldom down, the savings banks in New York State have just put into effect a decrease in premium rates for new life insurance policies. It varies widely among types of policies and ages, but it is significant.

title: Point of View
description: KABUL, AfghanistanIn a nation whose communications are as backward as those of Afghanistan, the true magnitude of a natural disaster may never be known. But the cost to Afghanistan resulting from three years of searing drought has been enormous.

title: U.S. AND MARKET SEEK NEW RULES
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 23The United States and what should be by next Jan. 1 an enlarged Common Market are trying to agree on a shape for commerce in the final decades of this century.

title: T. C. Werner, A Filmmaker, Weds Jill Troy
description: MILFORD, Pa., Jan. 23The marriage of Miss Jill Joslin Troy to Thomas C. Werner, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Henry Werner of New York and Elberon, N. J., took place today. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at Beaver Lake Lodge, the farm here belonging to the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Troy of New York.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ROANOKE, Va., Jan. 23 (AP)  Jimmy Conners defeated Vladimir Zednik, 64, 75, 76, today in the final of the Roanoke international tennis tournament. It was the second straight tournament he had won.

title: TV: With Cousteau and His Forgotten Mermaids
description: What can you say about a 1,000pound mermaid that is quite evidently useless? Quite a bit, if you happen to JacquesYves Cousteau. The latest hourlong installment in The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau is called The Forgotten Mermaids, and it can be seen tonight at 8 o'clock on the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Soviet Consulate Fire Bombed
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  Four firebombs were thrown at the entrance to the Soviet Union's Consulate here early today, the police reported. The devices caused slight damage to the building.

title: Burma's Economy Is Deteriorating
description: RANGOON, Burma  The curious mix of a military dictatorship imposing socialist policies which has endured for nearly nine years, has made many Burmese realize that honesty may not always be the best, or at least the most profitable, policy.

title: Carol Franck Wed To Arthur C. Levy
description: NEWARK, Jan. 23Miss Carol Elizabeth Franck and Arthur C. Levy were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, the Rev. Dr and Mrs. Howard G. Hageman. Rabbi Albert Belton and Dr. Hageman, a Protestant minister, officiated at the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: How wonderful to read about the new $5.5billion space shuttle (news story Jan. 6), especially while riding an earthbound shuttle unable to progress thirty miles along the Hudson River without its dated equipment collapsing.

title: Seals on Top, 31
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 23 (UPI)The California Seals climbed back into third place in the West Division when they defeated the Philadelphia Flyers tonight, 31.

title: Miss Rosenblatt, Yale Alumna, Married to Augustus K. Oliver
description: Miss Lisbeth Rosenblatt and Augustus Kountze Oliver, who were graduated last year from Yale, were married here yesterday afternoon at the Harmonie Club by Raboi Allen Block.

title: Ilene Schifter Married to Steven Aaron
description: Miss Ilene Sue Schifter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Schifter of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Steven David Aaron, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules B. Aaron of Neponsit, Queens. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Gotham.

title: Chinese Plans Emphasize Farming
description: HONG KONGThe Peoples Republic of China made new economic gains in 1971, and, if stable conditions continue, seems certain to achieve still further expansion this year.

title: Taylor Beats Kelner
description: Hoyt Taylor of the Harvard Club defeated George Kelner of the University Club, 157, 158, 159, yesterday in the final of the Class B invitation squash racquets tournament at the City Athletic Club.

title: Employer Uses Fatherly Care
description: SEOUL, South KoreaChun Joong Yoon manages his business with the same fatherly care for his employes that he gives to his own family.

title: Nader Suit on Milk Prices Links White House to Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, accused the Nixon Administration in a lawsuit filed here today of improperly and unlawfully raising the Federal price support level for milk in return for $322,500 in contributions from the dairy industry to various Republican campaign committees.

title: U. S. DISPLAY DRAWS BIG SOVIET CROWDS
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., Jan. 24 (AP) An exhibition of American products from skillets to spacecraft opened today and thousands of Soviet Georgians jammed the pavilion to question Russianspeaking guides on how everything works.

title: Boston College Head Quits
description: NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)  The Rev. W. Seavey Joyce has resigned as president of Boston College, effective June 30 or as soon afterward as a successor is named. The trustees said they were establishing a procedure for selecting Father Joyce's successor.

title: Reference Library Of Look Magazine Is Given to WNET
description: Cowles Communications, Inc., which published Look until the magazine ceased publication last October has donated Look's 4,500volume reference library to Channel 13 here.

title: 2 Injured in Protest Here When Struck by a Taxi
description: Two persons were taken to St. Clare's Hospital after a taxicab forced its way through a crowd of demonstrators blocking traffic in front of Governor Rockefeller's office here at 22 West 55th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The year 1971 both began and ended with unemployment at 6 per cent. Will 1972 be any better? Much of the growth of output which is expected in 1972 will be accomplished through the increased productivity of those already at work. Even if the rosy predictions of 5 to 6 per cent output growth are realized, the resultant increase in job opportunities could be matched by the expected 1.5to2million increase in the labor force. Unemployment may be almost as high at the end of 1972 as it is now.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Few New Yorkers can escape the statistics of the everincreasing numbers of street crimesassaults, robberies and vandalism. The causes of the upsurge are complex, with little agreement on the remedies by experts in psychology and sociology. What must be agreed to is that daily acts of violence do occur and that in some instances arrests are made.

title: Les Perils de New York Are Disputed
description: C'est tres exagere,  it's very exaggerated  exclaimed Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton yesterday after reading of a Paris newspaper's descriptions of the perils of New York.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Strong military defenses are not the enemy of peace, they are the guardians of peace, said President Nixon in his State of the Union Message, as preface to his announcement that he would ask for an increase in the defense budget. Undoubtedly, the Russians see it the same way, at least as regards their defenses, but the real question is not strength, but how much strength?

title: Space
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Administration plans, as outlined in the new budget, would commit the nation to spend twice as much on the space shuttle as the $5.5billion previously indicateda total of $10billion to $14billion that Congressional opponents have contended would be the real cost.

title: Health Care Fund Will Increase But Rise in Fees Should Slow
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Federal expenditures for health care will continue to rise in the fiscal year 1973, but the Administration is hoping that the galloping inflation in medical costs may be slowed next year.

title: DR. CHARLES CURRAN; WITH MUSEUM HERE
description: LEESBURG, Fla., Jan. 24Dr. Charles H. Curran, who retired in 1960 as curator of entomology at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: Profits at Texas Eastern Register Record for Year
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation achieved a new high in earnings in 1971, Baxter D. Goodrich, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

title: Nassau Relief Exploitation Charged
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger charged yesterday that some landlords In Long Beach, L. I., were exploiting welfare recipients and that the Nassau County Department of Social Services was at least lax.

title: Chapman Service Thursdays
description: A memorial service for John Chapman, drama critic emeritus of The Daily News, who died Jan. 19 at the age of 71, will be held Thursday at 11 A.M. at the Shubert Theater. Brooks Atkinson, the retired drama critic of The New York Times; Alfred Drake, the actor; Richard Watts, drama critic of The New York Post, and Francis Robinson, assistant manager of the Metropolitan Opera, will participate in the service.

title: 2 GREEK BISHOPS MAY FACE OUSTER
description: ATHENS, Jan. 24  Two Gteek Orthodox bishops are under ecclesiastical investigation on charges that may lead to expulsion from their sees. The accusations arise from their demands for the restoratign of democratic rule in the church, suspended in the church as well as in the state after the military coup of April 21, 1967.

title: Navy Contract Enlarged
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday it had received a $230.3million addition to a Navy contract for construction of three SSN688 Class highspeed nuclear attack submarines.

title: HOWARD L. AUERBACH
description: Howard L. Auerbach, a real estate broker with William A. White & Sons, died yesterday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 40 East 84th Street.

title: JUSTICE STOPS JURY ON PENTAGON PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. blocked today until Feb. 10 further testimony before a Federal grand jury in Boston on Senator Mike Gravel's version of the Pentagon papers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Negotiators for the city and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have stepped up their efforts to agree on terms of a new contract to replace the one that expired more than a year ago.

title: New Taxes Indicated in Budget Unless Federal Spending on New Programs Stops
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The theme runs throughout President Nixon's budget that additional taxes are going to he required soon if the Federal Government does not stop getting into new programs.tion of uncertainty about any of the estimates.

title: Pipe Bomb Explodes at Portuguese Air Office Here
description: Part of a fourpiece pipe bomb that the police said could have caused death or serious injury exploded at 10:15 A.M. yesterday in an empty stairwell of the Portuguese Airways office at 601 Fifth Avenue. The damage was slight and no one was injured. Minutes earlier there had been people on the stairway.

title: Butz Condemns Plan to Raise Wheat and FeedGrain Supports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz told the Senate Agriculture Committee today that a bill to raise Federal price supports of wheat and feed grains would hand windfall profits of $250million to agriculture middlemen and anger consumers by cutting meat supplies.

title: Egyptian Police Clash With Student Demonstrators
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24Egyptian policemen moved into Cairo University before dawn today to break up a sitin by students demanding a more militant policy against Israel, and later in the day used tear gas to challenge thousands of students marching into the center of Cairo.

title: Market Place:
description: Apollo Industries, a deficitridden conglomerate threatened with delisting by the American Stock Exchange, appears to be hailing itself out of an ocean of red ink through a land development near Walt Disney World in Florida.

title: CAHILL EXPLAINS HIS VETO ON TOBIN
description: Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey, who has vetoed a Port Authority decision creating the title of executive director emeritus for Austin J. Tobin, said yesterday that he had done so because the resolution was subject to a multitude of interpretations.

title: 3 ARRESTED HERE IN BEEF HIJACKING
description: Three suspectsone of them critically wounded by a blast from a detective's shotgun were arrested in the Bronx early yesterday after, the police said, they tried to hijack three truckloads of beef valued at $200,000.

title: 2 Democrats Urge U.S. to Pay For States WelfareCost Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Two Democratic Senators proposed today that the Federal Government reimburse the states about $2billion for recent increase in welfare costs.

title: Demonstrations Banned
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Egyptian Government tonight banned all demonstrations and urged students to disperse quietly after the police had fought back waves of angry demonstrators with tear gas in a street battle.

title: Europe of the Future
description: The accession to Europe's sixnation Common Market of Britain, Denmark, Norway and Ireland is likely to be remembered by history less for enlarging the European Economic Community (E.E.C.) than for accelerating its progress toward internal union and a new relationship with the outside world, especially the United States.

title: The Return of a Native: II
description: Direct and indirect attacks on the children who most need care and protection are increasing. Proposed legislation in Congress as well as the Brownie point foray in New York seem directed toward using children as pawns in campaigns to reduce welfare costs, impose conformity on poor parents and reduce essential services to the children of the poor.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up From WeekAgo Level
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Ruler of Persian Gulf Emirate Shot to Death in Attempted Coup
description: SHARJA, Tuesday, Jan. 25 (Reuters)The ruler of the Persian Gulf state of Sharja was found shot to death inside his palace today after an attempted coup by his cousin, the former ruler, and 18 followers.

title: 19YearOld Debbie Meyer Calls It Quits as Swimmer
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 24 (UPI)Debbie Meyer, who won three individual gold medals in the 4968 Olympics, said today she was retiring from swimming competition at the age of 19.

title: Enforcing Equality
description: It is more than seven years since Congress enacted a comprehensive Civil Rights Act banning discriminatory practices in many fields including employment. But the latest job statistics show that the rate of unemployment is twice as high for Negroes as for whites. In part, this lag is attributable to the inferior education and deprivation which many blacks have suffered in the past. Unfortunately, however, it is also due to concealed racial bias on the part of some employers and some unions.

title: 255 Add $9,234 to Fund for the Neediest
description: Contributions from an unemployed.woman, a newspaper delivery boy and the priest in charge of a mission in Nenana, Alaska, were among the 255 recorded yesterday that added $9,234.95 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES PLAN FOR ATTICA
description: A recruiting effort, backed with Federal Funds, to hire black and Puerto Rican guards for the Attica Correctional Facility is being challenged in court on the ground that it represents reverse discrimination.

title: Seoul Bids Tokyo Block Rise In Trade With Pyongyang
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 24  South Korea expressed strong objection today to a private trade memorandum signed in Pyongyang yesterday that calls for expansion of trade between Japan and North Korea.

title: RALPH S. EULER
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 Ralph S. Euler, a retired senior vice president of Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, died today at his home in Edgeworth, Pa. He was 83 years old.

title: Track Writers Elect Litsky
description: Frank Litsky of The New York Times and Jim Dunaway, Eastern editor of Track and Field News, were reelected yesterday president and secretarytreasurer, respectively, of the New York Track Writers Association.

title: DRUG MAKERS WIN HIGHCOURT TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24As a result of a tie vote in the Supreme Court today, three of the nation's largest drug manufacturers secured a reversal of a conviction on pricefixing charges brought by the Government 10 years ago.

title: The Talk of SoHo
description: Last October, a group of people who liked to cook and liked each other opened a restaurant on the corner of Prince and Wooster Streets and called it Food.

title: Future Duchess Looks to the Splendors of Blenheim
description: LONDON, Jan. 24Two of Britain's most illustrious, aristocrats will be married this week. But one of them is a little sad about leaving home.

title: She Cooks for and Copes With Those Gamma Delta Boys
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y. Union College has a handsome campus, a good basketball team and since last year, coeds and open dorms. But only the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity has Cookie. And Cookie, the Phi Gams will tell you, is worth her wellrounded weight in gold.

title: Lady Lawford Is Dead; Actor's Mother Was 83
description: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP)Lady Lawford, the mother of Peter Lawford, died at a convalescent hospital yesterday after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Development Program, governing council  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Royalty and Danish Commoners Honor King Frederik at Burial
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 24 (AP)The Danes laid King Frederik IX to rest among his royal ancestors today with pageantry, family love and popular affection.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President sent the Federal budget for the, 1973 fiscal year to Congress. Later he met separately with the United Nations Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, and Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia.

title: Stage:
description: The title vampire in Carmine by Wilford Leach is a creature of the halflight. That midpoint between life and death visited by the dying and the waking dead is the main sphere occupied, to date, by the work of Leach and John Braswell, his associate. Their subject is psychic terror.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON. Jan. 24There can be no doubt that the violence that has accompanied Lord Pearce's presence in Rhodesia has sorely dismayed him.

title: Bhutto Indicates an Easing of Curbs on Pakistan's Financial Elite
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 24 Apparently easing his hard line on Pakistan's financial elite, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto announced today that no new categories of industries would be nationalized, and appealed for the voluntary cooperation of businessmen in building the country's warshattered economy.

title: Shapp to Endorse Muskie Bid Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania will announce tomorrow his support of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: SAMUEL PATTERSON
description: RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 24 (AP)Dr. Samuel Jasper Patterson, former moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, U.S., died last night. He was 72 years old.

title: Scots Are Rallying to Save Viking Cathedral
description: KIRKWALL, Scotland, Jan. 19For more than 800 years St. Magnus Cathedral, begun by the Vikings, has withstood the buffetings of countless Atlantic storms and the corrosive effect of salt spray.

title: MISS CASA'S WINS COAST NET FINAL
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP)  Rosemary Casals of San Francisco used a strong net game to wear down Frangoise Durr of Paris and win the Long Beach women's professional tennis tournament last night, 62, 67, 63.

title: SOVIET OPENS TIES WITH BANGLADESH
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 24The Soviet Union has recognized Bangladesh as a sovereign nation.

title: Screen: 'Tenchu' Arrives:Killer Is Overachiever in Samurai Drama
description: Hideo Gosha's "Tenchu," which opened yesterday at the Bijou, is yet another samurai drama set in the 1860's, during the downfall of the Tokugawa shogunatewhich I begin to think must rank with Edison, Lumire and the shootout at O.K. Corral as among the leading first causes of world cinema. Students of history will remember the 1860's as traditionally signalling the end of the old, the birth of the new Japan. But for the movies it was a time of absolutely wholesale murder, largely on a freelance basis."Tenchu" (which means "Heaven's Punishment," and is supposed to be the cry of the assassin while dispatching his victim) is the story of an uncouth samurai named Izo (Shintaro Katsu), attached to a leader of the Tosa clan, for whom he kills not wisely but too well. Such is his zeal and so spectacular is his record that the leader (Tatsuya Nakadai), fearing too much of the wrong publicity, dismisses him, cancels his sake-shop expense account, has him blacklisted and more or less conspires in his arrest as a common vagrant Izo ultimately gets a self-sacrificial revenge, but it comes only as an ironic postscript to a misspent life."Tenchu" suffers, as do a good many samurai dramas, from a hero with more character traits than character; and in general, despite its slickness and its commitment to violent action, it suggests a craft that is overburdened with wasteful detail. Too much mood setting, too much obviously effective wide-screen composition, too many beads of sweat on Izo's screwed-up faceit is not art cinema but it is very arty, and it is as far as I can imagine from the proportionate balance of such masters as Ozu and Mizoguchi.However, there are points of interest. These include two pleasant performancesone by Yujiro Ishihara as a friend of Izo, a gentle sane man to whom of course nobody listens; another by Mitsuko Baisho as the prostitute Izo frequents, who plays with a coarse but complex vitality that might grace a better movie.Along with its bloody murders, "Tenchu" offers one equally bloody suicide. It is performed by a disgraced aristocrat played by the late Yukio Mishima, the novelist. Mishima, in addition to writing, acted in some movies, and I gather he rather coveted such roles. This must have been one of the last before his suicide in earnestwhich indicated that the spirit of the old Japan is not dead, but only repeatedly dying.

title: Advertising:
description: Benton & Bowles (snore) has just joined the ad agency lineup of Block Drug (zzzzzzzz) and the assignment (snore) is for Nytol Sleep Aid Tablets and Capsules.

title: Lindsay Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Mayor Lindsay of New York contended today that President Nixon's budget meant that we're going to build more for death abroad and less for life here at home.

title: FUTURES PRICES DECLINE WIDELY
description: Prices of copper futures on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday closed 1/20 cent higher to 1/10 cent lower, with the nearby March, 1972, contract at 48% cents a [pound, up 1/20 cent from the previous close. All other contracts closed lower.

title: Teachers of Writing Weigh Their Words to Students
description: A select group attends the writing courses at City College, for the pen is mightier than the horde.

title: Bradshaw's Passes Click
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP) Terry Bradshaw, quarterback of the Pittsburgh Steelers, will marry the 1969 Miss Teenage America, Melissa Babish of suburban Cuddy, Pa., Miss Babish's parents announced today. The wedding is planned for April.

title: POLISH SONG RECITAL GIVEN BY BACHLEDA
description: Like its Russian counterpart, the Polish art song is a bit confined  the general flavor tends to be either excessively sad or excessively merry. Still, it was intriguing to hear a collection of them so idiomatically and knowingly interpreted by Andrezej Bachleda Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Anniuersaries
description: KWEITPeace and love forever together, Rob. Haony anniversary. Love Cat.

title: S.I. Rapid Transit To Increase Fares To 35 Cents Feb.1
description: The fare on the Staten Island Rapid Transit lines will go to flat 35 cents on Feb. 1, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday. Federal Price Commission approval is expected.

title: Leading Quebec Radical Surrenders to the Police
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press)Pierre Vallieres, who disappeared more than four months ago before his trial on charges of seditious conspiracy and counseling kidnapping and murder, gave himself up to the poliec tonight.

title: Kennecott Copper Profit Halved in Quarter, All 1971
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the final quarter and in all 1971 had been cut in half because of a combination of adverse developments.

title: Hostage Laos
description: The illstarred war in Laos is proving a disaster. An early dryseason offensive of unprecedented strength by the North Vietnamese has taken a heavy toll of American airpower diverted to several Laotian fronts. Embarrassing defeats have been inflicted on Americandirected Laotian and Thai forces. The drive has approached Thailand's Mekong River border with Laos in the south, and apparently has activated Chinese antiaircraft crews against American planes in northern Laos.

title: Road's Quarter Profit Off
description: John P. Fishwick, president of the Norfolk & Western Railway, the nation's most profitable carrier, said yesterday that although the road's profits dropped sharply in the fourth quarter last year because of the coal strike it managed to increase its profits for the year before an extraordinary charge.

title: Further Efforts Pledged
description: MANILA, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  President Marcos, in his speech to Congress, said the opening of relations with Yugoslavia and Rumania two weeks ago should be regarded as only the first step in his Government's efforts to improve relations with Communist countries.

title: Richard P. McMullen, 46, Investment Banker Here
description: Richard P. McMullen, a general partner in Lazard Freres & Company, investment bankers, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived at 170 East 79th Street.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Nixon Administration's education budget for the next fiscal year includes no unexpected initiatives, but it does contain a disappointment for colleges and universities.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Recently numerous correspondents have been asking what equipment should be brought on a Florida fishing trip.

title: A LABOR ALLIANCE TO BE DISSOLVED
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24The Alliance for Labor Action, a joint venture by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the United Automobile Workers to organize the poor anti to use the resources of labor to help solve urban problems, will be phased out.

title: Pompidou Arrives in Niger
description: NIAMEY, Niger, Jan. 24 (AP) President Pompidou of France arrived today on an official visit to this former French African territory. Mr. Pompidou will continue on to Fort Lamy, Chad, on Wednesday.

title: Agnew Sees Housing Gains
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Vice President Agnew said today that America's housing industry was he Dithy, strong and optimistic.

title: I.L.A. Pact Backed by Shipping Group
description: Directors of the New York, Shipping Association approved a new agreement yesterday with the International Longshoremen's Association on working conditions in the port, and the union called a meeting for tomorrow at which its wage scale committee is scheduled to vote on the package.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Rider rallied from a 9point, firsthalf deficit tonight to beat Lehigh, 9184, in a Middle Atlantic Conference Western Division game. Terry Martin led Rider with 30 points.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Rights Unit Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 24 (AP) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate rejected today an amendment to provide for enforcement of equal employment opportunities through the courts rather than by administrative actions:

title: DELINQUENCY FIGHT CALLED MISDIRECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Bipartisan Congressional charges that Administration efforts to combat juvenile delinquency are inadequate, uncoordinated, and misdirected were leveled today at Senate hearings on a bill to create an independent institute for continuing studies in juvenile justice.

title: STOCKS REGISTER A SHARP DECLINE
description: Stock prices sagged yesterday in the sharpest decline in more than two months as rerecent glamour favorites were hit by substantial losses.

title: BRUNDAGE EASES SAPPORO'S FEARS
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Jan. 24 (UPI)The flags of five newly arrived national teams fluttered at the Olympic village here today, while Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, gave assurance in Tokyo that the Winter Games would begin Feb. 3 as scheduled.

title: FORDHAM DOWNS ARMY FIVE, 8171
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 Fordhain outscored Army by 132 during a fourminute stretch late in the second half tonight and went on to register an 8171 victory over the cadets. The triumph. Fordham's third in a row, ended a fourgame string by Army.

title: HIGH COURT VOIDS RESIDENCY LAWS IN WELFARE CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Supreme Court unanimously struck down today emergency laws passed last year by the New York and Connecticut Legislatures to bar state welfare aid to persons who had not lived in the states at least one year.

title: Regrets Over Bahamian
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The State Department today indicated it was sorry for any inconvenience caused the Bahamian Minister of Finance and Education, Carlton Francis, who was bodily searched by United States Customs Agents in Miami last Friday. The department said Mr. Francis arrived without any documents indicating his position.

title: BANK HOLDING UNITS GAIN ADVISORY ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board will permit onebank holding companies to act as investment advisers to investment companies, including mutual funds, under an amendment to its rule announced today.

title: Buckley Tours Quemoy
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, paid a flying visit today to the island of Quemoy, the Chinese Nationalist outpost three miles from the mainland. He toured the outpost, which is estimated to face 150 mainland artillery batteries.

title: LateLocked Barn
description: The City Council still seems to be having difficulty with the idea that New Yorkers ought to be told what they are getting into before municipal officials irrevocably commit them to terms of new labor contracts.

title: Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Nixon Administration has decided to cut back on its commitments to subsidized apartments in the fiscal year beginning next July 1, because of difficulties it has experienced in obtaining proper construction, sitelocation, management and financial stability.

title: Prisoner Slain in Attack on Marshal
description: Two prisoners handcuffed together were shot, one of them fatally, after one of them slashed a Federal marshal with a sharpened spoon in the marshal's car in front of the Federal courthouse in downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Brezhnev and Kosygin Go to Prague to Confer With Leaders of Bloc on a European Security Conference
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, and Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin flew to Prague today for a meeting with top Eastern European Communist leaders to put new pressure on the West to begin preliminary talks for a European security conference.

title: Port Chester Teachers Back Pay Pact and End Strike
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 24Teachers here ratified new twoyear contract and returned to work this morning, ending a weeklong strike.

title: Trip Around Persian Gulf Shows Iran Is Chief Power
description: ABOARD IRANIAN FRIGATE MILANIAN, in the Persian Gulf, Jan. 13Iran is reinforcing her position as the dominant sea power in the Persian Gulf.

title: Former inmate of Mexican Jail Says Police Frame Americans
description: A New York accountant who spent 13 months in a Mexican prison on a drug conviction that was ultimately reversed by an appellate court said yesterday that an unexpected result of United States pressure on Mexico to stamp out crossborder narcotics trafficking was the imprisonment of young Americans who had been framed or given onerously long sentences.

title: State Noise Control Regulation Signed into Jersey Law by Cahill
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24The nation's first statewide comprehensive noisecontrol legislation, designed to muffle the clamor in what has been called the country's noisiest state, was signed here today by Gov. William T. Cahill.

title: Hatfield Announces Plans To Seek 2d Senate Term
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 24Senator Mark O. Hatfield announced his bid for a second term today, apparently with the support of leading segments of the Republican party that he antagonized during his first term.

title: 4,400 G.I.'s Withdrawn
description: SAIGON, Jan. 24 (UPI)The United States command reported today that 4,400 American troops were pulled out of Vietnam last week, cutting the American force in the war zone to 143,700 men. It was the lowest number of United States servicemen in Vietnam since September, 1965, when 132,300 were here.

title: Wigan Rugby Victor, 2710
description: WIGAN, England, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  Wigan beat Wakefield Trinity, 2710, in an English Rugby League match tonight.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Orders Persico to Begin Sentence
description: The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to stay the start of a 14year prison term for Carmine Persico, reputed underworld figure, and he was ordered to surrender Thursday.

title: Bulls End Warrior Streak At 11 With 110105 Victory
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP)The Chicago Bulls, led by Jerry Sloan and Norm Van Lier in the final quarter, outlasted Golden State, 110105, tonight ending the Warriors 11game winning streak, the longest in the National Basketball Association club's history.

title: LETHAL DEFOLIANT TO BE DESTROYED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Air Force said today it had tentative plans to dispose of 23.4 million gallons of a defoliant called Agent Orange at commercial plants near Houston and in Sauget, Ill., near East St. Louis.

title: Transportation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The new budget contains the first endorsement by President Nixon of deregulation of freight transportationa plan to ease government controls and stimulate competitive price reductions that lacked Presidential support last year and was nearly smothered in Congress.

title: MATTLE CAPTURES CUP GIANT SLALOM
description: ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 24  It's off to Sapporo now. The last World Cup ski race before the Winter Olympics turned out to be a fogbound affair today that left the situation in the men's giant slalom about as clear as the weather.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24In the spirit of the times, the price of the new Federal budget has been held steady at $2.50, which is not bad for a long, softcover work of futurism. But as usual, there are few restraints on the rhetoric that it aims at dozens of political constituencies. And as usual, there are only the barest hints of the real assumptions and choices that the President faced and made in allocating his funds.

title: 2d Rams Draft Pick Given To Patriots in Olsen Case
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)The New England Patriots acquired a thirdround draft choice from Los Angeles today to complete compensation for the signing of Phil Olsen, a defensive lineman, by the Rams.

title: MRS. ROBERT 0. LOWERY
description: Mrs. Marjorie Harding Lowery, wife of Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery, died yesteray at their home in the River Terrace Cooperative on Riverside Drive West. She was 52 years old.

title: Romance, ContemporaryStyle, Is the Parisian Look for Spring
description: PARIS, Jan. 24Femininity is returning to fashion with a vengeance. Make way for flowering chiffons, flaring skirts, bare shoulders, tiny waistlines and all the other blandishments designers forgot about in the last few sad, bad years.

title: Indian Pullout Urged
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  President Bhutto called today for a withdrawal of Indian troops from Bangladesh to enable a new dialogue to begin between Pakistan and East Bengali leaders. He said at a news conference that this dialogue could be followed by IndianPakistani talks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Jacob Javits recent letter concerning the socalled national health crisis employs oftrepeated and warped statistics which rank the United States thirteenth in infant mortality and 22d in life span for men. He is apparently unaware of the great variations in statistical methods of recording infant mortality. Some countries hold only the parents responsible for reporting infant births and deaths, and Continental vital statistics vary with little relevance to the quality of the medical care in any particular country.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Terry Matson, the athletic director and basketball coach at Franklin Pierce College in Rindge, N. H., isn't too keen about having his team play Windham College of Putney, Vt., tomorrow night if Windham insists upon playing that girl. She is Karen Wise, a blond, 5foot5inch junior, who broke into the Windham varsity lineup for two minutes last Thursday night as Castleton State College of Vermont was trouncing the Lions, 8438.

title: BORROWING BY U.S. TO EBB IN BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Total borrowing from the public by the Treasury Department and Government  sponsored agencies will be just less than $30billion in fiscal 1973, President Nixon estimated in his new budget today.

title: Mortgage Rates in December Off a Bit for 2d Month in Row
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Interest rates on conventional mortgage loans inched downward in December, the second straight monthly decline, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: GTE International Elects
description: John B. Arnold has been elected president of GTE International, Inc., international manufacturing and marketing subsidiary of the General Telephone & Electronics Corporation. He formerly was senior vice president  telecommunications of GTE International. He succeeds William F. Bennett, who was elected executive vice presidentmanufacturing of GTE earlier this month.

title: Pender's Concern in Millrose Is Getting Off to a Right Start
description: Mel Pender is more concerned about who will be pulling the trigger for the start of the 60yard dash Friday night in the Millrose Games than the rivals who will challenge him at the finish line.

title: Gene Austin, Popular Crooner 011920's and 1930's, Is Dead
