description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 24Gene Austin, one of the country's most popular crooners of the nineteentwenties, whose theme song, My Bthe Heaven sold more than 12 million records, died in Desert Hospital here today of lung cancer. He was 71 years old.

title: Nation's 72 Output Rise Projected at $98Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The nation's total output of goods and services will rise $98billion this year to $1,145billion, according to the official Government forecast disclosed today.

title: AFTRA to Move on Employers Who Cut Pay Rates
description: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, the 29,000member union representing performers in broadcasting and segments of the recording industry, is taking steps to crack down hard on employers who use stratagems and subterfuge to avoid payments to its members. The union did not identify any individuals or companies engaging in such practices.

title: Marcos Urges SelfReliance
description: MANILA, Jan. 24  President Marcos said in his speech that the Philippines must rely, for a few years more on continued American protection while she prepares to assume full control of her internal and external defense.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In appointing the Scott Commission, Governor Rockefeller took a reasonable step forward in moving New York City toward a more responsible government. It is hoped that the commission will come forward with serious recommendations for reconstituting New York City's government.

title: Air Force Asks for Bids On New Transport Plane
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The Air Force asked nine aerospace companies today to submit bids on a new short takeoff and landing transport plane that may replace the C130 as the nation's main tactical airlift craft.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor The uproar about the Anderson revelations regarding East Pakistan is much ado about nothing. The documents that Anderson alluded to merely provided a journalistic bonanza for a group of columnists whose abiding passion is to apply the needle to the Nixon Administration.

title: Bond Analysts Skeptical About Budget Projection
description: Creditmarket analysts, active in firms that handle the securities the Government sells to finance its debt, took a highly skeptical view yesterday of the budget projections released by the Nixon Administration.

title: Kerrigan Judge Cautions Media on Jury Selection
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 24The Federal judge in the conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six others charged with plotting the abduction of President Nixon's advisor on foreign policy matters, Henry A. Kissinger, threatened today to exclude the news media from the jury selection if they ignored his request to withhold publication of the names of the prospective jurors and their answers under examination.

title: 17 Hurt in Electrical Blast
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 24 (AP)Six persons were hospitalized today and 11 others were treated at the scene of an electrical explosion at the Fort Wayne Magnavox plant. The explosion occurred in a section classified for Government antisubmarine projects.

title: Helga Hughes Was in Bank Dec. 28, 3 Weeks After Book Was Denounced
description: The woman who opened a Swiss hank account in the, name of H. R. Hughes was last seen in the Zurich bank on Dec. 28, some three weeks after the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes was first denounced by Hughes interests as a hoax.

title: F.D.A. Says Tests Show Soup Bowls Are Unsafe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that its tests had confirmed that 200,000 soup bowls distributed in a nationwide sales promotion had unsafe levels of lead and cadmium.

title: Democrats Score Budget; Most Republicans Back It
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Representative George H. Mahon, Democrat of Texas, accused President Nixon today of trying to sugar coat his new budget to hide record deficit spending, and warned that a tax increase was inevitable.

title: Research
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The funding level proposed for the National Institutes of Health in the President's 1973 budget has reinforced the fears of some that the muchpublicized increases in cancer and heart disease research are being made at the expense of other programs.

title: Most of Democrats Proposals For Reform Lose in Assembly
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24  With about half of the lawmakers absent, the Assembly today voted down, along party lines, a resolution requiring lawmakers to be physically present in the chamber to be recorded as voting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I never cease to wonder at the ability of ideologues to fit their interpretation of events to their doctrinal preferences.

title: MURRAY S. MARVIN
description: Murray S. Marvin, a member of the Los Angeles law firm of Musick, Peeler & Garrett, and formerly of Montclair, N.J., died of a heart attack Wednesday in Bel Air, Calif. He was 49 years old.

title: Move Long Expected
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24The Soviet recognition of Bangladesh, announced here in a brief dispatch by Tess, the Soviet press agency, had been expected following the Soviet diplomatic and material support for India in her war against Pakistan. But it was delayed two weeks ago when Pakistan immediately severed diplomatic ties with East Germany and Bulgaria over their recognition of the new Bengali Government.

title: Dancers Achieve Goal And More for Library
description: The Dance Collection of the New York Public Library, threatened with closure only one month ago because of a deficit, grossed $105,296.80 through a gala benefit performance at the City Center last night.

title: Steel Production Declined By 4% in Latest Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 22 fell to 2,220,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a decline of 4 per cent from the 2,312,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

title: JUDGE IN BAY STATE REFUSES TO RESIGN
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Superior Court Judge Vincent R. Brogna refused Gov. Francis W. Sargent's request that he resign today.

title: Willowbrook Woes Attributed in Part To Radical Group
description: Militants and radicals among staff personnel and parents of patients were blamed yesterday, along with overcrowding and lack of money, for some of the problems of the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island.

title: Kennedy Memorial Unveiled
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)A memorial plaque honoring President Kennedy was unveiled in front of the speaker's rostrum in the Massachusetts House today.

title: Hermit on Guam Says He's Japanese Noncom
description: AGANA, Guam, Jan. 24 (AP)  Two fishermen have captured a man who told authorities he was a Japanese Army sergeant and had fled to the jungles and hid when Americans invaded the island almost 28 years ago.

title: Croats, Rebuked by Tito, Are Sullen and Uneasy About the Future
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 A Croatian historian was trying to recount the tangled background of his people a few days ago when he paused to smile at a visitor's confusion. Our history is like a crime story, he said.

title: Israeli Jets Attack Guerrillas in Syria
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 24Israel reported today that her jets flew 20 miles into Syria this afternoon and dropped the first bombs on Syrian territory in 19 months.

title: White House Greets Waldheim And Affirms Support of U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Nixon Administration gave a wellpublicized welcome today to Kurt Waldhelm, the new United Nations Secretary General, and assured him of its 'full support both for him and for the world organization.

title: New Pro Hockey Loop Adds Boston U. Coach
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)The newly formed World Hockey Association dipped into the college ranks for leadership again today as Jack Kelley of Boston University's defending National Collegiate champions signed a sevenyear contract as coach and general manager of the New England Whalers.

title: Dentzer Sees Small Banks Holding Own
description: New York State's Superintendent of Banks William T. Dentzer Jr. belittled yesterday fears that the giant New York City banking organizations would swamp local institutions when the giants gained freedom to branch and merge throughout the state in January, 1976.

title: Bonavena Opens Training Here for Patterson Fight
description: Oscar Bonavena, who meets Floyd Patterson in a 10round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden Feb. 11, opened his local training program yesterday with six rounds of boxing at the Telstar Gymnasium on West 28th Street.

title: Executive Changes
description: The election of the top executives at two major companies was announced yesterday.

title: Former Mississippi Governor Spurns Subpoena, but Testifies
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., Jan. 24Former Gov. John Williams refused to accept a subpoena here today to appear before a grand jury investigating his recent release of 14 youthful drug offenders, but later Mr. Williams, who left office last Tuesday, voluntarily went before the jury.

title: CITY RECONSIDERS DETENTION CENTER
description: The Lindsay administration, which in the wake of the 1970 city prison riots gave top priority to building a new detention center, is reconsidering its position because of a shortage of construction funds.

title: 219 AUTOS IN RALLY REACH MONTE CARLO
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 1(UPI)  The first stage of the Monte Carlo auto rally ended today with 219 of 264 cars surviving the threeday grind across Europe and drivers hoping the final stages will be more interesting.

title: Crangle Predicts Rise in Number of Women Delegates to National Party Conventions
description: In what would be a major advance for women in politics, about half of the state's 278 delegates to the Democratic national convention are expected to be women, Joseph F. Crangle, the newly elected Democratic state chairman, said yesterday.

title: Barber Triumphs at 21st Extra Hole
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 24Miller Barber won the Dean MartinTucson open golf tourney in a new way today. After finishing the scheduled 18hole playoff all even with George Archer, he finally triumphed in a suddendeath session that went three extra holes. The tussle, which brought Barber $30,000 plus a $5,000 bonus from the television sponsors, took a special place in the old sport.

title: Britons Explain Rhodesia Pact; Crowd of Blacks Choruses No
description: MREWA, Rhodesia, Jan. 24 A crowd of about 1,000 black Africans listened quietly for 55 minutes this morning as two Britons explained a complicated new political formula for racially troubled Rhodesia.

title: Campbell Accuses A.A.U.
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 24 (AP)  Milt Campbell, former Olympic decathalon star, has accused the Amateur Athletic Union of blocking him from competing in judo at the Olympics.

title: Hernandez Takes Yamaha Cup
description: With the hotpinkandcanaryyellow boards surrounding the infield forming a backdrop, Steve Hernandez capped a noigy, smoky and exciting evening by capturing the $5,000 first prize in the Yamaha Silver Cup motorcycle competition in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: JAMES CAMPBELL OF POWER CONCERN
description: JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 24James H. Campbell, president of Consumers Power Company, builder of this state's first nuclear electric power plant, died today of a heart attack at his home. His age was 61.

title: BIG MAYBELLE SMITH, BLUES SINGER, DEAD
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 (AP) Maybelle Smith, a blues singer known as Big Maybelle, died yesterday in Cleveland Metropolitan General Hospital after being intermittently ill for the last 18 months. She was 48 years old.

title: Air Hostesses Get La Guardia Escort Following a Rape
description: United Air Lines has set up a nighttime escort service for its stewardesses working out of La Guardia Airport. Men employes, using a special ramp vehicle, drive the stewardesses from the aircraft landing area to their automobiles and then wait for the women to drive away.

title: Marquette Tops Notre Dame
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 24 (UPI)  Secondranked Marquette trailed Notre Dame by 9 points four different times in the first half tonight but managed to pull ahead by 2 at intermission and went on to 7162 victory.

title: 500 Firemen Attend Mass For Lieut. Joseph Connelly
description: About 500 offduty firemen attended a funeral mass yeserday for Fire Lieutenant Joseph P. Connelly, who died last Thursday while on duty at an industrial plant in Laurelton, Queens. Firefighters had responded to the plant when a faulty sprinkler system went off needlessly.

title: '71 Result Was Up 15% as Indicated Quarter Earnings Advanced
description: The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum enterprise, announced yesterday a 15 per cent increase in 1971 earnings and higher indicated fourthquarter profits.

title: Merger News
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation, which controls a $1billion retail merchandising complex, is planning to expand this business through a tender offer to purchase 950,000 shares, or about 49 per cent, of the common stock of the J. J. Newberry Company. It is offering $22 a share or a total of $20.9million. Meshulam Riklis, chairman and president of RapidAmerican, stated yesterday that his company intended to acquire control of Newberry and would seek to merge or combine Newberry with the McCrory Corporation if a study proved the merger could be effected upon appropriate terms. RapidAmerican owns 57 per cent of McCrory.

title: $83Billion Request for Defense Accelerates New Upward Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24President Nixon asked today for authority to spend $83.4billion for the Defense Department, an increase of $6.3billion over the request for the current budget year The new request markedly accelerates a rising trend in the military budget that began last year, after two years of decline.

title: Portion of the Johnson Library To Be Opened to Public Today
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 24Members of the Johnson Administration gathered in Austin today for the unveiling of a portion of the 31 million pages of documents in the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library tomorrow.

title: Mr. Paul B. Victor in Floridian
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI)  Mr. Paul B. fell back after an alert beginning, then closed strongly in the stretch to capture the first running of the $32,500 Floridian Handicap for 3yearolds at Gulfstream Park today.

title: C. W. Post Wins, 8367
description: BROOKVILLE, L. L, Jan. 24 C. W. Post led by Jim Webber's 20 points defeated Southern Connecticut, 8367, tonight. The victory was the ninth in 14 outings for the Pioneers.

title: NO TAX RISE ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24President Nixon sent Congress today his third budget, showing a cumulative deficit of $87billion for the three years of his term.

title: A Redistricting Bill For Pennsylvania Goes to Governor
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 24The Democraticcontrolled legislature sent to Gov. Milton J. Shapp tonight a bill that reapportions Pennsylvania's 27 Congressional districts into 25.

title: $100Million Record Set
description: Profits of the American Express Company and its subsidiaries in 1971 were the highest in its 121year history and exceeded the $100million mark for the first time, Howard L. Clark, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.

title: Excerpts From President Nixon's Budget Message as Presented to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Following are excerpts from President Nixon's Budget Message as presented to Congress today:

title: Books of The Times
description: In deference to the oblique speaking styles of Eddie Coyle and his friends, and because I find myself so utterly in thrall to the mood of George V. Higgins's first novel, The Friends of Eddie Coyle, let me approach the book's merits somewhat deviously. Not too far into the story, Dave Foley, the cop, parks his car at the Red Coach Grille in Braintree, Mass., goes into the bar, orders a vodka martini on the rocks with a twist, and sits back to watch the evening news on the television set above the bar. As the waitress arrived with Foley's drink, a black man with heavy jowls and an accent that made er sounds into or sounds delivered the first story. Four gunmen, masked with nylon stockings, made off with an estimated $97,000 from the First Agricultural and Commercial Bank and Trust Company in Hopedale this morning, he said.

title: Property Owners See a Threat In Jersey Wetlands Regulation
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Jan. 24 How far can the state restrict a man's use of his own property before it must buy it from him?

title: Levitz Furniture Down 9 After Criticism
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, the dramatically successful Miamibased furniture chain that had an 83point rise in its stock in 1971, reflected the pressure of an unfavorable article in a financial journal yesterday when its shares dropped by 9 points.

title: U. S. Now A dmitting Prostitutes To Some of Its Vietnam Bases
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam. Jan. 24 (UPI)The United States Army has opened its gates to Vietnamese prostitutes at several bases in South Vietnam and Army spokesmen said such a thing is apparently permissible under current regulations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am astonished that in your impressive Jan. 11 array of letters protesting the insanity of our transportation system not one addressed itself to the most glaring injustice of allthe failure to impose tolls on the free East River crossings.

title: Stanford Sitin Halted
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 24 (UPI)Sheriff's deputies forced Prof. H. Bruce Franklin and 350 of his supporters today from the Old Union office building on the Stanford University campus, where the demonstrators had staged a sitin. There were no arrests and no injuries. Professor Franklin, a radical Marxist, was dismissed by the university last week.

title: Hugh Croll, a Copy Editor With The Times 192855
description: SOUTH LAGUNA, Calif., Jan. 24Hugh Croll, a copy editor on The New York Times from 1928 until his retirement in 1955, died of cancer on Jan. 14 in South Coast Community Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Human Resources
description: WASHINGTON, Tan. 24The Nixon Administration's new budget calls for increases, dramatic in some areas, for social needs. But the gains are largely a result of legislation already enacted or long pending. The budget discloses little in the way of major social initiatives.

title: Gold fein Is Proud of His Yacht That Rides in Sea of Viewers
description: Philip E. Goldfein stood on the teaktextured deck of the whiteandblue fiberglass Concorde 41 doublecabin flyingbridge power yacht yesterday and patted the stainlesssteel railings as if he were the owner. The funny thing about it, he was.

title: Two Admit Stealing $2Million From City's Medicaid Program
description: Two men pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to charges of grand larceny and conspiracy in the theft of more than $2million from the city's Medicaid program.

title: Washington Post Writer Wins 1971 Braun Award
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Aaron Latham was named today as the winner of the Newspaper Guild's 1971 Heywood Broun Award for his fourpart series in The Washington Post on conditions in the District of Columbia's Junior Village for homeless children.

title: CEREAL MONOPOLY BY 4 TOP MAKERS CHARGED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Federal Trade Commission accused four food manufacturers today of illegally monopolizing the market for breakfast cereals and thus forcing consumers to pay artificially inflated prices for the products.

title: John D. Rockefeller 4th Enters West Virginia's Governor Race
description: BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Jan. 24  John D. Rockefeller 4th, the only wellknown Democrat in a wealthy Republican family, opened his campaign today for Governor of West Virginia.

title: Notes on People
description: I was raised in the tradition of the Navy and I want to follow it, said Barbara J. Brimmer, who was introduced by Senator Jacob K. Javits as his nominee to the 1972 plebe class at the United States Naval Academy.

title: 3 From Price Panel Seek Broad Support
description: A fair assessment of the success of the nation's price controls cannot be made until April, Robert F. Lanzillotti, a member of the Administration's Price Commission, said yesterday.

title: A New Era for the Renwick Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 After 111 years of being kicked around as a clothing warehouse, an Army office building, a courthouse for aggrieved citizens and a convention hall for pigeons, the Renwick Gallery finally has become what it was meant to bea home for the arts.

title: Basketball Ratings WRITERS POLL
description: The leading college teams, with points tabulated on a 201816141210987654321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace votes in parentheses). W. L. Pts.

title: Fregosi a Happy Met at Club Luncheon
description: The New York Mets signed three more players yesterday and introduced a fourthJim Fregosi, who soon will become the 46th man to guard third base in the club's 10year history.

title: Dolphin Player Stricken; 180 Feared in Danger
description: MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP)The Miami Dolphins wide receiver, Otto Stowe, has been hospitalized with infectious hepatitis and about 180 peoplehis teammates, their families and friendswill have to be immunized, the team disclosed today.

title: Soviet Notes Arms Outlay
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 (AP)The Soviet Union said tonight that the main feature of the budget presented to Congress by President Nixon was a decision to continue the arms race. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, cited the figure for military spending and said: It should be noted that this figure does not show the volume of all the military spending of the United States, for a number of allocations in this field are camouflaged in other articles of the budget.

title: Nixon Budget Highlights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Following are highlights President Nixon's new budget:

title: $5Billion Urban Reform Proposed by Architects
description: A national policy statement on the country's growth and development was released by the American Institute of Architects yesterday over the strong protest of some of the institute's members.

title: EXACTA MARK SET AT LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 A. L. Rose's Ah Netta and P. L. Charles and T. Grissom's Cold Biscuit combined for a record exacta payoff of $10,721.60 in the third race at Liberty Bell race track today, easily surpassing the track's previous high payoff of $3,486.40.

title: Budget Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  As every householder knows, the cost of running a house has been steadily going up. The White House is no exception.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AMARILLO, Tex., Jan. 24 (AP)West Texas State dominated the backboards and defeated Long Island University, 8469, tonight.

title: Marcos Pledges Effort to Open Ties With Moscow and Peking
description: MANILA, Jan. 24 (UPI) President Ferdinand E. Marcos today pledged to strive for establishment of diplomatic relations with both the Soviet Union and China because today is the era of multiple alignments.

title: Antipoverty Chief Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Phillip Sanchez was sworn in today as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity and pledged to reinstate the credibility, audibility and visibility of the antipoverty agency.

title: Buffalo Ordered to Submit A School Integration Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24The Buffalo Board of Education was told today by the State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Hyquist, to implement a sevenyearold order to integrate its schools and provide him with a desegregation plan by April 1.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24For the carious programs administered by the Environmental Protection Agency, President Nixon's total 1973 budget request is alinost exactly the same as last year.

title: Shop Talk
description: A kitchen stove for $2,500? Well, why not, reasons the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which has introduced a cooler version of that status symbol of today's kitchen the smoothsurfaced countertop range. It's those two characteristicsthe cooler surface and the higher pricethat provide the key differences between the CTII Cool/Heat appliance and the six or seven competitive models that preceded it on the market.

title: Wyman Resigning to Avoid A Reappointment Battle
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24The State Commissioner of Social Services, George K. Wyman, announced today that he would resign to avoid an expected Senate fight over his reappointment.

title: CHICAGO BOARD FINES 2 MEMBER CONCERNS
description: The Chicago Board of Trade announced yesterday it had taken disciplinary action against two member concerns and their executive officers for violations of the hoard's rules and regulations. The board is a market for futures of agricultural commodities.

title: JOB RIGHTS POWER STALLS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Administration forces in the Senate, capitalizing on the absence of two Democratic Presidential candidates, succeeded today in holding back a proposal to give strong enforcement powers to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: The Return of a Native: II
description: BERKELEY, Calif.To a Westerner, life in new China may appear earnest, sober and rather serious. We heard no firecrackers and saw no fireworks. We saw no Buddhist monks or Taoist priests. Nor did we see a single bridal procession or funeral cortege. The pigeons in Peking no longer have whistles that hum as they fly, but the sparrows are coming back. There are no dogs in the cities, but they are still in the villagesand they look now as though someone fed them. Small boys are still able to sleep happily on the backs of the water buffaloes they tend.

title: Advertising:
description: The president of L. W. Frohlich & Co./Intercom International has submitted his resignation to the board of directors because it has kept him in the dark as to the future of the agency.

title: Drivers Jeer and Applaud At Hearing on Gypsy Cabs
description: Three hundred enthusiastic but orderly gypsy cab drivers and industry officials alternately booed and cheered yesterday at a City Council hearing on legislation that would regulate their business for the first time.

title: DR. HANS L. STEINER
description: LINDENHURST, L. I., Jan. 24 Dr, Hans L. Steiner, a physician in general practice in this area for 35 years, died today. He was 71 years old and lived at 373 South Wellwood Avenue.

title: PRICES FALL AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered their fourth consecutive losses yesterday as both lists fell sharply in lighter trading.

title: Jackson Says Wallace Seeks To Disrupt Democratic Voting
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Senator Henry M. Jackson charged today that Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was out to make a shambles of the Democratic party by entering primaries as a Democrat.

title: Stage:
description: Theater as mystery and ritual  the theater as a nonverbal experience of tragedy  this is what Andrei Serban's cryptic reworking of Medea at the La Mama is all about. It is a potent theatrical event, and it offers deep insights into the nature of the dramatic experience.

title: CABINET MINISTER REPLACED IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 24President Salvador Allende Gossens named a new Minister of Interior today, filling the chief political post in the Cabinet in the first step toward reorganization of the Government.

title: NEW STATISTICS ON JOBS PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Government is planning to start collecting new statistics next year that will tell a more accurate and detailed story of how many people are unemployed, which type of workers are getting the biggest wage increases and what industries are the main sources of inflation.

title: 3 SOVIET SKIPPERS ARE CHARGED BY U. S.
description: ANCHORAGE, Jan. 24 (AP)The commander of a Soviet fishing fleet and two ship masters were charged today with illegal fishing activities in United States waters. The three were in command of two Soviet herring boats seized in the Bering Sea by the United States Coast Guard.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Colley Windflow, dean of American political analysts, yielded a moment of his day. Turning from a hot typewriter, he displayed his latest analysis of the political situation.

title: Nixon Asks Hospital in Bronx
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24Governor Rockefeller said today that President Nixon's budget for fiscal 1973 contained an appropriations request for construction of a new Veterans Administration hospital in the Bronx. It would cost about $65million. The initial request from Mr. Nixon to Congress is for $3.6million.

title: Intelsat 4, in Final Orbit, Is Primed to Cover Trip
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI)The new Intelsat 4 communications satellite shifted into its final stationary orbit high above the central Pacific tonight and engineers started preparing it for coverage of President Nixon's visit to China next month.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: N.H.L. Fails to Agree on Realignment
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 24  The National Hockey League's hoard of gcniernors formally awarded new franchises to Long Island and Atlanta today, but failed to reach agreement on a fourdivision alignment for the 197273 season.

title: Reagan Asks Aide Accused In Bribe Case to Resign
description: SACRAMBNTO, Calif., Jan. 24 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan asked today for the resignatton of Kerry Mulligan, the State Water Resources Control Board chairman, who was accused of attempting to bribe a Honolulu urban renewal official.

title: Swedes Upset Soviet Six
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 24 (AP) Sweden upset the defending world champion Soviet Union ice hockey team, 43, today as Bjorn Palmquist scored the winning goal with three minutes to play.

title: Canadian Air Controllers Reject Strike Settlement
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 24The air traffic controllers tonight rejected by a 5 to 1 vote a tentative settlement of the strike that has grounded all domestic airline operations and barred international flights over Canada.

title: RENT RISES TOTAL $87MILLION HERE
description: Twothirds of the tenants in the city's 1.2million rentcontrolled apartments will owe a total of $87million more in rent this year, city rent officials estimate.

title: MillionDollar Lottery Postponed by the State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) New York, State lottery officials today postponed next month's sale of milliondollar special lottery tickets until the summer so the sale will not compete with the lucrative weekly drawing, which was started last week.

title: G. D. Searle, Ethyl and ForemostMcKesson Raise Incomes
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday higher earnings and sales for the final quarter of 1971 and the year as a whole.

title: Sports of The Times
description: As Pat Matzdorf gazed upward with wondering eyes after landing on the foam rubber mattress, his lips moved in an almost involuntary exclamation and he sounded as if he had just committed a crime.

title: U.S. Reports 3 More Attacks in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24The United States Command today reported three more attacks by American aircraft on North Vietnamese missile and antiaircraft sites, making a total of five such incidents reported in the last 48 hours.

title: No Casualties, Syria Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24A Syrian military spokesman was quoted by the Damascus radio today as having said that Syrian air defenses drove off Israeli fighter planes that attacked a guerrilla base north of Dera. The spokesman reportedly said that there had been no casualties or property damage.

title: Iowa Democrats Hold Caucuses, First Step in Picking Delegates
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 24 Iowa Democrats made their way along icy roads to meetings in snowshrouded churches, schools and homes tonight to begin the selection of the state's 46 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: The NotSoHot Idea
description: The Hot Rock is a new movie about a diamond theft from the Brooklyn Museum and at least for tonight, tickets are going at scalpers rates$50 and $100 apiece. The showing tonight is billed as a special tribute to former Deputy Mayor Richard Aurelio, who recently left city government to head Mayor Lindsay's Presidential campaign. It is a fundraising event to help finance that campaign.

title: Bridge:  8 Teams Remain Unbeaten In Von Zedtwitz Knockout
description: Eight teams remain unbeaten in the Greater New York Bridge Association's double knockout team championship for the Von Zedtwitz trophy from an original entry of 64 teams.

title: Exchange of Visits by Sato and Kosygin Planned
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24  Foreign Minister Takeo Fukuda said tonight that Japan and the Soviet Union had agreed on exchanging visits of their heads, of government in the near future.

title: $875MILLION SUIT BY TELEX HITS I.B.M.
description: The Telex Corporation has added its name to the list of companies suing the International Business Machines Corporation for alleged violation of the antitrust laws.

title: Fighting Erupts in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 24 (UPI)An almost monthlong lull on Cambodian battlefields was broken today when sharp fighting broke out in the marshlands 12 miles east of Pnompenh.

title: EDUARDO PROPPER
description: Eduardo Propper de Callejon, a retired Spanish diplomat, who had served in the embassy in Washington as charg d'affaires and as minister councilor from 1949 to 1956, died Jan. 11 in London at the age of 76.

title: Villanova Wins
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (AP) Led by a 28point contribution from Hank Siemiontkowski, Villanova downed St. Bonaventure, 8772, before a sellout crowd of 3200 in the Villanova fieldhouse tonight.

title: Penn Central's Jersey Service Criticized
description: Ontime performances as low as 50 per cent, dirty cars and truncated scheduled on Penn Central commuter lines in New Jersey were discussed at a meeting of railroad and New Jersey Department of Transportation officials yesterday in Philadelphia.

title: Los Angeles Protest Se
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP)  The National Peace Action Coalition says it has chosen Los Angeles as the West Coast site of an antiwar demonstration April 22.

title: A CHAIR IS SET UP IN PEACE STUDIES
description: A professorship in peace studies, one of the first in the country, is to be established at Colgate University in Hamilton, N. Y.

title: Sometimes Second Best Is Best When Owners and Trainers Bet on Horses
description: A record $10,721.60 exacta, on which the owners of the secondplace horse won $53,388, touched off a debate here yesterday over the regulations governing exotic wagering.

title: All Wives Ruled Equal In U.S. Foreign Service
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Young American diplomatic wives overseas need no longer do laundry for the ambassador's wife, pack or unpack her personal effects or help prepare sandwiches for embassy receptions.

title: REACTION IS MIXED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25President Nixon's eightpoint peace proposal was applauded tonight by Congressional supporters of the Administration, but was greeted with a mixture of skepticism and surprise by critics of the Vietnam War.

title: Transcript of the President's Address to the Nation on U.S. Policy in Vietnam
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised address last night on Vietnam policy, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Redistricting Plan In Minnesota Cuts Legislature to 140
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 25 (UPI)A threejudge Federal court panel reapportioned the Minnesota Legislature today, cutting its membership to 140 from 202 and ordering all legislators to stand for election this fall.

title: Louis P. Politi, Horticulturist Of the Botanical Garden, Dies
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 25Louis P. Politi, chief horticulturist since 1955 of the New York Botanical Garden, died last Wednesday in Mount Vernon Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 55 years old and lived at 312 East Prospect Avenue.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the oddities, or perhaps inequities, of the scoring table is the advantage to be derived by sacrificing against a grand slam when the vulnerability is in your favor. If your opponents bid to a vulnerable seven hearts, which they are due to make, you can make a paper profit in seven spades doubled, not vulnerable, if you can make two tricks in a duplicate or Chicago game, or three tricks at rubber bridge.

title: A Dozen Dissidents Criticize the President and the Government in the People's State of the Union
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25A dozen dissidents, ranging from Ralph Nader to a Mississippi pulpwood cutter, took President Nixon and the Government to task today in what they called the people's state of the union.

title: PATROLMAN IS SLAIN; GIRLFRIEND ACCUSED
description: An offduty motorscooter patrolman was stabbed to death at about 5 A.M. yesterday in his girlfriend's Queens apartment.

title: Nixon Aide Says Disclosure Had Domestic Aims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25They White House explained tonight that President Nixon had decided to reveal the details of secret Vietnam peace negotiations because secrecy had fostered unacceptable political divisions at home.

title: New Zealand Boy Saved By Harlem Globetrotters
description: NAPIER, New Zealand, Jan. 25 (Reuters)The touring, Harlem Globetrotters holped in the rescue of 9yearold local boy from pcunding surf at this resort town today.

title: American Airlines Unit Elects a New Chairman
description: Carter L. Burgess, former chairman of the American Machine and Foundry Company and former United States ambassador to Argentina has been elected chairman of Sky Chefs, Inc., a subsidiary of American Airlines, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Burgess will succeed Marion Sadler as chairman of Sky Chefs, which does airline catering and operates hotels. Mr. Sadler, who recently underwent surgery, is convalescing at his home in Tucson, Ariz. Albert C. Ferrari will continue as president of Sky Chefs.

title: Consultants Differ on Ownership
description: Two leaders of the management  consulting fraternity yesterday, argued  genteelly, of course  as to whether private firms or those owned publicly or by institutions represented the future of their profession.

title: Court Backs a Prisoner's Right To Say What He Wants in Diary
description: A prisoner's right to say whatever he likes in his diary was upheld 9 to 3 yesterday by the Federal appeals court here.

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg discussing her post at Columbia
description: In a new accelerating competition among the nation's law schools, Columbia University has just scored a major coup: its law school, to its undisguised glee, has just bid for and won a woman for the job of full professorthe first in its I I 4year history.

title: Impeach Rockefeller Over Attica, Buffalo Assemblyman Demands
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25A resolution calling for the impeachment of Governor Rockefeller for lawless acts of officialdom in the state's handling of the Attica Correctional Facility uprising was introduced in the Assembly today and immediately set off bitter exchanges.tion, he charged that there was a plot by the Governor to encourage inmates to attack observers so the state would have a reason to go into the prison with force.

title: DRAMATIC SINGING BY MORGANA KING
description: Twice Oscar Peterson, the jazz pianist, has been scheduled to make his debut at the Rainbow Grill. And twice he has been forced to cancel the engagement because of illness.

title: N.H.L. TO RETAIN 2DIVISION SETUP
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 25 (AP)  The National Hockey League solved its realignment problem today by assigning the new Long Island and Atlanta franchises to the already existing East and West Divisions.

title: Flying Tiger Profit Up
description: The Flying Tiger Corporation realized a 90 per cent increase in earnings last year on a revenue gain of 69 per cent, the report disclosed yesterday.

title: 4,000 in South Carolina Charmed by Yevtushenko
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 25  When a University of South Carolina student presented some flowers here last night to Yevgeny Yevtushenko, he declared, Ah, you see, flowers are better than bullets.

title: DR. MARIE HEMPHILL, ENGLISH PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Marie de Kiewiet Hemphill, assistant professor of English at Englewood Cliffs College in New Jersey, died of cancer Monday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 40 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title: Rockets Repulse Blazers
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Houston Rockets lost all but 4 points of a 35point lead but held on to defeat the Portland Trail Blazers, 118104, tonight despite scoring only 20 points in the fourth quarter.

title: Market Place:New Riklis Bid Recalls Another
description: If some shareholders of J. J. Newberry are apprehensive over the bid Monday evening by Meshulam Riklis to buy nearly half of the shares of the varietystore chain, it is perhaps understandable.

title: Auto Makers Back Gas Tax for Transit
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25  The auto industry, in a major shift in policy, has decided to back legislation in Michigan that would divert part of the revenue from taxes on gasoline to support and develop public mass transportation in the state's major cities.

title: Latin Bank Seeks Capital
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 25Governors of the InterAmerican Bank met in Brasilia today to seek a way to obtain capital from nations outside the Americas, without giving them voting powers.

title: CLARENCE BARTOW, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Clarence W. Bartow, a former vice president and director of the investment banking firm of Drexel Firestone, Inc., died Monday night at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N. Y.

title: Four Die as Gale Winds Buffet City; Buildings Damaged, Utility Lines Felled
description: Winds of gale force savaged the metropolitan area yesterday in a fury of destruction that caused at least four deaths and untold thousands of dollars in property damage.

title: Journalist Who Disclosed the Mylai Story Now. Charges U.S officers Destroyed Papers
description: Seymour M. Hersh, the journalist who first disclosed the details of the Mylai massacre, has assorted that members of the Army's Americal Division destroyed documents about the incident to protect the officers involved.

title: U.S TRADE DEFICIT FIRST SINCE 1888
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The United States imported more than it exported last year for the first time in this century, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: JOHNSON LIBRARY IS OPEN TO PUBLIC
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 25 About 250,000 education documents from the Johnson Administration were open today to researchers at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library.

title: Prague Extends Recognition
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 25 (Reuters)Bangladesh has been recognized by Czechoslovakia, the fifth Eastern European country to do so, the official press agency reported today. It said recognition was extended yesterday, the same day as the Soviet Union did so.

title: Thousands of City Employes Attend Lindsay Benefit
description: Dozens of top city officials and thousands of city employes filled most of the Radio City Music Hall last night at a $300,000 benefit for the Lindsay for President campaign.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is not easy being a 30yearold virgin in this day and age, attests Fortune Dundy (Fortuneerhymes with have your sayto the world), the heroine of Cynthia Buchanan's first novel. Or more to the point of the book, it is not easy for Fortune not to be a virgin.

title: CANCER STUDY HALT URGED AT CINCINNATI
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 25Warren Bennis, president of the University of Cincinnati, Was urged today to order discontinuance of the totalbody radiation project that has been conducted by the school's medical center for the last 11 years and to instruct the medical center to cooperate fully with a Congressional hearing to be held in Cincinnati next month.

title: Irvings Plan Trip Here
description: MADRID, Jan. 25Mr. and Mrs. Irving said on Ibiza today that they planned to fly to Barcelona and on to New York from Ibiza tomorrow despite efforts by the Swiss police to persuade them to come to Zurich.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mayor Lindsay recently announced construction of pilings for the $750million North River Pollution Control Plant, due for completion in 1979. Most citizens agree with the Mayor that environmental concern is on the front burner, as it should be. But the price tag needs to be broken down into shares comprehensible to individuals.

title: PROFIT IS RECORDED BY MILWAUKEE ROAD
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad announced last night that its consolidated income for 1971 rose to $2,402,631, before extraordinary items, in contrast to a consolidated loss in 1970 of $10,992,173.

title: Walter Wilgus Dead at 80; Led Voice of America Unit
description: Walter Wilgus, retired director of the Far East division of the Voice of America, died Saturday in Rocky Mount, N. C. He was 80 years old and lived in Rocky Mount.

title: Budgeting for the Status Quo
description: A President's budgetary policy can be judged by three standards: Its overall impact on the national economy, its assignment of priorities, and the way it distributes tax burdens among different groups in the society. In our view, Mr. Nixon's budget policies are proving deficient in all three respects.

title: Ottawa and Air Controllers Join To Try Again for Strike Accord
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 25Government negotiators met with union officials late today after 1,600 striking airtraffic controllers rejected a tentative settlement. Prospects, if any, for an end to the strike were not immediately apparent.

title: ROMNEY PLEDGES QUALITY HOUSING
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25 With housing production goals now being met, the Government will stress quality rather than quantity, George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, told the nation's home builders today.

title: POLICEMAN IN ULSTER IS BELIEVED HOSTAGE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 25A policeman was kidnapped and three others were shot in a new wave of terrorist attacks today.

title: Text of the Joint Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Following is the text a proposal by the Governments of the United States and South Vietnam for a negotiated settlement of the Indochina conflict, as released by the White House tonight:

title: The Return of a Native: III
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Were we shown a succession of Potemkin villages? Certainly the Chinese want to make a good impression; we would do the same. But in Szechwan Province and elsewhere, we saw many places never before visited by foreigners (it becomes quite easy to recognize where you are a novelty). And we did not wear blindfolds. One does not need to enter and inspect a commune to be able to see, from the road as one drives past, the number of new dwellings (built and owned by the commune members). In the old days, a new farmhouse was a rarity.

title: 3 Kennedy Center Shows Due Here
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts expects to have three productions playing in New York by midsummer, two on Broadway and one at the Metropolitan Opera, Roger L. Stevens, the center's chairman, said yesterday.

title: Dance: Stars Shine at Library Gala
description: The Gala Performance to Save the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library, which took place at the New York City Center on Monday night, should be more a matter of record than a subject for criticism. The dancers were, after all, giving their services for this very particular dance charity, and the City Center of Music and Drama donated its 55th Street Theater for the evening. However, it was happily one of those nights when criticism was not only inappropriate, it was also unnecessary. Everything went as right as a waltz.

title: Thieu, on Radio, Endorses Election Plan
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 26President Nguyen Van Thieu endorsed in a radio address to the nation today the suggestion for a new South Vietnamese presidential election and other parts of the latest allied peace plan.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 90 per cent of the 1,000 public school teachers, custodial workers and administrative staff members in Madison Township, N. J., went on strike yesterday morning.

title: YIELDS ADVANCE FOR STATE BONDS
description: Yields on highquality, taxexempt state bonds moved substantially higher yesterday, and investors decided they liked the interest rates they were being offered.

title: Anyway, the Courreges Show Wasn't Dull
description: PARIS, Jan. 25The Rothschild women are certainly doing their bit to stiffen the morale of the couture here. Today, the Baroness Guy de Rothschild her husband is chief of the clanturned up at the Lanvin collection and chatted amiably with Meryl Lanvin, whose husband owns the house.

title: U.S. Offers Denial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The State Department said today that it was just plain inaccurate to assert that the United States had unnecessarily held up the transmission of the Pakistani surrender message to the Indian authorities.

title: ANTIBUSING PLEA IS SIGNED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, added his influence today to the movement in Congress for a constitutional amendment that would prohibit the busing of children to integrate schools.

title: P.S. C. APPROVES OVERHEAD LINE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25The Public Service Commission today approved the Consolidated Edison Company's controversial plan to construct 64 miles of overhead power lines through Rockland, Orange and Sullivan Counties.

title: Cavaliers Lose 11th in Row
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (UPI) Cazzie Russell scored 35 points and Jim Barnett added 29 tonight to pace the Golden State Warriors to a 117111 National Basketball Association victory over Cleveland as the Cavaliers dropped their 11th game in a row.

title: President's Peace Proposals
description: The Vietnam peace proposals which President Nixon made public last night represent a major advance over the Administration's previous public positions on ending the war. They therefore merit support from all shades of American opinion and a positive response from the other side.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Even at this late date, I must express my horror at finding James Reston in a mistake. In his Dec. 26 column, he says that Jim Hawkins was told to keep the boat steady  in the storm in Stevenson's Kidnapped.' What, was Mr. Reston never a boy? Did he never identify with Jim Hawkins, hero of Treasure Island?

title: Cigarette Maker Up for71  Dips in Final Period
description: American Brands, Inc., attained record sales and earnings in 1971 for the fifth consecutive year despite a fourthquarter dip in profits, Robert B. Walker, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.

title: Soviet and U.S. Negotiators Meet 2 Hours in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Jan. 25 (Reuters)Soviet and American delegations at the talks on limitation of strategic arms met here today for more than two hours in the 113th full session since the meetings began in late 1969.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Shirley J. Southwick's OpEd article (Jan. 14) The Psychological Side. Effects of Vasectomy is most unfortunate. The myths about vasectomy are prevalent enough without reinforcing them.

title: Lakers Triumph
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) Gale Goodrich, bucking a third quarter surge, scored 33 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers rallied to defeat the Phoenix Suns, 129119.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Floyd Patterson, a man of peace whose life has been devoted to beating men with his fists, stood up in public yesterday and, with shy and halting eloquence, tried to explain why a gentleman of means in his 38th year needs to go on fighting. This was at a luncheon arranged by Madison Square Garden to announce a 10round match for Feb. 11 between Patterson and big, brash Oscar Bonavena. A humble petitioner, the former heavyweight champion the world, has waited patiently for this bout for more than a year while the swaggering Argentine came up with a string of excuses that caused four postponements. Now they were together at one long table, and the contrast was like punch in the nose. Bonavena, called Ringo in Buenos Aires where he moonlights as television performer, mugged and postured and preened his long dark curls, firing off such witticisms as his limited English would permit. Three times he referred to Patterson as his grandfather, a designation this 29yearold clearly regarded as hilarious. Everybody look at me? he cried when it was announced that the fight would be sold for home television in most major American cities.

title: NarcoticsRelated Deaths Here Reported at 1,259 for Last Year
description: A total of 1,259 persons died from narcoticsrelated causes in New York City last yearmore than in any other previous year. Of the total, 624 were 24 years old or younger.

title: Persian Gulf State Gets a New Ruler After Assassination
description: SHARJA, Jan. 25 (Reuters)The ruling family of the Persian Gulf emirate of Sharja totoday elected an Interim Ruler to succeed the emir, who was shot to death in an attempted coup d'etat.

title: CARSALES RATE BEST IN 6 YEARS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25Domestic car sales in midJanuary were the best for the period in six years.

title: Chambers Nephew Is Shot In Law Office
description: A 61yearold lawyer was shot in the head and critically wounded yesterday in his office at 501 Fifth Avenue following an argument with a client, the police said.

title: OHIO STATE WINS GAME, LOSES FIGHT
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (AP)  Sixth  ranked Ohio State whipped Minnesota, 5044, tonight in a Big Ten basketball game that was called with 36 seconds to play when a fight broke out under the Buckeyes basket.

title: Mayors Say Nixon's Budget Will Cut Urban Aid by $765Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The nation's bigcity Mayors asserted today that President Nixon's budget would reduce major urban programs by $765million in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Rockefeller Asks $23.6Million To Cover Deficiencies in Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25  Governor Rockefeller has sent the Legislature a $23.6million deficiency budget to cover unanticipated expenses in the $7.9billion budget for the state fiscal year that ends March 31.

title: PLAYGOERS LIKE EARLIER CURTAIN
description: A majority of theatergoers prefer the 7:30 o'clock curtain time for weeknight attendance at Broadway shows. On Saturday, however, the 8:30 P.M. starting time has top preference among patrons. And, in the area of pretheater dining habits, more than half of theater audiences dine in a New York restaurant or hotel before the show.

title: Council Votes First Funds For a Convention Center
description: The first financial step toward construction of a $100million convention center on midtown Manhattan's Hudson shore was approved by the City Council yesterday.

title: All in All, Whitney Museum Annual Is Best in Years
description: All in all, which means making the most of its virtues and the least of its shortcomings, the 1972 Annual, which opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday, is the best in years. It scores about 5050 between paintings you're glad to see there and paintings you'd like to junk, which is fair enough, since no two people would junk the same half. So let's accept itwith relief, for the annuals lately have been sorely, and justly, belabored.

title: Knicks Win, 109106, Halting Celtics Streak at 5
description: In a game that could almost be considered vital to their hopes of finishing first in the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association, the Knicks last night squeezed out a 109.106 triumph over the Boston Celtics before a capacity crowd of 19,588 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Camilla Gray Prokofiev, Historian of Russian Art
description: Camilla Gray Prokofiev, a historian of Russian art, died of hepatitis Dec. 17 at Sochi on the, Black sea, according to word received here this week by Anne Fremantle, the art scholar and writer. She was 35 years old and the wife of Oleg Prokofiev, a son of the composer.

title: SUGAR FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Prices of the world No. 11 nearby sugar contract futures rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The March, 1972, contract closed at 8.68 cents a pound, up from 8.54 cents a pound on Monday. The May, 1972, option closed at 8.66 cents a pound, up from 8.51 cents a pound.

title: Executive Changes
description: Cornell C. Maier has been elected president of the Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation. He succeeds T. 3. Ready Jr., who becomes chairman of the executive committee and continues as chief executive officer.

title: GLEN MITCHELL
description: Glen Mitchell, an artist who had been professor of painting and display at the Fashion Institute of Technology, died Monday night in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 77 years old, and lived at 550 West 157th Street.

title: U.S. Reports Attacks on 3 Sites in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 (AP)The United States command reported today for the second day that American planes had attacked three missileradar sites in North Vietnam.

title: Injured Bengals Player Makes Important Gain
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 25 (UPI)Ken Dyer, a Cincinnati Bengals defensive back, walked out of St. Mary's Hospital today, winning a partial victory in a fourmonth battle to overcome paralysis.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Development Program, governing council  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Aborigines in Australia Given New Land Rights
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 25 Prime Minister William McMahon announced new land rights and other benefits for Australia's 140,000 aborigines today. In effect, however, the policy reaffirms a previous repudiation of aboriginal claims to ownership of tribal areas.

title: Auto Industry Drug Plan
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UPI)The American Motors Corporation and the United Automobile workers announced today agreement on establishing program fo rthe treatment and rehabilitation of drug and alcohol abuse among 11,000 workers.

title: Southern Railway Posted A Record Profit for 1971
description: The Southern Railway Company, one of the nation's most profitable railroads, yesterday announced record revenues and earnings for 1971.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP AS RALLY FALTERS
description: Stock prices fell yesterday morning, rallied briskly at midsession on hopes for new Vietnam peace proposals and then moved lower again in afternoon trading.

title: 65 Million Saw Super Bowl
description: Nielsen ratings showed the Super Bowl game between the Dallas Cowboys and Miami Dolphins was watched on television in 20,450,000 homes by an estimated 65 million viewers, 74 per cent of all those watching television at the time, the Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday.

title: Man Killed and 17 Felled By Gas Fumes in Harlem
description: A 51yearold man was killed and five other adults and 12 children overcome by noxious fumes last night in their Harlem tenement, the police reported.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Mixed At Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Yields on United States Treasury bills moved narrowly in both directions in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of those shortterm securities. December's auction produced a 3.930 per cent average rate for ninemonth bills and 3.927 for oneyear bills.

title: 73 Horses Sold at Hialeah In First Night of Auction
description: MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP)Opening night of the Hialeah horse sales last night brought an average price per horse of $14,826 and attracted a record crowd of 2,500 persons.

title: Oil Concern Gains in Year but Lags For Quarter
description: Cheers were not the order of the day in the oil industry as a number of major companies released earnings reports for the full year and final quarter of 1971.

title: TV: Search for the Nile
description: Last night at 7:30 the National Broadcasting Company presented the first two of six hourlong episodes that dramatize, in painstaking detail, The Search for the Nile. A coproduction of the British Broadcasting Corporation and TimeLife Films, the series was produced by Christopher Balling, who used African locations and factual documents to stay as rigidly as humanly possible to the plain unvarnished facts.

title: Republic's Earnings Plummet for Year as Sales Grow
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported gains in net income for the fourth quarter despite lower sales. Sales and net income for the full year ran higher than in 1970.

title: Prospective Berrigan Jurors Asked for Personal Feelings on Vietnam War and Catholics
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 25  Three prospective women jurors in the conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists, spoke up in court today to reveal their personal feelings against the war in Vietnam.

title: City Welfare Union Accused of Stalling New SpeedUp Plan
description: Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator, charged yesterday that union was illegally blocking plan to speed up closings of 2,400 workrelief cases.

title: I.B.M. to Increase Payout Sc to $1.35
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and several other companies announced yesterday that they were raising their dividends. A number of other concerns voted to omit or cut dividends. All changes were within Federal guidelines.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The Winston Western 500 stockcar race was over and Bobby Allison, runnerup to Richard Petty, was visiting in the press box. Someone told him A. J. Foyt, who had dropped out with a cracked transmission case, had said, I could have run up Allison's tailpipe any time I wanted to. Strong rhetoric is part of racing, but sometimes it is expedient to be diplomatic. Allison equivocated. Weeel, I don't know, he said at last in his Alabama drawl. If he could run up my tail and I had the faster car, I don't knower, something there doesn't fit into Alabama logic.

title: U. S. Said to Have Held Up Pakistani Surrender Message
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 25The brief war between India and Pakistan last month was prolonged by a day because the Pakistani message of surrender, conveyed to India through the United States, was held up in Washington, according to authoritative reports.

title: MUSE IS VICTOR IN IOWA CAUCUSES
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 25 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine won the largest share of the delegates in last night's Iowa precinct caucuses, late returns showed today.

title: Yale Six Beats Army, 65
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 25 Bob Kane, a center, scored three goals to lead Yale to 65 hockey victory over Army tonight, but the Elis were forced to withstand a rally by the cadets in the final three minutes to preserve the victory.

title: Sadat Says Outsiders Stirred Protest
description: CAIRO. Jan. 25President Anwar elSadat stood firm today against university students demonstrating for an unequivocal war policy against Israel, charging that the demonstrations had been instigated by outside elements to split Egypt's home front.

title: NEW HAT IN RING: MRS. CHISHOLM'S
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm announced her candidacy yesterday for the Democratic Presidential nomination  the first black woman to seek a majorparty Presidential nomination.

title: Carl T. Hayden Is Dead at 94; Arizonan in Congress 56 Years
description: MESA, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP)Carl Trumbull Hayden, who served in the United States Senate for 42 years, longer than any other man in the nation's history, died tonight. He was 94 years old.

title: Westmoreland Visits Saigon To Discuss War's Progress
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 26 (Reuters)Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Army Chief of Staff, arrived here today for talks with South Vietnamese and American military officials on the progress of the war.

title: Tito Plans a Major Party Overhaul to Avoid Crises
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25President Tito told the nation today that the Yugoslav Communist party would undergo a major reorganization to forestall crises such as the one over nationalism that recently erupted in the Republic of Croatia.

title: State Panel on Attica Urges Locally Based Prisons
description: The special state committee appointed after the Attica prison riot to recommend penal reform called yesterday for an end to the present prison system, with its central focus on bastillelike institutions better suited to the 19th century, and for the creation of a one with communitybased facilities and a whole constellation of degrees of security.

title: Japanese, Long in Cave, Now Hopes to Meditate
description: AGANA, Guam, Jan. 25 (UPI)  A Japanese Army sergeant who hid in the jungles of Guam for 28 years said today that after he returned home he would like to go up on a mountain and meditate.

title: Conservative Party Backs Ashbrook Against Nixon
description: The Conservative party of New York announced its support yesterday for Representative John M. Ashbrook, Republican of Ohio, for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: TOWN IS PLANNED AT DISNEY WORLD
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 25Walt Disney World, the $400million vacation complex that opened its gates four months ago, has been attracting so many visitors that Disney officials are worried about strangling on success.

title: Rangers Slate 3 Matinees
description: Three Ranger Sunday games have been switched to afternoon starting times. They are Sunday's game against the Minnesota North Stars, the following week's game against the Toronto Maple Leafs, and the final contest of the season on April 2, against the Montreal Canadiens. The games will begin at 2:05 P.M.

title: Giacomin Is Philosophical About His Ups and Downs
description: It seems to be the story of my life, said Ed Giacomin with a shrug yesterday. I'd give up three goals and then. Cesare Maniago or Don Simmons or Terry Sawchuk would replace me the next game. Now it's Gilles Villemure.

title: AMELIA H. MUNSON
description: Amelia Howard Munson, al librarian and author, died Friday at her home, 25 Tudor City Place.

title: SCRATCH AT BOWIE CAUSES CONFUSION
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 25 (AP)Eddie Blind, Bowie's starter, involved in a misunderstanding with stewards over a late scratch yesterday, became entangled in another controversy today.

title: PAY BOARD BACKS RAIL RAISES TIED TO COST CUTTING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Pay Board said today that it would approve wage increases of 10 per cent for 180,000 railroad trainmen later this year if a series of costcutting work rules were put into effect.

title: Rare Conditions Spawned GaleForce Winds in East
description: The winds that blew through New York yesterday were obeying simple laws of nature, but because of an unusual combination of atmospheric conditions that has not prevailed in this area for three years, they blasted with near hurricane force through the city's canyons.

title: Year Increase Is 4.2%
description: Eastern Air Lines, Inc., raised its 1971 net income by 4.2 per cent to $5,690,000, or 32 cents a share, from $5;461,000, or 39 cents a share, the year before, it was reported yesterday.

title: The Moral Cost of Chrome
description: The Nixon Administration has now taken an action that puts the United States in violation of the United Nations Charter and gives moral support, at a critical moment, to Rhodesia's white minority Government. Officials will doubtless say that the Treasury was bound by a proyision in the Military Procurement Act of 1971 to lift restrictions on imports of Rhodesian chromein spite of the mandatory sanctions invoked against Rhodesiawith American backingby the U.N. Security Council.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Shirley J. Southwick is perfectly right in bringing to the public's attention some of the unexpected situations which may result from vasectomy.

title: MISS CASALS GAINS IN WOMEN'S TENNIS
description: HINGHAM, Mass., Jan. 25 (AP)Rosie Casals of San Francisco defeated Corrine Molesworth of England in, threeset struggle today in the $18,000 Virginia Slims women's indoor tennis tournament.

title: Iowa Delegates: GrasRoot Voting Starts
description: CRESTON, Iowa, Jan. 25The snow was four inches deep, the temperature 8 degrees below zero and the wind was blowing 35 knots out of the northwest when the grandfather's clock in the hallway of the Creston Elks Club struck 8 last night.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Opposes Nixon Reelection
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that it would oppose President Nixon's reelection bid this year, regardless of whom the Democrats nominated.

title: Kremlin Warns Literary and Art Critics on Ideology
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 25  The Kremlin sharply attacked Soviet art and literary critics today for what it called easy tolerance of ideological backsliding and artistic trash and ordered them to improve their standards.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSSamuel, Passed away In Hollywood, Florida on January 24, 1972. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted father of Albert Abrahams and Sylvia Prosnit. Cherished grandfather of six and greatgrandfather of two. Dear brother of Philip. Reposing at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday P.M. to 10 P.M. Services Thursday, 2:15 P.M. Interment Acacia Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Pythias Camp for Underprivileged Children.

title: Laird Sees Peril in Atomic Attack Pulses
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird expressed concern today that the emergency command system that would direct the nation's response to a nuclear attack could be paralyzed by the electromagnetic pulses given off by the explosions.

title: Sargent to File Budget
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent will file with the legislature tomorrow a fiscal 1973 budget of slightly more than $2billion

title: Meers Is Named to S.I.P.C.
description: Henry W. Meers, a partner in White, Weld & Co., was nominated yesterday to be a director of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, the Governmentbacked unit that insures investors against losses in case of brokeragehouse failures. Mr. Meers, whose nomination is subject to Senate confirmation, is a govExchange.

title: Georgia Drug Bill Defeated
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Georgia Senate defeated today a bill calling for the death penalty for drug pushers. Under current Georgia law, a second conviction for selling hard narcotics provides a maximum penalty of life in prison. A first offense has a maximum penalty of 5 to 10 years in prison.

title: Antipoverty Legislation Scored By New O.E.O. Head at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The opening round of the 1972 battle over expansion of the Office of Economic Opportunity began today with the Nixon Administration announcing its opposition to major portions of new antipoverty legislation.

title: U. S. JUDGE STAYS RENT RAISES HERE
description: A Federal judge temporarily restrained housing officials here yesterday from permitting rent increases retroactive to Jan. 1 in 800,000 controlled apartments.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: CoBuild Companies, Inc., sold 500,000 shares and stockholders sold an additional 212,500 in a sale at $12 managed by Butcher & Sherrerd and Thomson & McKinnon Auchincloss. CoBuild, based in the Virgin Islands, builds low and moderate priced housing.

title: Prisoner Dies in Stabbing
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25 (AP)An inmate at Trenton State Prison died today of injuries suffered when he was stabbed repeatedly with a scissors blade by another inmate, according to a prison spokesman. He said the victim, John Woodridge, 25 years old who was serving a five to sevenyear term for assault, died of stab wounds inflicted last night by James Blake, who is serving a 12 to 30year sentence for a Burlington County murder committed in 1952.

title: Jerome Cowan, Character Actor Who Played in 100 Films, Dead
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 25 (AP) Jerome Cowan, the wellknown character actor, died yesterday at the age of 74. Mr. Cowan who appeared in more than 100 movies, came to the West Coast in 1936 after a stage career in New York.

title: Advertising:
description: Norman, Craig & Kummel, do you suppose the Vick Chemical Company is trying to tell you something? Is there a reason that it has assigned you the Lavoris Mouthwash account?

title: SONICS TROUNCED BY BUCKS, 12391
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP)Bob Dandridge scored 30 points and Kareem AbdulJabbar 26 tonight in leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 12391 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle Supersonics.

title: Utility Revenues Up
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971. The report, labeled a tentative income statement, placed operating revenues at $1,313,862,302 for 1971. This compared with $1,128,479,611 a year earlier. Net income rose to $145,183,831, or $2.35 a share, from $128,427,252, or $2.30 a share, in 1970.

title: DR. EDWARD E. PENN, C. C.N.Y. PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Edward E. Penn, a City College professor of English specializing in the drama, died of cardiac arrest Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 680 West End Avenue.

title: MONTE CARLO RALLY RUNS INTO BLIZZARD
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 25 (Reuters)  Positions switched dramatically in the Monte Carlo rally today as a blizzard swept across the Alps and part of the rally route, reducing visibility and delaying drivers.

title: Weight Watcher's Lunch: With Spaghetti on Menu?
description: Flanked by 28 former fatties, Mrs. Jean Nidetch, the curvaceous blond founder of Weight Watchers International, ate a few strands of spaghetti yesterday and dribbled meat sauce on her chin.

title: INTERESTING SONGS IN DIXON'S PROGRAM
description: Richard Dixon, baritone, has improved various aspects of his performances since his last appearance here, 11 months ago. His stage manner is more relaxed, his singing has gained in emotional involvement, his whole manner exudes greater confidence.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Kenneth Rush, named by President Nixon today to move from the ambassadorship to West Germany to the No. 2 post in the Defense Department, is said to have made a commitment and to have received one. He has agreed, Pentagon officials say, to serve for at least three years in defense, assuming that Mr. Nixon is reelected. And he has been assured that he will either continue as Deputy Secretary or be elevated to the job of Defense Secretary if the Republicans win in November.

title: Soviet Orbits Cosmos 472
description: MOSCOW, Jan 25 (AP)The Soviet Union launched today another unmanned Cosmos satellite, the 472d in the topsecret series.

title: Boat Show Offers a Wide Variety of Craft For InshoreOffshore Outboard Fisherman
description: Bertram has a new 38foot sportfisherman at the National Boat Show. Winner offers a 24foot family fishingbridge model. Egg Harbor is exhibiting a powerful biggame hunter and SportCraft has a 30foot sport fisherman on display. So does New Jersey Boat Works. Even the 48footplus turbinepowered Pacemaker, the the $130,000 queen of the show, is a sportfisherman.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISOn the eve of a long Asian journey one regards a world power balance that has tilted considerably over the last twenty years. Despite an active foreign policy, the United States, although remaining the West's only superpower, is no longer the unchallengeable force it used to represent.

title: Capitol Bomb Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (Reuters)  Policemen evacuated the central rotunda portion of the Capitol today after a telephoned bomb threat. The police searched the rotunda but did not find a bomb.

title: Spurring Technology
description: President Nixon's plan to spur American technological progress in civilian areas stems from a recognition that this country's technological edge has been diminishedan important holdback in its ability to compete in international markets. Another prod undoubtedly is the current research recession, with its consequent tragic fallout of highly trained engineers and scientists left unemployed.

title: Notes on People
description: Eudora Welty and Henry Steele Commager were named winners of gold medal awards of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, for the body of their work in the fields of fiction and history, respectively.

title: FLORIDA
description: STUART, Fla., Jan. 25From the air over Florida, the new gleaming houses spread out from the booming town, like sugar cubes in the sun. Here are the retired folks from the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, bronzed like the man and wife in the insurance advertisements, but mortgaged to the hilt and not quite so happy.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 13, 1972Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts was nominated for President by the Democratic National Convention todaythe first true draft of a nominee since that of Adlai E. Stevenson by the same party in 1952. It happened on the second roll call, despite the fact that even as late as this Mr. Kennedy urged the convention to choose another among the great Democratic candidates who are ready to carry your proud ensign.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The McGovern convention reforms which were instituted to make the Democratic party more open and representative of the broadst spectrum of opinion are, ironically, making the party less receptive to candidates by forcing state leaders to choose candidates very early before the actual convention. Previously, uncommitted and favoriteson delegations enabled potential candidates to seek support right up to and during the convention period. The new reforms, however, by requiring firm commitments, are forcing delegates to choose sides very early. And since all delegates naturally want to support a winner, they support the frontrunner, regardless of personal inclination.
