title: Midtown Planning Hearing Told Residents Fear Nighttime Crime
description: A hearing on the city's master plan for the East Side of midManhattan had hardly got underway at 8 P.M. when residents began to walk out. It proved, one speaker said, that people are afraid to stay late.

title: Threat to White Cloud Peaks
description: The White Cloud Peaks, about 250 in all, area spectacular range of mountains about thirty miles northwest of Sun Valley in Idaho. Averaging close to 10,000 feet in height, these snowcapped peaks are dotted with pure lakes, alpine meadows and clear, fastrunning streams. Virtually unpopulated, this rugged region has become the scene of intense political controversy because the American Smelting and Refining Company has staked out mining claims and would like to develop a huge open pit mine to extract molybdenum. Conservationminded voters defeated the Republican Governor of Idaho in 1970 because of his aggressive support of this mining venture.

title: City Bars 2 Drug Companies for Alleged Job Bias
description: Two major drug companies were barred yesterday from doing business with the city for allegedly failing to comply with the city's antidiscrimination policy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We protest The Times extraordinary editorial condemning Stanford English Professor Bruce Franklin. Its intemperate language, factual errors and misunderstanding of the issues sadden us profoundly. We had expected better of America's foremost paper.

title: DR. HENRY DUNNING
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Jan. 25Dr. Henry S Dunning, a retired clinical professor of neurology at Cornell Medical College, died today at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: Laotians Reoccupy Ridge
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25 (UPI) Government sources said today that Laotian forces were now back in control of the ridge that overlooks the Americanbacked base at Long Tieng.

title: Royals Owners Linked to Crime in Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Allegations by an Arizona Congressman that the owners of the Cincinnati Royals had business associations with underworld and organized crime figures provided a startling turn today to Senate hearings on bill that would permit the American and National Basketball Associations to merge.

title: HUGE MAIL FRAUD IS CHARGED TO 22
description: MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP)The authorities were rounding up 22 persons in seven states today after indictments by a Federal grand jury in what the Government said was a $150million mail fraud conspiracy.

title: Governors Seek Rail Link
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP)The Governors of the six New England states today urged the National Railroad Passenger Service Corporation to reestablish rail service linking Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont and New York with Montreal.

title: Tokyo Welcomes Plan; Hanoi Radio Is Silent
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 26 Japan welcomed President Nixon's latest Vietnam peace plan today as a hope for a settlement of the conflict.

title: Advertising:
description: Mary Wells Lawrence, who brought together Braniff and Pucci and then Hornet and Gucci, is now wedding Cardin and Javelin. Doesn't that sound yummy?

title: Hawks Down Braves, 123110
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 25 (UPI)Walt Bellamy and Pete Maravich led Atlanta in a 245 spree in the second period tonight as the Hawks went on to a 123110 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: Coast Dentist Is Convicted Of Helping Draft Evasion
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (Reuters)A dentist was convicted today on charges of fitting braces to a young man's teeth so the man could avoid the draft.

title: HARVEY'S STORES ASKS AIDE TO RESIGN
description: Harvey's Stores, Inc., announced yesterday that it and its subsidiary, the Liberty Circle Corporation, and its parent, Delanair, Inc., had requested David B. Rosenbloom to resign his positions.

title: Credit Card Law Puts $50 Limit on Liability
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)A new law that became effective yesterday provides that credit card owners cannot be held liable for more than $50 worth of unauthorized purchases regardless of when the card was issued.

title: Shapp Endorses Muskie
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 25 (UPI)Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania endorsed Senator Edmund J. Muskie today for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: $50Billion Rise Asked In National Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)  President Nixon asked Congress today for a $50billion rise in the national debt ceiling, the biggest single increase since World War II.

title: Jersey Plane Mechanic Wins $1Million Lottery
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)The New Jersey state lottery's 50cent millionaire fortune went today to an airplane mechanic and his wife from Hudson County.

title: More British Experts Warn of Ecological Disaster
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  A letter from 187 British scientists today warned of the gravity of the growing ecological crisis.

title: Nixon Said to Pick Industrialist as Envoy to Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Nixon intends to nominate Robert S. Ingersoll, chairman of the BorgWarner Corporation, to be Ambassador to Japan in an effort to upgrade the post at a time of strained relations between Washington and Tokyo, Administration sources said today.

title: Cost of Living Council Says A Price Suit Was in Error
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Cost of Living Council said today that it had been mistaken in suing Sharon Ruth, Inc., of Washington for failure to post prices.

title: Newhouse to Run Here For First Time Friday
description: Fred Newhouse never worries about the size or speed of an indoor track, but the challenge and tactics of indoor competition fascinate him.

title: Pakistan Accuses India
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25Pakistan, charging continuous ceasefire violations by the Indian Army, has requested an urgent meeting of the Security Council to consider the necessity of stationing United Nations observers on the border between India and West Pakistan.

title: Symbols from the collection of Henry Dreyfuss, at right. A key to their meaning Is at bottom left corner of page.
description: When language fails, symbols work. As wordless messengers they cut across barriers of nationality and race, speaking to minds that tongues cannot reach.

title: FOREIGN AID BILL IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The House of Representatives approved and sent to the White House today a longdelayed foreign aid bill authorizing a total of $2.75billion in economic and military assistance in the fiscal year ending on June 30.

title: News Analysis
description: It has become almost a clich that President Nixon always deals more effectively with the politics of his problems than he deals with the problems themselves. And this is what he appears to have done in announcing his secret peace negotiations with Hanoi. Politically, it is an effqctive move. It is Nearly awkward for his political opponents, who have been urging him to offer to set a date for total United States withdrawal from Vietnam and make arrangements for internationally supported elections in that country with some neutral government in power in Saigon.

title: McMillen Leads Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 25, (AP)Maryland's Terrapins shook off Buffalo in the second half tonight and defeated the Bulls, 8258.

title: A LEFRAK PROJECT OPPOSED AT HEARING
description: Queens residents filled the hearing room and lined the walls of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday in an effort to halt construction of two 20story apartment houses in the Kew GardensForest Hills area of that borough.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President addressed the nation by television and radio.

title: CONDORS CONQUER NETS IN OVERTIME
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25The Pittsburgh Condors reeled off 11 straight points early in an overtime period tonight to defeat the New York Nets 123116, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: SECRECY IS BROKEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25President Nixon disclosed to the American public tonight a proposal to end the war in Indochina that he said had been offered in secret channels three months ago but ignored by the North Vietnamese.

title: EDITH KEY HAINES, A COOKING EXPERT
description: Mrs. Edith Key Haines, a wellknown cook and hostess and the author of cookbooks, died yesterday at a convalescent home in Old Saybrook, Conn. She was believed to be in her seventies.

title: Senate Panel Told Crib Death Is Unsolved Despite High Toll
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Crib death, a mysterious disease that kills seemingly healthy babies while they sleep, claimed at least 10,000 lives last year, but the Federal Government spent only $46,000 on research and prevention of the disease, a Senate panel was told today.

title: Economic Analysis
description: President Nixon has called his prescription for deficit spending strong but necessary medicine. It certainly looks strong. In Mr. Nixon's three full fiscal years, 1971 through 1973, the gross Federal debt will increase by $110billion from $382billion to $493billion. The debt held by the publica better measure of its impact on financial marketswill rise by $86.4billion from $285billion to $371billion. Thus, in Mr. Nixon's own three fiscal years, the national debt in the hands of the public will climb by 30 per cent, the biggest rise since World War II.

title: THE ETERNAL IDOL IS PRESENTED HERE
description: Michael Smuin created his ballet, The Eternal Idol, as a homage to Rodin. In repose the work is reminiscent of Rodin's sculpture, but in action it is a contest between technique, clearly good and the choreography, clearly not so good. Sunday evening, the American Ballet Theater presented the work for the first time this season with Cynthia Gregory and Ivan Nagy, at City Center.

title: FANNY MAY PROFITS FOR71 UP SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's biggest supplier of funds to mortgage lenders, announced today that its 1971 earnings soared to $5.72 a share.

title: New Orders Fell 1.7% in December On Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25New orders for durable goods, which have followed a zigzag path for a year, turned down in December. They had risen in November.

title: Swiss Police Want to See the Irvings
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 25The police here said today that they wanted to see Clifford Irving, author of The Autobiography of Howard Hughes, and his wife, Edith Sommer Irving, in connection with the investigation into the deposit and withdrawal, by persons unknown, of $650,000 from McGrawHill, Inc.

title: EAST'S ALLSTARS DEFEAT WEST, 32
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 25It was most fitting that the National Hockey League's record scorer, Phil Esposito of the Boston Bruins, tallied the winning goal in tonight's AllStar game before 15,658 fans in the Metropolitan Sports Center.

title: DROP CONTINUES ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market continued to move lower yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Merger News
description: One of the nation's leading departmentstore chains disclosed here yesterday that it would expand its operations still further through the acquisition of 42 outlets in Indiana, Kentucky, Illinois and Ohio. The company, the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which operates Lord & Taylor here, said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire L. S. Ayres & Co., a departmentstore and discountstore chain with headquarters in Indianapolis.

title: Bhutto Says He Won't Sever Tie With Soviet on Bangladesh Issue
description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 25President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan said here today that he had ordered his Ambassador in Moscow to return home for consultations, but he indicated that Pakistan would not break diplomatic relations with the Soviet, Union as a result of its recognition of Bangladesh.

title: Fred Sherry's Cello Program Marked by Fierce Enthusiasm
description: Fred Sherry is a blackbearded young cellist who looks like Scriabin (that is, if Scriabin had worn his hair long and in a Geronimo knot), and he plays contemporary music with a fierce enthusiasm that the Russian mystic might have approved. Mr. Sherry, joined at times by the pianist and composer Charles Wuorinen, turned his expertise loose on recent works Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium.

title: Advertising:
description: Two agencies of the National Distillers Products Company are being givenadditional transfusions of the old juice.

title: RIVALRY IS REPORTED IN 2 DRUG AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Conflicts between two Federal agencies over narcotics investigations have reached the point where officials of the Customs Bureau have accidentally arrested agents of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, according to Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recently there has been considerable discussion between citizens block committees on the Upper West Side who ask for greater efforts to remove doubleparked cars and policemen who argue that their first attention should be to catch criminals. Several months ago we suggested to the city that it could hire unemployed people who would be given aerosol cans which would spray a dark color (which could be removed with some effort) on the windshields of doubleparked cars. They would not need any qualifications of a policeman other than being able to read the letters MD and DPL so they would not spray those cars. This would release policemen to perform their other duties, reduce unemployment and get the traffic moving again.

title: T.W.A. To Show Profit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., chairman of Trans World Airlines, said today that T.W.A. will announce Wednesday a $1millionto $5millionprofit for 1971 in contrast to a $64million loss in 1970.

title: Music:Handers'Athalia
description: Handel's Athalia has reputation as the first great English oratorio, and New Yorkers had a chance to catch up with this 239yearold work Monday night. It was presented by the Handel Society of New York in Carnegie Hall in what was billed as the first local professional performance.

title: A Fiscal Revolution At Trinity Parish
description: Trinity Parish, which was chartered by King William III of England in 1697 and has functioned like an ecclesiastical kingdom unto itself ever since, has quietly decreed a revolution.

title: William Munro, L.I. Judge, Dies After Tree Hits Car
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Jan. 25 William Munro, judge of the Suffolk County First District Court, died today after the car he was driving was struck by a tree blown down by the high wind. He was 44 years old.

title: Not So Wild a Political Dream
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 12, 1972Immediately after the adoption of the reports of the Committees on Rules, Credentials and Resolutions, Speaker Carl Albert, permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention, recognized Kevin White, a delegate from Massachusetts who is the Mayor of Boston.

title: Canada Hails Nixon Plan
description: OTTAWA, Jan, 26Mitchell W. Sharp, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, today applauded President Nixon's Vietnam peace proposal as a serious effort by the United States and South Vietnam to negotiate an end to the war.

title: MUNICIPAL BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: The taxexempt bond market, which seemed to be regaining its health Tuesday, had a setback yesterday.

title: Climate Experts Assay Ice Age Clues
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 26 After invading Nebraska and Colorado, the armadillos, faced with increasingly frigid weather, are in retreat from those states toward their ancestral home south of the Mexican border. The winter snow accumulation on Baffin Island has increased 35 per cent in the last decade.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President met with Republican Congressional leaders and later in the morning welcomed Netherlands Prime Minister B. W. Biesheuvel. The President met with his top economic advisers and then saw Representative Page Belcher, Republican of Oklahoma, and Agriculture Secretary Butz.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I offer the following compromise suggestion for the financing and operation of the City University. The state should take control of the City University and operate and finance it, charging tuition at the same rates as in the State University. The city, as its contribution, should pay the tuition of New York City residents, or at least of those who would be unable to pay the tuition. This would amount to about $200 million at most. In addition, the city could pay, or contribute to, the costs of remedial programs for openadmission students.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Constitution of the United States mandates that all persons accused of crime be afforded a speedy trial. The rights of defendants and the public interest require no less. There are enormous delays between arrest and trial in the State Supreme Court of those accused of serious crimes. Impecunious defendants, unable to furnish bail, must sit in jail awaiting trial, sometimes for more than a year. This at a time when the law presumes them to be innocent.

title: S. CAROLINA FACES FORDHAM'S PRESS
description: South Carolina, with three players from the metropolitan area in its starting lineup and three others on its 11man roster, opposes Fordham, with its pressing defense, tonight in what is likely to be the biggest drawing card of the Madison Square Garden college basketball season.

title: Diamond Theft Theme of Comic Caper
description: Peter Yates's The Hot Rock, which opened yesterday at the TransLux East and West and 85th Street theaters, is another comic caper moviea jewel theft this time, of a massive uncut diamond that has been the pride of conquest of several African nations but has never honestly been owned by anybody.

title: SAMUEL BERLIANT, A RABBI IN QUEENS
description: Rabbi Samuel Berliant, spiritual leader of Congregation Tifereth Israel In Jackson Heights, Queens, since 1934, died yesterday In Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 35.31 88th Street in Jackson Heights.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, officers and directors of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange issued no list this week.

title: A TUITION INCREASE IS BARRED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26The California state colleges, hit hard by recent budget cuts, have been enjoined from implementing a planned tuition increase for foreign students.

title: St. Peter's Tops Iona
description: St. Peter's College scored 8 points in the last 44 seconds to beat Iona College, 8071, last night at Mount St. Michael Academy in the Bronx.

title: B.B.C. Study Finds U.S. Fare Twice as Violent as British TV
description: LONDON, Jan 26A detailed study by the British Broadcasting Corporation has found that Americanproduced television programs shown here have twice gs many violent incidents as British productions.

title: The Return of a Native: IV
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The old saying was that good iron is not forged into nails: good men do not become soldiers. Now the army in China is a calling of proeminent prestige. A senior cadre tells of his daughter's (and his own) disappointment at her failure to qualify for enlistmentnot as an officer, but in the ranks.

title: POLL FINDS INCREASE IN INFLATION FEARS
description: Americans continue to be pessimistic about the job outlook, though less pessimistic than they were in October, the Gallup Poll said yesterday. However, it said more people believed that prices would rise in the coming months.

title: Those Paris Shows Mostly HoHum
description: PARIS, Jan. 26The couture here apparently exhausted itself on the first day of showings with Dior. It's been going steadily downhill ever since.

title: Governor Is Pushing Funds for City Inquiry Panel
description: ALBANY. Jan. 26  One of the few exceptions to the freeze in state spending imposed by Governor Rockefeller in his proposed new budget is the controversial commission created to investigate the governmenltal operations of New York City.

title: Burglary Detective Robbed
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 26 (UPI)Burglars broke into the home of Joe Swift yesterday and stole $200 in bills and $20 in dimes from a coin collection. Mr. Swift is the chief of the burglary division of the Pontiac Police Department's Detective Bureau.

title: Cairo's Students Stay Off the Streets After Warning by Sadatl
description: CAIRO, Jan. 26  Cairo's demonstrating university students, subjected to a severe scolding yesterday by President Anwar elSadat, vanished from the streets during the night. A holiday quiet settled over the city as Egyptians celebrated the beginning of the fourday Id Al Adha Moslem holiday.

title: Laws of Universe Put Into Question
description: Recent astronomical observations have so shaken the foundations of current theory that some physicists are proposing that the laws governing events here and now may not be valid in other regions of space and time.

title: U.S. Grants Parole To Daniel Berrigan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, a major figure in the antiwar movement, was granted parole from Federal prison today.

title: Manhattan Crushes St. Francis
description: Manhattan College trounced St. Francis College, 11175, last night on the Terriers floor in Brooklyn. The Jaspers connected on 44 field goals in 64 shots for a 65 per cent shooting average.

title: MARKET SLUMPS 6TH DAY IN A ROW
description: The stock market sagged yesterday under further profit taking and to a lesser degree, the negative tone of North Vietnam's initial response to peace proposals disclosed Tuesday, night by President Nixon.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Buckley, in Tokyo, Bids U.S. Win Back Asians Confidence
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26Senator James L. Buckley called today for concrete American measures to restore Asian confidence in Washington as a reliable ally in the Western Pacific. Senator Buckley gave his impressions of wary Asian opinions to a large luncheon audience of Japanese and foreigners, including businessmen and 11 ambassadors, at the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan.

title: A Few Clues From a SuperSecret Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's specialist in supersecret diplomacy, divulged some clues today about his modus operandi in going to Paris to meet with North Vietnamese officials there.

title: Market Place
description: Is it only the specialists who object to the idea of competing market makers on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange? What about the broker acting on behalf of a large retail house?

title: Hanoi is Stressing That U.S. Pullout Opens the Way for Big Annihilating Attacks
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Jan. 26In what appears to signal a switch in enemy military strategy, the North Vietnamese press and radio have emphasized that the withdrawal of American forces has preoared the way for big annihilating attacks by main forces.

title: C.W. Post Routs Wagner
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 26C.W. Post routed Wagner College, 8564, tonight for its 10th triumph in 15 outings. Jim Webber was high for the Pioneers with 18 points while Russell Wilson netted 16 and a game high of 14 rebounds.

title: President Is Named at Celotex; Celanese Elects Two Directors
description: Two major companies announced appointments yesterday.

title: Wind Damage in Northeast Is Estimated at $11Million
description: At least $11million in property damage was attributed yesterday to the windstorm that swept the Northeast Tuesday and caused at least four deaths in the metropolitan area.

title: Private and Public U. S. Activities in Peace Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26A series of secret diplomatic efforts to end the war in Vietnam formed the central disclosure made by President Nixon last night and discussed today by Henry A. Kissinger, his adviser on national security. Following is a listing of some of the formerly secret events, with a comparison of the publicly known and privately held activities that surrounded them:

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Nixon, with understandable satisfaction, remarked during his Tuesday night broadcast that it was difficult to see how anyone, regardless of his past position on the war, could now say that we have not gone the extra mile in offering a settlement that is fair to everybody concerned.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Before the publication of the Surgeon General's Advisory Committee Report on the impact of televised violence, The Times ran a reasonable story about it with a misleading headline, TV Violence Held Unharmful to Youth. Since then, Congressmen, editorialists, letter writers, mothers and others, whether they have read the report or not, have interpreted the report in the light of The Times headline.

title: FAULTS ARE CITED IN INSURANCE ACT
description: The State insurance Department's latest proposal to carry out a new law for protecting health insurance consumers has enough loopholes in it to run an ambulance through, Bess Mycrson, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, asserted yesterday.

title: CELSUS WHEELER, 74, CLERIC AND TEACHER
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 26The Rev. Celsus Wheeler, a teacher and administrator at St. Bonaventure University, died today in his quarters at the university. He was 74 years old.

title: Cahill Endorses Proposal For Rise in Jersey Tuition
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill today endorsed as reasonable the proposed $250ayear tuition increase at New Jersey's eight fouryear state colleges. The tuition is now $350.

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS RAISED NET IN 1971
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday that net income in 1971 amounted to $10,684,000, or $2.10 a share. This compared with $10,262,000, or $2.02 a share, in 1970.

title: Inland's Profit DownWheelingPittsburgh Results Increase
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday gains in net income for the final quarter of 1971 and the full year. Revenues for the year were higher but fourthquarter revenues trailed the 1970 level.

title: Private U.S. Experts Study Soviet Gas Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Two major Texasbased natural gas suppliers were reported today to have dispatched a team of specialists to the Soviet Union to study the feasibility of shipping liquefied Siberian gas to the American East Coast.

title: Rare Rhea Bird Used for Study Lost at Cornell
description: One of the rarest living birds in the United States, an ostrichlike Darwin's rhea, is missing from an ornithological laboratory at Cornell University in Ithaca.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Simeon Golar (letter Jan. 12) displays the mastery of what I would call honest deception or obfuscation by facts, a politician's tool.

title: Penn Six Routs Princeton
description: PRINCETON, Jan. 26Dietrich Gyetko, a junior forward, scored three goals in the first period tonight to spark Pennsylvania to a 113 victory over Princeton at Baker Rink. Sam Gellard and Paul Daigle added two goals apiece to seal the victory.

title: S.E.C. WILL STEP UP INSPECTION OF FIRMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Securities and Exchange Commission warned all brokerage firms today that it now has additional money from Congress to inspect their books more often and intends to do so.

title: Lindsay Gets News Director
description: A Fire Department aide, Paul M. O'Brien, was appointed news director of Mayor Lindsay's Presidential campaign organization yesterday. Mr. O'Brien will be on an unpaid leave of absence as special assistant to Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery while serving in the Lindsay campaign.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Job Equality Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate rejected today an amendment by Senator Peter Dominick, Republican of Colorado, providing for enforcement of equal employment legislation through the Federal courts rather than by administrative action:

title: Lawyer Reformers Tour Cheerless Spots
description: First to the Callagy Hall shelter for girls on the Lower East. Side, where one adolescent in pajamas lay crumpled on a sofa in the lounge, staring blankly ahead, and another, named Diana, said: Home or here, it's just the same thing,

title: A Christmas Surge Gives 10.4% Gain
description: A lastminute surge or Christmas business helper chainstore sales last month to rise 10.4 per cent from the December, 1970, level, recording to a survey of a major group of chainstore organizations. For the year as a whole, sales for the group were 9.8 per cent ahead of 1970.

title: East Bloc Nations Suggest Cuts in National
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26  Communistbloc leaders, deferring slightly to the Western allies, declared today that any EastWest accord to reduce forces in Europe should include the European nations own armies as well as foreign ones.

title: WOODCOCK URGES AN F,BI INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, called today on the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate an alleged conspiracy to kill the farm workers organizer Cesar Chavez.

title: Decline Is Halted on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock (Exchange and on the overthecounter market finished mixed yesterday on moderate trading.

title: FreeTransit Plan Urged in Rome
description: ROME, Jan. 26Rome's traffic commissioner proposed today that bus and streetcar fares be abolished permanently during the morning and evening rush hours, beginning March 15.

title: Transcript, Anyone?
description: The Republicancontrolled State Legislature has moved another reluctant inch or two toward procedural reform.

title: Pennsy Sets Sate In Five Properties
description: Trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company have signed contracts for the sale of their interest in five midManhattan properties for a total of $56,197,837, it was anflounced yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was completely dumfounded by the irresponsibility and ignorance of banking and banking practices reflected in your editorial of Jan. 13 entitled Loose Money in Wall Street. Your editorial implies it is relatively simple for a thief to secure a bank loan against stolen collateral, adding, and I quote, The banker, for his part, can make a good profit on the transaction if the collateral exceeds the loan. Accordingly, he has little incentive to check carefully on the borrowerprovided he thinks the securities will not be identified as stolen.

title: WAGE BOARD CUTS BACKLOG OF CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Pay Board said today that it had made substantial headway in cutting down a huge backlog of wage cases since its chairman, Judge George H. Boldt, had won authority to decide some of them alone.

title: L.I.R.R. Talks Recessed
description: Negotiations between the Long Island Rail Road and the United Transportation Union were recessed yesterday until 10 A.M. tomorrow. Sources close to the talks reported that significant progress had been made in the last two days. A strike that had been threatened last week was postponed until 4 P.M. next Sunday at the request of Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson.

title: Canadians Warned of Cold
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (Reutors)The Canadian weather, office warned today that the chill factor in the lower St. Lawrence River region was 62 degrees below zero and that it was extremely dangerous to be exposed to such cold.

title: MGM BLOC WINS IN SENATE, 4846, ON JOB EQUALITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Senate agreed today, 48 to 46, to give the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission the power to order companies to stop discrimination in their employment practices.

title: Canadians, Earthbound in Strike, Are Beset by Snow and Cold
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 26  While only a minority of Canadians travel by air, fewer still are escaping the torments and frustrations of 10 earthbound days resulting from a strike by the men who man the airport control towers.

title: Eligibility Review Begins
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26 (AP)The International Olympic Ccmmittce's commission on eligibility began a twoday meeting in Tokyo today. It is reviewing the amateur status of all competitors in the Winter Olympics.

title: Bulls Top Rockets
description: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 26 (AP) Bob Love and Chet Walker sparked a surge in the third quarter tonight and led the Chicago Bulls to a 117108 victory over the Houston Rockets.

title: St. John's Tops Hofstra, 72.64
description: St. John's defeated Hofstra, 7264, last night at its Jamaica, Queens, court.

title: FIVE OUT AS JURORS IN HARRISBURG TRIAI,
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26Of 14 prospective jurors interviewed today in the conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. BerBigan and six other antiwar activists, five were dismissed.

title: AUSTIN D. SHEAN
description: Austin D. Shean, director of I safety and compensation control for the Todd Shipyards Corporation, died yesterday while riding on a Seventh Avenue subway train. He was 61 years old and lived at 3 Sheridan Square.

title: FANS AND SINGERS PAY BREL TRIBUTE
description: Jacques Brel was alive and well and on stage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. But despite the cries of chanson! and an insistent chant of We want Jacques from the enthusiastic audience that filled the hall, the Belgian songwriter and singer could not be lured into a performance of any of his songs.

title: Oil Unit Lifts Dividend
description: The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday that its estimated net income for the fourth quarter of 1971 totaled $129,175,000, or $1.52 a share, compared with $126,888,000, or $1.49 a share a year earlier. Sales were $1,629,910,0.00, against $1,346,416,000.

title: Scottish Isle Welcomes the Sun
description: LERWICK, Scotland, Jan. 26With a torchlight procession, the burning of a Viking galley, mummers skits, dancing, feasting and drinking, Shetland islanders celebrated the return of the sun last night in a rousing festival they call UpHellyAa.

title: KAREN KRANTYKE VICTOR IN TENNIS
description: HINGHAM, Mass., Jan. 26 (AP)Karen Krantzcke of Australia survived a marathon loss of a 15minute game today en route to a 64, 60 victory over Marcie Louie of San Francisco in the Virginia Slims women's indoor tennis championships.

title: State School Chief Overrules Newark On Black Flag Plan
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26  The State Education Commissioner, Dr. Carl L. Marburger, ordered the Newark school board today to desist from implementing its own resolution to fly black liberation flags in all classrooms and schools where black students are in the majority.

title: Fireman's Book as Tough as His Work
description: When you were poor and Irish and growing up on the East Side in the nineteen fifties, the nuns never told you to become a doctor or a lawyerPresident of the United States perhaps, but if not that, then a policeman or a fireman.

title: CORE Planning to Fight Richmond Busing Order
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 26 (AP)Roy Innes, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said today that CORE was prepared to go to the Supreme Court if necessary to block courtordered merger of Richmond's predominantly black schools with those of two adjacent white suburbs.

title: Panel Urges U.S. to Set Limit on Noise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that the Federal Government should establish noise limits on aircraft and other transportation equipment, construction equip ment and internal combustion engines.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Development Program, Governing Council10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHOICE OF AN ENVOY TO JAPAN CONFIRMED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  The White House confirmed today that President Nixon intended to nominate Robert S. Ingersoll, chairman of the BorgWarner Corporation, to succeed Armin H. Meyer as Ambassador to Japan. In announcing Mr. Nixon's decision, the deputy White House press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said that Ambassador Meyer had done an outstanding job.

title: Mass for Casadesus Today
description: A special mass for Jean Casadesus will be offered at the Holy Roman Catholic Family Church, 315 East 47th Street, today at 11 A.M. Mr. Casadesus was killed a week ago in an automobile collision near Renfrew, Ontario.

title: Advertising:
description: Heidi has found a new homeagain.

title: Elizabeth Taylor Cast as Caine's Wife, Zee
description: Although I've seen "X Y & Zee" only once (and have no intention of sitting through it a second time), I'm reasonably convinced that the original screenplay by Edna O'Brien ("Three Into Two Won't Go") is a much more interesting study of an absolutely dreadful marriage, and of the sweet though not especially innocent girl who is brought into it, than anything in the movie that Brian G. Hutton has made from it. The film is coarse, noisy and, finally, stupid, like people at a nearby table who won't shut up.Zee (Elizabeth Taylor) and Robert (Michael Caine), a wealthy London architect, live on the edge of high-class despair and love every minute of it. Zee's face is still extraordinarily beautiful and she calls herself womanly, although she is probably just fat. It's hard to tell since she wears tent-like dresses that seem to have been designed for a restless grave. She also boozes constantly and plays the stereo at such a pitch that my first thought was that Robert was hanging around as often as he does only because he is deaf.He isn't, Robert likes confusion. He and Zee are blatantly unfaithful to each other, fight to physical knock-downs, and then make up in sudden moments of what pass for tenderness in your ordinary, upper middle-class, sado-masochistic relationships. All goes swingingly until Robert falls genuinely in love with Stella (Susannah York), who runs a boutique (and may thus quality as a hip equivalent to the old sewing machine girl).The story of "X Y & Zee" (my nomination for the dumbest title of the yearand this is only January) concerns Zee's fierce campaign to keep Robert, one way and another, which eventually necessitates her using (are you really ready?) her body, of which, of course, she has plenty to spare. Poor Stella, it seems, has tendencies.As directed by Mr. Hutton, who made one of my favorite idiotic action moves ("Where Eagles Dare"), "X Y & Zee" never misses an opportunity to overstate a line, a point or a mood, or simply to confuse the few things that, from the delicacy of the original (not televised) version of "Three Into Two Won't Go," I take to be Miss O'Brien's sensibilities.Behind the posh, but essentially junky production values (lovely sets, good character actors, including superb Margaret Leighton wearing a lot of odd-colored wigs), one can gather hints of what "X Y and Zee" means to be about. It isif I read Miss O'Brien correctlya kind of case history of a series of individual conspiracies, each designed to overthrow a heart. The tactics may be murderous but the manners always civilized.For the film to make any sense, the performances must be on something like the same plane. Not necessarily at the same volume, but in the same world, Mr. Caine and Miss York do, I think, effect connections that are occasionally complex and moving. Their characters have histories and recognizable patterns of behaviorpasts that are as much apparent in gestures and modes of speech as in spoken exposition.There is, however, a great void in the case of the character the film cannot take its eyes off of. Miss Taylor is not a very interesting actress, but she need not seem as bad as she does here. Mr. Hutton allows her to play Zee as if she were the ghost of whores past, present and future, clanking her jewelry, her headbands, her earrings and her feelings behind her like someone out to haunt a funhouse.It is an unfortunately ridiculous performance, and you may have some idea of the measure of the imbalance that her presence effects when I say that I'm convinced the story might have had a different ending had Miss Taylor worn just one less Medusa ringlet, or even one less layer of eye shadow.

title: For the Fancier of Foreign Goods, It Is a Time of Rising Prices
description: The millions of Americans who in the last decade have developed a taste for foreignmade goods are in for a time of anguished price watching over the next few months as new rules in the game of international trade take effect.

title: Reaction in Harrisburg
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26The defendants in the conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists rejoiced today over the granting of parole for his brother, the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan.

title: A Jersey Truck Driver Wins $1Million Lottery
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26 (AP)Lawrence 0. Palmer, a 52yearold truck driver of Stratford, today became the 14th milliondollar winner in the New Jersey state lottery. He won on a $2.50 ticket.

title: Oldest Mayor Retiring
description: GRAYSVILLE, Ohio (UPI)Edward Cline, 97 years old, believed to be the oldest mayor in America, said he was retiring because it's time for me to get out and give someone else a chance.

title: Longshoremen Reach Pact On New Work Conditions
description: Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that the union's New York wage  scale committee would recommend unanimously that union members here accept a management offer on a new set of working conditions in the port.

title: Books of The Times
description: AproPoeto get straightway into the spirit of this idiosyncratic critical valentine, which delights in rel'erring to its beloved subject as everything from Edgarpoe (as in France) to Idgar I Am Poet (as in Freud). Apropos of Edgar Allen Poe, Henry James wrote that to take him with more than a certain degree of seriousness is to lack seriousness one's self. Some 70 years later, in 1948, attempting to explain why Poe's appeal is primarily to readers at the period of life when they were just emerging from childhood, T. S. Eliot concluded that the variety and ardour of his curiosity delight and dazzle, yet in the end the eccentricity and lack of coherence of his interests tire. To day, especially considering the functions and unctions of Vincent Price in various films of Poe's stories, one is inclined to agree with both judgments.

title: Mrs. Miniver Yields to Ack Ack
description: Flashing a stilldazzling smile, Greer Garson confessed here yesterday she didn't mind playing the role of Mrs. Ack Ack instead of Mrs. Miniver.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: American Fletcher Mortgage Investors raised an indicated $21.09million yesterday with the sale of 760,000 shares of beneficial interest at $27 through a Goldman, Sachs & Co underwriting group. American Fletcher Mortgage, run by a subsidiary of an Indianapolis bank holding company, is a real estate investment trust.

title: SOL KLEIMAN
description: Sol Kleiman, a retired manufacturer of dresses and sportswear, died yesterday morning at St. Clare's Hospital after a fiveweek illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 315 West 70 Street.

title: George R. Hearst Sr. Is Dead; Newspaper Executive Was 67
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) George Randolph Hearst Sr., an executive of the Hearst Corporation, died today in Loma Linda Hospital after brief illness. He was 67 years old.

title: NICKEL DISTRIBUTORS FACING TRUST SUITS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)The Justice Department filed antitrust suits today against thre nickel distributors. It accused them of violating the Sherman and Clayton Acts by selling nickel to customers on the condition the customers also purchase electroplating materials from the defendants.

title: Proper Dazzle Highlights a Night for Diamonds
description: Diamonds may not work on the skirts, sweaters and droopy dresses that pass for evening fashion these days, but they're fine with formal prerecession ballgowns, and ballgowns, among other things, were what last night's Diamond Ball was all about. That and diamonds (although rubies and emeralds were 0.K, too) and rich, elegant New Yorkers doing their gala thing for a good cause.

title: Peru Ousts Newspaper's Head, A Leading Critic of the Regime
description: Peru's military Government has removed Pedro Beltran, one of its leading civilian critics, as publisher of the newspaper La Prensa of Lima.

title: Plans to Move to South
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Jan. 26 (UPI) Mr. Mancusi said he planned to move to the South and play a little golf where the weather is warmer. He said his retirement plans had not been hastened by the riot and that Commissioner Oswald had not asked him to step down.

title: Soaks Beat Hawks
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (AP)Lee Winfield and Don Smith sparked a fourthquarter rally tonight to lead the Seattle SuperSonics to a 131119 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Skepticism on Peace Plan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26 (UPI)Senator Buckley expressed some skepticism today about President Nixon's proposals for peace in Vietnam. The Senator said he did not want to come up with snap judgments about Mr. Nixon's moves, but he offered, random observations.

title: News of Dogs
description: George Spradling, a lawyer from Wichita, Kan., has bred and owned more than 100 champions. The list could have been longer, he said here last week on his way home from judging in Florida. I've had at least a dozen I stopped showing when they had 12 or 14 points. I bred them or became interested in something else. Spredling's career in dogs covers nearly a halfcentury. I started with cocker spaniels, he recalled. I then became interested in genetics and read everything I could find on the subject. I began breeding for colors in dogs and birds. I had great success as a breeder of pigeons, chickens and water fowl. I also had winning Shetland ponies, goats and sheep.

title: Makers of Sex After Death Sue Playboy Theater Here
description: An action asking for $1million in damages has been filed in Supreme Court here by AbelChild Productions, producers of Is There Sex After Death?, against the operators of the Playboy Theater here where the film was first shown for a sixweek engagement starting Oct. 24, 1971. According to Alan Abel, the producer, and Edward Gallant his attorney, the complaint alleges that the film's weekly grosses reported were considerably less than the actual income being tallied by private invetigators.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 26The apparent failure of President Nixon's new peace proposals to break the deadlock in Paris raises the question, What comes next in the Vietnam conflict?

title: President's Adviser Asks Public to Back Initiatives
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Henry A. Kissinger appealed today for public understanding and support of the Administration's peace initiatives in Vietnam.

title: PENN FIVE POSTS 1,000TH VICTORY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) Penn became the fifth major college to win 1,000 basketball games tonight as the ninthranked Quakers whipped La Salle, 8066, at the Palestra.

title: Soviet Chides U.S. Mildly on Arms Outlay
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26  Two authoritative Soviet newspapers chided President Nixon today for the increases in military, spending in his new budget but carefully avoided any suggestion that these would disrupt the strategic arms negotiations in Vienna.

title: Javits Deplores Friction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Senator Jacob K. Javits depiored today the public fraction, Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay and said it doesn't help the city, the state or the nation.

title: HIJACKER WITH 3 FLEES, THENLANDS AND IS SHOT DEAD
description: A Mohawk Airlines plane from Albany to New York City, hijacked to Westchester County Airport last night, took off again early today and landed at Poughkeepsie, with only the three crew members, the armed hijacker and the parachutes and $200,000 in cash he had demanded aboard.

title: Marlborough Marries Mrs. Canfield
description: LONDON, Jan. 26Mrs. Laura Canfield and the Duke of Marlborough were married in a civil ceremony here today.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's News Conference on the President's Peace Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Following are excerpts from the news conference held today by Henry A. Kissinger, assistant to the President for national security affairs, on Mr. Nixon's eightpoint proposal for peace in Indochina:

title: Rangers Beat Sabres at Garden, 51, After Bizarre Night, Threat to Coach
description: Capping a bizarre 24 hours In which nine players spent the night on a grounded plane in Minneapolis, and the Rangers coach, Emile Francis, received a death threat, the Rangers last night did only what was necessary in gaining a 51 decision over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since World War II there has been a recurrent, heated debate as to whether Pope Pius XII in fact did everything within his power to help the plight of the Jews. A similar and perhaps more profound (as it strikes closer to home) moral question now is posed visvis the Administration's attitude toward the butchery of an estimated one million East Pakistan Bengalis.

title: MILK PRICE FIGHT PUSHED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Lawyers for Ralph Nader and three consumer organizations asked Federal District Judge William B. Jones today to hasten the pretrial discovery process in their suit against the Government to rescind an increase in the price support for milk.

title: South Africa Critics Drop Film Awards; Blame Censorship
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 26Johannesburg's film society has suspended its annual award for the best film of the year because, it says, South African censorship prevents anyone from seeing the best films of the year.

title: City Aldes Act to Implement Theater Report
description: Representatives of three city agencies moved yesterday to implement recommendations for the improvement of the theater made recently by a citizens committee of 19 wellknown persons.

title: MAYOR IS SEEKING CATHOLIC BACKING
description: In a bid for Catholic support in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Mayor Lindsay gave a clearly political speech last night at the 72d annual dinner of the Cathedral Club of Brooklyn.

title: Lindsay Is Accused Of Charter Violation As PartTime Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay, a Manhattan lawyer charged yesterday, is violating the City Charter by campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Royals Bow to 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) Despite a 42point performance by Nate Archibald, the Cincinnati Royals dropped a 113102 decision to the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: DOCK STRIKE LAW URGED BY HODGSON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson, saying there was no basis for a negotiated settlement of the West Coast dock strike, urged the Senate Labor Committee today to act swiftly to process legislation that would end the economically damaging walkout.

title: British to Parole Spy
description: LONDON, Jan. 26 (UPI)Britain has decided to parole a convicted spy, William Vassall, a former admiralty clerk, eight years before his term is up. Vassall, 46 years old, was convicted in 1962 of selling British secrets to the Soviet Union and sentenced to 18 years imprisonment. He has been eligible for a parole since 1968. He will be freed next fall.

title: Chess. U.S.S.R.  Yugoslavia Match Used to Be a Close Contest
description: The annual team match between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia has long been one of the highlights of the chess year in Eastern Europe. Up until this year, the match has always followed the same script: the Soviet Union would invariably win, but by a very close margin, and not before the Yugoslays had posed a very reallooking threat to score an upset.

title: A HIJACKING PLAN BLOCKED ON COAST
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 26A man waving a 38caliber revolver briefly took an employe of S.F.O. Helicopter lines hostage at a heliport here tonight and demanded transportation to Cuba.

title: Treasury Discloses Terms Of New Financing Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Treasury offered today to holders of securities maturing in February the choice of a fouryear, threemonth note bearing 5 per cent interest and a 10year bond bearing 6 per cent.

title: Campaign Notes
description: DES MOJNES, Iowa, Jan. 26Students, whose willingness to participate in electoral politics this year has been widely doubted, turned out in droves for Monday night's Iowa Democratic precinct caucuses. According to Richard Bender assistant to the chairman of the state Democratic party, the largest caucuses in the state were those that college students attended. We don't have exact figures, he said, but it's safe to say that students participated three times as heavily as the population in general. Students are geographically concentrated, so they're much easier to organize.

title: Bullets Win in Last Second
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 (AP)Wes Unseld scored on an inbounds pass with one second left in overtime tonight to give the Baltimore Bullets a 115114 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: U. S. Attacks Radar in the North For the 19th Time This Month
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 27 (AP)The United States command announced another air strike against a radar missile site in North Vietnam yesterday as the heightened air war in Indochina continued.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26  Ambassador Meyer, in a statement issued by the United States Embassy today, characterized Mr. Ingersoll as an outstanding American with qualifications particularly noteworthy at a time when United StatesJapanese relationships are of crucial importance.

title: Woman Gets New Kidney
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)A 50yearold Cambridge woman was in good condition today at Boston City Hospital after receiving a kidney transplant from an Omaha, Neb., man killed in a car accident. She is Mrs. Frances Lapusada. She underwent the transplant last night.

title: Chief Executive Elected At Hormel Meat Concern
description: I. J. Holton, 52yearold president of Geo. A. Horniel & Co., has been named chief executive officer, succeeding M. B. Thompson, 63, who continues as chairman of the meatprocessing company, it was announced yesterday.

title: Greek Police Visit Shopowners To Warn of Blacklisted Books
description: ATHENS, Jan. 26The Greek Government, which officially lifted censorship in 1970, is quietly putting bookstores on guard against the sale of books its National Security Directorate has listed as Communist and AntiGovernment.

title: Coalition Focuses on City Abandonment
description: White racism as a factor in the decline of the nation's central cities was a major topic in a sometimes heated debate in a dosed meeting of the National Urban Coalition's top echelon yesterday.

title: Karras Receives $80,000 From Lions as Settlement
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25 (AP)The Detroit Lions have settled the contract of Alex Karras, a former AllPro guard, giving an $80,000 lumpsum payment to Karras, who is now a television panelist.

title: Mortgage Lending Rose 9% At Savings and Loan Units
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)Mortgage lending by savings and loan associations reached a nearrecord volume in December, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Heading on Memos
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The confidential memorandums that Mr. Cohen denied having written were distributed to regional administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency on Jan. 12. The first page was headed by these words: Prepared by Howard A. Cohen, Director, Office of Congressional Affairs, Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Shooting Brings Early Birth
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) A premature daughter has been dlivered by a patrolman's wife who was shot in the abdomen with her husband's .38caliber pistol. Mrs. James Gamble, 21 years old, was operated on after she was accidentally shot Friday. The bullet apparently entered her abdomen from the front, missed her uterus, passed behind the 7month unborn child and came out her lower back. The shock caused her to deliver her baby girl prematurely on Monday, her surgeon said.

title: Mosbacher May Go To Spain as Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)Emil (Bus) Mosbacher, chief of protocol, will soon be appointed by President Nixon as United States Ambassador to Spain, informed sources said today.

title: SOVIET EXPERTS ASSISTING CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 26A highlevel Soviet economic mission arrived today to develop an aid program for Chile's troubled economy, starting with a $50million loan in hard currency to finance imports.

title: Environmental Center Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) A bill that would establish a national environmental center was introduced today by Representative Louis Frey Jr., Republican of Florida. Mr. Frey said that the Center would act as a clearinghouse for longrange environmental planning and research and would not supplant activties of existing public and private agencies.

title: Texts of Hanoi and Vietcong Statements
description: PARIS, Jan. 26Following are the texts of statements in response to President Nixon issued today by the delegations of North Vietnam and the Vietcong at the Paris talks. The North Vietnamese statement was issued in English and the Vietcong statement in French.

title: MANHOUROUTPUT CLIMBS SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Labor Department reported two developments in the economy today which point toward a significant lessening of inflationary pressures:

title: DECEPTION IS SEEN
description: PARIS, Jan. 26  The Vietnamese Communists made it plain today that President Nixon's peace proposals last night were unacceptable.

title: 2 Suspects Killed in StakeOut At E. 42d Street Candy Shop
description: Two men were killed last evening by policemen staked out at a candy shop on crowded East 42d Street that had been held up several times recently.

title: The Return of a Native: IV
description: SAIGON, South VietnamIt is sadly clear to Vietnamese that the American Government not only interferes in but also controls South Vietnam.

title: Bonn Will Unfreeze Its Inflation Funds
description: BONN, Jan. 26Karl Schiller, the Minister of Economics and Finance, announced today that the Federal Government was preparing to unfreeze more than 10 billion marks it had set aside beginning two years agn to combat inflationary trends in West Germany.

title: Lewis Stops Turpin in 2d
description: WOLVERHAMPTON, ENGLAND, Jan. 26 (UPI)Jackie Turpin, voted Britain's best boxing prospect of 1971, was knocked out in two rounds tonight by a United States welterweight, Frankie Lewis. Turpin nephew of the former world middleweight champion, Randy Turpin, had racked up 13 successive knockout victories.

title: Man in the News
description: Shortly before the end of World War II, a young Navy pilot named Robert Ray Parks crashlanded his plane near Lake City, Fla., and seriously injured his spine.

title: Kahane Calls It Insane Act
description: JERUSALEM, Jan, 26 (UPI)Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, said today that the persons responsible for the fatal Manhattan fire were insane.

title: Dartmouth Six Wins
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 26 (AP)Bill Barry scored two goals and Bob Hayes and Dana Johnson one each tonight as Dartmouth's hockey team defeated St. Lawrence, 41.

title: Mansfield Hails Proposals As a Long Step Forward
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Senator Mike Mansfield, a leading critic of the Administration's policies on Vietnam, applauded President Nixon's peace proposals today as a long step forward that he hoped could lead to a negotiated settlement of the war.

title: Nixon Praised on Rights
description: BOSTON (UPI)Jack E. Robinson, president of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that there was an infusion of administrative concern for black Americans in President Nixon's proposed budget.

title: 30% Rise in Slayings Is Reported Here For 71, but Property Crime Declined
description: An increase of more than 30 per cent in murder and nonnegligent murder cases here, as compared with 1970, was reported by the Police Department yesterday.

title: Vendetta in Peru
description: The ouster by Peru's military dictatorship of Pedro Beltran as director and owner of La Prensa of Lima is purely and simply a savage vendetta against one of the most respected journalists in the Americas. La Prensa had criticized junta policies but had never indulged in partisan or personal attacks on the ruling generals or questioned their motives.

title: Big Retailer Names a President, 55
description: Jack B. Jackson, a onetime store manager for the J. C. Penney Company, who started his career as a highschool athletic coach, was elected yesterday president and chief administrative officer of Penney, effective April 1. Penney, with annual sales of more than $4billion, is the country's second largest retail chain, after Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: REGENTS OPPOSE CITY U. TAKEOVER
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26The State Board of Regents took issue with Governor Rockefeller today by recommending that the City University remain independent of the State University, but it said the municipal institution should charge tuition.

title: Bridge:
description: Taiwan recently earned a place in the next Bermuda Bowl world championship contest, not due until 1973, by winning the Far East title in Melbourne, Australia.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26The Vietnamese Communists negative reaction to the latest allied peace proposals, which was expected, tells much not only about why peace has been impossible to attain here but also about why the American and South Vietnamese Governments may have decided to make the secret negotiations of the past 30 months public now. During the past two months, North Vi etnamese forces have scored signal victories in conventional battles against outclassed Cambodian and Lao tian troops on Route 6 northeast of Pnompenh and on the Paine des Jarres and the Boloven Plateau in Laos. At the same time American and South Vietnamese officials here have been saying that they expect a large Communist offensive in South Vietnam by the middle of February, that is, over Tet, the Lunar New Year holiday, and just before President Nixon makes his trip to Peking on Feb. 21.

title: Hughes $650,000 Is Believed Still in Switzerland
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 26The Zurich police believe that the $650,000 paid by McGrawHill in the Hughes affair is still in Switzerland.

title: City Tightens Fire Rules For Glass Office Towers
description: Skyscraper firessimilar to the one in which one person died yesterday  have stirred increasing concern since the new style of glasswrapped, sealedwindow buildings have spread through New York City.

title: Labor's Opposition To. 2d Nixon Term Is Denied by Meany
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, denied today that the big labor federation had officially decided to oppose President Nixon's reelection.

title: POLLUTION PLAN BY STATE SCORED
description: The state's plan to reduce air pollution in the metropolitan area to levels that will not be dangerous to health, drew sharp criticism yesterday as state officials opened hearings on the proposal.

title: Advertising:
description: Anyone who knows Paul Harper, the daily jogging, wiry, exmarine who runs Needham, Harper & Steers, knows that he doesn't fool around. When he announces he's going to do something you can bet your bippy it's been well thoughtout and studiedit's not a publicity gimmick.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The blighted downtown business area in Glen Cove, L. I., will be rebuilt to provide modern shopping and commercial facilities and apartment houses under a $20million urban renewal project announced yesterday by Mayor Andrew J. DiPaola.

title: Head of Operation Breadbasket Says He Opposes Mrs. Chisholm
description: The Rev. William A. Jones Jr., acting national chairman of Operation Breadbasket and an influential black leader in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, has said there is widespread dissatisfaction with Representative Shirley Chisholm in that community.

title: JOHN H. FRAZEE
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 26John Henry Frazee, who at the age of 98 was Westfield's oldest resident, died last night after a short illness.

title: Notes on People
description: In Agana, Guam, Shoichi Yokoi, a Japanese Army sergeant who hid in the jungles for 28 years after World War II, until his capture this week, was reunited with two other Japanese soldiers who had held out for years on the island. Bunzo Minagawa and Tadashi Ito shared his exile in the jungles until their capture in 1960. Sergeant Yokoi knew the war was over, but did not give himself up because he feared execution. He will return to Japan.

title: Soviet Passes U.S. In Steel Output For the First Time
description: The Soviet Union realized an old ambition for the first time last year by exceeding United States steel production and becoming the largest steel producing nation in the world.

title: COLONELS BEATEN BY NETS, 118105
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 26The New York Nets, hitting on a remarkable 59 per cent of their shots, won their sixth straight game at home tonight and it was no soft touch they defeated the Kentucky Colonels, the showcase team of the American Basketball Association 118105.

title: Death Penalty Rejected
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (UPI)A hill providing the death penalty for drug pushers was defeated in the Georgia Senate yesterday by a vote of 27 to 17.

title: Rises Also Reported by Minnesota Mining and by Philip Morris
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest maker of soaps and detergents, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the three and six months ended last Dec. 31.

title: Abortion Clinic Formally Opens As Nearby Church Tolls Protest
description: A new family planning and abortion clinic held an open house yesterday afternoon while directly across Second Avenue at 22d Street a Roman Catholic church tolled its hell every seven seconds for four hours in protest.

title: Cheaper Than Buying Car: Free Bus
description: COMMERCE, Calif. When 22yearold Amado Soto moved here two years ago, he got a job as janitor at the local high school. Then he went looking for a car so he could get to his new jobuntil he discovered that the city had a free bus service.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN DOWN AT CHICAGO
description: The rejection yesterday by the Senate Agricultural Committee of a bill that would have established a wheat and feed reserve and increase loan rates to farmers by 25 per cent had a depressing effect on trading of soybean and grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: 1971 Profit at Record
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation achieved its highest sales and earnings to date in 1971, Donald C. Burnham, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: Price Controls Lifted For Nonprofit Schools
description: WASHINGTON, JAN. 26 (AP)  The Cost of Living Council exempted from price control today the tuition fees and room and board charges of private, nonprofit schools, colleges and universities.

title: Folk Art Museum Will Auction Items
description: The Museum of American Folk Art is holding a new exhibition with a dual purposea retrospective look at its fine collection and a show of objects from the collection that will be auctioned March 3.

title: Agnew, Speaking Here, Scores Democratic Foes of War Policy
description: Vice President Agnew denounced the Democratic critics of the Nixon Administration's Vietnam policy last night, charging that their criticism represented the luxury of partisans out of power whose simple goal, to the exclusion of all others, is a return to power.

title: Pershing to Incorporate
description: Pershing & Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it would shift from a partnership to the corporate tom next Tuesday. The firm also announced that F. Warren Pershing, a founding partner, would become chairman and that Van V. Burger, also a founding partner, would become vice chairman. Carl W. Timpson Jr. was named president and Barrant V. Merrill was named executive vice president.

title: OTTO H. KROEGER
description: Otto H. Kroeger, a former partner in the investment firm of Charles F. Zeltner & Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Tuesday night at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Kroeger, who lived at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South, was in his 70's.

title: Bucks Triumph
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UPI)The world champion Milwaukee Bucks, sparked by Kareem AbdulJabbar's 34 points and 15 rebounds, took command from the start tonight and defeated the Detroit Pistons, 120.94.

title: CITY CALLED LAX IN SUPPORT CASES
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger charged the city's welfare department yesterday with lax and uncoordinated procedures and a severe lack of concern on the part of staff in collecting support payments for welfare clients under Family Court orders.

title: Crime Table
description: The following are 1970 and 1971 crime index trends here as reported by the Police Department to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 7 HELD AT CONCERT AFTER DISRUPTION
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP)Four young men and three teenaged girls were arrested when small bottles of household ammonia were uncapped and rolled down the aisles during the performance of the Osipov Balalaika Orchestra tonight.

title: Fire Bomb Kills Woman, Hurts 13 in Hurok Office
description: A young woman was killed and 13 other persons, including Sol Hurok, the impressario, were injured yesterday when a fire, caused by an incendiary device set in an apparent act of antiSoviet vengeance, broke out in Mr. Hurok's midtown talentbooking offices.

title: Executive Changes
description: The United States Steel Corporation has elected as a director, Charles F. Meyers Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Burlington Industries, Inc., and appointed Earl W. Mallick, former vice presidentsouth, for U.S. Steel, as vice presidentenvironmental control.

title: Trial of Bergen Prosecutor On Bribery Charges Begins
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 26  Robert Dilts of the suspended Bergen County Prosecutor, was described in Superior Court here today as a betrayer of his public trust on the one hand and a a dedicated public servant on the other. Mr. Dilts and Michael Schiro, a former usedcar dealer, arc charged with participating in a conspiracy in which Mr. Dilts is alleged to have attempted to induce the courts to reduce punishment for several convicted figures involved in highjackings and other crimes in north Jersey in 1970 and 1971. The conspiracy is alleged to have run from May, 1970, to January, 1971.

title: Gromyko in Tokyo
description: Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko has had a long and varied career, but few of his previous missions outranked in importance his present task in Tokyo. One need be privy to no Kremlin secrets to realize that his objective is to persuade Japanin the aftermath of the shocks President Nixon administered to the Japanese last yearto tilt toward Moscow.

title: Stage: Sidney Brustein
description: Lorraine Hansberry's The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window, which opened last night at the Longacre Theater, is a play of very considerable passion. It is flawed play, a play at times likely to sink into melodrama, but it has the good red blood of a Broadway success running through it.

title: DUILIO A. PALMIERI
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Jan. Duilio A. Palmieri, who was named outstanding biology teacher by the New York State Science Teachers Association in 1962, died this morning while teaching a class at Fox Lane High School. Mr. Palmieri, who apparently suffered a heart attack, was 51 years old and lived in Bedford Hills.

title: 17 in Gay Alliance Held After Protests At Lindsay Offices
description: Seventeen persons were arrested yesterday when members of the Gay Activist Alliance, an organization of militant homosexuals, staged demonstrations at Mayor Lindsay's campaign headquarters and at City Hall.

title: Openings Toward Peace
description: The emphasis Presidential assistant Henry Kissinger has placed on the flexibility of the Administration's new Vietnam peace proposals strengthens hope that they may yet provide a key to ending this tragic conflict, despite their initial unacceptability to North Vietnam and the Vietcong.

title: DANCE SETS MOOD AT CUBICULO
description: The type of music chosen by choreographers for concerts is not always an infallible guide to the strength of the concert but it often is telling. In the case of Susan Okuhara, Karen Levy and Susan Solomon, Khachaurian's Saber Dance was the harbinger of a program that ran to an excess of selfindulgent expressionism at the Cubiculo Tuesday evening.

title: Outrage Upon Outrage
description: The firebombing of the offices of Sol Hurok and Columbia Artists, which took the life of a 27yearold receptionist and endangered the lives of countless others, is another mindless outrage. It follows by only three months a cowardly assault by gunfire on the Soviet Mission to the United Nations. In that assault, shots crashed through windows into a room containing a family of six, two adults and four children, miraculously missing all of them. A few months earlier Soviet airline and tourist offices here were bombed.

title: TV: A Night in Jail, A Day in Court on C.B.S.
description: Sharply observed details do notnecessarily make for broad generalizations. That bit of obvious wisdom was triggered after watching C.B.S. Reports hourlong special called A Night iri Jail, A Day in Court. Produced, written and reported by John Sharnik, it will be presented on the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight at 10 o'clock, immediately following an hour of Lyndon Johnson Talks Politics, with Walter Cronkite.

title: Harok Attraction Here: Ashkenazy, Soviet Jew
description: By ironic coincidence, last night's Sol Hurok attraction at Carnegie Hall was Vladimir Ashkenazy, the Russian Jewish pianist who exiled himself from the Soviet Union eight years ago.

title: lovine Expects to Stick In Third Try as Trainer
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 26 Pat Iovine, the trainerdriver and owner who has been in and out of the harness racing business twice, is back again and this time he feels it's for good.

title: 16Volume Jewish Encyclopedia Ready
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26A team of Israeli and other scholars has completed the first major Jewish encyclopedia to be published in 65 years.

title: $54.9Million in Mortgages Accepted by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Federal National Mortgage Associat ion accepted $54.9million in fourmonth home mortgage commitments in its regular, hiweekly free market auction at an average yield of 7.613, it was announced yesterday.

title: CAVALIERS UPSET CELTICS, 112108
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)John Johnson scored 10 of his 22 points in the final period tonight as the Cleveland Cavaliers snapped an 11game losing streak with a 112108 victory over the Boston Celtics in the National Basketball Association.

title: Smile but Don't Date, Sapporo Girls Told
description: SAPPORO, Japan., Jan. 26 In this remote northern city of 1 million, just across the water from Soviet Siberia, the Japanese girls have been told to beware: The Olympic athletes are in town.

title: EMIL ALBERT RICH, 66, OF BUILDING CONCERN
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 26Emil Albert Rich, founder, director and senior vice president of the F. D. Rich company, one of the largest construction firms in the country, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 39 Willow Road, Riverside.

title: BILL WOULD EXTEND BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26  A revised bill to extend New York City's interim Board of Education for two more years and to permit Borough Presidents to appoint successors to the present incombents on the board Was introduced today in the Senate.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Basketball can resemble schoolyard brawl when a strong defensive team puts on constant pressure. But Fairleigh Dickinson's scrambling little players manage to keep things under control without too much contact as they lead major colleges in defense. The team was the best in the land in defense last season, too. In giving up 56.6 points a game in their first 11 con tests, the Bergen County Knights have committed fewer than 13 fouls a game. They're just cutting down on all facets of scoring.

title: Kings Turn Back Leafs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)John Widing scored two goals in the last 3 minutes 38 seconds tonight to give the Los Angeles Kings a 53 victory over Toronto as the slumping Maple Leafs dropped their fifth straight decision.

title: INDIAM ARKSHOLIDAY WITH A WAR PAGEANT
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 26The flush of victory over Pakistan last month dominated the mood of Indians today as they celebrated their country's 22d anniversary as a republic.

title: Some Families of P.O.W.'s Get Added Hope From Nixon Plan
description: The families of American prisoners of war in Indochina expressed mixed feelings about the latest peace proposals unveiled by President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With regard to A. Edward Miller's Jan. 17 OpEd article Consumerism's Other Half we would like to point out that consumerism has indeed made it into the dictionary. The Addenda section of Webster's Third New International Dictionary (1971 copyright) has the following entry:

title: News of Skiing
description: NICE, France, Jan. 25 Rimmed by pill boxes, some built by Louis Napoleon and some by Mussolini to guard the FrancoItalian border, the Isola 2000 winter resort already has become an international one in its first season.

title: LATINS SAID TO BAR U.S. BANKVOTE PLAN
description: BRASILIA, Brazil, Jan. 26LatinAmerican directors of the Inter  American Development Bank were reported today to have indicated their unwillingness to sacrifice regional sovereignty in exchange for needed funds from countries outside the Western Hemisphere.

title: Dr. Howard Marraro, 74, Dies; Professor of Italian at Columbia
