description: TORONTONot since the free trade election of 1911 has Canada been so absorbed with the question of her economic relations with the United States, A halfcentury ago the electorate turned out Sir Wilfrid Laurier's Liberal Government, which had negotiated a reciprocal freetrade agreement with Washington, in favor of Sir Robert Borden and the Conservatives.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Florida House Unit Votes Repeal of Newspaper Law
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 27 (UPI)A subcommittee of the Florida House voted today to repeal a state law requiring newspapers to publish replies of political candidates whom they criticize.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WORLD OP ART. By Robert Payne. 534 pages. Doubleday. $12.50.

title: LEFKOWITZ SUBMITS OFFSHORE DRILL BAN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27With the backing of a bloc of suburban Republican legislators, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz introduced a bill today to prohibit drilling for offshore oil or gas in the state's coastal waters.

title: New York Port Notes
description: The cruise ship Island Venture became the first new liner to enter the port this year when she was brought into her berth yesterday at Pier 92, North River.

title: Court Bars Dismissal by Columbia of 30 Maids
description: The State Division of Human Rights succeeded yesterday in postponing the dismissal of 30 maids by Columbia University.

title: South Asian Reality
description: Secretary of State Rogers has given welcome notice that the Administration will try to straighten out the mess it has made of policy toward the nations of the Indian subcontinent. A first step toward the realistic relations Mr. Rogers defines as the United States goal ought to be early recognition of the new state of Bangladesh.

title: Avon Sets Records
description: The Union Carbide Corporation and several other major companies in the fields of chem icals, drugs and toiletries released their results yesterday for the final 1971 quarter and the year.

title: Market Place: Mates. Fund's Omega Shares
description: You may not remember that stunning moment a few Decembers back when the Mates Investment Fund, Inc., announced (with the Securities and Exchange Commission's blessing) that it would not redeem the fund's shares for an indefinite period.

title: Canadian Step Expected
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 27 (UPI) External Affairs Minister Mitchell Sharp said today that he expected Canada and a number of West European, Scandinavian and Commonwealth countries to announce recognition of Bangladesh soon.

title: KEY INDICATORS UP IN DECEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Government's leading business indicators increased sharply in December, foreshadowing a strong upward movement in the economy in coming months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Panama Now a Financial Center
description: PANAMAAmid a confusion of political ideologies, Panama's steady economic growth is converting this crossroads of the world into the financial center for Latin America.

title: Schranz Is Confident
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Jan. 27 Schranz, Austria's ace skier, was cheerful today although it was generally understood that Avery Brundage wanted him excluded from the Olympics because of violation of the amateur code.

title: Nixon Expected to Leave On Trip to China Feb. 16
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) President Nixon is expected to leave on Wednesday, Feb. 16, for China and will stop over two days in Hawaii and one day in Guam on his way.

title: Youths Get 6Year Terms In Queens Mugging Death
description: Two teenagers who pleaded guilty in the mugging death of an 80yearold Rockaway, Queens, woman, were each sentenced yesterday to prison terms not to exceed six years.

title: 3 Inches of Snow Here By Tonight Forecast
description: Snow began falling here late last night, and the National Weather Service forecast possible accumulations of up to three inches in the city and higher amounts in the northern suburbs.

title: Brian's Song Is Proving to Be a Film Phenomenon
description: Brian's Song, a madeforTV movie, was billed in the ads as a true story about love. Actually, it was a true story about a deep friendship between two Chicago Bears football players, black Gale Sayers and white Brian Piccolo, who died of cancer in 1970 at the age of 26.

title: Interest Expressed
description: PARIS, Jan. 27 (UPI)Allied spokesmen said after today's session of the peace talks that the North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegates had displayed interest in the eightpoint American plan.

title: Hall of Fame Game Sold Out
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 27 (UPI)  The annual Hall of Fame baseball game on Aug. 7, pairing the New York Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers, became a complete sellout within 36 hours after ticket sales began. Hall of Fame authorities announced today that all 9,775 tickets were gone and that all other applications would be returned. Sandy Koufax, a former Dodger, and Yogi Berra, a former Yankee, will be inducted into the hall this year.

title: Daughter to Help Nixon
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 27 (UPI) Jacksonville residents willing to pay $100 a couple will get an opportunity to greet President Nixon's daughter and soninlaw at an informal reception March 22. Republican officials say they hope to raise nearly $18,000 for Mr. Nixon's reelection campaign at the gathering honoring David and Julie Eisenhower at the Deerwood Country Club.

title: Mexico: No More Miracle
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexico suffered her worst economic slowdown in more than a decade last year as the Government of President Luis Echeverria Alvarez sought to give a social orientation to development. His policies have not won many friends among Mexican businessmen.

title: Students Win in Illinois
description: DANVILLE, Ill., Jan. 27 (UPI) The Champaign County Clerk, Dennis Bing, must apply the same voter registration rules to students that are applied to other registrants, Judge Henry Wise of the United States District Court ruled yesterday on a class action suit brought by seven University of Illinois students. He said Mr. Bing had violated students constitutional rights under the 14th Amendment by presuming that students were not residents.

title: Swiss Cautioned on Birds
description: GENEVA, Jan. 27  The Hunters Association of Friboug, a city northeast of Lake Geneva, warned the public today against eating wild pigeons, partirdges, pheasants and other game birds because of mercury contamination. A number of cases of mercury poisoning, none fatal, had been reported in the area.

title: 4 Are Killed as Fire Strikes A Montreal Office Building
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (AP) Fire struck an office building in downtown Montreal today, killing at least four persons and injuring 13 others.

title: CITY AWARDS R C A JOBTRAINING PACT
description: Despite the hoots and jeers of 200 footstomping teachers, the Board of Estimate approved a contract yesterday giving the RCA Corporation operational control over the city's jobtraining program for slum youths.

title: Inflation Buffets Paraguay
description: ASUNCION, ParaguayA critical shortage of foreign exchange hit Paraguay's business community just before last Christmas and caused near panic in the small monied class. It also dashed Paraguayan hopes of creating an international money market here.

title: SATELLITE KILLER TESTED BY SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 27  A Federal report on the Soviet space program disclosed today that since 1967 the Russians have launched at least 18 spacecraft aimed at developing a satellite destroyer program. The report said the Russians had deliberately blown up at least seven orbital payloads in tests of the system.

title: Jersey Warehouse Burns
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27 (UPI) A rubberfed fire roared through a warehouse here today, sending up a column of smoke that was visible 15 miles away. The blaze destroyed the Woodward Terminal at 200 Pacific Avenue, in an industrial section of the city. The building housed the Lee Terminal Company, handlers of raw rubber, and the Foremost Delivery Company, shippers of cloth garments.

title: Former Treasury Aide Joins Lehman Brothers
description: Lehman Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday that John R. Petty has resigned as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, effective Feb. 25, to join the investment banking firm.

title: State of the Economy
description: Mr. Nixon's Economic Report to Congress represents a marked advance over his earlier reports in realism and candor, but it does not present a program sufficiently strong to assure a return in the coming year to what can reasonably be called full employment or price stability.

title: Amphetamine Production Quota May Be Reduced by 10% by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Justice Department's Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs expects to cut the total United States production quota of amphetamines by 10 per cent because a major producer has agreed to stop exporting the stimulant drug.

title: TUITIONFEE PLAN ANITYU.ASSAILED
description: A coalition of community groups declared yesterday that the imposition of tuition charges at the City University would remove one of the few remalning incentives for white, middleclass families to remain in the citythe opportunity to send their sons and daughters to the tuitionfree City University.

title: Tito Sees Enemies in Yugoslavia and Out
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 27Yugoslavia's leaders demanded tighter discipline in the Communist party here today as the solution to a crisis over nationalism. The call came amid growing concern that extremists abroad were mounting a wave of terorism against the nation.

title: Guyana: Wider Markets
description: GEORGETOWN, GuyanaPrime Minister Forbes Burnham set a bold new course for South America's only Englishspeaking republic last year by nationalizing the country's largest industry and establishing relations with the Soviet Union and China.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Jan. 17 letter of Sidney Hook and Miro M. Todorovich apparently through a misreading of a Times report, grossly misstates my position on events at the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting in Philadelphia. Their letter asserts that Dr. Commoner proclaimed that disruption is a healthy sign because it shows that ideas are being expressed openly (news story Dec. 28). In contrast, The Times Dec. 28 story states, Dr. Commoner's position was that the dissension [my emphasis] is a healthy sign because it shows that ideas are being expressed openly.

title: Fanny May Requirements On Common Stock Pared
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (Reuters)The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today it has reduced the common stock subscription requirement affecting concerns selling mortgages to the association.

title: Cuba's Treasury Remains in Moscow
description: MIAMIIt is more difficult to govern than to wage guerrilla warfare, Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba remarked last month.

title: Colonels Down Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (AP) The Kentucky Colonels, trailing by as many as 10 points several times, rallied for a 9894 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: Convicted Murderer Studying For the Episcopal Priesthood
description: A man convicted of murdering his wife and who is serving a life sentence at the Pennsylvania State Correctional Institution in Graterford, near Philadelphia, is studying for the Episcopal priesthood with the approval of his bishop.

title: FARMERS PLANNING CUT IN CORN ACREAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Farmers intend to reduce corn plantings by 4 per cent this year following a pricedepressing record crop of 55 billion bushels harvested in 1971, according to a special survey announced today by the Agriculture Department.

title: Paris Paper Closing Down
description: PARIS, Jan. 27 (AP)ParisJour, a morning tabloid newspaper, announced today that it was closing down. A statement by the publisher, Mrs. Simone del Duca, said that the paper was losing money and that labor made it impossible to apply an economy program.

title: RedPrinted Budget Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, said today that he had introduced legislation to require that any Federal budget proposing deficit spending be printed completely in red ink.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS STABILITY IS KEY TO ENDING CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Price and wage controls will remain indefinitely until reasonable price stability can be maintained without controls, President Nixon told Congress today.

title: Brazilian Ambassador Robbed in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (Reuters)  Augusto Araujo Castro, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, was beaten and robbed last night after he interrupted another armed robbery and apparent rape attempt in the Embassy garden.

title: COURT OVERRULES WIFE ON SURGERY
description: With court permissionover the objections of the patient's wifesurgeons at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center have implanted a new battery in the pacemaker that maintains the heartbeat of a 79yearold investment banker.

title: Notes on People
description: A Federal judge in Topeka, Accusing William M. Kunstler, the lawyer, of constantly having shown disdain and contempt for the judicial process, refused to allow him to argue a case in court.

title: Life in Marijuana Case
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)A Harris County district court jury sentenced today a 34yearold man to life imprisonment for possession of a pound of marijuana. Bonnie Tim who had two previous convictions for robbery and burglary, received the life term in Judge Edmund Duggan's court. His, wife, Brenda, 26, received a 10year probated sentence.

title: Sarah Mitchell, 70, Dies; Wall St. Investment Broker
description: Sarah Mitchell, one of the first women investment brokers on Wall Street, died in Montefiore Hospital on Thursday. She was 70 years old and lived at 11 Fifth Avenue. She was a registered representative with Spencer Trask & Company.

title: U. S. Streamlines Alien Deportation
description: By 8:30 A.M. most weekdays, when the financialdistrict crowds are still scurrying to Work, the chairs in the waiting room at the Immigration and Naturalization Service here are already filled with the day's harvest of deportation cases.

title: PRESIDENT OPENS NARCOTICS DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Nixon ordered today a concentrated assault on the street level heroin pusher and created a new office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement in the Justice Department to press the attack.

title: Back on the Line
description: The first realistic prospect for ending the marathon strike of telephone installation and repair crews in this state has finally emerged in union and company responses to an arbitration proposal by Vincent McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.

title: Trudeau Elevates Key Aides In Major Cabinet Shuffle
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 28  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau named new Canadian Ministers of Finance and Defense tonight. in an extended rearrangement of Cabinet posts.

title: Commission's Report Prematurely Released
description: The Fleischmann Commission specified that the contents of its report were not to be released before 6 p.m. today.

title: Singer Protests War At a Nixon Dinner For Digest Editors
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) A young woman in a singing group. caused an embarrassed moment at a formal White House dinner tonight when she waved a placard and called to. President Nixon to stop the bombing in Vietnam.

title: NIXON APPROVES AID TO MARBLE INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28President Nixon declined today to raise tariffs on marble and travertine products, but opened the way for producers and workers in the industry to receive adjustment assistance.

title: MORTIMER J. COHEN, HEBREW SCHOLAR, 77
description: The Rev. Dr. Mortimer J. Cohen, Hebrew scholar and author, died on Thursday at his honie, 1624 Lindley Avenue, Philadelphia. He was 77 years old.

title: Transit Riders Found to Have Dropped 2.5% After Fare Rise
description: In the two weeks following, the Jan. 5 fare increase to 35 cents from 30 cents. the number of subway and Transit Authority bus riders dropped about 2.5 per cent compared with the like period a month earlier, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 12 editorial criticizing the NavyMarine Corps use of a state park in Maine for amphibious training has been called to my attention. I would like to correct several inaccuracies and rebut your somewhat emotional view of the threat to the ecology of the area. On Jan. 12 I walked through Reid State Park with local officials and conferred with the press, Government officials and concerned residents. All questions raised were satisfactorily answered. [The operation took place after this letter was written (news story Jan. 23).]

title: Spotting Hijackers
description: F.B.I. agents got their manthe ransom hijacker of a Mohawk Airlineron an airfield in Poughkeepsie the other night, but not before there had been moments of extreme danger for 42 passengers and the plane's crew, including especially a stewardess held as hostage and seated beside the hijacker in a getaway car when he was slain by the blast of an agent's shotgun.

title: Gulf Emirate's Enclaves Are Reported Seized
description: SHARJA, Jan. 28 (AP)Hundreds of desert Arabs be gan arriving in this capital of the Persian Gulf emirate of Sharja from the emirate's eastern enclaves. There were unconfirmed reports that the enclaves had been taken over by the neighboring sultanate of Oman.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The hotel suites change for Frank McGuire, but the phones in them never ring, as if they were too timid interrupt him.

title: Ruritans Encounter New York
description: Ruritan National opened its annual convention here yesterday. The organization is made up of 1,250 clubs in 31 states, and for the most part its 36,855 members are country people.

title: ANNA HISS
description: Ann Hiss, a retired professor of physical education at the University of Texas, and elder sister of Alger Hiss, the former State Department aide, who served a jail sentence for perjury, died yesterday morning at Long Green nursing home, outside Baltimore. Miss Hiss, who lived in Baltimore, was 79 years old.

title: F.D.A. Removes Saccharin From List of Safe Foods
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Food and Drug Administration removed saccharin from the list of food products generally recognized as safe and put interim limits on its use.

title: Out of the Ashes, A New LifeStyle
description: Martin Charnin and his family escaped without injury that winter night two years ago when their television set exploded and fire gutted their Greenwich Village duplex. Indeed, most of their furnishings, and all of their books (about 1,000) and hundreds of ,recordings of Broadway musicals, many of them irreplaceable, were destroyed.

title: Thomas Parisi, Administrator Of Kings County, Is Dead at 67
description: Thomas G. Parisi, Public Administrator of Kings County, died Thursday night while on vacation in Miami. He was 67 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: A SOVIET DISSIDENT SAID TO TRY SUICIDE
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 28Dissident sources reported today that an inmate of the Leningrad psychiatric prison hospital had attempted suicide after having been injected with depressive drug.

title: A City Official Admits He Aided Bidder
description: The deputy commissioner in charge of the city's Emergency Repair Program acknowledged yesterday that a powerful East Side Democratic leader had received special treatment in the awarding of a $300,000 contract.

title: Executive Changes
description: Nicholas R. Marone, formerly vice president, marketing, has been appointed president of the Progresso Foods Corporation, Jersey City.

title: Zumwalt Bids Italy Emulate U.S. Navy BuildUp
description: ROME, Jan. 28The United States Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., urged Italy today to increase her naval strength as we are doing.

title: Dr. William C. Wermuth, 57, Psychoanalyst and Teacher
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28Dr. William Charles Wermuth, a psychoanalyst who was associate professor of psychiatry at the Hahnemann Medical College and attending psychiatrist at the Institute of Pennsylvania Hospital and at Hahnemann Hospital, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived in Wynnewood.

title: For Colon, Twilight After a Place in the Sun
description: COLON, Panama, Jan. 13 It is now 26 years since a nightclub entertainer known as Jade Rhodora did her beautyandthebeast. dance, more than 40 years since Will Rogers slept at the Washington Hotel and 59 years since Vincent Astor walked the colored tiles on Front Street, past stores offering stuffed iguana paperweights and French lace. Noone does the beauty and thebeast dance in Collin any more (Miss Rhodora shed her costume, part girl and part lascivious gorilla, and became a landlady in Panama City after World War II, then married an Army officer and had a baby she called Cristal Jadeshe was last heard of in California); an American hotel chain is engaged in a seemingly interminable effort to erase the years of dilapidation in the Washington, which houses no guests, and only the iguana paperweights remain to stare sightlessly out onto a Front Street nearby empty of cash customers, Astor or others.

title: TALKS CONTINUE IN LI.R.R. DISPUTE
description: Negotiations aimed at averting a possible strike on the Long Island Rail Road tomorrow afternoon were moved to Washington yesterday at the request of W. J. Usery Jr., Assistant Secretary of Labor.

title: Soviet Comment Skeptical
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (Reuters) The first Soviet commentaries on President Nixon's peace proposals today were highly skeptical but avoided outright rejection.

title: Mrs. Fisher to Be Married Today
description: The marriage of Mrs. Harriet Cooper Fisher to David Lydig Frothingham, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer & Brooks, will take place in Baltimore today.

title: Hawks Top Pistons, 124106
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 28 (UPI)Pete Maravich, who had to have two stitches taken in his head in the second quarter, came back to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 124106 victors over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: Miss Schneirla Is Wed To London Consultant
description: Miss Dorothy Page Schneirla, daughter of the Very Rev. and Mrs. William Sutfin Schneirla of New York and Stanton, N. J., was married at her home in London last Saturday to David Malcolm Downie, a management consultant there. The bride's father, who is executive secretary of the Antiochian (Greek) Orthodox Archdiocese in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 28  Our diverse worlds  developed, underdeveloped. East, Westhave at least one article of faith in common: economic growth. For individuals, for economic enterprises and for nations, growth is happiness, the specific for ills and the foundation of hope. Next year our family will be richer, our company bigger, our country more productive.

title: Thieu Said to Have Backed Peace Bid Before Election
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28  President Nguyen Van 1Thieu agreed to the allies new peace proposals, including his offer to resign, even before his reelection last Oct. 3, according to authoritative American sources.

title: U.S. FISHING CHARGES DENIED BY 3 RUSSIANS
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Three Soviet fishing) captains pleaded not guilty today to charges of illegal fishing activities in American waters. They asked for a meeting with the Federal Judge and the prosecutor to see about speeding up a trial date.

title: DUBLIN ARRESTS 7 I.R.A. MEMBERS
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 28  The Irish Government, worried about the impact of a twohour gun battle yesterday between British soldiers and the Irish Republican Army, moved today against several known members of the illegal organization.

title: 10 G.I.'s Wounded In Several Clashes East of the Capital
description: SAIGON, South Victnam, Saturday, Jan. 29 (AP)Enemy forces wounded 10 Americans and shot up a resupply helicopter in a flurry of fighting east of Saigon yesterday, the United States command said today.

title: Chrysler Acids 3.2% to Cost Of JapaneseBuilt Dodge
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was raising the price of its Japanesebuilt Dodge Colt an average of 3.2 per cent, or $69.

title: BOHM CONDUCTS OPENING FIGARO
description: If Mozart had been alive to celebrate his 216th birthday on Thursday he might have enjoyed ending the day at the Metropolitan Opera, which presented a stylish and entertaining performance of Le Nozze de Figaro.

title: Jersey Utility Will Refund $1.1Million to Gas Users
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28  The Public Service Electric and Gas Company will refund $1.1million to its gas customers by reducing its February billing by fourtenths of a cent therm in the raw materials adjustment charge. A therm is unit for measuring heat.

title: CORNFELD IS SUED FOR $9.7MILLION
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP)A $9.7million suit has been filed against financier Bernard Cornfeld by woman who contends Mr. Cornfeld pocketed that amount in fees which should have been paid to her and other shareholders in his now defunct Investors Overseas Services fund.

title: Bart Cook Shows Classic Technique In City Ballet Duet
description: Nowhere in ballet has the interweaving of female corps and soloists been as marked as in the choreography of George Balanchine, artistic director of the New York City Ballet. A 16yearold corps member in the back row has as much if not more actual dancing to do as the principal ballerina had in a 19thcentury ballet.

title: LAKERS WIN, 118105
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers rallied from a 19point deficit to defeat the Houston Rockets, 118105,tonight.

title: Hadassah Assails Zionist Move Requiring Emigration to Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  The 28th World Zionist Congress ended early today in a stormy session when Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, withdrew from the convention hall in protest against a resolution binding Zionist leaders to settle in Israel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TED KIVTT RETURNS IN TOPPELIA WORK
Salvation Army Inducts A New National Chief
description: A 67yearold career officer in the Salvation Army was installed last night as its 14th national commander.

title: GROMYKO ADVISES NATIONS ON CHINA
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28  Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, warned today that countries desiring friendly re lations with both China and the Soviet Union must act without] adversely affecting the safety and interests of the Soviet Union.

title: Ribicoff Abandons Drive For Nixon Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28In a move that stunned both the Nixon Administration and Senate Democratic leaders, Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff abandoned today his drive for enactment this year of a guaranteed annual income for the poor.

title: Dance: A Zany Hoopla
description: Murray Louis's new ballet, Hoopla, which amply enjoyed its world premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, is mad, zany, adorable, and Mr. Louis's most considerable contribution so far to the pleasures of the world.

title: Gregory Foster Recalled as a Hero in War and as a Law Student
description: The young people on the Lower East Side where Patrolman Gregory P. Foster walked his beat at night called him Mister Cool, and last Christmas they left a gift for him at the precinct stationthe Ninth. It was plaque bearing his name and a copy of his shield.

title: AGENCY IS UPHELD BY RUCKELSHAUS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 William D. Ruckelshaus, ministrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, clashed today with Representative Paul G. Rogers over charges that the White House Office of Management and Budget, responding to industry pressure, had repeatedly forced the agency to temper its enforcement the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: Bridge: Nightly Duplicate Games Set For Club Opening Tomorrow
description: Manhattan's newest bridge club opens tomorrow at the Allan Rich Galleries, 787 Madison Avenue, near 66th Street, and will schedule duplicate games nightly at 7:45. A regular Sunday afternoon game will be preceded by brunch at 12:30 P.M., which will be free tomorrow.

title: Notes on People
description: Ralph Ginzburg, the magazine publisher who was convicted in 1963 on charges of having distributed obscene materials through the mails, was ordered to start serving his prison sentence Feb. 17.

title: Edith Irving Remained Cool While SheWas Playing a Double Role
description: It was, for the who have been with her since the start of the Hughes book mystery, impossible to believe that Edith Sdmmer Irving was leading a double life.

title: LINDSAY, IN MIAMI, DECRIES SLAYINGS
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28  Declaring that the United States is the most violent nation on earth today, Mayor Lindsay condemned the fatal wounding of two New York City policemen late last night and hammered away at the need for stricter guncontrol laws across the nation as he campaigned today in southern Florida.

title: Delacote, at Philharmonic, Picks Bruckner for Bow
description: A man who is horn on tope of a mountain begins with a, problem: How is he ever going to rise in the world? Jacques Delacote, the young French conductor who led the New York Philharmonic for the first time Thursday night, started in a somewhat similar fix, having chosen Bruckner's mammoth unfinished Symphony No. 9 in D minor for his debut piece.! If there is a Mount Everest among Bruckner symphonies, it is the Ninth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR SUBSIDY ASKED FOR SMALL TOWNS
description: Responding to the needs of isolated towns with deteriorating or nonexistent airline service, the Civil Aeronautics Bqard proposed yesterday an experiment to subsidize specially tailored air operations to such outoftheway spots.

title: Irving and City Bank Cut Prime to 41%
description: The First National City Bank, and the Irving Trust Company, dropped to 4 per cent yesterday the rates at which they lend to their best corporate customers.

title: Hanoi Seeks Clarification
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Jan. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Communist party newspaper Nhan Dan said today that North Vietnam would respond officially to President Nixon's proposals only after further clarification.

title: EAST MEETS WEST IN A.B.A. STRUGGLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 28Deferring to nobody but Archie Bunker, the American Basketball Association will hold its fifth AllStar Game here tomorrow night.

title: HAROLD M. GARTLEY
description: Harold M. Gartley, who retired in 1968 as president of Gartley & Associates, Inc., a financial public relations organization here, died yesterday in Sun City Center, Fla. He was 73 years old.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN FUNERAL TALKS
description: Negotiators for 1,800 hearse drivers and other funeral workers reached a contract agreement early yesterday morning with three metropolitan area funeral associations thus averting a strike that would have blocked funerals throughout the downstate area this weekend.

title: Peking Denounces Nixon's Proposals
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 28.Peking today denounced President Nixon's latest proposal for settlement of the war in Indochina as a plan of aggression and asserted that acceptance of the iVetnamese Communists demands was the only way out for the United States.

title: Shoals of Broncos Retires
description: DENVER, Jan. 28 (AP) Roger Shoals, an offensive tackle for nine years in the National Football League, announced his retirement today from the Denver Broncos.

title: Black Leaders Tell British Why Rhodesia Accord Is Unacceptable
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 28The voice of African nationalismmuffled for years in whiteruled Rhodesia  was heard again today as black leaders told an English peer why they oppose Britain's suggested agreement to recognize the independence of the white Government here.Six officers of the recently formed African National Congress sat across a table in a college lecture hall and told Lord Pearce, chairman of the British Commission on Rhodesian Opinion, that their organization represents most blacks here and that it unhestitating ly rejects a complex political formula that provides for a creeping increase in the po litical rights of the black majority.

title: Gale Meltzer Is Bride Of Steven Levenson
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Jan. 28Miss Gale Barbara Meltzer and Steven Michael Levenson were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.. Abe Meltzer. Rabbi Gilbert Klapperman performed the ceremony.

title: Say Hello to Preston, Rowell, N. M.I
description: Each morning, at the corner of 88th Street and Central Park West, a little ritual takes place that puts hundreds of persons, myself included, in a better frame of mind to face their jobs, the subway and the city.

title: PRICES OF LIQUOR TO RISE TUESDAY
description: Residents of New York State face a compounded increase in liquor costs beginning Tuesday.

title: Slain Policemen Were Buddies in War
2 Large Companies Are Sued By Trust Buster on Last Day
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)  Assistant Attorney General Richard W. McLaren, the first Federal trust buster to attack conglomerate mergers and longstanding reciprocal purchasing agreements, sued two more of the nation's largest companies today, his last day on the job.

title: 500Mile Snowmobile Race Is Captured by Duhamel
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 38Yvon Duhamel of Valcourt, Quebec, driving a 1972 SkiDoo Blizzard snowmobile, won the seventh international 500mile WinnipegtoSt. Paul snowmobile race. Duhamel's total elapsed time was 13 hours 25 minutes 37 seconds. His margin of victory was 22 minutes 50 seconds in the fourday race.

title: The Screen:'The Abductors' Begins Run at the DeMille
description: "The Abductors," starring Cheri Caffaro as the woman detective who was introduced in "Ginger" last year, makes a desperate effort to give new urgency to the old white slave theme. It's about a ring that seems to operate out of Wantagh, L. I., and kidnaps young girls who are then sold as mistresses to what are supposed to be business tycoons from Miami, Los Angeles and Oregon. It has, as you can see, a very curious conception of the seats of American high life.The movie, which could have been very funny, isn't, principally because the demands it makes upon our imaginations are too great. All of the women are idiots. The men look like the sort of people who pose in $42 suits in Sears Roebuck catalogues, and the main set, which is described in my synopsis as a baronial country estate, resembles a suburban garage without A/C.The only reason I bother to take note of it is that it opened yesterday at the DeMille Theater, which occasionally plays real movies.

title: HelpWanted Index Rose Four Points in December
description: The Conference Board reported yesterday that the helpwanted advertising index rose in December to 85 per cent of the 1967 base period. This was a gain of 4 points over the November level and 3 points above the December 1970 level.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Irving Discloses His Wife Is Helga Hughes Who Transferred $650,000 to Swiss Bank
description: Clifford Irving, the novelist who said he had compiled an autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, told the New York County District Attorney's office yesterday that it was his wife who opened a Swiss bank account after identifying herself as Helga Hughes.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GUATEMALA, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Guatemala's army has been put on the alert following the dispatch of British troops to British Honduras, a military spokesman here said tonight. The army will remain on alert because we must defend our territory according to circumstances, Col. Felix Roman Beteta said.

title: FEW PAPERS READ BY BERRIGAN JURORS
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 The jury for the trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists seems likely to be a rural and small town group relatively isolated from the peace movement and unaware of the Roman Catholic Left.

title: Drug Law Enforcer Myles Joseph Ambrose
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28President Nixon's new enforcer of narcotics laws is known as a relentless driver of subordinates who love him for it. One reason is that they know he sets an even tougher pace for himself. Nothing else could explain why 500 customs bureau workers chipped in to hire a movie house and walked there in a steady drizzle before the work ing hour today just to tell their boss goodby and good luck in his new job.

title: JOSEPH ROBERTS, 54, HEAD OF STORECAST
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 28 Joseph W. Roberts, president of the Storecast Corporation of America, New York, an instore salespromotion company, and executive vice president of the Comcast Corporation, a Pennsylvania concern that operates CATV stations, died today in the YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: BUCKS SET BACK 76ERS, 127 TO 118
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 34 points, Bob Dandridge 30 as the Milwaukee Bucks held off a late rally to beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 127118, tonight in the National Basketball Association.

title: Such Delicate Hands for a Blacksmith
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y.When Longfellow described the blacksmith as a mighty man is he, with large and sinewy hands, he hadn't met Donna Hincher. Donna is 19, 5 feet 2 and weighs 105 pounds. She has small hands with nicely manicured nails. A premed sophomore at Union College, she spends alb of her spare time working as an unpaid groom at the Saratoga Raceway, the harness track.

title: 5,000 Throng to Felt Forum for Poetry Reading by Yevtushenko
description: Is the Felt Forum, the public arena that seats 5,000 people a forum for the reading of poetry, an experience that is deeply felt but usually quite personal; Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the outgoing Russian poet, evidently thought so, and so did 5,000 persons who filled the hall in the first of two readings given fast evening. And as of this writing, the second reading was also sold out.

title: Ultrasonic Method Modifies Scalpel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Lewis Balamuth, a New York physicist, was granted a patent this week for a method of ultrasonic cauterization that he says will provide bloodless surgery. Patent 3,636,943 is assigned to Ultrasonic Systems, Inc., Farmingdale, L. I. for which Mr. Balamuth is director of research. The company, the manufacturer of ultrasonic and highfrequency motors, plans to produce the patented surgical knife after it undergoes medical tests. bloodless surgery. Patent 3,636,943 is assigned to Ultrasonic Systems, Inc., Farmingdale, L. I. for which Mr. Balamuth is director of research. The company, the manufacturer of ultrasonic and highfrequency motors, plans to produce the patented surgical knife after it undergoes medical tests.

title: PROFIT DECLINES AT NL INDUSTRIES
description: Operating income of NL, Industries, Inc., formerly National Lead, was $22,757,000, or 95 cents a share in 1971. After an extraordinary charge of $19.5million, or 81 cents share, the net was reduced to $3,257,000, or 14 cents, a share.

title: Nevada Court Allows Questioning of Hughes
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 28The Nevada Supreme Court issued an order today clearing the way for lawyers to question Howard R. Hughes personally in a $50million suit against him.

title: State Bar Group Elects
description: Robert MacCrate, a Manhattan lawyer and a member of the State Crime Control Planning Board, was officially designated presidentelect of the State Bar Association yesterday at the group's convention here. A partner in the law firm of Sullivan and Cromwell, Mr. MacCrate served as special counsel to the Army from December, 1969, to March, 1970, for the investigation of the Mylai massacre.

title: Shock in Ibiza By RICHARD EDER
description: MADRID, Jan. 28  Friends of Clifford and Edith Irving in Spain expressed shock at the news that Mr. Irving had admitted that his wife had posed Helga Hughes to open Swiss bank account and later withdraw $650,000 intended for Howard R. Hughes.

title: 3 Stars to Be in Angel For C.B.S.TV on Feb. 25
description: Geraldine Page, E. G. Marshall and Timothy Bottoms will star in Look Homeward, Angel, an adaptation of the Pulitzer Prizewinning play based on on Thomas Wolfe's famous autobiographical novel, which the Columbia Broadcasting System will televise next month as 90minute special.

title: Bullets Beat Royals, 132124
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 28 (UPI) Jack Marin scored 38 points tonight as the Baltimore Bullets defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 132124, for the fourth time in five games this season to hold onto first place in the N.B.A.'s Central Division.

title: U.S Steel to Close Plant and Lay Off 1,600 Employes
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday it would close down the major part of its Duluth, Minn., integrated steel mill by March 4. The shutdown would eliminate the jobs of some 1,600 of the plant's normal work force of 2,300.

title: $300,000 Boat Ordered for Fishing Off Jersey
description: Monticello is a small city in Arkansas, 30 miles south of the Arkansas River. But it loomed large at the National Boat Show yesterday when, Mon Ark Boats came through with what is likely to be the biggest single deal of the exhibition.

title: Windward Passage Wins Opener of Sailing Series
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP)The 73foot ketch, Windward Passage, led almost from start to finish for an easy triumph over Blackfin as their twoofthree match race off Long Beach Harbor began today.

title: U.A.W. HEAD BACKS IEJSKIE CANDIDACY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, wrote off the prospects today of seven candidates for I the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Patent Chief Sees an End to Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The new head of the Patent Office is confident that he can rescue the agency from an admittedly grave condition of piledup paper work and low morale.

title: Hughes Book: Plight of the Publishers
How to Pay for the Schools
description: In promising new solutions to the critical problem public school financing, President Nixon has lashed out against the rising property tax as one of the most oppressive and discriminatory of all taxes. His pledge to bring relief from this levy and, at the same time, provide new ways of paying for elementary and secondary education comes in the wake of several court rulingsin California, Texas and most recently in New Jerseyall holding that the present approach to school financing is discriminatory and thus violates the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection.

title: Reagan to Oppose Nixon on Welfare Before Congress
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 28 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan announced today that he would go before Congress next Tuesday to oppose the heart of President Nixon's welfare reform plan, which he labeled to costly and liberal.

title: Joan Sutherland Sings and Acts On 2 Minioperas for U.S. TV
description: LONDON, Jan. 28  For Joan Sutherland, the singing here this week proved no problem. But all that speaking is another story.

title: NORMAN H. KENT ARTIST AND EDITOR
description: Norman Howe Kent, artist, editor and teacher, died Thursday in a nursing home in Mamaroneck, N. Y. He was 68 years old and lived at 437 Carroll Avenue, Mamaroneck.

title: Dean Witter Co. Registers Public Offering of Stock
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., the brokerage concern, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday 1,492,120 shares, of which the concern will offer 1.25 million. The balance will be sold by private holders. The sale, which will be selfunderwritten, represents the company's first public offering.

title: G.O.P. Presses Campaign For Nixon's Peace Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 More than 123 members of Congress signed letters circulated by the Republican leadership today expressing support for President Nixon's eightpoint peace proposal for Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rocco Laurie Remembered as Quiet and Athletic as S. I. Youth
description: When Rocco Laurie was a boy, he stood out among the chidren bundled off to school each morning on his quiet street in Staten Island's Willowbrook section.

title: Soviet Aides Here Seek Exchange of Ship Trade
description: Igor M. Averin, head of the Soviet Union's Ministry of Merchant Marine, said yesterday that American ships are welcome in the Soviet Union as soon as the necessary business starts.

title: Violence Scored at Bomb Victim's Rites
description: The president of the New York Board of Rabbis yesterday called on those who justify violence as a means to noble ends to renounce that path) down which our society has! been moving, as a tribute tol Iris L. Kones, the 27yearold! secretary killed Wednesday in the firebombing of a Manhattan talentbooking office.

title: Garden DoubleHeader M. atches the Big Names
House Democrats See G.O.P. in Albany Mapping Some Districting Trades
Big 10 Backs Minnesota In Suspending 2 Players
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP)The Big Ten joined with the University of Minnesota today and agreed that two Minnesota basketball players he suspended for the remainder of the season for unsportsmanlike acts in last Tuesday night's game against Ohio State.

title: DINO BUZZATI DIES; ITALIAN WRITER, 65
description: ROME, Jan. 28 Dino Buzzati, a journalist and one of Italy's bestknown contempo rary writers, died in a hospital here today after an illness of two months. He was 65 years old.

title: Stock Volume Soars; OTC Sets a Record
description: The overthecounter market and the American Stock Exchange came alive yesterday as volume and prices made sharp gains.

title: Big Board Prices in a Broad Rise Dow Up 6.55
description: Stock prices moved, broadly higher yesterday on the heaviest volume in more than ,five months, with glamour issues continuing to lead the sharp recovery.

title: The Aim Is That Healthy, Natural Look
description: A natural element, called Base Dergyl and said to duplicate an element in human skin, is the basis of the Pier Aug cosmetics face and body preparations to be introduced by Saks Fifth Avenue on Monday. Mr. Auge, who started his own business in Paris 11 years ago, had formerly worked on the development of products for beauty salons and spas. An exponent of natural organic and hypoallergenic ingredients, his emulsions of proteins, vitamins and organic fatty compounds are aimed at returning to the skin its own natural substances lost because of environment and the aging process.

title: SIDNEY E. FRIEDMAN
description: Sidney E. Friedman, a consulting partner in the New York law firm of Friedman & Friedman, died Thursday in Coral Gables, Fla., where he lived. His age was 69.

title: Rites for Mahalia Jackson Set for Tuesday in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28Services for Mahalia Jackson, the Chicago gospel singer, will be held at 11 A.M. Tuesday in the Greater Salem Baptist Church on Chicago's South Side, it was announced tonight. The body will lie in state there beginning Monday morning. Miss Jackson died yesterday at the age of 60.

title: 3 LEAD BY STROKE
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29Takashi Murakami, a Japanese newcomer to the American professional golf tour shared a threeway tie today for the 36hole lead with 137 in the $150,000 Andy WilliamsSan Diego open.

title: Nixon Hails Reader's Digest on Jubilee
description: The Reader's Digest celebrated its 50th anniversary in the White House last night, long way from the modest quarters in which it was born in New York's Greenwich Village.

title: Anxiety on Dollar Persists As Gold Price Soars Again
description: ZURICH, Jan. 28Bankers in this sophisticated financial center see a stronger dollar emerging in the longer ru,n from the currency realignment last month, but they still are a little anxious about the cost that's immediately ahead.

title: Pay Unit Reports Accord On Construction Wages
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Construction Industry Stabilization Committee accepted today for the first time the general wage standards set by the Pay Board but was granted near autonomy in its operations and will not be held rigidly to the board's guidelines.

title: 2 IN STOCK CASE DUE IN CANADIAN COURT
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 28 I Charges of forgery, fraud and conspiracy have been laid against two Canadians and an American stemming from trading in Pan American Mines last summer, and two of them appear again in court Tuesday, when the judge will set a date for the preliminary hearing.

title: Bonanza for the Colonels
description: At a time when Congress has finally voted to cut off military aid to Greece, the Administration is quietly pushing a major Navy project that would provide the biggest prestige boost ever for the ruling colonels. With White House backing, the Navy seeks to establish homeport facilities in Greece to accommodate about a third of the Sixth Fleet and house 6,000 or more wives and children of U. S. Navy personnel in that country.

title: Hostess, in Rear of Jet, Survived Czech Crash
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 (UPI) The newspaper Borba said today that a Yugoslav stewardess survived a 31,000foot fall from an exploding plane when the tail section, where she was, fell to a snowcovered slope and bounced instead of smashing on impact.

title: Child's Body Is Frozen After Death on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP)The father of an 8yearold girl who died of a kidney disorder says her body has been frozen in the hope that science later will be able to revive and cure her.

title: Antiques: A Few Surprises in Art Nouveau Lamps
description: This week's sale of Art Nouveau at the ParkeBernet Galleries proved that surprises can still be found in lamps of the period.

title: 4 Youths Freed on Bail
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn. Jan. 28 (UPI)Four youths, described as members of the Jewish Defense League, were free on $250 bond today after being arrested and charged with breach of peace, for disturbing a Russian orchestra performance.

title: Do You Want to Live on Park Avenue?
Article 2  No Title
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28 (AP)Longshoremen and teamsters picketed at the United StatesMexico border today to stop trucks coming into California from the nearby Mexican port of Ensenada.

title: P. A. Fisher Weds Mrs. Frothingham
description: Mrs. Margaret Morgan Frothingham was married here yesterday to Pieter A. Fisher, a vice president of Goldman, Sachs & Co., investment bankers. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Figures Cast by Hanson Are Shown Downtown
description: The socalled superrealist sculpture of Duane Hanson, who has been showing his work in New York since 1968, is an art that depends on technique for its morerealthanreal effect. Just as the superrealist painters rely heavily on the camera for their precision in execution, so Mr. Hanson casts directly from the human body for his simulated lifelike accuracy.

title: JERSEY BOY IS KILLED BY CAR IN SNOWFALL
description: The heaviest snowfall of sofar almost snowless winter 1.8 inchescoated the city in white for a few hours yesterday and caused the death of one suburban child and injuries to at least seven other children.

title: Where Haute Cuisine and Creole Foods Mix
description: FORT DE FRANCE, MartiniqueIf it weren't for the green, volcanic mountains piercing the clouds to the north and the thousands of black Frenchmen in the streets, this could be Marseilles. The bustling center of this island has been solidly gallicized during its years as a French colony and now as an almost fullfledged French department.

title: Politics And Parole
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.The U. S. parole board's decision to grant parole to the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan illustrates the difficulties of applying traditional concepts of criminality and corrections to essentially political activity.

title: ERHARD MILCH, 79, LUFTWAFFE CHIEF
description: LUNEBURG, West Germany, Jan. 28 (AP)Erhard Milch, a protege of Hermann Goering, Adolf Hitler's close aide, and the organizer of the Luftwaffe in World War II, died here Tuesday at the age of 79.

title: CROP ESTIMATES AFFECT FUTURES
description: An Agriculture Department report that estimated acreage farmers would devote to major crops affected prices of soybean and grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The report was issued after the close of trading Thursday.

title: Yugoslav Reforms to Follow Suppression of Croat Nationalists
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28  The Yugoslav Deputy Premier, Dr. Anton Vratusa, asserted this week that the removal of nationalist leaders in Croatia last month had opened the way for broad federal economic reforms.

title: 3D CAREER BEGINS FOR AL CARMINES
description: Al Carmines, the associate minister of the Judson Memorial Church who has carved out a second career as a composer of scores for Off Broadway shows"Promenade, In Circles, Peace and the current Wanted, among othershas embarked upon a third career, that of nightclub performer.

title: Santa Barbara, 3 Years Later, Fights Oil Drilling
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 28  A solitary picket paced back and forth at the toot of Santa Barbara's main pier this week, waving a battered placard reading: Union and Sun Are Unfair.

title: American Medical Agrees to Acquire Hospitals Concern
description: American Medical International, Inc., announced yesterday that it has agreed in principle to acquire Chanco Medical Industries for 1 million shares of its stock. Based on the closing price of American Medical stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday of 38, the trans action is valued at over $38million.

title: S.E.C. and Senate Unit Differ on Fees
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and a key Senate subcommittee apparently are at odds over the question of the extent to which sales commissions should be freely negotiable in the securities industry.

title: Yanks Hope to Open 75 InHouse theCity Rebuilt
description: If present plans continue on schedule, Yankee Stadium will be modernized in time for the 1975 baseball season, the Yankees will play the 1974 season in Shea Stadium, and the football Giants may be looking for a home in 1973 and 1974.

title: Black Market Down, Saigon Hopes Rise
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28There was a time not long ago when Governmentsanctioned banks were seldom seen by Americans or other foreigners in South Vietnam.

title: 13 Colleges in State in Fiscal Trouble
Warriors Top Trail Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 28 (AP)Nate Thurmond and Jeff Mullins scored 53 points between Lnern tonight to lead the Golden State Warriors to 105102 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Buckley Ends Asian Tour
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, left Seoul for home this afternoon after twoweek tour of Southeast Asia aimed at sounding out views on recent United States foreign policy developments.

title: Market Place: Alden Defended On Schenley Bid
description: Not everyone believes that shareholders of Schenley Industries were badly treated by the Glen Alden management when Glen Alden merged interests of the two concerns.

title: STATE PANEL BIDS ALBANY TAKE OVER SCHOOL FINANCING
Chattanooga Told to Ignore] State Court's Busing Order
description: CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 28 (AP) Judge Frank Wilson of the United States District Court ruled today that a state court had no authority to rescind or interfere with Federal court jurisdiction in school desegregation cases.

title: BRITISH DENY AIRLIFT IS SHOW OF STRENGTH
description: LONDON, Jan. 28 (UPI)Britain said today that the disfiatch of forces to British Honduras was for land, air and sea exercises planned since last April and not a show of strength against Guatemala, which claims the British colony.

title: Books of The Times
description: Both of these novels arc firsts and both are variants on a classic theme: the passage of a young man from childhood through adolescence to adulthood  and with luck to maturity. It is the common substance of early fiction, but a substance capable of infinite renewal and infinite change. But how varied these changes can be is indicated by the way these books differ in language, in structure, in point of view. It is a little ironic, and maybe little unfair. that Shedding Skin, which fits into a familiar contemporary mold, nicely successful, while Skate, which more ambitious, is not successful at all.

title: 58 CAPTAINS GET NEW ASSIGNMENTS IN POLICE SHUFFLE
description: Fiftyeight of the Police Department's 340 captains were assigned new posts yesterday in what headquarters oldtimers said was probably the biggest shuffle of captains in 20 years.

title: Murphy Attacks Nations Prisons As Total Failure
description: Characterizing the nation's prisons as a total failure, PoL lice Commissioner Patrick Murphy called yesterday for a revolution in public attittdes and the infusion of hundreds of millions of dollars to sup.plant retribution with rehabilitation in the correctional system.

title: U.C.L.A. TROUNCES LOYOLA, 92 TO 64
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI)All five University of California, Los Angeles, starters scored in double figures tonight as the No. 1 ranked Bruins rolled to an easy 9264 victory over Loyola of Chicago at the Chicago Stadium.

title: PURCELL'S WORKS SUNG BY CHORALE
description: Lip service is paid to Henry Purcell as the greatest English composer, but his music, now 300 years old, is performed less often than it should be. Some of it turns up in churches and the concert hall, but not in the quantity that would provide genuine perspective of the composer's genius.

title: Allende's New Cabinet Has Nearly All the Old Faces
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 28President Salvador Allende Gossens reorganized his Cabinet today for a new push toward the construction of Socialism in Chile.

title: BUDGET EXCEEDS SPENDING FIGURES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Federal Government may have difficulty spending in the current fiscal year the $236.6billion estimated in the President's budget, new Treasury figures indicated today.

title: Talk Fiery at U.N. Council in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 28The United Nations, Security Council opened its speI cial meeting in Africa today with a barrage of fiery rhetor, is that some delegates think will set the tone for the weeks, to come.

title: Sonics Trim Braves 10493
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 28 (AP) The Seattle SuperSonics outscored Buffalo from the foul line 389, and rallied from 12 points behind in the final period to defeat the Braves, 10493, tonight.

title: Inco and U.S. Steel Plan Job Cutbacks
description: TORONTO, Jan. 28The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., disclosed today that it was abolishing 1,965 jobs and would slash production of nickel by 10 per cent. The move which followed a per cent production cut last August and a further 15 per cent cut announced in October, was attributed to weakening demand for the metal in world markets.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After a meeting with a parents group yesterday, officials at Willowbrook State School have agreed to reinstate two staff members who were dismissed four weeks ago.

title: Mad Killers of the Law
description: All available details in the senseless killing of two young police officers on the Lower East Side add up wanton, unprovoked murder. The patrolmen, Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie, who had become friends on military duty in Vietnam, volunteered for service in community police unit and had personally earned high degree of neighborhood confidence.

title: HERMAN LEVIN
description: Herman Levin, a certified public accountant and lawyer here since 1928, died Thursday at his home, 870 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: FinksToldMara:Yes,I'mConcerned About Offense
description: The New York Giants were the ones who initiated the trade of Francis Tarkenton to the Minnesota Vikings, which was completed on Thursday. The negotiators were Wellington Mara, president of the Giants, and Jim Finks, the Minnesota general manager. It took a month to work out the deal as these two virtually repeated in reverse their actions during January, 1967, when Tarkenton was traded by the Vikings for four future Giant draft choices.

title: Evans Outruns McGrady in 600
description: Lee Evans confirmed his Olympic intentions last night and convinced at least one competitor, Martin McGrady.

title: Looking at Le Corbusier the Painter
description: CharlesEdouard Jeanneret, known the world over as a great architect and architectural theorist under the name of Le Corbusier, a pseudonym adopted in 1918. was also a painter and graphic artist of some distinction. In the nineteentwenties, he was one of the leaders of the socalled Purist movement in Parisan attempt to codify the principles of cubism along the lines of a flat, simplified and highly architectural design surface without sacrificing the representational content of painting. The reigning motif of Purism was the still life.

title: President Consoles Boy Whose Pet Dog Had Leg Amputated
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 28 (AP) Jamie Wallace, 11 years old, became depressed when his pet dog, Chopper, was injured and had to have a leg amputated.

title: CONSUMERS POWER SHOWS INCOME DROP
description: The Consumers Power Company reported yesterday a decline in 1971 net income despite record sales of electricity and natural gas.

title: Prosecutors Call For Legal Gambling As Revenue Source
description: The State District Attorneys Association voted tentatively yesterday for a resolution urging the legalization of many forms of gambling.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Grayson Visits 4 Food Stores, Decides Prices Are Stabilizing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28C. Jackson Grayson Jr., Price Commission chairman, told the nation's largest consumer group today that he was encouraged about price controls because onl a shopping trip to four suburban supermarkets in Virginia last weekend he found only one food item whose price had gone up.

title: Courts and Parajudges
description: We have recently witnessed a series of harsh attacks on the judiciary, and some equally strident replies. At the risk of appearing in the selfserving role of the sick patient offering a cure for his own disease, I suggest that frustrations over the failure to solve serious problems in the administration of justice are grievously misplaced when they are expressed primarily in hostility against judges.

title: LAWYERS CALLED REMISS BY BOTEIN
description: The highestranking member of the city's organized bar conceded yesterday that for years lawyers have been remiss in not pressing hard enough for such things as court reform.

title: GOLDEN SEALS BEAT MAPLE LEAFS, 3 TO 0
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 28 (UPI)Gilles Meloche, a rookie goaltender, posted his third shutout of the season, 30, to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs for the California Golden Seals tonight.

title: Trevino Will Receive Hickok Award for '71
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 28Lee Trevino, the 32yearold MexicanAmerican golfer from El Paso, Tex., has been voted winner of the 22d annual Hickok professional athlete of the year award for 1971 and the diamond studded, goldbuckled belt, valued at $10,000, that goes with it.

title: Ideas on Central Market Modified in New Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) If certain conditions can be met, there would be no immediate need for a merger of exchanges in a central securities market, according to group including William McChesney Martin Jr.

title: Japanese Swarming to the Ski Country
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28  Friday and Saturday night at Ueno Station here make Grand Central in New York look like wide oven spaces.

title: Stram, Chiefs'
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 28 (UPI)Hank Stram, the only coach in the 12year history of the Kansas City Chiefs, received today a new title and a 10year contract from the team's owner, Lamar Hunt.

title: RAID IN MARSEILLES STIRS DRUGS DEBATE
description: PARIS, Jan. 28It was noted here today that the setting for a raid on what the police called a heroin laboratory in Marseilles a secluded villa occupied by an elderly couple, with trucks cdnstantly coming and goingfit the description of such laboratory given in an interview last summer by an American narcotics officer.

title: A.T. &T. Study to Resume As F.C.C. Gets New Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Reversing itself in response to broad public pressure, the Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would resume its investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's costs and management, including its relationship with the Western Electric Company, a manufacturing subsidiary.

title: Art: Difference of Negret's Sculpture
description: The sculptures of Edgar Negret in his latest show at the Galeria Bonino, 7 West 57th Street, seem to have been assembled from Ibeams, Tbeams, ventilator parts and other industrial steel forms. But these parts are neither found objects nor reclaimed construction scraps. Actually each part has been designed by the sculptor and manufactured to measure for a predetermined design. Hence the sculptures, rather than being ingenious in their adaptation of readymade material, are products of pure design from the beginning in spite of their nominal source useful forms.

title: Oil Nations Seeking 20% Interest
description: GENEVA, Jan. 28The chief negotiator for the Persian Gulf oilproducing countries said today that compensation for the 20 per cent participation they are demanding in Western oil companies operating on their territories would be determined solely by the book value of their investments.

title: HODGSON ASKS SPEED ON DOCK STRIKE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)  The Secretary of Labor, James D. Hodgson, said today that the West Coast dock strike threatened to halt the nation's economic recovery, and urged Congress to enact President Nixon's bill for a forcible settlement.

title: Dr. Richard Courant Dies at 84; Influential Mathematics Scholar
description: Dr. Richard Courant, one of the greatest organizers of mathematical research and teaching in the 20th century, died Thursday afternoon at New Rochelle, (N. Y.) Hospital, where he had been taken after suffering al stroke last November. Dr. Courant, who was 84 years old, lived at 142 Calton Road in New Rochelle.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 28 Quinas Brower sparked Hofstra to a recordbreaking performance tonight as the Flying Dutchmen defeated Wagner, 11888.

title: TWO CONCERNS AGREE TO CONSENT DECREES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Justice Department has accused Owens Illinois, Inc., and W. R. Grace, Inc., two major manufacturers, of entering into reciprocal purchase agreements with suppliers. The agency filed proposed consent decrees today to halt the practice.

title: ROCK CONCERT GIVEN BY YOUTH FOR CHRIST
description: We are still a long way from seeing the last of the Jesus Christinspired rock works. Yet another turned up at Town Hall Thursday night in the form of a contemporary pop/rock cantata called The Carpenter. In this case, however, the participants would seem to have pretty good credentials, since the production was staged by an organization called Youth For Christ.

title: Moon Eclipse Tomorrow To Be Partly Seen Here
description: The first of four lunar eclipses that will occur this year will be partially visible here tomorrow, weather permitting.

title: LANCIA CAPTURES MONTE CARLO RACE
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 28 (UPI)  Sandra Munari and Mario Manucci, driving a Lancia Fulvia, today became the first Italians to win the Monte Carlo Rally in the event's 61yearold history.

title: Gold Bill Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  The Nixon Administration has informed Congress it will not introduce legislation for an upward revaluation in the official gold price to $38 an ounce from $35 until at least Feb. 10, Congressional sources said today.

title: 2YEAR PRISON TERM SERVED BY HIJACKER
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington said that Heinrick von George, the hijacker of a Mohawk Airlines plane who was slain by an F.B.I. agent in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., early Thursday morning, had been arrested in San Francisco for grand larceny in 1947.

title: Zambia Imposes Surcharge
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 28 (Reuters)This country, hit by a slump in the world price of copper, its major foreign currency earner, today imposed temporary 5 per cent customs surcharge on all imports subject to duty and slashed Government spending by nearly 30 per cent.

title: Canadian Judge, Acting for Husband and Fetus, Bars an Abortion
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 28A judge, acting on behalf of a man and the infant plaintiff, the unborn child, has issued apermanent injunction restraining his wife from having an abortion. Lawyers say it is the first such injunction issued in Canada.

title: TRUST CORP. REVISION APPROVED BY COURT
description: The Trust Corporation of Bahamas, Ltd., custodian trustee of U.S.I.F. Real Estate Fund, reported yesterday that reorganization plan recommended by itself and Lehman Brothers, Inc., the investment firm, had been. approved by the Supreme Court of the Bahamas It added that the decision is subject to possible appeal.

title: Art
description: WHEN Yekaterina Furtseva, the Soviet Minister of Cultural Affairs, visited New York for the first time the other day, she paid a call at the Museum of Modern Art. This was a historic moment that should not go unrecorded: The Soviet Union's official apologist for the suppression of modernism in the very citadel of the enemy culture! The irony of the occasion was underscored by the presence of two important items in the museum's current exhibition of new acquisitions: a sculpture by Vladimir Baranoff Rossine called Symphony No. 1 (1913) and a painting by Ivan Puni called Flight of Forms (1919). These two outstanding works from the remarkable preRevolutionary period of the Russian avantgarde were acquired out of the big exhibition devoted to Russian modernism in the years 19081922 which opened at the Leonard Hutton Galleries, 967 Madison Avenue, in October, and is still having a marathon run (through Feb. 29). Needless to say, Mrs. Furtseva did not include the Hutton Galleries on her cultural tour of New York. She was, however, shown the two works now on view in the museum's first floor galleries. Her response was said to be something less than enthusiastic.

title: Standby Alert Reported
description: SAIGON, Jan. 29 (AP)Informed sources said today that South Vietnamese field commanders and police had been placed on standby alert for any enemy offensive or increased attacks next month.

title: Nancy Merrill Becomes Bride Of Gene Foehl
description: FREDERICK, Md., Jan. 29 Miss Nancy Lee Merrill and Gene Alan Foehl were married here this afternoon in the Coffman Chapel of Hood College by the Rev. James A. Smith, an ordained minister of the United Church of Christ and chaplain of Hood College.

title: Medicine/Science
description: More than a decade ago Soviet and American experts in seismology  the study of earth tremors  sat down in Geneva to explore possible methods for policing a ban on testing nuclear weapons underground. The Americans presented data from earthquake monitors of that period to show that it was impossible to discriminate reliably between earthquakes and nuclear explosions. Consequently the United States insisted on being allowed to inspect places in the Soviet Union from which suspicious seismic waves had originated. The Russians refused and ever since the issue of onsite inspection has stood in the way of a total ban on nuclear testing.

title: Morgan Horse History to Get The Disney Treatment on TV
description: The early history of the Morgan horsethe first native American breed and perhaps still the most versatile will be shown on the Wonderful World of Disney television program in two parts next Sunday and Feb. 13. The programs will be on Channel 4 in New York starting at 7:30 P.M. In the program, which stars Don Murray, the Disney organization conveys the development of the breed in the late 1700's, and more specifically, the colorful life of Justin Morgan and his little bay stallion, who could outrun, outwork and generally outdo any horse brought against him.

title: Open Peace Covenants, Openly Arrived At
description: WASHINGTONLast Tuesday, the day of President Nixon's speech on Vietnam, proved to be a sad day for our country. If one took the time to pierce the rhetoric, he found there a record of two and a half years of completely unproductive negotiations in Faris. The collapse of our negotiating effort was, compounded by President Nixon's decision to publicize the results of secret meetings so as practically to insure major difficulty in resuming effective offtherecord discussions:

title: CURTIS CUP SQUAD NAMED BY UM,
description: The fourday annual meeting of the United States Golf Association concluded yesterday with the selection of the women's Curtis Cup team, election of officers and presentation of two awards.

title: IRISH FIVE ROUTED BY U.C.LA., 5732
description: (UPI)The University of California, Los Angeles, riddled Notre Dame's stall with pre cision shooting today to gain a 5732 triumph over the Irish.

title: GENSUS DISCLOSES AGE GROUPS DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29More Americans are 12 years old than any other age, a final report of the 1970 census disclosed today.

title: The Peace Plan
description: President Nixon's peace plan, as revealed to the world in general and to the American electorate in particular last Tuesday night in his own special brand of TV spectacular, does represent a significant advance of the American position in the complex negotiating effort to bring an end to the Vietnam war. While Mr. Nixon's dramatic announcement may indeed have been timed to soften up American and world opinion for a massive renewal of aerial bombing in response to the anticipated major Tet offensive on the part of Hanoi, the fact remains that the proposals are substantial enough, and are flexible enough, to warrant more serious exploration from the naturally suspicious enemy than has yet been publicly evidenced.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Deborah E. Carson Captain's Fiancee
description: LACKLAND AIR FORCE BASE, Tex., Jan. 29 Maj. Gen. Charles W. Carson Jr., U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Carson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Elizabeth Carson, to Capt. Duane L. Hutchins, U.S.A.F., an instructor pilot stationed at Reese Air Force Base in Lubbock. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson W. Hutchins of La Habra, Calif.

title: State Says Pan Am Fees On 747's Were Not Told
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that Pan American World Airways had falsely advertised that there were no fees for bevI erages, movies or music in the coach section of its 747 planes and that passengers weree permitted access to a selfservice section.

title: TALKS TO RESUME AT NEWARK PAPER
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29Negotiations between pressmen and The Evening News are expected to resume this week in a further effort to open the way for resumption of, publication.

title: Mahovlichs Pace Canadiens
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Mahovlich brothers, Frank and Pete, scored a goal each tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 40 triumph over the St. Louis Blues as Ken Dryden earned his fifth shutout of the season in goal.

title: ExOfficial Convicted in TV Bribe Plot
description: A former City Councilman in Johnstown, Pa., was found guilty here yesterday on bribery and conspiracy charges in scheme to award a cable television company an exclusive franchise in that city.

title: U. N.'s Staff in Ethiopia: Lots of Paper, No Files
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 29  A United Nations secretary scurried along a marble corridor in the huge, crowded conference hall here this morning, carrying some documents and a typewriter ribbon imported from New York. Suddenly she stopped, baffled.

title: Plane Going to Peking Delayed by Hijacking
description: A chartered flight that was expected to be the first commercial American flight to the Peoples Republic of China was delayed for more than two hours yesterday because of the hijacking of the Trans World Airlines plane at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Reports, Then Denials, Befog Vietnam News
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 (Reuters)A radio report of a battle with Vietcong guerrillas on s outskirts yesterday, later officially denied, is the latest in a series of such incidents to confuse war, correspondents in Vietnam.

title: A Fur Show for Spain's First Lady
description: MADRID  Jose Maria Pascual knew that his fur show was a success when Spain's First Lady, Dona Carmen de Franco, asked the House of Villagroy for a private showing.

title: Marasco Brothers Top Choices
description: The following 26 players, listed alphabetically, were selected as the best available, regardless of position, of the 442 college football players to be drafted on Tuesday and Wednesday by the 26 National Football League teams. The selection was made by Carl Marasco and his brother, Pete, amateur scouts and draft experts.

title: GEORGE 0. NEJLAENDER
description: MUSKOGEE, Okla., Jan. 29 George 0. Nejlaender, a rancher here and a former New York shipping broker who during World War II was in charge of Norwegian shipping, at the Norwegian Embassy in Washington, died Thursday at the age of 72.

title: Dance:Moor's Pavane
description: Most ballets based on Shakespeare are well and truly based on Shakespeare. They are story ballets, often of great complexity, that frequently depend more on the Shakespearean narrative than the Shakespearean spirit. One great exception is Jose Lim6n's The Moor's Pavane, which presents the most subtle dance variations of the theme of Shakespeare's Othello.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Central casting had him pegged
description: Central casting had David Niven pegged from the start. Launched on his Hollywood career as AngloSaxon Type No. 2008, he hasn't changed a bit.
