Thirtyseven years later, he is still the classic, uppercrust, stage Englishman, all butterfly charm and surface flash, renting himself out in three basic mutations: the stiffupperlipped gentleman hero, worshiped by his men and destined to die beautifully; the debonair gentleman playboy, guarding his sensitive spirit behind a brittle mask of gaiety; the libidinous gentleman scamp, witty, lovably unprincipled, romping from bed to bed in wellpressed pajamas.

title: STUDENTS UNEASY AT PUERTO RICO U.
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.An uneasy, mood has settled over the Rio, Piedras campus of the University of Puerto Rico as students return for the spring semester.

title: Mrs. Edgar Married To Michael A. Tappan
description: Mrs. Patricia Dickson Edgar was married yesterday afternoon to Michael A. Tappan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Tappan of Brooklyn Heights, and Buck Hill Falls, Pa. The Rev. Samuel Taylor performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Lynn Haney's article The Terrace Derided and Defended [Jan. 9] missed the point in several ways. As one of the city's active architects in the residential field, I would like to clarify what I consider to be a few of the fundamental issues.

title: Photography
description: FILM and theater devotees, nostalgia freaks, and anyone interested in vintage photographs will find moments of pleasant escape from more serious concerns in the exhibit of James Abbe's photographs at the Lexington Labs Gallery, 17 West 45thStreet.

title: Patterson, Bonavena To Hold Public Drills
description: Floyd Patterson and Oscar Bonavena will hold public workouts in the Felt Forum Tuesday and Wednesday in preparation for their 10round heavyweight bout a week from Friday in Madison Square Garden.

title: Princeton Wins New Jersey Track Championship 3d Year in a Row
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29 Surprising no one, Princeton set two meet records and won the third annual New Jersey state college track meet at its Jadwin Gymnasium today.

title: ECOLOGISTS MAKE STRIPMINE STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Friends of the Earth asserted today that if the coal industry was allowed to claim all of they 45 billion tons of fuel that Government studies have located in shallow beds, readily recoverable by surface, or strip, mining methods, the land area disrupted in the United States would total more than twice the size of Connecticut, or 10,276 square miles.

title: Eileen Rabin Married Here
description: Miss Eileen Lauren Rabin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon J. Rabin of Charleston, S. C., and Richard L. Sorota, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sorota of Golden Beach, Fla., were married here last evening in the Plaza by Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum of Temple Shaaray Telifa.

title: Life Hints Hughes Aide Stole Book Data
description: Life magazine, in its forthcoming issue, reaffirms its belief in the genuineness of the manuscript sold by the author Clifford Irving as an autobiography of Howard R. Hughes. But Life suggests that the material may have been stolen from Mr. Hughes by a disloyal or greedy employe.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: Adopting the stance of a stern family doctor, President Nixon in two sessions with Congress last week offered advice to an ailing patientthe nation's economy: Take your medicine, keep your crutches, and don't ask me when you'll be on your feet again.

title: Indiana Defeated, 8373
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 29 (AP)Mike Robinson, a Michigan State sophomore guard, scored a personal high of 34 points in pacing the Spartans to an upset 8373 victory over Indiana today.

title: Gymnasts Display Grace, Skill, Strength and Courage in U.S.Japanese Meet
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 29  Blonde ponytail held by a ribbon of pink yarn, America's bestknown gymnast scuffed her practice slippers in resin and stepped nimbly across a blue mat to the balance beam.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 29 (AP)Henry Wilmore scored 8 straight points midway through the second half today as Michigan took a 9point lead and then coasted to an 8878 victory over Ohio State to move into the Big Ten basketball lead.

title: A U.S. sodden with art appreciation
description: In the first pages of Bringing Down the House a few regulars of the Manhattan Repertory Company are trotted outDwight Macdonald, Diana Trilling, Louis Auchincloss. Then Richard Bricluier, having chosen a theatrical setting for his novel, follows the lead of the theater itself and departs New York for the hinterland.

title: Photography
description: THE Cosmopoltan Chapter of the Photographic Society of America (PSA) will sponsor an allday series of howto programs in photography on Sunday, March 19, at the Hotel Commodore, 42d Street at Grand Central Station. Called TeachIn II, the program will start at 9 A.M. and continue to 5 P.M. with many different classes (50 minutes each) being offered simultaneously in three basic courses: Black and White, Color Slides, and Color Prints.

title: A Ford in fashion
description: Top leftDior's satin evening dress was chosen for its soft apricot color and the Vneck. I've worn it twice already, she said. It's perfect for blacktie dinners or a ball. Mrs. Ford posed in the living room of her Sutton Place triplex.

title: PETER PASSELL &
description: Mr. Passell and Mr. Ross teach economics and law at Columbia University. They are associate: of the Center For Policy Research,

title: YORKERS SLATES $3 SUPERFECTA
description: Yonkers Raceway announced yesterday it would offer the $3 superfecta when the spring meeting opens on March 1.

title: 2 Garbage Men Who Went to Yale
description: MONROE, N.Y. (AP)  Until two years ago, 34yearold Rowland Stebbins 3d, educated at St. Paul's School, Yale and Harvard Law School and listed in the Social Register, was practicing law with a prestigious Wall Street firm.

title: Sports Today
description: Bullets vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Baltimore. (TelevisionCharnel 7, 2 P.M.)

title: Seton Hall Scores, 7371
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 29 Ron Wood's jump shot from the corner with two seconds left brought Seton Hall University a 7371 victory over St. Francis College tonight.

title: RULES ON POLLUTION ADOPTED BY OREGON
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 29A tough set of regulations governing the industrial use of 820,000 acres of wilderness has been adopted by Oregon on the ground that Federal regulations are too lax. The regulations were approved by the Department of Environmental Quality this week despite a lastminute plea by industry spokesmen to put off the action.

title: Donald Cope to Wed Anne Morgan Thomas
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morgan Thomas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Morgan Thomas, to Donald Gene Cope, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray E. Cope of Superior, Neb. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: May I say that I agree with Mr. Pollack of the Rosenwach Tank Company [letter. Jan. 9] about the skyline of New York. My sentiments have many roots. As an artist my most popular painting Manhattan's roofs, including those same tanks. So I know many others feel the same way about them.

title: HUNTER TITLE WON BY SEAN DE BERGA
description: POTTERSVILLE, N. J., Jan 29 Bev Walter, a Bernardsville, N. J., saddler, rode Sean de Berge to the regular working hunter championship today at the Tewksbury Farm's horse show.

title: A's Sign Tommy Davis
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP)Tommy Davis, who led the Oakland Athletics in hitting with a.324 average last year, has signed for the 1972 season, the baseball team announced today.

title: Patricia R. Silleck Plans Bridal
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bosworth Silleck of Scarsdale and Laverton, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ranlet Silleck, to William E. Buckley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Buckley of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York.

title: J. B. Minnick to Marry Miss Henning
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 29 Miss Margaret Linden Henning and Jeffrey Baekeland Minnick, who are with the Marine Midland BankNew York, will be married in May.

title: Religion
description: The Rev. Carl E. Creswell, an Episcopal chaplain in Vietnam at the time of the Mylai massacre, told a military court recently that he had mentioned a report of the incident to army superiors. In hindsight, I feel I should have done more, he added.

title: Nice Boy From the Bronx?
description: LONDON SO what is a nice Jewish boy from The Bronx like Stanley Kubrick doing making bizarre films like A Clockwork Orange"? Well, says Stanley, everybody starts off being a nice boy from somewhere. He smiles. He has a good sense of humor. He is eating halibut in a restaurant, he is wearing his habitual drab olive flak jacket, and with his brooding, bearded face he looks not unlike the Napoleon he is going to make his next movie about. He doesn't look like a genius, no apocalyptic lumina haloes his head, and with his soft New York accent he could almost still be that mythical nice boy from The Bronx.

title: N.F.L. Players Insist That Testa Be Ended
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. Jan. 29 (AP)The National Football League Players Association called last night for an end to personality and psychological testing of players by N.F.L. teams because of questions involving the validity and use of such tests.

title: The World
description: LONDONThe emotions unleashed in Rhodesia by the test of opinion on the proposed constitutional settlement with Britain seemed to quiet down last week. The demonstrations and the riots stopped, at least for the moment, and the toll of fatal shootings by the police stood at last weekend's mark of 15.

title: The Nation
description: PARISPresident Nixon indicated that his adviser had seen the North Vietnamese 13 times. Mr. Kissinger corrected him: No, it was 12 times. A French radio commentator last week suggested yet another figure. Pretending that the divorced Mr. Kissinger was still married, the commentator jested that the Presidential aide was in trouble at home because he'd told his wife he had gone to Paris on official business 16 times.

title: Godfrey Reaches Semifinals
description: Ray Godfrey of the Yale Club, the topseeded player, advanced to the semifinal round of the limited Class A squash racquets tournament at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday by defeating William MacMillen of the Racquet and Tennis Club, 1513, 1510, 1416, 157. John Leathers of Scott of the Columbia Club and the University Club, Jeffrey Alfred Audi of the host club also advanced.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: HIJACKER IS SHOT AT AIRPORT HERE AFTER FREEING 93
description: An erratic hijacker who pulled a gun from a fake plaster arm cast and commandeered a transcontinental jet over the Middle West before dawn was shot and captured at Kennedy International Airport yesterday afternoon by a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent posing as a replacement crew member.

title: Son to the Westbrooks
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 29A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Westbrook of Byram on Jan. 13 in the Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Westbrook is the former Miss Daryl Acheson, daughter of William G. H. Acheson of New York and the late Mrs. Acheson. The child, whose father is studying for a master's degree at New York University, is named William Hays Hawkins.

title: Nuisance on Runners
description: The snowmobile, for several years a growing affliction in this country and Canada, is now meeting gratifying resistance in the winter resorts of Europe. The International Commission for the Protection of Alpine Regions, revolted by the noise, smell and danger of this noxious toy, has warned its member nations against the vehicle as a source of disturbance that threatens in short time to become a veritable plague.

title: Campaign Funds:
description: WASHINGTON Cows Contesting for Commodious Consumption of Cottage Cheese. Or how about Bitter Barnhands for Better Bovines?

title: LOUISVILLE TOPS BRADLEY, 5246
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 29 AP) Fourthranked Louisville, rattled by Bradley's slowdown tactics in the second half, held on today for a 5246 Missouri Valley Conference basketball victory.

title: Barber, Middlebury Student, Wins Class A Ski Jumping at Bear Mountain
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 29Making his first appearance here in five years, Hugh Barber, the solidly built Middlebury College junior, easily dominated the Telemark Ski Club's annual jumping event today.

title: Federal Work Study Payments At U. of Montana Under Inquiry
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Jan. 29A University of Montana auditor's report of irregularities in the handling of Federal work study payments at the school has led to an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: BONNIE STREAK ENDS AT 4TH LOSS, 76 TO 73
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 29 (UPI) St. Bonaventure snapped fourgame losing streak today by defeating Niagara, 7673, for its eighth victory in 14 games.

title: Little League Ski Will Start Today At 80 Locations
description: A Little League of ski racing will open today in 80 selected ski centers around the country. Its aim: To develop national competition on the slopes for skiers 18 years old and under.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JERUSALEMThe prospects of peace In the Middle Eastnever exactly glowinghave been further diminished by the recent IndiaPakistan war. The reason for this conclusion is simple.

title: Education
description: Each Monday morning, upon awakening, Tom Sawyer examined himself for ailmentsreal or imaginedthat might enable him to postpone the beginning of a new school week. Today's hooky player is a very different breed.

title: Doctor, do we have a choice?
description: IN the grim drama of surgery the pediatric surgeon's lot is usually a happy one. He operates on critically ill newborn infants and gives them the 70 years life expectancy of which nature would have deprived them.

title: You've Gotta Be Crazy to Leave New York City
description: SOMETIMES I can hardly believe it when I read all the sad articles about how everything is breaking down in New York City. The garbage isn't collected, the air is polluted, crime is up and the phones don't work. Pretty soon, the sad writers predict, the whole city is going to be fleeing upstate, or else to Vermont. There a man can live in peace. Well, I have a counterprediction: If the exodus ever does occur, 90 per cent of those who flee from their apartments will be back in the city within six months. At least, if they go to Vermont they will. It may be different upstate.

title: Elizabeth Peterken Married to Banker
description: Min Elizabeth Helen Peterken and Thomas Hinman McCaughey of New York were married yesterday afternoon in the Calvary Episcopal Church by the Rev. Robert Hess.

title: Cincinnati Transit Held Phases 1 and 2 Violator
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 29 (AP) United States District Court Judge David S. Porter ruled yesterday that Cincinnati Transit, Inc., had violated both phases of the Economic Stabilization Act last year by raising fares and reducing service.

title: Smith Named Oilers Aide
description: HOUSTON, Jan 29 (AP)Jerry Smith who coached the Denver Broncos the last five games of the 1971 National Football League season, has been named defensive line coach of the Houston Oilers.

title: Du Pont Gives $2.5Million In Grants to 149 Colleges
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 29 Grants totaling $2,575,000 will be awarded to 149 colleges and universities this year by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.

title: City College Loses, 85.58
description: TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 29City College, showing signs of rustiness after its exam period, committed 36 turnovers tonight and bowed to Trenton State, 8588. Trenton State's wonlost record is 106. City is 77.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Foreign aid is in the doldrums. It is being assaulted by waves from left and right. But beneath the surface waves is a deep swell of discontent with what is happening in the developing countries. Is there a way out of this storm?

title: 80 New Supersonic Jet Fighters Believed Put Into Use by China
description: PARIS, Jan. 29The Chinese Air Force is now armed with a jet fighter, the F9, which could fly at speeds up to roughly twice the speed of sound, or 1,400 miles an hour, the monthly magazine of the French Air Force reported here.

title: U.S. Men Gymnasts Lose, Women Win Against Japan
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 29The United States national gymnastic squad won the women's competition and lost the men's as the twoday match with Japan ended tonight at Penn State.

title: Child to Mrs. Shields Jr.
description: A daughter was born Jan. 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Shields Jr. of Larchmont, N. Y., in Doctors Hospital here. Mrs. Shields is the former Miss Carol Mahon. Her husband is a partner of Shields & Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, and skipper of the America's Cup yacht Columbia in 1962. The child has been named Allison.

title: Brian Carty to Wed Miss Mary M'Grath
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 29  Miss Mary Virginia McGrath, a sophomore at Radcliffe College. and Brian T. Carty, a senior at Harvard College, plan to be married in September.

title: Music
description: NEW YORK has an enormous share of accomplished young musicians who keep turning up in the various ensembles put together for special programs. Often these are for the performance of contemporary music. Two such players, Fred Sherry, cellist, and Richard Fitz, percussionist, had been doing this for some time when it occurred to them that they might set up a permanent group of their own. They approached two colleagues who had shown a similar interest in new music, Ursula Oppens, pianist, and Rolf Schulte, violinist. The four became the charter members, so to speak, of an organization called Speculum Musicae (Mirror of Music). They gathered other players around them, went through the red tape of getting incorporated and applying for grants. They gave couple of concerts last season at the Shakespeare Public Theater in the Village, appeared at Dartmouth College in its summer series and at Tanglewood during the Berkshire Music Festival and had some outoftown engagements this season.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: John Scanlon faces difficult money problems, probably the toughest in American corporate finance because they are so gigantic. In the last three years, he has solved them by selling the largest bond and stock issues ever sold and by doing the biggest private placement ever placed, and he still must raise $2.5billion a year from investors. Outside of government, no one has to get his hands on so much money.

title: The Nation
description: I'm the only unique individual that's running, peppery Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn declared as she tossed her bonnet in the Democratic Presidential ring last week. And, indeed she is a novel addition to the Presidential race. No shrinking Shirley she.

title: ULSTER CAR BOMBED; POLICEMAN IS SLAIN
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 29 (UPI)A bomb planted in a parked automobile exploded in a downtown shopping center today minutes after a telephoned warning. Seven shoppers and store attendants were injured.

title: Duquesne's Quintet And Manhattan Win
description: Duquesne, with one of the best records as an independent team in the East, and Manhattan, which counts its blessings for every infrequent victory, turned in triumphs yesterday afternon in a college basketball doubleheader at dadison Square Garden. Neither triumph came easily.

title: ST. JOHN'S FIVE TRIUMPHS,10066
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 29St. John's University put together excellent shooting, a blitzing fast break, domination of the backboards and an unyielding zone defense and recorded an easy 10066 basketball victory over Dartmouth before 2,200 fans at Alumni Gym tonight.

title: Goldstein, Fencer, Is Given Helms Hall of Fame Award
description: Ralph Goldstein of Yonkers received a Helms Hall of Fame award yesterday at the New York Athletic Club for his achievements in fencing.

title: Reader's Report
description: 1939, a bad year in which to be poor and bereft, finds forlorn boy of 10 making his way across 800 miles of Australia to the home of an aunt and uncle. Paul Thompson's companion is a black named Luther, an ancient retainer of

title: METHODISTS UNITE IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 29The historic separation of white and black Methodist conferences in South Carolina ended this week when the two conferences, meeting together for the first time, voted to accept a plan of union.

title: Music
description: THE onliest Mingus, as a nightclub cornas once introduced him, was editing his first new American album in six years at a Columbia studio in midtown. Some of the material on it will be part of his Philharmonic Hall appearance this Friday evening  the first concert of Charles Mingus compositions in New York in a decade. At 49, the expansive bassistcomposerleader is warming up for what may be his most productive period.

title: Chess
description: THE name of the popular Bulgarian Black Sea resort of Varna, famous for its golden sands, is familiar to many chess fans as the site of the 1962 Olympics, in which teams from 38 countries participated. Since then, Varna has hosted a large number of chess events, mostly minor ones. The latest, an international tournament with 16 playersall but one, Basman of England, from Eastern Europe, was won by the Soviet grandmaster Yevgeni Vasyukov, whose 11.5 score placed him half a point ahead of Rumanian champion Florian Gheorghiu. Smejkal of Czechoslovakia and Spassov of Bulgaria were third and fourth respectively.

title: Russell MacMullan Jr. to Wed Miss Wendy Thorsen in June
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 29The engagement of Miss Wendy Josephine Thorsen to Russell Jamison MacMullan Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Thorsen, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Henry Snowden Rigby of Media, Pa., and Mrs. MacMullan of Washington.

title: FARMERS STUDY ORGANIC MARKET
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 29The state's commercial fruit and vegetable growers are looking into the fastgrowing market for organic foods and finding a source of potential profits and psychological problems.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The World
description: MADRIDAfter Spaniards eat and spend their way through the threeweek Christmas holiday, they go through a fourweek hangover that is known traditionally as The Long Uphill of January. For the Spanish regime, this January's uphill has been particularly steep. The students, the Basques and the Common Market have all, in different ways, tested its aging powers.

title: Defect Hinted in 4 Million Fords Asa Private Agency Holds Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29New evidence of a possibly inherent safety defect in more than 4 million Fords has revived agitation for recall and repair of the cars.

title: News of the Rialto
description: ONE of the nice things about being artistic director of the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., is that even in the bleakest time of winter, you're thinking of spring and summer. And Michael Kahn has not only been thinking but also doing. The result is that the upcoming summer program is in shape, the major actors signed and rehearsals set to commence Feb. 7. Thus, what the picnickers on the banks of the Housatonic can look forward to is a playbill comprising Shakespeare's Julius Caesar and Antony and Cleopatra and Shaw's Major Barbara, the season commencing June 20

title: M'GOVERN GAINS COALITION'S VOTE
description: The New Democratic Coalition, the liberalreform wing of the Democratic party in this state, endorsed Senator George McGovern yesterday for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Paraliterature, paralanguage, paranovel
description: J.M.G. Le Cldzio emerged nine years ago as the shining child crusader of the nouveau roman, wielding a full panoply of new novelistic arms. His first novel, The Interrogation, published when he was 23, was a Parisian literary event because it seemed to inaugurate a second generation of innovation, to answer the question that the literary press had been echoing, somewhat inanely, in numerous reviews and interviews: after Alain RobbeGrillet, Nathalie Sarraute, Michel Butor, Claude Simon, what came next? The Interrogation demonstrated an easy mastery of the premises of the new novel: liberation from the conventions of narrative, demolition of the coherent literary character, rejection of psychological analysisan acute recognition of the exhaustion of literary forms and language, the need to write against

title: DOMINICANS BUILD IMAGE OF PEACE
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominitan Republic, Jan. 24There is an air of peace in Santo Domingo, a city that gives the impression of being more interested in tourism than in troop movements.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: ZEDNIK TAKES FINAL AT CLEVELAND NET
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Vladimir Zednik of (Czechoslovakia outlasted HaIroon Rahim of Pakistan today to win the Cleveland international indoor tennis tourament.

title: Reader's Report
description: The fig tree is a hanging tree on a nameless penal island, where political prisoners are suspended by their feet and sometimes beaten to death: such a fate befalls the subject of this French narrative in free verse. The man's wife is finally permitted to visit him after years of waitingand Miss Xenakis offers a heavily accentedcounterpoint between his anticipation and the brutal actuality of their meeting. The doomed captive seems anesthetized by his experience, talks vacantly of soap, Red Cross cigarettes and his rations. (This evening we shall be having bean soup... I really like beans).

title: Bribes to Evade Draft or Pass a Test or Get a Job Make Corruption a Way of Life in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29A forged identification card giving a false age usually costs a man trying to, avoid the draft more than $100. It costs twice as much in piasters80,000to arrange for the transfer of a soldier to a, job in the rear where he be safe from combat, or nearer his family.

title: Wheelwright of Colgate Gets New Coaching Pact
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Jan. 29 (AP)Neil Wheelwright has been given a new fouryear contract as head football coach at Colgate University, the school announced today.

title: Black Women Form a Group for Political Leverage
description: The national drive to mobilize black political power for negotiations at the major parties, political conventions advanced a notch yesterday with the establishment of the Coalition of 100 Black Women.

title: The Nation
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  Inside the small modern courtroom in the glasswalled Federal District Court building here, the arduous task of picking an impartial jury to hear the conspiracy case against the Harrisburg Seven began last week. The seven defendants  mainly Catholic clergy led by the Rev. Philip Berrigan  are charged with conspiring to blow up the heating system under Federal buildings in Washington, with conspiring to kidnap President Nixon's foreign policy adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, and with other alleged offenses against the United States.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: HINGHAM, Mass., Jan. 29 (AP)Virginia Wade of Britain overcame Rosemary Casals, 75, 62, in the semifinals of the $18,000 Virginia slims professional indoor tennis tournament tonight. Miss Casals lost a 4.1 lead in the first set and a 20 lead in the second.

title: State Study Favors Erection Of a RyeOyster Bay Bride
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29Construction of the controversial bridge across Long Island Sound between Oyster Bay, L. I., and Rye, N. Y., was recommended today by a consulting concern hired by the State Department of Transportation to study the need for a bridge and its possible impact on the physical and ecological environment.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn an Administration plagued by major leaks, it was the best kept of secrets. For nearly 30 months, the negotiations had been conducted in the strictest secrecy, with Henry A. Kissinger, the President's national security adviser, slipping surreptitiously across the Atlantic for a dozen clandestine meetings with North Vietnamese representatives on the outskirts of Paris.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Art
description: THE big de Chirico retrospective at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle sounds like a major event but turns out to he only an extended footnote hardly connected with de Chirico, the artist whose high position in 20thcentury painting has been established for so long in the textbooks and museum catalogues. Anyone familiar with de Chirico's work only through these standard but rigidly selective sources might wander through this show of nearly a hundred paintings and generous numbers of sculptures, drawings, and graphics, mistaking it for an exhibition of forgeries and not very good copies plus a group of paintings from the 1940's by a thirdrater coincidentally named Giorgio de Chirico but unrelated in any way to the master

title: Legislature Lists Dates For Committee Hearings
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Following are public hearings scheduled for the near future by committees of the Senate and the Assembly:

title: Susan Trainor Wed To Robert B. Mills
description: Miss Susan Honora Trainor, a candidate for a master's degree in education at the University of Miami, was married here yesterday morning to Robert Belden Mills. a Miami graduate serving with the Peace Corps in Bucaramanga, Colombia. The Rev. Robert Moller performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. in the Lady Chapel of St. Patirck's Cathedral.

title: Medicine; FeeSplitting:; Why Shouldn't I Get Some Of It?
description: You have a bellyache. Your family doctor diagnoses your trouble as appendicitis and sends you to a surgeon. You end up minus your appendix and a good chunk of your bankroll. And unbeknownst to you, part of the surgeon's fee ends up in the pocket of your family physicianas payment for sending the surgeon a lucrative piece of work.

title: A Rockefeller Makes His Bid
description: In 1964, John D. Rockefeller 4th arrived in West Virginia as an antipoverty worker. With his shirtsleeves rolled up and with indefatigable energy and great charm, Jay Rockefeller won the allegiance of those he worked among, and two years later, as his Republican family's only Democrat, he was elected overwhelmingly to the state House of Delegates. In 1968, he was elected West Virginia's Secretary of State. Last week, the 34yearold Rockefeller heir announced that he was seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, a nomination he is expected to get without any serious opposition.

title: Dog Registrations Mount to 1,129,200
description: The increasing popularity of purebred dogs is evinced in the 1971 list of registrations isued last Thursday by the American Kennel Club. A record 1,129,200 are listed, an increase of 72,975 over 1970 when the million mark for a single year was achieved for the first time since the club's stud book was started in 1878.

title: Jersey Judges to Testify in Dilts Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 29 A procession of judges and Bergen County assistant prosecutors is scheduled to come to stand in the coming weeks in the trial of Robert Dilts, the suspended Bergen County Prosecutor, on charges of conspiracy, bribery and misconduct in office.

title: The World
description: CAIROThe student demonstrations that shook Egypt last week contained lessons for the country's leadership, both present and future, and for other countries as well, principally Israel, the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: MECHANIC SEIZED IN INDIAN PT. FIRE
description: An operating mechanic at the Consolidated Edison Company's Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County was arrested last night and charged with setting the fire last November that caused an estimated $5million damage to the unfinished generating facility.

title: My heart leaped and swept aside my judgment
description: There can be little question that the two greatest British politicians of this century have been Winston Churchill and David Lloyd George. Both made their first significant marks as apparently radical reformers in the great Liberal Government that came to power at the end of 1905. Lloyd George had his period of triumph during World War I, when, as Prime Minister of the coalition Government, he led his country to victory. The same war began period of frustration for Churchill that did not end until 1940, when he, in his turn25 years after Lloyd Georgebecame the leader of his country. Both men used rather than served party; neither was a good party man.

title: A Squeeze
description: DETROIT  The Internal Revenue Service isn't the onlyor necessarily the most effectivegroup working to keep businesses crises from climbing.

title: Bridge
description: NEVERENDING argument concerns the desirability of using complex bidding methods. This is not particularly a matter of system, for it is quite possible to play Standard American with a multitude of artificial attachments, or to play something else, such as a strong One Club system, in a simple fashion.

title: SCHOOL BOARD SUIT ON FUNDS DISMISSED
description: The State Supreme Court has dismissed a motion by Community School Board 3 to restrain the Board of Education from interfering with the use of funds allocated to the district from the central schools budget.

title: Hialeah Sales of 2Year0Ids Sets Record of $4.3 Million
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29 (AP)Two of the highest prices bid during the fournight Hialeah sales of the twoyearold thoroughbred horses in training helped set a record of $4.3 million for 288 horses.

title: Monty Watkins Is Bride Of Richard I. Burnham
description: St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Fanchon Metcalf Watkins to Richard Irving Burnham. The Rev. Almus W. Thorp Jr. performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: OPPOSITION BRITONS BARRED BY RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Prime Minister IanSmith refused tonight to let five members of the British Opposition come here to sound out public opinion on the proposed settlement of Rhodesia's dispute with Britain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We would appreciate your publishing the following corrections to the Jan. 16 article on Bronx housing problems.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Dock Talks Resume Tomorrow
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 Formal negotiations will resume Monday in the West Coast dock strike while both sides continued to maneuver to bring outside pressure to bear on the talks.

title: Criminals At Large
description: By now the Chandlerderived private eye novel is as solidified in its form as a cowboy movie or an Egyptian mummy. The writing is lean, crisp, cynical. The conventions include a hero who is tough and ruthless, yet honest and sensitive. He lives in squalid surroundings. A good deal of his time is spent in selfpity. He works for $50 a day and expenses. Vast sums are often in his grasp, but he quixotically passthem

title: Radical Sheik
description: Siesta time came around in Sharja, the Persian Gulf emirate, last Tuesday and all was quiet in the. palace of Sharja's ruler, Sheik Khalid bin Mohammed alQasmi. Most police and palace officials were home celebrating a Moslem festival.

title: MINNESOTA PRESS FORMS A COUNCIL
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 27Residents of Minnesota who believe they have been unfairly or inaccurately portrayed by a state newspaper now have a forum in which to air their complaints.

title: 60 Consultants Aided 18Man Commission in Drafting Plan on School Finances
Reserve Clause Is Merger's Real Issue
description: If all the claims, counterclaims, passionate arguments, contortions of logic and legislative maneuvers about the proposed merger of the American and National Basketball Associations leave you confused here's a clue:

title: Susan Sheldon Is Bride
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., Jan. 29Miss Susan Roberts Sheldon of Philadelphia and John Brigan Crysler Jr. were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Willoughby Newton and the Rev. Haig Nargesian in St. John's Episcopal Parish. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Rhodes Sheldon of Grapevine, Tex., and her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Crysler of Devon, Pa.

title: Dozen Cities Planning or Building Transit Lines
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29After two decades in which American cities all but abandoned construction of new rapid transit systems in submission to the automobile, at least a dozen are now planning or building transit lines.

title: McLain and 13 Others Sign Contracts With Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Jan. 29 (AP)The Texas Rangers of the Amercan League, formerly the Washington Senators, announced today the signings of 14 players, including Denny McLain.

title: HIGH FRENCH AIDE VISITOR IN ATHENS; Trip Gives ?? or a U.S.Paris Rivalry
description: ATHENS, Jan. 29France's Secretary of State for the Foreign Affairs, JeanNoel de Liptrowski, arrived in Athens: Thursday for an official fourday visit at a time when thel ?? Greek Governpent appeared to he capitalizing on rivalry between the United States and France.

title: Miss Edith A. Price Fiancee of Teacher
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29  The Rev. Charles P. Price, who is Preacher to the University at Harvard, and Mrs. Price have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Arensberg Price, to Edward Arthur Robbins. His parents are Mrs. Israel Robbins of Brookline, and the late Mr. Robbins.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: An effort is under way to enlist fishermen in a nationwide effort to combat water pollution.

title: Coins
description: THE 1972 Pidyon Haben coin, the third to be issued by Israel in this annual series, is now available to collectors, it was announced by Rafael Aldor, Director for North America of the Israel Government Coins and Medals Corporation here.

title: POLICE KILL MAN, 35, ON BROOKLYN STREET
description: Three plainclothes patrolmen shot and killed a man in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night after he allegedly pulled a gun on them when they stopped to question him.

title: SABIGH TRIUMPHS IN GIANT SLALOM
description: HUNTER MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP)Vladimir (Spider) Sabich won the giant slalom half of the $20,000 Benson & Hedges pro ski competition today in convincing fashion. He defeated Hugo Nindl, the resident pro, in Nindl's specialty.

title: Mrs. Patricia Fahnestock Locke Is Married to David H. Klipste in
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Jan. 29Mrs. Patricia Fahnestock Locke, widow of Robert W. Locke 2d, an executive vice president of the McGrawHill Book Company, was married here today to David Hampton Klipstein, who is marketing manager for trade paint intermediates with the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Metamorphosis of The Campus Radical
description: IOWA CITY. I AM a born, habitual New Yorker and nothing surprises me more than to be living in Iowa, unless it is that as a former Ivy Leaguer and editor, I am now a teacher at the University of Iowa. Iowa City is Grant Wood's town, surrounded by his cornfields and cluttered with the AmericanGothic houses which the Eastern eye takes some months to find appealing.

title: Thomas D. Neelands Jr. Dead; Aviation Financial Consultant
description: Thomas D. Neelands Jr., a retired financial consultant, who had been active in the aviation industry, died Thursday in Beaconsfield, England, while on a visit there. He was 69 years old and lived at 30 East 65th Street.

title: Recordings
description: MICHAEL PONTI is laying siege to New York. The 33year old American pianist has l'ved in Germany since 1955 but will return March 13 to make his debut here and unlike most pianists who post a decorous notice of the programs (which invariably include the standard classic pieces, one contemporary work, and a premiere placed after intermission to prevent the critics from leaving early) Ponti plans an outright onslaught in this debut. After the usual program, he will go into overtime, offering some 40 encore pieces to be selected by the audience from a printed list. He has said, although the prospect is exhausting to contemplate, that he will play every request, so audience remains!

title: Devaney to Coach AllStars
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP)Bob Devaney, who coached Nebraska to an unbeaten National Collegiate football championship in each of the last two seasons, was named head coach today of the College AllStars for their game with the pro champion Dallas Cowboys in Soldier Field July 28.

title: Orioles Choose Asheville
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (AP)Asheville, N.C., of the Southern league will replace DallasFt. Worth as the Baltimore Orioles AA team next season, the Orioles announced today. The Asheville club will be named the Orioles.

title: Long Island Man Arrested On Pornography Charges
description: A Long Island man described by the police as controlling up to 95 per cent of the peep shows in the Times Square area was arrested yesterday and charged with the wholesale promotion of pornography.

title: A bitter little story with a happy ending
description: Photographs of Jean Giraudoux went on showing the same aging boyish face and the same round granny glasses for years and years, as if he had come into the world as a bookish diplomat of 50. One splendid young portrait of him exists: he is elegant, handsome, wears an officer's uniform and a monocle, and looks the way Proust must have imagined SaintLoup. Then there is the Jean Cocteau drawing of him on his deathbed, with the head thrown back, the gaunt profile and long throat, all softness vanished. It is remarkable work, because he really does look dead and not asleep.

title: Summers Gets New Post
description: Neil Summers, eastern scouting supervisor for the Cincinnati Reds, has been appointed liaison man with the Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League and the Hot Stove League. Summers, of Forest Hills, Queens, has been scouting the metropolitan area for 10 years. The collegiate league has five teams: Long Island, BrooklynQueens, Bergen, N. J., Mount Vernon and Scranton, Pa.

title: Menetrey Wins in 7th
description: ANNECY, France, Jan. 29 (UPI) The European welterweight boxing champion, Roger Menetrey of France, beat Brazil's Joao Dos Santos when the Brazilian quit in the seventh round last night. Dos Santos was forced to retire with a broken rib after having fallen to the deck three times in the fight.

title: IN THE NATION; The Hard Choice; The net effect of the [WashingtonHanoi] deadlock is that the war must go on,
description: The outpouring this week of proposals and counterproposals, arguments and counterarguments, in Washington, Hanoi and Paris, has at least reiterated the point that the real issue of the war is political control of South Vietnam.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Returning from Europe and an important job with Unilever, Henry M. Schachte at 52 years of age had just about done it all in advertising and marketing. His only plan was to build stone walls in Connecticut.

title: Hunter Stops Stony Brook
description: Larry Pyser scored 10 secondhalf points, to break a halftime tie and help Hunter College defeat Stony Brook, 7773, at Hunter last night. John Bradley led Hunter with 22 points. Hunter's won lost record is now 124, Stony Brook's 107.

title: How things work, including butterflies; What Makes; It Go?; What Makes It Work? What Makes It Fly? What Makes It Float? By Joe Kaufman. Illustrated by the author. 93 pp. New York: Golden Press. $3.95. (Ages 7 to 11)
description: What makes this or that device work? It's a common enough childhood question and one to which Joe Kaufman supplies abundant answers. The mechanics and mechanical concepts behind nearly one hundred objects are covered here, all the way from bicycles, cars and transmissions to trains of all sorts, ships, rockets and lunar modules, to jetstream tooth cleaners, escalators, clocks, tools, musical instruments, radar and toilets.

title: E. J. Boyd 5th Will Marry Miss Hilliard
description: WAXAHACHIE, Tex., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. Russell Warren Wetjen have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wetjen's daughter, Miss Josephine Antoinette Hilliard, to Edward John Boyd 5th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Boyd 4th of Garden City, L. I.

title: The Nation
description: There will be no black liberation flags flying in Newark, N. J., schools after all.

title: Tuna War Spreads to U.S.
description: GUAYAQUIL, EcuadorA conflict between the State and Defense Departments in the United States is widening the annual tuna war this season.

title: Rams Gabriel Is Married
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (UPI) Roman Gabriel, the Los Angeles Rams quarterback, was married today to 21yearold Tedra Lynn Bidwell, a secretary for an air freight company. Gabriel, 31, was divorced from his first wife.

title: Kelly Trims Work Load
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (UPI) Red Kelly resigned today as general manager of the Pittsburgh Penguins to concentrate on his duties as coach, and Jack Riley, the National Hockey League team's executive director, moved back into his old job as general manager.

title: Kerr on Wanted
description: IMIGHT have thought Wanted slightly preposterous if I hadn't suddenly remembered one thing. There was a time in this country when killers, if they could just get themselves acquitted, went straight into vaudeville.

title: Coldens Have Child
description: EAST SETAUKET, L. I., Jan. 29  A daughter was born Jan. 15 to Dr. and Mrs. William W. Colden in the St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson. Mrs. Colden is the former Barbara Rosendorf. The child has been named Cerena Frost. Her father is a physician.

title: Is Inflation A Psychosomatic Illness?
description: WASHINGTON. ON Oct. 15, 1971, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., who had been reluctant accountant, an enthusiastic newspaperman and a nonconformist F.B.I. agent, was dean of the School of Business Administration at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, on the threshold of an ambitious, totally innovative program. On Oct. 20, he flew to Washington. On Oct. 22, he met President Nixon for the first time. On Oct. 26, he was chairman of the Price Commission, leading six other commission members through their first meeting in borrowed office.

title: Dance
description: VIVATI VIVAT REGINA! a play by Robert Bolt, got eight favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watts, Post; Oppenheimer, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI; Rollin, NBCTV; Sanders, ABCTV, three mixed (Watt, News; Klein, WNEWTV; Bookspan, WPIXTV) and two unfavorable reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Harris, CBSTV).

title: The Nation
description: The tall, casually dressed novelist told newsmen that he had a bad case of laryngitis when he alighted from jet airliner in New York last Wednesday following a long flight from Barcelona. His lawyer spoke to newsmen as Clifford Irving whispered and shrugged alongside him. The attorney, Martin S. Ackerman, told the shouting crowd of reporters and cameramen that Mr. Irving had no idea who the mysterious woman wasthe woman who had opened a bank account in Zurich as Helga Hughes, deposited checks totaling $650,000 made out to H. R. Hughes and then withdrawn the money.

title: Missionary Building Ark
description: TYLER, Tex., Jan. 29 (UPI) The Rev. Daylon H. Hicks, a Baptist missionary, says he will finish a 51foot wood ark by March in time to sail with his wife and five children, 7 to 12 years old, to his next assignment in the Virgin Islands. The ark, to be launched at Beaumont, Tex., is made of chicken wire, concrete and treated pine and will be powered by a 50horsepower outboard motor.

title: Orioles Acquire Donaldson From Toledo for Burbach
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (AP)  The Baltimore Orioles have sent Bill Burbach, a pitcher, from their Rochester club to the Toledo Mud Hens of the International League for an infielder, John Donaldson, the Orioles announced today.

title: Windward Passage Wins In Long Beach Yacht Race
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)The 73foot frame ketch, Windward Passage, racing under the pennant of the Lahaina Yacht Club, Maui, Hawaii, defeated Blackfin today in the second of a twoofthree series of 18mile match yacht races.

title: OBSERVER; Mister Professident; Who would be the President when he might, instead, be the Professident?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29It is no longer enough to call him Professor Kissinger. He has transcended academia, has put professorship lightyears behind him. Tenure, the musty polysyllabics of the Blue Book, faculty parties with that cutrate California sherry, the smartly administered knucklerapping which keeps the presumptuous undergraduate in his place all these belong to a receding past.

title: Excerpts From the Transcript of the Interview With Premier Meir in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28Following are excerpts from the transcription of an interview with Premier GoIda Meir by C. L. Sulzberger at Mrs. Meir's office in Jerusalem:

title: SOLOMON FINEMAN, A ROENTGENOLOGIST
description: Dr. Solomon Fineman, a roentgenologist at Montefiore Hospital and Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, died Friday in Montefiore Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 227 East 57th Street. His office was at 133 East 58th Street.

title: Brent and Barker Advance To Final in State Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 29Rod Brent of Australia and Bob Barker reached the final of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: Evans Joins K. of C. Field
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP)Lee Evans, who set the world 400meter dash record at the 1968 Olympics with a 43.8second clocking, has entered the 600yard run in next Saturday's 32d annual Knights of Columbus meet. Evans won the 600 at the Millrose Games in New York last night.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: What the Metropolitan Transportation Authority describes as the world's first rail commuter cars powered by a gas turbineelectric propulsion system should be in regular service on local commuter lines two years from now, the M.T.A. said yesterday.

title: Penn Routs Princeton, 8259, Creating 4Way Tie for Lead in Ivy League
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29Pennsylvania reasserted its ability to make a strong drive for a third straight Ivy League basketball championship tonight when the Quakers led all the way to trounce Princetoa 8259, and throw the Ivy League into a fourway tic.

title: Education
description: OTTAWA  Noontime strollers across a downtown square in the capital last summer paused to hear a Bach partita played by a quartet of young instrumentalists wearing blue jeans and opennecked shirts., At the same time, along the Rideau Canal outside the city, 30 college students completed a survey of a 100mile hiking trail linking Kingston, Canada's onetime capital on Lake Ontario, with Ottawa, the present capital on the Ottawa River.

title: BOROS, BOLT TIED FOR SENIORS LEAD
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP)Julius Boros and Tommy Bolt, who have both won the Professional Golfers Association Seniors Championship twice, were tied for the thirdround lead in the 33d event at the P.G.A. National Golf Club today. with 54hole totals of 212.

title: Movies
description: THERE is literally nothing about Malcolm McDowell that remotely suggests the dashing ogre Alex of A Clockwork Orange, or even the more earthly, recognizable paraplegic of Bryan Forbes's Long Ago, Tomorrow, none of the odd, sardonic, almost Gothic intensity he is capable of on camera. In this quiet hotel suite, he could be a forthright, articulate scholar just in on holiday from Oxford. But you note something erratic behind the alert eyes, which are the color of West Point uniforms.

title: Stamps
description: GREECE has released a sevenstamp series devoted to her historic monasteries and her churches. Multicolored, from designs by P. Gravalos, the issued stamps, according to P. J. Drossos of Athens, are as follows: 50 drachmae, Monastery of Hosios Loukas, Boeotia; 1 dr, Church of Daphni, Attica; 2 dr, Monastery of St. John the Divine, Patmos; 2.50 dr, Church of the Panaghia Koumbelidiki, Castoria; 4.50 dr, Church of the Panaghia ton Chalkeon, Thessaloniki; 6.50 dr, Church of the Panaghia Paregoritissa, Arta; 8.50 dr, Monastery of St. Paul, Mt. Athos.

title: France incarnate
description: In a mordant last conversation with Andre Malraux, General de Gaulle accused him of having invented Gaullism. Makatur responded by defining it less as an ideology than as the national will. This evocation of Rousseau's volonte generale brings us close to the heart of the matter. Gaullism, Malraux went on, has been France, but also something else. The something else remains with us yet.

title: Getting Back to Nature: The Pleasures and Pains of It All
description: ONE evening last October, a friend asked me how I, as a writer, could afford to live so much of the time on an islandout of touch with everything that was happening. Well, it all depends on what you think is worth happening. Let me put it this way:

title: Code Name for Nixon in Talks With Hanoi Was Quarterback
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) An authoritative White House source said today that President Nixon called the plays for Henry A. Kissinger during the progress of secret negotiations with the North Vietnamese. Mr. Nixon's code name, the source said, was Quarterback.

title: Fire Exchanged, Israel Says
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 29 (AP)Arabs and Israelis exchanged shots across the ceasefire line between the Israelioccupied Golan heights and Syria today in the second incident in two days, the Israeli military command said.

title: LINDSAY IS SEEKING WISCONSIN BACKING
description: DARBOY, Wis., Jan. 29Mayor Lindsay flew to Wisconsin today where he appealed to a fourcounty Democratic committee dinner in this snowbound town to help him introduce system of government that is responsive and humane.

title: 10MILLION WASTE IN CITY CONTRACTS LAID10 STATE LAW
description: As much as $70million of New York City's $800million building bill this year is being wasted because of a state law requiring that contracts he split up among several types of construction work, the Municipal Services Administrator said yesterday.

title: Top Police Officials Believe Black Militants Were the Slayers of Two Policemen on Lower East Side
description: Deputy Police Commissioner Robert Daley asserted yesterday that the killing of two policemen on the Lower East Side was indicative of guerrilla warfare that may be going further than it's already gone.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Donations Being Collected To Save an Old Cathedral
description: The American Scottish Foundation announced yesterday that the organization was forwarding donations to save the St. Magnus Cathedral, which is in danger of collapse in Kirkwall, Scotland.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Miriam Underhill's career as a mountain climber covered five decades, from technical first ascents in the Alps in the 1920's, through explorations in the littleknown ranges of Montana in the 1940's, to becoming (with her husband) the first to climb all of New Hampshire's 4,000ers in the 1960's. In the course of it she sufferedbut was not fazed bythe centuriesold prejudices against women climbers. With guides, she put up routes 45 years ago that are still regarded as difficult. With Alice Damesme she made the first manless ascent of the

title: Linda Benton, Paul Andrews Are Affianced
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 22The engagement of Miss Linda Marie Benton to Paul R. P. Andrews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Andrews of Greenwich, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Benton. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Clare Mayer Engaged
description: PACKANACK LAKE, N. J., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mayer of Packanack Lake have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clare Mayer, to George Richard Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gould of Richmond Hill, Queens. Miss Mayer is a graduate of Nassau Community College. Her fianc is a junior at City College in New York.

title: Home Life Linked to School Success
City Charges Health Violations At 19 Restaurants and Stores
description: The Health Department last week charged 19 more restaurants and other food establishments wiht serious Health Code violations and threatened to close them unless the violations were eliminated in time for final inspections early next month.

title: Winter Olympics Start Thursday
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Jan. 29 The 11th Winter Olympic Games begin an 11day run over snowfilled mountains and icy rinks on Thursday.

title: Richard W.Moore, Harvard'71, Is Fiance of Barbara K. Forster
description: GLADWYNE, Pa., Jan. 29 The engagement of Miss Barbara Kane Forster, a 1971 graduate of Radcliffe College, to Richard W. Moore, a 1971 graduate of Harvard College, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. H. Walter Forster Jr., parents of the prospective bride. Her finance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Moore of Rye, N.Y., and a greatgrandson of the late Joseph Pulitzer, the publisher who endowed the Pulitzer Prizes.

title: Smoking the Chinese way
description: Smoked chicken is a Chinese delicacy with an elusive taste of tea leaves and other combustibles that vary according to the recipe. The chicken is peppered, simmered and then smoked on the stove in a covered iron pot containing, this case, lapsang souchong, flour and sugar. Smoke billows out from under the lid. On its way, it turns the chicken a lovely brown and imparts a flavor that will surprise anybody who was brought up on meat smoked only with hickory. The Chinese way produces a far more pungent taste; it is quicker; and it can be accomplished with a minimum of special fuss at home. Don't overdo it, however, because too much time on the stove will make the chicken too pungent, not to mention the acrid smell it will spread through your kitchen. It's a good idea anyway to leave a window open during the smoking.

title: How things work, including butterflies; The Blue Butterfly By Ned O'Gorman. Illustrated by Thomas di Grazia. 59 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $3.50. The Boy, The Rat, and The Butterfly By Beatrice Schenk de Regniers. Illustrated by Haig and Regina Shekerjian. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $4.25. (Ages 6 to 9)
description: Many good books do not make good movies. Here we have a converse example: The Blue Butterfly is book that uses film techniques to tell a story in print, and, while it is fascinating, it has a hard go as fiction.

title: LendLease 1972 Style
description: English secretaries have been in American offices for several years. So now the former colonies are sending American office workers to Britain.

title: And Mao said, let there be acupuncture
description: Sensational as were recent dispatches from Peking on the use of 3,000yearold needle therapy to cure deafness and paralysis, it was only after word got back that the needles had actually been stuck into a wellknown American journalist that there was rush to bookstores for literature on acupuncture.

title: Soviet Prints Yevtushenko Poem on Fire
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29Yevgeny Yevtushenko today matched his showmanship on the stage of Madison Square Garden with a display of political astutenessby publishing a poem about the fire in the New York offices of Sol Hurok, the impresario, in Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper.

title: Q. If You Rape a Woman And Steal Her TV, What Can They Get You For in New York? A. Stealing Her TV
description: MOST rapes in Central Park, as elsewhere, have no more particularity than most muggings. Occasionally there are cases with Gothic overtonesan 83yearold woman is picked up bodily from bench on Fifth Avenue in the 60's, lifted over the park wall and raped in the bushes; a girl, just raped, cries out to a man passing by, Please help me, I've been raped, and the passerby rapes herbut even these cases are likely as not to wind up in a twoinch squib on Page 27.

title: REV. JOHN W. DARR
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 29The Rev. John Whittier Darr, professor of religion emeritus at Wesleyan Unitversity, died Thursday evening at his home in Seattle. He was 83 years old.

title: Missouri Promotes Teel
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Jan. 29 (AP)Bob Teel, Missouri's assistant track coach, will succeed Tom Botts as head coach next fall, the university announced today. Botts has served more than 30 years.

title: Carol Ann Von Elm Plans Bridal
description: Miss Carol Ann Von Elm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Von Elm of Forest Hills, Queens, and Thomas Edward McDonnell of New. York, plan to be married in May 13 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: TRACK AWARD TO GO TO DALEY OF TIMES
description: Arthur Daley, sports columnist of The New York Times, will receive a special award for significant contributions to track and field at the fourth Olympic Invitation meet Feb. 18 at Madison Square Garden. Daley has covered the Olympic Games since 1932 and is coauthor with John Kiernan of the book, The Story of the Olympic Games.

title: The Nation Crackdown On Drugs
description: In my view of very terrible crimes, declared President Nixon last Friday, the most despicable crime is that of the drug pusher and drug trafficker, where the life of an individual is destroyed. The occasion for the statement, was the signing of an Executive Order setting in motion a new drugabuse program that the President said will drive heroin pushers off the nation's streets.

title: BREDICE WINNER IN WEIGHT THROW
description: Frank Bredice of Southern Connecticut State College won the Millrose Games 35pound weight throw with a meetrecord toss of 65 feet 1 inches yesterday in freezing temperatures at New York University's Ohio Field in the Bronx.

title: South Sea Reef Proclaimed A Republic by 3 Americans
description: SUVA, Fiji, Jan. 29 (AP)Three Americans proclaimed a utopian republic on a wreckstrewn South Sea reef recently after sailing 450 miles south of Fiji.

title: Carla L. Schafer Wed
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29 Miss Carla Louise Schafer, a graduate of Butler University, and Ballard Bruce Hogg Jr., who expects to receive a degree from Butler in June, were married here this afternoon in the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Dr. William I. Lockwood, an Episcopal priest and greatuncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Schafer Jr. of Kingston and Mr. and Mrs. Hogg of Morristown are the parents of the couple.

title: Froehling and Addison Join World Title Tennis Tour
description: DALLAS, Jan. 29 CAP)World Championship Tennis announced yesterday that Frank Froehling and Terry Addison have joined the organization's circuit.

title: ARMED TRIBESMEN TROUBLE BENGALIS
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 29Armed Mizo tribesmen from the hill areas of India have become an unsettled security problem for East Pakistan's new Bengali regime.

title: BEACH CAPTURES CARTER BOWLING
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)A Pennsylvania barberturnedbowler, Bill Beach, surpassed the semifinal leader in the $60,000 Don Carter bowling classic today and won the nationallytelevised event with a 225202 victory.

title: A Mailing Mixap Costs The I.R.S. $2.5 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)A not so funny comedy of errors, Senator Frank E. Moss said yesterday of what he called a $2.5million mixup that resulted in mailing this year's tax forms first class, instead of third class.

title: WESTBURY TRACK AVERTS A BOYCOTT
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 29A threatened boycott of tonight's harness racing card at Roosevelt Raceway by members of the Standardbred Owners Association was averted this afternoon when William (Buddy) Gilmour and Maurice Pusey, whose horses had failed to pass urine and saliva tests on Thursday night, were permitted to race.

title: Youths'
description: Much of yesterday's delicate discussions between an airplane hijacker and ground negotiators at Kennedy International Airport was broadcast to the metropolitan area by WCBS radio while it was going on.

title: Germans Find Ancient Ship
description: KREFELD, West Germany, Jan. 29 (UPI)Dredging crews have uncovered the wreckage of a 40foot wooden ship that archeologists said was built in the 13th or 14th century. It is in 35 feet of mud in the harbor of this Rhine city.

title: RISE IN ACID FOUND IN RAINFALL STUDY
description: Rainfall in the northeastern United States has become surprisingly acid, according to study just completed by three scientists. So far, however, the trend has not been noticed in New York City's water supply.

title: A.B.A. AllStars Rated Equal to N.B.A.'s
description: LOUISVILLE, Jan. 29A year ago, Joe Mullaney was the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers in that other pro basketball league, with problems such as getting Jerry West, Elgin Baylor and Wilt Chamberlain all healthy. It was not a time for observing the American Basketball Association.

title: Early Bird Tax Tips
description: It's not an especially happy thought, but chances are you have just received your W2 forms in the mail  those official little documents telling you how much money your employer paid you last year and how much tax was withheld.

title: Canucks Triumph, 52
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 29 (UPI)Orland Kurtenbach scored once and set up three other goals tonight in leading the Vancouver Canucks to a 52 victory over the Maple Leafs, extending Toronto's string to seven games without victory.

title: COAST STAKE ENDS WITH A DEAD HEAT
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29Autobiography and Triple Bend raced to a dead heat today in the 20th running of the $89,350 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita as five horses reached the wire in a blanket finish.

title: Gardens
description: In case the backyard putterer thinks everything is idling by, waiting for spring, he might like to know that there is some real action going on behind the scenes.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Once upon a time David E. Lilienthal was the passionate radical of the New Deal, bane of Wall Street, T.V.A. chairman who battled the bankers and power companies to bring water and power to the poor of the Tennessee Valley. Later he was first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. Today he is a millionaire, a partner of bankers, chairman of three giant corporations, an adviser to presidents and kings.

title: Matzdorf to Get Award
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 29 (AP) Pat Matzdorf, University of Wisconsin high jumper, will travel to Paris on Feb. 6 to receive a European sports magazine's award as the world's outstanding athlete in 1971. Matzdorf holds the world record in the high jump of 7 feet 6.

title: Vival! Vivat Eileen Atkins, Actress
description: IN Vivat! Vivat Regina! two whole scenes play out before Eileen Atkins comes on stage. And much of the life of the play comes with her.

title: Nancy Krumm Plans Wedding
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Jan. 29 The engagement of Miss Nancy Ann Krumm to Joseph Eberhardt Sichler 3d, on of Mr. and Mrs. Sichler Jr. of Smoke Rise, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Krumm of Far Hills.

title: AntiTrust:
description: Four corporations produce nine of every 10 boxes of readytoeat cereal sold in the United States. For the past two decades, their ?? have held steady at nears 20 per centtwice the average rate for manufacturing as a whole. They have turned back or bought up virtually every entrepreneur who invaded their domain. But last week the big four cerealmakers faced a different kind of threat, which may one day bring an end to their hegemony over the American breakfast table.

title: Snowmobile Race: 3 Drivers Lose Fingers
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 29The 626mile WinnipegtoSt. Paul snowmobile race, which ended yesterday with Yvon Duhamel the winner, was a battle against snow, ice, wind, subzero temperatures and poor visibility, all of of which took a heavy toll.

title: At a School in Taiwan, U.S. Officials Study Chinese With the Help of Reading Materials From Peking
description: TAICHUNG, Taiwan, Jan. 14 On the outskirts of this provincial city, there is a school that uses the official Peking newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao in teaching its advanced students. It takes care, however, that no copies are taken out of the building, for Chinese Communist newspapers are not permitted to he circulated in Nationalist China.

title: Arabs Criticizing Moscow For the Mideast Stalemate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Jan. 29Arab feelings seem to be gradually turning against the Soviet Union.

title: Florida Gains in Banking
description: MIAMIFlorida has finally come out of its financial underdevelopment, a prominent banker said here recently, and bank holding companies are principally respon sible for it.

title: Miss Colten To Be Bride
description: WABAN, Mass., Jan. 29Miss Barbara Lee Colten plans to be married in March in New York to Christopher W. Brody, grandson of the late Albert D. Lasker, a leader in the advertising field, who with Mrs. Lasker of New York, set up the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation for philanthropies in various fields.

title: Game of the Foxes
description: In war, hot or cold, spying is a continuous industry. Certainly those who become involved in it think it important, and the layman, listening afterwards to their elaborate stories, may sometimes wonder whether it really makes much difference. Those tales of trivial adventure and misadventure, of seduction of typists and salvage of waste paper, become tedious in multiplicity and seem remote from great issues. Nor are spies themselves, in real life, as romantic as novelists would have them. Seldom reliable, sometimes venal, they are more often social misfits seeking compensation for their inadequacy than idealists prepared for martyrdom in

title: Ah Progress, No More Ajman Stamps
description: AJMAN, Union of Arab Emirates (AP)One result of the creation of a new nation in the Persian Gulf will be the eventual phasing out of one of the world's smallest and most unusual post offices.

title: Frei Joins Broncos'
description: DENVER, Jan. 29 (AP)Jerry Frei, head football coach at the University of Oregon for the past five years, has been named offensive line coach for the Denver Broncos, the National Football League club announced today.

title: JapanU.S.S.R.:
description: MOSCOWLike a diplomatic corollary to Newton's axiom about action and reaction, the Soviet Union's current courtship of Japan seemed an inevitable response to President Nixon's sudden flirtation with Communist China.

title: CLIENTS OF DARE HOLD L.I. SESSION
description: Glenn W. Turner, whose Dare to Be Great success motivation course has been banned in New Jersey, met with his New Jersey clients on Long Island last week and promised he would have a new moneymaking proposition for them soon.

title: PARENTS FOLLOW CHILDRENT GIFTS
description: In sending you our check, we are following the example set by our 8and 11year old children, who have already sent in their contributions, wrote Mrs. Lloyd Frank of 25 Central Park West in a note accompanying her $25 contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Royals Top Cavaliers, 120118
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (UPI)Ken Durrett dropped in a pair of foul shots with four seconds left today to give the Cincinnat Royals at 120118 National Basketball Association victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Where to Play CacheCache* in France; *Hide and Seek
description: FOR many years I have played cachecache  that is, hide and seekin France, collecting what I call hideaway hotels. It is true, of course, that hotels of this kind, charming and often reasonable in price, sometimes become too well knownor deteriorate when they change hands or when the chef movesbut there are always other hideaways to take their place. One simply has to find them, and consequently collecting good auberges away from the cities and auto routes becomes a continuing project. Nevertheless, for me at least, the project is beguiling one, and I am going to share my findings with you.

title: DIGGINGS IN HONAN YIELD TREASURES
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 29China has added to her collection of archeological treasures with a series of important new finds in the central province of Honan.

title: Ryan, Azcue and 7 Others Sign Angel Pacts for 1972
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)  Nolan Ryan, acquired from the New York Mets as part of a trade for Jim Fregosi, and Joe Azcue, who sat out the 1971 season, are among nine California Angels who have signed 1972 contracts, the team's general manager, Harry Dalton, announced today.

title: Mrs. McCarthy Married

The parents of the couple are Mrs. Harry Wells of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, and the late Mr. Wells and Mr. and Mrs. Herbert K. Beshar of New Rochelle, N.Y. The bride's previous marriage was terminated by divorce.

title: Mrs. Meir Asserts Israel Is Ready to Resume Talks

Jarring, the United Nations special envoy.

title: Court Writ Averts Strike on L.I.R.R. As Deadline Nears
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced last night that had obtained a temporary restraining order in Federal court in Brooklyn blocking threatened strike by conductors and trainmen that had been set for 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Arizona Democrats Picking Delegates
description: PHOENIX, Ariz, Jan. 29 what amounted to the nation's first primary election, Arizona Democrats voted today for delegates to the state convention two weeks from now. That meeting will choose the state's 25 delegates to the Democratic National Convention next August.

description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 29 (AP)David L. Bowen, director of communications for The Associated Press, has been named the 1972 winner of the ByLine Award of the Marquette University College of Journalism. The award, announced Thursday, is presented to Marquette journalism alumni who have distinguished themselves in communications fields.

title: 3 IN SCHOOL BUS RIOT SENT BACK TO JAIL
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., Jan. 29 Three men returned to jail here yesterday to complete sentences originally imposed after they were convicted of rioting at Lamar, S.C., where school buses were overturned almost two years ago.

Such cards, or credentials, are obtained by playing successfully and passing an examination during an annual players school conducted by the Tournament Players Division of the P.G.A.

title: SATO SAYS U.S. TIE IS JAPAN'S BEST
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29  Premier Eisaku Sato declared in his annual policy speech today that friendly relations with the United States were still more important to Japan than those with any other country, despite the increased influence of other world powers.

title: Gunboat DipIomacy

Now, the territory seized then, British Honduras, is the last British colonial foothold on mainland America. Even that foothold is temporary, since the colony is; soon to be granted independence, but in the meantime the British Navy stands ready to protect it.

description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP)  The Lake Carriers Association has said that shipments of major bulk commodities on the Great Lakes in 1971 totaled 189,718,140 net tons, the lowest total since 1963 and nearly 20 million tons lower than the record volume of 1970.

Theokratis Gemistos, Greek emigre with a compulsion to return to his native land. Kurt Helmuth, who was in Greece during the Nazi invasion, and can't understand why Gemistos doesn't like him. title: SEOUL SAYS IT SEIZED 23 FROM 7 SPY RINGS

Mr. Belaunde arrived from the United States, where he is a lecturer on multinational planning at the University of Cincinnati.

description: From Lenin through Stalin, Khrushchev and now Brezhnev, Soviet leaders have dreamed of the time they would seize world leadership in steel production. Last week it became known that this 50yearold ambition has finally been fulfilled. In 1971 the Soviet Union passed the United States in steel production for the first time and became the world's No. 1 steel maker.

Post College and the son of Gabriel M. DeStio of Greenvale and the late Mrs. DeStio. The senior Mr. DeStio is with the sales department of Heinrich Fischer & Co. of Cincinnati.

Terms of his new contract were not disclosed.

We planned to drive around the coast of the island, beginning and ending at Palermo, a distance of slightly more than 400 miles.

description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)Services ordaining and consecrating the Rev. Morris Fairchild Arnold as Suffragan Bishop of Massachusetts were held today in historical Trinity Church.

description: I hope there will be no piore surprises, Harold W. McGraw Jr., president of the book division of McGrawHill, Inc., wearily told an executive editorial meeting last Thursday morning.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: FOR the third week in a row, the stock market churned about and achieved little net change as it consolidated the strong gains that were run up in the eight weeks following Thanksgiving. The market, however, did endure an erratic period in recent sessions, first sinking in a continuance of the preceding week's late decline and then rebounding quite sharply the last two days, in response to a mixed but mostly favorable bag of economic, business and political developments.
