description: SAO JAULO, Brazil, Jan. 29 (UPI)The United States won the sixth intercontinental basketball tournament tonight when Brazil upset the Soviet Union, 6564, in the second game of the closing doubleheader.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: To compare Flaubert and Joyce is hardly a novel idea; it's been going on since 1922, when Ezra Pound called attention to the resemblance in a review of Ulysses. Hugh Kenner and Harry Levin are among those who did it more recently. Mr. Cross's book is essentially a modest attempt to document points made by these critics, jtuctapos[ing] in a given chapter elements of a single book by each artist For examppie, expressionistic techniques for dramatically objectifying dreams and fantasies are studied through comparisons of the Circe episode in Ulysses and in Flaubert's La Tentation de Sainte Antoine. The early chapters contain rather vague discussions of moral issues and of authorial sympathy and judgment; Mr. Cross is more successful in the second half of his book where he illustrates the writers use of new techniques for a sustained and intensive probing of mental life. For the most part, however, he is merely providing further documentation of points already made by numerous others. In his final chapter he raises issues which would have made for a stimulating workFlaubert's and Joyce's attitudes toward language and culture. In a time when culture at every level is providing us with potentially seductive substitutes for personal perception, these deserve extended inquiry.

title: Shelly Hill Gile Plans June Bridal
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. Clement Dexter Gile of Rye and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelly Hill Gile, to Charles Frank Pfeifer, son of Charles Pfeifer of New York and the late Mrs. Charlene Church Pfeifer.

description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29The Soviet Union has announced that offshore oil production has increased with the start of operations in a new field in the Caspian Sea.

title: Art
description: COMPARED to woodcuts, etchings and lithographs, the silkscreen print is a relative newcomer in the field of graphics. The large and lively exhibition, Silkscreen: History of a Medium, currently on view at the Philadelphia Museum, organized by curator Richard S. Field, traces the medium back at least to its commercial beginnings in the early 20th century in the United States. (Mr. Field believes it may have an earlier history in textile manufacturing but has been unable to document it at this point.) In the twenties, the techniquewhich consisted of using handcut stencils to lay down flat areas of colorwas used in the production of commercial posters and advertising displays. In the thirties, W.P.A. artists employed the method for making posters while other artists adopted it for fineart

description: The hijacker of a Los AngelestoNew York Trans World Airlines jet yesterday was described as an accused bank robher and jewel thief, and James Bond character.

title: MALTA NEGOTIATIONS ADJOURN ABRUPTLY

Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta said he had decided to return home to consult members of his Government and the trade unions on what he termed unforeseen developments in the negotiations.

Mike McLaren of Yale and Jerry Hudson of M.I.T. shared scoring honors with 15 points apiece as Yale von its third straight game, lifting its wonlost record to 59 M.I.T. is 76.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 (AP)  To look like Ple in soccercrazy Brazil is turning out to be a bounty for Horacio Joao, a taxi driver. The similarity with the King of soccer has given him many joys, he says.

This black pianist out of Texas, who was the father of ragtime and died in New York in 1917, has been the subject of much recent talk, and there is even a Collected Edition of his music on the way.

title: Stamps

March 1 will mark the inaugural of an 8stamp Na.. tional Parks Centennial series with issuance at Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, and at Washington, of an 8cent socalled jumbosize stamp depicting Old Faithful geyser at the park. The second firstday, this one in New York, will be on March 18 when the longdelayed 8c Family Planning stamp will be issued.

title: Homecoming in Bangladesh Some Hindus say: If you have been bitten by a snake you are scared of a rope
description: THAT opening of the story The Longest Night, by the East Bengali writer Abou Ahmed, sums up the feelings of the people of Bangladesh. There is not one family in the country which has not lost some relative, or had its home burned or looted or its womenfolk insulted, said Abdus Salam, editor of The Bangladesh [formerly Pakistan] Morning News. They will pay a heavy price for it, he added bitterly.

title: City Crime Wave Spreading to Suburbs

description: Windward Passage and Blackfin, big recordsetting oceanracing ketches, will wind up their torrid rivalry today in a rubbermatch race series off Long Beach, Calif.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Not many days ago Japanese Olympic officials recoiled in horror as rain pattered down and unseasonable thaw settled over Sapporo, where the Olympic Winter Games wilt open on Thursdayweather permitting, of course. By this time, though, all Olympians should be reconciled to an unavoidable fact. There is no escape from the refrigerated whammy that has bedeviled this appendage to the Olympic movement Perhaps Zeus and the other ancient Greek gods atop Mount Olympus are showing disapproval. Maybe it's the old story of the weather gods engaging in their quadrennial prank, bit of funmaldng they have not been able to resist in half a century. As soon as a winter Olympics approaches they press the crazy button.

title: Television
description: MEDICAL shows are big again this year on the tubeMedical Center, Marcus Welby, M.D., General Hospital, Dr. Simon Locke, frequent reruns of previous ailmentoriented hits along with the daily assortment of sicknesses seen on soap operas. Sports shows, too, are riding high, with pro football and its superbowls, AllStar Golf, Game of the Week, Wide World of Sports.

title: THOSE TOPSYTURVY XRAYS
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Miss Caroline Bryan to Be Wed
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 29 Mrs. Geraldyn Livingston Redmond of Glen Cove and Anthony John Adrian Bryan of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Bryan, to Russell Walker McCandless Jr. of Woollahra, Australia, son of Mrs. John Tribuno and Russell Walker McCandless of Bronxville, N. Y. A wedding next month is planned.

title: Donald Gabays Have Son
description: A son was born on Jan. 5 at the Mount Sinai Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Gabay of New York. The child has been named Daniel Jonathan. Mrs. Gabay is the former Miss Vicky Geula.

title: Forgotten Man
description: Ninety years ago today Franklin Delano Roosevelt was born on his family's estate overlooking the Hudson Hyde Park, N. Y. Though dead for more than a quartercentury, Franklin Roosevelt still lives for millions of Americansand indeed for men and women everywhere as an unparalleled leader of the free world, one of the three or four authentically great political figures of our era.

title: Kangaroos Ordered Shot
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan, 29 (AP)  The Australian Government has ordered the shooting of 5,000 kangaroos in a protected area of New South Wales State, and wildlife preservation groups are protesting. The National Parks and Wildlife Service said ranchers complained that the kangaroos were damaging pastures.

title: Basques Battle Police
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Jan. 29 (AP)Policemen and five Basque guerrillas exchanged gunfire here last. night hut the guerrillas escaped, the police said. No injuries were rernrted.

title: Cornell Wins, 8470
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29 (AP)Paced by Carmel Stewart. Cornell gained the lead early and held it to defeat Buffalo, 8470. Stewart scored 19 points. The losers had 28 turnovers.

title: 230 Women Confer in Auckland on the Human Family
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 29  Concerned women from the suburbs of New York and Tokyo, from South Sea Island villages and from many other diverse communities have just concluded an intensive discussion here of their not so diverse family problems.

title: the traveler's world
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, West Indies The Grenadine Islands are not for land creatures. They lie scattered haphazardly in a 60mile arc from Grenada to St. Vincent in the Windward Islands, separating the Caribbean Sea from the Atlantic. Many of them you cannot reach except by boat, so we compromised with the current rage for chartering yachts and took passage on a 143foot, threemasted wooden schooner, enjoying some of the discomforts of yachting and most of the comfortable luxuries of a cruise ship.

title: Cultural Exchange:
description: Thick black smoke, flame and panic filled the 20thstory offices of Sol Hurok Enterprises at 56th Street and the Avenue of the Americas early Wednesday when a firebomb exploded, killing one person and injuring 13 others, including 83yearold Mr. Hurok himself. The death of a 27yearold receptionist raised the stakes in the ongoing campaign against the Soviet Union for its treatment of Jews.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: East German Holiday Inns?
description: HANOVER, West Germany, Jan. 29 (Reuters)The Holiday Inn hotels, the world's biggest chain, is negotiating to build three firstclass hotels in East Germany. The company's European directors, Hans Gloor, said approval was being sought to build the hotels in East Berlin, Leipzig and Dresden.

title: Geraldine Jane Vernon Is Fiancee of Student
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 29  Miss Geraldine Jane Vernon and Theophilus McGuire Killion, a sophomore at Tufts University, plan to be married next year.

title: Trouble Elsewhere Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  A high official in the Federal Office of Education said he doubted that any irregularities had occurred elsewhere in the program.

title: STUDY URGES AID FOR JEWISH POOR
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 A major human relations agency presented today a bleak picture of Jewish poor, numbering between 400,000 and 800,000 and concentrated in the nation's inner cities.

title: GEORGE F. GOLDSMITH
description: George F. Goldsmith, founder of Reader Mail, Inc., a service dealing with dress and needlework feature articles, died Friday at his home, 875 Fifth Avenue. He was 75 years old.

title: North Stars Beat Rangers On Two Late Goals, 4 to 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 29The Minnesota North Stars are one expansion team in the National Hockey League that does not roll over and play dead when the New York Rangers appear. Tonight in the Metropolitan Sports Center. before 15,522 fans, the third largest crowd of the local season, the Stars handed New York a decisive 42 defeat.

title: Wings Strategy Gains Tie
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP) Marcel Dionne, a rookie, scored on a screened slap shot with, 1:10 to play tonight, after his team removed its goalie for an extra skater, to give the Detroit Red Wings a 44 tie with the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Home Improvement
description: ANEW line of wall paneling with patterns and textures designed to resemble cork, brick and stone has been added to Masonite's selection of factoryfinished hardboard paneling. Designed especially for accent walls, the authentic looking 4x8foot panels can be easily installed with nails or panel adhesive. The brick panels come in two colors  Plantation Red and Plantation White  both designed to resemble stacked brick, and both ideal for fireplace walls or behind bars and other accent areas. The bricks have realistic looking white spots, minor chips and burn marks, and the mortar is in contrasting grayish brown or gray to give an antique appearance.

title: February
description: You could look at the light at evening dusk and know February is at hand. And whatever happens now, even should February act like January in any normal year, March lies just ahead. The vernal equinox occurs just seven weeks from tomorrow.

title: An envy of antiquarians
description: This weathered saltbox, built by whaling captain Jonathan Baker 1705, nestles into its dune setting as if it had been there for centuries. Actually its present owners, Mr. and Mrs. James Tyson, moved it from East Hampton's Main Street to this ocean site 27 years ago. Then they invested 10 years in restoring it. The fruits of their labor are the envy of antiquarians. There is wood paneling in the original oxblood stain, fireplaces of ancient, coralcolored brick, handhewn beams and antique furnishings, some of which belonged to Captain Baker's wife, Rebecca, who lies buried in the picturesque town cemetery.

title: YouCanLookItUp Man Is Here
description: Joe Torre and Roberto Clemente will take the chief bows tonight when New York's baseball writers bestow their annual prizes at their 49th dinner and follies.

title: KAPLAN CONDUCTS CAMERATA GROUP
description: For several years, now, Abraham Kaplan has been known as a choral man about town, appearing most frequently as director of the Collegiate Chorale, which is an amateur group, and his own Camerata Singers, who are professionals.

title: BROWN IS VICTOR IN HAYES MILE
description: Mike Brown of La Salle Academy and Matt Centrowitz of Power Memorial each won their third individual gold medals of the indoor season yesterday, but scholastic fans will have to wait until Feb. 26 for a showdown race between them.

title: WASHINGTON
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29On the scale of popular interests in Florida these days, Presidential politics rats fairly lowwell behind the weather, health tips, sports, prices, skyjackings or Disney World.

title: A Mining Town Purty as a Gal's Calico Skirt
description: CALICO, CalifVisible for miles, the word CALICO is spelled out boldly in 20foot whitewashed letters near the crest of the softly folded, tawny golden hills whose patchwork volcanic pattern gave the old mining town its nostalgic name.

title: Canadian Doctors Termed Indecisive On Drag Problem
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29The Government's advisers on drugs have accused the Canadian medical profession of having been indecisive and poorly prepared to advise drug addicts.

title: Soviet Lead in Steel Is Confirmed
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29A Soviet economic analyst confirmed today that the Soviet steel industry surged into first place among the world's steel producers last year, realizing an old dream of Moscow's economic planners.

title: What Has Stephane Audran Got? Glamour
description: EARLY in Claude Chabrol's Le Boucher (The Butcher), now at the 68th Street Playhouse, there is an incredibly beautiful moment that might seem superfluous in a movie by a different director, and certainly in a movie with different actors. Popaul (Jean Yanne), a butcher who has just returned to his village in the south of France after 10 years in the Army, walks home from a wedding reception with Mlle. Hlne (StOphane Audran), the local schoolmistress whom he has just met. It is early autumn and the dwindling afternoon sunlight is as golden as the shadows they cast are black. Both Popaul and Mlle. Helene are a little high on champagne. As they pass through the narrow streets they are in the process of discovering each other with the kind of small, marvelous surprises that are the preliminaries of love.

title: A Snow Avalanche Kills 2 Youths at Nevada Resort
description: RENO, Nev., Jan. 29  Two Reno teenagers died this after noon when they were buried in a snow avalanche at a ski resort about 15 miles south of the city.

title: Madrid Seeks Bidders For a Third of 2 Cows
description: MADRID, Jan. 29 (Reuters) The Madrid provincial government has announced in a communiqu in its official gazette that it will make a fourth attempt to auction off some redundant state property  onethird of two cows.

title: Travel Notes: Immunization Cards No Longer Needed for European Trips
description: THAT familiar yellow immunization card that used to be almost as necessary as a passport for getting from country to country is gradually losing its importance. Last summer the United States Public Health Service announced it was easing the requirement that returning United States citizens must have a smallpox vaccination no more than three years old. Without discarding the rule altogether, the service made it clear that unless the traveler was returning from one of seven or eight countries where smallpox cases are still found, no one at United States ports of entry would bother to check the card.

title: Miss Dunne Engaged To Robert J. Moore
description: BABYLON, L. I., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. James J. Dunne have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Ann Dunne, to Robert Johnston Moore. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Moore of East Greenbush, N.Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I hope that Police Commissioner Murphy does not read Larry Kardish's article of Jan. 2, It's Nice to Live Near Stadium. If he does I am sure that he will reduce the number of police officers in the area.

title: Colts, for a Draft Choice, Acquire Raiders Dickey
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Baltimore Colts last night announced that they have acquired a wide receiver, Eldridge Dickey, from the Oakland Raiders for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: PARTY TIGHTENING ORDERED BY TITO
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29A new Communist party executive bureau, less powerful but more administratively competent than the old one, has emerged from this week's national party conference.

title: What Lola Wants Is Victory at Daytona
description: What Lola wants Ferrari gets, which is another way of saying it's time for some FerrariAlfaLola competition. Right on the heels of last week's opening of the stockcar season comes the start of the 1972 road racing schedule, the occasion being the Daytona Continental next Sunday on the 3.81mile road course of Daytona International Speedway in Florida. This six hour endurance race is one of the 11 events conducted on three continents for the World Championship for Makes. The Continental also is the first of three manufacturers races run in this country, the others being Sebring in March and Watkins Glen in July.

title: LEVY TAKES LEAD IN SPEED SKATING
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 29 (AP) Barth Levy of Colorado Springs, Colo., took the lead today in the senior men's division as one meet record was set and one tied in the first day of the twoday National outdoor speeding skating championships at Lake Como.

title: The Way of It Is Fine And The Why of It? Well...
Deborah Love Matthiessen, Author and Teacher, 44
description: Mrs. Deborah Love Matthiessen, an author and teacher, and the wife of Peter Matthiessen, the writer and naturalist, died of cancer Thursday in Memorial Hospital. She was 44 years old and lived in Sagaponack, L. I.

title: Coast Guard to Attempt To Curb Cargo Thefts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)Pilot programs in maritime cargo security will be set up by the Coast Guard at the ports of Baltimore, New Orleans, San FranciscoOakland and Seattle in March.

title: Study in Absenteeism: One Senate Committee's Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Senate Foreign Relations Committee held an organizational meeting this week, but only of the 15 members showed up and most of them did not stay for long.

title: Miss Fredericka Galuppo to Be Bride
description: POUGHICEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 29Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Galuppo have made known the engagement of their daughter Miss Fredericka Ann Galuppo, to Charles Kingsley Mabon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley Mabon of New York and Norfolk, Conn.

title: Emily Coogan Is Bride Here
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Miss Emily Marie Coogan, daughter of Mrs. W. Gordon Coogan of Madison, N. J., and the late Mr. Coogan, was married to Frederick Fatzler, a widower of Maplewood, N. J. and Palm Beach, Fla. The J., Charles Genet performed the ceremony.

title: Medicine/Science
description: Cradle's empty, baby's gone. It happens at least 10,000 times a year in the United States: A happy, apparently healthy, gurgling infant  usually 2 to 3 months oldis diapered, burped and bedded. In the morning, it lies dead, often curled up in a corner of the crib, its little body seemingly exhausted by some huge labor. And nobody knows why.

title: May Return to Zurich
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 29The district attorney's office of the Zurich Canton announced today that a woman who identified herself as Edith Sommer Irving telephoned yesterday from New York to say that she had opened an account at a Swiss bank while posing as Helga Hughes and that she was prepared to come to Zurich in the course of the next week.

title: Q. and A.: Seaver Gives His Opinions
description: It's time for Tom Seaver's annual State of the Union message and here it is, in interview form direct from the Seaver home in Greenwich, Conn., where he has been getting into shape for the approaching baseball season:

title: Americana Brings Top Prices At ParkeBernet Gallery Sale
description: A pair of sugar nips, or tongs, engraved with the crest of George Washington were among the most glamorous and soughtfor items to be auctioned last week, in a series of sales devoted to Americana at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: Manchester City 5to2 Victor in English Soccer
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Manchester City climbed to the top of the English Soccer League First Division for the first time this season today when they registered a 52 triumph over the Wolverhampton Wanderers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Major Industries Are Not Likely to Curb the Unemployment Rate in U.S.
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29Some of the nation's largest industries, even those especially favored by the Nixon Administration's new economic policies, will do little to bring down the nation's unemployment rate this year.

title: Chiefs and Eagles Clash In Roller Derby Tonight
description: The Chiefs meet the Eagles tonight at Madison Square Garden in an International Roller Derby League game beginning at 7:30. The Eagles, a new team, made their debut last week and have split four games.

title: CONIES ENTRY 1,2 AT LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29An entry from Florida sped to a 1, 2 finish today in the $34,175 Militia Handicap at Liberty Bell Race Track where a crowd of 20,995 wagered $2,517,357.

title: Hawks Down Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (UPI)Goals by Stan Mikita and Pit Martin less than two minutes apart in the second period sparked the Chicago Black Hawks to a 42 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

title: Dr. Louis Wolff, Professor And Noted Heart Specialist
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)Dr. Louis Wolff of Brookline, who in 1930, with Dr. Paul Dudley White and Sir John Parkinson, described a heart condition now known as the WolffParkinsonWhite syndrome, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital here.

title: The Guest Word
description: When a man writes a book, he should be willing to take the bad reviews, but it seems excessive that Gay Talese should be attacked three times in The New York Times for Honor Thy Father once in the daily paper, once in the Sunday Book Review, and again last week in the Review, this time by Joe Flaherty, who, insisting that earlier critics have misunderstood the book and been too kind to it, repeats the exact charges of both the daily and the Sunday reviewers.

title: Bills Hire Billy Atkins
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29Lou Saban, head coach of the Buffalo Bills, said today that Billy Atkins would join the National Football League club as defensive backfield coach. Atkins, a safety and punter, ended his playing career with the Denver Broncos in 1964.

title: Luce Foundation Grants 2 More Professorships
description: The Henry Luce Foundation announced yesterday the establishment of two new Henry R. Luce professorships.

title: R. W. Lee 3d Weds Christine Feng
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29 Miss Christine Feng, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chihsiang Feng of Taipei, Taiwan, was married here today to Rensselaer Wright Lee 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rensselaer Wright Lee. The Rev: Joseph Harrison performed the ceremony at noon in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Italian Official Asks A Fund to Prevent Decay of Treasures
description: ROME, Jan. 29  One of Italy's top officials has publicly urged Parliament and the Government to earmark extraordinary funds to save the country's scenic beauty and art treasures from ruin.

title: Reader's Report
description: Elizabeth Jane Howard, known also as Mrs. Kingsley Amis, has here contrived a shallow meringue of a novel. Edmund and Anne Cornhill are a sybaritic, middleaged couple living in a dovecote near London, where Edmund is a realestate agent. Edmund loves Anne and Anne loves Edmund at least, until 22yearold Arabella, an authentic kissing cousin, comes to live with them between unwed pregnancies. Arabella is a breed of incandescent waif found only in novels and movies. With her suitcase full of Pucci shirts and her thirst for loveas is now the fashionshe takes both her hosts by storm. When away from Anne, she sweeps Edmund off his feet. (She was girl, nymph, goddess, bare footed, beflowered.) When Edmund is absent, Arabella makes out with Anne. (I do love youwith all

title: Washington's Black Society: New Leaders
description: WASHINGTONIt has often been said that if the Government were removed from Washington, all that would be left here would be a big hole in the ground.

title: Men's Wear Looks to Knits
description: It's hard to find a manufacturer of men's tailored clothing these days who isn't saying something about knits. For this segment of the men's apparel industry its traditional bulwarkhas just wound up two of its leanest years and is count ing on the excitement generated by knitwear to make 1972 much more successful.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: What a lovely life Jean Geiger's family has had in Millington, N. J. (If This Is Progress in the Suburbs, No Thank You, Jan. 9.] It fairly drips with the nostalgia of rural Americana. The blacksmith shop. Christmas caroling rear the shapely old pine, the kindly truant officer and, of course, the good old swimming hole all to themselves.

title: Pakistan Cuts Prague Ties
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Pakistan broke diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia and Cyprus today because of their recognition of an independent Bangladesh in what was East Pakistan.

title: Observer Observed
description: I didn't set out in life to be a humorist, said Russell Baker. I set out to be a novelist, and I look like a novelist Art Buchwald looks like a humorist. Art Buchwald looks like Art Buchwald. I don't look like him and most of the time I don't even look like myself.

title: CHARGERS TRADE FOR DEACON JONES
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Los Angeles Rams announced tonight they had traded their premier defensive end, David (beacon) Jones, and two other players to the San Diego Chargers for a linebacker, Jeff Staggs, and three draft Choices.

title: Dance
description: BERNARD SHAW once commented that the trouble with critics was that they were so rarely criticized. But then Mr. Shaw never lived in New York, where the criticism of critics is a ritual as timehonored as the muggings in Central Park. However, in the dance world one area of the art rarely criticized is company's overall direction.

title: Letters:
description: To THIS EDITORS

title: Yvonne Strachwitz Engaged To John Atterbury McQuilkin
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Jan. 29 Mayor and Mrs. William Dowdell Denson have announced the engagement of Mrs. Denson's daughter, Miss Yvonne Maria Strachwitz, to John Atterbury McQuilkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Winters McQuilkin of Rochester. Miss Strachwitz is also the daughter of Count Hyazinth Strachwitz of Hamburg, Germany.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Isadora Duncan (18781927) may not quite fit the encomium Mr. Seroff bestows in his opening sentencethe greatest performing artist the United States ever producedbut she certainly was an extraordinary woman. Her terpsichorean innovations had lasting effect on the classic ballet and the dance of the 20th century. Her appearances were toasted on two continents, exciting a host of illustrious admirers who also became friendsincluding Stanislaysky, Ellen Terry, Eleanora Duse, D'Annunzio, as well as a number of painters and sculptors. She sponsored schools in Berlin, Paris and Moscow and adopted a half dozen daughters who continued her artistic tradition. She had uncounted liaisons and at least three illegitimate children; and stirred up many a storm in her progress from her native San Franend in Nice.

title: Welfare
description: Wasteful... demeaning.. outmoded  these are the words President Nixon used to describe the nation's welfare system in his State of the Union address 10 days ago and again last week in his Budget Message. This message contained the news that funds would be made available to effect administrative changes that must precede general welfare reform.

title: Iowa State Triumphs, 7572
description: AMES, Iowa, Jan. 29 (AP)Iowa State posted a 7572 Big Eight Conference victory today over Oklahoma State. The Cowboys losing streak was extended to 10 games.

title: Carol J. Abeles, Farrell Glasser Are Betrothed
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 29The engagement of Miss Carol Jane Abeles to Farrell Craig Glasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Glasser of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Claus K. Abeles of White Plains. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Music
description: FINALLY it comesthe first American staged performance of Hector Berlioz's Les Troyens in its entirety (previous productions, such as the one by the San Francisco Opera, were abridged). The Opera Company of Boston will present Part of the monumental operaLa Prise de Troleon Thursday, and the next night will complete the work with Les Troyens a Carthage. Then, on Sunday, both parts will be given: Part I in the afternoon, Part II in the evening.

title: William Drorbaugh Weds Jane Clausen
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 29Miss Jane Carolyn Clausen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Clausen, was married here this afternoon to William Colt Drorbaugh of Rye, president of Drorbaugh Publications of New York. He is the son of Wells Drorbaugh, who before his retirement founded and was publisher of Bride's Magazine, and Mrs. Drorbaugh of Little Campton, R.I.

title: Trial of Russo Ordered
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP) A Federal judge has ruled that Anthony J. Russo was in error in arguing that he had immunity from prosecution in the Pentagon papers case and that he must stand trial with his former Rand Corporation colleague, Dr. Daniel Ellsherg. Federal District Judge Matthew Bryne Jr. ruled yesterday that since Mr. Russo had never testified at grand jury hearings on the case, he had not met the requirement granting him immunity from prosecution. He scheduled the trial for May 9. colleague, Dr. Daniel Ellsherg. Federal District Judge Matthew Bryne Jr. ruled yesterday that since Mr. Russo had never testified at grand jury hearings on the case, he had not met the requirement granting him immunity from prosecution. He scheduled the trial for May 9.

title: Zaire Casts Off Vestiges of Congo
description: KINSHASA. Zaire  The accent here is on change.

title: Iraq's Deportees: Pawns in a Power Game
description: NASRABAD, Iran, Jan. 9 We were like fish in a frying pan always ready to burn, Ozra an Iranian baker said explaining the recent mass expulsion of Iranians from Iraq.

title: Taxes Bite Deeper
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30  Phase One of President Nixon's economic stabilization program has passed and Phase Two is struggling at the inflation barricades. But neither has included any restraints on state or local taxes, and these burdens are rising at record rates in almost every part of the nation.

title: Leftists Rob Argentine Bank, Announce Loot Is.$450,000
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 (AP)Fourteen leftist guerrillas held a dozen persons hostage for eight hours today while they bored a hole into the vault of the stateowned National Development Bank. While there was no official estimate of the amount stolen.

title: Avalanche Survivor Says Ski Slope Appeared Safe
description: RENO, Nev., Jan. 30 (UPI)A survivor of a ski slope avalanche that killed two teenage companions said today that the young skiers who triggered the snowslide thought the slope was safe.

title: CHIEFS LOSE, 2927, IN ROLLER CONTEST
description: The Chiefs lost to the Eagles, 2927, last night in an International Roller Derby League game at Madison Square Garden before 10,348 fans. An apparent score by the Chiefs was nullified as time ran out.

title: Runout on Reform
description: The defection of Senator Ribicoff of Connecticut from the fight for fundamental welfare reform represents crushing blow to a program that offers the only real hope for erasing the degrading line between relief recipients and the working poor.

title: PHILHARMONIC GIVES ITS FINAL SPECIAL
description: The season's second and final special New York Philharmonic concert with Andre Kostelanetz on the podium was given at Philharmonic Hall on Saturday night.

title: Yorty, in New Hampshire, Warns on Tax Promises
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 30 (AP)Mayor Sam Yorty of Los Angeles spoke before the FrancoAmerican Lafayette Club in New Hampshire's largest city today and got a standing ovation.

title: JAMES M'K. ROSE, LAWYER, 81, DIES
description: James McKinley Rose, a lawyer who was active in church, civic and philanthropic affairs, died Friday in an automobile accident near Baltimore. He was 81 years old and lived at 215 East 72d Street.

title: A Laser Yardstick For Space and Time Hailed by Scientists
description: Scientists of the National Bureau of Standards have developed a potential yardstick for the measurement of both distance and time.

title: Phone Threat in Capital Closes Soviet Art Show
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)A Soviet art exhibition being held one block from the White House was closed this afternoon when a telephone caller threatened to cause trouble.

title: GrassRoots Politics in a Phoenix District: Women, Youths and Chicanos Get Involved
description: PHOENIX, Ariz. Jan. 30Mary Joyce Norton is a painter and a housewife, a sober and respectable mother of four. Yesterday afternoon she walked into the Plumbers and Steamfitters Hall here looking rather disheveled and out of breath.

title: Port Body. Names Aviation Chief
description: Neal R. Montanus has been named director of aviation for the Port of New York Authority, succeeding John R. Wiley, who is retiring tomorrow after 17 years in the $59,000ayear post.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator William Proxmire's recent letter (Jan. 25) incorrectly quotes me as saying that trying to get unemployment down to 4 per cent could be a mistake. What I did say was that trying to get unemployment down to per cent through expansive monetary and fiscal policies alone could be mistake in today's context. (See Business Week, Dec. 25, 1971.)

title: Cameroon Pushes Back Frontier
description: YAOUNDE, CameroonAlong the new 235mile extension of the Trancameroonian Railway from here to 1361abo, the arrival of trains is like a replay of the Iron Horse days of the American West.

title: Mauritania Mines the Sahara
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania This West African country looks to exploitation of its mineral resources to maintain a favorable trade balance in 1972.

title: N. Marshall Seeburg Dies; CoinPhonograph Pioneer
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP)N. Marshall Seeburg, a pioneer in the coinoperated phonograph and the vendingmachine industry, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: Gains in Gambia
description: BATHURST, GambiaAfter years of relying on subsidies from her former colonial master, Britain, tiny Gambia is steadily moving toward selfsufficiency.

title: Hanoi Said to Mass Force For Offensive in February
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 American intelligence sources reported today that political officers attached to North Vietnamese and Vietcong units were telling their troops that decisive blows must be dealt against United States and South Vietnamese forces while President Nixon visits China in February.

title: Breaking Up City Hall: I
description: WASHINGTONThe Italian revolutionary Giuseppe Mazzini warned us not to imagine that you can free, yourselves from unjust social conditions before winning a country of your own. Do not be seduced by the idea of improving your material conditions without first solving the national questions.

title: Bengalis Seal Dacca's Bihari Areas
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 30Bengali soldiers and policemen cordoned off the two main non Bengali neighborhoods in Dacca today and began a search for weapons. A 24hour curfew was also imposed on the neighborhoods.

title: Interest Rates'
description: The credit markets have been moving toward higher interest rates and lower bond prices for the last two weeks and these trends most likely will continue in the days ahead, Wall Street analysts and traders agreed late last week.

title: Red Smith
description: Bill Wishnick was fairly well inshore in the Bahamas when the boat pitched violently, flung Jack Wishnick headlong and stove in his ribs. In the wet and lumpy world of ocean powerboat racing, fractures are part of the game but Jack was in pain and his brother hated to subject him to additional hours of pounding. As gently as circumstances permitted, they slid Jack overboard, confident that his life jacket would support him and pretty sure he wouldn't attract sharks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While the Defense Department prosecutes a war and churchfolk stand accused of conspiring to threaten the security of the country, leaders of men offer the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1973 as the largest peacetime deficit in the history of the United States, because, in part, more funds are needed in order to increase armament and wine a generation of peace.

title: Employes Kept Informed
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 (AP)The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation said today, that employes who want to check on efforts to save the Pittsburgh Works and its 5,500 jobs may dial a special telephone number for a report taped daily by the works manager, John A. Glasgow. A temporary shutdown began Sept. 18. Some 2,000 of the laidoff workers were called back this month.

title: Jonathan Kertzer Weds Claudia Helms
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 30Miss Claudia F. Helms, a senior at. the Rhode Island School of Design, was married at Temple Beth El here this afternoon to Jonathan M. Kertzer, a senior at Brown University.

title: Senegal Looks Beyond Peanuts
description: DAKAR, SenegalThe peanut is still king in the meager economy of this West African country. But its crown is slipping, as the Government tries urgently to diversify, and the story behind the move is typical of modern Africa.

title: Ivory Coast Plans Public Investment
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory CoastDetermined to maintain the spectacular growth that has made it West Africa's most prosperous country, the Ivory Coast is beginning a $900million development plan designed to achieve a true transformation of living standards.

title: Bayard Rustin Arrested With a Cane Sword
description: Bayard Bustin, the civil rights leader, was arrested on 42d Street just west of Times Square last night for possession of a cane sword, normally a misdemeanor. He was being held early this morning at the West 35th Street Station.

title: Ethiopia Endures Setback
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaBy 1974, according to official planning here, construction will start on Ethiopia's first earthsatellite station.

title: Torture Charges Dropping Steadily in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30The charges of physical torture of political prisoners in Brazil, numerous from late 1969 through 1970 and well into 1971 have declined steadily in number in the last three or four months.

title: Political Ferment Hurts Guinea
description: PARIS  Guinea's economy has suffered sharply from the political ferment that disrupted the Government of President Sekou Tourd in the last year.

title: Earnings of FMC Corp. in 1971 Declined While Sales Increased
description: Operating earnings of the FMC Corporation last year were $49.3million or $1.45 share before extraordinary charges, the diversified manuffacturer reported over the weekend.

title: Gains in Angola, Mozambique
description: LISBONPortugal's African territories are still restive politically, but they are beginning to feel the benefits of Lisbon's attempts to counter the continuing guerrilla threat with economic and social reforms.

title: New Juvenile Delinquency Role Assumed by Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Justice Department has quietly taken on a new role in the Administration's efforts to combat juvenile delinquency.

title: Cambodia Is Weighing Secret Talks With Hanoi
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Monday. Jan. 31 (Agence FrancePresse)Official communications out of Pnompenh were cut today, while the Information Ministry confirmed that the Cambodian Government was considering the possibility of secret talks with North Vietnam.

title: The New Spirit To Guide Liberia
description: MONROVIA, LiberiaFollowing two events earlier this monththe inauguration of a new President and the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the nation's foundingLiberia is starting a new era with the hope and promise of greater economic progress.

title: Drivers Vote to End Strike Against Jersey Bus Line
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Jan. 30 (AP)Bus drivers at the Northern Boulevard Transportation Company voted 63 to 62 today to ratify a new twoyear wage pact and end their 98dayold strike, a union spokesman said.

title: Muskie Wins Arizona Vote As Lindsay Places Second
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine won 37.8 per cent of the delegates in yesterday's Arizona Democratic Presidential voting more than any other candidate final figures showed today.

title: Maisel Will Linger A Reserve Board; Successor Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The term of Sherman J. Maisel as a member of the, Federal Reserve Board expires tomorrow, but he will continue to serve until President Nixon names, and the Senate confirms, a successor.

title: THOMAS ARRESTED IN DRUG INCIDENT
description: GREENVILLE, Tex., Jan. 30 (UPI)Duane Thomas, the Dallas Cowboys controversial running back, was arrested early today and charged with possession of marijuana.

title: Gomez, Youngs, Harridge Elected to Hall of Fame
description: The Baseball Hall of Fame Committee on Veterans elected three men to its shrine in Cooperstown, N. Y., yesterday, including Vernon (Lefty) Gomez former pitching great for the New York Yankees.

title: Mark Karasick Weds Miss Ulevitch
description: Miss Linda Ulevitch and Mark Wakmann Karasick, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Joseph Karasick of New York, were married here last evening in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

title: Henry Street Gets Grant
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has awarded a $250,000 grant for the expansion of the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater over a threeyear period. Since 1970, the multiethnic community theater has been presenting works from minority groups.

title: WellFed Commission
description: The temporary state commission to study the administrative operation of New York City looms as not only one of the most potentially destructive forces on the political horizon but also as one of the most expensive. Born last year in a crucible of hate at the closing moments of a bitterly antiurban session of the State Legislature, the commission was given $250,000 and told to submit its report by March 31 of this year.

title: Black Hawks on Top
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP)Late goals by Darryl Maggs, Stan Mikita and Bobby Hull rallied the Chicago Black Hawks to a 42 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

title: DONEGAN DECIDES ON A NEW CAREER
description: The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan will begin a second pastoral career, at the age of 72, following his retirement in May after 21 years as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

title: Bhutto Removes Pakistan From the Commonwealth
description: RAWALPINDI Pakistan Jan 30  Pakistan withdrew from the Commonwealth today after having been advised that Britain Australia and New Zealand would recognize the Bengali Government in East Pakistan.

title: CLASS A SKI JUMP TAKEN BY BARBER
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 30Hugh Barber, the 21yearold Middlebury College junior from Brattleboro, Vt., is at his best on larger skijumping hills, but he mastered the smaller 50meter slope here today to win the Dwight D. Eisenhower Trophy.

title: Report Terms Black Muslims A Source of AntiSemitic Views
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30  The American Jewish Committee charged today that the Black Muslim movement had become a significant source of antiSemitic infection in the black community.

title: Nixon and Muskie Nearly Even At 43% and 42% in Gallup Poll
description: A Presidential election involving President Nixon, Senator Edmund S. Muskie and Gov. George C. Wallace, if conducted this month, would have been almost a dead heat between the President and the Senator, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: Here is a book whose basic premise is so compelling, whose points are so dramatically and entertainingly illustrated, and whose author's outrage is so infectious, that a reviewer wants very much to recommend it without reservation. Reading Design for the Real World, is difficult to dispute Victor Papanek's contention that the profession of industrial design in this country is irresponsibly practiced, superficially taught, insensitive to human needs, and as damning a reflection of what is wrong with Western industrial society as is the presence of aluminum beer cans in the biosphere. It is hard not to scrap one's TV set and dishwasher. It is tempting to sell all thou hast and follow Victor Papanek. Who could fail to be provoked by Mr. Papanek's contemptuous dismissal of all definitions of design from Horatio Greenough's to that of the German Bauhaus on the grounds that the concept that what works well will of necessity look well has been the lame excuse for all the sterile, operatingroomlike furniture and implements of the twenties and thirties"? Yet who could resist applauding his alternative, more complex definition of good design (a function complex that takes into account such considerations as method, use, need, association, and esthetics), if only because it damns by definition such absurd items as the throwaway paper dress priced at $149.50 and the ballpoint pen with fake polyethylene orchid surrounded by fake styrene carrot leaves sprouting out of its top?

title: Jobs Cut by Investing Abroad? U.S. Rebuts Union Contention
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A Commerce Department staff study rejected today the claim that investments abroad by United States multinational companies cost jobs at home.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that Bangladesh has surfaced, curiosity centers on its future role. Will it add to the balkanization of the subcontinentIndia, (West) Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim and, now, Bangladesh? Is there another solution debalkanization?

title: Tiny Togo Is Gaining Ground
description: LOME, Togo  Thanks to continued political stability, steady crop increases and liberal trade policies tiny Togo is gaining ground as one of the brighter spots economically in West Africa.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Ryun Runs 4th as Prefontaine Takes 2Mile Event in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 30 (AP)Steve Prefontaine lapped Jim Ryun last night and won the twomile run in 8 minutes 26.6 seconds, the fastest time of the indoor track season, at the Oregon indoor track and field meet.

title: National Ballet Will Open At City Center Tomorrow
description: The National Ballet of Washington will open an eightperformance engagement at the City Center tomorrow night with the local premiere of its fulllength production of The Sleeping Beauty.

title: GREEK PUBLISHES WORK FROM JAIL
description: ATHENS Jan. 29Dr. Dionysios Karageorgas will soon publish, under the auspices of the Ford Foundation a monograph entitled The Distribution of Fiscal Burden in Greece, a study of public finance.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Party Signs Alliance With Indian Reds
description: CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 30 (UPI)  The governing New Congress party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today signed its first alliance with a unit of the proMoscow Communist party. The agreement was reached with the party's West Bengal state chapter for the state's legislative assembly elections March 11.

title: Nixon Names Two Doctors To New Panel on Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  The White House announced today the names of two members of the new threemember Presidential panel on cancer.

title: Elections to Be Held May 2 In 14 Areas of the West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 30Arab citizens of the west bank of the Jordan will go to the polls May 2 for the first time since the Israeli occupation of 1967.

title: Bulls Conquer Pistons
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI)Chet Walker scored 29 points today to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 10999 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game.

title: DEEP SPLIT OPENS IN WORLD ZIONISM
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30  A deep and unexpected split has opened in the World Zionist Organization, separating some of the most influential American Jewish leaders from representatives of Israel's main political parties.

title: Dahomey, a Garden of Eden in Africa
description: COTONOU, Dahomey For a visitor to Dahomey, there is an unfailing reaction one of wonder that the small West African country's tourist potential is so little developed.

title: In Madagascar, the Pace Quickens
description: TANANARIVE, MadagascarThis land at the end of the earth is rapidly losing its ageold remoteness as a formerly stagnant economy responds to the stimulus of new foreign business activityFrench, South African, Japanese, West German and American.

title: Volta Relaxes Austerity Measures
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper VoltaEncouraged by successes in the first fouryearplan from 1967 to 1970, Gen. Sanoule Lamizana's military regime in the former French territory of Upper Volta is relaxing some austerity measures. They were introduced five years ago to alleviate chronic budgetary problems inherited from an ousted civilian Government.

title: Kings Tie Sabres, 22
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 30 (UPI)Bill Lesuk and Juha Widing scored thirdperiod goals tonight to give the Los Angeles Kings a 22 tie with the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Miss Sills Blends Her Many Talents For Bright Recital
description: When an artist is equally comfortable with a florid baroque aria and a tender chanson; when she can sustain the poignant serenity of Schubert's Ave Maria one moment and soar through the sportive roulades of Delibes's Les Files de Cadiz the next; when she has the persuasive charm to make rarely heard songs sound like old friends and the creative flexibility to bring new freshness to thricefamiliar material; when she has the magnetism to fill Philharmonic Hall and the graciousness to sing her first encore to the overflow listeners In stage seatschances are her time is Beverly Sills.

title: Snead Takes Senior Golf, Beating Bolt, Boros on 18th
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) Slammin Sam Snead shot a finalround 71 today for a total of 286 and won the Professional Golfers association seniors title. It was his fifth victory in the event.

title: Food Staples Up Sharply Here; Ground Beef Chuck Rises 20c
description: Prices of food staples have increased sharplyup 20 cents a pound for ground beef chuck and up $1.10 a pound for salmon steakin New York City's leading retail markets in the last three weeks, reports from the State Department of Agriculture showed yesterday.

title: Blues Recall 2 Defensemen
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30 (AP)The St. Louis Blues of the Na tional Hockey League recalled Dick Proceviat of the Kansas City Blues and Kurt Bennett of the Denver Spurs, both de fensernen, today.

title: South Africa Sees Economic Pickup
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  After a year of inflation, dropping reserves and labor shortage, South Africa's economic prospects appear brighter for 1972.

title: Woods Breaks 5Mile Mark In National Speed Skating
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 30 (AP)Mike Woods of West Allis, Wis., lapped the entire field and won the fivemile event in meetrecord time today in the national outdoor speed skating championships at Lake Como.

title: Ivory Coast Schools Turning to Television
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory CoastShortly before 9:30 A.M. the window shades are drawn in hundreds of firstgrade classrooms of this West African country. Then, in each classroom, a television set is turned on and for an eager audience of 40 pupils the first three halfhour ETV lesson begins.

title: TWO DANCERS BOW IN HARLEQUINADE
description: Two dancers who appeared for the first time in new roles with the New York City Ballet were both seen at a Saturday matinee at the State Theater in George Balanchine's own version of the PetipaDrigo ballet, Hariequinade. Gelsey Kirkland stepped in for Patricia McBride as Colombine and Elise Flagg took over the part of, Pierrette.

title: Shultz Links Inflation Rate To Possibility of Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) George Shultz, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that a Federal tax increase was not inevitable under present economic conditions but that one could become necessary if inflation accelerated again.

title: Point of View
description: NAIROBI, Kenya The modern story of the green revolution, which has swept through Asia and Mexico over the last six years, has galvanized the attention of the whole world. From being the second largest customer in the United States of America's foodaid program in 1967, Pakistan has now just about been transformed to selfsufficiency in cereal production. From being concerned largely with stepping up massive production of maize, Mexico is now turning her attention to the breeding of a more nutritious and highyielding variety of maize.

title: Mrs. Bachert Married
description: Mrs. Helen Weisman Bachert, widow of Alex F. Bachert, who was president of Smart and Thrifty, a retail women's clothing store chain, was married here yesterday to Leo M. Rogers, a widower. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment, where the couple will live. Mr. Rogers is chairman of the executive committee of the Rogers Engraving and Offset Company here and is a collector of impressionist art.

title: Advertising:
description: Wells, Rich, Greene is continuing to add blue chip names to its client list, the latest being Westinghouse.

title: BANKRUPTCIES RISE PUT AT 3.6% OVER '70
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 30 (AP) Bankruptcy petitions passed the 200,000 mark in 1971, up 3.6 per cent over 1970, with consumers accounting for 90 per cent of them, according to a survey by the Family Economics Bureau of the Northwestern Life Insurance Company.

title: Community Finds A Ray of Light
description: NAIROBI, KenyaMember nations of the East African Community hope that 1972 will bring an end to the dispute that has interrupted economic and social progress.

title: Thousands of Birds Killed
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla. Jan. 30 (AP)Thousands of dead birds, many of them robins, have been found in a Field here. Conservationists believe they were poisoned by chemical spraying., Alice Wainwright, president of he Tropical Audubon Society,, attributed the deaths to the aerial spraying of a potato field.

title: BARR FETED AT 70 BY MUSEUM'S FANS
description: It was Alfred H. Barr Jr. night at the Museum of Modern Art last eveningand though Pablo Picasso's name was also on the bill, the artist was for once upstaged.

title: Japan Debates Spirit of War Holdout
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30The discovery of a former Japanese soldier who hid on Guam for almost 28 years rather than surrender has stirred complex reactions here.

title: Africa's Dream: Strong but Distant
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaAfrica last year was like a man who has been knocked backward while climbing uphill with a heavy load. Almost all the world economic problems of 1971the recession in the industrialized countries, the consequent sag in African exports, inflation, the monetary crisisseem to have had an extra impact upon Africa.

title: Clapp Wins Ice Boating
description: BANTAM LAKES, Conn., Jan. 30David Clapp of Little Silver. N. J., won the A Division competition today in the International Skeeter Association ice boat regatta, held in winds of 5 to 12 miles an hour.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One thing this country desperately needs is protection against strikes that cripple transportation. Legislation to curb transportation disputes, which have an especially destructive potential, is at hand. The present Administration's Emergency Public Interest Protection Bill has been waiting for Congressional action. Labor's opposition is understandable, but the country has been plagued too often with transportation strikes which have disrupted the nation's economy and jeopardized the public welfare.

title: I.T.T. IS SEEKING A GERMAN GROUP
description: The Intenational Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire a privately owned group of German companies for 2 million shares of I.T.T. common stock. The cost would be nearly $128million at Friday's closing price of 63 for I.T.T. common on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 1971 ORDERS FELL IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: Machine tool orders in 1971 trailed the 1970 level by 6 per cent despite a gain of 17.8 per cent in December orders over the level of November, 1971, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.

title: LORENZO G. VOIGT
description: Lorenzo G. Voigt, an architectural and industrial design consultant, formerly with Walter Dorwin Teague Associates, industrial designers, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 155 East 38th Street.

title: State Rights Body Reports 5% Rise in Complaints in '71
description: Jack M. Sable, State Commissioner of Human Rights, reported yesterday that filings of discrimination complaints totaled 3,028 in 1971, an increase of 5 per cent over the 1970 total.

title: An Open Appeal Is Made Of Ginzburg's Conviction
description: Ralph Ginzburg, the magazine publisher who has been ordered to begin serving a threeyear prison sentence on Feb. 17, held a news conference yesterday to explain his open appeal of his 10yearold conviction for using the mails to disseminate obscene materials.

title: Kenya: The Drought Ends
description: NAIROBI, KenyaMarked economic improvement is the hope for Kenya this year after some setbacks in 1971, including a drought that lasted for many months.

title: SLAIN PATROLMEN WILL BE HONORED
description: Two rookie patrolmen, murdered in an apparently unprovoked attack on the Lower East Side on Thursday night, will be buried with full departmental honors tomorrow, with one of the services to be in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Bucks Top Bullets
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 30 (AP)Jon McGlocklin's two foul shots with one second to play iced the Milwaukee Buck's 116112 victory over the Baltimore Bullets today in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Suns Repulse Hawks, 105103
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP)All five Phoenix starters scored in double figures tonight as the Suns held off a fourthperiod rally by the Atlantic Hawks to post a 105103 victory.

title: Bilingualism Is Hidden Asset In Cameroon's Trade Growth
description: YAOUNDE, CameroonStudents seeking degrees at the Federal University of Cameroon, whether In law, letters, economics or science, must pass examinations showing that they can do their work equally well in French and English.

title: Municipal Jobholders Fearful Of Reverse Discrimination Here
description: Reverse discrimination. That is the fear of some city employes who are worried about the agencybyagency census being conducted to determine the race, sex ethnic origin and physical disabilities of the 400,000 municipal employes.

title: Blair Pole Vaults 173 As Penn Captures Meet
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30Tom Blair of Pennsylvania vaulted 17 feet 3 inches today, his best, as the Quakers defeated Yale and Brown in a triangular track meet. Penn had 88 points as the Elis tallied 41 and Brown 19.

title: President Visits Dinner Honoring a Black Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)President Nixon paid a surprise visit to a dinner honoring one of his top black assistants today and told the predominantly black audience that his Administration had not accomplished all that it wanted to in the area of civil rights.

title: Unit Pricing Called Something of a Dud
description: WASHINGTON  In the middle of a supermarket that bears hundreds of labels on its shelves indicating the unit price for hundreds of items, Miss Margaret Campopiano looked around in surprise and said:

title: AideSuggests Hughes Computer May Be a Source of Irving Book
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30A computer owned by the Hughes Tool Company and loaded with biographical information may have been a source for some material used in the controversial book The Autobiography of Howard Hughes, a spokesman for the company said today.

title: Rarigers Tied by Stars, 11 at Garden
description: A tired group of Rangers managed to blast 41 shotsand missed 40 of themas they were held to a 11 tie by the Minnesota North Stars yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: For Arab Countries:
description: CAIROHope soared in Egypt a year ago, after the ceasefire on the Suez Canal front, that 1971 would be the year for a settlement of the long and enervating conflict with Israel. Such a settlement would have freed money and resources to deal with increasingly urgent internal economic and social problemslow living standards, unemployment, illiteracy, disease. tumbledown housing and all the other blights of a backward economy geared to war instead of development.

title: CHARISMA VICTOR IN FLORIDA SAILING
description: VENICE, Fla., Jan. 30Chicagoarea yachts dominated all but one of the five classes in the 105mile St. PetersburgtoVenice sailboat race that ended yesterday as the Southern Ocean Racing Conference opened.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Tan. 30In the memory of the race, man has always struggled to overcome the limits imposed by nature. His success has been spectacular, especially in this last century of accelerating technology: Today he sees that he has the means to fight pestilence and disease, to unlock even the binding energy of the material world.

title: For Arab Countries:
description: ALGIERSAlgeria, now in her 10th year of Independence, has come a long way economically but still has far to go, and her ambitious $5.2billion development plan is now entering its most difficult phasewhen costs keep mounting but benefits are still to come.

title: Employers Asked to Train Prisoners
description: The city's new Commissioner of Correction, Benjamin J. Malcolm, said yesterday he hoped to get the city's major employers to go into prisons to help set up manpowertraining programs that would lead to jobs for former prisoners.

title: Recital Is Triumph By Margaret Price
description: The world is never short of sopranos with canary voices and brains to match, but there never are and never can be enough artists of the quality of Margaret Price.

title: Zambia: Farming the Copperbelt
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  Gains in agriculture are offsetting declines in copper earnings for this central African country.

title: Planes Lost in Alaska Fire
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  A fire causing estimated damage of $2million destroyed three planes at a hangar of Interior Airways yes terday. There were no injuries. The cause of the fire was not known.

title: Advertising:
description: Richard Durrell, assistant to the publisher of Life, has been named the magazine's director of advertising.

title: Austrians Are Shocked
description: SAPPORO, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP)The decision on Karl Schranz came as a shock to other Austrians today.

title: Youth Challenges African Tradition
description: AMONG the strongest of African traditions is deference to the wisdom of the eldersthe older generation. But in many African countries, younger people now are beginning to take a harder look at their elders: to question leaders policies, particularly in the allimportant matter of economic development.

title: EXTEACHERS OWE CITY $1.1MILLION
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that more than 3,100 former New York City school teachers still owed the city about $1.1million paid to them in error.

title: For Arab Countries:
description: TRIPOLI, LibyaEconomic activity in oilrich Libya began to flourish again in 1971 after a year of drift, decline and uncertainty under the country's austere, socialistminded military regime. And well it should, since Libya's already overflowing treasury was further enriched during the year by the submission of foreign oil companies to a posted price of $3.45 a barrel50 per cent above the posted price that prevailed before the army coup d'etat on Sept. 1, 1969.

title: U.S. Power Unit Scored. As Lax on Environment
description: The Federal Power Commission has been sharply criticized by the United States Court of Appeals here for having abdicated a significant part of its responsibility to protect the environment.

title: HARNEY,WITH 275, WINS BY STROKE
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30Paul Harney, a 42yearold who considers himself a stayathome club professional, won the Andy WilliamsSan Diego open today by one stroke.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A hearing is scheduled in Brooklyn Federal Court today on a temporary restraining order issued Saturday night that blocked a strike threatened for yesterday by conductors and trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Underground Cloud
description: The feebleness with which the Pay Board is defending its own battered antiinflation guideposts threatens to create fresh misery for New York City subway straphangers, already writhing under a 35cent fare for the privilege of being pushed around in their underground torture chamber.

title: Sudan Turns To Friends
description: CAIROThe economy of the Sudan, fragile even in the best of times because of its vulnerable agricultural character, was badly shaken last year by political turmoil in Communistoriented coup on July 19 and a swift countercoup three days later.

title: Botswana, Once Poor, Mines Wealth
description: GABORONE, BotswanaA struggling country relying almost entirely on cattle ranching in her thirsty scrubland and on supplying labor to South Africa mines since her independence from Britain in 1966, Botswana has begun a new industrymining.

title: Lead Peril Closing British Plant 2 Months
description: AVONMOUTH, England, Jan. 30The Imperial Smelting Corporation will close its $36.4million lead and zinc smelter here, the world's largest, for two months of costly overhaul and rebuilding beginning tomorrow because of mounting concern over lead poisoning of workers.

title: 90th Anniversary of Roosevelt's Birth Observed
description: Fond reminiscences of Franklin Delano Roosevelt but less than unanimous appraisals of his place in history were offered last night at a commemoation of the 90th anniversary of his birth.

title: Penn's Ivy League Drive Is Generated by Calhoun
description: When Corky Calhoun drives toward the basket, Penn is a better basketball team. Chuck Daly, the Quaker coach, says so and Villanova, La Salle and Princeton have found it out in the last 10 days.

title: New Ghana Chief Inherits a Crisis
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Nearly three weeks after the seizure of power here by a group of army officers, Ghana seems no nearer to solving the critical economic problems that provoked the military takeover.

title: Incorporations in State Reached 77,024 in 1971
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP)Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo reported today that more business concerns filed certificates of incorporation in his office last year than in any year except 1969.

title: Humphrey Says U.S. Needs Decentralized Government
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey told a Junior Chamber of Commerce convention today that there was a need to decentralize the Government.

title: Chess: Soviet Tournament Loaded With Heavyweight Players
description: The recent Alekhine Memorial Tournament, an 18man round robin in Moscow, ended in a twin victory for the Soviet grandmaster Anatoll Karpov and his compatriot, Leonid Stein, a former Soviet champion. Each had 11 points.

title: Boat Show Orders Hit $56.4Million, Missing a Record
description: Yawns and smiles emanated from the Coliseum starting at 7 P.M. yesterday as tired but happy dealers completed their ninth and final day of the 62d National Boat Show.

title: 3 Tanks Reported Destroyed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP)The South Vietnamese command announced today that its planes had destroyed three enemy tanks in the Central Highlands.

title: Mary Goldner Bride of Ross Meretsky
description: Miss Mary Louise Goldner was married here last evening to Ross B. Meretsky, a Detroit lawyer. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony in the Pierre.

title: Northwestern Life Gains
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, the world's largest individual life insurance writers, reported over the weekend a record $2.3billion in sales last year, an increase of 20.7 per cent over the $1.93billion sold in 1970. Francis E. Ferguson, president of the Milwaukeebased insurer, said the bulk of the increase was in personal insurance.

title: Uganda Setting Ailing Economy Aright
description: KAMPALA, Uganda This East African country, which has reversed a leftward political swing, appears now to be heading out of serious economic trouble.

title: GUNMAN STEALS $74,000 IN GEMS
description: A softspoken, welldressed gunman, who seemed to know what he was after, stole a diamond ring and earrings, worth more than $74,000, from the wife of a wealthy shopowner as she and her husband entered the lobby of their East Side apartment house at 3 A. M. yesterday.

title: Black Political Power in South Up in '71
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 30  Black political power in the South increased significantly during 1971, according to the Voter. Education Project, Inc.

title: Braves Conquer Cavs
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 30 (AP)Walt Hazzard's 15foot shot with five seconds left gave the Buffalo Braves a 9998 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: East German High Jumper Equals Women's Mark
description: BERLIN, Jan. 30 (UPI)Rita Schmidt of East Germany, equaled the world's unofficial best indoor high jump record for women today by leaping 6 feet 1 inches in an East Berlin meet.

title: Rhodesia: Politics Is Economics
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia The economic future of Rhodesia's 5.5 million people will be more profoundly affected by the first few weeks of the new year than by any comparable period in the breakaway British colony's 82yearold history.

title: BRITISH SOLDIERS KILL 13 AS RIOTING ERUPTS IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST Northern Ireland Jan. 30At least 13 persons were shot dead by British troops in Londonderry today when rioting broke out after civil rights march held in defiance of a Government ban.

title: Brent Wins State Net Title, Beating Barker,67,63,61
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 30Rod Brent, a 28yearold Australian who came here in November as a teaching pro, won the New York State men's indoor tennis championship today with a 6.7, 63, 61 victory over Bob Barker in the final at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Pentagon Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin said today that the Defense Department was planning to give contractors at least 6 per cent interest on the final settlement of disputed claims, surcharge he called a waste of taxpayers money.

title: Prince Buu Hoi, Physicist, Dies; Saigon Diplomat Served at U.N.
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Prince Buu Hoi, an internationally known physicist and cancer researcher who had acted as a diplomatic troubleshooter for his native Vietnam, died of cancer at his home here Friday. He was 55 years old.

title: Uranium Powers a Boom in Niger
description: NIAMEY, Niger  Uranium is transforming the Niger Republic from one of the poorest nations in former French West Africa into a boom state.

title: WILT SETS RECORD AS LAKERS SCORE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP)Wilt Chamberlain became the National Basketball Association's alltime leading rebounder tonight AS he'helped the Los Angeles Lakers trounce the. Portland Trail.Blazers, 153131.

title: Oil Fuels the Nigerian Economy
description: LAGOS, NigeriaThe oil industry in this West African land is burgeoning, and is becoming a key factor in Nigerian economic growth.

title: $557Million Is Refunded Under Repeal of Auto Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Jan: 30 (AP)  Automobile buyers and manufacturers have received about $557million in auto excise tax refunds from the Government since midDecember, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: Fraternity Opens Chapter
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 30 (UPI)  The Delta Tau Delta fraternity is active at the University of North Carolina after an absence of 37 years. Its Gamma Omega chapter was formally installed in ceremonies yesterday.

title: Tanzania: Left Progresses
description: DAR ES SALAAM, TanzaniaIn the struggle to forge an economy based on African socialism, Tanzania finds capitalistic ailments such as inflation and a slowing down of what is left of the private sector.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: When Sir Oswald Mosley was leading the British Union of Fascists he demonstrated his belief in all the attitudes and acts he now decries [OpEd Jan. 191: He was a racist, he was proNazi, he was against civil liberties, and he and his Blackshirts did believe in the use of force against the left, Jews, radicals, and liberals. If Stalin were alive I wouldn't be surprised to see him emerge on the OpEd page as a nonviolent defender of civil liberties and free enterprise.

title: Flyers Down Penguins, 40
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP) The Philadelphia Flyers broke a fourgame losing streak tonight by beating the Pittsburgh Penguins, 40.

title: McDonald's Sold on Its Think Tank Office
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., Jan. 30The computers of the McDonald's hamburger chain estimate that at the current sales rate of 5 million a day their 1,920 restaurants will peddle their nine billionth hamburger Tuesday. That's about 45 for every living American.

title: Adm. Paul F. Foster, 83, Dead; U.S. Envoy to Atomic Sessions
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Jan. 30 (AP)Retired Vice Adm. Paul Frederick Foster, a Medal of Honor winner and one of the Navy's mostdecorated men, died today. He was 83 years old.

title: New Newfoundland Government Is Challenging Javelin's Project
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 30 With the judicial confirmation of the new Newfoundland government headed by Frank Moores, a showdown has come over former Premier Joseph Smallwood's extensive use of public funds for the support of the Javelin Paper Corporation's big linerboard project a Stephenville and associated woodland, operations at Goose Bay.

title: Wounded Jetliner Hijacker to Be Arraigned Today
description: Garrett Brock Trapnell, the hijacker of a Los Angeles toNew York jet who was shot and captured at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday, is scheduled to be arraigned today on an airpiracy charge before a United States magistrate in Brooklyn.

title: A Beer Bet and the Canal
description: CAIROIn a flush of optimism last summer over the chances for an accord to reopen the Suez Canal, blocked and idle since the ArabIsraeli war in June, 1967, an East European diplomat in Cairo wagered a case of PIIsener beer against a case of Spanish brandy from a West European colleague that work to clear the wreckage and silt from the 107mile waterway would be under way before the dawn of Jan. 1, 1972.

title: Squires of N.Y.A.C. Wins 4Mile Run in 20:51.4
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club, a 21yearold student at Manhattan College, won the ninth annual Henry E. Isola Memorial run yesterday over a 4mile course in the Bronx.

title: Are There Any Issues?
description: In its abandonment of outmoded conservative doctrine, the Nixon Administration has moved much more swiftly and thoroughly than did the Eisenhower Administration. General Eisenhower, the first Republican President in twenty years, not only swept out his party's lingering isolationism but also accepted Social Security and other features of the rudimentary welfare state which his Democratic predecessors had begun.

title: Mali Needs Tranfusion of Aid
description: BAMAKO, MaliPresident Moussa Traore of Mali is making major efforts to move his huge but impoverished country away from the disastrous economy he inherited three years ago, but progress is slow.

title: Stockholm: Sounds of Conflict in the Opera
description: STOCKHOLMThere may be more sound than substance in all the talk here lately about the conflict that has roiled the Royal Opera House in the year since Goeran Gentele left for the Metropolitan Opera. Yet with the artists strongly supporting their new head, Bertil Bokstedt, and with the board of the Opera House threatening to quit, the talk has at least been full of piquant interest. Bokstedt, and with the board of the Opera House threatening to quit, the talk has at least been full of piquant interest.

title: JOSEPH PELLICANE
description: Joseph Pellicane, a life insurance underwriter with the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company for 52 years, died Saturday in Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 79 years old and lived at 192.10 B 64th Avenue, Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Massachusetts Reforms To Doom Youth Prisons
description: AMHERST, Mass., Jan 30Massachusetts is moving rapidly ahead with a program to abolish institutions for juvenile offenders and to replace them with communitybased work and educational programs.

title: Bergen County Enjoying Industrial and Retail Boom
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 30Barely two miles outside this city, the seat of Bergen County, westward on Interstate SO, the flatness of small boxy houses and one level stuccoed commercial structures yields with unexpected suddenness to the silhouettes of three tall modern hotels.
